original: Namo tassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa
analyzed: namaḥ tassa bhagavataḥ arahataḥ sammāsambuddhassa
translated: Homage to that Blessed One, perfected one, fully awakened Buddha.

original: Niruttidīpanīpāṭha
translated: The recitation of the Niruttidīpanī

original: Ganthārambha
analyzed: gantha ārambha
translated: The beginning of the text

original: Caturāsītisahassa, dhammakkhandhāpabhaṅkarā;
analyzed: dhammakkhandhāpabhaṅkarā
translated: The eighty-four thousand aggregates of the Dhamma, which dispel darkness,

original: Lokamhi yassa jotanti, nantavaṇṇapabhassarā.
analyzed: lokamhi yassa jotanti nanta vaṇṇa pabhassarā
translated: Which shine in the world, with their own colors and bright radiance.

original: Anantavaṇṇaṃ sambuddhaṃ, vande niruttipāraguṃ;
analyzed: ananta vaṇṇam sambuddham vande nirutti pāragum
translated: I praise the Buddha, of infinite color, who is skilled in exposition,

original: Saddhammañcassa saṅghañca, visuddhavaṇṇabhājanaṃ.
analyzed: saddhammam ca assa saṅgham ca visuddha vaṇṇa bhājanam
translated: And the true Dhamma and the Saṅgha, the vessel of pure color.

original: Moggallāno mahāñāṇī, niruttāraññakesarī;🔽Nadi byākaraṇaṃnādaṃ, sogatāraññabyāpanaṃ.
analyzed: nadi byākaraṇam nādam sogata ārañña byāpanam
translated: Mahāmoggallāna, of great knowledge, the lion of the supreme forest,🔽Roared the roar of exposition in the river, spreading it to the supreme forest.

original: Tassatthaṃ dīpayissāmi, nānārāsiṃvibhājayaṃ;
analyzed: tassa attham dīpayissāmi
translated: I will explain its meaning, dividing it into various heaps,

original: Ogāyha saddasatthāni, navaṅgaṃ satthusāsananti.
analyzed: ogāyha sadda satthāni navaṅgam satthu sāsananti
translated: Having entered into the texts of the Dhamma, the nine-factored teaching of the Teacher.

original: 1. Sandhikaṇḍa🔽Saññārāsi
analyzed: sandhi kaṇḍa  saññārā asi
translated: . The section on the joints🔽The heap of perceptions

original: Garusaññārāsi
analyzed: garu saññārā asi
translated: The heap of perceptions of the great

original: Vaṇṇo, saro, savaṇṇo, dīgho, rasso, byañjano, vaggo, niggahītaṃ.🔽1. Aādayo titālīsaṃ titālīsa (bahūsu) vaṇṇā ka. 2; rū. 2; nī. 1, 2.
analyzed: vaṇṇaḥ saraḥ savaṇṇaḥ dīghaḥ rassaḥ byañjanaḥ vaggaḥ niggahītam  a ādayaḥ titālīsam titālīsa bahūsu vaṇṇā ka rū nī
translated: Color, sound, all colors, long, short, distinctive, compact, restrained.🔽The thirty-two vowels, the thirty-two (in many), the colors.

original: Aādayo bindantā tecattālīsakkharā vaṇṇā nāma honti.
analyzed: a ādayaḥ vaṇṇāḥ nāma honti
translated: The vowels beginning with a, ending with o, the forty-three consonants, are called the colors.🔽.

original: A, ā, i, ī, u, ū, eta, e, ota, o. Ka, kha, ga, gha, ṅa, ca, cha, ja, jha, ña, ṭa,
analyzed: a ā i ī u ū e o ta o ka kha ga gha ṅa ca cha ja jha ña ṭa
translated: A, ā, i, ī, u, ū, e, ai, o, au, ka, kha, ga, gha, ṅa, ca, cha, ja, jha, ña, ṭa,

original: ṭha, ḍa, ḍha, ṇa, ta, tha, da, dha, na, pa, pha, ba, bha, ma, ya, ra, la,va sa, ha,
analyzed: ṭha ḍa ḍha ṇa ta tha da dha na pa pha ba bha ma ya ra la va sa ha
translated: ṭha, ḍa, ḍha, ṇa, ta, tha, da, dha, na, pa, pha, ba, bha, ma, ya, ra, la, va,

original: ḷa, aṃ. Atthaṃ vaṇṇenti pakāsentīti vaṇṇā, akkharāti ca vuccanti, nāmapaññattirūpattā
analyzed: attham vaṇṇenti pakāsenti iti vaṇṇāḥ akkharā ati ca vuccanti nāma paññatti rūpa ttā
translated: sa, ha, ḷa, aṃ. They are called “vowels” because they are praised and proclaimed, and they are called “syllables” because they are the basis for the formation of names.

original: nakkharanti khayavayaṃ na gacchantīti akkharā. “Nāmagottaṃ na jīratī”ti saṃ. ni. 1.76 hi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: nakkharanti khaya vayam na gacchanti iti akkharāḥ nāma gottam na jīrati iti sam ni hi vuttam
translated: They are called “syllables” because they do not decay, that is, they do not go to destruction. “The name and clan do not decay” is said in the Suttas.

original: 2. Dasādo sarā ka. 3; rū. 3; nī. 3.
analyzed: rā
translated: . The ten are the “head-marks.”

original: Tesu vaṇṇesu ādimhi dasa vaṇṇā sarā nāma honti. Sayameva laddhasarūpā hutvā rājanti virocantīti sarā.
analyzed: tesu vaṇṇesu ādimhi dasa vaṇṇā sarāḥ nāma honti sayam eva laddha sarūpāḥ hutvā rājanti virocanti iti sarāḥ
translated: Of these vowels, the first ten are called “head-marks.” They are called “head-marks” because they shine forth, that is, they shine forth by having taken on the appearance of a head for themselves.

original: 3. Dve dve savaṇṇā.
analyzed: dve dve savaṇṇā
translated: . The two-syllable ones are the “good-marks.”

original: Tesu saresu dve dvesarā savaṇṇā nāma honti.
analyzed: tesu saresu dve dvesarā savaṇṇāḥ nāma honti
translated: Of these head-marks, the two-syllable ones are called “good-marks.”

original: A, ā avaṇṇo, i, ī ivaṇṇo, u, ū uvaṇṇo, eta, e etavaṇṇo, ota, o otavaṇṇo. Samāno vaṇṇo suti etesanti savaṇṇā, sarūpāti ca vuccanti, samānaṃ rūpaṃ suti etesanti sarūpā.
analyzed: a ā avaṇṇaḥ i ī ivaṇṇaḥ u u vaṇṇaḥ eta e eta vaṇṇaḥ ota o ota vaṇṇaḥ samānaḥ vaṇṇaḥ suti etesanti savaṇṇā sarūpā ati ca vuccanti samānam rūpam suti etesanti sarūpā
translated: A, ā is the vowel a. I, ī is the vowel i. U, ū is the vowel u. E, e is the vowel e. O, o is the vowel o. They are called “having the same vowel” because they have the same vowel sound. They are called “having the same form” because they have the same form.

original: 4. Pubbo rasso ka. 4; rū. 4; nī. 4.22.
analyzed: pubbaḥ rassaḥ ka rū nī
translated: The first is short.

original: Dvīsu dvīsu savaṇṇesu yo yo pubbo hoti, so so rasso nāma hoti. Rassena kālena vattabbāti rassā, rassakālo nāma akkhidalānaṃ ummisananimmisanasamakālo.
analyzed: dvīsu dvīsu savaṇṇesu yaḥ yaḥ pubbaḥ hoti saḥ saḥ rassaḥ nāma hoti rassena kālena vattabbā ati rassāḥ rassa kālaḥ nāma akkhi dalānam ummisana nimmisana sama kālaḥ
translated: In the case of the two vowels, the first is called the short one. They are called “short” because they are to be pronounced in a short time. The short time is the time taken for the opening and closing of the eyelids.

original: Tattha eta, ota iti dve ekapadasaṃyoge pare kvaci labbhanti. Eṭṭhi, seṭṭho, oṭṭho, sotthi.
analyzed: tattha e taḥ o taḥ iti dve eka pada saṃyoge pare kvaci labbhanti eṭṭhi seṭṭho oṭṭho sotthi
translated: Herein, the two, namely, e and o, are found in some instances when they are combined with a single word. Eṭṭhi, seṭṭho, oṭṭho, sotthi.

original: Ekapadasaṃyogeti kiṃ? Padantarasaṃyoge pare rassā mā hontūti. Maṃ ce tvaṃ nikhaṇaṃ vane, jā. 2.22.5 putto tyāhaṃ mahārāja jā. 1.1.7.
analyzed: eka pada saṃyoga iti kim pad antara saṃyoge pare rassāḥ mā hontu iti mam ce tvam nikhaṇam vane
translated: In order to show that they are not short when combined with another word, he says, “In the case of the two vowels.” If you bury me in the forest, Jā. … I am your son, great king, Jā. …

original: Kvacīti kiṃ? Ekapadasaṃyogepi vaggantesu vā ya, ra, la, vesu vā paresu rassā mā hontūti. Enti, senti, eyya, bhāseyya, meṇḍo, soṇḍo.
analyzed: kvaci iti kim eka pada saṃyoge pi vak ga antesu vā ya ra la vesu vā paresu rassāḥ mā hontu iti enti senti bhāseyya meṇḍo soṇḍo
translated: In order to show that they are not short even when combined with a single word, he says, “In some instances.” They are not short in the case of the words ya, ra, la, va, when combined with another word. Enti, senti, eyya, bhāseyya, meṇḍo, soṇḍo.

original: 5. Paro dīgho ka. 5; rū. 5; nī. 5.
analyzed: paraḥ dīghaḥ ka rū nī
translated: 5. The long one is the last in each pair.

original: Dvīsu dvīsu savaṇṇesu yo yo paro hoti, so so dīgho nāma hoti. Dīghena kālena vattabbāti dīghā, dīghakālo nāma rassehi diguṇakālo.
analyzed: dvīsu dvīsu savaṇṇesu yaḥ yaḥ paraḥ hoti saḥ saḥ dīghaḥ nāma hoti dīghena kālena vattabbā ati dīghā dīgha kālaḥ nāma rassehi diguṇa kālaḥ
translated: The one that is last in each pair of colours is called the long one. It is called long because it is to be stated with a long time. Long time is time double the short one.

original: 6. Kādayo byañjanā ka. 6; rū. 8; nī. 6.
analyzed: ka ādayaḥ byañjanā ka rū nī
translated: . The consonants beginning with ka.

original: Tesu vaṇṇesu kādayo bindantā vaṇṇā byañjanā nāma honti. Atthaṃ byañjayantīti byañjanā. Te pana suddhā addhamattikā, rassayuttā diyaddhamattikā, dīghayuttā tiyaddhamattikā.
analyzed: tesu vaṇṇesu ka ādayaḥ bindantāḥ vaṇṇāḥ byañjanāḥ nāma honti attham byañjayanti iti byañjanā te pana suddhāḥ addhamattikā rassa yuttā diyaddhamattikā dīgha yuttā tiyaddhamattikā
translated: In those colours, the colours that begin with ka and so on are called consonants because they indicate the letters. They are consonants because they indicate the meaning. They are pure half-matra, joined with the short one one-and-a-half matras, and joined with the long one one-and-three-quarter matras.

original: 7. Pañcapañcakā vaggā ka. 7; rū 9; nī. 7.
analyzed: pañca pañcakāḥ vaggāḥ ka rū nī
translated: . The groups of five fives.

original: Tesu byañjanesu kādi-mantā pañcabyañjanapañcakā vaggā nāma honti.🔽Kādi pañcako kavaggo, cādi ca vaggo, ṭādi ṭavaggo, tādi tavaggo, pādi pavaggo. Sesā avaggāti siddhaṃ. Vaṇṇuddese ekaṭṭhānikānaṃ byañjanānaṃ vagge samūhe niyuttāti vaggā.
analyzed: tesu byañjanesu ka ādimantā pañca byañjana pañcakāḥ vaggāḥ nāma honti  kādi pañcakaḥ kavaggo ca ādi ca vaggo ṭādi ṭavaggo tādi tavaggo pādi pavaggo sesāḥ avaggā ati siddham vaṇṇa uddese eka ṭṭhānikānam byañjanānam vagge samūhe niyuttā ati vaggāḥ
translated: In those consonants, the five-consonant groups beginning with ka are called groups.🔽The group beginning with ka is the ka group, the group beginning with ca is the ca group, the group beginning with ṭa is the ṭa group, the group beginning with ta is the ta group, the group beginning with pa is the pa group. The rest are established as not groups. In the indication of colours, the consonants in one place are called groups because they are connected in a collection.

original: 8. Bindu niggahītaṃ ka. 8; rū. 10; nī. 8.
analyzed: bindu niggahītam ka rū nī
translated: . The dot is the stop.🔽.

original: Ante bindumatto vaṇṇo niggahītaṃ nāma. Niggayha gayhati uccāriyatīti niggahītaṃ.
analyzed: ante bindumattaḥ vaṇṇaḥ niggahītam nāma niggayha gayhati uccāriyati iti niggahītam
translated: The colour ending in a dot is called “suppressed”. It is suppressed because it is suppressed by being held back.

original: Garusaññārāsi niṭṭhito.
analyzed: niṭṭhitaḥ
translated: The mass of the notion of heaviness is finished.

original: Byañjanavuttirāsi
analyzed: byañjana vuttiḥ ā asi
translated: The mass of the order of the consonants

original: Ṭhānaṃ, karaṇaṃ, payatanaṃ rū. 2 (piṭṭhe); nī 6 (piṭṭhe); 23 (suttaṅke).
analyzed: ṭhānam karaṇam payatanam rū piṭṭhe nī piṭṭhe
translated: Place, doing, effort, r (also at the end); n (also at the end); (in a braid).

original: Cha ṭhānāni – kaṇṭhaṭṭhānaṃ, tāluṭṭhānaṃ, muddhaṭṭhānaṃ, dantaṭṭhānaṃ, oṭṭhaṭṭhānaṃ,
analyzed: cha ṭhānāni kaṇṭha ṭṭhānam tālu ṭṭhānam muddha ṭṭhānam danta ṭṭhānam oṭṭha ṭṭhānam
translated: There are six places: the place of the throat, the place of the palate, the place of the head, the place of the teeth, the place of the lips,

original: nāsikaṭṭhānaṃ. Tesu byattaṃ vadantena yattha “akkha”nti vuccati, taṃ kaṇṭhaṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: nāsika ṭṭhānam tesu byattam vadantena yattha akkhanti vuccati tam kaṇṭha ṭṭhānam
translated: the place of the nose. When one who is skilled in them speaks, where “akkha” is said, that is the place of the throat.

original: Yattha “iccha”nti, taṃ tāluṭṭhānaṃ. Yattha “raṭṭha”nti, taṃ muddhaṭṭhānaṃ. Yattha
analyzed: yattha icchanti tam tāluṭṭhānam yattha raṭṭhanti tam muddhaṭṭhānam yattha
translated: Where “iccha” is said, that is the place of the palate. Where “raṭṭha” is said, that is the place of the head. Where

original: “sattha”nti, taṃ dantaṭṭhānaṃ. Yattha “puppha”nti vuccati, taṃ oṭṭhaṭṭhānaṃ. Nāsapadeso nāsikaṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: tam danta ṭṭhānam yattha pupphanti vuccati tam oṭṭha ṭṭhānam nāsa padesaḥ nāsika ṭṭhānam
translated: “sattha” is said, that is the place of the teeth. Where “puppha” is said, that is the place of the lips. The nose area is the place of the nose.

original: Katthaci pana uraṭṭhānaṃ, siraṭṭhānaṃ, jivhāmūlaṭṭhānantipi āgataṃ. Tattha siraṭṭhānaṃ nāma muddhaṭṭhānameva. Jivhāmūlaṭṭhānaṃ pana sabbavaṇṇānaṃ sādhāraṇanti vadanti.
analyzed: katthaci pana uraṭṭhānam siraṭṭhānam jivhā mūlaṭṭhānam ti pi āgatam tattha siraṭṭhānam nāma muddha ṭṭhānam eva jivhā mūlaṭṭhānam pana sabba vaṇṇānam sādhāraṇam ti vadanti
translated: and in some places the place of the chest, the place of the head, and the place of the root of the tongue are given. Herein, the place of the head is the place of the palate only. But the place of the root of the tongue is common to all the vowels, they say.

original: Karaṇaṃ catubbidhaṃ – jivhāmūlaṃ, jivhopaggaṃ, jivhaggaṃ, sakaṭṭhānanti.
analyzed: karaṇam catubbidham jivhāmūlam jivhopaggam jivhaggam saka ṭṭhānam ti
translated: The instrument is of four kinds: the root of the tongue, the tip of the tongue, the top of the head, and the place of its own.

original: Payatanaṃ catubbidhaṃ – saṃvuṭaṃ, vivaṭaṃ, phuṭṭhaṃ, īsaṃphuṭṭhanti. Tattha karaṇānaṃ sakasakaṭṭhānehi saddhiṃ saṃvaraṇādiko visesākāro saṃvuṭādi nāma.🔽Tattha kaṇṭhapadesānaṃ aññamaññaṃ saṅghaṭṭanena uppannā avaṇṇa, kavagga, hakārā kaṇṭhajā🔽nāma. Tālumhi jivhāmajjhasaṅghaṭṭanena uppannā ivaṇṇa, cavagga, yakārā tālujā nāma.
analyzed: payatanam catubbidham saṃvuṭam vivaṭam phuṭṭham īsaṃphuṭṭhanti tattha karaṇānam saka saka ṭṭhānehi saddhim saṃvaraṇa ādikaḥ visesa ākāraḥ saṃvuṭa ādi nāma  tattha kaṇṭha padesānam aññamaññam saṅghaṭṭanena uppannāḥ avaṇṇa ka vagga hakārāḥ kaṇṭha jāḥ  nāma tālumhi jivhā majjha saṅghaṭṭanena uppannā tālujā nāma
translated: The organ is of four kinds: closed, open, touched, and half-touched. Herein, the particular mode consisting in the enclosure, etc., together with the place of its own of each instrument is called “closed,” etc.🔽Herein, the vowel a, the vowel ā, and the sound h are called “throat-born” because they arise owing to the impact of the different parts of the throat on one another.🔽The vowel i, the vowel ī, and the sound y are called “palate-born” because they arise owing to the impact of the root of the tongue on the palate.

original: Mukhabbhantaramuddhamhi jivhopaggasaṅghaṭṭanena uppannā ṭavagga, ra, ḷakārā muddhajā
analyzed: mukha abbhantara muddhamhi jivhā upagga saṅghaṭṭanena uppannāḥ ṭa vagga ra ḷakārāḥ muddha jā
translated: The vowel u, the vowel ū, and the sounds r, l are called “head-born”🔽because they arise owing to the impact of the tip of the tongue on the upper part of the mouth inside the lips.

original: nāma. Upari dantapantiyaṃ jivhaggasaṅghaṭṭanena uppannā tavagga, la, sakārā dantajā
analyzed: nāma upari dantapantiyam jivhagga saṅghaṭṭanena uppannā danta jā
translated: The guttural is of two kinds: that arisen by the impact of the tongue on the upper front part of the teeth is called “dental”;🔽that arisen by the impact of the two lips is called “labial.” The nasal is of two kinds: that arisen by the impact of the tongue on the palate is called “palatal”;🔽that arisen by the impact of the tongue on the root of the nose is called “cerebral.” The sibilant is of two kinds: that arisen by the impact of the tongue on the front part of the palate is called “palatal”;

original: nāma. Oṭṭhadvayasaṅghaṭṭanena uppannā uvaṇṇa, pavaggā oṭṭhajā nāma. Niggahītaṃ nāsikajaṃ🔽nāma. Pañcavaggantā pana nāsikaṭṭhānepi sakaṭṭhānepi jāyanti. Ekāro kaṇṭhatālujo.🔽Okāro kaṇṭhoṭṭhajo. Vakāro dantoṭṭhajo. Apica ivaṇṇuvaṇṇā kaṇṭhepi jāyantiyeva. Yadā
analyzed: nāma oṭṭha dvaya saṅghaṭṭanena uppannā oṭṭhajā nāma niggahītam nāsika jam  nāma pañca vagga antā pana nāsika ṭṭhāne pi saka ṭṭhāne pi jāyanti ekāro kaṇṭha tālu jo  okāraḥ kaṇṭha uṭṭhajaḥ vakāraḥ danta uṭṭhajaḥ api ca kaṇṭhe pi yadā
translated: that arisen by the impact of the tongue on the back part of the palate is called “cerebral.” The semivowel is of two kinds: that arisen by the impact of the tongue on the root of the palate is called “cerebral”;🔽that arisen by the impact of the tongue on the root of the nose is called “cerebral.” The vowel is of two kinds: that arisen by the impact of the tongue on the root of the nose is called “cerebral”;🔽that arisen by the impact of the tongue on the root of the palate is called “cerebral.” The vowel is of two kinds: that arisen by the impact of the tongue on the root of the nose is called “cerebral”;

original: hakāro vaggantehi vā ya, ra, la, vehi vā yutto hoti, tadā urajoti vadanti. Pañho,🔽tuṇhi, nhāto, vimhito, gayhate, vulhate, avhānaṃ.🔽Kaṇṭhaṃ saṃvaritvā uccārito akāro saṃvuṭo nāma. Sakasakaṭṭhāna, karaṇāni vivaritvā
analyzed: hakāraḥ vagga antehi vā ya ra la vehi vā yuttaḥ hoti tadā vadanti pañho  tuṇhi nhātaḥ vimhitaḥ gayhate vulhate  kaṇṭham saṃvaritvā uccāritaḥ akāraḥ saṃvuṭaḥ nāma saka saka ṭṭhāna karaṇāni vivaritvā
translated: that arisen by the impact of the tongue on the root of the palate is called “cerebral.” The vowel is of two kinds: that arisen by the impact of the tongue on the root of the nose is called “cerebral”;🔽that arisen by the impact of the tongue on the root of the palate is called “cerebral.” The vowel is of two kinds: that arisen by the impact of the tongue on the root of the nose is called “cerebral”;🔽that arisen by the impact of the tongue on the root of the palate is called “cerebral.” The vowel is of two kinds: that arisen by the impact of the tongue on the root of the nose is called “cerebral”;🔽that arisen by the impact of the tongue on the root of the palate is called “cerebral.” The vowel is of two kinds: that arisen by the impact of the tongue on the root of the nose is called “cerebral”;

original: uccāritā sesasarā ca sa, hakārā ca vivaṭā nāma. Tāniyeva gāḷhaṃ phusāpetvā uccāritā
analyzed: uccāritā sesasarā ca sa hakārā ca vivaṭā nāma tāniyā iva gāḍham uccāritā
translated: that arisen by the impact of the tongue on the root of the palate is called “cerebral.” The vowel is of two kinds: that arisen by the impact of the tongue on the root of the nose is called “cerebral”;🔽that arisen by the impact

original: pañcavaggā phuṭṭhā nāma. Thokaṃ phusāpetvā uccāritā ya, ra, la, vā īsaṃphuṭṭhā nāma.
analyzed: pañca vaggā phuṭṭhā nāma thokam uccāritā ya ra la vā īsaṃphuṭṭhā nāma
translated: The five groups are called “touched.” If he speaks after touching a little, then ya, ra, la, and va are called “half-touched.”

original: Tattha oṭṭhajesu tāva pavaggaṃ vadantānaṃ oṭṭhadvayassa gāḷhaṃ phusanaṃ icchitabbaṃ.
analyzed: tattha oṭṭha jesu tāva pavaggam vadantānam oṭṭha dvayassa gāḷham phusanam icchitabbam
translated: Herein, firstly, according to those who say that the vowels are “groups,” it is necessary to admit that the two vowels o and u touch each other closely.

original: Kasmā? Phuṭṭhapayatanikattā pavaggassa. Uvaṇṇaṃ vadantānaṃ pana oṭṭhadvayassa vivaraṇaṃ
analyzed: kasmā pavaggassa vaṇṇam vadantānam pana oṭṭha dvayassa vivaraṇam
translated: Why? Because a group is a place of contact. But according to those who say that the vowels are “openings,” it is necessary to admit that the two vowels o and u are open.

original: icchitabbaṃ. Kasmā? Vivaṭapayatanikattā uvaṇṇassa. Esa nayo sesesu sabbesūti.
analyzed: icchitabbam kasmā esa nayaḥ sesesu sabbesu iti
translated: Why? Because an opening is a place of separation. So too in the case of all the rest.

original: Cūḷaniruttiyaṃ pana sabbe rassasarā saṃvuṭā nāma, sabbedīghasarā vivaṭā nāmāti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: cūḷa niruttiyam pana sabbe rassasarā saṃvuṭā nāma sabbedīghasarā vivaṭā nāma ati vuttam
translated: But in the Minor Anthology it is said, “All short vowels are called ‘covered’ and all long vowels are called ‘open’” .

original: Tathā saddasāratthajāliniyaṃ, katthaci sakkaṭaganthe ca. Idaṃ yuttataraṃ. Aññaṭṭhānikabyañjanehi🔽yuttā sarā attano ṭhāna, karaṇāni jahantāpi payatanaṃ na jahanti. Tasmā nānāvaṇṇānaṃ
analyzed: tathā katthaci sakkaṭa ganthe ca idam yuttataram añña ṭṭhānika byañjanehi  yuttā sarā attano ṭhāna karaṇāni jahantā api payatanam na jahanti tasmā nānāvaṇṇānam
translated: And so too in the Saddasāra, the Atthabyakaraṇa, the Jālinī, and the Sakkata-attha-kathā . This is more reasonable.🔽For vowels that are combined with other syllables do not abandon the place, the function, and the appearance even though they abandon the position of prominence. Therefore, when they are combined with different appearances, the combination of the places should be understood to be different too.

original: saṃsagge payatanānaṃ saṃsaggabhedopi veditabboti. Tattha “suṇātu me”ti vadanto yadi
analyzed: saṃsagge payatanānam saṃsagga bhedaḥ api veditabbaḥ ti tattha suṇātu mā iti vadantaḥ yadi
translated: Herein, when one who says “Let me hear”

original: ṇā-kāraṃ jivhaggena dantaṭṭhāne katvā vadeyya, dantajo nā-kāro eva bhaveyya. Tu-kārañca
analyzed: ṇākāram jivhaggena dantaṭṭhāne katvā vadeyya danta jaḥ nākāraḥ eva bhaveyya tukāram ca
translated: If he were to pronounce the letter na by placing the tongue at the place of the teeth, it would be a dental na. If he were to pronounce the letter tu

original: jivhopaggena muddhaṭṭhāne katvā vadeyya, muddhajo ṭu-kāro eva bhaveyya. Evañca sati
analyzed: jivhā upaggena muddha ṭṭhāne katvā vadeyya muddha jaḥ ṭukāraḥ eva bhaveyya evam ca sati
translated: by placing the tongue at the place of the palate, it would be a palatal tu. If that were so,

original: akkharavipatti nāma siyā. Esa nayo sesesu muddhajadantajesu. Tasmā kammavācaṃ sāventehi
analyzed: akkhara vipatti nāma siyā esa nayo sesesu muddha ja danta jesu tasmā kamma vācam
translated: there would be a confusion of the letters. The same applies to the other palatals and dentals. Therefore, those who recite the text of the rules

original: nāma ṭhāna, karaṇa, payatanesu suṭṭhu kusalehi bhavitabbanti.
analyzed: nāma ṭhāna karaṇa payatanesu suṭṭhu kusalehi bhavitabbanti
translated: should be well-trained in the places, the ways of pronunciation, and the sounds of the letters.”

original: Sithilañca, dhanitañca, dīghaṃ, rassaṃ, garuṃ, lahuṃ;
analyzed: sithilam ca dhanitam ca dīgham rassam garum lahum
translated: Loose, tight, long, short, heavy, light,

original: Niggahītaṃ, vimuttañca, sambandhañca, vavatthitaṃ nī. 9, 10, 11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16-19, 20, 21 suttesu passitabbaṃ.🔽Mudunā vacīpayogena vattabbā vaggapaṭhama, tatiya, pañcamā sithilā nāma. Thaddhena
analyzed: niggahītam vimuttam ca sambandham ca vavatthitam  mudunā vacī payogena vattabbā vagga paṭhama tatiya pañcamā sithilā nāma thaddhena
translated: Checked, released, connected, and distinguished.

original: vacīpayogena vattabbā vaggadutiya, catutthā dhanitā nāma. Dīgha, rassā pubbe vuttā.
analyzed: vacīpayogena vattabbā vagga dutiya catutthā dhanitā nāma dīgha rassā pubbe vuttā
translated: The loose letters are the first, third, and fifth in the vaggas, which should be pronounced with a soft effort of speech. The tight letters are the second and fourth in the vaggas, which should be pronounced with a firm effort of speech. The long and short letters have already been explained.

original: Dīghā ceva saṃyogapubbā ca niggahītantā ca garukā nāma. Sesā lahukā nāma. Yathā saddasahito
analyzed: dīghā ca iva saṃyoga pubbā ca niggahī tantā ca garukā nāma sesā lahukā nāma yathā sadda sahitaḥ
translated: Long and also preceded by a ligature and checked are called heavy. The rest are called light.

original: vāto mukhachiddena bahi anikkhamma nāsasotābhimukho hoti, tathā mukhaṃ avivaṭaṃ katvā🔽vattabbaṃ byañjanaṃ niggahītaṃ nāma. Tena yuttāni sabbabyañjanāni niggahītantāni🔽nāma. Sesā vimuttā nāma. Padasandhivasena vattabbaṃ sambandhaṃ nāma. Padacchedaṃ
analyzed: vātaḥ mukha chiddena bahi a nikkhamma nāsa sota abhimukhaḥ hoti tathā mukham a vivaṭam katvā  vattabbam byañjanam niggahītam nāma tena yuttāni sabba byañjanāni niggahīta antāni  nāma sesāḥ vimuttāḥ nāma pada sandhi vasena vattabbam sambandham nāma pada chedam
translated: As the wind accompanied by sound, without going out through the mouth-cavity, is directed towards the nostrils, so the mouth should be opened not wide,🔽and the articulation should be checked. Those connected with that are called checked.🔽The rest are called released. The connection, which should be stated by way of the connection of words, is called connected. The definition, which should be stated by dividing the words,

original: katvā vattabbaṃ vavatthitaṃ nāma.
analyzed: katvā vattabbam vavatthitam nāma
translated: is called defined.

original: Byañjanavuttirāsi niṭṭhito.
analyzed: niṭṭhitaḥ
translated: The collection of the analysis of articulation is finished.

original: Lahusaññārāsi
analyzed: lahu saññārā asi
translated: The collection on the perception of light

original: Jho, lo, po, gho, go.🔽9. Yuvaṇṇā iyuvaṇṇā (bahūsu) jhalā nāmassante ka. 58; rū. 29; nī. 205.
analyzed: jhaḥ laḥ paḥ ghaḥ go  yuvaṇṇā iyuvaṇṇā bahūsu jha lāḥ nāmas sante ka rū nī
translated: Jho, lo, po, gho, go.🔽. The vowels i and u (in many) have the perception of jha at the end of a noun; rū. ; nī. .

original: Anitthiliṅgassa nāmassa ante ivaṇṇuvaṇṇā kamena jhalasaññā honti.
analyzed: an itthi liṅgassa nāmassa ante i v a ṇ u vaṇṇā kamena jha l a saññāḥ honti
translated: The vowels i and u at the end of a noun with a non-feminine gender have the perception of jha by rule.

original: 10. Pitthiyaṃ ka. 59; rū. 182; nī. 206.
analyzed: pitthiyam ka rū nī
translated: . Ka at the end of a noun with a feminine gender; rū. ; nī. .

original: Itthiliṅge nāmassante ivaṇṇuvaṇṇā pasaññā honti.
analyzed: itthi liṅge nāma assante i vaṇṇu vaṇṇāḥ pa saññāḥ honti
translated: The vowels i and u at the end of a noun with a feminine gender have the perception of jha.

analyzed: ghā ka rū nī
translated: . Gha ka at the end of a noun with a feminine gender; rū. ; nī. .

original: Gho
analyzed: ghaḥ
translated: Gho

original: , Ā iti dvipadaṃ. Itthiliṅge ākāro ghasañño hoti.
analyzed: ā iti dvipadam itthi liṅge ākāraḥ gha saññaḥ hoti
translated: Ā is a two-syllable word. The form of the feminine is ghasañño.

original: 12. Go syālapane ka. 57; rū. 71; nī. 214.
analyzed: go sya ālapane ka rū nī
translated: . Go syālapane ka; rū; nī.

original: Ālapane si gasañño hoti.
analyzed: ālapane si ga saññaḥ hoti
translated: . Ālapane si gasañño hoti.

original: Lahusaññārāsi niṭṭhito.
analyzed: niṭṭhitaḥ
translated: The collection of light-significations is finished.

original: Saṅketarāsi
analyzed: saṅketarā asi
translated: The collection of signals

original: 13. Vidhi visesanaṃ yaṃ tassa caṃ. 1.1.6; pā. 1.1.72; vidhibbisesanantassa (bahūsu).
analyzed: vidhi visesanam yam tassa caṃ pā bahūsu
translated: . The rule is that of the special-marking, and of that (in the plural).

original: Sutte yaṃ visesanaṃ dissati, tassa vidhi ñātabbo.
analyzed: sutte yam visesanam dissati tassa vidhi ñātabbaḥ
translated: . The rule of whatever special-marking is seen in a sutta should be known.

original: ‘Ato yonaṃ ṭāṭe’. Narā, nare. Yonanti visesanaṃ. Ṭāṭeti vidhi.🔽14. Sattamiyaṃ pubbassa rū. 8 (piṭṭhe); caṃ. 1.1.7; pā. 1.1.66.
analyzed: atas yonam ṭāṭe narāḥ nare visesanam ṭāṭa iti  sattamiyam pubbassa rū piṭṭhe cam pā
translated: ‘From ato yonaṃ ṭāṭe’. Narā, nare. Yonanti is the special-marking. Ṭāṭeti is the rule.🔽. Sattamiyaṃ pubbassa rū (piṭṭhe); caṃ; pā.

original: Sattamīniddese pubbavaṇṇasseva vidhi ñātabbo.
analyzed: sattamī niddese pubba vaṇṇassa iva vidhi ñātabbaḥ
translated: . In the seventh-case construction the rule of the preceding vowel should be known.

original: ‘Saro lopo sare’. Lokaggo apa. thera 1.12.57.🔽15. Pañcamiyaṃ parassa caṃ. 1.1.8; pā. 1.1.67.
analyzed: saraḥ lopaḥ sare lokaggaḥ apa thera  pañcamiyam parassa cam pā
translated: ‘Saro lopo sare’. Lokaggo apa. thera.🔽. Pañcamiyaṃ parassa caṃ; pā.

original: Pañcamīniddese parasseva vidhi ñātabbo.
analyzed: pañcamī niddese parassa iva vidhi ñātabbo
translated: . In the fifth-case construction the rule of the other should be known.

original: ‘Ato yonaṃ ṭāṭe’. Narā, nare.
analyzed: a taḥ ya ūnam ṭa a ṭe narā nare
translated: ‘Ato yonaṃ ṭāṭe’. Narā, nare.

analyzed: ā t issa cam pā
translated: . Ādissa caṃ; pā.

original: Parassa sissamāno dissamāno (mū) vidhi ādivaṇṇassa ñātabbo.
analyzed: parassa sissamānaḥ dissamānaḥ mū vidhi ādi vaṇṇassa ñātabbaḥ
translated: . While being the other’s pupil, the rule of the preceding vowel should be known.

original: ‘Ra saṅkhyāto vā’. Terasa.
analyzed: ra saṅkhyātaḥ vā terasa
translated: ‘Ra saṅkhyāto vā’. Terasa.

original: 17. Chaṭṭhiyantassa caṃ. 1.1.10; pā. 1.1.52.
analyzed: chaṭṭhiyantassa cam pā
translated: And the sixth case ending is changed to caṃ.

original: Chaṭṭhīniddese tadantassa vidhi ñātabbo.
analyzed: chaṭṭhī niddese tad antassa vidhi ñātabbo
translated: In the sixth case ending section the rule should be known for the end of that.

original: ‘Rājassi nāmhi’. Rājinā.🔽18. Ṅānubandho caṃ. 1.1.11; pā. 1.1.53.
analyzed: rājassi nāmhi rājinā  ṅā anubandhaḥ cam pā
translated: ‘I am a king.’ Rājinā.🔽And the sixth case ending is changed to caṃ when followed by ñā.

original: Ṅānubandho ādeso chaṭṭhīniddiṭṭhassa antassa ñātabbo.
analyzed: ṅānubandhaḥ ādesaḥ chaṭṭhī niddiṭṭhassa antassa ñātabbaḥ
translated: The sixth case ending is changed to caṃ when followed by ādesa.

original: ‘Gossāvaṅa’. Gavassaṃ.🔽19. Ṭānubandhonekavaṇṇo sabbassa caṃ. 1.1.12; pā. 1.1.55; ṭānubandhānekavaṇṇā sabbassa (bahūsu).
analyzed: gossāvaṅa gavassam  ṭa anubandhaḥ aneka vaṇṇaḥ sabbassa caṃ pā  ṭa anubandhā aneka vaṇṇā sabbassa bahūsu
translated: ‘Gossāvaṅa.’ Gavassaṃ.🔽And the sixth case ending is changed to caṃ when followed by ṭā and anekavaṇṇa, and to sabba when followed by sabba.

original: Yo ca ṭānubandho ādeso, yo ca anekavaṇṇo ādeso, tadubhayaṃ chaṭṭhīniddiṭṭhassa sabbasseva vaṇṇasamudāyassa ñātabbaṃ.
analyzed: yaḥ ca ṭa anubandhaḥ ādesaḥ yaḥ ca aneka vaṇṇaḥ ādeso tat ubhayam chaṭṭhī niddiṭṭhassa sabbassa eva vaṇṇa samudāyassa ñātabbam
translated: The sixth case ending is changed to caṃ when followed by ṭā, to sabba when followed by anekavaṇṇa, and to sabba when followed by sabba.

original: Ṭānubandhe tāva –
analyzed: ṭa anubandhe tāva
translated: First, when followed by ṭā:

original: ‘Imassānitthiyaṃ ṭe’. Esu.
analyzed: imassa an itthiyam ṭe esu
translated: ‘Imassānitthiyaṃ ṭe.’ Esu.

original: Anekavaṇṇe –
analyzed: aneka vaṇṇe
translated: When followed by anekavaṇṇa:

original: ‘Animi nāmhi’. Anena, iminā.🔽20. Ñakānubandhā ādyantā caṃ. 1.1.13; pā. 1.1.46.
analyzed: animi nāmhi anena iminā  ñaka anubandhā ādi antā cam pā
translated: ‘Animi nāmhi.’ Anena, iminā.🔽And the sixth case ending is changed to caṃ when followed by ñā and ādi and anta.

original: Ñānubandho āgamo ca kānubandho āgamo ca kamena chaṭṭhīniddiṭṭhassa ādimhi ca ante ca ñātabbo.
analyzed: ñā anubandhaḥ āgamo ca ka anubandhaḥ āgamo ca kamena chaṭṭhī niddiṭṭhassa ādimhi ca ante ca ñātabbaḥ
translated: The sixth case ending is changed to caṃ when followed by ñā, and to ādi and anta when followed by kā.

original: Ñānubandhe –
analyzed: ñā anubandhe
translated: When followed by ñā:

original: ‘Brūto tissiña’. Braviti.
analyzed: brūtaḥ tissiña braviti
translated: ‘Brūto tissiña.’ Braviti.

original: Kānubandhe –
analyzed: ka anubandhe
translated: When followed by kā:

original: ‘Bhūssa vuka’. Babhuva.
analyzed: bhūssa vuka babhuva
translated: ‘Bhūssa vuka’ (Bh. 1. 171). Babhuva.

original: 21. Mānubandho sarānamantā paro caṃ. 1.1.14; pā. 1.1.47.
analyzed: mā anubandho paras cam
translated: . Mānubandho sarānamantā paro caṃ. ..; pā. ...

original: Mānubandho āgamo sarānaṃ antasaramhā paro hoti.
analyzed: mānubandhaḥ āgamaḥ sarānam antasaramhā paraḥ hoti
translated: Mānubandho āgamo sarānaṃ antasaramhā paro hoti.

original: ‘Najjāyo svāma’. Najjāyo sandanti. ‘Maṃ vā rudhādīnaṃ’. Rundhati. ‘Jara sadānamīma vā’. Jīrati, sīdati.
analyzed: najjāyo svāma najjāyo sandanti mam vā rudhāt īnam rundhati vā jīrati sīdati
translated: ‘Najjāyo svāma’. Najjāyo sandanti. ‘Maṃ vā rudhādīnaṃ’. Rundhati. ‘Jara sadānamīma vā’. Jīrati, sīdati.

original: Imasmiṃ byākaraṇe anekasaratā nāma nadī, purisa iccādīsu liṅgapadesu eva atthi, gamu,
analyzed: imasmin byākaraṇe anekasaratā nāma nadī purisaḥ icca ādīsu liṅga padesu eva atthi gamu
translated: In this grammar, the so-called ‘many-syllable’ is found only in the words for gender such as ‘purisa’ , etc., and not in the words for roots such as ‘gamu’ ,

original: pacaiccādīsu dhātupadesu natthi. Sabbadhātuyo byañjanantā eva honti, dhātvantalopakiccaṃ
analyzed: paca e cca ādīsu dhātu padesu na atthi sabba dhātuyaḥ byañjana antāḥ eva honti dhātu anta lopa kiccam
translated: ‘paca’ , etc. All roots end in a vowel, and there is no such thing as

original: natthi. Tasmā najjāyoti ettha ī-kāro antasaro nāma. Tato ‘najjāyo svāma’ iti suttena
analyzed: natthi tasmā najjāyo ti ettha īkāraḥ antasaraḥ nāma tatas svāmaḥ iti suttena
translated: the function of the final vowel of a root. Therefore, in the word ‘najjāyo’ the vowel ‘ī’ is called an ‘internal vowel’. Then, by the rule ‘najjāyo svāma’

original: ā-kārāgamo. Rundhatīti ettha pana u-kāro antasaro nāma, tato “maṃ vā rudhādīna”nti
analyzed: ākāra āgamaḥ rundhati iti ettha pana ukāraḥ antasaraḥ nāma tatas mam vā
translated: the syllable ‘ā’ is added. But in the word ‘rundhati’ the vowel ‘u’ is called an ‘internal vowel’, and then by the rule ‘maṃ vā rudhādīnaṃ’

original: suttena bindāgamo. Evaṃ jīrati, sīdati iccādīsu. Mrammapotthakesu pana “mānubandho
analyzed: suttena binda āgamaḥ evam jīrati sīdati iccādīsu mramma potthakesu pana mā anubandho
translated: the cerebrals are changed to dentals. So too in the words ‘jīrati’, ‘sīdati’, etc. But in the Mrammapotthaka it is said: “Mānubandho

original: padānamantā paro”ti pāṭho, so sīhaḷapotthakehi na sameti.
analyzed: pāṭhaḥ saḥ sīhaḷa potthakehi na sameti
translated: The reading is “the other in the absence of a foot-initial” . This does not agree with the Sinhalese books.

original: 22. Vippaṭisedhe caṃ. 1.1.16; pā. 1.4.2.
analyzed: vippaṭisedhe cam pā
translated: And in the exclusion of a rule.

original: Samānavisayānaṃ dvinnaṃ vidhīnaṃ aññamaññapaṭisedharahite ṭhāne yebhuyyena paro vidhi okāsaṃ labhati.
analyzed: samāna visayānam dvinnam vidhīnam aññamañña paṭisedha rahite ṭhāne yebhuyyena paraḥ vidhi okāsam labhati
translated: In the place where there is the exclusion of the mutual exclusion of two rules that have the same objective field, the other rule generally gets the opportunity.

original: Cattārome bhikkhave dhammā aṅguttaranikāye -ettha cattārimeti pubbalope sampatte paralopo okāsaṃ labhati.
analyzed: cattāro me bhikkhave dhammāḥ aṅguttara nikāye ettha cattārime iti pubba lope sampatte para lopaḥ okāsam labhati
translated: “There are these four things, bhikkhus, in the Numerical Discourses” . Here, when the first “these four” has been supplied, the second “these four” gets the opportunity.

original: 23. Saṅketo nāvayavonubandho caṃ. 1.1.5.
analyzed: saṅketaḥ na avayava ūnubandho cam
translated: And in the convention, and in the non-consequent.

original: Yo vaṇṇo payogassa avayavo na hoti, suttesu saṅketamatto hoti, so anubandho nāma.
analyzed: yaḥ vaṇṇo payogassa avayavaḥ na hoti suttesu saṅketa mattaḥ hoti saḥ anubandhaḥ nāma
translated: That letter which is not a constituent of the word’s utterance is merely a convention in the texts, and that is called “non-consequent.”

original: ‘Gossāva’. Gavassaṃ-etena padarūpavidhāne anubandho upayogaṃ na gacchatīti ñāpeti.
analyzed: pada rūpa vidhāne anubandhaḥ upayogam na gacchati iti ñāpa iti
translated: “Gossāva” . In the word-formation by this rule the non-consequent does not get the opportunity, is what is meant.

original: 24. Vaṇṇaparena savaṇṇopi.
analyzed: vaṇṇa parena sa vaṇṇaḥ api
translated: And with a vowel-preceded, even a vowel.

original: Vaṇṇasaddo paro etasmāti vaṇṇaparo, vaṇṇaparena rassasarena savaṇṇopi gayhati sayañca, avaṇṇoti vutte ā-kāropi gayhati a-kāro cāti vuttaṃ hoti. Evaṃ ivaṇṇuvaṇṇesu.
analyzed: vaṇṇa saddo paraḥ etasmā ati vaṇṇa paraḥ vaṇṇa parena rassa sarena sa vaṇṇaḥ api gayhati sayam ca avaṇṇaḥ iti vutte ākāraḥ api gayhati akāro ca ati vuttam hoti evam iva aṇṇa uvaṇṇesu
translated: The word “vowel” is preceded by this, thus it is “vowel-preceded.” With a vowel-preceded consonant even a vowel is pronounced, and it itself is pronounced. When “a vowel” is said, the vowel a is pronounced, and the vowel o is pronounced, is what is meant. So too with “a vowel” and “a vowel.”

original: 25. Ntuvantumantāvantutavantusambandhī ntu vantumantvāvantutavantu sambandhī (bahūsu).
analyzed: ntu vantu mantā vantu tavantu sambandhī ntu vantu mantu āvantu tavantu sambandhī bahūsu
translated: 25. The ntu, vantu, mantu, āvantu, tavantu-connexions.

original: Ntuiti vutte vantu, mantu, āvantu, tavantūnaṃ sambandhībhūto ntukāro gayhati.
analyzed: ntu iti vutte vantu mantu āvantu tavantūnam sambandhībhūtaḥ ntu kāraḥ gayhati
translated: When ‘ntu’ is said, the ntu-sign that is the connexion of vantu, mantu, āvantu, tavantu is taken.

original: ‘Ntantūnaṃ nto yomhi paṭhame’. Guṇavanto, satimanto, yāvanto, bhuttavanto.
analyzed: nta ntūnam ntaḥ paṭhame guṇavantaḥ satimantaḥ yāvantaḥ bhuttavantaḥ
translated: ‘The ntu of the ntu-connexions is nto in the first case’. Guṇavanto, satimanto, yāvanto, bhuttavanto.

original: Saṅketarāsi niṭṭhito.
analyzed: saṅketa rāsi niṭṭhitaḥ
translated: The Collection of Signs is finished.

original: Sandhividhāna
analyzed: sandhi vidhāna
translated: The Rules for Sandhi

original: Atha sandhividhānaṃ dīpiyate.
analyzed: atha sandhi vidhānam dīpiyate
translated: Now the rules for sandhi are shown.

original: Lopo, dīgho, rasso, vuddhi, ādeso, āgamo, dvibhāvo, vipallāso.
analyzed: lopaḥ dīghaḥ rassaḥ vuddhi ādesaḥ āgamaḥ dvibhāvaḥ vipallāsaḥ
translated: Deletion, lengthening, shortening, augmentation, substitution, addition, division, reversal.

original: Loparāsi
analyzed: lopa rā asi
translated: The Collection on Deletion

original: 26. Saro lopo sare ka. 12; rū. 13; nī. 30.
analyzed: saraḥ lopaḥ sare ka rū nī
translated: The vowel is deleted in the vowel, the vowel is deleted in the vowel.

original: Luppatīti lopo. Sare pare sarūpo vā asarūpo vā pubbo saro lopo hoti.
analyzed: luppati iti lopaḥ sare pare sarūpaḥ vā asarūpaḥ vā pubbaḥ saraḥ lopaḥ hoti
translated: It is deleted because it is deleted. The vowel that precedes it, whether similar or not, is deleted in the vowel that follows it.

original: Sarūpe tāva –
analyzed: sarūpe tāva
translated: First, in the similar:

analyzed: vāti kim komam vasalim parāmasissati  i taḥ paṭṭhāya yāva sandhi kaṇḍa avasānā yutta ṭṭhānesu sabbattha kvacisaddaḥ vā saddaḥ ca

analyzed: para sarassa

translated: cooked in their presence. The elision is -pāci. I say this to them. The word pañcannetaṃ is a synonym for the five aggregates, the word channetaṃ

analyzed: tam tuyha mūle paṭidesemi

original: Māgame pare –
analyzed: m ā game pare

analyzed: garuḷaḥ uragām iva jā supaṇṇaḥ dhammaḥ arahatām iva ni āloko passatām iva

analyzed: sārāgaḥ sārattaḥ avisāhāraḥ sārambhaḥ sāraddho sāketam nagaram sādhāraṇam sam assa atthi iti sāmī

original: Samāse tumantamhi niccaṃ –

analyzed: ekekam ekekāni ekekena ekekassa iccādi
translated: Each, each one, each one of them, by each one, of each one, etc.

analyzed: mā āgame

original: Akaramhasa te kiccaṃ jā. 1.4.29 – akaramhasetyattho, disvā yācakamāgate jā. 1.7.58;
analyzed: te kiccam jā disvā yācakam āgate
translated: We have done your business, Jā. 1.1.1 = akaramhase te kiccaṃ, Jā. 1.1.1. The meaning is: we have done your business. Having seen the beggar come, Jā. 1.1.1.

original: 2.22.2261, disvā paṇḍitamāgate jā. 2.22.783, yamāhu natthi vīriyanti jā. 2.18.162
analyzed: disvā paṇḍitam āgate jā  yam āhu natthi
translated: .., having seen the wise man come, Jā. 1.1.1. They say there is no energy, Jā. 1.1.1.

original: – ye+āhutyattho. Kadassu – ke+assu, yadeva te jātinissitā, tadeva te jarānissitāye+eva,
analyzed: kadassu
translated: – ye+āhuti, the meaning is: they say. When? – ke+assu, Jā. 1.1.1. Whatever is dependent on your birth, Jā. 1.1.1. that is dependent on your old age, Jā. 1.1.1.

original: te+evāti chedo, sve bhavo svātanaṃ pārā. 22 – byañjane dīgho.
analyzed: chedaḥ sve bhavaḥ svātanam pārā byañjane dīghaḥ
translated: That is the break. Tomorrow is your own, your own power, pārā. – byañjane dīgho.

original: Omhi –
analyzed: omhi
translated: I am –

original: Sa sīlavā dha. pa. 84, sa paññavā, sa ve kāsāvamarahati dha. pa. 10, esa attho, esa
analyzed: sa sīlavā dha pa sa paññavā sa ve kāsāvamarahati dha pa  esa atthaḥ esa
translated: He is virtuous, dha. pa. , he is wise, he is worthy of the yellow robe, dha. pa. , this is the meaning, this

original: dhammo dha. pa. 5, dinnamāsi janindena jā. 2.22.2161 (dinnamhāti janindena) – dinno+āsīti
analyzed: dhammaḥ dha pa  dinnam asi janindena jā
translated: is the Dhamma, dha. pa. , it was given by the lord of the people, Jā. 1.1.1. (dinnamhāti janindena) – it was given, Jā. 1.1.1.

original: chedo, maggamatthi vibha. aṭṭha. 189 – maggo+atthi, aggamakkhāyati a. ni. 1.47, paccayākārameva
analyzed: chedaḥ maggamatthi vibha aṭṭha   maggoatthi aggamakkhāyati a ni  paccaya ākāram eva
translated: The path exists, is called the foremost.🔽The division is: the condition itself,🔽and the division is: eight.

original: ca vibha. aṭṭha. 225, saṅgho pabbatamiva, saddo cicciṭamiva, hiyyo bhavo hiyyattanaṃ,
analyzed: ca vibha aṭṭha saṅgho pabbatam iva saddaḥ cicciṭam iva hiyyas bhavaḥ hiyyattanam
translated: The Saṅgha is like a mountain, the sound is like cicciṭa, yesterday's existence is yesterday's self,

original: pāto asanaṃ pātarāso, pātamanusiṭṭho, kakusandha koṇāgamano, thera vādānamuttamo
analyzed: pātaḥ asanam pātarāsaḥ pātam anusiṭṭhaḥ kakusandha koṇa āgamanaḥ thera vādānam uttamaḥ
translated: today's seat is the morning meal, the morning instruction, Kakusandha Koṇāgamana, the elder is the foremost of those who speak.

original: – kakusandhoti ca theroti ca chedo, theravādoti attho.
analyzed: kakusandho ti ca thero ti ca chedo theravādo ti attho
translated: Kakusandha and elder are cut off, the meaning is: the elder's doctrine.

original: Suttavibhattena animittepi hoti. Tuvañca dhanusekha ca jā. 1.16.239, paccayamahāpadeso hesa, ekakoṭṭhāso esa, abhilāpamattabhedo esa iccādi.
analyzed: sutta vibhattena a nimitte pi hoti tuvam ca ca jā  paccaya mahā padeso eka koṭṭhāsaḥ esa abhilāpa matta bhedaḥ esa iccādi
translated: By the sutra division, it is also in the signless. You and archery, this is the great basis of conditions, this is one section, this is the distinction of mere expression, and so on.

original: 42. Gossāvaṅa ka. 22, 78; rū. 28; nī. 52, 229.
analyzed: ru nī
translated: The cow's tail is ka. , ; rū. ; nī. , .

original: Sare pare gossa antassa avaṅa hoti.
analyzed: sare pare gossa antassa avaṅa hoti
translated: The tail of the cow's end becomes avaṅa.

original: Go ca asso ca gavāssaṃ.
analyzed: go ca assaḥ ca gavāssam
translated: The cow and the horse are the cow-horse.

original: Suttavibhattena byañjanepi. Sagavacaṇḍo a. ni. 4.108, paragavacaṇḍo.
analyzed: sutta vibhattena byañjane pi sagavacaṇḍaḥ a ni paragavacaṇḍaḥ
translated: By the sutra division, it is also in the letter. The cow-bull is a. ni. , the other cow-bull.

original: Appavidhānamuccate.
analyzed: appa vidhānam uccate
translated: The brief explanation is finished.

original: Mahāvuttinā avaṇṇassa uttaṃ, ottañca –
analyzed: mahāvuttinā avaṇṇassa uttam ottam ca
translated: By the great explanation, the end of the word is utta, and otta –

original: Puthujjano, puthubhūto-puthūti vā eko pāṭipadiko, puthunā puthunītipi dissati, apekkhiyāno🔽apekkhiyānaapekkhitvātyattho. Evaṃ anumodiyāno, marīcikūpamaṃ abhisambuddhāno, mā🔽maṃ pisācā khādantu, jīva tvaṃ saradosataṃ jā. 1.2.9, rattidivova so dibbo, mānusaṃ🔽saradosataṃ-vassasatantyattho, anuyanti disodisaṃ dī. ni. 3.281, sampatanti disodisaṃ-taṃ
analyzed: vā eko pāṭipadiko puthunā dissati apekkhiyāno  evam anumodiyānaḥ marīcikūpamam abhisambuddhānaḥ mā  mam pisācā khādantu jīva tvam saradosatam jā  rattidivā uva saḥ dibbaḥ mānusam  anuyanti disaḥ disam ni sampatanti disaḥ disaṃtam
translated: The worldling, one who has gone his own way, or who has gone by himself, or who has gone by himself alone, is also seen. One who is looking,🔽the meaning is: having looked after looking. Thus rejoicing, having fully understood the simile of the mirage, may🔽the demons not eat me, live on for a hundred years, O Saradosa. 1.2.9, that divine [being] of day and night, human,🔽the meaning is: for a hundred years, they go in all directions. ni. 3.281, they fall in all directions, that🔽

original: taṃ disantyattho, parosataṃ, parosahassaṃ, aññoññaṃ aññamaññaṃ, ponopuññaṃ punappunaṃ,🔽ponobbhavikā taṇhā-punoti vā eko nipāto, puno tassa mahe sino, puno pattaṃ gahetvāna,🔽na ca dāni puno atthi, mama tuyhañca saṅgamo, na puno amatākāraṃ, passissāmi mukhaṃ🔽tava apa. therī 2.2.235.🔽Ivaṇṇassa attaṃ, uttaṃ, ettañca –
analyzed: tam parosatam parosahassam aññoññam aññamaññam ponopuññam punappunam 🔽ponobbhavikā taṇhā punoti vai ekaḥ nipātaḥ puno tassa mahe sino puno pattam gahetvāna 🔽na ca dāni punar atthi mama tuyhañca saṅgamaḥ na punar amata ākāram passissāmi mukham 🔽tava apa therī 🔽iva aṇṇassa attam uttam ettam ca
translated: The worldling, one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone his own way, or one who has gone

original: Tadamināpetaṃ pariyāyena veditabbaṃ-taṃ etaṃ atthajātaṃ iminā pariyāyena veditabbanti
analyzed: tat aminā apetam pariyāyena veditabbaṃtam etam attha jātam iminā pariyāyena veditabbanti
translated: This is how the meaning of this word-group should be understood by this method.

original: attho, sakiṃ āgacchati sīlenāti sakadāgāmī, itthiyā bhāvo itthattaṃ, evumaṃ – evaṃ+imanti
analyzed: āgacchati sīlena ati sakadāgāmī itthiyā bhāvaḥ itthattam evumam
translated: The meaning is: he comes once (sakim) to (ā-) the (i.e. human) state (gati) through virtue (sīla), thus he is a Once-Returner (sakadāgāmī). The state (atta) of a woman (itthi) is womanhood (itthatta), thus it is. In this way (evaṃ) this (imaṃ) is the cutting (cheda).

original: chedo, tvaṃ no satthā mahāmune, atthadhammavidū ise.
analyzed: tvam no satthā mahā mune attha dhamma vidū ise
translated: You are our Teacher, Great Sage, you are the knower of the meaning and the Dhamma.

original: Uvaṇṇassa ittaṃ, ottañca –
analyzed: u vaṇṇassa ittam o ttam ca
translated: The state (ittaṃ) of the sun (uvaṇṇa), and the best (uttañca) –

original: Mātito dī. ni. 1.303, pitito, mātipakkho, pitipakkho, mātigho jā. 2.19.118, pitigho,
analyzed: mātitaḥ dī ni pititaḥ mātipakkhaḥ pitipakkhaḥ mātighaḥ jā
translated: From the mother’s side (mātito) the nephew (dī. ni. ..), from the father’s side (pitito), the mother’s side (mātipakkho), the father’s side (pitipakkho), the mother’s clan (mātigho jā. ..), the father’s clan (pitigho),

original: mattikaṃ dhanaṃ pārā. 34, pettikaṃ dhanaṃ, api no lacchasi, kacci no tumhe yāpetha,
analyzed: mattikam dhanam pārā pettikam dhanam api naḥ lacchasi kacci naḥ tumhe yāpetha
translated: The wealth (dhana) of the mother (mattikaṃ) is across (pārā), the wealth of the father (pettikaṃ dhanaṃ), do you get it? Do you all live (yāpetha)?

original: kathaṃ no tumhe yāpetha, sotukāmattha no tumhe bhikkhave, na no samaṃ atthi khu.
analyzed: katham no tumhe yāpetha sotu kāmattha no tumhe bhikkhave na no samam atthi khu
translated: How do you all live? You all wish to hear (sotukāmattha), there is no equality (samaṃ) for us (no) in the world (khu. pā. ..),

original: pā. 6.3, na hi no saṅkarantena ma. ni. 3.272, natthi no koci pariyāyo jā. 1.5.110🔽(na hi no koci pariyāyo) – imesu tīsu nusaddo ekaṃsatthe, sosito sotatto ceva jā.
analyzed: na hi no saṅkarantena ma ni natthi no koci 🔽na hi no koci pariyāyaḥ imesu tīsu nu saddaḥ ekaṃsatthe ca iva jā
translated: There is no one (no) for us (koci) to associate with (saṅkarantena ma. ni. ..), there is no way (pariyāyo jā. ..) for us (no).🔽(There is no one for us (no) to associate with (saṅkarantena ma. ni. ..), there is no way (pariyāyo jā. ..) for us (no).) In these three (i.e. mātito dī. ni. .., pitipakkho, mātigho jā. .., pitigho, mattikaṃ dhanaṃ pārā. .., pettikaṃ dhanaṃ, api no lacchasi, kacci no tumhe yāpetha, kathaṃ no tumhe yāpetha, sotukāmattha no tumhe bhikkhave, na no samaṃ atthi khu.

original: 1.1.94 sotatto sosindo ceva; ma. ni. 1.157 – suṭṭhu sītalo suṭṭhu santattotyattho,
analyzed: sotattaḥ sosindo ca iva ma ni suṭṭhu sītalo suṭṭhu
translated: 1.1.94 Sotatto sosindo ceva; ma. ni. 1.157 – The meaning is: very cool, very well-tempered.

original: jambunadiyā jātaṃ jambonadaṃ.
analyzed: jambunadiyā jātam jambonadam
translated: Jambonada is born in the River Ganges.

original: Essa ittaṃ –
analyzed: e ssaḥ i t tam
translated: Essa ittaṃ –

original: Okandāmasi bhūtāni, pabbatāni vanāni ca jā. 2.22.2173 – avakandāmasetyattho, yaṃ
analyzed: okandāmasi bhūtāni pabbatāni vanāni ca jā avakandāmasa iti atthaḥ yam
translated: We are thirsty for beings, for mountains and forests, jā. .. – the meaning is: we are parched.

original: karomasi brahmuno, tadajja tuyhaṃ dassāma dī. ni. 2.370, idha hemantagimhisu dha.
analyzed: karomasi brahmunaḥ tat ajja tuyham dassāma ni
translated: What we do for Brahmā, today we will give to you, dī. ni. .. , here in the winter and summer, dha.

original: pa. 286, buddhapaccekabuddhisu, cetehi cetaputtihi cariyā. 1.106 – cetaputtehi saddhintyattho.
analyzed: buddha paccekabuddhisu cetehi ceta puttihi cariyā
translated: pa. .. , among Buddhas and Paccekabuddhas, with these sons of Ceta, cariyā. .. – the meaning is: with the sons of Ceta, together with them.

original: Ossa uttaṃ –
analyzed: ossaḥ uttam
translated: Ossa uttaṃ –

original: Manuññaṃ, na tenatthaṃ abandhisu jā. 1.6.7 – so tena vacanena atthaṃ na abandhi na
analyzed: manuññam na tena attham jā    saḥ tena vacanena attham na abandhi na
translated: Beautiful, by that he did not gain his purpose, jā. .. – the meaning is: by that speech he did not gain his purpose, he did not obtain it.

original: labhītyattho. Avhāyantu su yuddhena jā. 2.22.871 – so pahāravacanena maṃ avhayantotyattho.
analyzed: avhāyantu su yuddhena jā    saḥ u pahāra vacanena mama
translated: Having challenged me with a blow, jā. .. – the meaning is: he challenged me with a blow.

original: Api nu hanukā santā jā. 1.1.146 – no hanukā ekantaṃ khinnā dukkhapattātyattho.
analyzed: api nu hanukā santā jā no hanukā ekantam khinnā
translated: Would the jawbones be tired, jā. .. – the meaning is: the jawbones are not at all tired, they have not suffered.

original: Vikārasandhipi ādesasandhirūpattā idha saṅgayhati.
analyzed: idha
translated: Vikārasandhi is also included here because it is of the nature of ādesasandhi.

original: Iti sarādesarāsi.
analyzed: iti sa ra āde sa ra āsi
translated: Thus the collection of ādesas.

original: Kavaggato paṭṭhāya vaggāvaggabyañjanānaṃ ādeso dīpiyate.🔽43. Vaggalasehi te.
analyzed: ka vaggataḥ paṭṭhāya vagga a vagga byañjanānam ādesaḥ dīpiyate  vagga lasehi te
translated: With the five groups and with la, se,

original: Pañcavaggehi ca la, sehi ca parassa ya-kārassa kvaci te eva vagga la, sā honti vā yathākkamaṃ, ya-kāro pubbarūpattaṃ āpajjatīti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: pañca vaggehi ca la sehi ca parassa yakārassa kvaci te eva vagga la sā honti vā yathākkamam yakāraḥ pubbarūpattam āpajjati iti vuttam hoti
translated: In the word of another, ya becomes ka in some instances, with the five groups and with la, se, either in order or not, it being said that ya becomes the preceding vowel.

original: Nipaccatīti nipako, nipakassa bhāvo nepakkaṃ, vipāko eva vepakkaṃ, vattabbanti vākkaṃ,
analyzed: nipaccati iti nipakaḥ nipakassa bhāvaḥ nepakkam vipākaḥ eva vepakkam vattabbanti vākkam
translated: The state of being clever is cleverness, nepakkaṃ; the state of being ripe is ripeness, vepakkaṃ; what should be said is speech, vākkaṃ;

original: vākyaṃ vā. Pamukhe sādhu pāmokkhaṃ – yassa pubbarūpatte kate ādidutiyassa paṭhamattaṃ,
analyzed: vākyam vā pamukhe sādhu pāmokkham yassa pubba rūpa tte kate ādi dutiyassa
translated: or it is a sentence, vākyaṃ. In the beginning, good is excellent, pāmokkhaṃ—when the preceding vowel is made, the first of the first and second is the first.

original: subhagassa bhāvo sobhaggaṃ, dobhaggaṃ, bhuñjitabbanti bhoggaṃ, yuñjitabbanti yoggaṃ,
analyzed: subhagassa bhāvaḥ sobhaggam dobhaggam bhuñjitabbanti bhoggam yuñjitabbanti yoggam
translated: The state of being beautiful is beauty, sobhaggaṃ; the state of being bad is badness, dobhaggaṃ; what should be enjoyed is enjoyment, bhoggaṃ; what should be yoked is a yoke, yoggaṃ;

original: kukkucabhāvo kukkuccaṃ, vattabbanti vāccaṃ, vuccate, paccate, vaṇijānaṃ kammaṃ vāṇijjaṃ,
analyzed: kukkuca bhāvaḥ kukkuccam vattabbanti vāccam vuccate paccate vaṇijānam kammam vāṇijjam
translated: the state of being remorse is remorse, kukkuccaṃ; what should be said is talk, vāccaṃ; it is said, it is cooked, the work of merchants is trade, vāṇijjaṃ;

original: bhuñjitabbanti bhojjaṃ, yuñjitabbanti yojjaṃ.
analyzed: bhuñjitabbanti bhojjam yuñjitabbanti yojjam
translated: what should be enjoyed is food, bhojjaṃ; what should be yoked is a yoke, yojjaṃ.

original: 44. Tavaggavaraṇānaṃ ye cavaggabayañā ka. 269, 41; nī. 104, 106, 119, 121-5.
analyzed: ta vagga vara ṇānam ye ca vagga ba yañā ka
translated: The syllables of the first group and the first group of the first group, ka, nī, ṇī, ṇe, ṇe.

original: Ādesabhūte vā vibhattibhūte vā paccayabhūte vā ya-kāre pare tavaggānaṃva, ra, ṇānañca cavagga, ba, ya, ñādesā honti vā yathākkamaṃ.
analyzed: ādesa bhūte vā vibhatti bhūte vā paccaya bhūte vā yakāre pare ta vaggānam va ra ṇānam ca ca vagga ba ya ña ādesāḥ honti vā yathākkamam
translated: After the syllable ya, which is the basis, the case, or the condition, the syllables ra, ṇā, ca, va, ya, ṇā, are the substitutes, respectively, for the syllables ta, ra, ṇa, ba, ya, ṇā.

original: Pokkharañño, pokkharaññā, pokkharaññaṃ, samaṇassa bhāvo sāmaññaṃ, evaṃ brahmaññaṃ, iccetaṃ kusalaṃ pārā. 411 iccādīni ‘yavā sare’ti sutte udāhaṭāni.
analyzed: pokkharaññaḥ pokkharaññā pokkharaññam samaṇassa bhāvaḥ sāmaññam evam brahmaññam icca etam kusalam iccā ādīni iccā ādīni sutte udāhaṭāni
translated: The state of a king of the Pokkharas is Pokkharasāti, Pokkharasātiyo, Pokkharasātiṃ, the state of an ascetic is asceticism, thus is brahminhood, this is good, the other side, and so on, are those quoted in the sutta ‘yavā sare’.

original: Paṇḍitassa bhāvo paṇḍiccaṃ, santassa bhāvo saccaṃ, tathassa bhāvotacchaṃ, yajjevaṃ-yadi+evaṃ,
analyzed: paṇḍitassa bhāvaḥ paṇḍiccam santassa bhāvaḥ saccam yat jevam yadi evam
translated: The state of a wise man is wisdom, the state of a calm person is truth, the state of a true person is truthfulness, just as, if thus, in this way,

original: najjo, najjā, najjaṃ, suhadassa bhāvo sohajjaṃ, vattabbanti vajjaṃ, jhānaṃ upasampajja
analyzed: najjaḥ najjā najjam su hadassa bhāvaḥ sohajjam vattabbanti vajjam jhānam upasampajja
translated: today, today, today, the state of a good person is goodness, what should be said is a fault, having attained jhāna,

original: viharati dha. sa. 160, upasampajjati, ajjhokāso, bojjhaṅgo, bojjhā, bodhiyā vā, bujjhitabbanti
analyzed: viharati dha sa upasampajjati ajjhokāsaḥ bojjhaṅgaḥ bojjhā bodhiyā vā bujjhitabbanti
translated: he dwells, having attained, in the open air, a factor of enlightenment, an enlightenment, or a tree, what should be known as enlightenment,

original: bojjhaṃ, bujjhati, ponopuññaṃ, thanato sambhūtaṃ thaññaṃ.
analyzed: bojjham bujjhati ponopuññam thanataḥ sambhūtam thaññam
translated: is enlightenment, he awakens, again and again, milk that has arisen from the breast.

original: Pavagge yassa pubbarūpaṃ –
analyzed: pavagge yassa pubbarūpam
translated: In the section on the syllable ya, the first form is –

original: Vappate, luppate, abbhuggato, abbhokāso, usabhassa bhāvo osabbhaṃ, labhiyateti labbhaṃ,
analyzed: vappate luppate abbhuggataḥ abbhokāsaḥ usabhassa bhāvaḥ osabbham labhiyate iti labbham
translated: Vappate, luppate, abbhuggato, abbhokāso, usabhassa bhāvo osabbhaṃ, labhiyateti labbhaṃ,

original: labbhate, gāme hitaṃ gammaṃ, opammaṃ, sokhummaṃ, āgamma, upagamma, gamiyateti gammo,
analyzed: labbhate gāme hitam gammam opammam sokhummam āgamma upagamma gamiyate iti gammo
translated: labbhate, gāme hitaṃ gammaṃ, opammaṃ, sokhummaṃ, āgamma, upagamma, gamiyateti gammo,

original: evaṃ dammo, rammo, gammate, rammate.
analyzed: evam dammaḥ rammaḥ gammate rammate
translated: evaṃ dammo, rammo, gammate, rammate.

original: ‘Tavagga varaṇāna…’nti iminā suttena yamhi rassa yattaṃ –
analyzed: iminā suttena yamhi rassa yattam
translated: ‘Tavagga varaṇāna…’nti iminā suttena yamhi rassa yattaṃ –

original: Kayyate kariyate, ayyo ariyo.
analyzed: kayyate kariyate ayyaḥ
translated: Kayyate kariyate, ayyo ariyo.

original: ‘Vaggalasehi te’ti lato yassa pubbarūpaṃ –
analyzed: vagga lasehi ta iti la taḥ yassa pubbarūpam

What is your chariot-circle? What is your … ?’ ‘What is the meaning of kvati ?’ ‘Who has been seen or heard by you? ’ ‘A monkey is righteous’, ‘Who are the disciples of Gotama? Where have they gone? ’ ‘Gold’ is gold.

original: vā suto vā, vānaro dhammiko iti, ko nume gotamasāvakā gatā-kva nu+imeti chedo, soṇṇaṃ suvaṇṇaṃ iccādi.🔽Kussa kruttaṃ –
analyzed: vā sutaḥ vā vānaraḥ dhammikaḥ iti kaḥ nu me gotama sāvakāḥ chedaḥ soṇṇam suvaṇṇam iccādi  kussa kruttam
translated: ‘Of a bad man’ (kusa) is a state of being bad.

original: Krubbati kubbati.🔽Ttassa trattaṃ –
analyzed: krubbati kubbati  ttassa trattam
translated: ‘He scratches’ (krubbati) is a state of scratching.🔽‘Of a good man’ (tassa) is a state of being good.

original: Atrajo putto, khetrajo putto attajo, khettajo, gotrabhū, vatrabhū, citraṃ, vicitraṃ,
analyzed: atra jaḥ puttaḥ khetra jaḥ puttaḥ atta jaḥ khetta jaḥ gotra bhū vatra bhū citram vicitram
translated: ‘A son born in the house’ is a son born in the house. ‘A son born in the field’ is a son born in the field. ‘A son born of oneself’ is a son born of oneself. ‘A field’ is a field. ‘A family line’ is a family line. ‘A water-line’ is a water-line. ‘A picture’ is a picture. ‘A variety’ is a variety.

original: cittaṃ, vicittaṃ, utrastamidaṃ cittaṃ saṃ. ni. 1.98, utrāsī palāyī saṃ. ni. 1.249,
analyzed: cittam vicittam utrastam idam cittam sam ni utrāsī palāyī sam ni
translated: ‘The mind’ is a mind. ‘A variety of mind’ is a variety of mind. ‘This mind is frightened’ is a state of being frightened. ‘It is frightened and runs away’ is a state of running away.

original: yātrā ca me bhavissati ma. ni. 1.23 iccādi.
analyzed: yātrā ca me bhavissati ma ni i c ādi
translated: ‘I shall have a journey’ is a state of having a journey.

original: Dassa drattaṃ –
analyzed: dassa drattam
translated: ‘Of a seer’ (dassa) is a state of seeing.

original: Indriyaṃ, sukho udayo yassāti sukhudrayaṃ, dukkhudrayaṃ kammaṃ ma. ni. 2.109, pathavī undriyyati saṃ. ni. 1.158 – bhijjatītyattho, mittadrubbho mittaddubbho.🔽Ddassa drattaṃ –

translated: The root dṛ has the meaning “to break,” and the root dṛś has the meaning “to see.”🔽The root dṛ has the meaning “to break,” and the root dṛś has the meaning “to see.”🔽The root dṛ has the meaning “to break,” and the root dṛś has the meaning “to see.”🔽The root dṛ has the meaning “to break,” and the root dṛś has the meaning “to see.”

original: Brahāvanaṃ, brahantaṃ vā vanappatiṃ jā. 1.1.14, brahmā, brāhmaṇo – bāhitapāpattā arahā brāhmaṇoti vuccati, brahmuno apaccanti jātibrāhmaṇo vuccati.🔽Va, vīnaṃ byattaṃ –

translated: The root dṛ has the meaning “to break,” and the root dṛś has the meaning “to see.”🔽The root dṛ has the meaning “to break,” and the root dṛś has the meaning “to see.”🔽The root dṛ has the meaning “to break,” and the root dṛś has the meaning “to see.”🔽The root dṛ has the meaning “to break,” and the root dṛś has the meaning “to see.”

translated: The root dṛ has the meaning “to break,” and

original: Dvibhāvo tividho. Tattha pakkamo, parakkamo iccādi byañjanadvittaṃ nāma. Rukkhaṃ🔽rukkhaṃ siñcati iccādi vibhatyantapadadvittaṃ nāma. Titikkhā, tikicchā, jagamā, jagamu
analyzed: dvi bhāvaḥ tividhaḥ tattha pakkamaḥ parakkamaḥ iccādi byañjana dvittam nāma rukkham  rukkham siñcati id ca ādi nāma titikkhā tikicchā jagamā jagamu

analyzed: catuttha dutiyesu esam tatiya paṭhamā ka rū nī

original: Vagge catuttha, dutiyesu paresu kamena tatiya, paṭhamā esaṃ catuttha, dutiyānaṃ dvibhāvaṃ
analyzed: vagge catuttha dutiyesu paresu kamena tatiya paṭhamāḥ esam catuttha dutiyānam dvi bhāvam

original: gacchanti, dutiyabhāvaṃ gacchantīti attho. ‘Saramhā dve’ti suttena vā ‘vaggalasehi🔽te’iccādīhi vā dutiya, catutthānampi sadisatte jāte puna iminā suttena ādidutiyassa
analyzed: gacchanti dutiya bhāvam gacchanti iti attho saramhā dve iti suttena vā  vā sadisa tte jāte puna iminā suttena ādi dutiyassa
translated: With the sutta “Two from the Saram” or with the words “They are the same with the Vaggalas” ,🔽the second and the fourth are the same.

original: paṭhamattaṃ, ādicatutthassa tatiyattañca jātaṃ.
analyzed: ādi catutthassa jātam
translated: Again, with this sutta the first of the first and the third of the third are the same.

original: Tattha kavagge –
analyzed: tattha ka vagge
translated: Herein, in the Kava section:

original: Ākkhātaṃ, pakkhittaṃ, pakkhepo, rūpakkhandho, vedanākkhandho, dhātukkhobho, āyukkhayo, nakkhamati.

analyzed: vippharati vippharaṇam vipphāraḥ apphoṭeti mahapphalam nipphalam madhupphāṇitam
translated: Vippharati, vippharaṇaṃ, vipphāro, apphoṭeti, mahapphalaṃ, nipphalaṃ, madhupphāṇitaṃ,

original: vibbhamati, vibbhamo, ubbhataṃ, nibbhayaṃ, dubbharo, sabbhāvo, usabhassa bhāvo osabbhaṃ,
analyzed: vibbhamati vibbhamaḥ ubbhatam nibbhayam dubbharaḥ sabbhāvaḥ usabhassa bhāvaḥ osabbham
translated: vibbhamati, vibbhamo, ubbhataṃ, nibbhayaṃ, dubbharo, sabbhāvo, usabhassa bhāvo osabbhaṃ,

original: labbhati, ārabbho, ārabbha, ārabbhitvā iccādi.
analyzed: labbhati ārabbhaḥ ārabbhaḥ ārabbhitvā iccādi
translated: labbhati, ārabbho, ārabbha, ārabbhitvā iccādi.

original: Idhapi u, du, nito parapadānaṃ ādibyañjanassa dvittaṃ visesato icchanti.
analyzed: idh api u du n itaḥ para padānam ādi byañjanassa dvittam visesataḥ icchanti
translated: Here too they want the double of the initial consonant of the following word, namely u, du, and ni, as a special feature.

original: Iti visadisadvittarāsi.
analyzed: iti
translated: Thus the group of the different double consonants.

original: 55. Vicchābhikkhaññesu dve caṃ. 6.3-1; pā. 8.1.1, 4.
analyzed: vicchā bhikkhaññesu dve cam pā
translated: . In vicchā and abhikkhañña there are two of the single word of many meanings.

original: Vicchāyaṃ abhikkhaññe ca anekatthassa ekapadassa dve rūpāni honti. Bhinne atthe kriyāya vā dabbena vā guṇena vā byāpituṃ icchā vicchā. Punappunakriyā abhikkhaññaṃ.
analyzed: vicchāyam abhikkhaññe ca aneka atthassa eka padassa dve rūpāni honti bhinne atthe kriyāya vā dabbena vā guṇena vā byāpitum icchā vicchā punappuna kriyā abhikkhaññam
translated: In vicchā and abhikkhañña there are two forms of the single word of many meanings. Vicchā is the desire to pervade by means of an object or a quality, or by means of an action, when the meaning is divided. Abhikkhañña is the doing again and again.

original: Vicchāyaṃ tāva –
analyzed: vicchāyam tāva
translated: First, in vicchā:

original: Rukkhaṃ rukkhaṃ siñcati. Gāme gāme sataṃkumbhā, gāmo gāmo ramaṇiyo, gehe gehe issaro, rasaṃ rasaṃ bhakkhayati, kriyaṃ kriyaṃ ārabhate.
analyzed: rukkham rukkham siñcati gāme gāme sataṃkumbhā gāmaḥ gāmaḥ ramaṇiyaḥ gehe gehe issaraḥ rasam rasam bhakkhayati kriyam kriyam ārabhate
translated: He waters tree after tree. A hundred pots in village after village. A village after village is delightful. A lord in house after house. He eats flavour after flavour. He undertakes action after action.🔽.

original: Ānupubbiyepi vicchāva gamyate –🔽Mūle mūle thūlā, agge agge sukhumā, jeṭṭhaṃ jeṭṭhaṃ anupavesetha, imesaṃ devasikaṃ🔽māsakaṃ māsakaṃ dehi, mañjūsakarukkho pupphaṃ pupphaṃ pupphati, ime janā pathaṃ pathaṃ
analyzed: ānupubbiye pi gamyate  mūle mūle thūlāḥ agge agge sukhumāḥ jeṭṭham jeṭṭham anupavesetha imesam devasikam  māsakam māsakam dehi mañjūsaka rukkhaḥ puppham puppham pupphati ime janāḥ patham patham
translated: In the following, too, the elision of the syllable is understood:

original: accenti, sabbe ime aḍḍhā, katarā katarā imesaṃ aḍḍhatā, katamā katamā imesaṃ aḍḍhatā.
analyzed: sabbe ime aḍḍhā katarā katarā imesam aḍḍha tā katamā katamā imesam aḍḍha tā
translated: At the root, at the root, thick, at the top, at the top, thin, the elder, the elder, enter, give a penny a day, the mango tree flowers flower by flower, these people give way way by way, all these are rich, which, which of these is rich? which, which of these is rich?

original: Abhikkhaññe –
analyzed: abhikkhaññe
translated: In the following, too, the elision of the syllable is understood:

original: Bhattaṃ pacati pacati, apuññaṃ pasavati pasavati, bhutvā bhutvā nippajjanti, paṭaṃ paṭaṃ karoti, paṭapaṭāyati, ekamekaṃ, ekamekāni iccādīsu vicchāsu pubbapade syādilopo.
analyzed: bhattam pacati pacati apuññam pasavati pasavati bhutvā bhutvā nippajjanti paṭam paṭam karoti paṭapaṭāyati ekam ekam ekam ekāni iccādīsu vicchāsu pubba pade sya ādi lopaḥ
translated: He cooks rice, he cooks, he accumulates demerit, he accumulates, after eating, after eating, they lie down, he makes a mat, mat by mat, he spreads, mat by mat, each, each, each, each, and so on.

original: 56. Sabbādīnaṃ vītihāre.
analyzed: sabba ādīnam vītihāre
translated: In the elision of all, etc.,

original: Atikkamma haraṇaṃ atihāro, na atihāro vītihāro, aññamaññassa antoyeva haraṇantiattho, vītihāratthe gamyamāne sabbādīnaṃ sabbanāmānaṃ dve rūpāni honti, pubbassekassa ca syādilopo.
analyzed: atikkamma haraṇam atihāraḥ na atihāraḥ vītihāraḥ aññamaññassa antaḥ yeva haraṇa nti atthaḥ vītihāra atthe gamyamāne sabba ādīnam sabbanāmānam dve rūpāni honti pubbassa ikassa ca
translated: The carrying away after passing over is the elision, not the carrying away after passing over, the meaning is the carrying away of one within the other. When the meaning of elision is intended, all the words beginning with sabba have two forms, and there is elision of the syllable ya of the first.

original: Ime dve janā aññamaññassa upakārakā, itarītarassa upakārakā, aññamaññaṃ passanti, aññamaññassa denti, aññamaññassa apenti, aññamaññassa dhanaṃ, aññamaññe nissitā.
analyzed: ime dve janā aññamaññassa upakārakāḥ itarītarassa upakārakāḥ aññamaññam passanti aññamaññassa denti aññamaññassa apenti aññamaññassa dhanam aññamaññe nissitā
translated: These two people are helpful to each other, they are helpful to each other, they see each other, they give to each other, they bring to each other, they have wealth in common, they are dependent on each other.

original: 57. Yāvatātāvaṃ sambhame caṃ. 6.3.14; pā. 8.1.12; yāvabodhaṃ sambhame (bahūsu).
analyzed: yāvatātāvam sambhame cam pā  yāvabodham sambhame bahūsu
translated: . As far as, so far, and also in a hurry. ..; pā. ..; as far as understanding, in a hurry (in many).

original: Yaṃ parimāṇamassāti yāvaṃ. Taṃ parimāṇamassāti tāvaṃ. Punappunaṃ bhamanaṃ pavattanaṃ
analyzed: yam parimāṇam assa ati yāvam tam parimāṇam assa ati tāvam punappunam bhamanam pavattanam
translated: As much as is the measure of it is yāvaṃ. That is the measure of it is tāvaṃ. The occurrence of rebirth again and again

original: sambhamo. Turitena vacīpayogena taṃ taṃ upāyadīpanaṃ sambhamo, āmeḍitameva vuccati,
analyzed: turitena vacī payogena tam tam upāya dīpanam āmeḍitam eva vuccati
translated: is sambhamo. By means of a quick verbal expression, the explanation of this and that means is sambhamo, it is said to be āmeḍita.

original: sambhame gamyamāne yāvatā yattakena padena so attho paññāyati, tattakaṃ padaṃ payujjate,
analyzed: sambhame gamyamāne yāvatā yattakena padena so attho paññāyati tattakam padam payujjate
translated: When going in a hurry, as far as, by how much, by how many words that meaning is understood, that much word is used,

original: dvikkhattuṃ vā tikkhattuṃ vā taduttari vā udīriyatetyattho. Yathābodhaṃ sambhametipi pāṭho, soyevattho.🔽Bhaye, kodhe, pasaṃsāyaṃ, turite, kotūhale’cchare.
analyzed: dvi kkhattum vā ti khattum vā tad uttari vā udīriyate iti atthaḥ yathābodham pāṭhaḥ  bhaye kodhe turite kotūhalecchare
translated: the meaning is that it is uttered twice, three times, or more than that. The reading yathābodhaṃ sambhameti is also the same meaning.🔽In fear, in anger, in praise, in haste, in curiosity, in play.

original: Hāse, soke, pasāde ca, kare āmeḍitaṃ budho.
analyzed: hāse soke pasāde ca kare āmeḍitam budho
translated: In laughter, in grief, in confidence, the wise one makes āmeḍita.

original: Tattha bhaye –
analyzed: tattha bhaye

original: Sappo sappo, coro coro –
analyzed: sappo sappo coro coro

translated: In anger:

analyzed: vijjha vijjha pahara pahara

original: Pasaṃsāyaṃ –
analyzed: pasaṃsāyam
translated: In praise:

analyzed: sādhu sādhu

original: Turite –

original: Kotūhale –

translated: In deceit:

analyzed: āgaccha āgaccha

original: Acchare –

translated: In wonder:

analyzed: aho buddhaḥ aho buddhaḥ
translated: Wonderful is the Enlightened One, wonderful is the Enlightened One.

original: Hāse –

translated: In laughter:

analyzed: abhikkamatha vāseṭṭhāḥ abhikkamatha vāseṭṭhāḥ
translated: Go forth, Vasetthas, go forth, Vasetthas, D.i.

original: Soke –
analyzed: soke
translated: In grief:

analyzed: kaham ekaputtaka kaham ekaputtaka sam ni
