original: Pasāde –
analyzed: pasāde
translated: In confidence:🔽Excellent, Master Gotama, excellent, Master Gotama, M.i.

original: Abhikkantaṃ bho gotama abhikkantaṃ bho gotama ma. ni. 2.106 iccādi. Tikkhattuṃudānaṃ udānesi “namo tassa bhagavato” ma. ni. 2.357 iccādi.🔽Iti padavākyadvittarāsi.
analyzed: abhikkantam bho gotama abhikkantam bho gotama ma ni iccādi tikkhattum udānam udānesi namaḥ tassa bhagavataḥ ma ni iccādi  iti pada vākya dvittarā asi
translated: So this is the collection of the three-factored groups of words and groups of sentences.

original: Dvibhāvasandhirāsi niṭṭhito.
analyzed: niṭṭhitaḥ
translated: The collection of the two- factored groups of words and groups of sentences is ended.

original: Vipallāsasandhi
analyzed: vipallāsa sandhi
translated: The Mode of Conveying an Inversion

original: Atha vipallāsasandhi dīpiyate.🔽Padakkharānaṃ pubbāparavipariyāyo vipallāso.
analyzed: atha vipallāsa sandhi dīpiyate  pada akkharānam pubba apara vipariyāyaḥ vipallāsaḥ
translated: Now the mode of conveying an inversion is revealed.🔽An inversion is the reversal of the order of the words.

original: 58. Hassa vipallāso.
analyzed: hassa vipallāsaḥ
translated: There is an inversion of laughter.

original: Yamhi pare hassa pubbāparavipallāso hoti vā.
analyzed: yamhi pare hassa pubba apara vipallāsaḥ hoti vā
translated: Where there is a reversal of the order of the words in the laughter of others,🔽and

original: Dayhati, saṅgayhati, sannayhati, vuyhati, duyhati, muyhati.
analyzed: dayhati saṅgayhati sannayhati vuyhati duyhati muyhati
translated: He burns, he is burnt, he is being burnt, he is being burnt up, he is being heated, he is being melted.

original: Vātveva? Saṅgaṇhiyati, evaṃ saṅgayha saṅgaṇhitvā, āruyha āruhitvā, ogāyha ogāhitvā. Pasayha pasahitvā.
analyzed: vātvā iva saṅgaṇhiyati evam saṅgayha saṅgaṇhitvā āruyha āruhitvā ogāyha ogāhitvā pasayha pasahitvā
translated: Wind, indeed? He is being gathered together, thus he is being gathered together, having gathered together, having ascended, having gone down, having overcome.

original: 59. Ve vā rū. 40 (piṭṭhe).
analyzed: ve vā rū piṭṭhe
translated: Ve, vā, rū, (on the back).

original: Vamhi pare hassa vipallāso hoti vā.
analyzed: vamhi pare hassa vipallāsaḥ hoti vā
translated: Vamhi, pare, hassa, vipallāso is vā.

original: Bavhābādho bahvābādho, bavhettha nhāyatī jano udā. 9 =bahvettha nhāyatī jano.
analyzed: bavhā ābādhaḥ bahu ābādhaḥ bavhā ittha nhāyatī jano udā bahu ettha nhāyatī jano
translated: Bavhābādho, bahvābādho, bavhettha nhāyatī jano udā. =bahvettha nhāyatī jano.

original: Mahāvuttividhānaṃ vuccate.
analyzed: mahāvutti vidhānam vuccate
translated: The Mahāvuttividhāna is said.

original: Ya, rānaṃ vipallāso –
analyzed: ya vipallāsaḥ
translated: Ya, rānaṃ vipallāso –

original: Kuṭi me kayirati pārā. 358, vacanaṃ payirudāhāsi, garuṃ payirūpāsati, vandāmi te ayyire pasannacitto jā. 2.17.54 -yassa dvittaṃ.
analyzed: me vacanam garum payirūpāsati vandāmi te pasanna cittaḥ jā yassa
translated: Kuṭi me kayirati pārā. , vacanaṃ payirudāhāsi, garuṃ payirūpāsati, vandāmi te ayyire pasannacitto jā. .. -yassa dvittaṃ.

original: Niggahītassa vipallāso –
analyzed: niggahītassa vipallāsaḥ
translated: Niggahītassa vipallāso –

original: Nirayamhi apaccisuṃ jā. 2.22.60, te me asse ayācisuṃ jā. 2.22.1863. Imā gāthā abhāsisuṃ.
analyzed: nirayamhi te me asse ayācisum jā imāḥ gāthāḥ abhāsisum
translated: Nirayamhi apaccisuṃ jā. .. , te me asse ayācisuṃ jā. ... Imā gāthā abhāsisuṃ.

original: Sarānampi vipallāso –
analyzed: vipallāsaḥ
translated: Sarānampi vipallāso –

original: Haññayyevāpi koci naṃ jā. 2.22.1193 – haññeyyāti ṭhiti, amūlamūlaṃ gantvā-mūlamūlaṃ
analyzed: haññayyā iva api koci nam amūla mūlam gantvā amūla mūlam
translated: Haññayyevāpi koci naṃ jā. .. – haññeyyāti ṭhiti, amūlamūlaṃ gantvā-mūlamūlaṃ

original: agantvāti attho. Evaṃ paratra. Anokāsaṃ kārāpetvā pārā 389, animittaṃ katvā, saddhaṃ
analyzed: a gantvā iti evam paratra anokāsam kārāpetvā pārā animittam katvā saddham
translated: the meaning is, without going. So too with the other. Having had a non-offence made, having made a non-sign, not eating with faith,

original: na bhuñjatīti asaddhabhoji, disvā padamanuttiṇṇaṃ jā. 1.1.20 – uttiṇṇaṃ adisvāti attho.
analyzed: na bhuñjati iti asaddha bhoji disvā padam anuttiṇṇam jā uttiṇṇam a disvā iti attho
translated: not eating with faith, the meaning is, without seeing a step that has not been crossed, having crossed, having seen.

original: Padānampi vipallāso –
analyzed: vipallāsaḥ
translated: There is a perversion of the steps too:

original: Navaṃ pana bhikkhunā cīvaralābhena, nāgakaññā caritaṃ gaṇena jā. 1.15.268 -nāgakaññāgaṇena caritanti ṭhiti.
analyzed: navam pana bhikkhunā cīvara lābhena nāga kaññā caritam gaṇena jā nāga kaññā gaṇena caritanti
translated: but when a bhikkhu gets a new robe, the meaning is, used by a troop of nāga-maidens, used by a troop of nāga-maidens.

original: Iti vipallāsarāsi.🔽60. Bahulaṃ caṃ. 1.1.130; pā. 3.3.113.
analyzed: iti  bahulam cam pā
translated: So this is a heap of perversions.🔽and also frequently …

original: Sandhividhānaṃ nāma bahulaṃ hoti, yebhuyyena hotīti attho. Adhikārasuttaṃ. Yāvaganthapariyosānā
analyzed: sandhi vidhānam nāma bahulam hoti yebhuyyena hoti iti attho adhikāra suttam yā avagantha pariyosānā
translated: the meaning is, there is a great deal of the making of a compound, there is a great many of the making of a compound. The Discourse on the Topic. Up to the end of the Summary

original: yuttaṭṭhānesu sabbattha vattate. Etena sabbasaddasuttesu aniṭṭhanivatti ca iṭṭhapariggaho ca kato hoti.
analyzed: yutta ṭṭhānesu sabbattha vattate etena sabba sadda suttesu aniṭṭha nivatti ca iṭṭha pariggaho ca kataḥ hoti
translated: it occurs everywhere in the appropriate places. By this means the non-ending of the Thread and the taking of the Thread as desired is done in all the Threads beginning with the word all.

original: Iti niruttidīpaniyā nāma moggallānadīpaniyaṃ
analyzed: iti niruttidīpaniyā nāma moggallānadīpaniyam
translated: So the Explanatory Verses called the Elucidation of the Grammar of Moggallana

original: Sandhikaṇḍo niṭṭhito.
analyzed: sandhi kaṇḍaḥ niṭṭhitaḥ
translated: The Section on Compounds is finished.

original: 2. Nāmakaṇḍa
analyzed: nāmakaṇḍa
translated: The Chapter on Names

original: Vibhattirāsi
analyzed: vibhattiḥ āsi
translated: The Heap of Declensions

original: Atha liṅgamhā syādivibhattividhānaṃ dīpiyate.
analyzed: atha sya ādi vibhatti vidhānam dīpiyate
translated: Now the making of the case-endings beginning with the nominative is elucidated from the gender.

original: Liṅgaṃ, nāmaṃ, pāṭipadikanti atthato ekaṃ, dabbābhidhānassa purisādikassa pakatirūpassetaṃ🔽nāmaṃ. Tañhi sattannaṃ vibhattīnaṃ vasena vibhāgaṃ patvā kiñci visadarūpaṃ hoti,
analyzed: liṅgam nāmam pāṭipadikanti atthataḥ ekam dabba abhidhānassa purisa ādikassa pakati rūpassa etam  nāmam tat hi vibhattīnam vasena vibhāgam kiñci hoti
translated: The sex, the name, and the declension are one in meaning. This is the natural materiality of a person, etc., which is called by the name “sign” .🔽For that becomes divided into three kinds of materiality, namely, clear, unclear, and middling, when it comes to the seven declensions.

original: kiñci avisadarūpaṃ, kiñci majjhimarūpanti evaṃ tividhena liṅgarūpena yuttattā liṅganti vuccati.🔽Tadeva kiñci saddaliṅgānurūpaṃ, kiñci atthaliṅgānurūpañca pariṇamantaṃ pavattati, tasmā nāmanti ca vuccati.
analyzed: evam tividhena liṅga rūpena yutta ttā liṅga nti vuccati  tat eva kiñci sadda liṅga anurūpam kiñci attha liṅga anurūpam ca pariṇamantam pavattati tasmā ca vuccati
translated: It is called “sign” because it is associated with the three kinds of materiality beginning with the sex.🔽That same materiality is called “name” because it occurs changing in conformity with the sex-sign and the meaning-sign.

original: Tadeva dhātu, paccaya, vibhattipadehi cevasaddapadatthakapadehi ca ‘visuṃ bhūtaṃ pada’nti katvā pāṭipadikanti ca vuccati.
analyzed: tat eva dhātu paccaya vibhatti padehi ca iva sadda padatthaka padehi ca visum bhūtam katvā pāṭipadikam ti ca vuccati
translated: That same materiality is called “declension” because it is a “different state” in the sense of a “different word” by means of the element, the preposition, the case-ending, and the word-endings.

original: Tattha dhātupadaṃ nāma brū, bhū, hūiccādi.🔽Paccayapadaṃ nāma ṇa, tabba, anīya iccādi.
analyzed: dhātu padam nāma brū bhū  paccaya padam nāma ṇa tabba anīyaḥ iti ādi
translated: Herein, the element-word is such as brū, bhū, hū, etc.;🔽the preposition-word is such as ṇa, tabba, anīya, etc.;

original: Vibhattipadaṃ nāma si, yo, aṃ, yo,ti, anti iccādi.
analyzed: vibhatti padam nāma si yaḥ aṃ ya o ti anti i c ādi
translated: the case-ending-word is such as si, yo, aṃ, yo, ti, anti, etc.;

original: Saddapadatthakapadāni nāma rājassa, sakhassa, pumassa iccādīni. Ettha ca rājassaiccādīni🔽saddasutte saddapadatthakāni honti, payoge atthapadatthakāni. Dhātupaccayavibhattipadāni
analyzed: sadda pada atthaka padāni nāma rājassa sakhassa pumassa icca ādīni ettha ca rājassa ecca ādīni  sadda sutte sadda pada atthakāni honti payoge attha pada atthakāni dhātu paccaya vibhatti padāni
translated: The words that are bases for the meaning of a word are such words as “king’s,” “friend’s,” “man’s.” Herein,

original: pana niccaṃ saddapadatthakāni eva honti, saddasuttesveva ca labbhanti, na payogeti,
analyzed: pana niccam sadda padatthakāni eva honti sadda suttesu eva ca labbhanti na payoge iti
translated: “king’s” and so on are bases for the meaning of a word in the sound-text, but in the application they are bases for the meaning of a sentence. But the bases for the meaning of a word in the sound-text are always bases for the meaning of a word in the sound-text only, and they are not found in the application.

original: idaṃ dvinnaṃ nānattaṃ.🔽Yadievaṃ bhussa, brussa, bhūto, hūto, ṇe, tabbe, simhi, timhi iccādinā tehi kathaṃ
analyzed: idam dvinnam nānattam  yadi evam bhussa brussa bhūtaḥ hūtaḥ ṇe tabbe simhi timhi icca ādinā tehi katham
translated: This is the difference between the two.

original: vibhattuppatti hotīti? Anukaraṇapadāni nāma tāni atthissa, karotissa iccādīni viya,
analyzed: hoti iti anukaraṇa padāni nāma tāni atthissa karotissa iccādīni viya
translated: But how is it that the endings are formed with those such as “bhussa,” “brussa,” “bhūto,” “hūto,” “ṇe,” “tabbe,” “simhi,” “timhi,” and so on? The words that are imitative words are such words as “atthissa,” “karotissa,” and so on,

original: tasmā tāni ca rājassa iccādīni ca anukaraṇaliṅgabhāvena ettha saṅgayhanti, na ekantaliṅgabhāvenāti.
analyzed: tasmā tāni ca rājassa iccādīni ca anukaraṇa liṅga bhāvena ettha saṅgayhanti na ekanta liṅga bhāvena ati
translated: and so they and the words “king’s” and so on are included here as having the nature of imitative words, not as having the nature of a single ending.

original: Evañca katvā ‘dhātu- paccaya, vibhattivajjitamatthavaṃ liṅga’nti avocuṃ. Tattha atthavanti
analyzed: evañca katvā dhātu paccaya vibhatti vajjitam atthavam liṅganti avocum tattha atthavanti
translated: And it was with this in mind that they said “The gender is the meaning apart from the bases for the meaning of a word and the endings” . Herein,

original: atthapadatthakaṃ vuccati, rājassaiccādikaṃ saddapadatthakaṃ vivajjeti, etena atthapadatthake
analyzed: attha padatthakam vuccati sadda padatthakam vivajjeti etena attha padatthake
translated: is called the meaning of the case-endings. The meaning of the word-endings beginning with the case-ending iccā is excluded.

original: sati taddhita, samāsa, kitakapadānampi ekantaliṅgabhāvaṃ sādhenti. Na hi tesaṃ liṅganāmabyapadesakiccaṃ
analyzed: eka anta liṅga bhāvam sādhenti na hi tesam liṅga nāma vyapadesa kiccam
translated: By this means, when there is the meaning of the case-endings, the affix taddhita, the compound, and the kit-word, all have a single gender. For they do not have the function of a name-declension.

original: atthi, yāni ca nāmassa visesanāni bhavituṃ arahanti, tāni upasagga, nipātapadāni
analyzed: atthi yāni ca nāmassa visesanāni bhavitum arahanti tāni upasagga nipāta padāni
translated: And those which are suitable to be the qualifiers of a noun, the prefix, the indeclinable word,

original: tvāntādipadāni ca idha visesananāmabhāvena saṅgayhantīti.🔽61. Dve dvekānekesu nāmasmā si yo aṃyo nā hi sa naṃ smāhi sanaṃsmiṃsu ka. 55; rū. 63; nī. 200.
analyzed: tva anta ādi padāni ca idha visesana nāma bhāvena saṅgayhanti iti  dve dvi ka anekesu nāma si yaḥ aṃyaḥ nā hi sa nam smā hi sa nam smin su
translated: and the word ending in tvā, etc., are included here as the qualifying noun.🔽. The two, the single, the dual, and the plural, from a noun, are si, yo, …pe… smiṃ, su, the case-endings.

original: Ekasmiṃ atthe ca anekesu atthesu ca pavattā nāmasmā dve dve si, yo…pe… smiṃ, suvibhattiyo honti.
analyzed: ekasmin atthe ca anekesu atthesu ca pavattā nāmasmā dve dve si ya upe smim su vibhattiyaḥ honti
translated: And the case-endings which occur in the sense of the single and in the sense of the many, from a noun, are two, two, si, yo, …pe… smiṃ, su, the case-endings.

original: Vibhajantīti vibhattiyo, ekamekaṃ pakatināmapadaṃ nānārūpavibhāgavasena kattu, kammādinānāatthavibhāgavasena
analyzed: vibhajanti iti vibhattiyaḥ ekam ekam nānā rūpa vibhāga vasena kattu kamma ādi nānā attha vibhāga vasena
translated: They are case-endings because they divide. They are made by the single ordinary-declensional noun by way of the division of the various forms, and by way of the division of the various meanings such as the action, etc.

original: ekatta, bahuttasaṅkhyāvibhāgavasena ca vibhajantīti attho. Si, lo iti paṭhamā nāma…pe…
analyzed: eka tta bahu tta saṅkhyā vibhāga vasena ca vibhajanti iti iti paṭhamā nāma pe
translated: The first case is called the nominative, etc.

original: smiṃ, su iti sattamī nāma. Dvīsu dvīsu pubbaṃ pubbaṃ ‘ekasmiṃ atthe pavattaṃ vacana’nti
analyzed: smim su iti sattamī nāma dvīsu dvīsu pubbam pubbam ekasmin atthe pavattam vacananti
translated: The seventh case is called the locative. In the two, the first is called the singular,

original: ekavacanaṃ nāma. Paraṃ paraṃ ‘anekesu atthesu pavattaṃ vacana’nti anekavacanaṃ nāma.
analyzed: ekavacanam nāma param param anekesu atthesu pavattam vacanan ti anekavacanam nāma
translated: in the sense of ‘a statement occurring in one meaning.’ The second is called the plural, in the sense of ‘a statement occurring in many meanings.’

original: Bahuvacananti ca puthuvacananti ca etassa nāmaṃ. Sabbamidaṃ iminā suttena siddhaṃ.
analyzed: bahuvacanan ti ca puthuvacanan ti ca etassa nāmam sabbam idam iminā suttena siddham
translated: The meaning is ‘many words.’ All this is established by this sutta.

original: 62. Paṭhamātthamatte ka. 284; rū. 65; nī. 577; caṃ. 2.1.93; pā. 2.3.46.
analyzed: paṭhama a t t ha ma t te ka rū nī cam pā
translated: In the first meaning, ka. ; rū. ; nī. ; caṃ. ..; pā. ...

original: Kattu, kammādikaṃ bāhiratthaṃ anapekkhitvā liṅgatthamatte pavattā nāmasmā paṭhamāvibhatti hoti.
analyzed: kattu kamma ādikam bāhira attham an apekkhitvā liṅga attha matte pavattā nāmasma paṭhamā vibhatti hoti
translated: The first case is that which occurs in the meaning of the gender, disregarding the external meaning such as the doing, the action, etc.

original: Ayaṃ mama puriso, ime mama purisā.
analyzed: ayam mama purisaḥ ime mama purisāḥ
translated: This is my man, these are my men.

analyzed: āmantane ka rū nī caṃ pā
translated: . In addressing, ka. ; rū. ; nī. ; caṃ. ..; pā. ...

original: Āmantanaṃ vuccati ālapanaṃ. Āmantanavisaye liṅgatthamatte pavattā nāmasmā paṭhamāvibhatti hoti.
analyzed: āmantanam vuccati ālapanam āmantana visaye liṅga attha matte pavattā nāmasma paṭhamā vibhatti hoti
translated: Addressing is said to be speaking to. The first case is that which occurs in the meaning of the gender in the sphere of addressing.

original: Bho purisa, bhonto purisā.
analyzed: bho purisa bhonto purisā
translated: O man, sirs, men.

analyzed: kamme dutiyā ka rū   nī cam pā

original: Nāmasmā kammatthe dutiyāvibhatti hoti.
analyzed: nāmasmā kammatthe dutiyā vibhatti hoti
translated: 64. In the sense of instrument, the second case is used.

original: Purisaṃ passati, purise passanti.🔽65. Kattukaraṇesu tatiyā ka. 286, 288; rū. 83; nī. 591, 594; caṃ. 2.1.62, 63; pā. 2.3.18.
analyzed: purisam passati purise passanti  kattu karaṇesu tatiyā ka   rū nī   cam   pā
translated: He sees a man, they see men.

original: Nāmasmā kattari ca karaṇe ca tatiyāvibhatti hoti.
analyzed: nāmasmā kattari ca karaṇe ca tatiyā vibhatti hoti
translated: . In the sense of agent and instrument, the third case is used.

original: Purisena kataṃ, purisehi kataṃ, purisena kulaṃ sobhati, purisehi kulaṃ sobhati.
analyzed: purisena katam purisehi katam purisena kulam sobhati purisehi kulam sobhati
translated: Done by a man, done by men; a family is adorned by a man, a family is adorned by men.

original: 66. Catutthī sampadāne ka. 293; rū 85, 301; nī. 605; caṃ. 2.1.73; pā. 2.3.13.🔽Nāmasmā sampadānatthe catutthīvibhatti hoti.
analyzed: catutthī sampadāne ka rū  nī caṃ pā  nāmasmā sampadāna atthe catutthī vibhatti hoti
translated: . In the sense of distribution, the fourth case is used.

original: Purisassa deti, purisānaṃ deti.🔽67. Pañcamyāvadhismiṃ ka. 295; rū. 89, 307; nī. 607 caṃ. 2.1.81; pā. 2.3.28; 1.4.24 pañcamyavadhismā (bahūsu).
analyzed: purisassa deti purisānam deti  pañcamyā avadhi smin ka rū   nī cam pā   pañcamī avadhi smā bahūsu
translated: He gives to a man, he gives to men.

original: Avadhi vuccati apādānaṃ. Nāmasmā avadhiatthe pañcamīvibhatti hoti.
analyzed: avadhi vuccati apādānam nāmasmai avadhi atthe pañcamī vibhatti hoti
translated: . In the sense of limit, the fifth case is used.

original: Purisasmā apeti, purisehi apeti.
analyzed: purisasmai apeti purisehi apeti
translated: He takes away from a man, he takes away from men.🔽The word “limit” means “without exception.”

original: 68. Chaṭṭhī sambandhe ka. 30; rū. 92, 315; nī. 609; caṃ. 2.1.95; pā. 2.3.50.
analyzed: chaṭṭhī sambandhe ka rū nī caṃ pā
translated: 68. The sixth case is used for connection.

original: Nāmasmā sambandhatthe chaṭṭhīvibhatti hoti.
analyzed: nāmasmā sambandha tthe chaṭṭhī vibhatti hoti
translated: The sixth case is used after a noun to show connection.

original: Purisassa dhanaṃ, purisānaṃ dhanaṃ.
analyzed: purisassa dhanam purisānam dhanam
translated: The wealth of a man, the wealth of men.🔽. The seventh case is used for support.

original: 69. Sattamyādhāre ka. 312; rū. 94, 319; nī. 630; caṃ. 2.1.88; pā. 2.3.36; 1.3.45.🔽Nāmasmā ādhāratthe sattamīvibhatti hoti.
analyzed: sattamī ādhāre ka rū        nāmasmai ādhāra atthe sattamī vibhatti hoti
translated: The seventh case is used after a noun to show support.

original: Purisasmiṃ tiṭṭhati, purisesu tiṭṭhati.
analyzed: purisasmin tiṭṭhati purisesu tiṭṭhati
translated: He stands in a man, he stands in men.

original: Vibhattirāsi niṭṭhito.
analyzed: vibhattiḥ āsi niṭṭhitaḥ
translated: The heap of case endings is finished.

original: Itthipaccayarāsi
analyzed: itthi paccaya rāsi
translated: The heap of feminine endings🔽. The feminine ending is used for a feminine noun.🔽The feminine ending is used for a feminine noun.🔽The feminine ending is used for a feminine noun.

original: 70. Itthiyamatvā ka. 237; rū. 176; nī. 466; caṃ. 2.3.15; pā. 4.1.4.
analyzed: itthiyama tvā ka rū nī cam pā
translated: The feminine ending is used for a feminine noun.🔽The feminine ending is used for a feminine noun.

original: Itthiyaṃ+ato+āti chedo. Akārantanāmamhā itthiyaṃ āpaccayo hoti.🔽Abhāsitapumehi kehici saññāsaddehi niccaṃ –
analyzed: itthiyam atas ā ti chedaḥ akāra anta nāmamhā itthiyam ā paccayaḥ hoti  a bhāsita pumehi kehici saññā saddehi niccam
translated: The feminine ending is used for a feminine noun.🔽The feminine ending is used for a feminine noun.🔽The feminine ending is used for a feminine noun.🔽The feminine ending is used for a feminine noun.🔽The feminine ending is used for a feminine noun.🔽The feminine ending is used for a feminine noun.🔽The feminine ending is used for a feminine noun.🔽The feminine ending is used for a feminine noun.🔽The feminine ending is used for a feminine noun.🔽The feminine ending is used for a feminine noun.🔽The feminine ending is used for a feminine noun.🔽The feminine ending is used for a feminine noun.🔽The feminine ending is used for a feminine noun.🔽The feminine ending is used for a feminine noun.🔽The feminine ending is used for a feminine noun.🔽The feminine ending is used for a feminine noun.🔽The feminine ending is used for a feminine noun.🔽The feminine ending is used for a feminine noun.🔽The feminine ending is used for a feminine noun.🔽The feminine ending is used for a feminine noun.🔽The feminine ending is used for a feminine noun.🔽The feminine ending is used for a feminine noun.🔽The feminine ending is used for a feminine noun.🔽The feminine ending is used for a feminine noun.🔽The feminine ending is used for a feminine noun.🔽The feminine ending is used for a feminine noun.🔽The feminine ending is used for a feminine noun.🔽The feminine ending is used for a feminine noun.🔽The feminine ending is used for a feminine noun.🔽The feminine ending is used for a feminine noun.🔽The feminine ending is used for a feminine noun.

original: Kaññā, paññā, saññā, nāvā, sālā, taṇhā, icchā, bhikkhā, sikkhā, gīvā, jivhā, vīsā, tiṃsā, cattālīsā, paññāsā iccādi.
analyzed: kaññā paññā saññā nāvā sālā taṇhā icchā bhikkhā sikkhā gīvā jivhā vīsā tiṃsā cattālīsā paññāsā iccādi
translated: The feminine ending is used for a feminine noun.🔽The feminine ending is used for a feminine noun.

original: Bhāsitapumehipi sabbanāmehi tabbā, nīya, tapaccayantehi ca niccaṃ –
analyzed: bhāsita pumehi pi sabbanāmehi tabbāḥ nīya ta paccaya ntehi ca niccam
translated: The feminine ending is used

original: Sabbā, katarā, katamā, anubhavitabbā, anubhavanīyā, gatā, jātā, bhūtā, hūtā iccādi.
analyzed: sabbā katarā katamā anubhavitabbā anubhavanīyā gatā jātā bhūtā hūtā iccādi
translated: All, which, which one, which ones, which is to be experienced, which is to be felt, gone, born, become, made, and so on.

original: Aññehi pana aniccaṃ –
analyzed: aññehi pana aniccam
translated: But with others, impermanent:

original: Kalyāṇā, kalyāṇī, sundarā, sundarī, sobhaṇā, sobhaṇī, kumbhakārā, kumbhakārī, kumbhakārinī,
analyzed: kalyāṇā kalyāṇī sundarā sundarī sobhaṇā sobhaṇī kumbhakārā kumbhakārī kumbhakārinī
translated: Good, good, beautiful, beautiful, lovely, lovely, potter, potter, potteress,

original: atthakāmā, atthakāmī, atthakāminī, paribbājikā, paribbājikinī, ekākā, ekākinī, dīpanā, dīpanī iccādi.
analyzed: attha kāmā attha kāmī attha kāminī paribbājikā paribbājikinī ekākā ekākinī dīpanā dīpanī iccādi
translated: well-wishing, well-wishing, well-wishing, female wanderer, female wanderer, alone, alone, illuminating, illuminating, and so on.

original: Suttavibhattena samāse mātu, dhītu iccādīhi āpaccayo hoti. Nandamātā, uttaramātā, devadhītā, rājadhītā, assamaṇī hoti asakyadhītarā iccādi.
analyzed: sutta vibhattena samāse mātu dhītu iccādīhi ā paccayaḥ hoti nanda mātā uttara mātā deva dhītā rāja dhītā assamaṇī hoti asakya dhītarā iccādi
translated: In a compound with the locative case ending, the feminine form is formed with the suffix -ī after mātu, dhītu, and so on. Nandamātā, Uttaramātā, devadhītā, rājadhītā, assamaṇī is the daughter of the Sakyan, and so on.

original: Ettha ca ‘itthiya’nti katthaci saddamattassa vā, katthaci atthamattassa vā itthibhāve
analyzed: ettha ca itthiyanti katthaci sadda mattassa vā katthaci attha mattassa vā itthi bhāve
translated: And here, in some cases, the mere sound, in some cases, the mere meaning of the feminine is to be understood.

original: jotetabbeti attho. Evañca sati itthipaccayāpi syādayo viya jotakamattā eva honti,
analyzed: jotetabbā iti atthaḥ evañca sati itthi paccayā api syā ādayaḥ viya jotaka mattāḥ eva honti
translated: This is the meaning. And in that case, the suffixes such as -ī, like the suffixes such as -ā, are mere indicators,

original: na vācakāti siddhaṃ hoti.
analyzed: na siddham ha iti
translated: not denotative.

original: 71. Nadādīhi ṅī ka. 238; rū. 187; nī. 467; nadādito vī (bahūsu).
analyzed: nada ādīhi ṅī ka rū nī nada ādeḥ vī bahūsu
translated: With nadā and so on, ṅī ka; with rū, nī; with nadā and so on, vī (in many).

original: Nadādīhi itthiyaṃ ṅī hoti. Ṅānubandho ‘ntantūnaṃ ṅīmhi to vā’ti ettha visesanattho.
analyzed: nad ādīhi itthiyam ṅī hoti ṅānubandhaḥ n t ntūnam ṅīmhi taḥ vā ti ettha visesana tthaḥ
translated: The feminine of nadī, etc., is formed by adding ṅī. The word ṅānubandha in the following rule is a specification.

original: Nadī, mahī, itthī, kumārī, taruṇī, vāseṭṭhī, gotamī, kaccānī, kaccāyanī, māṇavī,
analyzed: nadī mahī itthī kumārī taruṇī vāseṭṭhī gotamī kaccānī kaccāyanī māṇavī
translated: Nadī, mahī, itthī, kumārī, taruṇī, vāseṭṭhī, gotamī, kaccānī, kaccāyanī, māṇavī,

original: sāmaṇerī, nāvikī, pañcamī, chaṭṭhī, catuddasī, pañcadasī, sahassī, dasasahassī, satasahassī,
analyzed: sāmaṇerī nāvikī pañcamī chaṭṭhī catuddasī pañcadasī sahassī dasa sahassī sata sahassī
translated: sāmaṇerī, nāvikī, pañcamī, chaṭṭhī, catuddasī, pañcadasī, sahassī, dasasahassī, satasahassī,

original: kumbhakārī, mālakārī, cakkhukaraṇī, ñāṇakaraṇī, dhammadīpanī iccādi.🔽72. Ntantūnaṃ ṅīmhi to vā ka. 239, 241; rū. 190, 191; nī. 468, 471.
analyzed: kumbhakārī mālakārī cakkhukaraṇī ñāṇakaraṇī dhammadīpanī iccādi  n t n tūnam ṅīp hi taḥ vā ka   rū    nī
translated: kumbhakārī, mālakārī, cakkhukaraṇī, ñāṇakaraṇī, dhammadīpanī, and so on.🔽The feminine of nta and ntūna is formed by adding ṅī or to.

original: Nta, ntūnaṃ to hoti vā ṅīmhi pare.
analyzed: nta n tūnam taḥ hoti vā ṅīmhi pare
translated: The feminine of nta and ntūna is formed by adding to or ṅī.

original: Gacchatī, gacchantī, satī, santī, bhavissatī, bhavissantī, guṇavatī, guṇavantī, satimatī,
analyzed: gacchatī gacchantī satī santī bhavissatī bhavissantī guṇavatī guṇavantī satimatī
translated: Gacchatī, gacchantī, satī, santī, bhavissatī, bhavissantī, guṇavatī, guṇavantī, satimatī,

original: satimantī, sabbāvatī, sabbāvantī, yāvatī, yāvantī, tāvatī, tāvantī, bhuttavatī, bhuttavantī.🔽73. Goto vā ka. 238; rū. 187; nī. 467.
analyzed: satimantī sabbāvatī sabbāvantī yāvatī yāvantī tāvatī tāvantī bhuttavatī bhuttavantī  gotaḥ vā ka rū nī
translated: satimantī, sabbāvatī, sabbāvantī, yāvatī, yāvantī, tāvatī, tāvantī, bhuttavatī, bhuttavantī.🔽The feminine of nta and ntūna is formed by adding to or ṅī.

original: Gosaddamhā itthiyaṃ vī hoti vā.
analyzed: gosaddamhā itthiyam vī hoti vā
translated: The feminine of gosaddha is formed by adding vī or ṅī.

original: Gāvī.
analyzed: gāvī
translated: Cow.

original: Vāti kiṃ? Gokāṇā pariyantacārinīti pāḷi. Tattha kāṇāti andhā.🔽74. Yakkhādīhinī ca ka. 238, 240; rū. 287, 193; nī. 467, 469; yakkhāditvinī ca (bahūsu).
analyzed: vāti kim go kāṇā pariyanta cārinī iti andhā  yakkha ādīhinī ca ka   rū   nī   yakkha āditvinī ca bahūsu
translated: What is it? The text has “wandering about the edge of a cow-pen.” Herein, kāṇā = blind.

original: Yakkhādīhi akārantehi itthiyaṃ vī ca hoti inī ca.
analyzed: yakkha ādīhi akāra antehi itthiyam vī ca hoti inī ca
translated: Yakkhādīhinī ca ka, rū, nī, yakkhādīhi akārantehi itthiyaṃ vī ca hoti inī ca.

original: Yakkhī, yakkhinī, nāgī, nāginī, mahiṃsī, mahiṃsinī, migī, miginī, sīhī, sīhinī, dīpī, dīpinī, byagghī, byagghinī, kākī, kākinī, kapotī, kapotinī, mānusī, mānusinī iccādi.
analyzed: yakkhī yakkhinī nāgī nāginī mahiṃsī mahiṃsinī migī miginī sīhī sīhinī dīpī dīpinī byagghī byagghinī kākī kākinī kapotī kapotinī mānusī mānusinī iccādi
translated: Yakkhī, yakkhinī, nāgī, nāginī, mahiṃsī, mahiṃsinī, migī, miginī, sīhī, sīhinī, dīpī, dīpinī, byagghī, byagghinī, kākī, kākinī, kapotī, kapotinī, mānusī, mānusinī, and so on.

original: 75. Ārāmikādīhi ka. 240; rū. 193; nī. 469.
analyzed: ārāmika ādīhi ka rū nī
translated: Ārāmikādīhi ka, rū, nī.

original: Ārāmikādīhi akārantehi itthiyaṃ inī hoti.
analyzed: ārāmika ādīhi akāra antehi itthiyam inī hoti
translated: Ārāmikādīhi akārantehi itthiyaṃ inī hoti.

original: Ārāmikinī, antarāyikinī, nāvikinī, olumbikinī, paṃsukūlikinī, paribbājikinī, rājinī, ekākinī iccādi.
analyzed: ārāmikinī antarāyikinī nāvikinī olumbikinī paṃsukūlikinī paribbājikinī rājinī ekākinī iccādi
translated: Ārāmikinī, antarāyikinī, nāvikinī, olumbikinī, paṃsukūlikinī, paribbājikinī, rājinī, ekākinī, and so on.

original: Saññāyaṃ –
analyzed: saññāyam
translated: In saññā—

original: Mānusinī mānusā vā, aññatra mānusī sampatti.🔽76. Gharaṇyādayo ka. 240; rū. 193; nī. 469.
analyzed: mānusinī mānusā vai aññatra mānusī sampatti  gharaṇī ādayaḥ ka rū nī
translated: Mānusinī mānusā vā, aññatra mānusī sampatti.🔽Gharaṇyādayo ka, rū, nī.

original: Gharaṇīiccādayo itthiyaṃ nīpaccayantā sijjhanti.
analyzed: gharaṇī icca ādayaḥ itthiyam nī pacca yantā sijjhanti
translated: Gharaṇī, and so on, are formed with itthiyaṃ nīpaccayantā sijjhanti.

original: Gharaṇī, vetraṇī, pokkharaṇī-esu nassa ṇattaṃ. Ācarinīyalopo, ācariyā vā.🔽77. Mātulāditvānī bhariyāyaṃ ka. 98; rū. 189; nī. 261.
analyzed: gharaṇī vetraṇī pokkharaṇīesu nassa ācarinīya lopaḥ ācariyā vā  mātula ādi tvānī bhariyāyam ka rū nī
translated: In the words gharani, vetrani, pokkharani, the -n- is lost. The -i- is lost in the word acarinīya, or the -i- is lost in the word ācariya.

original: Mātulādīhi akārantehi bhariyāyaṃ ānī hoti.
analyzed: mātula ādīhi a kāra antehi hoti
translated: The feminine of words ending in -ula, etc., is formed by adding -ani.🔽The feminine of words ending in -ula, etc., is formed by adding -ani to the stem.

original: Mātubhātā mātulo, tassa bhariyā mātulānī, evaṃ varuṇānī, gahapatānī, ācariyānī, khattiyānī.
analyzed: mātu bhātā mātulaḥ tassa bhariyā mātulānī evam varuṇānī gahapatānī ācariyānī khattiyānī
translated: The feminine of mātula is mātulānī, the feminine of varuṇa is varuṇānī, the feminine of gahapati is gahapatānī, the feminine of ācariya is ācariyānī, the feminine of khattiya is khattiyānī.

original: ‘Bahulā’dhikārā khattiyī khattiyā ca.🔽78. Yuvaṇṇehi nī.
analyzed: bahula adhikārā khattiyī khattiyā ca  yuvaṇṇehi nī
translated: The feminine of khattiya is khattiyā, because the word bahulā is the basis for the feminine.🔽The feminine of words ending in -uṇṇa is formed by adding -inī.

original: Ivaṇṇantehi uvaṇṇantehi ca itthiyaṃ nī hoti.
analyzed: i vaṇṇa antehi u vaṇṇa antehi ca itthiyam nī hoti
translated: The feminine of words ending in -uṇṇa is formed by adding -inī.

original: Chattapāṇinī, daṇḍapāṇinī, daṇḍinī, chattinī, hatthinī, mālinī, māyāvinī, medhāvinī,
analyzed: chatta pāṇinī daṇḍa pāṇinī daṇḍinī chattinī hatthinī mālinī māyāvinī medhāvinī
translated: The feminine of chattapāṇi is chattapāṇinī, the feminine of daṇḍapāṇi is daṇḍapāṇinī, the feminine of daṇḍi is daṇḍinī, the feminine of chatti is chattinī, the feminine of hatthi is hatthinī, the feminine of māla is mālinī, the feminine of māyāvin is māyāvinī, the feminine of medhāvin is medhāvinī,

original: piyapasaṃsinī, brahmacārinī, bhayadassāvinī, atthakāminī, hitacārinī, bhikkhunī,🔽khattiyabandhunī, paṭunī, paracittavidunī, mattaññunī, atthaññunī, dhammaññunī iccādi.
analyzed: piya pasaṃsinī brahmacārinī bhaya dassāvinī attha kāminī hita cārinī bhikkhunī  khattiya bandhunī paṭunī para citta vidunī mattaññunī atthaññunī dhammaññunī iccādi
translated: the feminine of piyapasaṃsin is piyapasaṃsinī, the feminine of brahmacārin is brahmacārinī, the feminine of bhayadassāvin is bhayadassāvinī, the feminine of atthakāmin is atthakāminī, the feminine of hitacārin is hitacārinī, the feminine of bhikkhu is bhikkhunī,

original: 79. Timhāññatthe ktimhāññatthe (bahūsu), moggallāne 31 suttaṅke.
analyzed: timhāññatthe ktimhāññatthe bahūsu moggallāne suttaṅke
translated: the feminine of khattiya-bandhu is khattiyabandhunī, the feminine of paṭu is paṭunī, the feminine of paracittavidu is paracittavidunī, the feminine of mattaññu is mattaññunī, the feminine of atthaññu is atthaññunī, the feminine of dhammaññu is dhammaññunī

original: Aññapadatthasamāse tipaccayantamhā itthiyaṃ nī hoti.
analyzed: añña padattha samāse ti paccaya antamhā itthiyam nī hoti
translated: In a compound with a preposition, the feminine of a word ending in -nī becomes -nī.

original: Ahiṃsāratinī, dhammaratinī, vacchagiddhinī, puttagiddhinī, muṭṭhassatinī, micchādiṭṭhinī, sammādiṭṭhinī, attaguttinī iccādi.
analyzed: ahiṃsā ratinī dhamma ratinī vaccha giddhinī putta giddhinī muṭṭhassatinī micchādiṭṭhinī sammādiṭṭhinī atta guttinī iccādi
translated: Ahiṃsāratinī, dhammaratinī, vacchagiddhinī, puttagiddhinī, muṭṭhassatinī, micchādiṭṭhinī, sammādiṭṭhinī, attaguttinī.

original: Aññattheti kiṃ? Dhamme rati dhammarati.
analyzed: aññattha iti kim dhamme rati dhamma rati
translated: What is meant by “in the sense of another”? Dhamme rati = dhammarati.

original: 80. Yuvāti.
analyzed: yuvāti
translated: Yuvāti.

original: Yuvato itthiyanti hoti.
analyzed: yuvataḥ itthiyanti hoti
translated: Yuvato itthiyanti hoti.

original: Yuvati.
analyzed: yuvati
translated: Yuvati.

original: Ettha ca ‘ti’ iti suttavibhattena vīsa, tiṃsatopiti hoti vā. Vīsati, vīsaṃ, tiṃsati, tiṃsaṃ.
analyzed: ettha ca ti iti sutta vibhattena hoti vā vīsati vīsam tiṃsati tiṃsam
translated: And here the twenty is vīsa, the thirty is tiṃsa, with the locative case ending -i, or tiṃsa, tiṃsaṃ.

original: 81. Upamā saṃhita sahita saññata saha sapha vāmalakkhaṇāditūrutvū caṃ. 2.3.79; pā. 4.1.69, 70 tūrutū (bahūsu).
analyzed: upamā saṃhita sahita saññata saha sapha vāma lakkhaṇa ādi tūru tvū cam pā    tūru tū bahūsu
translated: Upamā, saṃhita, sahitā, saññatā, saha, sapa, vāma, lakkhaṇā, etc., are words ending in -ū.

original: Lakkhaṇādito+ūruto+ūti chedo.
analyzed: chedaḥ
translated: The break is after the first syllable.

original: Aññapadatthasamāse upamādipubbā ūrusaddamhā itthiyaṃ ū hoti.
analyzed: añña padattha samāse upamā ādi pubbā ūru sadda mhā itthiyam ū hoti
translated: In a compound with a preposition, the feminine of a word ending in -ū becomes -ū.

original: Nāgassa nāsā viya ūrū yassāti nāganāsūrū, saṃhitā sambandhā ūrū yassāti saṃhitorū,
analyzed: nāgassa nāsā viyas ūrū yassa ati nāga nāsūrū saṃhitā sambandhā ūrū yassa ati saṃhita ūrū
translated: Nāgassa nāsā viya ūrū yassāti nāganāsūrū, saṃhitā sambandhā ūrū yassāti saṃhitorū,

original: sahitā ekabaddhā ūrū yassāti sahitorū, saññatā alolā ūrū yassāti saññatorū, ūruyā
analyzed: sahitāḥ eka baddhāḥ ūrū yassa ati sahita ūrū saññatāḥ alolāḥ ūrū yassa ati saññata ūrū ūruyā
translated: He who has thighs that are joined together, that is, are not separated, is sahitoru. He who has thighs that are well-controlled, that is, not unsteady, is saññatoru.🔽With what? With thighs.

original: ūrunā? saha vattatīti sahorū, sapho vuccati khuro, saṃsiliṭṭhatāya saphabhūtā ūrū
analyzed: ūrunā saha vattati iti saha ūrū saphaḥ vuccati khuraḥ saṃsiliṭṭha tāya sapha bhūtau ūrū
translated: He who has thighs that are together, that is, joined, is sahoru. The hoof is called a ‘pho’. The thighs of one who has thighs that are like a hoof, that is, are joined together, are sapho.

original: yassāti saphorū, vāmā sundarā ūrū yassāti vāmorū, lakkhaṇasampannā ūrū yassāti lakkhaṇorū.
analyzed: yassa ati sapha ūrū vāmā sundarā ūrū yassa ati vāma ūrū lakkhaṇa sampannā ūrū yassa ati lakkhaṇa ūrū
translated: He who has beautiful thighs is vāmoru. He who has thighs that are endowed with the characteristics is lakkhaṇorū.

original: Suttavibhattena brahmabandhūti sijjhati.
analyzed: sutta vibhattena brahmabandhū ti sijjhati
translated: The word brahmabandhu is established by the method of analysis.

original: “Sace maṃ nāganāsūrū, olokeyya pabhāvatī”ti jā. 2.20.14 ca “ekā tuvaṃ tiṭṭhasi sahitūrū”ti🔽jā. 1.16.297 ca “saññatūrū mahāmāyā, kumāri cārudassanā”ti jā. 2.17.109 ca “vāmorū
analyzed: sace mam nāga nāsūrū olokeyya pabhāvatī iti jā ca ekā tuvam tiṭṭhasi  ca mahāmāyā kumāri cārudassanāti jā ca vāmorū
translated: “If Pabhāvatī were to look at me with her eyes that are like the eyes of a young nāga” (Jā i 100), and “You stand alone with your thighs that are joined together” (Jā i 100),

original: saja maṃ bhadde”ti dī. ni. 2.348 ca “kāraṇaṃ nappajānāmi, sammatto lakkhaṇūruyā”ti
analyzed: saja mama bhadda iti ca kāraṇam na ppajānāmi sammattaḥ lakkhaṇūruyā ti
translated: and “The well-controlled thighs of the beautiful Mahāmāyā” (Jā i 100), and “Embraced me, O good lady, with your beautiful thighs” (Dī 1.1), and “I do not understand the reason why you are fond of my thighs that are endowed with the characteristics” (Dī 1.1),

original: dī. ni. 2.348 ca “gārayhassaṃ brahmabandhuyā”ti jā. 2.22.2109 ca pāḷipadāni dissanti.
analyzed: ca brahmabandhuyāti ca pāḷi padāni dissanti
translated: and “I would be reproached by the brahmin who is endowed with the characteristics” (Jā i 100), these lines are found.

original: Tattha ‘sajā’ti āliṅgāhi, ‘gārayhassa’nti ahaṃ gārayho bhaveyyaṃ.
analyzed: tattha sajāti āliṅgāhi gārayhassanti aham gārayhaḥ bhaveyyaṃ
translated: Herein, ‘sajā’ means ‘embrace me’. ‘Gārayhassa’ means ‘I would be reproached’.

original: Ettha ca tāpaccayantā sabhāvaitthiliṅgā eva – lahutā, mudutā, gāmatā, janatā, devatā iccādi.
analyzed: ettha ca sabhā vaitthiliṅgāḥ eva lahutā mudutā gāmatā janatā devatā iccādi
translated: And here the feminine nouns ending in -ā are: lightness, softness, strength, people, gods, etc.

original: Tathā tipaccayantā – gati, mati, ratti, sati, tuṭṭhi, diṭṭhi, iddhi, siddhi iccādi,
analyzed: tathā ti paccaya ntā gati mati ratti sati tuṭṭhi diṭṭhi iddhi siddhi iccādi
translated: Similarly, those ending in -ī are: going, knowledge, night, mindfulness, satisfaction, view, success, etc.

original: tathā yāgu, dhātu, dhenu, kaṇḍu, kacchu, mātu, dhītu, duhitu iccādi, jambū, vadhū,
analyzed: tathā yāgu dhātu dhenu kaṇḍu kacchu mātu dhītu duhitu iccādi jambū vadhū
translated: Similarly, those ending in -ā are: gruel, element, cow, itch, itch-covering, mother, mother’s sister, daughter, etc.

original: camū, sutanū, sarabū iccādi ca. Sakkataganthesu pana sutanū, sarabū iccādīsupi ūpaccayaṃ vidahanti.
analyzed: camū sutanū sarabū iccādi ca sakkata ganthesu pana sutanū sarabū iccādīsupi ū paccayam vidahanti
translated: Similarly, those ending in -ū are: rose-apple, bride, army, good-natured, Sarabhū, etc. But in the Sakkarāgāthā the words good-natured and Sarabhū are analysed with the feminine ending -ā.

original: Tattha itthiliṅgabhūtā sabbe ‘ivaṇṇuvaṇṇā pitthiya’nti suttena niccaṃ pasaññā honti. ‘Ākāro ca ghā’ti suttena niccaṃ ghasañño.
analyzed: tattha sabbe sabbe pitthiyanti suttena niccam pasaññāḥ honti ākāro ca gha ati suttena niccam
translated: Herein, all feminine nouns ending in -ā are always known as ‘having a back vowel’ by the rule ‘The back vowels are ā, i, u, and the vowel of pitthi’ . They are always known as ‘having the sound of ga’ by the rule ‘The sound of ga is ā, ī, ṝ, ḷī, ū, ỿ, ai, o, au’ .

original: Itthipaccayarāsi niṭṭhito.
analyzed: itthi paccaya rāsi niṭṭhito
translated: The collection of feminine nouns ending in -ā is completed.

original: Ākārantitthiliṅgarāsi
analyzed: ākārantitthi liṅgarāsi
translated: The collection of feminine nouns ending in -ī

original: Itthiliṅgaṃ chabbidhaṃ ākārantaṃ, ikārantaṃ, īkārantaṃ, ukārantaṃ, ūkārantaṃ, okārantaṃ. Tattha kaññāsaddamhā atthamatte paṭhamā.
analyzed: itthi liṅgam chabbidham ākāra antam ikāra antam īkāra antam ukāra antam ūkāra antam okāra antam tattha attha matte paṭhamā
translated: Feminine nouns ending in -ī are of six kinds, namely, those ending in -āka, -ikā, -īka, -ūkā, -ūka, and -okā. Herein, the first is that consisting of the word kaññā in the sense of ‘a girl’:

original: 82. Gasīnaṃ ka. 220; rū. 74; nī. 447.
analyzed: gasīnam ka rū nī
translated: 82. The G-group.

original: Kenaci suttena aladdhavidhīnaṃ gasīnaṃ lopo hotīti silopo.
analyzed: kenacid suttena a laddha vidhīnam gasīnam lopaḥ hoti iti si lopaḥ
translated: The loss of the G-group, which has not obtained a rule by any Sutta, is a loss of a syllable.

original: Kaññā tiṭṭhati.🔽83. Jantuhetvīghapehi vā ka. 118; rū. 146; nī. 293.🔽Jantu, hetūhi ca punnapuṃsakesu īkārantehi ca ghato ca pasaññehi ivaṇṇuvaṇṇehi ca yonaṃ lopo hoti vā.🔽Kaññā tiṭṭhanti, kaññāyo tiṭṭhanti.🔽Āmantanatthe paṭhamā, ‘gosyālapane’ti gasaññā.
analyzed: kaññā tiṭṭhati  vā ka rū nī  jantu hetūhi ca punnapuṃsakesu īkāra antehi ca gha taḥ ca pa saññehi i va ṇ u vaṇṇehi ca yonam lopaḥ hoti vā  kaññā tiṭṭhanti kaññāyaḥ tiṭṭhanti  āmantana atthe paṭhamā go sya ālapanā iti ga saññā
translated: A maiden stands.

original: 84. Ghabrahmāditve ka. 114, 193; rū. 122, 178; nī. 288; ghabrahmādite (bahasu).🔽Ghato ca brahmādito ca gassa e hoti vā. Ādisaddena isi, muni, revatī, kattu, khattuiccāditopi.🔽Bhoti kaññe, bhoti kaññā, bhotiyo kaññāyo, bhotī kaññāyo, “uṭṭhehi puttika pabbajjā🔽dukkarā puttika” iti therīpāḷi therīgā. 465, tasmā ge pare mahāvuttinā rassopi yujjati.
analyzed: gha brahma ādi tve ka rū   nī gha brahma ādite baha su 🔽ghataḥ ca brahma āditaḥ ca gassa e hoti vā ādi saddena isi muni revatī kattu khattu icca āditaḥ pi 🔽bhoti kaññe bhoti kaññāḥ bhotiyo kaññāyaḥ bhotī kaññāyaḥ uṭṭhehi puttika pabbajjā 🔽dukkarā puttikā iti therī pāḷi therī gā tasmā ge pare mahāvuttinā yujjati
translated: Or by creatures, causes, and by the G-group, which has the I-sign, and by the G-group, which has the A-sign, and by the G-group, which has the U-sign, and by the G-group, which has the O-sign, and by the G-group, which has the U-sign, and by the G-group, which has the U-sign, and by the G-group, which has the U-sign, and by the G-group, which has the U-sign, and by the G-group, which has the U-sign, and by the G-group, which has the U-sign, and by the G-group, which has the U-sign, and by the G-group, which has the U-sign, and by the G-group, which has the U-sign, and by the G-group, which has the U-sign, and by the G-group, which has the U-sign, and by the G-group, which has the U-sign, and by the G-group, which has the U-sign, and by the G-group, which has the U-sign, and by the G-group, which has the U-sign, and by the G-group, which has the U-sign, and by the G-group, which has the U-sign, and by the G-group, which has the U-sign, and by the G-group, which has the U-sign, and by the G-group, which has the U-sign, and by the G-group, which has the U-sign, and by the G-group, which has the U-sign, and by the G-group, which has the U-sign, and by the G-group, which has the U-sign, and by the G-group, which has the U-sign, and by the G-group, which has the U-sign, and by the G-group, which has the U-sign, and by the G-group, which has the U-sign, and by the G-group, which has the U-sign, and by

original: Kusajātake “na me akāsi vacanaṃ, atthakāmāya puttike”tipi jā. 2.20.47 atthi.🔽Kammatthe dutiyā, ‘saro lopo sare’ti pubbasaralopo.
analyzed: kusa jātake na me akāsi vacanam attha kāmāya puttikā iti pi jā atthi  kammatthe dutiyā saraḥ lopaḥ sara iti pubba sara lopaḥ
translated: In the Kusajātaka: “You did not do what I said, dear child, who wish you well” .

original: Kaññaṃ passati, kaññā passati, kaññāyo passati.
analyzed: kaññam passati kaññā passati kaññāyo passati
translated: In the sense of an object, the second case is used: “He sees a girl”, “a girl sees”, “girls see”.

original: Kattari tatiyā.🔽85. Ghapatekasmiṃ nādīnaṃ yayā ka. 111, 112; rū. 179, 183 nī. 283, 284.
analyzed: kattari tatiyā  gha pata ikasmin na a dīnam yayā ka    rū
translated: In the sense of an instrument, the third case is used:

original: Ghato ca pasaññehi ivaṇṇuvaṇṇehi ca ekatte pavattānaṃ nādīnaṃ pañcannaṃ ekavacanānaṃ kamena ya, yā honti.
analyzed: gha taḥ ca pa saññehi i va ṇ u vaṇṇehi ca ekatte pavattānam na ādīnam pañcannam ekavacanānam kamena ya yā honti
translated: In the case of a single pot, the five singular forms of the verbs beginning with “to be” are used with ya and yā: “The pot is with the paints and the colours” .

original: Kaññāya kataṃ, kaññāhi kataṃ. Ettha ca ghatopi yāādeso dissati. “Te ca tattha nisīditvā,
analyzed: kaññāya katam kaññāhi katam ettha ca gha taḥ pi yā ā ādesaḥ dissati te ca tattha nisīditvā
translated: “Done by a girl”, “done by girls”. And here the forms of ya and yā are also seen in the case of a pot: “And sitting there,

original: tassa rukkhassa chāyayā” jā. 1.14.182 ti ca “samantā parivāriṃsu, tassa rukkhassa🔽chāyayā” jā. 1.14.189 ti ca pāḷi, tathā “sakkharopamayā vade” saccasaṅkhepa 176 gāthā,
analyzed: tassa rukkhassa chāyayā jā ti ca samantā parivāriṃsu tassa rukkhassa  chāyayā ti ca tathā sakkhara upamayā vade sacca saṅkhepa gāthā
translated: in the shade of that tree” , and “They surrounded him on all sides,

original: “bāladārakalīlayā”ti vibhāvinī 154 ca dissanti. Mahāvuttinā ghassa rasso.
analyzed: bāla dāraka līlayā ati vibhāvinī ca dissanti mahāvuttinā
translated: in the shade of that tree” , and the text “Speak with a simile like a pebble” , and the explanatory verse “With the play of a foolish child” are seen. The long vowel of gh is according to the Mahā-vutti.

original: 86. Smāhismiṃnaṃ mhābhimhi vā ka. 99; rū. 81.
analyzed: sma ahi smiṃnam mha abhi vā ka rū
translated: 86. In the Genitive and Ablative, in the sense of ‘from’, the forms are the same as those in the Locative.

original: Tesaṃ kamena mhā, bhi, mhi honti vā. Ete ādesā gāthāsu bahulaṃ dissanti.
analyzed: tesam kamena mhā bhi mhi honti vā ete ādesāḥ gāthāsu bahulam dissanti
translated: These are the endings that are found frequently in the verses.

original: Kaññāhi kataṃ, kaññābhi kataṃ.
analyzed: kaññāhi katam kaññābhi katam
translated: Done by girls, done by girls.

original: Sampadāne catutthī, kaññāya deti, kaññānaṃ deti, kaññāya ābhataṃ vatthaṃ, kaññānaṃ ābhataṃ vatthaṃ.
analyzed: sampadāne catutthī kaññāya deti kaññānam deti kaññāya ābhatam vattham kaññānam ābhatam vattham
translated: In the Instrumental, the fourth case is used: He gives to a girl, he gives to girls, cloth obtained from a girl, cloth obtained from girls.

original: Apādāne pañcamī, kaññāya apeti, kaññamhā apetirassattaṃ, kaññāhi kaññābhi apeti.🔽Sambandhe chaṭṭhī, kaññāya santakaṃ, kaññānaṃ santakaṃ.
analyzed: apādāne pañcamī kaññāya apeti kaññamhā apeti rassattam kaññāhi kaññābhi apeti  sambandhe chaṭṭhī kaññāya santakam kaññānam santakam
translated: In the Ablative, the fifth case is used: He takes away from a girl, he takes away from a girl, he takes away from girls.🔽In the Genitive, the sixth case is used: Belonging to a girl, belonging to girls.

original: Okāse sattamī, kaññāya tiṭṭhati.🔽87. Yaṃ ka. 116; rū. 180; nī. 443.
analyzed: okāse sattamī kaññāya tiṭṭhati  yam ka rū nī
translated: In the Locative, the seventh case is used: He stands in a girl, he stands in a girl, he stands in girls.🔽. What is the case? ; what is the gender? ; what is the number? .

original: Ghato ca pasaññehi ivaṇṇuvaṇṇehi ca smiṃno yaṃ hoti vā.
analyzed: gha taḥ ca pa saññehi i va ṇ u vaṇṇehi ca smin naḥ yam hoti vā
translated: As in the case of a pot with various colours, so in the case of a girl, what is used is the Locative.

original: Kaññāyaṃ tiṭṭhati, kaññāya tiṭṭhati, kaññāsu tiṭṭhati.🔽Saddhā medhā paññā vijjā, cintā mantā vīṇā taṇhā.
analyzed: kaññāyam tiṭṭhati kaññāya tiṭṭhati kaññāsu tiṭṭhati  saddhā medhā paññā vijjā cintā mantā vīṇā taṇhā
translated: He stands in a girl, he stands in a girl, he stands in girls.🔽Faith, intelligence, wisdom, knowledge, thought, reflection, lute, craving.

original: Icchā mucchā ejā māyā, mettā mattā sikkhā bhikkhā.
analyzed: icchā mucchā ejā māyā mettā mattā sikkhā bhikkhā
translated: Desire, infatuation, passion, illusion, love, moderation, training, alms.

original: Jaṅghā gīvā jivhā vācā, chāyā āsā gaṅgānāvā.
analyzed: jaṅghā gīvā jivhā vācā chāyā āsā gaṅgā nāvā
translated: Calf, neck, tongue, speech, shadow, hope, the Ganges, a boat.

original: Gāthā senā lekhā sākhā, mālā velā pūjā khiḍḍā.
analyzed: gāthā senā lekhā sākhā mālā velā pūjā khiḍḍā
translated: Verse, army, line, branch, garland, time, worship, play.

original: Pipāsā vedanā saññā, cetanā tasiṇāpajā.
analyzed: pipāsā vedanā saññā cetanā
translated: Thirst, feeling, perception, volition, the (four) formless (absorptions), the (four) kinds of rebirth.

original: Devatā vaṭṭakā godhā, balākā parisā sabhā.🔽Ūkā sephālikā laṅkā, salākā vālikā sikhā.
analyzed: devatā vaṭṭakā godhā balākā parisā sabhā  ūkā sephālikā laṅkā salākā vālikā sikhā
translated: Deity, circle, crocodile, heron, assembly, council.🔽Owl, spider, Lanka, voting ticket, sand, crest.

original: Visākhā visikhā sākhā, gacchā vañjhā jaṭā ghaṭā.
analyzed: visākhā visikhā sākhā gacchā vañjhā jaṭā ghaṭā
translated: Visākhā, Visikhā, branch, path, barren, matted hair, pot.

original: Jeṭṭhā soṇḍā vitaṇḍā ca, varuṇā vanitā latā.🔽Kathā niddā sudhā rādhā, vāsanā sīsapā papā.
analyzed: jeṭṭhā soṇḍā vitaṇḍā ca varuṇā vanitā latā  kathā niddā sudhā rādhā vāsanā sīsapā papā
translated: Eldest, beak, dispute, Varuna, woman, creeper.🔽Story, sleep, nectar, Rādhi, perfume, Sīsapā, papā.

original: Pabhā sīmā khamā jāyā, khattiyā sakkharā surā.🔽Dolā tulā silā līlā, lāle’lā mekhalā kalā.
analyzed: pabhā sīmā khamā jāyā khattiyā sakkharā surā  dolā tulā silā līlā lālelā mekhalā kalā
translated: Light, boundary, forgiveness, wife, khattiya, gravel, liquor.🔽Swing, balance, stone, sport, Lāle, Alā, girdle, art.

original: Vaḷavā’ lambusā mūsā, mañjūsā sulasā disā.
analyzed: vaḷavā lambusā mūsā mañjūsā sulasā disā
translated: Ox, long-haired, mouse, sweet-voiced, easy to live with, direction.

original: Nāsā juṇhā guhā īhā, lasikā vasudhādayo.
analyzed: nāsā juṇhā guhā īhā lasikā vasudhā ādayaḥ
translated: Nose, rainy season, cave, desire, oil, earth, etc.

original: 88. Nambādīhi nambādīhi (bahūsu).
analyzed: namba ādīhi namba ādīhi bahūsu
translated: . With nam and so on, nam and so on (in many).

original: Gasaññehi amba, anna, ammaiccetehi gassa e na hoti.
analyzed: ga saññehi amba anna ammaiccetehi gassa e na hoti
translated: With the perception of ga, in amba, anna, ammaiccetehi, ga e does not become na.

original: 89. Rasso vā.
analyzed: rassaḥ vā
translated: . Or ra.

original: Ambādīnaṃ rasso hoti vā ge pare.
analyzed: ambā ādīnam rassaḥ hoti vā ge pare
translated: Of amba and so on, ra becomes ho or va after ge.

original: Bhoti amba, bhoti ambā, bhoti anna, bhoti annā, bhoti amma, bhoti ammā, sesaṃ kaññāsamaṃ.
analyzed: bhoti amba bhoti ambā bhoti anna bhoti annā bhoti amma bhoti ammā sesam kaññāsamam
translated: Bhoti amba, bhoti ambā, bhoti anna, bhoti annā, bhoti amma, bhoti ammā, the rest is the same as for a maiden.

original: Ettha visesavidhānamuccate.
analyzed: ettha visesa vidhānam uccate
translated: Herein, the special rules are stated.

original: 90. Ti sabhāparisāya.
analyzed: ti sabhā parisāya
translated: . Ti sabhāparisāya.

original: Sabhāparisāhi smiṃnoti hoti. ‘Gho ssaṃssāssāya tīsū’ti suttena timhi rasso.
analyzed: sabhā parisāhi hoti gho tīsu iti suttena timhi rassaḥ
translated: Sabhāparisāhi smiṃnoti hoti. ‘Gho ssaṃssāssāya tīsū’ti suttena timhi rasso.

original: Sabhati, sabhāya, sabhāyaṃ, sabhāsu, parisati, parisāya, parisāyaṃ, parisāsu, tamaddasa
analyzed: sabhati sabhāya sabhāyam sabhāsu parisati parisāya parisāyam parisāsu tamaddasa
translated: Sabhati, sabhāya, sabhāyaṃ, sabhāsu, parisati, parisāya, parisāyaṃ, parisāsu, tamaddasa

original: mahābrahmā, nisinnaṃ samhi parisati, iti bhagavā tasmiṃ parisati suvaṇṇavaṇṇaṃ kāyaṃ
analyzed: mahābrahmā nisinnam samhi parisati iti bhagavā tasmin parisati suvaṇṇa vaṇṇam kāyam
translated: mahābrahmā, nisinnaṃ samhi parisati, iti bhagavā tasmiṃ parisati suvaṇṇavaṇṇaṃ kāyaṃ

original: vivari ma. ni. 1.359.
analyzed: vivari ma ni
translated: vivari ma. ni. ..

original: Nandamātā, rājadhītāiccādīsu ‘ghabrahmāditve’ti ghassa ettaṃ.
analyzed: nandamātā rājadhītā aicca ādīsu gha brahma ādi tvā iti ghassaḥ e t tam
translated: Nandamātā, rājadhītāiccādīsu ‘ghabrahmāditve’ti ghassa ettaṃ.

original: Acchariyaṃ nandamāte, abbhutaṃ nandamāte a. ni. 7.53, bhoti devadhīte, bhoti sakyadhītare-mahāvuttinā
analyzed: acchariyam nandamāte abbhutam nandamāte a ni bhoti deva dhīte bhoti sakya dhītare mahāvuttinā
translated: Acchariyaṃ nandamāte, abbhutaṃ nandamāte a. ni. ., bhoti devadhīte, bhoti sakyadhītare-mahāvuttinā

original: samāse syādīsu ārattaṃ rassattañca. Ltupaccayantā pana yebhuyyena tīsu liṅgesu samānarūpā
analyzed: samāse sya ādīsu ārattam ltu paccaya ntā pana yebhuyyena tīsu liṅgesu samāna rūpā
translated: samāse syādīsu ārattaṃ rassattañca. Ltupaccayantā pana yebhuyyena tīsu liṅgesu samānarūpā

original: honti, “atthadhammaṃ paripucchitā ca uggahetā ca dhammānaṃ sotā ca payirūpāsitā cā”ti
analyzed: honti attha dhammam paripucchitā ca uggahetā ca dhammānam sotā ca payirūpāsitā ca ati
translated: “They are those who ask about the meaning and the Dhamma, and who learn the Dhamma, and who attend upon it.”

original: therīpāḷi. Tathā kvaci gacchantādisaddāpi. Tamokhandhaṃ padālayaṃ, evaṃ dubbhāsitaṃ
analyzed: therī pāḷi tathā kvaci tamaḥ khandham pada ālayam evam dubbhāsitam
translated: The Therīpāḷi. Likewise, in some places, the words gacchantā, etc., are also found. Tamokhandhaṃ padālayaṃ, evaṃ dubbhāsitaṃ

original: bhaṇaṃ iccādi-tattha padālayanti padālayantī, bhaṇanti bhaṇantīti attho.
analyzed: padālayanti padālayantī bhaṇanti bhaṇanti iti atthaḥ
translated: bhaṇaṃ iccādi—there padālayanti, padālayantī, bhaṇanti, bhaṇantī—this is the meaning.

original: Vīsā, tiṃsā, cattālīsā, paññāsā iccete saṅkhyārāsimhi āgamissanti.
analyzed: vīsā tiṃsā cattālīsā paññāsā icc ete saṅkhyā rāsimhi āgamissanti
translated: Vīsā, tiṃsā, cattālīsā, paññāsā—these will come in the section on numbers.

original: Ākārantitthiliṅgarāsi niṭṭhito.
analyzed: niṭṭhito
translated: The section on the heap of forms of the base of the second case is finished.

original: Ikārantitthiliṅgarāsi
analyzed: ikāra antitthi liṅga rā si
translated: The section on the heap of forms of the base of the first case

original: ‘Gasīna’nti silopo. Ratti tiṭṭhati, rattiyo tiṭṭhanti.
analyzed: si lopaḥ ratti tiṭṭhati rattiyaḥ tiṭṭhanti
translated: ‘Gasīna’—this is a mispronunciation. Ratti tiṭṭhati, rattiyo tiṭṭhanti.

original: ‘Jantuhetvā’disuttena yolope –🔽91. Yolopanīsu dīgho ka. 88; rū. 147; nī. 245.
analyzed: jantu hetu ādi suttena yaḥ lope  ya u lopa nīsu dīghaḥ ka rū nī
translated: ‘Jantuhetvā’disuttena yolope—🔽. In yolopanī, ka is lengthened. rū. ; nī. .

original: Tiliṅge yonaṃ lope ca niādese ca rassānaṃ dīgho hoti.
analyzed: ti liṅge lope ca ni ādese ca rassānam dīghaḥ hoti
translated: In the first case, the short vowel of the first member is lengthened before a vowel and before a sibilant.

original: Rattī tiṭṭhanti.
analyzed: rattī tiṭṭhanti
translated: Rattiyo tiṭṭhanti.

original: 92. Ye passivaṇṇassa.
analyzed: ye passi vaṇṇassa
translated: . Of the passive ending.

original: Vibhattibhūte vibhattādesabhūte ca yakāre pare pasaññassa ivaṇṇassa lopo hoti. Gāthāsuyeva idaṃ vidhānaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: vibhatti bhūte vibhatta ādesa bhūte ca yakāre pare pa saññassa i va ṇṇassa lopaḥ hoti gāthāsu yā iva idam vidhānam daṭṭhabbam
translated: The vowel of the passive ending is elided before the vowel ya, and before the vowel of the passive ending. This rule should be seen only in the verses.

original: Ratyo tiṭṭhanti rū. 84 piṭṭhe -sandhivasena āditakāralopo.
analyzed: ratyo tiṭṭhanti rū piṭṭhe sandhi vasena ādi takāra lopaḥ
translated: The joy remains in the back, the initial k is elided by the sandhi rule.🔽Or the long of ayuna.

original: 63. Ayunaṃ vā dīgho ka. 88; rū. 147; nī. 245.🔽Ge pare tiliṅge aiunaṃ dīgho hoti vā.
analyzed: ayunam vā dīghaḥ ka rū nī  ge pare ti liṅge aiunam dīghaḥ vā
translated: The long of aiuna is optionally in the locative.

original: He rattī, he ratti. Bahuvacane he rattī, he rattiyo, he ratyo.
analyzed: he rattī he ratti bahuvacane he rattī he rattiyaḥ he ratyo
translated: He rattī, he ratti. In the plural he rattī, he rattiyo, he ratyo.

original: Aṃvacane ‘paro kvacī’ti suttena parasare lutte niggahītaṃ pubbe ivaṇṇuvaṇṇesu tiṭṭhati.
analyzed: aṃvacane paraḥ kvaci iti suttena para sare lutte niggahītam pubbe i vaṇṇa uvaṇṇesu tiṭṭhati
translated: In the ablative ‘para in some cases’ by the rule, the para is elided, and the i remains as before in the case of the vowels i and u.

original: Rattiṃ, tathā itthiṃ, dhenuṃ, vadhuṃ, aggiṃ, daṇḍiṃ, bhikkhuṃ, sayambhuṃ iti. Rattiyaṃ,
analyzed: rattim tathā itthim dhenum vadhum aggim daṇḍim bhikkhum sayambhum iti rattiyam
translated: Rattiṃ, likewise itthiṃ, dhenuṃ, vadhuṃ, aggiṃ, daṇḍiṃ, bhikkhuṃ, sayambhuṃ. Rattiyāṃ,

original: ‘bujjhassu jinabodhiya’nti pāḷi bu. vaṃ. 2.182, rattinaṃ vā, ‘yāvanto purisassatthaṃ,
analyzed: vā yāvantaḥ
translated: The reading is ‘bujjhassu jinabodhiya’ (wake up, O Victorious One, to the enlightenment). The long of ayuna is optionally in the locative.

original: guyhaṃ jānanti mantina’ntipāḷi jā. 1.15.335.
analyzed: guyham jānanti
translated: The reading is ‘yāvanto purisassatthaṃ, guyhaṃ jānanti mantina’ (as many as know the secret of man). The long of ayuna is optionally in the ablative.

original: Rattī, rattiyo, ratyo-‘ghapatekasmiṃ nādīnaṃ yayā’ti nādīnaṃ yā hoti, rattiyā, yakāre pare ivaṇṇalopo, ratyā.🔽94. Sunaṃhisu ka. 89; rū. 87; nī. 246.
analyzed: rattiḥ rattiyaḥ rati ogha pate ikasmin na adīnam yayā ati na adīnam yā hoti rattiyā yakāre pare i vā a ṇ lopaḥ ratyā  su naṃhi su ka rū nī
translated: Ratti, rattiyo, ratyo. In the locative singular ‘ya of nadi’ by the rule, the ya of nadi becomes ya, rattiyā. The i is elided by the sandhi rule, ratyā.🔽The long of rassā is optionally.

original: Su, naṃ, hisu rassānaṃ dīgho hoti.
analyzed: su nam hi su rassānam dīghaḥ hoti
translated: Su, naṃ, hisu. The long of rassā is optionally.

original: Rattīhi, rattībhi, rattiyā, ratyā, rattīnaṃ, rattiyā, ratyā, rattīhi, rattībhi, rattiyā, ratyā, rattīnaṃ, rattiyā, ratyā, rattiyaṃ, ratyaṃ, rattīsu.
analyzed: rattīhi rattībhiḥ rattiyā ratyā rattīnam rattiyā ratyā rattīhi rattībhiḥ rattiyā ratyā rattīnam rattiyā ratyā rattiyam ratyam rattīsu
translated: By nights, by nights, by night, by night, of nights, by night, by night, by nights, by nights, by night, by night, of nights, by night, by night, in the night, in the night, in nights.

original: Ettha garū su, naṃ, hisu dīghattaṃ aniccaṃ icchanti, taṃ gāthāsu yujjati.
analyzed: ettha su nam hi su aniccam icchanti tam gāthāsu yujjati
translated: Here they desire that the long vowel is optional in su, naṃ, hisu, and that is correct in the verses.

original: Patti yutti vutti kitti, mutti titti khanti kanti.
analyzed: patti yutti vutti kitti mutti titti khanti kanti
translated: Patti, yutti, vutti, kitti, mutti, titti, khanti, kanti.

original: Santi tanti siddhi suddhi, iddhi vuddhi buddhi bodhi.
analyzed: santi tanti siddhi suddhi iddhi vuddhi buddhi bodhi
translated: Santi, tanti, siddhi, suddhi, iddhi, vuddhi, buddhi, bodhi.

original: Bhūmi jāti pīti suti, nandi sandhi sāṇi koṭi.
analyzed: bhūmi jāti pīti suti nandi sandhi sāṇi koṭi
translated: Bhūmi, jāti, pīti, suti, nandi, sandhi, sāṇi, koṭi.

original: Diṭṭhi vuḍḍhi tuṭṭhi yaṭṭhi, pāḷi āḷi nāḷi keḷi.
analyzed: diṭṭhi vuḍḍhi tuṭṭhi yaṭṭhi pāḷi āḷi nāḷi keḷi
translated: Diṭṭhi, vuḍḍhi, tuṭṭhi, yaṭṭhi, pāḷi, āḷi, nāḷi, keḷi.

original: Sati mati gati muti, dhīti yuvati vikati.
analyzed: sati mati gati muti dhīti yuvati vikati
translated: Sati, mati, gati, muti, dhīti, yuvati, vikati.

original: Rati ruci rasmi asani vasani osadhi aṅguli dhūli dudrabhi
analyzed: rati ruci rasmi asani vasani osadhi aṅguli dhūli dudrabhi
translated: Rati, ruci, rasmi, asani, vasani, osadhi, aṅguli, dhūli, dudrabhi.

original: Doṇi aṭavi chaviādayo rattādi.
analyzed: doṇi aṭavi chavi ādayoḥ ratta ādi
translated: Doṇi, aṭavi, chavi, etc., are like night, etc.

original: Ettha visesavidhānamuccate.
analyzed: ettha visesa vidhānam uccate
translated: Here the special rules are stated.

original: 95. Rattādīhi ṭo smiṃno ka. 69; rū. 186; nī. 218, 219; rattyādīhi ṭo smino (bahūsu) ratyādīhi (katthaci).
analyzed: ratta ādīhi ṭaḥ smin naḥ ka rū nī   ratti ādīhi ṭaḥ sminaḥ bahūsu rati ādīhi katthaci
translated: By night, etc., ṭo is added to smiṃ, ka; rū; nī; by night, etc., ṭo is added to smiṃ (in many cases); by night, etc., (in some cases).

original: Rattisadda, ādisaddehi smiṃno ṭo hoti vā.
analyzed: ratti saddaḥ ādi saddehi smin naḥ ṭaḥ hoti vā
translated: The words ratti, ādi, are declined like divā, etc.

original: Divā ca ratto ca khu. pā. 6.2; jā. 1.9.92, ādo, ādimhi, pādādo, pādādimhi, gāthādo,
analyzed: divā ca ratto ca khu pā  jā ādaḥ ādimhi pāda ādo pāda ādimhi gāthā
translated: Khu, pā, jā, ādo, ādimhi, pādādo, pādādimhi, gāthādo,

original: gāthādimhi-ādisaddo pana pulliṅgoyeva, rattiṃ bhojanaṃ bhuñjati, ādiṃ tiṭṭhatīti🔽ādhāratthe dutiyāva, ratyo amoghā gacchanti jā. 2.22.105, tiṇalatāni osadhyo jā.
analyzed: gāthā ādimhi ādi saddo pana rattim bhojanam bhuñjati ādim tiṭṭhati iti  ādhāra atthe dutiyā ava ratyaḥ amoghāḥ gacchanti jā tiṇa latāni osadhyaḥ jā
translated: gāthādimhi. But the word ādi is only masculine. He eats food at night, he stands at the beginning.

original: 2.22.2174, tato ratyā vivasāne jā. 2.22.1689, na jaccā vasalo hoti, na jaccā hoti
analyzed: tatas ratyā vivasāne jā na jaccā vasalaḥ hoti na jaccā hoti
translated: In the sense of basis, only the second (case is used): Rattiyo amoghā gacchanti jā. .., Tiṇalatāni osadhyaṃ jā. .., Tato ratyā vivasāne jā. .., Na jaccā vasalo hoti, na jaccā hoti

original: brāhmaṇo su. ni. 142 -jaccāti jātiyā, na nikatyā sukhamedhati jā. 1.1.38, khantyā
analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ su ni jaccāti jātiyā na nikatyā sukhamedhati jā khantyā
translated: Brāhmaṇo su. ni. -Jaccāti jātiyā, Na nikatyā sukhamedhati jā. .., Khantyā

original: bhiyyo na vijjati saṃ. ni. 1.250.
analyzed: bhiyyas na vijjati sam ni
translated: Bhiyyo na vijjati saṃ. ni. ..

original: Nāññatra bojjhā tapasā saṃ. ni. 1.98, yatheva khalatī bhūmyā, bhūmyāyeva patiṭṭhati
analyzed: na aññatra bojjhā tapasā sam ni yathā iva khalatī bhūmyāḥ bhūmyāya iva patiṭṭhati
translated: Nāññatra bojjhā tapasā saṃ. ni. .., Yatheva khalatī bhūmyā, Bhūmyāyeva patiṭṭhati

original: jā. 2.22.1522, mahāvuttinā māti, pitisaddā nādīhi saddhiṃ matyā, petyāti sijjhanti,
analyzed: mahāvuttinā mā ati piti saddāḥ na ādīhi saddhim matyā petya ati sijjhanti
translated: Jā. .., Mahāvuttinā māti, Pitisaddā nādīhi saddhiṃ Matyā, Petyāti sijjhanti,

original: matyā ca petyā ca etaṃ jānāmimātito pititoti attho, matyā ca petyā ca kataṃ susādhu
analyzed: matyā ca petyā ca etam jānāmi mātito pitito ti matyā ca petyā ca katam su sādhu
translated: Matyā ca petyā ca Etaṃ jānāmimātito Pititoti attho, Matyā ca petyā ca Kataṃ susādhu

original: jā. 2.18.61 -katanti kataṃ nāmaṃ, susādhūti atisundaraṃ. ‘Anuññāto ahaṃ matyā, sañcatto
analyzed: jā kata nti katam nāmam su sādhu iti ati sundaram anuññātaḥ aham matyā sañcattaḥ
translated: ‘Jā. 2.18.61. Katanti kataṃ nāmaṃ, susādhūti atisundaraṃ. ‘Anuññāto ahaṃ matyā, sañcatto

original: pitarā aha’nti jā. 2.22.29 pāḷipadāni. ‘Mātīnaṃ dohaḷo nāma janinda vuccatī’ jā.
analyzed: pitarā ahanti jā pāḷipadāni mātīnam dohaḷaḥ nāma janinda vuccati jā
translated: ‘Katanti’ means ‘done’, ‘kataṃ’ is a name, ‘susādhū’ means ‘very beautiful’. ‘Anuññāto ahaṃ matyā, sañcatto pitarā aha’ (Jā. 1.18.61) are the lines. ‘Mātīnaṃ dohaḷo nāma janinda vuccatī’ (Jā. 1.18.61) is the text.

original: 2.22.1347 ti ca pāḷi, vīsati, tiṃsati, saṭṭhi, sattati, asīti, navuti, koṭi, pakoṭi
analyzed: ti ca pāḷi vīsati tiṃsati saṭṭhi sattati asīti navuti koṭi pakoṭi
translated: And ‘vīsati’, ‘tiṃsati’, ‘saṭṭhi’, ‘satta-ti’, ‘asīti’, ‘navuti’, ‘koṭi’, ‘pakoṭi’

original: iccete saṅkhyārāsimhi āgamissanti.🔽Ikārantitthiliṅgarāsi niṭṭhito.
analyzed: iccā ete saṅkhyā rāsimhi āgamissanti  niṭṭhitaḥ
translated: these will come in the collection of numbers.🔽The collection of words beginning with ‘ikā’ is finished.

original: Īkārantitthiliṅgarāsi
analyzed: īkāra antitthi liṅga rāsi
translated: The collection of words beginning with ‘īkā’.
