original: gavassa, gavaṃ, gonaṃ, gunnaṃ, gavaṃ, gāvasmiṃ, gāvamhi, gāve, gavasmiṃ, gavamhi,
analyzed: gavassa gavam gonam gunnam gavam gāvasmin gāvamhi gāve gavasmin gavamhi
translated: gavassa, gavaṃ, gonaṃ, gunnaṃ, gavaṃ, gāvasmiṃ, gāvamhi, gāve, gavasmiṃ, gavamhi,

original: gave, gosu, gāvesu, gavesu.
analyzed: gave gosu gāvesu gavesu
translated: gave, gosu, gāvesu, gavesu.

original: Yosu gāva, gavādese kate ato yonaṃ ṭā, ṭe ca honti, usabhā rukkhā gāviyo gavā ca
analyzed: yosu gāva gavā ādese kate a taḥ yonam ṭāḥ ṭe ca honti usabhāḥ rukkhāḥ gāviyaḥ gavā ca
translated: Yosu gāva, gavādese kate ato yonaṃ ṭā, ṭe ca honti, usabhā rukkhā gāviyo gavā ca

original: jā. 1.1.77. Balagavā dammagavā vā gaṅgāya pāraṃ agamiṃsu. Athāpare patāresi balagāve
analyzed: jā balagavā dammagavā vā gaṅgāya pāram agamiṃsu atha apare balagāve
translated: and the strong and the weak cows crossed to the other side of the Ganges. Then the other cows were swept away,

original: dammagāve ma. ni. 1.352 (thokaṃ visadisaṃ) ti pāḷipadāni.
analyzed: dammagāve ma ni thokam visadisam ti pāḷi padāni
translated: the strong and the weak cows were swept away, ma. ni. . (slightly different).

original: Ettha ca gāvo no paramā mittā, yāsu jāyanti osadhā su. ni. 298 ti ca, gavā khīraṃ,
analyzed: ettha ca gāvaḥ no paramāḥ mittāḥ yāsu jāyanti osadhāḥ su ni ti ca gavā khīram
translated: And here (the words) ‘cows are not the highest friends, in which are born the herbs, su. ni. .’ and ‘from the cow comes milk,

original: khīramhā dadhi, dadhimhā navanītaṃ, navanītamhā sappi, sappimhā sappimaṇḍoti ca itthiyaṃ
analyzed: khīramhā dadhi dadhimhā navanītam navanītamhā sappi sappimhā sappimaṇḍā uti ca itthiyam
translated: from milk comes curd, from curd comes butter, from butter comes ghee, from ghee comes the essence of ghee,’ and in the feminine

original: vattanti. Gāviyo gavāti ca balagavā dammagavā balagave dammagaveti ma. ni. 1.351
analyzed: vattanti gāviyaḥ gavā ati ca balagavā dammagavā balagave dammagave iti ma ni
translated: (the words) ‘cows’ and ‘cow’ and ‘the strong cows and the weak cows’ and ‘the strong cows and the weak cows’ and ma. ni. .

original: ca gāvuṃ vā te dammi gāviṃ vā te dammīti ca gavaṃva siṅgino siṅganti jā. 1.12.39
analyzed: ca gāvum vā te dammi gāvim vā te dammi iti ca gavam iva siṅginaḥ siṅganti jā
translated: and ‘I give you a cow or I give you a cow’ and ‘like a cow with horns’ and ‘horns’ and jā. ..

original: ca pume bhavanti. Atittheneva gāvo patāresi, atha kho tā gāvo majjhe gaṅgāya anayabyasanaṃ
analyzed: ca pume bhavanti atitthena iva gāvaḥ patāresi atha kho tāḥ gāvaḥ majjhe gaṅgāya anaya byasanam
translated: and in the masculine (the words) ‘cows’ and ‘cow’ are used. The cows were swept away by the current, then those cows came to destruction and loss in the middle of the Ganges,

original: āpajjiṃsū ma. ni. 1.350 ti ca annadā baladā cetā, vaṇṇadā sukhadā ca tā, etamatthavasaṃ
analyzed: āpajjiṃsū ma ni ti ca anna dā bala dā ca itā vaṇṇa dā sukha dā ca tā etam attha vasam
translated: ma. ni. . and ‘they give food, they give strength, they give beauty, they give happiness,’ for this reason

original: ñatvā, nāssu gāvo haniṃsu teti su. ni. 298 ca bhaddavasena itthiyaṃ atthavasena missake
analyzed: ñatvā na assu gāvaḥ haniṃsu teti su ni ca bhadda vasena itthiyam attha vasena missake
translated: In the feminine: “In the sense of a woman, in the sense of a mixture.”🔽“If the cattle are crossing, if the cows are crossing, the bull goes straight on, all

original: vattanti. Gunnaṃ ce taramānānaṃ, gavaṃ ce taramānānaṃ, ujuṃ gacchati puṅgavo, sabbā🔽tā ujuṃ gacchantīti jā. 1.4.135; 2.18.104 ca missake eva. Balagava, dammagavasaddā
analyzed: vattanti gunnam ce taramānānam gavam ce taramānānam ujum gacchati puṅgavaḥ sabbā  tāḥ ujum gacchanti iti jā ca missake eva balagava dammagava saddā
translated: follow the bull straight on.”

original: jaraggava, puṅgava, sagava, paragava, dāragavasaddā viya akārantā samāsasaddātipi yujjati.
analyzed: jaraggava puṅgava sagava paragava dāragava saddāḥ a kāra antā samāsa sadda atipi yujjati
translated: “Bull,” “cow,” are compounds with the final vowel elided, like the words “calf,” “bullock,” “bull,” “other bull,” “young bull.”

original: Missakaṭṭhānesu pana itthibahulattā tā gāvo etā gāvotiādinā itthiliṅgameva dissati.
analyzed: missaka ṭṭhānesu pana itthi bahula ttā tāḥ gāvaḥ etāḥ gāvaḥ iti ādinā itthi liṅgam eva dissati
translated: But in the passages about a mixture, the feminine form is seen, “These cows are those cows,” because of the predominance of the feminine.

original: Iti okārantarāsi.
analyzed: iti okāra antarā asi
translated: So much for the section on words ending in vowels.

original: Itthiliṅgarāsi niṭṭhito.
analyzed: niṭṭhito
translated: The section on feminine words is finished.

original: Pulliṅgarāsi
analyzed: pulliṅga rā asi
translated: The neuter section

original: Akāranta pulliṅgapurisādirāsi
analyzed: akāra anta pulliṅga purisa ādiḥ ā asi
translated: The neuter section on words not ending in a vowel, beginning with the word for “man”

original: Atha pulliṅgāni dīpiyante.
analyzed: atha pulliṅgāni dīpiyante
translated: Now the neuters are illustrated.

original: Sattavidhaṃ pulliṅgaṃ – adantaṃ, ādantaṃ, idantaṃ, īdantaṃ, udantaṃ, ūdantaṃ, odantaṃ.🔽107. Sisso ka. 104; rū. 66; nī. 272.
analyzed: sattavidham pulliṅgam ad antam ād antam id antam ī d antam ud antam ū d antam o d antam  ro ka rū nī
translated: The neuter has seven forms: the adanta, ādanta, idanta, īdanta, udanta, ūdanta, and odanta.

original: Ato sissa o hoti pume.
analyzed: a taḥ si ssa o hoti pume
translated: “Boy” (ka), “form” (rūpa), “blue” (nīla).🔽After “boy,” o is substituted for the final vowel in the masculine.

original: Puriso tiṭṭhati.
analyzed: puriso tiṭṭhati
translated: “Man” (purisa) stands.

original: 108. Ato yonaṃ ṭāṭe ka. 107; rū. 69; nī. 275, 277.
analyzed: a taḥ ya ūnam ṭā ṭe ka rū nī
translated: 108. Therefore, on the other side of the river, etc.

original: Ato paṭhamāyonaṃ dutiyāyonañca kamena ṭā, ṭe honti puṃ, napuṃsakesu. Ṭānubandho sabbādesattho.
analyzed: a taḥ paṭhamā yonam dutiyā yonam ca kamena ṭāḥ ṭe honti pum napuṃsakesu ṭa anubandhaḥ sabba ādesa tthaḥ
translated: 108. Therefore, in the case of the words for ‘man’, etc., the forms ṭā, ṭe, etc., are made by the method stated in the preceding rule. Ṭānubandha is the meaning of ‘in all places’.

original: Purisā tiṭṭhanti.
analyzed: purisā tiṭṭhanti
translated: Men stand.

original: ‘Gasīna’nti silopo, bho purisa, ‘ayunaṃ vā dīgho’ti dīgho, bho purisā, bhonto purisā, purisaṃ, purise.🔽109. Atena ka. 103; rū. 79; nī. 271.
analyzed: si lopaḥ bho purisa vā dīghaḥ iti dīghaḥ bho purisāḥ bhontaḥ purisāḥ purisam purise  a tena ka rū nī
translated: ‘Gasīna’ is a reduplicate. ‘Long in the case of the words for “man”, etc.’: long, sirs, men, sirs, man, men.

original: Ato nāvacanassa enādeso hoti puṃ, napuṃsakesu.
analyzed: a taḥ nā vacanassa e na ādesaḥ hoti pum napuṃsakesu
translated: . Therefore, in the case of the words for ‘man’, etc., the forms enā, enāni, etc., are made by the method stated in the preceding rule.

original: Purisena.🔽110. Suhisvasse ka. 101; rū. 80; nī. 68.
analyzed: purisena  suhisvasse ka rū nī
translated: By a man.

original: Su, hisu paresu assa e hoti puṃ, napuṃsakesu.
analyzed: su hi su paresu assa e hoti pum napuṃsakesu
translated: . In the case of the words for ‘friend’, etc., the forms e, ehi, etc., are made by the method stated in the preceding rule.

original: Purisehi, purisebhi.🔽111. Suu sassa ka. 61; rū. 86; nī. 208.🔽Sassa ādimhi sāgamo hoti. Ukāro uccāraṇattho, ñānubandho ādimhīti dīpanattho.
analyzed: purisehi purisebhi  ru sassa ka rū nī  sassa ādimhi sa āgamaḥ hoti ukāraḥ uccāraṇa atthaḥ ñā anubandhaḥ ādimhi iti dīpana tthaḥ
translated: With friends, with friends.🔽. In the case of the words for ‘friend’, etc., the forms ehi, ehi, etc., are made by the method stated in the preceding rule.🔽By friends, by friends.🔽. In the case of the words for ‘friend’, etc., the forms assa, assā, etc., are made by the method stated in the preceding rule.🔽Of a friend, of friends.

original: Purisassa, ‘sunaṃhisū’ti dīgho. Purisānaṃ, purisasmā, purisamhā.
analyzed: purisassa dīghaḥ purisānam purisasmā purisamhā
translated: . In the case of the words for ‘friend’, etc., the forms amhā, amhākaṃ, etc., are made by the method stated in the preceding rule.

original: 112. Smāsmiṃnaṃ ka. 108; rū. 90; nī. 276.
analyzed: sma asmin nam ka rū nī
translated: . In the case of the words for ‘friend’, etc., the forms amhā, amhākaṃ, etc., are made by the method stated in the preceding rule.

original: Ato smā, smiṃnaṃ kamena ṭā, ṭe honti puṃ, napuṃsakesu.🔽Purisā, purisehi, purisebhi, purisassa, purisānaṃ, purisasmiṃ, purisamhi, purise, purisesu.
analyzed: a taḥ smā smin nam kamena ṭāḥ ṭe honti pum napuṃsakesu  purisā purisehi purisebhi purisassa purisānam purisasmin purisamhi purise purisesu
translated: Therefore, in the feminine and neuter, the forms are the same as those in the masculine.🔽Men, with men, by men, of a man, of men, in a man, in a man, in men, in men.

original: Evaṃ buddho, dhammo, saṅgho, sakko, devo, satto, naro, goṇo, puṅgavo, jaraggavo, sagavo, paragavo, rājagavo, mātugāmo, orodho, dāroiccādi.🔽Visesavidhānamuccate.🔽113. Kvace vā nī. 277.🔽Ato sissa kvaci e hoti vā puṃ, napuṃsakesu.🔽Pume tāva –🔽Vanappagumbe yatha phussitagge khu. pā. 6.13; su. ni. 236, “ke gandhabbe rakkhase🔽ca nāge, ke kimpurise cāpi mānuse. Ke paṇḍite sabbakāmadade. Dīgharattaṃ bhattā me🔽bhavissati” jā. 2.22.1352. Natthi attakāre natthi parakāre natthi purisakāre dī.🔽ni. 1.168, eke ekatthe, same samabhāge, nahevaṃ vattabbe kathā. 1, ke chave siṅgāle,
analyzed: evam buddhaḥ dhammaḥ saṅghaḥ sakkaḥ devo sattaḥ naraḥ goṇaḥ puṅgavaḥ jaraggavaḥ sagavaḥ paragavaḥ rājagavaḥ mātugāmaḥ orodhaḥ dāroiccādi 🔽visesa vidhānam uccate 🔽kva ce vā nī 🔽a taḥ si ssa kva ci e hoti vā pum napuṃsakesu 🔽pume tāva 🔽vanappagumbe yatha phussitagge khu pā su ni ke gandhabbe rakkhase 🔽ca nāge ke kimpurise ca api mānuse ke paṇḍite sabba kāma dade dīgharattam bhattā me 🔽bhavissati jā natthi attakāre natthi parakāre natthi purisakāre 🔽ni eke ekatthe same sama bhāge na ha ivam vattabbe kathā ke chave siṅgāle
translated: Therefore, in the above-mentioned way, the endings -ā, -e, -i, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi, -ehi,

original: ke chave pāthikaputte dī. ni. 3.29-31 iccādi.
analyzed: ke cha ve pāthika putte dī ni icca ādi
translated: and what other Pāṭhikas?

original: Napuṃsake pana –
analyzed: napuṃsake pana
translated: But in the neuter:

original: Bhogavatī nāma mandire, nagare nimmite kañcanamaye jā. 2.22.1370 iccādi.
analyzed: bhogavatī nāma mandire nagare nimmite kañcana maye iccādi
translated: In the palace called Bhogavatī, in the city made of gold, Jā.

original: Vāti kiṃ? Vanappagumbo.
analyzed: vāti kim vanappagumbaḥ
translated: What does it blow? A forest-fire.

original: Kvacīti kiṃ? Puriso.
analyzed: kvaci iti kim purisaḥ
translated: What is somewhere? A man.

original: Mahāvuttinā paṭhamāyonañca kvaci ṭe hoti. Bāle ca paṇḍite ca sandhāvitvā saṃsaritvā
analyzed: mahāvuttinā bāle ca paṇḍite ca sandhāvitvā saṃsaritvā
translated: In the Mahā-vutti the first is sometimes ṭe. Fools and wise men, having run and wandered,

original: dukkhassantaṃ karissanti dī. ni. 1.168, kvaci yonaṃ pakati hoti, vane vāḷamigā ceva,
analyzed: dukkhassantam karissanti ni kvaci yonam pakati hoti vane vāḷamigā ca iva
translated: will make an end of suffering Dī. ni. ., and sometimes the original form is used: In the forest there are wild beasts,

original: acchakokataracchayo, bahūhi paripanthayo jā. 2.22.255, kyassa byapathayo assu iccādi.🔽114. Divādito ka. 206; rū. 165.🔽Divādīhi smiṃno ṭi hoti.
analyzed: bahūhi paripanthayaḥ jā  kyassa bya pathayaḥ assu it cādi  divā dito ka rū  div ādīhi smin naḥ ṭi ho ti
translated: and many dangers, with peacocks and francolin-partridges, Jā. ., and what are the dangers of the ky?🔽Day and so on.🔽In day and so on ṭi is sometimes used.

original: Divi-devaloketyattho.
analyzed: divi deva loka ityattho
translated: In the sky – in the world of the gods is the meaning.

original: Ādisaddena asa bhuvi, niccaṃ vāgamo. Ayyasaddamhā mahāvuttinā ālapane ga, yonaṃ ṭo hoti vā. Bho ayyo ayya vā, bhonto ayyo ayyā vā. Sesaṃ purisasamaṃ.
analyzed: ādi saddena asa bhuvi niccam vā āgamaḥ ayya saddamhā mahāvuttinā ālapane ga yonam ṭaḥ hoti vā bho ayyaḥ ayya vā bhontaḥ ayyaḥ ayyāḥ vā sesam purisa samam
translated: By the word “and so on” (ādisaddena) in the earth, or always the prefix is used. In the Mahā-vutti from the word “venerable” (ayyassa) in addressing, ṭo is sometimes used. “Venerable sir”, “venerable sir”, “venerable sirs”. The rest is the same as for a man.

original: Purisādirāsi niṭṭhito.
analyzed: niṭṭhitaḥ
translated: The group of words beginning with “man” is finished.

original: Manogaṇarāsi
analyzed: manaḥ gaṇa rā asi
translated: The group of words beginning with “mind”

original: Mano, manā, bho mana, bho manā, bhonto manā.🔽115. Manādīhi smiṃsaṃnāsmānaṃ sisoosāsā ka. 181-2, 184; rū. 95-97; nī. 373-4, 376-7.
analyzed: manaḥ manā bho mana bho manā bhontaḥ manā  sis os āsā ka rū nī
translated: Mind, minds, O mind, O minds, venerable sirs, minds.🔽. With manā, etc., in the locative singular, dual, and plural, the endings si, so, sā, sā are used.

original: Tehi smiṃ, sa, aṃ, nā, smānaṃ kamena si, so, o, sā, sā honti vā.
analyzed: smin sa aṃ nā smānam kamena si saḥ o sā sā honti vā
translated: With them in the locative, the endings sa, aṃ, nā, smānaṃ, kamena, si, so, o, sā, sā are used.

original: Manaṃ, mano, mane, manena, manasā, manehi, manebhi, manassa, manaso, manānaṃ, manasmā,
analyzed: manam manaḥ mane manena manasā manehi manebhiḥ manassa manasaḥ manānam manasmā
translated: Mind, mind, minds, by mind, by the mind, with mind, with minds, of mind, of the mind, of minds, from mind,

original: manamhā, manasā, manā, manehi, manebhi, manassa, manaso, manānaṃ, manasmiṃ, manamhi,
analyzed: manamhā manasā manā manehi manebhiḥ manassa manasaḥ manānam manasmin manamhi
translated: from the mind, with mind, with minds, of mind, of the mind, of minds, in mind, in the mind, in minds,

original: manasi, mane, manesu.
analyzed: manasi mane manesu
translated: in mind, in the mind, in minds.

original: Tamo, tapo, tejo, siro, uro, vaco, rajo, ojo, ayo, payo, vayo, saro, yaso, ceto, chando, radhatā, aho iccādi manogaṇo.
analyzed: tamo tapo tejaḥ siraḥ uraḥ vacaḥ rajaḥ ojaḥ ayo payaḥ vayo saraḥ yaso ceto chandaḥ radhatā aho iccādi manas gaṇaḥ
translated: Darkness, austerity, splendor, head, chest, speech, dust, strength, iron, milk, age, lake, fame, heart, desire, the state of being a chariot, day, etc. are the group of words beginning with manā.

original: Idaṃ manogaṇalakkhaṇaṃ. Kriyākamme odanto, nādīnaṃ sāditā, samāsataddhitamajjhe odanto cāti.
analyzed: idam manaḥ gaṇa lakkhaṇam kriyā kamme o dantaḥ na ādīnam sāditā samāsa taddhita majjhe o dantaḥ ca ati
translated: This is the characteristic of the group of words beginning with manā. The ending -o is used in the locative case of verbs and nouns, the endings -ā, etc. are used with the locative of nouns beginning with n, and the ending -o is used in the middle of compounds and in the locative of the secondary suffixes.

original: Yo ve dassanti vatvāna, adāne kurute mano jā. 1.15.61, kassapassa vaco sutvā, tapo idha pakrubbati saṃ. ni. 1.204, ceto paricca jānāti dī. ni. 1.242, siro te bādhayissāmi iccādi.
analyzed: yaḥ ve dassanti vatvāna adāne kurute manaḥ jā kassapassa vacaḥ sutvā tapaḥ idha pakrubbati sam ni cetaḥ paricca jānāti ni siraḥ te bādhayissāmi iccādi
translated: He who, having seen, then gives, makes his mind to be inclined to giving. Having heard the word of Kassapa, he practices austerity here. He knows the mind of another. He will afflict your head.

original: Manasā ce pasannena dha. pa. 2, vippasannena cetasā jā. 2.22.551, vacasā manasā ceva,
analyzed: manasā ce pasannena dha pa  vippasannena cetasā jā  vacasā manasā ca iva
translated: If with a clear mind, with a clear heart, with speech and mind,

original: vandā me te tathāgate parittapāḷi āṭānāṭiyasutta. Ekūnatiṃso vayasā dī. ni. 2.214,
analyzed: me te tathāgate paritta pāḷi āṭānāṭiya sutte ekūnatiṃsaḥ
translated: I pay homage to those Tathāgatas. The Atānātiya Sutta. At the age of twenty-nine,

original: tejasā yasasā jalaṃ vi. va. 857, tapasā uttamo satto, ghatena vā bhuñjassu payasā
analyzed: tejasā yasasā jalam vi va tapasā uttamaḥ sattaḥ ghatena vā bhuñjassu payasā
translated: shining with splendor, the most excellent being, eat with a bowl or with milk,

original: vā, vandāmi sirasā pāde jā. 2.20.68, ye etā upasevanti, chandasā vā dhanena vā jā.
analyzed: vā vandāmi sirasā pāde jā  ye etāḥ upasevanti chandasā vā dhanena vā jā
translated: I pay homage with my head to your feet. Those who serve these, either with desire or with wealth,

original: 2.21.350, urasā panudissāmi jā. 2.22.1833, ayasā paṭikujjhito a. ni. 3.36 iccādi.

original: Yosu aṃ, hi, smā, naṃsu sakhantassa āraṅa hoti. ‘Ṭoṭe vā’ti suttena ārādesato yonaṃ kamena ṭo, ṭe honti.
analyzed: yosu aṃ hi smā naṃsu sakha antassa āraṅa hoti ṭaḥ ṭe vā ati suttena āra ādesataḥ yo nam kamena ṭaḥ ṭe honti
translated: In yosu aṃ, hi, smā, naṃ, sakhantassa āraṅa is the form. ‘Ṭoṭe vā’ is the Sutta. Ṭo, ṭe are the forms from ārādesato by the rule of yonaṃ kamena.

original: Sakhāro tiṭṭhanti. ‘Ghabrahmāditve’ti gassa vikappena ettaṃ, bho sakha, bho sakhā, bho sakhe, hare sakhā kissa maṃ jahāsi jā. 1.6.94.

original: Yuvānā, yuvānehi, yuvānebhi, yuvehi, yuvebhi, yuvassa, yuvino, yuvānaṃ, yuvasmiṃ, yuvamhi, yuve, yuvāne, yuvānesu, yuvesu.

translated: Young men, with young men, by young men, with young men, by young men, of a young man, of a young man, of young men, in a young man, in me, young men, young men, in young men, in young men.

original: Rūpasiddhiyaṃ pana “maghava, yuvādīnamantassa ānādeso hoti vā sabbāsu vibhattīsū”ti rū. 140; nī. 343 vuttaṃ.
analyzed: pana maghava yuva ādīnam antassa āna ādesaḥ hoti vā sabbāsu vibhattīsu iti rū nī vuttam
translated: But in the Rūpasiddhi it is said: “The elision of the final of magha, yuvā, etc., is in all the cases.”

original: Pumā, pumāno, he puma, he pumā.
analyzed: pumān he he pumā
translated: Man, men, O man, O men.

analyzed: gassam ka rū nī

analyzed: he pumam he pumānaḥ pumānam pumāne pume

original: 160. Pumakammathāmaddhānaṃ vā sasmāsu ca ka. 157, 159; rū. 139, 140; nī. 338, 140.
analyzed: pum a kam matha a mad dhānam vā sa sma āsu ca ka       /

analyzed: nāmhi ca sa sma āsu ca puma kamma antaḥ u hoti vā
translated: The elision of the final of nāmhi, and of sa, smā, and of pum, kamma, thā, and addhāna is in u, inside.

original: Maghavasaddo yuvasaddasadisoti rūpasiddhiyaṃ rū. 66 vuttaṃ, guṇavādigaṇikoti saddanītiyaṃ
analyzed: maghava saddaḥ yuva sadda sadisaḥ ti rūpa siddhiyam vuttam guṇavādi gaṇikā iti saddanītiyam
translated: Maghavasaddo yuvasaddasadisoti rūpasiddhiyaṃ rū.  vuttaṃ, guṇavādigaṇikoti saddanītiyaṃ

original: nī. pada. 220 icchito. Aghanti dukkhaṃ pāpañca vuccati, na aghaṃ maghaṃ, sukhaṃ puññañca,
analyzed: nī pade icchitaḥ aghanti dukkham pāpañca vuccati na agham magham sukham puññañca
translated: Nī. Pada. 220. The meaning of the word agha is “pain” and “evil,” and the meaning of the word magha is “pleasure” and “merit.”

original: magho iti purāṇaṃ nāmaṃ assa atthīti maghavāti saṃ. ni. 1.259 attho pāḷiyaṃ dissati.
analyzed: magho iti purāṇam nāmam assa atthi iti maghavā ati sam ni pāḷiyam dissati
translated: The word magha is an ancient name for the moon, and the meaning of the word maghavā is “having the moon,” as is shown in the text.

original: Thāmasaddo purisādigaṇo, thāmena, thāmunā, thāmassa, thāmuno, thāmasmā, thāmamhā, thāmā, thāmunā, thāmassa, thāmuno. Sesaṃ purisasamaṃ.
analyzed: thāma saddo purisa ādi gaṇaḥ thāmena thāmunā thāmassa thāmuno thāmasmā thāmamhā thāmā thāmunā thāmassa thāmuno sesam purisa samam
translated: The word thāma is a word for a man, and it is declined thus: Thāmena, thāmunā, thāmassa, thāmuno, thāmasmā, thāmamhā, thāmā, thāmunā, thāmassa, thāmuno. The rest is like the word purisa.

original: Addhā vuccati kālo. Nādyekavacanesu-dīghena addhunā, addhanā, addhena, dīghassa addhuno,
analyzed: addhā vuccati kālaḥ na ādi ekavacanesu dīghena addhunā addhanā addhena dīghassa addhuno
translated: The word addhā is said to mean “time.” In the singular forms: Dīghena addhunā, addhanā, addhena, dīghassa addhuno,

original: addhussa, addhassa, addhunā, addhumhā, addhusmā, addhā, addhamhā, addhasmā, addhuno,
analyzed: addhussa addhassa addhunā addhumhā addhusmā addhā addhamhā addhuno
translated: addhussa, addhassa, addhunā, addhumhā, addhusmā, addhā, addhamhā, addhasmā, addhuno,

original: addhussa, addhassa, addhani, addhe, addhamhi, addhasminti cūḷamoggallāne āgataṃ. Sesaṃ yuvasadisaṃ.
analyzed: addhussa addhassa addhani addhe addhamhi addhasmin ti cūḷa moggallāne āgatam sesam yuva sadisam
translated: addhussa, addhassa, addhani, addhe, addhamhi, addhasminti. This is given in the Cūḷamoggallāna Sutta. The rest is like the word yuvā.

original: Upaddhavācako addhasaddo idha na labbhati, ekaṃsatthavācako ca nipāto eva. “Addhānamaggappaṭipanno”tiādīsu addhānasaddo pana visuṃ siddho napuṃsakaliṅgova.
analyzed: upaddha vācakaḥ addha saddaḥ idha na labbhati ekaṃsattha vācakaḥ ca nipātaḥ eva addhāna magga ppaṭipannaḥ ti ādīsu addhāna saddaḥ pana visum siddhaḥ napuṃsaka liṅgaḥ uva
translated: The word addhā is not found here in the sense of “a long time,” and the indeclinable eva is in the sense of “only.” But the word addhāna is established separately in the sense of “a long time” and is neuter in gender.

original: Muddhasadde “muddhā te phalatu sattadhā, muddhā me phalatu sattadhā” iccādīsu jā.
analyzed: muddha sadde muddhā te phalatu sattadhā muddhā me phalatu sattadhā iccādīsu jā
translated: In the word muddhā, in such passages as “Muddhā te phalatu sattadhā, muddhā me phalatu sattadhā” (Jā.

original: 1.16.295; dha. pa. aṭṭha. 1.tissattheravatthu siro vuccati, “pabbatamuddhaniṭṭhito”🔽iccādīsu dī. ni. 2.70 matthakaṃ vuccati, tadubhayaṃ idha labbhati, smiṃvacane muddhanīti
analyzed: dha pa aṭṭha tissa thera vatthu siraḥ vuccati pabbata muddha niṭṭhito  icca ādīsu dī ni matthakam vuccati tat ubhayam idha labbhati smiṃvacane iti
translated: ..; Dha. Pa. Aṭṭha. .), the elder Tissa’s story), the head is meant; in such passages as “Pabbatamuddhaniṭṭhito”

original: siddhaṃ, sesaṃ yuvasamaṃ. Bālavācako pana purisanayo. Hatthamuṭṭhivācako itthiliṅgo.
analyzed: siddham sesam yuva samam bāla vācako pana purisa nayo hattha muṭṭhi vācako itthi liṅgo
translated: (Th. 1091), the top of the mountain is meant. In the present passage both are meant. The word muddhāni is established in the locative case. The rest is the same as in the word yuva. The word bāla is masculine in gender. The word hatthamuṭṭhi is feminine in gender.

original: Asmā vuccati pāsāṇo, usmā vuccati kāyaggi, bhismā vuccati bhayānako mahākāyo.
analyzed: vuccati pāsāṇaḥ vuccati kāyaggi bhismā vuccati bhayānakaḥ mahā kāyaḥ
translated: The word asmiṃ is a stone; the word usmiṃ is a bodily heat; the word bhismā is a fearful, huge-bodied being.

original: Tattha asmasadde “taṃ te paññāya bhindāmi, āmaṃ pakkaṃva asmanā su. ni. 445, mā tvaṃ cande khali asmanī”ti pāḷī. Sesaṃ yuvasamaṃ. Usmā, bhismāsaddāpi yuvasadisāti vadanti.
analyzed: tattha asmasadde tam te paññāya bhindāmi āmam asmanā su ni mā tvam cande khali asmani iti pāḷī sesam yuvasamam usmā bhismāsaddā api yuvasadisā iti vadanti
translated: Herein, as for the word asma, the text reads: “I split it with my wisdom, as one splits a rawhide with a knife. Do not, Moon, be empty-handed” . The rest is similar to the young man. And they say that the words usma and bhismā are similar to the young man.

original: Cūḷamoggallāne muddha, gāṇḍīvadhanva, aṇima, laghimādayo ca asmasadisāti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: ca vuttam
translated: And the words muddha, gāṇḍī, dhanva, aṇima, laghimā, etc., are said to be similar to the rawhide.

original: Yattha suttavidhānaṃ na dissati, tattha mahāvuttinā vā suttavibhattena vā rūpaṃ vidhiyati.
analyzed: yattha sutta vidhānam na dissati tattha mahāvuttinā vā sutta vibhattena vā rūpam
translated: Where the rule is not seen in the suttas, there it is prescribed by the Great Commentary or by the analysis of the suttas.

original: Iti rājādiyuvādigaṇarāsi.
analyzed: iti rāja ādi yuva ādi gaṇa rāsi
translated: So the mass of the class of young men, etc., kings, etc.

original: Akārantapulliṅgaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: akāra anta pulliṅgam niṭṭhitam
translated: The class of words ending in a vowel is finished.

original: Ākārantapulliṅgarāsi
analyzed: ākāra anta pul liṅga rā si
translated: The class of words ending in a consonant

original: ‘Gasīna’nti silopo, sā tiṭṭhati.
analyzed: sā tiṭṭhati
translated: ‘Gasīna’ is a misprint. It stands thus:

original: ‘Ekavacanayosvaghona’nti yosu ca ekavacanesu ca rasso, ‘ato yona’miccādinā vidhānaṃ, sā tiṭṭhanti.
analyzed: ekavacana yosu aghonanti ca ekavacanesu ca rassaḥ a taḥ yonam iccādinā vidhānam sā tiṭṭhanti
translated: ‘In feminine singulars and in singulars in o there is a short vowel’ . The rule beginning with ‘ato yona’ is not applicable. It stands thus:

original: 163. Sāssaṃse cānaṅa.
analyzed: sās saṃse ca anaṅa
translated: ‘Sāssaṃse cānaṅa’ .

original: Aṃ, sesu ge ca sāsaddassa ānaṅa hoti.
analyzed: aṃ sesu ge ca sā saddassa ānaṅa hoti
translated: ‘Aṃ, sesu ge ca sāsaddassa ānaṅa hoti’ .

original: Bho sāna, bhonto sā, saṃ, sānaṃ, se, sena, sāhi, sābhi, sassa, sānassa, sānaṃ, sasmā, samhā, sā, sāhi, sābhi, sassa, sānassa, sānaṃ, sasmiṃ, samhi, se, sāsu.
analyzed: bho sāna bhonto sā sam sānam se sena sāhi sā abhi sassa sānassa sānam sasmā samhā sā sāhi sā abhi sassa sānassa sānam sasmin samhi se sāsu
translated: Bho sāna, bhonto sā, saṃ, sānaṃ, se, sena, sāhi, sābhi, sassa, sānassa, sānaṃ, sasmā, samhā, sā, sāhi, sābhi, sassa, sānassa, sānaṃ, sasmiṃ, samhi, se, sāsu.

original: Atha vā ‘sāssaṃse cānaṅa’iti sutte casaddo avuttasamuccayatthopi hotītikatvā sito sesāsu vibhattīsupi ānaṅa hoti vā, mahāvuttinā ca ānādesato yonaṃ o.
analyzed: atha vā sāssaṃse ca ānaṅ eti sutte ca saddaḥ a vutta samuccaya tthaḥ pi hoti iti katvā s itaḥ sesāsu vibhattīsu pi hoti vā mahāvuttinā ca āna ādesataḥ o
translated: Or else, in the sutta ‘sāssaṃse cānaṅa’ the word ca has the meaning of a conjunction that is not separated (from the word to which it is attached), and so ānaṅa is also in the other cases, and with the great base the o is from the ānaṅa-change.

original: Sā gacchati, sāno gacchanti, sā vā, he sa, he sā, he sāna, he sā, he sāno, saṃ, sānaṃ, se, sāne iccādi.

translated: Sā gacchati, sāno gacchanti, sā vā, he sa, he sā, he sāna, he sā, he sāno, saṃ, sānaṃ, se, sāne, etc.

original: Saddanītirūpaṃ vuccate –
analyzed: saddanīti rūpam vuccate
translated: The method of the words is stated thus:

translated: The being called Vattahā is Sakka (in the Amarakośa, - in the verse).

original: 164. Vattahā sanaṃnaṃ nonānaṃ.🔽Vattahato sassa no hoti, naṃvacanassa nānaṃ hoti.🔽Vattahāno deti, vattahānānaṃ deti. Sesaṃ yuvasaddasamaṃ.🔽Saddanītiyaṃ pana nā, sesu vattahinā, vattahinoti nīti. pada. 219; (tattha nāmhi vattahānāti dissati) vuttaṃ.🔽Daḷhadhammā, daḷhadhammā, daḷhadhammāno. “Sikkhitā daḷhadhammino”tipi saṃ. ni. 1.209
analyzed: vattahā sanaṃnaṃ nonānaṃ  vatta hataḥ sassa no hoti naṃvacanassa nānam hoti  vatta hānaḥ deti vatta hānānam deti sesam yuva sadda samam  saddanītiyam pana nā sesu vattahinā vattahinoti nīti pada tattha nāmhi vattahānā ati dissati vuttam  daḷha dhammāḥ daḷha dhammāḥ daḷha dhammānaḥ sikkhitāḥ daḷha dhammino tipi sam ni
translated: 164. Of those who have gone to the field, of the fields.🔽The form of the word sassa is no; the form of the word naṃ is nānaṃ.🔽Vattahāno deti, vattahānānaṃ deti. The rest is the same as in the word yuva.🔽But in the Saddanīti it is said: “na, sesu vattahinā, vattahino” .🔽Daḷhadhammā, daḷhadhammā, daḷhadhammāno. “Sikkhitā daḷhadhammino” .

original: pāḷi. Bho daḷhadhammā, bhonto daḷhadhammā, daḷhadhammāno, daḷhadhammino, daḷhadhammānaṃ,🔽daḷhadhammāne, daḷhadhamminā, daḷhadhammehi. Sesaṃ purisasamaṃ. Evaṃ paccakkhadhammāti.🔽Vivaṭacchadasadde pana nāmhi ittaṃ natthi, sesaṃ daḷhadhammasamaṃ. Pāḷiyaṃ pana “daḷhadhammoti🔽vissuto”ti jā. 2.22.300 ca “loke vivaṭacchado”ti dī. ni. 1.258 ca diṭṭhattā ete saddā

analyzed: vuttam idha pana mahāvuttinā siddham

original: Iti ākārantapulliṅgarāsi.
analyzed: iti ākāra anta pulliṅga rāsi

analyzed: ikāra anta pul liṅga rā si

analyzed: lopaḥ muni gacchati

analyzed: lopaḥ ka rū nī
translated: . Elides ka; rū; nī.

original: Jha, lato yonaṃ lopo hoti. ‘Yolopanīsu dīgho’ti dīgho.
analyzed: jha lataḥ lopaḥ hoti yolopanīsu
translated: The jh of jhā is elided before a vowel. ‘Yolopanīsu dīgho’ means long.

original: Munī gacchanti.
analyzed: munī gacchanti
translated: Sages go.🔽. In the feminine jhissa ka; rū; nī.

analyzed: yosu jhissa pume ka rū nī
translated: 166. Yosu jhissa pume ka. 96; rū. 148; nī. 259.

analyzed: pul liṅge yosu jha saññassa ikārassa ṭa hoti vā

analyzed: munayaḥ gacchanti  kim rattiyaḥ daṇḍinaḥ

analyzed: pumā iti kim aṭṭhīni

analyzed: bho muni ayunam vā dīghaḥ iti dīghaḥ bho munī bhontaḥ munī bhontaḥ munayaḥ munim munī munayaḥ muninā munīhi munībhi munissa muninaḥ munīnam munismā munimhā

analyzed: vānamuttāḥ mahesayaḥ ti abhidhamma attha saṅgahe piṭṭhe ca na tam sammaggatāḥ yaññam  upayanti mahesinaḥ etam sammaggatāḥ yaññam upayanti mahesinaḥ sam ni pahantā

analyzed: dha pa nimmāna ratinaḥ devāḥ ye devāḥ vasa vattinaḥ sam ni aṭṭhete cakka vattinaḥ  dhamme dhamma anuvattinaḥ sam ni saggam sugatinaḥ yanti dha pa tomara aṅkusa pāṇinaḥ
translated: The gods who delight in creation, the gods who wield power over others’ creations, the wheel-turning monarchs,🔽the Dhamma-followers, the Dhamma-followers who follow the Dhamma, the well-gone ones go to heaven, those who have goads and hooks in their hands,

original: jā. 2.22.223, daṇḍamuggarapāṇino, ariyavuttino, nipakā santavuttino iccādi.
analyzed: daṇḍa muggara pāṇinaḥ ariya vuttinaḥ nipakā santa vuttinaḥ iccādi
translated: those who have staves and clubs in their hands, those who conduct themselves righteously, those who conduct themselves peacefully.

original: Dutiyāyomhi –
analyzed: dutiya ayomhi
translated: I am the second:

original: Muṭṭhassatine, upaṭṭhitassatine, ariyavuttine, tomara’ṅkusapāṇine jā. 2.22.190 iccādi.
analyzed: muṭṭhassatine upaṭṭhitassatine ariya vuttine tomaraṅkusa pāṇine iccādi
translated: those who are heedless and faithless, those who are heedful and faithful, those who conduct themselves righteously, those who have goads and hooks in their hands.

original: Vātveva? Micchādiṭṭhī janā gacchanti, micchādiṭṭhī jane passati.
analyzed: vātvā eva micchādiṭṭhī janāḥ gacchanti micchādiṭṭhī jane passati
translated: What about ‘wind’? People go by wrong views, one sees people by wrong views.

original: Garū pana “tomara’ṅkusapāṇayo, atthe visāradamatayo”ti ka. 253 rūpāni idha icchanti.
analyzed: garū pana atthe ka rūpāni idha icchanti
translated: But the elders say: ‘Those who have goads and hooks in their hands, those who have confidence in the meaning.’ Here they want ‘forms.’

original: Aññattheti kiṃ? Micchādiṭṭhiyo dhammā, micchādiṭṭhiyo dhamme.
analyzed: aññattha iti kim micchādiṭṭhiyaḥ dhammā micchādiṭṭhiyaḥ dhamme
translated: What about ‘in another meaning’? Wrong views are dhammas, wrong views are dhammas.

original: Pumeti kiṃ? Micchādiṭṭhiniyo itthiyo, micchādiṭṭhīni kulāni.🔽172. Ne smiṃno kvaci nī. 453.
analyzed: pumā iti kim micchādiṭṭhiniyaḥ itthiyaḥ micchādiṭṭhīni kulāni  ne smin naḥ kvaci nī
translated: What about ‘in a male’? Women with wrong views, families with wrong views.🔽. Ne is not in any of these.

original: Pume aññatthe ito smiṃno kvaci ne hoti.
analyzed: pume aññatthe i taḥ smin no kvaci ne hoti
translated: In a male and in another meaning, ne is not in any of these.

original: Kataññumhi ca posamhi, sīlavante ariyavuttine jā. 1.10.78. Sabbakāmasamiddhine kule, chattapāṇine, daṇḍapāṇine, tomara’ṅkusapāṇine jā. 2.22.190 iccādi.🔽Suttavibhattena ītopi smiṃno kvaci ne hoti, mātaṅgasmiṃ yasassine jā. 2.19.96, devavaṇṇine, brahmavaṇṇine, arahantamhi tādine theragā. 1182 iccādi.🔽Ikārantapulliṅgarāsi niṭṭhito.
analyzed: kataññumhi ca posamhi sīlavante ariya vuttine jā sabba kāma samiddhine kule chatta pāṇine daṇḍa pāṇine tomaraṅkusa pāṇine jā  iccādi  sutta vibhattena ī taḥ pi smin no kvaci ne hoti mātaṅgasmim yasassine jā deva vaṇṇine brahma vaṇṇine arahantamhi tādine theragā iccādi  ikāra anta pulliṅga rāsi niṭṭhito
translated: and in a grateful, virtuous, noble-natured person.🔽in a family that is successful in all desires, in a person holding a sunshade, in a person holding a staff, in a person holding a spear or goad.🔽By the Sutta method, ī is not changed to i in the locative case, in the famous Mātaṅga, in a person of divine appearance, in a person of Brahmā’s appearance, in the venerable Tādī, in a person of noble appearance.🔽The collection of nouns ending in a vowel is finished.

original: Īkārantapulliṅgarāsi🔽Īkārante ‘simhi nā’napuṃsakassā’ti suttena simhi rassattaṃ natthi, ‘ge vā’ti ge pare🔽vikappena rasso, yosu ca aṃ, nā, sa, smā, smiṃ su ca ‘ekavacanayosvaghona’nti niccaṃ🔽rasso, daṇḍī gacchati. ‘Jantu hetu’ iccādisuttena vikappena yonaṃ lopo, daṇḍī gacchanti.🔽Pakkhe –🔽173. original: Daṇḍino gacchanti, bhodaṇḍi, bho daṇḍī, bhonto daṇḍino, daṇḍiṃ.🔽174. Naṃ jhīto ka. 224; rū. 153; nī. 451.

original: Sussapi kvaci nesu hoti, susukhaṃ vata jīvāma, verinesu averino dha. pa. 197, verinesu manussesu, viharāma averino. Tattha ‘verinesū’ti verīcittavantesu.

original: Naṃmhi pare ltu, pitādīnaṃ u-kāro āraṅa hoti vā. Imesaṃ mahānāma tiṇṇaṃ satthārānaṃ ekā niṭṭhā udāhu puthu niṭṭhāti a. ni. 3.127. Satthūnaṃ.
analyzed: nam mhi pare l tu pitā ādīnam ukāraḥ hoti vā imesam mahānāma tiṇṇam satthārānam ekā niṭṭhā udāhu puthu niṭṭhāti a ni
translated: The u of the father, etc., is ā or is not. Of these three teachers, is the end one or is the end different?

analyzed: ā ka rū nī
translated: Of teachers.

original: Naṃmhi pare ltu, pitādīnaṃ u-kāro ā hoti vā.
analyzed: nam mhi pare l tu pitā ādīnam ukāraḥ ā hoti vā
translated: Naṃmhi pare ltu, pitādīnaṃ u-kāro ā hoti vā.

original: Satthānaṃ, satthārā, satthārehi, satthārebhi, satthu, satthussa, satthuno, satthūnaṃ, satthārānaṃ, satthānaṃ.
analyzed: satthānam satthārā satthārehi satthārebhi satthu satthussa satthunaḥ satthūnam satthārānam satthānam
translated: Of teachers, by a teacher, by teachers, by teachers, of a teacher, of a teacher’s, of a teacher, of teachers, of teachers, of teachers.

original: 191. Ṭi smiṃno ka. 206; rū. 165; nī. 422.
analyzed: ṭi smin naḥ ka rū nī
translated: Ṭi smiṃno ka. ; rū. ; nī. .

original: Āraṅato smiṃno ṭi hoti.
analyzed: ā ra ṅ ataḥ smin naḥ ṭi
translated: From āraṅka ṭi is made in smiṃ.

original: 192. Rassāraṅa ka. 208; rū. 166; nī. 424.
analyzed: ras sāraṅa ka rū nī
translated: Rassāraṅa ka. ; rū. ; nī. .

original: Smiṃmhi pare āraṅkato rasso hoti.
analyzed: smin mhi pare āraṅkataḥ rassaḥ hoti
translated: In smiṃ the short vowel is made before āraṅka.

original: Satthari, satthāresu.
analyzed: satthari satthāresu
translated: In a teacher, in teachers.

original: Bahulādhikārā nā, smāsu satthunāti ca sumhi satthūsūti ca siddhaṃ. “Dhammarājena satthunā, pūjaṃ labbhati bhattusū”ti jā. 2.22.1517 pāḷi. ‘Bhattusū’ti sāmīsu, ‘bhattāsū’tipi pāṭho.
analyzed: bahula adhikārā nā sma āsu satthunā ati ca sumhi ca siddham dhammarājena satthunā pūjam labbhati bhattusūti sāmīsu
translated: The word nā is used in the sense of bahula, and satthu and satthuno are established in the sense of smā. “By the teacher, the king of the Dhamma, worship is obtained by the disciple” (Jā. .. pāḷi). ‘Bhattusū’ means ‘among disciples’, ‘bhattāsū’ is also a reading.

original: ‘Ltupitādīnamase’ti aseggahaṇena tomhi āraṅa hoti nī. 414, “satthārato satthāraṃ gacchanti, satthārato satthāraṃ ghaṭentī”ti mahāni. 27 pāḷi.
analyzed: l tup ita ādīnam ase ti ase ggahaṇena tomhi āraṅa hoti nī satthārataḥ satthāram gacchanti satthārataḥ satthāram ghaṭenti iti mahāni pāḷi
translated: ‘Satthārato satthāraṃ gacchanti, satthārato satthāraṃ ghaṭentī’ is the text of the Mahā-Niddesa.

original: Evaṃ kattā, bhattā, gantā, jetā, janetā, chettā, cheditā, viññātā, viññāpetā, uṭṭhātā,
analyzed: evam kattā bhattā gantā jetā janetā chettā cheditā viññātā viññāpetā uṭṭhātā
translated: Thus ‘kattā’, ‘bhattā’, ‘gantā’, ‘jetā’, ‘janetā’, ‘chettā’, ‘cheditā’, ‘viññātā’, ‘viññāpetā’, ‘uṭṭhātā’,

original: uṭṭhāpetā, taritā, tāretā, dātā, dāpetā, sandhātā, sandhāpetā, netā, nettā, posetā,
analyzed: uṭṭhāpetā taritā tāretā dātā dāpetā sandhātā sandhāpetā netā nettā posetā
translated: ‘uṭṭhāpetā’, ‘taritā’, ‘tāretā’, ‘dātā’, ‘dāpetā’, ‘sandhātā’, ‘sandhāpetā’, ‘netā’, ‘nettā’, ‘posetā’,

original: bhettā, yātā, vattā, setā, hantā, sakamandhātā, mahāmandhātā iccādayo.
analyzed: bhettā yātā vattā setā hantā sakamandhātā mahāmandhātā icca ādayaḥ
translated: ‘bhettā’, ‘yātā’, ‘vattā’, ‘setā’, ‘hantā’, ‘sakamandhātā’, ‘mahāmandhātā’ and so on.

original: Visesavidhānamuccate.
analyzed: visesa vidhānam uccate
translated: The special rules are stated.

original: Mahāvuttinā yonaṃ ā hoti, avitakkitā gabbhamupavajanti jā. 1.13.138 (visadisaṃ), te bhikkhū brūhetā suññāgārānaṃ.
analyzed: mahāvuttinā yonam ā hoti a vitakkitāḥ gabbham upavajanti jā visadisam te bhikkhū suññāgārānaṃ
translated: ‘Mahāvuttinā yonaṃ ā hoti’ means ‘Mahāvuttinā yonaṃ ā hoti’ is the base of the word ‘ā’. ‘Avitakkitā gabbhamupavajanti jā’ (they enter the womb without thinking) is the text of the Jātaka. ‘Te bhikkhū brūhetā suññāgārānaṃ’ (those monks are the proclaimers of the empty places) is the text of the Vinaya.

original: Amaccavācīhi kattu, khattusaddehi gassa ettaṃ, uṭṭhehi katte taramāno jā. 2.22.1690, natthi bho khatte paroloko dī. ni. 2.408.
analyzed: amacca vācīhi kattu khattu saddehi gassa ettam uṭṭhehi katte taramānaḥ natthi bho khatte parolokaḥ ni
translated: ‘Amaccavācīhi kattu, khattusaddehi gassa ettaṃ’ means ‘Amaccavācīhi kattu’ is the base of the word ‘kattu’. ‘Khattusaddehi gassa ettaṃ’ is the base of the word ‘ettaṃ’. ‘Uṭṭhehi katte taramāno jā’ (arise, O warrior, quickly) is the text of the Jātaka. ‘Natthi bho khatte paroloko dī’ (there is no other world, O warrior) is the text of the Dīghanikāya.

original: Ge pare āraṅa ca hoti, pucchāma kattāra anomapañña, “kattāraṃ anomapañña”ntipi jā. 1.10.28 yujjati.
analyzed: ge pare ca hoti pucchāma kattāra kattāram
translated: and the other is the agent, we ask the one of incomparable discernment, “the one of incomparable discernment” is also correct.

original: Aṃmhi pare pubbassaralopo ca hoti, anukampakaṃ pāṇasamampi bhattuṃ jahanti itthiyo.
analyzed: a ṃmhi pare pubbassara lopaḥ ca hoti anukampakam bhattum jahanti itthiyaḥ
translated: and the other is the object, there is elision of the first syllable, women abandon even a compassionate husband who is like their own life.

original: “So patīto pamuttena, bhattunā bhattugāravo”ti jā. 2.21.48 diṭṭhattā kattunā, gantunā
analyzed: so patītaḥ pamuttena bhattunā bhattu gāravā iti jā diṭṭha ttā kattunā gantunā
translated: “He, being released by the one who is satisfied, by the husband, the one who is satisfied is respectful to the husband,” because of seeing the agent, the goer,

original: iccādīnipi yujjanti.
analyzed: i t ca ādīni pi yujjanti
translated: and so on, are also correct.

original: Nettumhā smiṃno ettaṃ nī. 430, nette ujuṃ gate sati jā. 1.4.133, ete saddā tīsu liṅgesu samānarūpā honti, kattā itthī, kattā puriso, kattā kulaṃ iccādi.
analyzed: smin no ettam nī  nette ujum gate sati jā  ete saddā tīsu liṅgesu samāna rūpāḥ honti kattā itthī kattā purisaḥ kattā kulam iccādi

analyzed: pitā ādiḥ āsi

original: Sabbaññū, sabbaññuno. Sesaṃ suviññeyyaṃ.🔽Viññū, vadaññū, atthaññū, dhammaññū, mattaññū, vidū. Idha kūsaddena rūpaccayantāpi gayhanti, vedagū, pāragū. Tathā bhīrū, pabhaṅgū, virāgūiccādi ca.🔽Ūkārantapulliṅgarāsi niṭṭhito.🔽Okāranto pana gosaddo eva, so pubbe vuttoyeva.
analyzed: sabbaññū sabbaññuno sesam su viññeyyam  viññū vadaññū atthaññū dhammaññū mattaññū vidū idha kū saddena gayhanti vedagū pāragū tathā bhīrū pabhaṅgū virāgū iccādi ca  ūkāra anta pulliṅga rāsi niṭṭhito  okāra antaḥ pana go saddaḥ eva so pubbe vuttaḥ yeva
translated: All-knowing, all-knowing. The rest is easy to understand.

original: Pulliṅgarāsi niṭṭhito.🔽Napuṃsakaliṅgarāsi🔽Akārantanapuṃsaka cittādirāsi🔽Atha napuṃsakaliṅgaṃ dīpiyate. Taṃ pana pañcavidhaṃ adantaṃ, idantaṃ īdantaṃ, udantaṃ, ūdantanti.🔽195. analyzed: naccam rajjam pajjam ambujam dhaññam thaññam araññam puññam kiliṭṭham piṭṭham

translated: bhaṇḍa, tuṇḍa, ñāṇa, tāṇa, leṇa, karaṇa, caraṇa, chatta, khetta, netta,

original: amataṃ, sotaṃ, pīṭhaṃ, vatthaṃ, padaṃ, gadaṃ, āvudhaṃ, kānanaṃ, ghānaṃ, jhānaṃ, dānaṃ,
analyzed: amatam sotam pīṭham vattham padam gadam āvudham kānanam ghānam jhānam dānam
translated: amata, sota, pīṭha, vattha, pada, gada, āvudha, kānana, ghāna, jhāna, dāna,

original: dhanaṃ, vanaṃ, pāpaṃ, dumaṃ, hadayaṃ, cīraṃ, cīvaraṃ, kulaṃ, mūlaṃ, balaṃ, maṅgalaṃ,
analyzed: dhanam vanam pāpam dumam hadayam cīram cīvaram kulam mūlam balam maṅgalam
translated: dhana, vana, pāpa, duma, hadaya, cīra, cīvara, kula, mūla, bala, maṅgala,

original: bhisaṃ, sīsaṃ, lohaṃiccādayo.
analyzed: bhisam sīsam
translated: bhisaṃ, sīsa, loha, etc., are like the words in the citta group.

original: Iti cittādirāsi.🔽Kammādirāsi
analyzed: iti citta ādiḥ āsi  kamma ādiḥ āsi
translated: Thus the citta group.

original: Kammasadde –
analyzed: kamma sadde
translated: The kamma group🔽In the case of the words of the kamma group,

original: 198. Nāsseno ka. 103; rū. 79; nī. 271.
analyzed: nāssenaḥ ka rū nī
translated: 198. Nāsseno ka. 103; rū. 79; nī. 271.

original: Kammādīhi nāssa eno hoti vā.
analyzed: kamma ādīhi na assa enaḥ hoti vā
translated: With kammādīhi, nāsseno is or is not.

original: Kammena, kammanā.
analyzed: kammena kammanā
translated: By means of action, by means of action.

original: ‘Pumakammathāmaddhāna’nti suttena nā, smāsu uttaṃ, kammunā, kammassa, kammuno, kammasmā, kammamhā, kammanā, kammunā, kammassa, kammuno.
analyzed: suttena nā sma āsu uttam kammunā kammassa kammunaḥ kammasmā kammamhā kammanā kammunā kammassa kammunaḥ
translated: ‘By means of a man’s action, by means of a man’s effort’—by means of the Thread, it is not so, with kammunā, kammassa, kammuno, kammasmā, kammamhā, kammanā, kammunā, kammassa, kammuno.

original: 199. Kammādito ka. 197; rū. 125; nī. 404.
analyzed: kamma āditaḥ ka rū nī
translated: . Kammādīhi ka. ; rū. ; nī. .

original: Kammādīhi smiṃno ni hoti vā.
analyzed: kamma ādīhi hoti vā
translated: With kammādīhi, smiṃno ni is or is not.

original: Kammasmiṃ, kammamhi, kammani, kamme. Sesaṃ cittasamaṃ.
analyzed: kammasmim kammamhi kammani kamme sesam citta samam
translated: In action, in action, in action, in action. The rest is the same as in cittasamaṃ .

original: Kamma camma ghamma asma vesma addha muddha aha brahma attaātumā kammādi. Kammani,🔽cammani. “Kiṃ chando kimadhippāyo, eko sammasi ghammanī”ti jā. 1.16.1 ca “kiṃ patthayaṃ🔽mahābrahme, eko sammasi ghammanī”ti jā. 1.13.83 ca “mā tvaṃ cande khali asmanī”ti
analyzed: kamma camma ghamma asma vesma addha muddha aha brahma kamma ādi kammani  cammani kim chandaḥ kim adhippāyaḥ ekaḥ ca kim  mahābrahme ca mā tvam cande khali asmani iti
translated: Kamma, camma, ghamma, asma, vesma, addha, muddha, aha, brahma, attaātumā, kammādi. In action,

original: ca “tamaddasa mahābrahmā, nisinnaṃ samhi vesmanī”ti ca dissanti. Addhani, muddhani,
analyzed: ca tam addasa mahā brahmā nisinnam samhi vesmani iti ca dissanti addhani muddhani
translated: in camma, in ghamma. “What is the desire, what is the aim, that you, O Ghammanī, are alone intent upon?” (Jā. i. 11) and “What is the desire, O Great Brahmā, that you, O Ghammanī, are alone intent upon?” (Jā. i. 12) and “Do not be empty, O Asmanī” (Jā. i. 13) and “The Great Brahmā saw him sitting in the house” (Jā. i. 14) are found. In the head, in the head,

original: ahani, brahmani, attani, ātumani, sabbametaṃ pubbepi vuttameva ca. Tattha ‘sammasī’ti
analyzed: ahani brahmani attani ātumani sabbam etam pubbe api vuttam eva ca tattha sammasi iti
translated: ‘Ahani’, ‘brahmani’, ‘attani’, ‘ātumani’, all these are just as said before.

original: acchasi, ‘ghammanī’ti gimhakāle ātape vā, ‘asmanī’ti pāsāṇe, ‘vesmanī’ti ghare.
analyzed: acchasi ghammani iti gimha kāle ātape vā asmani iti pāsāṇe vesmani iti ghare
translated: Herein, ‘sammasī’ means you breathe, ‘ghammanī’ means in the heat in the hot season, ‘asmanī’ means on a rock, ‘vesmanī’ means in the house.

original: Iti kammādirāsi.🔽200. Aṃ napuṃsake ka. 125; rū. 198; nī. 300; ‘aṃṅaṃ napuṃsake’ (bahūsu)?.
analyzed: iti  am napuṃsake ka rū nī aṃ ṅam napuṃsake bahūsu
translated: Thus the group of words beginning with ‘kamma’.🔽Aṃ is the neuter gender.

original: Napuṃsake simhi ntussa aṃ hoti vā. Silopo.
analyzed: napuṃsake simhi n tussa am hoti vā si lopaḥ
translated: In the neuter gender, aṃ is optionally added to ntu. Silopa.

original: Guṇavaṃ kulaṃ.
analyzed: guṇavam kulam
translated: A family endowed with virtue.

original: Pakkhe –
analyzed: pakkhe
translated: In the dual:

original: Simhi mahāvuttinā ntussa anto a hoti, tato sissa aṃ hoti, guṇavantaṃ kulaṃ.
analyzed: simhi mahāvuttinā ntussa antaḥ a hoti tatas sissa aṃ hoti guṇavantam kulam
translated: In the neuter gender, aṃ is optionally added to ntu, after the great vowel i. Then aṃ is added to s. A virtuous family.

original: ‘Yvādo ntussā’ti yvādīsu ntussantassa attaṃ, guṇavantāni, guṇavantā, he guṇava, he🔽guṇavā, he guṇavantāni, he guṇavantā, guṇavaṃ, guṇavantaṃ, guṇavantāni, guṇavante,
analyzed: yu ādaḥ ntussantassa attam guṇavantāni guṇavantā he guṇava he  guṇavā he guṇavantāni he guṇavantā guṇavam guṇavantam guṇavantāni guṇavante
translated: ‘Yvādo ntussā’ means in the case of yvādo, etc., the ntu is attaṃ. Endowed with virtue, endowed with virtue, O virtuous one,

original: guṇavantena, guṇavatā kulena. Sabbaṃ pulliṅgasamaṃ.
analyzed: guṇavantena guṇavatā kulena sabbam pulliṅga samam
translated: O virtuous one, O virtuous ones, virtuous, virtuous, virtuous, virtuous ones, virtuous, virtuous ones, virtuous ones, by a virtuous one, by a virtuous one, by a virtuous family. All is the same as the feminine.

original: Satimaṃ kulaṃ, satimantaṃ kulaṃ iccādi.
analyzed: satimam kulam satimantam kulam it ca ādi
translated: A mindful family, a mindful family, and so on.

original: Gacchaṃ kulaṃ, gacchantaṃ kulaṃ, gacchantāni kulāni iccādi.
analyzed: gaccham kulam gacchantam kulam gacchantāni kulāni iccādi
translated: Going to a family, going to families, going to families.

original: Iti akārantanapuṃsakarāsi.
analyzed: iti akāra anta napuṃsaka rāsi
translated: Thus the neuter class ending in a.

original: Ikārantanapuṃsakarāsi
analyzed: ikāra anta napuṃsaka rā asi
translated: The neuter class ending in i

original: Aṭṭhi tiṭṭhati, aṭṭhī tiṭṭhanti.🔽201. Jhalā vā ka. 217; rū. 199; nī. 444.
analyzed: aṭṭhi tiṭṭhati aṭṭhī tiṭṭhanti  jha lā vā ka rū nī
translated: A bone stands, bones stand.🔽The neuter class ending in i

original: Napuṃsake jha, lato yonaṃ ni hoti vā. ‘Yolopanīsū’ti dīgho.
analyzed: napuṃsake jha lataḥ yonam ni hoti vā dīghaḥ
translated: In the neuter, i becomes ni after jha, l, and y, optionally. ‘Yolopanīsū’ is long.

original: Aṭṭhīni, he aṭṭhi, he aṭṭhī, he aṭṭhīni, he aṭṭhī vā, aṭṭhiṃ, aṭṭhinaṃ, aṭṭhīni, aṭṭhī, aṭṭhinā, aṭṭhīhi, aṭṭhībhi. Sesaṃ munisamaṃ.
analyzed: aṭṭhīni he aṭṭhi he aṭṭhī he aṭṭhīni he aṭṭhī vā aṭṭhim aṭṭhinam aṭṭhīni aṭṭhī aṭṭhinā aṭṭhīhi aṭṭhībhi sesam muni samam
translated: Bones, O bone, O bones, O bones, O bones, O bones, a bone, of a bone, bones, a bone, of a bone, with bones, with bones. The rest is like the sage.

original: Samāsepi sammādiṭṭhi kulaṃ, sammādiṭṭhīni kulāni iccādi, yonaṃ no, ne natthi.
analyzed: samāse pi sammādiṭṭhi kulam sammādiṭṭhīni kulāni iccādi ya ūnam naḥ ne natthi
translated: In a compound too: right view is a family, right views are families, etc. After y, ni is not.

original: Smiṃmhi sammādiṭṭhismiṃ, sammādiṭṭhimhi, sammādiṭṭhini, sammādiṭṭhine kule, ariyavuttine kule iti vattabbaṃ.
analyzed: smimhi sammādiṭṭhismim sammādiṭṭhimhi sammādiṭṭhini sammādiṭṭhine kule ariyavuttine kule iti vattabbam
translated: In the locative: in right view, in right views, in right view, in right views, in a family, in families, in a family of noble conduct, in families of noble conduct.

original: Evaṃ akkhi, acchi, satthi, dadhi, vāri iccādayo.
analyzed: evam akkhi acchi satthi dadhi vāri icca ādayaḥ
translated: Thus eye, tongue, teeth, curd, water, etc.

original: Iti ikārantanapuṃsakarāsi.
analyzed: iti ikāra anta napuṃsaka rāsi
translated: Thus the neuter class ending in i.

original: Īkārantanapuṃsakarāsi
analyzed: īkāra anta napuṃsaka rāsi
translated: The neuter class ending in ī

original: Īkārante ‘ekavacanayosvaghona’nti suttena simhi rasso, daṇḍi kulaṃ, daṇḍīni kulāni, yonaṃ lope daṇḍī.
analyzed: īkāra ante suttena simhi rassaḥ daṇḍi kulam daṇḍīni kulāni yonam lope daṇḍī
translated: The vowel i is lengthened by the rule ‘In the singular of the feminine, the vowel of the first syllable is lengthened’ (1.2.28), thus simhi, daṇḍi kulaṃ, daṇḍīni kulāni, daṇḍī yonaṃ lope.

original: ‘Ge vā’ti rasso, he daṇḍi, he daṇḍī vā, he daṇḍīni, he daṇḍī, daṇḍiṃ, daṇḍinaṃ, daṇḍīni, daṇḍī, daṇḍinā, daṇḍīhi, daṇḍībhi. Pulliṅgasamaṃ.
analyzed: ge vā ati rassaḥ he daṇḍi he daṇḍī vā he daṇḍīni he daṇḍī daṇḍim daṇḍinam daṇḍīni daṇḍī daṇḍinā daṇḍīhi daṇḍībhi pulliṅga samam
translated: The vowel i is lengthened by the rule ‘The vowel of the first syllable is lengthened before ge’ (1.2.29), thus he daṇḍi, he daṇḍī vā, he daṇḍīni, he daṇḍī, daṇḍiṃ, daṇḍinaṃ, daṇḍīni, daṇḍī, daṇḍinā, daṇḍīhi, daṇḍībhi. The same as the masculine.

original: Samāsepi sīghayāyi cittaṃ, sīghayāyīni, sīghayāyī, he sīghayāyi, he sīghayāyī vā, he sīghayāyīni, he sīghayāyī, sīghayāyiṃ, sīghayāyinaṃ, sīghayāyīni iccādi.
analyzed: samāse pi sīgha yāyi cittam sīgha yāyīni sīgha yāyī he sīgha yāyi he sīgha yāyī vā he sīgha yāyīni he sīgha yāyī sīgha yāyim sīgha yāyinam sīgha yāyīni icca ādi
translated: In a compound too: sīghayāyi cittaṃ, sīghayāyīni, sīghayāyī, he sīghayāyi, he sīghayāyī vā, he sīghayāyīni, he sīghayāyī, sīghayāyiṃ, sīghayāyinaṃ, sīghayāyīni, etc.

original: Evaṃ sukhakāri dānaṃ, cakkī, pakkhī, sukhī, sikhī iccādayo kulasambandhino ca veditabbā.
analyzed: evam sukha kāri dānam cakkī pakkhī sukhī sikhī iccādayaḥ kula sambandhinaḥ ca veditabbā
translated: So too: sukhakāri dānaṃ, cakkī, pakkhī, sukhī, sikhī, etc., and those connected with a family should be known.

original: Iti īkārantanapuṃsakarāsi.
analyzed: iti īkāra anta napuṃsaka rāsi
translated: So much for the neuter class ending in i.

original: Ukārantanapuṃsakarāsi
analyzed: ukāra anta napuṃsaka rā asi
translated: The neuter class ending in u

original: Āyu tiṭṭhati, ‘jhalā vā’ti yonaṃ nitte lope ca dīgho, āyūni, āyū, he āyu, he āyū, he āyūni, he āyū, āyuṃ, āyunaṃ, āyūni, āyū. Sesaṃ bhikkhusamaṃ.
analyzed: āyu tiṭṭhati vāti yonam nitte lope ca dīghaḥ āyūni āyū he āyu he āyū he āyū he āyū āyum āyunam āyūni āyū sesam bhikkhu samam
translated: Āyu tiṭṭhati, the vowel is lengthened by the rule ‘The vowel of the first syllable is lengthened before jhalā, etc.’ (1.2.27), thus āyūni, āyū, he āyu, he āyū, he āyūni, he āyū, āyuṃ, āyunaṃ, āyūni, āyū. The rest is the same as for bhikkhu.

original: Āyusaddo pulliṅgepi vattati, “punarāyu ca me laddho dī. ni. 2.369, āyuñca vo kīvatako
analyzed: āyu saddo pulliṅge pi vattati punar āyu ca me laddhaḥ dī ni āyuḥ ca vaḥ kīvatakaḥ
translated: The word āyu is used in the neuter gender too: “I have obtained life again” (D.ii,136), “How long is your life-span?” (D.ii,136),

original: nu samma jā. 1.15.205, āyu nu khīṇo maraṇañca santike, na cāyu khīṇo maraṇañca dūre”ti pāḷipadāni.
analyzed: nu samma jāḥ āyu nu khīṇaḥ maraṇañca santike na ca āyu khīṇaḥ maraṇañca dūrā iti pāḷipadāni
translated: The word āyu is used in the neuter gender too: “Again life has been granted to me” (D.ii,369), “How long is your life-span, dear Sir?” (J.i,18), “Is life exhausted, and is death near, or is life not exhausted, and is death far off?” (S.i,100).

original: Evaṃ cakkhu, hiṅgu, siggu, jatu, vatthu, matthu, madhu, dhanu, tipu, dāru, vasu, assu iccādayo.
analyzed: evam cakkhu hiṅgu siggu jatu vatthu matthu madhu dhanu tipu dāru vasu assu icca ādayaḥ
translated: So too cakkhu , hiṅgu , siggu , jatu , vatthu , matthu , madhu , dhanu , tipu , dāru , vasu , assu , etc.

original: 202. Ambādīhi ka. 217; rū. 199; nī. 444; ‘ambādīhi’ (bahūsu).
analyzed: ambā ādīhi ka rū nī ambā ādīhi bahūsu
translated: With amba , etc., the k-stem is ka; the r-stem is rū; the n-stem is nī; ‘with amba, etc.’ is in the plural.

original: Ambu, paṃsuiccādīhi smiṃno ni hoti vā.
analyzed: ambu paṃsu icca ādīhi smin naḥ ni hoti vā
translated: With ambu , paṃsu , etc., the s-stem is ni or no.

original: Phalaṃ patati ambuni, pupphaṃ yathā paṃsuni ātape gataṃ. Sesaṃ āyusamaṃ. Citragu, vahagu, digu iccādayopi ukārantapakatikā evāti.
analyzed: phalam patati ambuni puppham yathā paṃsuni ātape gatam sesam āyu samam citragu vahagu digu icca ādayaḥ api ukāra anta pakatikāḥ eva ati
translated: The fruit falls on the ambu , just as a flower falls on the paṃsu when it is heated. The rest is like āyu. Citragu , vahagu , digu , etc., are also natural bases ending in u.

original: Iti ukārantanapuṃsakarāsi.
analyzed: iti ukāra anta napuṃsaka rāsi
translated: So much for the neuter class ending in u.

original: Ūkārantanapuṃsakarāsi
analyzed: ūkāra anta napuṃsaka rā asi

original: Simhi rasso, gotrabhu ñāṇaṃ, gotrabhūni, gotrabhū, he gotrabhu, he gotrabhū, he gotrabhūni,
analyzed: simhi rassaḥ gotra bhu ñāṇam gotra bhūni gotra bhū he gotra bhu he gotra bhū he gotra bhūni
translated: Simhi is the feminine of siṅgālo , rasso is the feminine of rakkha , gotrabhu is the feminine of gotrabhū , ñāṇaṃ is the feminine of ñāṇaṃ , gotrabhūni is the feminine of gotrabhū , he gotrabhū is the vocative of gotrabhū , he gotrabhū is the vocative of gotrabhū , he gotrabhūni is the vocative of gotrabhūni ,

original: hegotrabhū, gotrabhuṃ, gotrabhunaṃ, gotrabhūni, gotrabhū. Sesaṃ pulliṅgasamaṃ. Evaṃ
analyzed: he gotrabhū gotrabhum gotrabhunam gotrabhūni gotrabhū put liṅga samam evam
translated: Hegotrabhū, gotrabhuṃ, gotrabhunaṃ, gotrabhūni, gotrabhū. The rest is the same as the neuter. Thus

original: sayambhu ñāṇaṃ, abhibhu jhānaṃ iccādi.
analyzed: sayambhu ñāṇam abhibhu jhānam iccādi
translated: Sayambhu ñāṇaṃ, abhibhu jhānaṃ, etc.

original: Iti ūkārantanapuṃsakarāsi.

original: Sabbādirāsi
analyzed: sap bādiḥ ā asi

analyzed: atha sabba nāmāni dīpiyante

translated: Sabba, katara, katama, ubhaya, itara, añña, aññatara, aññatama, pubba, para, apara,

analyzed: dakkhiṇa uttara adhara ya ta tya ete ima amu kim eka ubha dviti catu
translated: Dakkhiṇa, uttara, adhara, ya, ta, tya, eta, ima, amu, kiṃ, eka, ubha, dvi, ti, catu,

original: tumha, amha imāni aṭṭhavīsati sabbanāmāni nāma. Sabbesaṃ liṅgatthānaṃ sādhāraṇāni nāmāni sabbanāmāni.
analyzed: tumha amha imāni aṭṭhavīsati sabbanāmāni nāma sabbesam liṅgatthānam sādhāraṇāni nāmāni sabbanāmāni
translated: Tumha, amha. These twenty-eight all-names are names. All-names are names common to all genders and meanings.

original: Tattha sabbasaddo sakalattho.
analyzed: tattha sabba saddaḥ sakala atthaḥ
translated: Herein, the word sabba has the meaning of totality.

original: Katara, katamasaddā pucchanatthā.
analyzed: katara katama saddā
translated: The words katara and katama have the meaning of asking.

original: Ubhayasaddo dvinnaṃ avayavānaṃ samudāyattho.🔽Itarasaddo ekato vuttassa paṭiyogīvacano.
analyzed: ubhaya saddaḥ dvinnam avayavānam samudāya tthaḥ  itara saddo ekatas vuttassa paṭiyogī vacanaḥ
translated: The word ubhaya has the meaning of the totality of two components.🔽The word itara is a term for the opposite of what is stated.

original: Aññasaddo yathādhigatamhā aparavacano.
analyzed: añña saddaḥ yathā adhigatamhā a para vacanaḥ
translated: The word añña is a term for what is other than what is known.

original: Aññatara, aññatamasaddā aniyamatthā.
analyzed: aññatara aññatama saddāḥ a niyama tthā
translated: The words aññatara and aññatamas mean ‘one of several’.

original: Pubbādayo saddā disā, kālādivavatthānavacanā.
analyzed: pubba ādayaḥ saddāḥ disā kāla ādi vavatthāna vacanā
translated: The words pubba, etc., mean ‘direction’, since they are terms for the delimitation of time, etc.

original: Yasaddo aniyamatthavacano.🔽Ta, tyasaddā parammukhe dūravacanā.🔽Etasaddo parammukhe samīpavacano, sammukhe dūravacano. Aṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana “eteti
analyzed: ya saddaḥ a niyama attha vacanaḥ  ta parammukhe dūra vacanā  eta saddo parammukhe samīpa vacano sammukhe dūra vacano aṭṭhakathā ayam pana eta iti
translated: The word yasa means ‘one who is famous’.🔽The words ta and tyā mean ‘far away’ when the person addressed is not present.

original: cakkhupathaṃ atikkamitvā dūragate sandhāyāhā”ti jā. aṭṭha 4.15.104 vuttaṃ, tasmā
analyzed: cakkhu patham atikkamitvā dūra gate sandhāya āha ati jā aṭṭha vuttam tasmā
translated: The word eta means ‘near’ when the person addressed is present, and ‘far away’ when he is not present. But in the Commentary it is said: “The word eta is used with reference to those who are far away, having gone beyond the range of vision.” Therefore

original: tasaddatthepi vattati.
analyzed: tasaddatthe pi vattati
translated: it is also used in the sense of ‘that’.

original: Imasaddo sammukhe samīpavacano.
analyzed: ima saddaḥ sammukhe samīpa vacanaḥ

original: Amusaddo dūravacano. Samīpa, dūratā ca parikappabuddhivasenāpi hoti.
analyzed: amu saddaḥ dūra vacanaḥ ca parikappa buddhi vasena api hoti
translated: The word amu means ‘far away’. And nearness and farness are also according to the idea of proximity or remoteness.

original: Kiṃsaddo pucchanattho.
analyzed: kiṃsaddaḥ pucchana ttho

translated: The word eka means ‘one’ and ‘another’.

analyzed: ubha saddaḥ dvi sadda pariyāyaḥ  tattha tya saddaḥ api bahulam dissati khiḍḍā paṇihitā tyāsu rati tyāsu patiṭṭhitā

analyzed: bījāni tyāsu ruhanti jā katham nu vissase tyamhi jā atha vissasate
translated: Here the word tyā is also often seen: “Play is laid up in them, delight is established in them” , “Seeds grow in them” , “How can you trust him?” , “But if you trust him” ,

analyzed: itarā ekā aññā etā i hoti
translated: In the case of the words itarā, ekā, aññā, etā, imā, i is the substitute.

original: Itarissā kataṃ, itarissā deti, itarissā apeti, itarissā dhanaṃ, itarissā, itarissaṃ ṭhitaṃ. Sesaṃ sabbasamaṃ.
analyzed: itarissā katam itarissā deti itarissā apeti itarissā dhanam itarissā itarissam ṭhitam sesam sabbasamam
translated: Itarissā kataṃ, itarissā deti, itarissā apeti, itarissā dhanaṃ, itarissā, itarissaṃ ṭhitaṃ. The rest is the same in all cases.

original: Aññā, aññā, aññāyo, aññaṃ, aññā, aññāyo, aññāya, aññissā, aññāhi, aññābhi, aññāya,
analyzed: aññāḥ aññāḥ aññāyaḥ aññam aññāḥ aññāyaḥ aññāya aññissā aññāhi aññābhi aññāya
translated: Aññā, aññā, aññāyo, aññaṃ, aññā, aññāyo, aññāya, aññissā, aññāhi, aññābhi, aññāya,

original: aññissā, aññāsaṃ, aññāsānaṃ, aññissā, aññāhi, aññābhi, aññāya, aññissā, aññāsaṃ,
analyzed: aññissā aññāsam aññāsānam aññissā aññāhi aññābhi aññāya aññissā aññāsam
translated: aññissā, aññāsaṃ, aññāsānaṃ, aññissā, aññāhi, aññābhi, aññāya, aññissā, aññāsaṃ,

original: aññāsānaṃ, aññāya, aññissā, aññāyaṃ, aññissaṃ, aññāsu. Sesaliṅgesu sabbasamaṃ.
analyzed: aññāsānam aññāya aññissā aññāyam aññissam aññāsu sesa liṅgesu sabbasamam
translated: aññāsānaṃ, aññāya, aññissā, aññāyaṃ, aññissaṃ, aññāsu. The rest is the same in all cases.

original: “Aññatarissā itthiyā paṭibaddhacitto hotī”ti pārā. 73 pāḷi, idha suttavibhattena sijjhati. Sesaṃ aññatara, aññatamesu sabbasamaṃ.
analyzed: aññatarissā itthiyā paṭibaddha cittaḥ hoti iti idha sutta vibhattena sijjhati sesam aññatara aññatamesu sabbasamam
translated: “He is attached to a certain woman” is a Pārājika rule. Here it is established by the locative case. The rest is the same in all cases in the words aññatara and aññatamasmiṃ.

original: Iti sabbādiaṭṭhakarāsi.
analyzed: iti sabba ādi aṭṭhakarā asi
translated: Thus the eight groups of all words.

original: Pubbā itthī, pubbā, pubbāyo, pubbaṃ, pubbā, pubbāyo, pubbāya, pubbassā, pubbāhi,
analyzed: pubbā itthī pubbā pubbāyaḥ pubbam pubbā pubbāyaḥ pubbassā pubbāhi
translated: The feminine of pubba is pubbā, the neuter pubbam, the feminine plural pubbāyo, the nominative singular pubbā, the accusative pubbāya, the genitive pubbassā, the instrumental pubbāhi,

original: pubbābhi, pubbāya, pubbassā, pubbāsaṃ, pubbāsānaṃ, sattamiyaṃ pubbāya, pubbassā,
analyzed: pubbābhi pubbāya pubbassa pubbāsam pubbāsānam sattamiyam pubbāya pubbassa
translated: the dative and ablative pubbābhi, the locative pubbāya, the genitive plural pubbassā, the instrumental pubbāsaṃ, the ablative pubbāsānaṃ. In the seventh case the feminine is pubbāya, the masculine and neuter pubbassa,

original: pubbāyaṃ, pubbassaṃ, pubbāsu.
analyzed: pubbāyam pubbassam pubbāsu
translated: the feminine plural pubbāsu.

original: 211. Pubbādīhi chahi ka. 164; rū. 200; nī. 347; caṃ. 2.1.15; pā. 1.1.34.
analyzed: pubba ādīhi chahi ka rū nī cam pā
translated: The six words beginning with pubba are declined like ka, rū, nī, caṃ, pā.

original: Tehi chahi yonaṃ eṭa hoti vā.
analyzed: tehi chahi vā
translated: With the six words beginning with pubba, eṭa is used optionally.

original: Pubbe, pubbā, pare, parā, apare, aparā, dakkhiṇe, dakkhiṇā, uttare, uttarā, adhare,
analyzed: pubbe pubbā pare parāḥ apare aparāḥ dakkhiṇe dakkhiṇāḥ uttare uttarāḥ adhare
translated: The feminine of pacchima is pacchima, the neuter pacchimaṃ, the feminine plural pacchimayo, the nominative singular pacchima, the accusative pacchimaṃ, the genitive pacchimaṃ, the instrumental pacchimahi,🔽the dative and ablative pacchimabhi, the locative pacchimaṃ, the genitive plural pacchimaṃ, the instrumental pacchimahi, the ablative pacchimahi. In the seventh case the feminine is pacchimaya, the masculine and neuter pacchimaṃ,🔽the feminine plural pacchimahi. The feminine of dakkhiṇa is dakkhiṇā, the neuter dakkhiṇaṃ, the feminine plural dakkhiṇayo, the nominative singular dakkhiṇā, the accusative dakkhiṇaṃ, the genitive dakkhiṇāya, the instrumental dakkhiṇāya,🔽the dative and ablative dakkhiṇābhi, the locative dakkhiṇāya, the genitive plural dakkhiṇānaṃ, the instrumental dakkhiṇībhi, the ablative dakkhiṇābhi. In the seventh case the feminine is dakkhiṇāya, the masculine and neuter dakkhiṇaṃ,

original: adharā. Tattha ‘pubbe pubbā’ti puratthimadisābhāgā, tatraṭṭhakā vā atthā, purātanā
analyzed: adharā tattha pubbe pubbā ati puratthima disā bhāgā vā atthā purātanā
translated: the feminine plural dakkhiṇībhi. The feminine of uttara is uttarā, the neuter uttaraṃ, the feminine plural uttarayo, the nominative singular uttarā, the accusative uttaraṃ, the genitive uttarāya, the instrumental uttarāya,

original: vā sattā saṅkhārā ca. “Pubbabuddhā, pubbadevā, pubbācariyā”tiādīsu “pubbe buddhā🔽pubbabuddhā, pubbā buddhā vā pubbabuddhā”tiādinā attho veditabbo. Evaṃ sesesu.
analyzed: vā sattā saṅkhārā ca pubba buddhā pubba devā pubba ācariyā ati ādīsu pubbe buddhā 🔽pubba buddhāḥ pubbāḥ buddhāḥ vā pubba buddha ati ādinā atthaḥ veditabbaḥ evam sesesu
translated: the dative and ablative uttarābhi, the locative uttarāya, the genitive plural uttarānaṃ, the instrumental uttarībhi, the ablative

original: Pubbesaṃ, pubbesānaṃ, paresaṃ, paresānaṃ, aparesaṃ, aparesānaṃ, dakkhiṇesaṃ, dakkhiṇesānaṃ, uttaresaṃ, uttaresānaṃ, adharesaṃ, adharesānaṃ. Sesaṃ ñeyyaṃ.
analyzed: pubbesam pubbesānam paresam paresānam aparesam aparesānam dakkhiṇesam dakkhiṇesānam uttaresam uttaresānam adharesam adharesānam sesam ñeyyam
translated: Pubbe, pubbesaṃ, paresaṃ, paresānaṃ, aparesaṃ, aparesānaṃ, dakkhiṇesaṃ, dakkhiṇesānaṃ, uttaresaṃ, uttaresānaṃ, adharesaṃ, adharesānaṃ. The rest should be understood.

original: Pubbādīhīti kiṃ? Sabbe.
analyzed: pubba ādīhi iti kim sabbe
translated: What as to ‘pubbe, etc.’? Sabbe.

original: Chahīti kiṃ? Ye, te.
analyzed: chahi iti kim ye te
translated: What as to ‘chahi’? Ye, te.

original: 212. Nāññañca nāmappadhānā caṃ. 2.1.10; pā. 1.1.27-29.🔽Suddhanāmabhūtā ca samāse appadhānabhūtā ca sabbādito pubbe vuttaṃ sabbādikāriyaṃ🔽aññañca upari vuccamānaṃ sabbādikāriyaṃ na hoti. Tattha suddhanāmabhūtaṃ sabbādināma
analyzed: nāññañca nāma ppadhānā cam pā  suddha nāma bhūtā ca samāse appadhāna bhūtā ca sabba āditaḥ pubbe vuttam sabba ādi kāriyam  aññañca upari vuccamānam sabba ādi kāriyam na hoti tattha suddha nāma bhūtam sabba ādi nāma
translated: . And ‘aññañca nāma’ is not a principal word.🔽In a compound, a pure name is not a principal word. The rule stated above as to ‘pubbe, etc.’🔽does not apply to ‘aññañca, etc.’, which is stated later. Herein, the word ‘aññañca’ is a foolish person’s word in the sense of ‘does not know’,

original: na jānātīti atthena bālavācako aññasaddo, ājānātīti atthena majjhemaggaphalañāṇavācako
analyzed: na jānāti iti atthena bāla vācakaḥ añña saddaḥ ājānāti iti atthena majjhe magga phala ñāṇa vācakaḥ
translated: the word ‘aññañca’ is a person of middle sort’s word in the sense of ‘knows’,

original: aññasaddo, arahattaphalañāṇavācako aññasaddo, ‘pubbo lohita’ntiādīsu pubbasaddo,
analyzed: añña saddaḥ arahatta phala ñāṇa vācakaḥ añña saddaḥ pubbaḥ lohita nti ādīsu pubba saddaḥ
translated: the word ‘aññañca’ is a person of superior sort’s word in the sense of ‘knows’, the word ‘pubba’ in the passage ‘pubbo lohita’ ,🔽the word ‘para’ in the passage ‘atirekaparamā’ ,

original: atirekaparamādivācako parasaddo, disākālādito aññesu atthesu pavattā dakkhiṇu’ttarasaddā
analyzed: atireka parama ādi vācako para saddaḥ disā kāla āditaḥ aññesu atthesu pavattā dakkhiṇa uttara saddā
translated: the words ‘dakkhiṇa’ and ‘uttara’ in the passage ‘dakkhiṇodakkhiṇā’ ,

original: ca saṅkhyatthavācito añño ekasaddo cāti sabbametaṃ suddhanāmaṃ nāma, tato sabbādikāriyaṃ natthi.
analyzed: ca saṅkhyā attha vācitaḥ aññaḥ eka saddo ca ati sabbam etam suddhanāmam nāma tatas sabba ādi kāriyam natthi
translated: and the word eka, which is a numeral and a name, and the word eka, which is a name only, and the word eka, which is a name and a verbal expression, and the word eka, which is a name and a numeral—all these are pure names, and there is no function of the base in any of them.

original: Appadhāne diṭṭhapubba, gatapubba, piyapubba iccādi. Tattha pubbe diṭṭho diṭṭhapubbo
analyzed: a ppadhāne diṭṭha pubba gata pubba piya pubba iccādi tattha pubbe diṭṭhaḥ diṭṭha pubbaḥ
translated: In the indeclinable class: diṭṭhapubbaṃ, gatapubbaṃ, piyapubbaṃ, etc. Herein, diṭṭhapubbaṃ means seen before.

original: buddho purisena. Pubbe diṭṭho yenāti vā diṭṭhapubbo puriso buddhaṃ. Evaṃ gatapubbo
analyzed: buddhaḥ purisena pubbe diṭṭhaḥ yena ati vā diṭṭha pubbaḥ purisaḥ buddham evam gata pubbaḥ
translated: The man saw the Buddha. Or: The man who saw before is the man who saw the Buddha.🔽The man went along the road. Or: The man who went before is the man who went along the road.

original: maggo purisena, gatapubbo vā puriso maggaṃ. Piyā vuccati bhariyā, piyā pubbā purāṇā
analyzed: maggaḥ purisena gata pubbaḥ vā purisaḥ maggam piyā vuccati bhariyā piyā pubbā purāṇā
translated: Piya is a wife. Piyā pubbā is an old wife.🔽The man who has an old wife is piyapubba. Piya is a husband. Piyo pubbo yassa is an old husband.

original: etassāti piyapubbo, piyo vuccati pati, piyo pubbo yassāti piyapubbā. Etehi ca sabbādikāriyaṃ natthi.
analyzed: etassa ati piya pubbaḥ piyaḥ vuccati pati piyaḥ pubbaḥ yassa ati piya pubbāḥ etehi ca sabba ādi kāriyam natthi
translated: And there is no function of the base in any of these.

original: 213. Tatiyatthayoge nī. 350; caṃ. 2.1.11; pā. 1.1.30.
analyzed: tatiya ttha yoge nī cam pā
translated: In the third-case co-ordination: nī, caṃ, pā.

original: Tatiyatthena padena yoge sabbādikāriyaṃ natthi.
analyzed: tatiya tthena padena yoge sabba ādi kāriyam na atthi
translated: In co-ordination with a third-case word there is no function of the base.

original: Māsena pubbānaṃ māsapubbānaṃ.
analyzed: māsena pubbānam māsa pubbānam
translated: Māsena pubbānaṃ is of the months that went before.

analyzed: cattha samāse ka rū nī cam pā
translated: In the sixth-case co-ordination: ka, rū, nī, caṃ, pā.

original: Catthasamāso vuccati dvandasamāso, tasmiṃ sabbādikāriyaṃ natthi.
analyzed: cattha samāsaḥ vuccati dvanda samāsaḥ tasmin sabba ādi kāriyam na atthi
translated: Sixth-case co-ordination is called compound co-ordination. There is no function of the base in that.

original: Dakkhiṇā ca uttarā ca pubbā ca dakkhiṇuttarapubbā, dakkhiṇuttarapubbānaṃ.🔽Cattheti kiṃ? Dakkhiṇassā ca pubbassā ca yā antaradisāti dakkhiṇapubbā, dakkhiṇā ca sā pubbā cāti dakkhiṇapubbā, dakkhiṇapubbassā, dakkhiṇapubbassaṃ.
analyzed: dakkhiṇā ca uttarā ca pubbā ca dakkhiṇa uttara pubbā dakkhiṇa uttara pubbānam  catthā iti kim dakkhiṇassā ca pubbassā ca yā antaradisā ati dakkhiṇa pubbā dakkhiṇā ca sā pubbā ca ati dakkhiṇa pubbā dakkhiṇa pubbassā dakkhiṇa pubbassam
translated: And southern and northern and eastern and southern-and-northern-and-eastern, of the southern-and-northern-and-eastern.🔽What is the fourth? That which is between the southern and the eastern is the south-eastern, and it is southern and it is eastern, thus it is south-eastern; of the south-eastern, of the south-eastern one.

original: 215. Veṭa ka. 165; rū. 208; nī. 348; caṃ. 2.1.13; pā. 1.1.32.🔽Catthasamāse yonaṃ eṭa hoti vā.🔽Katarakatame, katarakatamā, itaritare, itaritarā, aññamaññe, aññamaññā, pubbapare, pubbaparā, pubbāpare, pubbāparā iccādi.🔽Imesu pubbādīsu smā, smiṃnaṃ ā, ettaṃ hoti, pubbā, pubbe, parā, pare, aparā, apare, dakkhiṇā, dakkhiṇe, uttarā, uttare, adharā, adhare.🔽Iti pubbādichakkarāsi.

analyzed: tassā katam tāhi tābhi tāya tassā  tā assi vā ka rū nī

translated: Her.

translated: ‘I am not’ (anamhi) is a word in the text (jā. .. (anamhi kāle susoṇi))—in this place the word anamhi is not a substitute for the word smiṃ of the great declension.

original: Imaṃ cittaṃ.

translated: This is mind, these are minds, this is, this is that, these are, by this, by this, by these, by this, by this, by these. All is the same as the feminine.

original: Idha missakarūpaṃ vuccati –
analyzed: idha missaka rūpam vuccati
translated: Here mixed-up matter is called🔽She, she, they, that, she, she, they, that,

original: Yā, sā itthī, yā, tā itthiyo, yaṃ, taṃ itthiṃ, yā, esā itthī, yā, etā itthiyo, yaṃ,🔽etaṃ itthiṃ, yā, ayaṃ itthī, yā, imā itthiyo, yaṃ, imaṃ itthiṃ, yo, so puriso, ye, te purisāiccādayo.
analyzed: yā sā itthī yāḥ tāḥ itthiyaḥ yam tam itthim yāḥ esā itthī yāḥ etāḥ itthiyaḥ yam  etam itthim yā ayam itthī yāḥ imāḥ itthiyaḥ yam imam saḥ purisaḥ ye te
translated: she, she, they, that, she, she, they, that, he, he, they, they, and so on.

original: “Sa kho so kumāro vuddhimanvāyā”ti ettha so so kumāroti, ‘ese se eke ekatthe’ti ettha🔽eso so eko ekatthoti vattabbaṃ. Tattha pubbaṃ pubbaṃ atthapadaṃ, paraṃ paraṃ byañjanamattaṃ.
analyzed: sa kho saḥ kumāraḥ vuddhim anvāyāti ettha saḥ so kumāro ti ese se eke ekattha iti ettha  eso saḥ ekaḥ eka atthaḥ iti vattabbam tattha pubbam pubbam attha padam param param byañjana mattam
translated: “That boy, having grown up” , here “that that boy” should be said to be “this this one one” . Here the meaning-word comes first and the mere letter comes last.

original: “Ayaṃ so sārathi etī”ti jā. 2.22.51 ettha pana dvepi visuṃ visuṃ atthapadāni evāti.
analyzed: ayam saḥ sārathi eti iti jā ettha pana dve api visum visum attha padāni eva ati
translated: “This is the charioteer coming” , here, however, both are meaning-words each separately.

original: Yaṃ, taṃ, idanti ime saddā nipātarūpāpi hutvā pāḷivākyesu sañcaranti sabbaliṅgavibhattīsu abhinnarūpāti.
analyzed: yam tam idam ti ime saddāḥ nipāta rūpā api hutvā pāḷi vākyesu sañcaranti sabba liṅga vibhattīsu abhinna rūpā ati
translated: The words “that this here” , etc., are also used as particles in the sentences of the texts, and they are of invariable form in all genders and in all cases.

original: 226. Imetānamenānvādese dutiyāyaṃ nī. 375-6 piṭṭhe; pā. 2.4.34.
analyzed: dutiya ayam nī piṭṭhe pā
translated: These are the endings in the second case.

original: Anvādeso vuccati anukathanaṃ, punakathanaṃ, anvādesaṭhāne ima, etānaṃ enādeso hoti dutiyāvibhattīsu.
analyzed: anvādesaḥ vuccati anukathanam punakathanam anvādesa ṭhāne ime etānam ena ādesaḥ hoti dutiyā vibhattīsu
translated: It is said that a “repetition” is a re-statement, a re-telling. In the place of the repetition, these are the endings in the second case.

original: Imaṃ bhikkhuṃ vinayaṃ ajjhāpehi, atho enaṃ bhikkhuṃ dhammaṃ ajjhāpehi, ime bhikkhū🔽vinayaṃ ajjhāpehi, atho ene bhikkhū dhammaṃ ajjhāpehi, etaṃ bhikkhuṃ vinayaṃ ajjhāpehiiccādinā

original: vattabbaṃ. Tamenaṃ bhikkhave nirayapālā a. ni. 3.36, yatvādhikaraṇamenaṃ bhikkhuṃ

original: iccādīsupi dī. ni. 1.213 anukathanameva.

original: Asukā itthī, asukā, asukāyo. Asuko puriso, asukā purisā. Asukaṃ kulaṃ, asukāni kulāni. Sabbaṃ kaññā, purisa, cittasamaṃ.
analyzed: asukā itthī asukā asu kāyaḥ asukaḥ purisaḥ asukā purisā asukam kulam asukāni kulāni sabbam kaññā purisa citta samam
translated: This woman, these women, these women. This man, these men. This family, these families. All is the same as in the feminine of ‘girl’ and ‘man’ and ‘mind’.

original: ‘Itthiyamatvā’ti ettha ‘itthiyaṃ ā’ti vibhattasuttena kiṃsaddato itthiyaṃ āpaccayo.🔽232. Kiṃssa ko ka. 227-9; rū. 270, 226; nī. 456-7-8? ‘kissa ko sabbāsu’ (bahūsu).
analyzed: itthiyam atvā ati ettha itthiyam ā ti vibhatta suttena kiṃsaddataḥ itthiyam ā paccayaḥ  kiṃssa kaḥ ka rū  nī kissa kaḥ sabbāsu bahūsu
translated: In the case of the feminine of ‘woman’ here, the case-ending is made by the rule ‘in the feminine of a noun in -ī’.🔽What?🔽What is his, is so of all.

original: Sabbesu vibhattipaccayesu kiṃssa ko hoti.
analyzed: sabbesu vibhatti paccayesu kiṃssa kaḥ hoti
translated: In all case-endings what is his is so.

original: Kā itthī, kā, kāyo, kaṃ, kā, kāyo, kāya, kassā iccādi sabbasamaṃ. Ko puriso, ke purisā, kaṃ, ke, kena, kehi, kebhi, kassa.🔽233. Ki sasmiṃsu vānitthiyaṃ.🔽Anitthiliṅge sa, smiṃsu kiṃsaddassa ki hoti vā.🔽Kissa, kesaṃ, kesānaṃ, kasmā, kamhā, kehi, kebhi, kassa, kissa, kesaṃ, kesānaṃ, kasmiṃ, kamhi, kismiṃ, kimhi, kesu.🔽234. Kimaṃsisu napuṃsake ‘kimaṃsisu saha napuṃsake’ (bahūsu).🔽Napuṃsake aṃ, sisu kiṃsaddassa tehi aṃsīhi saha kiṃ hoti.🔽Kiṃ cittaṃ, kāni, kiṃ, kaṃ vā, kāni. Sesaṃ pulliṅgasamaṃ. Idaṃ pucchanatthassa suddhakiṃsaddassa rūpaṃ.
analyzed: kā itthī kā kāyaḥ kam kā kāyaḥ kassa iccādi sabbasamam ko puriso ke purisā kam ke kena kehi kebhi kassa  ki sasminsu vā anitthiyam  an itthi liṅge sa sminsu kiṃsaddassa ki hoti vā  kissa kesam kesānam kasmā kamhā kehi kebhi kassa kissa kesam kesānam kasmin kamhi kismin kimhi kesu  kimaṃsisu napuṃsake kimaṃsisu saha napuṃsake bahūsu  napuṃsake aṃ si su kiṃsaddassa tehi aṃsīhi saha kim hoti  kim cittam kāni kim kam vā kāni sesam pulliṅga samam idam pucchana atthassa suddha kim saddassa rūpam
translated: Kā itthī, kā, kāyo, kaṃ, kā, kāyo, kāya, kassā, etc., are all the same as the foregoing. Ko puriso, ke purisā, kaṃ, ke, kena, kehi, kebhi, kassa, etc., are all the same as the foregoing.🔽233. Kiṃ is in the feminine.🔽In the feminine gender, kiṃ is kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, kiṃ, ki
