original: kiñci itthiṃ, kāci, kāyaci, kāhici, kāyaci, kassāci, kāsañci, kutoci, kāhici. Sattamiyaṃ🔽- kāyaci, katthaci, kāsuci.
analyzed: kiñci itthim kāci kāyaci kāhici kāyaci kassāci kāsañci kutoci kāhici sattamiyam  kāyaci katthaci kāsuci
translated: Herein, some here, somewhere, some here.

original: Koci puriso, keci, kiñci, keci, kenaci, kehici, kassaci, kesañci, kismiñci, kimhici, katthaci, kesuci.
analyzed: koci puriso keci kiñci keci kenaci kehici kassaci kesañci kismiñci kimhici katthaci kesuci
translated: Any man, some, anything, some, by anyone, by some, of anyone, of some, in anything, anywhere, somewhere, anywhere.

original: Kiñci kulaṃ, kānici kulāni, kiñci, kānici. Sesaṃ pulliṅgasamaṃ.
analyzed: kiñci kulam kānici kulāni kiñci kānici sesam pulliṅga samam
translated: Any family, some families, anything, some. The rest is the same as the neuter.

original: Puna yasaddena yutte sakalatthaṃ vadati. Yā kāci itthī, yākāci itthiyo.
analyzed: punar ya saddena yutte sakalattham vadati yā kāci itthī yā kāci
translated: Again, when connected with the word “which,” it expresses the whole meaning. Any woman, any women.

original: Yo koci puriso, ye keci, yaṃ kiñci, ye keci yena kenaci, yehi kehici, yassa kassaci,
analyzed: yaḥ koci purisaḥ ye keci yam kiñci ye keci yena kenaci yehi kehici yassa kassaci
translated: Any man, some, anything, some, by anyone, by some, of anyone,

original: yesaṃ kesañci yato kutoci, yehi kehici, yassa kassaci, yesaṃkesañci, yasmiṃ kismiñci,🔽yamhi kimhici, yattha katthaci, yesu kesuci.
analyzed: yatas kutoci yehi kehici yassa kassaci yesaṃkesañci yasmin kismiñci  yamhi kimhici yattha katthaci yesu kesuci
translated: of some, from anywhere, by some, of anyone, of some, in anything,🔽anywhere, somewhere, in some.

original: Yaṃ kiñcicittaṃ, yāni kānici, yaṃ kiñci, yāni kānici. Sesaṃ pulliṅgasamaṃ.
analyzed: yam kiñcid cittam yāni kānici yam kiñci yāni kānici sesam put liṅga samam
translated: Any consciousness, some, anything, some. The rest is the same as the neuter.

original: Saṅkhyārāsi
analyzed: saṅkhyā rāj asi
translated: The Collection of Numerals

original: Ekasaddo saṅkhyatthe pavatto ekavacanantova, aññatthe pavatto ekabahuvacananto.
analyzed: eka saddo saṅkhya atthe pavatto eka vacana ntaḥ va aññatthe pavatto eka bahuvacana ntaḥ
translated: The word eka, when it denotes number, is the singular form of the base eka; when it denotes something else, it is the singular and plural form of the base eka.

original: Tattha saṅkhyatthe – ekā itthī, ekaṃ, ekāya, ekissā iccādi. Punnapuṃsakesu ekavacanesu purisa, cittarūpameva.
analyzed: tattha saṅkhyā atthe ekā itthī ekam ekāya ekissā iccādi punnapuṃsakesu ekavacanesu purisa citta rūpam eva
translated: Herein, when it denotes number: one woman, one, to one, to one woman, etc.; in the case of the masculine and neuter, one man, one form.

original: Aññatthe – ekā itthī, ekā itthiyo, ekaṃ, ekā, ekāya, ekissā, ekāhi, ekābhi iccādi.🔽Eko puriso, eke, ekaṃ, eke, ekena, ekehi, ekebhi, ekassa, ekesaṃ, ekesānaṃ. Pulliṅga sabbasamaṃ.
analyzed: aññatthe ekā itthī ekā itthiyaḥ ekam ekā ekāya ekissaṃ ekāhi ekābhi iccādi  ekaḥ purisaḥ eke ekam eke ekena ekehi ekebhi ekassa eka esam eka esānam pulliṅga sabba samam
translated: When it denotes something else: one woman, one women, one, one woman, to one, to one woman, by one, by one woman, etc.🔽One man, one men, one, one man, one men, by one, by one man, by one man, by one men, of one, of one man, of one men. The same as the neuter.

original: Ekaṃ kulaṃ, ekāni kulāni, ekaṃ kulaṃ, ekāni kulāni. Sesaṃ pulliṅgasamaṃ.
analyzed: ekam kulam ekāni kulāni ekam kulam ekāni kulāni sesam pulliṅga samam
translated: One family, one families, one family, one families. The rest is the same as the neuter.

original: Kapaccaye pare sabbādirūpaṃ natthi.
analyzed: ka paccaye pare sabba ādi rūpam na atthi
translated: In the case of the preposition eka, there is no other form beginning with sabba, etc.

original: “Ekikā sayane setu, yā te ambe avāhari jā. 1.4.175. Ekākinī gahaṭṭhāhaṃ, mātuyā paricoditā”ti
analyzed: ekikā sayane setu yā te ambe avāhari jā ekākinī gahaṭṭhā aham mātuyā paricoditā ati
translated: “Alone on the bed, O my mother, you who brought me forth, I am a single woman, urged on by my mother” (Therīgāthā 1.1).

original: apa. therī 2.3.188 pāḷi, ekako puriso, ekakaṃ, ekakena. Ekakaṃ kulaṃ iccādi ekavacanantameva,
analyzed: apa therī pāḷi ekakaḥ purisaḥ ekakam ekakena ekakam kulam iccādi eka vacana antam eva
translated: The verse of the Elder Nun Apa, one man, one, by one, one family, etc., are only the singular form.

original: ekakānaṃ bahutte vattabbe dve ekakā, dve ekake, dvīhi ekakehīti labbhati. “Pañcālo
analyzed: ekakānam bahutte vattabbe dve ekakāḥ dve ekake dvīhi ekakehi iti labbhati pañcālaḥ
translated: When it is said of one or many, two ones, two ones, by two ones, is allowable. “Five from Pañcāla,

original: ca videho ca, ubho ekā bhavantu te”ti pāḷi. Iminā nayena bahuvacanampi labbhati. ‘Ekā’ti missakā.
analyzed: ca videho ca ubho ekā bhavantu te iti iminā nayena bahuvacanam pi labbhati ekā ati missakā
translated: In the case of the singular of many, two singulars, two singulars, with two, with one, two, etc., is allowable. The text has: “Pañcāla and Videha, both of them are one to you” . In this way the plural is also allowable. “One” is mixed.

original: Paṭisedhayutte pana anekā itthiyo, anekāsaṃ itthīnaṃ. Aneke purisā, anekesaṃ purisānaṃ.
analyzed: paṭisedha yutte pana anekāḥ itthiyaḥ anekāsam itthīnam aneke purisāḥ anekesam purisānam
translated: But in the case of the negative, many women, many women’s, many men, many men’s,

original: Anekāni kulāni, anekesaṃ kulānaṃ. Pāḷiyaṃ pana “nekāni dhaññagaṇāni, nekāni khettagaṇāni,
analyzed: anekāni kulāni anekesam kulānam pāḷiyam pana nekāni dhañña gaṇāni nekāni khetta gaṇāni
translated: many families, many families’ . But in the texts there is also “many kinds of grain, many kinds of fields,

original: nekānaṃ dhaññagaṇānaṃ, nekānaṃ khettagaṇāna”ntipi atthi.
analyzed: nekānam dhañña gaṇānam nekānam khetta gaṇānam tipi atthi
translated: of many kinds of grain, of many kinds of fields” .

original: Ekacca, ekacciya, kati, bahusaddāpi idha vattabbā. Ekaccā itthī, ekaccā, ekaccāyoti sabbaṃ kaññāsamaṃ.
analyzed: kati bahu saddā api idha vattabbā ekaccāḥ itthī ekaccāḥ sabbam kaññāsamam
translated: And “some”, “some”, “how many”, and the words for “many” should be mentioned here too. Some women, some, some, all is the same as “a maiden”.

original: Ekacco puriso.🔽135. Ekaccādīhyato ‘ekaccādīhato’ (bahūsu).
analyzed: ekaccaḥ purisaḥ  ekacca adīhyataḥ ekacca adīhataḥ bahūsu
translated: Some man.

original: Akārantehi ekaccādīhi yonaṃ ṭe hoti.
analyzed: akāra antehi ekacca ādīhi yonam ṭe hoti
translated: . In the case of “some” and so on, “in the case of ‘some’ and so on” (in many).🔽The feminine is ṭe with “some” and so on that do not end in a vowel.

original: Ekacce purisā, ekacce purise. Sesaṃ purisasamaṃ. Ādisaddena appekacca, ekatiya, ubhādayo saṅgayhanti. Appekacce purisā, ekatiye purisā, ubhe purisā.
analyzed: ekacce purisāḥ ekacce purise sesam purisa samam ādi saddena appekaccaḥ ekatiyaḥ ubh ādayaḥ saṅgayhanti appekacce purisāḥ ekatiye purisāḥ ubhe purisā
translated: Some men, some men. The rest is the same as in the case of man. The word ādi includes some, one, both, etc. Some men, one man, two men.

original: Ekaccaṃ cittaṃ.
analyzed: ekaccam cittam
translated: Some consciousness.

original: 236. Na nissa ṭā.
analyzed: na nis ṭā
translated: Not with nissaṭṭha.

original: Ekaccādīhi nissa ṭā na hoti.
analyzed: ekacca ādīhi nissa ṭā na hoti
translated: With ekacca, etc., it is not.

original: Ekaccāni cittāni. Sesaṃ cittasamaṃ.
analyzed: ekaccāni cittāni sesam citta samam
translated: Some consciousnesses. The rest is the same as in the case of consciousness.

original: Ekacciya, ekacceyya, ekatiyasaddā kaññā, purisa, cittanayā. “Itthīpi hi ekacciyā,
analyzed: ekacciya ekacceyya ekatiya saddā kaññā purisa cittanayā itthī pi hi ekacciyā
translated: The words ekacciya, ekacceyya, ekatiya are like the words kaññā, purisa, citta. “Even one woman,

original: seyyā posa janādhipa saṃ. ni. 1.127. Saccaṃ kirevamāhaṃsu, narā ekacciyā idha. Kaṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: seyyā posa janādhipa sam ni saccam narāḥ ekacciyāḥ idha kaṭṭham
translated: better, O Lord of men, is a support to a man. They say, it seems, ‘In this world, men,

original: niplavitaṃ seyyo, na tvevekacciyo naro”ti jā. 1.1.73 ca “parivāritā muñcare ekacceyyā”ti
analyzed: niplavitam ca parivāritā ca
translated: even one, are better than a log of wood washed about in the water.’ ” Jā. 1.11. “Some, surrounded, let go of one”

original: ca “na vissase ekatiyesū”ti ca pāḷī – tattha ‘niplavita’nti udakato ubbhataṃ.
analyzed: ca na ekatiyesu iti ca pāḷī tattha niplavitam ti udakataḥ ubbhatam
translated: “One should not trust some” is the text. There ‘washed about’ is what is risen from the water.

original: Katisaddo bahuvacanantova.
analyzed: kati saddaḥ bahuvacana ntaḥ vā
translated: The word kati has only the plural ending.

original: 237. Ṭikatimhā rū. 120 piṭṭhe.🔽Katimhā yonaṃ ṭi hoti.
analyzed: ṭi ka timhāḥ rū piṭṭhe 🔽katimhā yonam ṭi hoti
translated: . Ṭi, timhā, rū, piṭṭhe.🔽Ṭi is for timhā in the feminine.

original: Kati itthiyo, kati purisā, kati purise, kati cittāni. Katihi itthīhi, katihi purisehi, katihi cittehi.
analyzed: kati itthiyaḥ kati purisā kati purise kati cittāni katihi itthīhi katihi purisehi katihi cittehi
translated: How many women, how many men, how many cognizances?

original: 238. Bahukatīnaṃ ‘bahu katinnaṃ’ (bahūsu).
analyzed: bahukatīnam bahu bahūsu
translated: In the case of many, ‘of many’ is (bahūsu).

original: Naṃmhi bahu, katīnaṃ ante nuka hoti.🔽Katinnaṃ itthīnaṃ, katinnaṃ purisānaṃ, katinnaṃ cittānaṃ, ayaṃ nāgamo bahulaṃ na
analyzed: namhi bahu katīnam ante nuka hoti  katinnam itthīnam katinnam purisānam katinnam cittānam ayam na āgamaḥ bahulam na
translated: In the case of many, at the end of nuka is bahu.

original: hoti, ‘katinaṃ tithīnaṃ pūraṇī katimī’ti ca dissati. “Bahūnaṃ vassasatānaṃ, bahūnaṃ
analyzed: hoti tithīnam pūraṇī katimī iti ca dissati bahūnam vassa satānam bahūnam
translated: In the case of many women, many men, many cognizances, this bahulaṃ does not occur, and ‘katimī is seen as ‘of how many days is the full moon day? ‘ “Of many hundreds of years, of many

original: vassasahassāna”nti ca “bahūnaṃ kusaladhammānaṃ, bahūnaṃ akusaladhammāna”nti ca “bahūnaṃ
analyzed: vassa sahassānam ti ca bahūnam kusala dhammānam bahūnam akusala dhammānam ti ca bahūnam
translated: thousands of years” and “of many profitable ideas, of many unprofitable ideas” and “for the benefit of many

original: vata atthāya, uppajjiṃsu tathāgatā”ti vi. va. 807 ca pāḷī.
analyzed: vata atthāya uppajjiṃsu tathāgatāti vi va ca pāḷī
translated: people, the Enlightened Ones arise” is the text.

original: Katisu itthīsu, katisu purisesu, katisu cittesu.
analyzed: katisu itthīsu katisu purisesu katisu cittesu
translated: In how many women, in how many men, in how many cognizances?

original: Bahusadde dvīsu naṃvacanesu bahunnaṃ, bahunnanti vattabbaṃ. Sesaṃ dhenu, bhikkhu, āyusadisaṃ.
analyzed: bahu sadde dvīsu naṃ vacanesu bahunnam bahunnam ti vattabbam sesam dhenu bhikkhu āyu sadisam
translated: In the case of many sounds, in the case of the two nuka-declensions, bahunnanti should be said. The rest is like cow, monk, life.

original: Kapaccaye kaññā, purisa, cittasadisaṃ, bahū itthiyo, bahukā itthiyo. Bahū purisā,
analyzed: ka paccaye kaññā purisa citta sadisam bahū itthiyaḥ bahukāḥ itthiyaḥ bahū purisā
translated: In the Instrumental case, a girl, a man, like the mind, many women, many women, many men,

original: bahavo purisā, bahukā purisā. Bahūni cittāni, bahukāni cittāni iccādinā vattabbaṃ.
analyzed: bahavaḥ purisāḥ bahukā purisāḥ bahūni cittāni bahukāni cittāni iccādinā vattabbam
translated: many men, many men, many minds, many minds, etc., should be said.

original: Bahūnaṃ samudāyāpekkhane sati ekavacanampi labbhati, “bahujanassa atthāya bahujanassa
analyzed: bahūnam samudāya apekkhane sati ekavacanam pi labbhati bahu janassa atthāya bahu janassa
translated: When a collection of many is intended, the singular is also found: “For the benefit of many people,

original: hitāya, bahuno janassa atthāya hitāyā”ti a. ni. 1.141 pāḷi.
analyzed: hitāya bahuno janassa atthāya hitāya ati a ni
translated: for the welfare of many people, for the benefit, for the welfare of many people,” A. ni. . pāḷi.

original: Ubhasaddo bahuvacanantova, ‘ubhagohi ṭo’ti yonaṃ ṭo, ubho itthiyo, purisā, kulāni gacchanti, ubho itthiyo, purisā, kulāni passati.
analyzed: ubha saddaḥ bahuvacana antaḥ va ubhago hi ṭaḥ ti yonam ṭaḥ ubho itthiyo purisā kulāni gacchanti ubho itthiyo purisā kulāni passati
translated: The word “both” has only the plural ending. “Both” has ṭo by the rule “ubhagohi ṭo.” Both women, men, families go. Both women, men, families he sees.

original: 239. Suhisubhasso nī. 313.
analyzed: suhi subhassaḥ nī
translated: . Suhisubhasso nī. .

original: Su, hisu ubhassa anto o hoti.
analyzed: su hi su ubhassa antaḥ o hoti
translated: Su, hisu, o is in the middle of ubha.

original: Ubhohi, ubhosu.
analyzed: ubhohi ubhosu
translated: By both, in both.

original: 240. Ubhinnaṃ ka. 86; nīrū. 227; nī. 341.
analyzed: u bhinnam ka nī rū nī
translated: . Ubhinnaṃ ka. ; nīrū. ; nī. .

original: Ubhamhā naṃvacanassa innaṃ hoti.
analyzed: ubhamhā naṃvacanassa innam hoti
translated: Inna is in the Instrumental case.

original: Ubhinnaṃ. Sabbattha itthi, purisa, kulehi yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: ubhinnam sabbattha itthi purisa kulehi yojetabbam
translated: Of both. Everywhere it should be connected with women, men, families.

original: 241. Yomhi dvinnaṃ duvedve ka. 132; rū. 228; ni. 310.
analyzed: dvinnam duvedve ka rū ni
translated: . Yomhi dvinnaṃ duvedve ka. ; rū. ; ni. .🔽.

original: Yosu savibhattissa dvissa duve, dve honti. ‘Dvinna’nti vacanaṃ dvissa bahuvacanantaniyamatthaṃ.
analyzed: yosu sa vibhattissa dvissa duve dve honti vacanam dvissa bahuvacana nta niyama ttham
translated: In the case of the dual, two are used with the case endings. The word ‘dvinnaṃ’ is for the purpose of making the plural invariable.

original: Dve itthiyo, dve purisā, dve purise, dve cittāni, duve itthiyo, duve purisā, duve purise, duve cittāni, dvīhi, dvībhi.
analyzed: dve itthiyaḥ dve purisāḥ dve purise dve cittāni duve itthiyaḥ duve purisāḥ duve purise duve cittāni dvīhi dvībhi
translated: Two women, two men, two persons, two thoughts, two women, two men, two persons, two thoughts, by two, by two.

original: 242. Naṃmhi nuka dvādīnaṃ sattarasannaṃ ka. 67; nī. 229; nī. 214.🔽Naṃmhi pare dvādīnaṃ aṭṭhārasantānaṃ sattarasannaṃ saṅkhyānaṃ ante nuka hoti. U-kāro uccāraṇattho. Kānubandhaṃ disvā anteti ñāyati.🔽Dvinnaṃ.🔽243. Duvinnaṃ naṃmhi ka. 132; rū. 228; nī. 244.🔽Naṃmhi savibhattissa dvissa duvinnaṃ hoti vā.🔽Duvinnaṃ, dvīhi, dvībhi, dvinnaṃ, duvinnaṃ, dvīsu. Mahāvuttinā sumhi duve hoti, nāgassa
analyzed: nam mhi nu ka dva ādīnam sattarasa nnam ka nī nī  naṃ mhi pare dvi ādīnam aṭṭhārasa antānam sattarasannam saṅkhyānam ante hoti ukāraḥ uccāraṇa atthaḥ ka anubandham disvā anta iti ñāyati  dvinnam  duvinnam namhi ka rū nī  nam mhi sa vibhattissa dvissa du vinnam hoti vā  duvinnam dvīhi dvībhi dvinnam duvinnam dvīsu mahāvuttinā sumhi duve hoti nāgassa
translated: In the case of the genitive, nuka is used for the twenty-two, the seventeen, the twenty-two, the eighteen, the seventeen.

analyzed: duvesu dantesu nimmitā vi va cakkāni pādesu duvesu vindati

original: Evañca sati duvehi, duvebhītipi siddhameva hoti, ayaṃ dvisaddo ubhasaddo viya aliṅgo.🔽244. Tisso catasso yomhi savibhattīnaṃ ka. 133; rū. 230; nī. 311.
analyzed: evam ca sati siddham eva hoti ayam dvi saddaḥ ubha saddaḥ viya aliṅgaḥ  tissaḥ catassaḥ yaḥ omhi sa vibhattīnam ka rū nī
translated: And so it is established that there are two by two, etc., too. This word duve is like the word ubho, which is not a sign.

original: Itthiyaṃ yosu savibhattīnanti, catunnaṃ tisso, catasso honti.
analyzed: itthiyam yosu sa vibhattīnam ti catunnam tissaḥ catassaḥ honti
translated: Tisso catasso yomhi savibhattīnanti, catunnaṃ tisso, catasso honti.

original: Tisso itthiyo, catasso itthiyo.
analyzed: tisso itthiyo catasso itthiyo
translated: Tisso itthiyo, catasso itthiyo.

original: Mahāvuttinā hisu ca tissa, catassā honti, “tissehi catassehi parisāhi, catassehi sahito lokanāyako”ti pāḷī. Tīhi, tībhi itthīhi, catūhi, catūbhi, catubbhi itthīhi.
analyzed: mahāvuttinā hisu ca tissa catassā honti tissehi catassehi parisāhi catassehi sahitaḥ loka nāyakaḥ ti pāḷī tīhi tībhi itthīhi catūhi catūbhi catubbhi itthīhi
translated: Tisso, catasso, however, are with the Mahāvagga, “With three, with four assemblies, the Leader of the world is accompanied by four” .

original: 245. Naṃmhi ticatunnamitthiyaṃ tissacatassā dī. ni. 3.205.
analyzed: nam mhi ti catur nam itthiyam tissa catassāḥ dī ni
translated: Naṃmhi ticatunnamitthiyaṃ tissacatassā dī. ni. ..

original: Itthiyaṃ naṃmhiti, catunnaṃ tissa, catassā honti.🔽Tissannaṃ itthīnaṃ, catassannaṃ itthīnaṃ, tiṇṇaṃ itthīnaṃ, catunnaṃ itthīnaṃ, samaṇo
analyzed: itthiyam naṃmhi iti catunnam tissa catassāḥ honti  tissannam itthīnam catassannam itthīnam tiṇṇam itthīnam catunnam itthīnam samaṇaḥ
translated: Itthiyaṃ naṃmhiti, catunnaṃ tissa, catassā honti.

original: gotamo catunnaṃ parisānaṃ sakkato hoti, catunnaṃ parisānaṃ piyo hoti manāpoti dī.
analyzed: gotamo catunnam parisānam sakkataḥ hoti catunnam parisānam piyaḥ hoti manāpaḥ iti dī
translated: Tissannaṃ itthīnaṃ, catassannaṃ itthīnaṃ, tiṇṇaṃ itthīnaṃ, catunnaṃ itthīnaṃ, the recluse Gotama is honoured by four assemblies, is dear to four assemblies, is loved by four assemblies” .

original: ni. 1.304, tissehi, catassehi, tīhi, tībhi, catūhi, catūbhi, catubbhi, tissannaṃ,
analyzed: ni tissehi catassehi tīhi tībhi catūhi catūbhi catubbhi tissannam
translated: with three, four, three, three, four, four, four, of three,

original: catassannaṃ, tiṇṇaṃ, catunnaṃ, tīsu, catūsu.
analyzed: catassannam tiṇṇam catunnam tīsu catūsu
translated: of four, of three, of four, in three, in four.

original: Pāḷiyaṃ “catassehī”ti diṭṭhattā tissesu, catassesūtipi diṭṭhameva hoti.🔽246. Pume tayo cattāro ka. 133; rū. 230; nī. 311.
analyzed: pāḷiyam catassehi iti diṭṭha ttā tissesu catassesu iti pi diṭṭham eva hoti  pume tayaḥ cattāro ka rū nī
translated: Since “with four” is seen in the texts, “with three” and “with four” are seen too.🔽In the masculine there are three and four.🔽In the neuter there are four and four with case endings.

original: Pulliṅge yosu savibhattīnanti, catunnaṃ tayo, cattāro honti.
analyzed: pul liṅge yosu catunnam tayaḥ cattāraḥ honti
translated: Of four, of three, four, four are used.

original: Tayo purisā, tayo purise, cattāro purisā, cattāro purise.🔽247. Caturo catussa ka. 78, 205, 31; rū. 160; nī. 234; ‘caturo vā catussa’ (bahūsu).
analyzed: tayo purisā tayo purise cattāro purisā cattāro purise  caturaḥ catussa ka    rū nī caturaḥ vā catussa bahūsu
translated: Three men, three persons, four men, four persons.

original: Pume savibhattissa catusaddassa caturo hoti.
analyzed: pume sa vibhattissa catu saddassa caturaḥ hoti
translated: In the masculine with case endings four is used for the word catus.

original: Caturo purisā, caturo purise. Kathaṃ caturo nimitte nādassiṃ, caturo phalamuttameti? “Liṅgavipallāsā”ti vuttiyaṃ vuttaṃ, tīhi, tībhi, catūhi, catūbhi, catubbhi.
analyzed: caturaḥ purisā caturaḥ purise katham caturaḥ nimitte caturaḥ phalam uttamā iti liṅga vipallāsā ati vuttiyam vuttam tīhi tībhi catūhi catūbhi catubbhi
translated: Four men, four persons. How is it that “I saw four signs” and “Four fruits are said to be attained”? It is said in the commentary that there is a change of gender: with three, with three, with four, with four, with four.

original: 248. Iṇṇaṃiṇṇannaṃ tito jhā ka. 87; rū. 231; nī. 243; ‘ṇṇaṃṇṇannaṃtiko jhā’ (bahūsu).🔽Jhasaññamhā timhā naṃvacanassa iṇṇaṃ, iṇṇannaṃ honti.
analyzed: iṇ ṇaṃ iṇ nannam titaḥ jhā ka rū nī bahūsu  jha sam ñamhā timhā naṃ vacanassa iṇ ṇam iṇ nan nam honti
translated: The forms iṇṇaṃ, iṇṇannaṃ are formed by adding iṇṇaṃ, iṇṇannaṃ to the three, the four, etc., in the nominative case.

original: Tiṇṇaṃ, tiṇṇannaṃ, catunnaṃ, tīhi, tībhi, catūhi, catūbhi, catubbhi, tiṇṇaṃ, tiṇṇannaṃ, catunnaṃ, tīsu, catūsu.🔽249. Tīṇicattāri napuṃsake ka. 133; rū. 230; nī. 311.🔽Napuṃsake yosu savibhattīnanti, catunnaṃ tīṇi, cattāri honti.
analyzed: tiṇṇam tiṇṇannam catunnam tīhi tībhi catūhi catūbhi catubbhi tiṇṇam tiṇṇannam catunnam tīsu catūsu  tīṇi cattāri napuṃsake ka rū nī  napuṃsake yosu sa vibhattīnam ti catunnam tīṇi cattāri honti
translated: The forms tiṇṇaṃ, tiṇṇannaṃ, catunnaṃ, tīhi, tībhi, catūhi, catūbhi, catubbhi, tiṇṇaṃ, tiṇṇannaṃ, catunnaṃ, tīsu, catūsu are formed by adding the case endings to the three, the four, etc., in the nominative case.🔽249. The three, the four, etc., are formed by adding i, o to the three, the four, etc., in the neuter.🔽The forms tīṇi, cattāri are formed by adding i, o to the three, the four, etc., in the neuter.

original: Tīṇi cittāni, cattāri cittāni. Sesaṃ pulliṅgasamaṃ.
analyzed: tīṇi cittāni cattāri cittāni sesam pulliṅga samam
translated: The forms tīṇi cittāni, cattāri cittāni are formed by adding i, o to the three, the four, etc., in the neuter. The rest is the same as in the masculine.

original: Vacanasiliṭṭhatte pana sati visadisaliṅgavacanānampi padānaṃ aññamaññasaṃyogo hoti,
analyzed: pana sati visadisa liṅga vacanānam pi padānam aññamañña saṃyogaḥ hoti
translated: But when there is a rule of speech, there is a combination of words with different genders and numbers,

original: cattāro satipaṭṭhānā dī. ni. 3.145, cattāro sammappadhānā dī. ni. 3.145, tayomahābhūtā,
analyzed: cattāro satipaṭṭhānā cattāro sammappadhānā tayo mahābhūtā
translated: e.g. cattāro satipaṭṭhānā, cattāro sammappadhānā, tayo mahābhūtā,

original: tayo mahābhūte paṭṭhā. 1.1.58, sabbe mālā upenti maṃ dhu. 3.6, sabbe kaññā upenti
analyzed: tayaḥ mahābhūte paṭṭhā sabbe mālāḥ upenti mam sabbe kaññāḥ upenti
translated: tayo mahābhūte paṭṭhapeti, sabbe mālā upenti maṃ, sabbe kaññā upenti maṃ,

original: maṃ dhu. 3.6, sabbe ratanā upenti maṃ dhu. 3.6, sabbe yānā upenti maṃ dhu. 3.6, avijjāya
analyzed: mam dhu sabbe ratanāḥ upenti mam dhu sabbe yānāḥ upenti mam dhu avijjāya
translated: All jewels approach me, all vehicles approach me, ignorance,

original: sati saṅkhārā honti, saṅkhāresu sati viññāṇaṃ hoti saṃ. ni. 2.50 iccādi.
analyzed: sati saṅkhārāḥ honti saṅkhāresu sati viññāṇam hoti sam ni iccādi
translated: when there is ignorance, volitional formations come to be, when there are volitional formations, consciousness comes to be, thus, etc.

original: Gāthāsu vipallāsāpi bahulaṃ dissanti, aññe dhammāni desenti, evaṃ dhammāni sutvāna,
analyzed: gāthāsu vipallāsā api bahulam dissanti aññe dhammāni desenti evam dhammāni sutvāna
translated: In the verses, perversions are also seen much, others teach the teachings, having heard the teachings thus,

original: satañca dhammāni sukittitāni sutvā, atthāni cintayitvāna, uttamatthāni tayi labhimhā,
analyzed: satañca dhammāni su kittitāni sutvā atthāni cintayitvāna uttamatthāni tayi labhimhā
translated: and having heard the well-proclaimed teachings, having reflected on the meanings, we have attained the highest meanings in you,

original: kiṃ tvaṃ atthāni jānāsi, iccheyyāmi bhante sattaputtāni, siviputtāni avhaya jā. 2.22.2235,
analyzed: kim tvam atthāni jānāsi iccheyyāmi bhante satta puttāni sivi puttāni
translated: do you know the meanings? I wish, venerable sir, for seven sons, the sons of Sivi, O you who are young,

original: puttadārāni posenti, balībaddāni soḷasa iccādi.
analyzed: putta dārāni posenti balībaddāni soḷasaḥ iccādi
translated: they support wives and children, the sixteen domestic animals, thus, etc.

original: Idha sesasaṅkhyānāmāni dīpiyante.
analyzed: idha sesa saṅkhyā nāmāni dīpiyante
translated: Here the names of the remaining numbers are illustrated.

original: 250. Ṭa pañcādīhi cuddasahi ka. 134; rū. 251; nī. 247.
analyzed: ṭa pañca ādīhi cut dasahi ka rū nī
translated: . Ṭa with five and so on up to fourteen, ka. ; rū. ; nī. .

original: Pañcādīhi aṭṭhārasantehi saṅkhyāsaddehi yonaṃ ṭa hoti.
analyzed: pañca ādīhi aṭṭhārasa antehi saṅkhyā saddehi ya ūnam ṭa hoti
translated: Ṭa is substituted for the final vowel of the numeral from five to eighteen.

original: Pañca itthiyo, pañca purisā, purise, pañca cittāni, cha itthiyo.
analyzed: pañca itthiyo pañca purisā purise pañca cittāni cha itthiyo
translated: Five women, five men, men, five minds, six women.

original: Ḷāgame pana “itthibhāvā na muccissaṃ, chaḷāni gatiyo imā”ti pāḷi.
analyzed: ḷāgame pana itthi bhāvā na muccissam chaḷāni gatiyaḥ imā ati
translated: But in the Lāghava, the text reads: “I will not be released from the state of a woman, these are the six destinations.”

original: Cha purisā, cha purise, cha cittāni. Evaṃ satta, aṭṭha, nava, dasa, ekādasa…pe… aṭṭhārasa.
analyzed: cha purisā cha purise cha cittāni evam satta aṭṭha nava dasa ekādasape aṭṭhārasa
translated: Six men, six men, six thoughts. So seven, eight, nine, ten, eleven … and so on up to eighteen.

original: 251. Pañcādīnaṃ cuddasannama ka. 90; rū. 252; nī. 247.
analyzed: pañca ādi nam cud dasa nama ka rū nī
translated: The five and the rest, up to the fourteen, ka. ; rū. ; nī. .

original: Su, naṃ, hisu pañcādīnaṃ cuddasannaṃ assa attameva hoti, na ettaṃ vā dīghattaṃ vā hoti.
analyzed: su nam hi su pañca ādīnam assa attam eva hoti na ettam vā dīghattam vā hoti
translated: Su, naṃ, hisu, in the five and the rest, up to the fourteen, it is only atta, not ettaṃ or dīghattaṃ.

original: Pañcahi, pañcannaṃ, pañcasu, chahi, channaṃ, chasu, sattahi, sattannaṃ, sattasu,🔽aṭṭhahi, aṭṭhannaṃ, aṭṭhasu, navahi, navannaṃ, navasu, dasahi, dasannaṃ, dasasu,
analyzed: pañcahi pañcannam pañcasu chahi channam chasu sattahi sattannam sattasu  aṭṭhahi aṭṭhannam aṭṭhasu navahi navannam navasu dasahi dasannam dasasu
translated: With five, of five, in five, with six, of six, in six, with seven, of seven, in seven,🔽with eight, of eight, in eight, with nine, of nine, in nine, with ten, of ten, in ten,

original: ekādasahi, ekādasannaṃ, ekādasasu…pe… aṭṭhārasahi, aṭṭhārasannaṃ, aṭṭhārasasu.
analyzed: ekādasa hi ekādasa nam ekādasa supe aṭṭhārasa hi aṭṭhārasa nam aṭṭhārasa su
translated: with eleven, of eleven, in eleven … and so on up to with eighteen, of eighteen, in eighteen.

original: Ete sabbe aliṅgā bahuvacanantā eva.
analyzed: ete sabbe aliṅgāḥ bahuvacana antāḥ eva
translated: All these are without gender and are in the plural.

analyzed: itthiya matvā ati vīsa tiṃsa cattālīsa paññāsehi ā paccayaḥ mahāvuttinā simhi rassaḥ

analyzed: si lopaḥ ca vikappena niggahīta āgamaḥ vikappena aṃ lopaḥ na ādīnam ekavacanānam
translated: and silopo, ‘niggahīta’ is the addition of niggahīta by vikappa, the elision of aṃ by vikappa, the ya-a of the singular

original: yādeso, vīsa itthiyo, vīsaṃ itthiyo, vīsa purisā, vīsaṃ purisā, vīsa purise, vīsaṃ
analyzed: yā desaḥ vīsaḥ itthiyaḥ vīsaṃ itthiyaḥ vīsa purisāḥ vīsam purisāḥ vīsa purise vīsam
translated: of the indeclinables, twenty women, twenty women, twenty men, twenty men, twenty men, twenty men, twenty minds,

original: purise, vīsa cittāni, vīsaṃ cittāni, vīsāya itthīhi kammaṃ kataṃ, vīsāya purisehi
analyzed: purise vīsa cittāni vīsam cittāni vīsāya itthīhi kammam katam vīsāya purisehi

analyzed: kammam katam vīsāya kulehi kammam katam vīsāya itthīnam purisānam kulānam sattamiyam
translated: an action done by twenty families, of twenty women, of twenty men, of twenty families, in the locative

original: vīsāya itthīsu, purisesu, kulesu.
analyzed: vīsāya itthīsu purisesu kulesu
translated: in twenty women, in twenty men, in twenty families.

original: Tipaccaye vīsati, tiṃsatisaddāpi saṭṭhi, sattati, asīti, navutisaddā viya niccaṃ
analyzed: ti paccaye vīsati tiṃsati saddā api saṭṭhi sattati asīti navuti saddā viya niccam
translated: In the tristubh metre, twenty, the words thirty, sixty, seventy, eighty, ninety, like the words

analyzed: itthi liṅga ekavacana antāḥ eva si aṃ lopaḥ vīsati itthiyaḥ vīsati purisā purise vīsati
translated: women, in the singular, si, the elision of aṃ, twenty women, twenty men, men, twenty

analyzed: kulāni vīsatiyā itthīhi itthīnam purisehi purisānam kulehi kulānam vīsatiyā
translated: families, by twenty women, of women, of men, of families, of twenty,

analyzed: itthi purisa kulesu evam yāvanavutiyā veditabbā vagga bhede pana sati

translated: the plural is also seen by elision, as in “two twenties” and so on.

original: Sataṃ, sahassaṃ, dasasahassaṃ, satasahassaṃ, dasasatasahassanti ime napuṃsakaliṅgāyeva.🔽Saṅkhyeyyapadhāne pana itthiliṅge vattabbe sahassī, dasasahassī, satasahassīti itthiliṅgaṃ
analyzed: satam sahassam dasa sahassam sata sahassam dasa sata sahassanti ime napuṃsaka liṅgāya iva  saṅkhyeyya apadhāne pana itthi liṅge vattabbe sahassī dasasahassī sata sahassī iti itthi liṅgam
translated: A hundred, a thousand, ten thousand, a hundred thousand, a hundred times a hundred thousand—these are neuter.🔽But in the case of the feminine, when it is to be expressed in the feminine, a thousand is sahassī, ten thousand is dasasahassī, a hundred thousand is satasahassī.

original: bhavati. Vaggabhede pana dve satāni, tīṇi satāni, dve sahassāni, tīṇi sahassāni iccādīni
analyzed: bhavati vagga bhede pana dve satāni tīṇi satāni dve sahassāni tīṇi sahassāni iccādīni
translated: But when there is a compound, two hundreds is dve satāni, three hundreds is tīṇi satāni, two thousands is dve sahassāni, three thousands is tīṇi sahassāni, and so on.

original: bhavanti. Koṭi, pakoṭi, koṭipakoṭi, akkhobhiṇīsaddā itthiliṅgā eva. Sesaṃ sabbaṃ
analyzed: bhavanti koṭi pakoṭi koṭi pakoṭi akkhobhiṇī saddāḥ itthi liṅgāḥ eva sesam sabbam
translated: A koṭi, a pakoṭi, a koṭipakoṭi, an akkhobhiṇī—these are feminine. The rest,

original: yāvaasaṅkhyeyyā napuṃsakameva.
analyzed: yāva a saṅkhyeyyāḥ napuṃsakam eva
translated: all the way up to asaṅkhyeyya, is neuter.

original: Sahassaṃ kāsi nāma, dasasahassaṃ nahutaṃ nāma, satasahassaṃ lakkhaṃ nāma.
analyzed: sahassam kāsi nāma dasa sahassam nahutam nāma sata sahassam lakkham nāma
translated: A thousand is called a kāsi, ten thousand is called a nahuta, a hundred thousand is called a lakkha.

original: Duvidhaṃ padhānaṃ saṅkhyāpadhānaṃ, saṅkhyeyyapadhānañca. Purisānaṃ vīsati hoti, purisānaṃ
analyzed: duvidham padhānam saṅkhyā apadhānam saṅkhyeyyapadhānam ca purisānam vīsati hoti purisānam
translated: There are two kinds of compounds: a numerical compound and a compound of things to be counted. Twenty men is purisānaṃ vīsati,

original: navuti hoti, purisānaṃ sataṃ hoti, sahassaṃ hoti iccādi saṅkhyāpadhānaṃ nāma, vīsati🔽purisā, navuti purisā, sataṃ purisā, sahassaṃ purisā iccādi saṅkhyeyyapadhānaṃ nāma.
analyzed: navuti hoti purisānam satam hoti sahassam hoti iccādi saṅkhyāpadhānam nāma vīsati  purisā navuti purisā satam purisā sahassam purisā iccādi saṅkhyeyyapadhānam nāma
translated: The words for the number of a hundred, a thousand, etc., are called the “base for the number of a hundred, a thousand, etc.”🔽The words for the countable things, twenty men, ninety men, a hundred men, a thousand men, etc., are called the “base for the countable things.”

original: Etthapi vīsatisaddo itthiliṅgekavacano eva. Sata, sahassasaddā napuṃsakekavacanā eva. Saṅkhyāsaddānaṃ pana padavidhānañca guṇavidhānañca samāsakaṇḍe āgamissati.
analyzed: ettha api vīsati saddaḥ itthi liṅga ekavacanaḥ eva sata sahassa saddāḥ napuṃsaka ekavacanāḥ eva saṅkhyā saddānam pana pada vidhānam ca guṇa vidhānam ca samāsa kaṇḍe āgamissati
translated: Herein, the word twenty is a feminine singular only. The words a hundred, a thousand are neuter singular only. But the analysis of the words for numbers and the analysis of the analysis of the words will come in the section on compounds.

original: Saṅkhyārāsi niṭṭhito.🔽252. Simhāhaṃ ka. 149; rū. 232; nī. 319; ‘simhahaṃ’ (bahūsu).
analyzed: saṅkhyā rāsi niṭṭhitaḥ  simhāham ka rū nī simhaham bahūsu
translated: The mass (of words) for numbers is finished.🔽I am a lion.

original: Simhi savibhattissa amhassa ahaṃ hoti.
analyzed: simhi sa vibhattissa amhassa aham hoti
translated: In the case of the nominative singular ending in -i, amhassa becomes ahaṃ.🔽I go.

original: Ahaṃ gacchāmi.🔽253. Mayamasmāmhassa ka. 121; rū. 233; nī. 296.
analyzed: aham gacchāmi  maya masma amhassa ka rū nī
translated: We are.

original: Yosu savibhattissa amhassa kamena mayaṃ, asmā honti vā.
analyzed: yosu sa vibhattissa amhassa kamena mayam asmā honti vā
translated: In the case of the nominative plural ending in -u, amhassa becomes mayaṃ, asmā.

original: Mayaṃ gacchāma, asme passāmi.🔽Pakkhe –
analyzed: mayam gacchāma asme passāmi  pakkhe
translated: We go, I see us.🔽In the case of the instrumental plural ending in -e, amhassa becomes amhe.

original: ‘Yonameṭa’ iti vidhi, amhe gacchāma.
analyzed: yonameṭa iti vidhi amhe gacchāma
translated: We go.

original: 254. Tumhassa tuvaṃtvaṃmhi ca ka. 146; rū. 236; nī. 324; ‘tumhassa tuvaṃtvamamhica’ (bahūsu).
analyzed: tumhassa tuvaṃtvamhi ca ka rū nī tumhassa tuvaṃtvamamhi ca bahūsu
translated: 254. In the case of yours, your, mine, your, your, in the case of many,

original: Simhi ca aṃmhi ca savibhattissa tumhassa tuvaṃ, tvaṃ honti.
analyzed: simhi ca aṃmhi ca sa vibhattissa tumhassa tuvam tvam honti
translated: in the case of the case-ending-marked yours, your, your are.

original: Tuvaṃ buddho tuvaṃ satthā, tuvaṃ mārābhibhū muni theragā. 839, tvaṃ no satthā anuttaro, tumhe gacchatha, tuvaṃ passati, tvaṃ passati.
analyzed: tuvam buddhaḥ tuvam satthā tuvam māra abhibhū muni theragā tvam no satthā anuttaraḥ tumhe gacchatha tuvam passati tvam passati
translated: Your is the Buddha, your is the Teacher, your is the Sage who has overcome Mara, your is our unsurpassed Teacher, you go, you see, you see.

original: 255. Aṃmhi taṃ maṃ tavaṃ mamaṃ ka. 143-4; rū. 234-5; nī. 322.🔽Aṃmhi savibhattīnaṃ tumhā’mhānaṃ taṃ, maṃ, tavaṃ, mamaṃ honti.
analyzed: tam mam tavam mamam ka  am mhi sa vibhattīnam tumha amhānam tam mam tavam mamam honti
translated: 255. In the case of me, mine, your, my,🔽in the case of the case-ending-marked me, mine, your, my are.

original: Maṃ passati, mamaṃ passati, taṃ passati, tavaṃ passati, amhe passati, tumhe passati.
analyzed: mam passati mamam passati tam passati tavam passati amhe passati tumhe passati
translated: Me sees, mine sees, you sees, your sees, we see, you see.

original: 256. Dutiyāyomhi vā ka. 162; rū. 237; nī. 345; ‘dutiye yomhi vā’ (bahūsu).
analyzed: dutiye yomhi vā ka rū nī dutiye yomhi vā bahūsu
translated: 256. In the case of second, I, or,🔽in the case of the case-ending-marked second, I, or, in the case of many,

original: Dutiyāyomhi savibhattīnaṃ tumhā’mhānaṃ ṅānubandhā aṃ, ākaṃādesā honti vā.
analyzed: dutiya yomhi sa vibhattīnam tumha amhānam ṅā anubandhāḥ aṃ ā kaṃ ādesāḥ honti vā
translated: the a-sign and the a-sign of the case-ending-marked yours, mine, are, or.

original: Amhaṃ, amhākaṃ passati, tumhaṃ, tumhākaṃ passati.
analyzed: amham amhākam passati tumham tumhākam passati
translated: Yours, yours sees, ours, ours sees, yours, yours sees, yours, yours sees.

original: 257. Nāsmāsu tayāmayā ka. 145, 270; rū. 238, 120; nī. 323, 542.
analyzed: na asmāsu tayāmayā ka
translated: 257. Nāsmāsu tayāmayā ka. 145, 270; rū. 238, 120; nī. 323, 542.

original: Nā, smāsu savibhattīnaṃ tumhā’mhānaṃ tayā, mayā honti.
analyzed: nā sma āsu sa vibhattīnam tumha amhānam tayā mayā honti
translated: Nā, smāsu savibhattīnaṃ tumhā’mhānaṃ tayā, mayā honti.

original: Mayā kataṃ, tayā kataṃ, mayā apeti, tayā apeti.
analyzed: mayā katam tayā katam mayā apa iti tayā apa iti
translated: Mayā kataṃ, tayā kataṃ, mayā apeti, tayā apeti.

original: 258. Tayātayīnaṃ tva vā tassa ka. 210; rū. 239; nī. 435.
analyzed: tayātayīnam tva vā tassa ka ru
translated: . Tayātayīnaṃ tva vā tassa ka. ; rū. ; nī. .

original: Tayā, tayīnaṃ tassa tva hoti vā.
analyzed: tayā tayīnam hoti vā
translated: Tayā, tayīnaṃ tassa tva hoti vā.

original: Tvayā kataṃ, tvayā apeti, amhehi kataṃ, tumhehi kataṃ.
analyzed: tvayā katam tvayā apa iti amhehi katam tumhehi katam
translated: Tvayā kataṃ, tvayā apeti, amhehi kataṃ, tumhehi kataṃ.

original: 259. Tavamamatuyhaṃmayhaṃ se ka. 141-2; rū. 241-2; nī. 321.
analyzed: tava mama tuyham mayham se ka rū nī
translated: . Tavamamatuyhaṃmayhaṃ se ka. -; rū. -; nī. .

original: Samhi savibhattīnaṃ tumhā’mhānaṃ tavādayo honti.
analyzed: samhi sa vibhattīnam tumha amhānam tava ādayaḥ honti
translated: Samhi savibhattīnaṃ tumhā’mhānaṃ tavādayo honti.

original: Mama dīyate, mayhaṃ dīyate, tava dīyate, tuyhaṃ dīyate.
analyzed: mama dīyate mayham dīyate tava dīyate tuyham dīyate
translated: Mama dīyate, mayhaṃ dīyate, tava dīyate, tuyhaṃ dīyate.

original: 260. Naṃsesvasmākaṃmamaṃ nī. 438.
analyzed: naṃ se su asmākam mamam nī
translated: . Naṃsesvasmākaṃmamaṃ nī. .

original: Naṃ, sesu savibhattissa amhassa kamena asmākaṃ, mamaṃ honti.
analyzed: nam sesu sa vibhattissa amhassa kamena asmākam mamam honti
translated: Naṃ, sesu savibhattissa amhassa kamena asmākaṃ, mamaṃ honti.

original: Mamaṃ dīyate, asmākaṃ dīyate.
analyzed: mamam dīyate asmākam dīyate
translated: Mamaṃ dīyate, asmākaṃ dīyate.

original: 261. Ṅaṃṅākaṃ naṃmhi ka. 161; rū. 244; nī. 344.
analyzed: ṅaṃ ṅā kam nam mhi ka rū nī
translated: . Ṅaṃṅākaṃ naṃmhi ka. ; rū. ; nī. .

original: Naṃmhi savibhattīnaṃ tumhā’mhānaṃ ṅānubandhā aṃ, ākaṃādesā honti vā.
analyzed: nam mhi sa vibhattīnam tumha amhānam ṅā anubandhāḥ aṃ ā kam ādesāḥ honti vā
translated: Naṃmhi savibhattīnaṃ tumhā’mhānaṃ ṅānubandhā aṃ, ākaṃādesā honti vā.

original: Amhaṃ dīyate, amhākaṃ dīyate, tumhaṃ dīyate, tumhākaṃ dīyate. Pañcamiyaṃ mayā, tayā, tvayā, pubbe vuttāva.
analyzed: amham dīyate amhākam dīyate tumham dīyate tumhākam dīyate pañcamiyam mayā tayā tvayā pubbe vuttā ava
translated: Amhaṃ dīyate, amhākaṃ dīyate, tumhaṃ dīyate, tumhākaṃ dīyate. The fifth is as already stated in the case of tvā, tvayā, pubbe.

original: 262. Smāmhi tvamhā.
analyzed: sma amhi tvamhā
translated: . Smāmhi tvamhā.

original: Smāmhi savibhattissa tumhassa tvamhā hoti.
analyzed: sma amhi sa vibhattissa tumhassa tvamhā hoti
translated: Smāmhi savibhattiṃssa tumhassa tvamhā hoti.

original: Tvamhā apeti, amhehi, tumhehi, mama, mamaṃ, mayhaṃ, tava, tuyhaṃ, amhaṃ, amhākaṃ, asmākaṃ, tumhaṃ, tumhākaṃ.
analyzed: apa iti amhehi tumhehi mama mamam mayham tava tuyham amham amhākam asmākam tumham tumhākam
translated: Tvamhā apeti, amhehi, tumhehi, mama, mamaṃ, mayhaṃ, tava, tuyhaṃ, amhaṃ, amhākaṃ, asmākaṃ, tumhaṃ, tumhākaṃ.

original: 263. Smiṃmhi tumhamhānaṃ tayimayi ka. 139; rū. 245; nī. 318.
analyzed: tayi mayi ka rū nī
translated: . Smiṃmhi tumhamhānaṃ tayimayi ka. ; rū. ; nī. .

original: Smiṃmhi savibhattīnaṃ tumhā’mhānaṃ tayi, mayi honti.
analyzed: smin mhi sa vibhattīnam tumha amhānam tayi mayi honti
translated: Smiṃmhi savibhattīnaṃ tumhā’mhānaṃ tayi, mayi honti.

original: Tayi, mayi, tvatte tvayi, amhesu, tumhesu.
analyzed: tayi mayi tvad te tvayi amhesu tumhesu
translated: Tayi, mayi, tvatte tvayi, amhesu, tumhesu.

original: 264. Sumhāmhassāsmā nī. 438.
analyzed: su mha amhas sā asmā nī
translated: . Sumhāmhassāsmā nī. .

original: Sumhi amhassa asmā hoti.
analyzed: sumhi amhassa asmā hoti
translated: Sumhi amhassa asmā hoti.

original: Asmāsu.
analyzed: asmāsu
translated: Asmāsu.

original: Mahāvuttinā yo, hisu amhassa asmādeso, yonaṃ ettañca, asmā gacchāma, asme passati,
analyzed: mahāvuttinā yaḥ hi su amhassa asma ādesaḥ ettañca asmā gacchāma asme passati
translated: By the great grammarians the place of asmā is that of amhassa, and this is the same as that of yonaṃ. We go to asmā, he sees in asmā.

original: asmāhi kataṃ, asmākaṃ dīyate, asmāhi apeti, asmākaṃ dhanaṃ, asmāsu ṭhitaṃ. “Asmābhijappanti
analyzed: asmāhi katam asmākam dīyate asmāhi apeti asmākam dhanam asmāsu ṭhitam
translated: It is done by asmāhi, it is given to asmākaṃ, it is taken away from asmāhi, the wealth of asmākaṃ, it is established in asmāsu. “They pray to asmā.”🔽. Smiṃmhi savibhattīnaṃ tumhā’mhānaṃ mayi, tayi honti.🔽Mayi, tayi, tvatte tvayi, amhesu, tumhesu.

original: janā anekā”ti jā. 1.7.68 pāḷi-asme abhijappanti patthentīti attho. “Asmābhi pariciṇṇosi,
analyzed: janāḥ anekā ati jā abhijappanti patthenti iti atthaḥ asmābhi
translated: “We have served you,🔽for leaders are friendly-minded” .

original: mettacittā hi nāyakā”ti apa. therī 2.2.230 therīpāḷi – ‘pariciṇṇo’ti paricārito.
analyzed: hi therī pariciṇṇoti paricārito
translated: “Served” means attended on.

original: Catutthiyaṃ asmākaṃ adhipannānaṃ, khamassu rājakuñjara jā. 2.21.181 – ‘adhipannāna’nti dukkhābhibhūtānaṃ.
analyzed: catutthiyam asmākam adhipannānam khamassu rāja kuñjara jā adhipannānam ti dukkha abhibhūtānam
translated: In the fourth verse “our” means “ourselves” .

original: Chaṭṭhiyaṃ esasmākaṃ kule dhammo jā. 1.4.147, esā asmākaṃ dhammatā.🔽Sattamiyaṃ yaṃ kiccaṃ parame mitte, katamasmāsu taṃ tayā. Pattā nissaṃsayaṃ tvamhā,
analyzed: chaṭṭhiyam esā asmākam kule dhammaḥ jā esā asmākam dhamma tā  yam kiccam parame mitte katamasmāsu tam tayā pattā nissaṃsayam tu amhā
translated: In the sixth verse “this is our custom” means “this is our custom” .

original: bhattirasmāsu yā tava jā. 2.21.81 – tattha ‘yaṃ kicca’nti yaṃ kammaṃ kattabbaṃ, tava
analyzed: bhattiḥ asmāsu yā tava jā tattha yam yam kammam kattabbam tava
translated: In the seventh verse “what service to the highest friends you have done for us” means “what service you have done for us” .

original: asmāsu yā bhatti, tāya mayaṃ tvamhā nissaṃsayataṃ pattāti attho.🔽265. Apādādo padatekavākye caṃ. 6.3.15; pā. 8.1.17, 18.
analyzed: asmāsu yā tāya mayam tvamhā nissaṃsayatam patta ati  a pāda ādaḥ pada tā ikavākye cam pā
translated: “We have certainly attained your favour” means “we have certainly attained your favour” .🔽. In the case of a sentence consisting of one word beginning with apada, .

original: Apādādimhi pavattānaṃ padato paresaṃ ekavākye ṭhitānaṃ tumhā’mhānaṃ vidhi hoti. Adhikārasuttamidaṃ.
analyzed: a pāda ādimhi pavattānam padataḥ paresam ekavākye ṭhitānam hoti adhikāra suttam idam
translated: The method is that of tumhā and amhā in the case of other words occurring in the same sentence as a word beginning with apada, etc. This is a suttanta on the topic.

original: 266. Yonaṃhisvapañcamyā vono ka. 147, 151; rū. 246, 250; nī. 325, 329, 330.
analyzed: ya u naṃ hi sva pañcamyāḥ va ū naḥ ka rū nī
translated: In the fifth case, in the words beginning with yonaṃ, hisu, and so on, the forms of the words beginning with naṃ, hisu, and so on, are not the same as those of the words beginning with yo, hisu, and so on, in the fifth case.

original: Pañcamīvajjitesu yo, naṃ, hisu paresu apādādopavattānaṃ padato paresaṃ ekavākye ṭhitānaṃ savibhattīnaṃ tumhā’mhasaddānaṃ vo, no honti vā.🔽Gacchatha vo, gacchatha tumhe, gacchāma no, gacchāma amhe, passeyya vo, passeyya
analyzed: pañcamī vat jitesu yaḥ nam hisu paresu padataḥ paresam eka vākye ṭhitānam savibhattīnam tumha amha saddānam vaḥ no honti vā  gacchatha vaḥ gacchatha tumhe gacchāma no gacchāma amhe passeyya vaḥ passeyya
translated: The forms of the words beginning with naṃ, hisu, and so on, are not the same as those of the words beginning with yo, hisu, and so on, in the fifth case, in the same sentence with other words that have case endings, and in the words beginning with paresu, apādādopavattānaṃ, padato, paresaṃ, ekavākye, ṭhitānaṃ, savibhattīnaṃ, tumhā, amhasaddānaṃ, vo, no.

original: tumhe, passeyya no, passeyya amhe, dīyate vo, dīyate tumhākaṃ, dīyate no, dīyate🔽amhākaṃ, dhanaṃ vo, dhanaṃ tumhākaṃ, dhanaṃ no, dhanaṃ amhākaṃ, kataṃ vo puññaṃ,🔽kataṃ tumhehi puññaṃ, kataṃ no puññaṃ, kataṃ amhehi puññaṃ.
analyzed: tumhe passeyya no passeyya amhe dīyate vaḥ dīyate tumhākam dīyate no dīyate  amhākam dhanam vaḥ dhanam tumhākam dhanam naḥ dhanam amhākam katam vaḥ puññam  katam tumhehi puññam katam no puññam katam amhehi puññam
translated: Go vo, go tumhe, gacchāma no, gacchāma amhe, passeyya vo, passeyya tumhe, passeyya no, passeyya amhe, dīyate vo, dīyate tumhākaṃ, dīyate no, dīyate amhākaṃ, dhanaṃ vo, dhanaṃ tumhākaṃ, dhanaṃ no, dhanaṃ amhākaṃ, kataṃ vo puññaṃ, kataṃ tumhehi puññaṃ, kataṃ no puññaṃ, kataṃ amhehi puññaṃ.

original: Apañcamyāti kiṃ? Nissaṭaṃ tumhehi, nissaṭaṃ amhehi.
analyzed: a pañcamyā ati kim nissaṭam tumhehi nissaṭam amhehi
translated: What is not in the fifth case? Nissaṭaṃ tumhehi, nissaṭaṃ amhehi.

original: Apādādotveva? Balañca bhikkhūnamanuppadinnaṃ, tumhehi puññaṃ pasutaṃ anappakaṃ khu. pā. 7.12.
analyzed: balañca bhikkhūnam an uppadinnam tumhehi puññam pasutam anappakam khu pā
translated: And only in the fifth case? Balañca bhikkhūnamanuppadinnaṃ, tumhehi puññaṃ pasutaṃ anappakaṃ khu. pā. ..

original: Padatotveva? Tumhe gacchatha, amhe gacchāma.
analyzed: tumhe gacchatha amhe gacchāma
translated: In the singular? You go, we go.

original: Ekavākyetveva? Devadatto tiṭṭhati gāme, tumhe tiṭṭhatha nagare.
analyzed: eka vākyetvā eva devadatto tiṭṭhati gāme tumhe tiṭṭhatha nagare
translated: In the singular and plural? Devadatta stands in the village, you stand in the town.

original: Savibhattīnantveva? Arahati dhammo tumhādisānaṃ.
analyzed: arahati
translated: In the singular and plural, with the case endings? The Dhamma is worthy of you.

analyzed: teme nāse ka rū nī  cam pā
translated: These are the forms of the singular and plural, with the case endings, of the words tumha and amha.

original: Nā, sesu tādisānaṃ savibhattīnaṃ tumha, amhasaddānaṃ te, me honti vā.🔽Kataṃ te puññaṃ, kataṃ tayā puññaṃ, kataṃ me puññaṃ, kataṃ mayā puññaṃ, dinnaṃ te🔽vatthaṃ, dinnaṃ tuyhaṃ vatthaṃ, dinnaṃ me vatthaṃ, dinnaṃ mayhaṃ vatthaṃ, idaṃ te🔽raṭṭhaṃ, idaṃ tava raṭṭhaṃ, idaṃ me raṭṭhaṃ, idaṃ mama raṭṭhaṃ.
analyzed: na ā sesu tādisānam sa vibhattīnam tumha amha saddānam te me honti vā  katam te puññam katam tayā puññam katam me puññam katam mayā puññam dinnam te  vattham dinnam tuyham vattham dinnam me vattham dinnam mayham vattham idam te  raṭṭham idam tava raṭṭham idam me raṭṭham idam mama raṭṭham
translated: Te, me are used with them in the nominative and accusative cases.🔽Your merit is done, your merit is done, my merit is done, my merit is done, your cloth is given, your cloth is given, my cloth is given, my cloth is given, this country is yours, this country is yours, this country is mine, this country is mine.

analyzed: anvādese cam pā
translated: The forms of the singular and plural, with the case endings, of the words tumha and amha are used with the words te and me.

original: Anvādesaṭṭhāne tumhā’mhasaddānaṃ vo, no, te, meādesā niccaṃ bhavanti punabbidhānā.
analyzed: anu ādesa ṭṭhāne tumha amha saddānam vaḥ no te me ādesāḥ niccam bhavanti punabbidhānā
translated: In the place of the endings, the forms vo, no, te, me are used instead of tumhākaṃ, amhākaṃ, tumhaṃ, amhaṃ.

original: Gāmo tumhākaṃ pariggaho, atho nagarampi vo pariggaho. Evaṃ sesesu.
analyzed: gāmaḥ tumhākam pariggahaḥ atho nagaram pi vaḥ pariggahaḥ evam sesesu
translated: The village is yours, the town is yours, the village is yours, the town is yours. So too with the rest.

original: 269. Sapubbā paṭhamantā vā ‘saṃpubbā paṭhamanthā vā’ (mūlapāṭhe) caṃ. 6.1.21; pā. 8.1.26.🔽Saṃvijjati pubbapadaṃ assāti sapubbaṃ, sapubbā paṭhamantapadamhā paresaṃ savibhattīnaṃ tumhā’mhasaddānaṃ vo, no, te, meādesā vikappena honti anvādesaṭṭhānepi.🔽Gāme paṭo tumhākaṃ, atho nagare kambalaṃ vo, atho nagare kambalaṃ tumhākaṃ vā. Evaṃ sesesu.
analyzed: sa pubbā paṭhamantā vā saṃ pubbā paṭhamanthā vā mūla pāṭhe caṃ pā  saṃvijjati pubba padam assa ati sa pubbam sa pubbā paṭhama anta pada mhā paresam sa vibhattīnam tumha amha saddānam vaḥ no te me ādesāḥ vikappena honti anvādesa ṭṭhāne pi  gāme paṭaḥ tumhākam atho nagare kambalam vaḥ atho nagare kambalam tumhākam vā evam sesesu
translated: The words sapubbā paṭhamantā vā are formed by adding the feminine plural ending -ā to the words sapubbā paṭhamantā, which are derived from the words sapubbā paṭhamantā with the addition of the feminine singular ending -ā.🔽The words sapubbā paṭhamantā vā are formed by adding the feminine plural ending -ā to the words sapubbā paṭhamantā, which are derived from the words sapubbā paṭhamantā with the addition of the feminine singular ending -ā.🔽The words sapubbā paṭhamantā vā are formed by adding the feminine plural ending -ā to the words sapubbā paṭhamantā, which are derived from the words sapubbā paṭhamantā with the addition of the feminine singular ending -ā.

original: 270. Na cavāhāhevayoge caṃ. 6.3.22; pā. 8.1.24.🔽Ca, vā, ha, aha, evasaddehi yoge tumhā’mhānaṃ vo, no, te, meādesā na honti.
analyzed: na ca vā ha aha iva yoge cam pā  ca vā ha aha eva saddehi yoge tumha amhānam vaḥ no te me ādesāḥ na honti
translated: The words sapubbā paṭhamantā vā are formed by adding the feminine plural ending -ā to the words sapubbā paṭhamantā, which are derived from the words sapubbā paṭhamantā with the addition of the feminine singular ending -ā.🔽The words sapubbā paṭhamantā vā are formed by adding the feminine plural ending -ā to the words sapubbā paṭhamantā, which are derived from the words sapubbā paṭhamantā with the addition of the feminine singular ending -ā.🔽The words sapubbā paṭhamantā vā are formed by adding the feminine plural ending -ā to the words sapubbā paṭhamantā, which are derived from the words sapubbā paṭhamantā with the addition of the feminine singular ending -ā.🔽The words sapubbā paṭhamantā vā are formed by adding the feminine plural ending -ā to the words sapubbā paṭhamantā, which are derived from the words sapubbā paṭhamantā with the addition of the feminine singular ending -ā.

original: Gāmo tava ca mama ca pariggaho, gāmo tava vā mama vā pariggaho iccādi.🔽Cādiyogeti kiṃ? Gāmo ca te pariggaho, nagarañca me pariggaho.
analyzed: gāmo tava ca mama ca pariggahaḥ gāmo tava vā mama vā pariggahaḥ iccādi  ca ādi yoga iti kim gāmaḥ ca te pariggahaḥ nagaram ca me pariggahaḥ
translated: The words sapubbā paṭhamantā vā are formed by adding the feminine plural ending -ā to the words sapubbā paṭhamantā, which are derived from the words sapubbā paṭhamantā with the addition of the feminine singular ending -ā.

original: 271. Dassanatthenālocane caṃ. 6.3.23; pā. 8.1.25.
analyzed: dassana atthena ālocane caṃ pā
translated: The words sapubbā paṭhamantā vā are

original: Ālocanaṃ olokanaṃ, ālocanato aññasmiṃ dassanatthe payujjamāne tumhā’mhānaṃ vo, no, te, meādesā na honti.
analyzed: ālocanam olokanam ālocanataḥ aññasmin dassana atthe payujjamāne tumha amhānam vo no te me ādesāḥ na honti
translated: Looking is seeing. When the words tumhe, amhe, vo, no, te, me are used in the sense of seeing, they are not used in the sense of looking.

original: Gāmo tumhe uddissa āgato, gāmo amhe uddissa āgato – ‘gāmo’ti gāmavāsī mahājano.
analyzed: gāmaḥ tumhe uddissa āgataḥ gāmaḥ amhe uddissa āgataḥ gāmaḥ iti gāma vāsī mahājanaḥ
translated: The village has come for you, the village has come for us. The village means the multitude of villagers.

original: Anālocaneti kiṃ? Gāmo vo passati, gāmo no passati.🔽272. Āmantanapubbaṃ asantaṃva ‘āmantaṇaṃ pubbamasantaṃva’ (bahūsu) caṃ. 6.3.24; pā. 8.1.72.
analyzed: anālocanā iti kim gāmaḥ vaḥ passati gāmaḥ no passati  āmantana pubbam a santam vā āmantaṇam pubbam a santam vā bahūsu caṃ pā
translated: In the absence of looking, what is the case? The village sees you, the village sees us.🔽The word āmantaṇaṃ is used in the sense of a word of address.

original: Āmantanabhūtaṃ pubbapadaṃ asantaṃ viya hoti, padatoti saṅkhyaṃ na gacchati.
analyzed: āmantana bhūtam pubba padam asantam viya hoti saṅkhyam na gacchati
translated: A word of address is as if it were not there, it does not count as a word.

original: Devadatta! Tava pariggaho.🔽273. Na sāmaññavacanamekatthe caṃ. 6.3.25; pā. 8.1.73.
analyzed: devadatta tava pariggahaḥ  na sāmañña vacanam ekatthe cam pā
translated: Devadatta! Your possession.🔽The word sāmaññavacana is used in the sense of a word that is common to all.

original: Tulyādhikaraṇabhūte pade sati pubbaṃ sāmaññavacanabhūtaṃ āmantanapadaṃ asantaṃ viya na hoti, padatoti saṅkhyaṃ gacchati.
analyzed: tulya adhikaraṇa bhūte pade sati pubbam sāmaññavacana bhūtam āmantana padam asantam viya na hoti saṅkhyam gacchati
translated: When there is a word that is in the same case, a word of address that is common to all is not as if it were not there, it counts as a word.

original: Māṇavaka jaṭila! Te pariggaho.
analyzed: māṇavaka jaṭila te pariggaho
translated: Young man, ascetic! Your possession.

original: Sāmaññavacananti kiṃ? Māṇavaka devadatta! Tuyhaṃ pariggaho.
analyzed: sāmañña vacanam ti kim māṇavaka devadatta tuyham pariggahaḥ
translated: In the absence of a word that is common to all, what is the case? Young man, Devadatta! Your possession.

original: Ekattheti kiṃ? Devadatta! Yaññadatta! Tumhākaṃ pariggaho.🔽274. Bahūsu vā caṃ. 6.3.26; pā. 8.1.74.
analyzed: ekattha iti kim devadatta yaññadatta tumhākam pariggahaḥ  bahūsu vā cam pā
translated: . In many? What?

original: Bahūsu janesu pavattamānaṃ sāmaññavacanabhūtampi āmantanapadaṃ ekatthe pade sati asantaṃ viya na hoti vā.
analyzed: bahūsu janesu pavattamānam sāmañña vacana bhūtam pi āmantana padam ekatthe pade sati asantam viya na hoti vā
translated: In many people, the word of common usage that occurs is not as if non-existent when there is a word in one meaning.

original: Brāhmaṇā guṇavanto vo pariggaho, brāhmaṇā guṇavanto tumhākaṃ pariggaho.
analyzed: brāhmaṇāḥ guṇavantaḥ vaḥ pariggahaḥ brāhmaṇāḥ guṇavantaḥ tumhākam pariggahaḥ
translated: Brahmins are your possession who are virtuous, brahmins who are virtuous are your possession.

original: Sabbādirāsi niṭṭhito.
analyzed: niṭṭhitaḥ
translated: The class beginning with all is finished.

original: Vibhattipaccayantarāsi
analyzed: vibhatti paccaya antarā asi
translated: The class of conditions with the case endings

original: Atha vibhattipaccayā dīpiyante.
analyzed: atha vibhatti paccayāḥ dīpiyante
translated: Now the conditions with the case endings are shown.

original: Vibhatyatthānaṃ jotakattā vibhattiṭṭhāne ṭhitā paccayā vibhattipaccayā.
analyzed: vibhati atthānam jotaka attā vibhatti ṭṭhāne ṭhitā paccayā vibhatti paccayā
translated: Because of the indication of the meanings of the case endings, the conditions that are placed in the places of the case endings are conditions with the case endings.🔽. To with the fifth. ; form. ; blue. ; in many? What?

analyzed: taḥ pañcamyā ka rū nī cam pā
translated: . In many? What?

original: Pañcamiyā vibhattiyā atthe topaccayo hoti.
analyzed: pañcamiyā vibhattiyā atthe to paccayaḥ hoti
translated: A condition is with the meaning of the fifth case ending.

original: Tomhi dīghānaṃ rasso, kaññato, rattito, itthito, dhenuto. Mahāvuttinā tomhi mātāpitūnaṃ
analyzed: tomhi dīghānam rassaḥ kaññataḥ rattitaḥ itthitaḥ dhenutaḥ mahāvuttinā tomhi mātā pitūnam
translated: To me of the long ones, of the girl, of the night, of the woman, of the cow, by the Great Collection to me of mother and father

original: ittaṃ, mātito, pitito, vadhuto, purisato, munito, daṇḍito, bhikkhuto, satthārato,
analyzed: ittam mātitaḥ pititaḥ vadhutaḥ purisataḥ munitaḥ daṇḍitaḥ bhikkhutaḥ satthārataḥ
translated: is the respect, of the mother, of the father, of the bride, of the man, of the sage, of the stick, of the monk, of the teacher,🔽.

original: kattuto, gotrabhuto, sabbato, yato, tato.
analyzed: kattutaḥ gotra bhutaḥ sabbataḥ yatas tatas
translated: As to source, as to origin, as to all, as to where, as to whence.

original: Ima, eta, kiṃsaddehi to.
analyzed: ime eta kiṃsaddehi to
translated: This, that, what, with the particle to.

original: 276. Itotettokuto ‘ito tetto kato’ (bahūsu) caṃ. 4.3.8; pā. 7.2.104.
analyzed: itas tetto kutas itas tetto katas bahūsu cam pā
translated: From this, from that, from where, from this, from that, from where (in the plural), and so on.

original: Ito, ato, etto, kutoti ete saddā topaccayantā nipaccante.
analyzed: itas atas ettas kutas iti ete saddāḥ to paccaya ntāḥ nipaccante
translated: From this, from that, from where, from whence—these words are inflected with the particle to.

original: Imamhā imehīti vā ito, etasmā etehīti vā ato, etto, kasmā kehīti vā kuto. Ettha ca
analyzed: imamhā imehi iti vā itas etasmai etehi iti vā atas ettas kasmā kehi iti vā kutas ettha ca
translated: From this, from these, or from that, from those, or from where, from whence—and here

original: imamhā, imehītiādikaṃ atthavākyaṃ disvā pakatiliṅgaṃ veditabbaṃ. Iminā suttena imassa
analyzed: imamhā imehi iti ādikam attha vākyam disvā pakati liṅgam veditabbam iminā suttena imassa
translated: the inflected form beginning with “from this, from these” should be understood according to the gender. By this sutta

original: ittaṃ, etassa attaṃ ettañca, ‘saramhā dve’ti esaramhā dvittaṃ, kiṃsaddassa kuttaṃ.
analyzed: ittam etassa attam ettam ca saramhā dve iti esaramhā dvittam kiṃsaddassa kuttam
translated: this, that, and that, and by “from two with esara” the dual form, and the kutta form of the word what.

original: Esa nayo sesesu nipātanesu.🔽277. Abhyādīhi pā. 5.3.9.
analyzed: esa nayaḥ sesesu nipātanesu  abhyādīhi pā
translated: The same method applies to the other inflected forms.🔽With abhi, etc.

original: Abhiādīhi to hoti, punabbidhānā’pañcamyatthepītipi siddhaṃ.🔽Abhito gāmaṃ gāmassa abhimukheti attho.
analyzed: abhi ādīhi taḥ ha iti siddham  abhitas gāmam gāmassa abhimukhā iti atthaḥ
translated: With abhi, etc., to becomes the case ending, and it is established that the fifth case meaning is repeated.🔽From this side of the village, in front of the village, is the meaning.

original: Parito gāmaṃ gāmassa samantatoti attho.
analyzed: paritas gāmam gāmassa samantataḥ ti attho
translated: From all around the village, all around the village, is the meaning.

original: Ubhato gāmaṃ gāmassa ubhosu passesūti attho.
analyzed: ubhatas gāmam gāmassa ubhosu passesu iti atthaḥ
translated: From both sides of the village, on both sides of the village, is the meaning.

original: Pacchato, heṭṭhato, uparito.
analyzed: pacchatas heṭṭhatas uparitas
translated: From behind, from below, from above.

original: 278. Ādyādīhi caṃ. 4.3.9; pā. 5.4.44.
analyzed: ādi ādīhi cam pā
translated: And with ādi, etc.

original: Ādipabhutīhi apañcamyatthepi to hoti.
analyzed: ādi pabhutīhi a pañcamī atthe pi taḥ hoti
translated: The particle to is also used when the seventh case is not intended, with words beginning with ādi.

original: Ādito, majjhato, purato, passato, piṭṭhito, orato, parato, pacchato, puratthimato, dakkhiṇatoiccādīsu bahulaṃ sattamyatthe dissati.
analyzed: āditas majjhatas puratas passatas piṭṭhitas oratas paratas pacchatas puratthimatas dakkhiṇatas icca ādīsu bahulam sattamī atthe dissati
translated: At the beginning, in the middle, in front, behind, on the left, on the right, on the far side, on the near side, on the east side, on the south side, etc., it is often found in the seventh case.

original: Tathā tatiyatthepi rūpaṃ attato samanupassati saṃ. ni. 3.44, pañcakkhandhe aniccato vipassati iccādi.
analyzed: tathā tatiya tthe pi rūpam attataḥ samanupassati sam ni pañca kkhandhe aniccataḥ vipassati iccādi
translated: So too in the third case: He regards materiality as self, he sees the five aggregates as impermanent, etc.

original: Yatonidānaṃ su. ni. 275, yatvādhikaraṇaṃ, yatodakaṃ tadādittamiccādīsu jā. 1.9.58 paṭhamatthe icchanti.
analyzed: yatonidānam su ni yatvā adhikaraṇam yatodakam paṭhama atthe icchanti
translated: They hold that in such passages as “From which source, by which agency, from which cause, from which occasion, from which source, from which beginning,” etc., the word ādi has the first case as its meaning.

original: Ito ehi, ito balāke āgaccha, caṇḍo me vāyaso sakhā iccādīsu dutiyatthe.
analyzed: itas ehi itas balāke āgaccha caṇḍaḥ me vāyasaḥ sakhā icca ādīsu dutiya tthe
translated: Come from here, O cranes, come from here, my friend the hawk is fierce, etc., it has the second case as its meaning.

original: Paratoghoso, nādiṭṭhā parato dosaṃ iccādīsu chaṭṭhyatthe.🔽279. Sabbādito sattamyā tratthā ka. 249; rū. 266; nī. 494; caṃ. 4.1.10; pā. 5.3.10.
analyzed: paratas ghosaḥ na ādiṭṭhā paratas dosam icca ādīsu chaṭṭhī atthe  sabba ādeḥ sattamyā tratthā ka rū nī caṃ pā
translated: The sound from the other side, the hate that is not seen from the other side, etc., it has the sixth case as its meaning.🔽With all ādi, in the seventh, the third, and the fourth cases.

original: Sabbādināmakehi sabbanāmehi sattamiyā atthe tra, tthā honti.
analyzed: sabba ādi nāmakehi sabba nāmehi sattamiyāḥ atthe tra tthāḥ honti
translated: With all words formed with the prefix ā, the seventh case has the forms tra, tthā.

original: Sabbasmiṃ sabbesūti vā sabbatra, sabbattha, sabbassaṃ sabbāsu vātipi. Evaṃ kataratra, katarattha, aññatra, aññattha iccādi.
analyzed: sabbasmin sabbesu iti vā sabbatra sabbattha sabbassam sabbāsu vā atipi evam kataratra katarattha aññatra aññattha iccādi
translated: So too kataratra, katarattha, aññatra, aññattha, etc.

original: Yatra, yattha, tatra, tattha.
analyzed: yatra yattha tatra tattha
translated: Yatra, yattha, tatra, tattha.

original: 280. Katthetthakutrātrakvehidha ka. 251; rū. 269; nī. 499; caṃ. 4.1.11; pā. 5.3.11, 12.
analyzed: kattha ittha kutra atra kva ihidha ka rū nī cam pā
translated: Katthetthakutrātrakvehidha ka. ; rū. ; nī. ; caṃ. ..; pā. .., .

original: Kattha, ettha, kutra, atra, tva, iha, idhāti ete saddāttha, tra,va ha, dhāpaccayantā sattamyatthe sijjhanti.
analyzed: kattha ettha kutra atra tva iha idha ati ete saddāttha trava ha dhā paccayantā sattamī atthe sijjhanti
translated: Kattha, ettha, kutra, atra, tva, iha, idhāti these seven words ending in a locative case are established in the locative case.

original: Kasmiṃ kesūti vā kattha, kutra, kva. ‘Kuva’ntipi sijjhati, “kuvaṃ sattassa kārako, kuvaṃ satto samuppanno saṃ. ni. 1.171, kuvaṃ asissaṃ, kuvaṃ khādissa”nti pāḷi.
analyzed: kasmin vā kattha kutra kva sijjhati kuvam sattassa kārako kuvam satto samuppanno sam ni kuvam asissam kuvam khādissanti
translated: Kasmiṃ, kesūti is kattha, kutra, kva. ‘Kuva’ is also established. “Kuvaṃ sattassa kārako, kuvaṃ satto samuppanno saṃ. ni. ., kuvaṃ asissaṃ, kuvaṃ khādissa” (Ja. i, 165).

original: Etasmiṃ etesūti vā ettha, atra, imasmiṃ imesūti vā iha, idha.
analyzed: etasmin etesu iti vai ettha atra imasmin imesu iti vā iha idha
translated: Etasmiṃ, etesūti is ettha, atra. Imasmiṃ, imesūti is iha, idha.

original: 281. Dhi sabbā vā ka. 250; rū. 268; nī. 502.
analyzed: dhi sabbā vā ka rū nī
translated: . Dhi sabbā vā ka. ; rū. ; nī. .

original: Sabbasaddamhā sattamyatthe dhi hoti vā.
analyzed: sabba saddam hā sattamī atthe dhi hoti vā
translated: Sabbasaddamhā sattamyatthe dhi is established optionally.

original: Namo te buddha vīra’tthu, vippamuttosi sabbadhi saṃ. ni. 1.90.
analyzed: namaḥ te buddha vīratthu vippamuttaḥ asi sabbadhi sam ni
translated: Namo te buddha vīra’tthu, vippamuttosi sabbadhi saṃ. ni. ..🔽.

analyzed: yā hiṃ ka rū nī

original: Yamhā sattamyatthe hiṃ hoti.
analyzed: yam hā sattamī atthe him hoti
translated: Hiṃ is used in the sense of the locative case.

original: Yahiṃ.
analyzed: yahim
translated: Yahiṃ.

original: 283. Tā hañca ka. 253; rū. 273; nī. 501.
analyzed: tā hañca ka rū nī
translated: . Tā hañca ka. ; rū. ; nī. .

original: Tamhā sattamyatthe hiṃ hoti hañca.
analyzed: tamhā sattamī atthe hiṃ hoti hañ ca
translated: Hiṃ is used in the sense of the locative case, and also hañca.

original: Tahiṃ, tahaṃ. Dutiyatthepi dissati “tahaṃ tahaṃ olokento gacchatī”ti.
analyzed: tahim taham dutiya tthe pi dissati taham taham olokentaḥ gacchati iti
translated: Tahiṃ, tahaṃ. It is also seen in the sense of the second case: “He goes looking here and there” .

analyzed: kiṃssa kukañca ka   rū
translated: . Kiṃssa kukañca ka. , --; rū. , --; nī. , -, .

original: Kiṃmhā sattamyatthe hiṃ, taṃ hoti. Kiṃssa kuttaṃ kattañca hoti.
analyzed: sattamī atthe hiṃ tam hoti kiṃssa kuttam kattam ca hoti
translated: Kiṃmhā is used in the sense of the locative case, and also taṃ is used. Kiṃssa kuttaṃ kattañca is used.

original: Kuhiṃ gacchati, kuhaṃ gacchati. Kahaṃ ekaputtaka kahaṃ ekaputtaka saṃ. ni. 2.63. Kuhiñci, kuhiñcananti dve ci, cana-nipātantā sijjhanti.
analyzed: kuhim gacchati kuham gacchati kaham eka puttaka kaham eka puttaka sam ni kuhiñci dve ci cana nipāta antā sijjhanti
translated: Kuhiṃ gacchati, kuhaṃ gacchati. Kahaṃ ekaputtaka kahaṃ ekaputtaka saṃ. ni. .. Kuhiñci, kuhiñcananti dve ci, cana-nipātantā sijjhanti.

original: Iti sāmaññasattamyantarāsi.🔽Kālasattamyantaṃ vuccate.🔽285. Sabbekaññayatehi kāledā ka. 257; rū. 276; nī. 505.
analyzed: iti sāmañña sattamī antarā asi  kāla sattamī antam vuccate  sabbe kañña yatehi kāla idā ka rū nī
translated: Thus the group of locative case endings in common.🔽The locative case endings in the sense of time are stated.🔽. Sabbekaññayatehi kāledā ka. ; rū. ; nī. .

original: Sabba, eka, añña, ya, tasaddehi kāle dā hoti.
analyzed: sabba eka añña ya ta saddehi kāle dā hoti
translated: Kāledā is used with sabba, eka, añña, ya, and tasaddas.🔽.

original: Sabbasmiṃ kāle sabbadā, ekasmiṃ kāle ekadā, aññasmiṃ kāle aññadā, yasmiṃ kāle yadā, tasmiṃ kāle tadā.🔽286. Kadākudāsadāadhunedāni ka. 257-8-9; rū. 276-8-9; nī. 505-6-7.
analyzed: sabbasmin kāle sabbadā ekasmin kāle ekadā aññasmin kāle aññadā yasmin kāle yadā tasmin kāle tadā  kadā kudā sadā adhunā idāni ka rū nī
translated: When? At what time? At what period? Now? At present?

original: Etepi sattamyatthe kāle dā, dhunā, dānipaccayantā sijjhanti.
analyzed: ete pi sattamī atthe kāle dā dhunā dāni paccaya ntā sijjhanti
translated: These also are formed with the suffix -dā, -dhunā, -dāni, in the sense of the locative case.🔽At what time? When? At all times? Always? At this time? Now? At present?

original: Kiṃsmiṃ kāle kadā, kudā, sabbasmiṃ kāle sadā, imasmiṃ kāle adhunā, idāni.🔽287. Ajjasajjuparajjetarahikarahā ka. 259; rū. 279, 423; nī. 507.
analyzed: kiṃsmin kāle kadā kudā sabbasmin kāle sadā imasmin kāle adhunā idāni  ajja sajju parajja itarahi karahā ka rū
translated: Today, immediately, at present, now, at this time, at this moment.

original: Etepi kāle jja, jju, rahi, raha paccayantā sijjhanti.
analyzed: ete pi kāle sijjhanti
translated: These also are formed with the suffix -jja, -jju, -rahi, -raha, in the sense of the locative case.

original: Imasmiṃ kāle ajja, imasmiṃ divasetyattho.
analyzed: imasmin kāle ajja imasmin divasa ityatthaḥ
translated: At this time, today; the meaning is, on this day.

original: Samāne kāle sajju-‘samāne’ti vijjamāne. Na hi pāpaṃ kataṃ kammaṃ, sajju khīraṃva muccati dha. pa. 71, sajjukaṃ pāhesi – tattha ‘sajjū’ti tasmiṃ divase.
analyzed: samāne kāle sajju samānā iti vijjamāne na hi pāpam katam kammam sajju khīram iva muccati sajjukam tattha sajju iti tasmin divase
translated: At the same time, immediately; ‘at the same time’ means existing. For the evil deed done does not immediately bring its fruit, like milk turning to curd. Dhp 101; he sent immediately; there ‘immediately’ means on that day.

original: Aparasmiṃ kāle aparajju, punadivaseti attho.
analyzed: aparasmin kāle punadivasa iti
translated: At another time, at another period; the meaning is, on another day, on a subsequent day.

original: Imasmiṃ kāle etarahi, kiṃsmiṃ kāle karaha. Kutoci, kvaci, katthaci, kuhiñci, kadāci,
analyzed: imasmin kāle etarahi kiṃsmin kāle karaha kutoci kvaci katthaci kuhiñci kadācid
translated: At this time, now, at this time, what time? From somewhere, somewhere, somewhere, somewhere, sometime,

original: karahacisaddā pana ci-nipātantā honti, tathā yato kutoci, yattha katthaci, yadā kadācīti.
analyzed: kara ha ci saddāḥ pana ci nipāta antāḥ honti tathā yatas kutoci yattha katthaci yadā kadāci iti
translated: But karahacisaddā are with the ci-group, thus from somewhere, somewhere, sometime.

original: Kiñcanaṃ, kuhiñcanaṃ, kudācananti cana-nipātantāti.
analyzed: kiñcanam kuhiñcanam kudācananti cana nipātanta ati
translated: Kiñcanaṃ, kuhiñcanaṃ, kudācananti cana-group.

original: Vibhattipaccayantarāsi niṭṭhito.
analyzed: vibhatti paccaya antarā asi niṭṭhitaḥ
translated: The collection of inflected words is finished.

original: Abyayapadāni
analyzed: abyaya padāni
translated: Indefinite words

original: Upasaggapadarāsi
analyzed: upasagga pada rāsi
translated: Prefix words

original: Atha abyayapadāni dīpiyante.
analyzed: atha abyaya padāni dīpiyante
translated: Now the indefinite words are shown.

original: Chabbidhāni abyayapadāni upasaggapadaṃ, nipātapadaṃ, vibhattipaccayantapadaṃ, abyayībhāvasamāsapadaṃ,
analyzed: chabbidhāni abyaya padāni upasagga padam nipāta padam vibhatti paccaya nta padam abyayībhāva samāsa padam
translated: Indefinite words are of six kinds: prefix words, indeclinable words, inflected words,

original: abyayataddhitapadaṃ, tvādipaccayantapadanti. Byayo vuccati vikāro, nānāliṅgavibhattivacanehi
analyzed: a byaya taddhita padam byayaḥ vuccati vikāraḥ nānā liṅga vibhatti vacanehi
translated: indeclinable compounds, indeclinable derivatives, and words with the tvādi case endings. Decay is said to be change, with various genders and case endings,

original: natthi rūpabyayo etesanti abyayā, asaṅkhyāti ca vuccanti.
analyzed: natthi rūpa byayaḥ etesanti abyayāḥ asaṅkhyā ati ca vuccanti
translated: there is no change of form in these, therefore they are indefinite, and they are said to be uncountable.

original: Tattha vibhattipaccayantapadato puna vibhattuppatti nāma natthi. Abyayībhāvasamāsamhi vibhattīnaṃ vidhi samāsakaṇḍe vakkhati, tasmā tāni dve ṭhapetvā sesāni cattāri idha vuccante.🔽288. Asaṅkhyehi sabbāsaṃ caṃ. 2.1.38; pā. 2.4.82.🔽Asaṅkhyehi padehi yathārahaṃ sabbāsaṃ vibhattīnaṃ lopo hoti, kehici padehi paṭhamāya🔽lopo, kehici padehi dutiyāya lopo…pe… kehici sattamiyā, kehici dvinnaṃ, kehici tissannaṃ…pe…🔽kehici sattannanti vuttaṃ hoti.🔽Tattha āvuso, bho, bhanteiccādīhi āmantananipātehi atthi, natthi, sakkā, labbhā, siyā, siyuṃ, sādhu, tuṇhīiccādīhi ca paṭhamāya lopo.
analyzed: tattha vibhatti paccaya anta padato puna nāma natthi abyayībhāva samāsamhi vibhattīnam vidhi samāsa kaṇḍe vakkhati tasmā tāni dve ṭhapetvā sesāni cattāri idha vuccante  asaṅkhyehi sabbāsam cam pā  asaṅkhyehi padehi yathāraham sabbāsam vibhattīnam lopaḥ hoti kehici padehi paṭhamāya  lopaḥ kehici padehi dutiyāya kehici sattamiyā kehici dvinnam kehici  kehici vuttam hoti  tattha āvuso bho bhante iccādīhi āmantana nipātehi atthi natthi sakkā labbhā siyā siyum sādhu tuṇhī iccādīhi ca paṭhamāya lopaḥ
translated: Herein, there is no further appearance of a case-ending after a case-ending and a dependent word. The rule for the case-endings in the indeclinable-compound and the co-pulative compound is stated in the section on compounds, so those two are set aside and the remaining four are mentioned here.

original: Ciraṃ, cirassaṃ, niccaṃ, satataṃ, abhiṇhaṃ, abhikkhaṇaṃ, muhuttaṃ iccādīhi accantasaṃyogalakkhaṇe dutiyāya.
analyzed: ciram cirassam niccam satatam abhiṇham abhikkhaṇam muhuttam icca ādīhi acc anta saṃyoga lakkhaṇe dutiyāya
translated: For a long time, for a long period, constantly, always, frequently, repeatedly, for a moment, etc., are in the second, which has the characteristic of connection with the extreme.

original: Yathā, tathā, sabbathā, sabbaso, musā, micchāiccādīhi tatiyāya.
analyzed: yathā tathā sabbathā sabbasas musā micchā aicca ādīhi tatiyāya
translated: As, thus, in every way, entirely, falsely, wrongly, etc., with the third.

original: Kātuṃ, kātave iccādīhi catutthiyā.
analyzed: kātum kātave icca ādīhi catutthiyā
translated: To do, to be done, etc., with the fourth.

original: Samantā, samantato, dīghaso, orasoiccādīhi pañcamiyā.
analyzed: samantā samantataḥ dīghasaḥ orasaḥ it ca ādīhi pañcamiyā
translated: All round, all around, lengthwise, crosswise, etc., with the fifth.

original: Pure, purā, pacchā, uddhaṃ, upari, adho, heṭṭhā, antarā, anto, raho, āvi, hiyyo, suveiccādīhi sattamiyā lopo.
analyzed: pure purā pacchā uddham upari adhas heṭṭhā antarā antarahar raho āvi hiyyo suveicca ādīhi sattamiyāḥ lopaḥ
translated: Before, formerly, afterwards, above, on high, below, underneath, between, within, in secret, in public, yesterday, tomorrow, etc., with the seventh.

original: Namosaddamhā “namo te buddha vīra’tthū”ti ettha paṭhamāya. “Namo karohi nāgassā”ti ettha dutiyāya.
analyzed: namosaddamhā namaḥ te buddha vīratthu iti ettha paṭhamāya namaḥ karohi nāgassa ati ettha dutiyāya
translated: With the word “homage” in “Homage to you, O Buddha, O hero” it is the first case; in “Do homage to the Nāga” it is the second case.

original: Sayaṃsaddamhā “kusūlo sayameva bhijjate”ti ettha paṭhamāya. “Sayaṃ kataṃ sukhadukkha”nti dī. ni. 3.191, 193 ettha tatiyāya, iccādinā yathārahavibhāgo veditabbo.
analyzed: kusūlaḥ sayam eva bhijjate iti ettha paṭhamāya sayam katam sukha dukkha nti dī ni ettha tatiyāya iccādinā yathāraha vibhāgaḥ veditabbo
translated: With the word “self” in “The bundle of sticks breaks by itself” it is the first case; in “Pleasure and pain are self-made” it is the third case, etc.; the analysis should be understood according to the method.

original: Iti, evaṃsaddehi payogānurūpaṃ sattannaṃ vibhattīnaṃ lopaṃ icchanti.
analyzed: iti evaṃsaddehi payoga anurūpam vibhattīnam lopam icchanti
translated: So they maintain that the omission of the seven cases is according to the construction of the words “thus” and “so.”

original: Upasaggehipi atthānurūpaṃ taṃtaṃvibhattilopo.
analyzed: upasagga ihi pi attha anurūpam taṃ taṃ vibhatti lopaḥ
translated: And also with the prepositions the omission of the respective cases is according to the meaning.

original: Rūpasiddhiyaṃ pana “tehi paṭhamekavacanameva bhavatī”ti rū. 131 (piṭṭhe) vuttaṃ.🔽Tattha “abhikkamati, abhidhammo” iccādīsu dhātuliṅgāni upecca tesaṃ atthaṃ nānāppakāraṃ
analyzed: pana tehi paṭhama ekavacanam eva bhavati iti  tattha abhikkamati abhidhammaḥ iccādīsu dhātu liṅgāni upecca tesam attham nānā ppakāram
translated: But in the Rūpasiddhi it is said: “The prefix is only one in the first case” .🔽Herein, in such words as abhikkamati , abhidhammo , the prefixes are attached to the verbal roots and nouns, and they are called prefixes because they go before and make the meaning of the verbal roots and nouns various in such and such a way.

original: karontā sajjanti saṅkharontīti upasaggā. Te hi kvaci tadatthaṃ visiṭṭhaṃ karonti🔽“jānāti, pajānāti, sañjānāti, avajānāti, abhijānāti, parijānāti, susīlo, dussīlo,
analyzed: karontā sajjanti saṅkharonti iti upasaggā te hi kvaci tad attham visiṭṭham karonti  jānāti pajānāti sañjānāti avajānāti abhijānāti parijānāti su sīlaḥ dussīlaḥ
translated: For they make the meaning of the verbal roots and nouns distinguished in some instances,

original: suvaṇṇo, dubbaṇṇo, surājā, durājā” iccādīsu.
analyzed: suvaṇṇaḥ dubbaṇṇaḥ surājā durājā iccādīsu
translated: as in such passages as “He knows, he understands, he perceives, he despises, he remembers, he fully understands, he is well behaved, he is badly behaved, he is fair, he is ugly, he is a good king, he is a bad king” .

original: Kvaci tadatthaṃ nānāppakāraṃ katvā vibhajjanti “gacchati, āgacchati, uggacchati, ogacchati”iccādīsu.
analyzed: kvacid tad attham katvā vibhajjanti gacchati āgacchati uggacchati ogacchati iccādīsu
translated: In some instances they make the meaning of the verbal roots and nouns various in such and such a way, as in such passages as “he goes, he comes, he goes up, he goes down” .

original: Kvaci tadatthaṃ bādhetvā tappaṭiviruddhe vā tadaññasmiṃ vā atthe tāni yojenti.
analyzed: kvaci tad attham bādhetvā tad paṭiviruddhe vā tad aññasmin vā atthe tāni yojenti
translated: In some instances they are attached to the verbal roots and nouns in order to contradict the meaning or to give a meaning other than that.

original: Tattha tappaṭiviruddhe –
analyzed: tattha tad paṭiviruddhe
translated: Herein, in order to contradict the meaning:

original: Jeti, parājeti, omuñcati, paṭimuñcati, gilati, uggilati, nimmujjati, ummujjati, dhammo, uddhammoiccādi.
analyzed: jeti parājeti omuñcati paṭimuñcati gilati uggilati nimmujjati ummujjati dhammaḥ uddhammaḥ iccādi
translated: “He conquers, he is conquered, he unties, he is untied, he swallows, he is swallowed, he sinks, he floats, he is the Dhamma, he is against the Dhamma” , and so on.

original: Tadaññasmiṃ –
analyzed: tad aññasmin
translated: In order to give a meaning other than that:

original: Dadāti, ādadāti, dadhāti, vidheti, pidheti, nidheti, sandhiyati, saddahati, abhidhātiiccādi.
analyzed: dadāti ādadāti dadhāti vidheti pidheti nidheti sandhiyati saddahati abhidhāti iccādi
translated: gives, receives, places, enjoins, presses, deposits, is joined, is heated, is called, etc.

original: Kvaci pana padasobhaṇaṃ katvā tadatthaṃ anuvattanti, “vijjati, saṃvijjati, labhati, paṭilabhati” iccādi.
analyzed: kvaci pana pada sobhaṇam katvā tad attham anuvattanti vijjati saṃvijjati labhati paṭilabhati iccādi
translated: But in some instances they follow the meaning by making a word- ornament, thus: “exists, is found, obtains, acquires,” etc.

original: Te vīsati honti-pa, ā, u, o, du, ni, vi, su, saṃ, ati, adhi, anu, apa, api, abhi, ava, upa, pati, parā, pari.
analyzed: te vīsati honti pa ā u o du ni vi su sam ati adhi anu apa api abhi ava upa pati parā pari
translated: They are twenty in number, namely, pa, ā, u, o, du, ni, vi, su, saṃ, ati, adhi, anu, apa, api, abhi, ava, upa, pati, parā, pari.

original: Kaccāyane pana osaddo avakāriyamattanti taṃ aggahetvā nīsaddaṃ gaṇhāti, idha pana nīsaddo nissa dīghamattanti taṃ aggahetvā osaddaṃ gaṇhāti.
analyzed: kaccāyane pana osaddaḥ avakāriya mattanti tam aggahetvā nīsaddam gaṇhāti idha pana nīsaddaḥ nissa dīgham attanti tam aggahetvā osaddam gaṇhāti
translated: But in the Kaccāyana grammar the word osaddo is taken not as a root but as a noun, while here the word nīsaddo is taken not as a noun but as a root.

original: Tattha pa –🔽Pakāratthe-paññā. Ādikamme-vippakataṃ. Padhāne-paṇītaṃ. Issariye-pabhū. Antobhāve-pakkhittaṃ,
analyzed: tattha pa  pakāra atthe paññā ādi kamme vippakatam padhāne paṇītam issariye pabhū antobhāve pakkhittam
translated: Herein, pa:🔽In the sense of “cooking” : wisdom . In the sense of “beginning” : done . In the sense of “predominance” : excellent . In the sense of “lordship” : powerful . In the sense of “internal state” : included .

original: passāso. Viyoge-pavāso. Tappare-pācariyo. Tadanubandhe-putto, paputto, nattā, panattā.
analyzed: viyoge pavāsaḥ tad pare pācariyaḥ tad anubandhe putto pa puttaḥ nattā pa nattā
translated: In the sense of “breathing” : breath . In the sense of “separation” : absence . In the sense of “superiority” : teacher . In the sense of “being related to that” : son, grandson, nephew, great-nephew.

original: Bhusatthe-pavaḍḍho. Sambhave-pabhavati. Tittiyaṃ-pahutaṃ annaṃ. Anāvile-pasanno.🔽Patthanāyaṃ-paṇidhānaṃ.🔽Ā –🔽Abhimukhe-āgacchati. Uddhaṃkamme-ārohati. Mariyādāyaṃ-āpabbatā khettaṃ. Abhividhimhi-ābrahmalokā🔽kittisaddo. Pattiyaṃ-āpanno. Icchāyaṃ-ākaṅkhā. Parissajane-āliṅgati. Ādikamme-ārambho.🔽Gahaṇe-ādīyati. Nivāse-āvasatho. Samīpe-āsannaṃ. Avhāne-āmantanaṃ.🔽U –
analyzed: sambhave pabhavati tittiyam pahutam annam anāvile pasannaḥ  patthanāyaṃpaṇidhānam  ā  abhimukhe āgacchati uddhaṃkamme ārohati khettam  kitti saddaḥ pattiyam āpannaḥ icchāyam ākaṅkhā parissajane āliṅgati ādi kamme ārambhaḥ  nivāse āvasathaḥ samīpe āsannam avhāne āmantanam  u
