translated: In the sense of ‘increasing’ (pavaḍḍho) in the sense of ‘prospering’ (pabhavati) in the sense of ‘abundance’ (pahutaṃ) in the sense of ‘clear’ (pasanno) in the sense of ‘aspiration’ (paṇidhānaṃ).🔽Ā –🔽In the sense of ‘coming’ (āgacchati) in the sense of ‘ascending’ (ārohati) in the sense of ‘boundary’ (āpabbatā) in the sense of ‘abode’ (ābrahmalokā) in the sense of ‘attained’ (āpanno) in the sense of ‘desire’ (ākaṅkhā) in the sense of ‘embracing’ (āliṅgati) in the sense of ‘beginning’ (ārambho).🔽In the sense of ‘taking’ (ādīyati) in the sense of ‘dwelling’ (āvasatho) in the sense of ‘near’ (āsannaṃ) in the sense of ‘invitation’ (āmantanaṃ).🔽U –🔽🔽

original: Uggate-uggacchati. Uddhaṃkamme-uṭṭhāti. Padhāne-uttaro. Viyoge-upavāso. Sambhave-ubbhūto. Atthalābhe-rūpassa uppādo. Sattiyaṃ-ussahati gantuṃ. Sarūpakhyāne-uddeso.🔽O –🔽Antobhāve-ocarako, orodho. Adhokamme-okkhitto. Niggahe-ovādo. Antare, dese ca-okāso. Pātubhāve-opapātiko. Yesu atthesu avasaddo vattati, tesupi osaddo vattati.🔽Du –
analyzed: uggate uggacchati uddham kamme uṭṭhāti padhāne uttaraḥ viyoge upavāsaḥ sambhave ubbhūtaḥ attha lābhe rūpassa uppādo sattiyam ussahati gantum sarūpa khyāne uddesaḥ 🔽o 🔽orodhaḥ adhokamme okkhittaḥ niggahe ovādaḥ antare dese ca okāsaḥ pātubhāve opapātikaḥ yesu atthesu avasaddaḥ vattati tesu pi osaddaḥ vattati 🔽du
translated: In the sense of ‘increasing’ (pavaḍḍho) in the sense of ‘prospering’ (pabhavati) in the sense of ‘abundant’ (pahutaṃ) in the sense of ‘pleased’ (pasanno) in the sense of ‘aspiration’ (paṇidhānaṃ) in the sense of ‘going’ (āgacchati) in the sense of ‘climbing’ (ārohati) in the sense of ‘boundary’ (āpabbatā khettaṃ) in the sense of ‘the sound of fame’ (kittisaddo) in the sense of ‘attained’ (āpanno) in the sense of ‘desire’ (ākaṅkhā) in the sense of ‘embracing’ (āliṅgati) in the sense of ‘beginning’ (ārambho) in the sense of ‘taking’ (ādīyati) in the sense of ‘dwelling’ (āvasatho) in the sense of ‘near’ (āsannaṃ) in the sense of ‘invitation’ (āmantanaṃ) in the sense of ‘rising’ (uggacchati) in the sense of ‘rising up’ (uṭṭhāti) in the sense of ‘superior’ (uttaro) in the sense of ‘separation’ (upavāso) in the sense of ‘arisen’ (ubbhūto) in the sense of ‘appearance’ (uppādo) in the sense of ‘able to go’ (ussahati gantuṃ) in the sense of ‘preaching’ (uddeso) in the sense of ‘wandering’ (ocarako, orodho) in the sense of ‘thrown down’ (okkhitto) in the sense of ‘advice’ (ovādo) in the sense of ‘place’ (okāso) in the sense of ‘appearing’ (opapātiko) in the sense of ‘dwelling’ (avasaddo) in the sense of ‘dwelling’ (osaddo) in the sense of ‘going’ (gacchati) in the sense of ‘rising up’ (uṭṭhāti) in the sense of ‘superior’ (uttaro) in the sense of ‘separation’ (upavāso) in the sense of ‘arisen’ (ubbhūto) in the sense of ‘appearance’ (uppādo) in the sense of ‘able to go’ (ussahati g

original: Asobhaṇe-duggandho. Abhāve-dubbhikkhaṃ, dussīlo, duppañño. Kucchite-dukkaṭaṃ. Asamiddhiyaṃ-dusassaṃ. Kicche-dukkaraṃ. Virūpe-dubbaṇṇo, dummukho.
analyzed: a sobhaṇe duggandhaḥ abhāve dubbhikkham dussīlaḥ duppaññaḥ kucchite dukkaṭam a samiddhiyaṃ dusassam kicche dukkaram virūpe dubbaṇṇaḥ dummukhaḥ
translated: In the sense of not to be smelt: foul-smelling. In the sense of absence: famine, unvirtuous, unwise. In the sense of belly: misconduct. In the sense of not being kindled: bad harvest. In the sense of difficulty: difficult. In the sense of ugly: ugly, ugly-faced.

original: Ni –🔽Nissese-nirutti. Niggate-niyyānaṃ. Nīharaṇe-niddhāraṇaṃ. Antopavesane-nikhāto. Abhāve-nimmakkhikaṃ.
analyzed: ni  nissese nirutti niggate niyyānam nīharaṇe niddhāraṇam anta upavesane nikhātaḥ abhāve nimmakkhikam
translated: Ni –🔽In the sense of remainder: language. In the sense of gone out: outlet. In the sense of taking out: taking out. In the sense of being put inside: thrown in. In the sense of absence: free from salt.

original: Nisedhe-nivāreti. Nikkhante-nibbānaṃ. Pātubhāve-nimmitaṃ. Avadhāraṇe-vinicchayo.
analyzed: nisedhe nivāreti nikkhantenibbānam pātubhāvenimmitam avadhāraṇe vinicchayaḥ
translated: In the sense of stopping: he stops. In the sense of gone forth: Nibbāna. In the sense of manifestation: created. In the sense of determining: decision.

original: Vibhajjane-niddeso. Upamāyaṃ-nidassanaṃ. Upadhāraṇe-nisāmeti. Avasāne-niṭṭhitaṃ. Cheke-nipuṇo.
analyzed: vibhajjane niddesaḥ upamāyam nidassanam upadhāraṇe nisāma iti avasāne niṭṭhitam cheke nipuṇaḥ
translated: In the sense of distinguishing: description. In the sense of simile: illustration. In the sense of holding: he holds. In the sense of end: finished. In the sense of skill: skilled.

original: Vi –
analyzed: vi
translated: Vi –🔽🔽

original: Visese-vipassati. Vividhe-vicittaṃ. Viruddhe-vivādo. Vigate-vimalo. Viyoge-vippayutto. Virūpe-vippaṭisāro.
analyzed: visese vipassati vividhe vicittam viruddhe vivādaḥ vigate vimalaḥ viyoge vippayuttaḥ virūpe vippaṭisāraḥ
translated: In the sense of distinction: he sees. In the sense of various: variegated. In the sense of opposed: dispute. In the sense of departed: stainless. In the sense of separation: unassociated. In the sense of ugly: regret.

original: Su –
analyzed: su
translated: Su –🔽🔽

original: Sobhaṇe-suggati. Sundare-sumano. Sammāsaddatthe-sugato. Samiddhiyaṃ-subhikkhaṃ. Sukhatthe-sukaro.
analyzed: sobhaṇe suggati sundare sumano sammā saddatthe sugato samiddhiyam subhikkham sukhatthe sukaro
translated: In the sense of beautiful: good destination. In the sense of lovely: well-disposed. In the sense of right faith: well-gone. In the sense of being kindled: good harvest. In the sense of pleasant: easy.

original: Saṃ –
analyzed: sam
translated: Sāriputta:🔽🔽

original: Samodhāne-sandhi. Sammā, samatthesu-samādhi, sampayutto. Samantabhāve-saṃkiṇṇo. Saṅgate-samāgamo,
analyzed: samodhāne sandhi sammā samatthe su samādhi sampayuttaḥ samanta bhāve saṃkiṇṇaḥ saṅgate samāgamaḥ
translated: In combination: a junction. In the sense of right: concentration. In the sense of being able: concentration. In the sense of being associated: associated. In the sense of being all-round: mixed. In the sense of being joined: a meeting.

original: saṅkhepe-samāso. Bhusatthe-sāratto. Sahatthe-saṃvāso, sambhogo. Appatthe-samaggho.
analyzed: saṅkhepe samāsaḥ bhu satthe sārattaḥ saha atthe saṃvāsaḥ sambhogaḥ appatthe samagghaḥ
translated: In the sense of being brief: a compound. In the sense of being abundant: affection. In the sense of being in the hand: living together, enjoyment. In the sense of being not enough: united.

original: Pabhave-sambhavo. Abhimukhe-sammukhaṃ. Saṅgahe-saṅgayhati. Pidahane-saṃvuto. Punappunakamme-sandhāvati,
analyzed: abhimukhe sammukham saṅgahe saṅgayhati pidahane saṃvutaḥ punappuna kamme sandhāvati
translated: In the sense of origination: origination. In the sense of being in front: face to face. In the sense of being collected: he collects. In the sense of being covered: covered. In the sense of being done again and again: he runs,

original: saṃsarati. Samiddhiyaṃ-sampanno.
analyzed: saṃsarati samiddhiyam sampannaḥ
translated: he transmigrates. In the sense of being complete: endowed.

original: Ati –
analyzed: ati
translated: Ati –

original: Atikkame-atirocati, accayo, atīto. Atikkante-accantaṃ. Atissaye-atikusalo. Bhusatthe-atikodho. Antokamme-mañcaṃ vā pīṭhaṃ vā atiharitvā ṭhapeti.
analyzed: atikkame atirocati accayaḥ atītaḥ atikkante accantam atissaye atikusalaḥ bhusatthe ati kodhaḥ antokamme mañcam vā pīṭham vā atiharitvā ṭhapeti
translated: In the sense of surpassing: he surpasses, transgression, past. In the sense of being past: extreme. In the sense of being superior: very skilled. In the sense of being abundant: great anger. In the sense of being done inside: having carried a bed or chair, he sets it down.

original: Adhi –
analyzed: adhi
translated: Adhi –

original: Adhike-adhisīlaṃ. Issare-adhipati, adhibrahmadatte pañcālā. Uparibhāve-adhiseti.
analyzed: adhike adhisīlam issare adhipati adhibrahmadatte pañcālā upari bhāve adhiseti
translated: In the sense of being superior: higher virtue. In the sense of being powerful: lord, the Brahmadattas of Pañcāla. In the sense of being in a higher state: he rules.

original: Paribhavane-adhibhūto. Ajjhāyane-ajjheti, byākaraṇamadhīte. Adhiṭṭhāne-navakammaṃ
analyzed: paribhavane adhibhūtaḥ byākaraṇam adhīte
translated: In the sense of being reproached: reproached. In the sense of being recited: he recites, he has mastered the grammar. In the sense of being determined: new work,

original: adhiṭṭhāti, cīvaraṃ adhiṭṭhāti, iddhivikubbanaṃ adhiṭṭhāti. Nicchaye-adhimuccati.
analyzed: adhiṭṭhāti cīvaram adhiṭṭhāti iddhi vikubbanam adhiṭṭhāti nicchaye adhimuccati
translated: He is confident in the case of:

original: Pāpuṇane-bhogakkhandhaṃ adhigacchati, amataṃ adhigacchati.
analyzed: pāpuṇana bhoga kkhandham adhigacchati amatam adhigacchati
translated: He attains the aggregate of pleasure, he attains the deathless.

original: Anu –🔽Anugate-anveti. Anuppacchinne-anusayo. Pacchāsaddatthe-anurathaṃ. Punappunabhāve-anvaḍḍhamāsaṃ,
analyzed: anu  anugate anveti anuppacchinne anusayo pacchā saddatthe anuratham punappunabhāve anvaḍḍhamāsam
translated: Anu:

original: anusaṃvaccharaṃ. Yogyabhāve-anurūpaṃ.Kaniṭṭhabhāve-anubuddho, anuthero. Sesaṃ kārakakaṇḍe vakkhati.
analyzed: anusaṃvaccharam yogya bhāve anurūpam kaniṭṭha bhāve anubuddhaḥ anu theraḥ sesam kāraka kaṇḍe vakkhati
translated: He follows what has gone: he follows. He follows what has not been cut off: a latent tendency. He follows what is meant by the word “after”: he is eager. He follows what is repeated: every half-month, every year. He follows what is suitable: what is suitable. He follows what is junior: a junior, a junior monk. The rest he will explain in the chapter on the case endings.

original: Apa –
analyzed: apa
translated: Apa:

original: Apagate-apeti, apāyo. Garahe-apagabbho, apasaddo. Vajjane-apasālāya āyanti. Pūjāyaṃ-vuḍḍha-mapacāyanti. Padussane-aparajjhati.
analyzed: apagate apeti apāyaḥ garahe apagabbhaḥ apasaddaḥ vajjane apasālāya āyanti pūjāyaṃvuḍḍham apacāyanti padussane aparajjhati
translated: He sends away what has gone: he sends away, a bad destination. He sends away what is blame: a non-abortion, a non-offensive sound. He sends away what is to be rejected: they come to a non-thatched shed. He sends away what is worship: they honour the elders. He sends away what is to be transgressed: they do not transgress.

original: Api –🔽Sambhāvane-apipabbataṃ bhindeyya, merumpi vinivijjheyya. Apekkhāyaṃ-ayampi dhammo
analyzed: api  sambhāvane api pabbatam bhindeyya merum pi vinivijjheyya apekkha ayam ayam pi dhammo
translated: Api:

original: aniyato. Samuccaye-itipi arahaṃ, chavimpi dahati, cammampi dahati, maṃsampi dahati.
analyzed: aniyataḥ samuccaye itipi araham chavim dahati cammam pi dahati maṃsam pi dahati
translated: He is confident in the case of: he would split a mountain, he would cleave a rock. He is confident in the case of: this rule too is not definite. He is confident in the case of: he is a Perfect One, he burns the skin, he burns the flesh, he burns the sinews.

original: Garahāyaṃ-api amhākaṃ paṇḍitaka. Pucchāyaṃ-api bhante bhikkhaṃ labhittha, api nu tumhe sotukāmāttha.
analyzed: amhākam paṇḍitaka pucchāyam api bhante bhikkham labhittha api nu tumhe sotu kāmā āttha
translated: In the sense of blame, too, (we say) our learned one. In the sense of asking, too, venerable Sir, did you get alms? Do you wish to hear?

original: Abhi –
analyzed: abhi
translated: Abhi –

original: Abhimukhe-abhikkanto. Visiṭṭhe-abhiññā. Adhike-abhidhammo. Uddhaṃkamme-abhirūhati. Kule-abhijāto. Sāruppe-abhirūpo. Vandane-abhivādeti. Sesaṃ kārakakaṇḍe vakkhati.
analyzed: abhimukhe abhikkantaḥ visiṭṭhe abhiññā adhike abhidhammaḥ uddhaṃkamme abhirūhati kule abhijātaḥ sāruppe abhirūpaḥ vandane abhivādeti sesam kāraka kaṇḍe vakkhati
translated: (It means) gone forward in the sense of facing; direct knowledge in the sense of distinguished; the Abhidhamma in the sense of superior; he ascends in the sense of upper action; he is of high birth in the sense of family; he is handsome in the sense of beauty; he worships in the sense of saluting. The rest (will be explained) in the section on the doing.

original: Ava –
analyzed: ava
translated: Ava –

original: Adhobhāge-avakkhitto. Viyoge-avakokilaṃ vanaṃ. Paribhave-avajānāti. Jānane-avagacchati. Suddhiyaṃ-vodāyati, vodānaṃ. Nicchaye-avadhāraṇaṃ. Dese-avakāso. Theyye-avahāro.
analyzed: adhobhāge avakkhittaḥ viyoge avakokilam vanam paribhave avajānāti jānane avagacchati suddhiyam vodāyati vodānam nicchaye avadhāraṇam dese avakāsaḥ theyye avahāraḥ
translated: (It means) thrown down in the sense of the lower part; the cuckoo forest in the sense of separation; he despises in the sense of contempt; he understands in the sense of knowing; it is purified in the sense of purification; it is a definition in the sense of certainty; it is an opportunity in the sense of a place; it is a loss in the sense of a trick.

original: Upa –
analyzed: upa
translated: Upa –

original: Upagame-upanisīdati. Samīpe-upacāro, upanagaraṃ. Upapattiyaṃ-saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati.
analyzed: upagame upanisīdati samīpe upacāraḥ upanagaram upapattiyam saggam lokam upapajjati
translated: (It means) he sits down in the sense of approaching; it is a custom in the sense of near; a suburb in the sense of near the city; he is reborn in the sense of rebirth; in the world of heaven.

original: Sadise-upamāṇaṃ, upameyyaṃ. Adhike-upakhāriyaṃ doṇo. Uparibhāve – upasampanno, upacayo.
analyzed: upameyyam adhikeupakhāriyam doṇaḥ upari bhāve upasampannaḥ upacayaḥ
translated: It is a simile in the sense of a similar thing; it is a thing compared in the sense of a similar thing; it is a gift in the sense of superior; a measure in the sense of more.

original: Anasane-upavāso. Dosakkhāne-paraṃ upavadati. Saññāyaṃ-upadhā, upasaggo. Pubbakamme-upakkamo,
analyzed: an asane upavāsaḥ dosa kkhāne param upavadati saññā ayam upadhā upasaggaḥ pubba kamme upakkamaḥ
translated: In the sense of not being taken: the Uposatha of the non-virtuous. In the sense of accusing: one accuses another. In the sense of a sign: a sign, a prefix. In the sense of previous action: a crime,

original: upahāro. Pūjāyaṃ-buddhaṃ upaṭṭhāti. Gayhākāre-paccupaṭṭhānaṃ. Bhusatthe-upādānaṃ,
analyzed: upahāro upaṭṭhāti gayhākāre paccupaṭṭhānam bhusatthe upādānam
translated: a present. In the sense of worship: one attends on the Buddha. In the sense of a mode of conveyance: a means of conveyance. In the sense of a store: a store,

original: upāyāso, upanissayo.
analyzed: upāyāsaḥ upanissayaḥ
translated: a storehouse, a reliance.

original: Pati –🔽Patigate-paccakkhaṃ. Paṭilome-paṭisotaṃ. Paṭiyogimhi-paṭipuggalo. Nisedhe-paṭisedho.
analyzed: pati  patigate paccakkham paṭilome paṭisotam paṭiyogimhi paṭipuggalaḥ nisedhe paṭisedhaḥ
translated: Paṭi –🔽In the sense of a path: a direct path. In the sense of going against: going against the stream. In the sense of an opponent: an opponent. In the sense of a prohibition: a prohibition.

original: Nivatte-paṭikkamati. Sadise-paṭirūpakaṃ. Paṭikamme-rogassa paṭikāro. Ādāne-paṭiggaṇhāti.
analyzed: nivatte paṭikkamati sadise paṭirūpakam paṭikamme rogassa paṭikāraḥ ādāne paṭiggaṇhāti
translated: In the sense of turning back: one turns back. In the sense of a likeness: a likeness. In the sense of a remedy: a remedy for a disease. In the sense of receiving: one receives.

original: Paṭibodhe-paṭivedho. Paṭicce-paccayo. Sesaṃ kārakakaṇḍe vakkhati.
analyzed: paṭibodhe paṭivedhaḥ paṭiccepaccayo sesam kāraka kaṇḍe vakkhati
translated: In the sense of penetrating: penetration. In the sense of a condition: a condition. The rest is stated in the section on the causative.

original: Parā –
analyzed: parā
translated: Parā –

original: Parihāniyaṃ-parābhavo. Parājaye-parājito. Gatiyaṃ-parāyanaṃ. Vikkame-parakkamo. Āmasane-parāmasanaṃ.
analyzed: parihāniyam parābhavaḥ parājaye parājitaḥ gatiyam parāyanam vikkame parakkamaḥ āmasane parāmasanam
translated: In the sense of a loss: a loss. In the sense of defeat: defeated. In the sense of a destination: a destination. In the sense of exertion: exertion. In the sense of a touch: a touch.

original: Pari –
analyzed: pari
translated: Pari –

original: Samantabhāve-parivuto, parikkhitto, parikkhāro. Paricchede-pariññeyyaṃ, parijānāti.
analyzed: samanta bhāve parivutaḥ parikkhittaḥ parikkhāraḥ paricchede pariññeyyam parijānāti
translated: In the sense of surrounding: surrounded, surrounded by, an attendant. In the sense of delimitation: what should be fully known, one fully knows.

original: Vajjane-pariharati. Parihāro. Āliṅgane-parissajati. Nivāsane-vatthaṃ paridahati.
analyzed: vajjane pariharati parihāraḥ āliṅgane parissajati nivāsane vattham paridahati
translated: He avoids what is improper. The avoidance. He embraces in the embrace. He puts on the robe in the robe.

original: Pūjāyaṃ-pāricariyā. Bhojane-parivisati. Abhibhave-paribhavati. Dosakkhāne-paribhāsati.
analyzed: pūjā idam pāricariyā bhojane parivisati abhibhave paribhavati dosa khāne paribhāsati
translated: He attends on in the worship. He serves in the food. He despises in the overcoming. He reviles in the accusation.

original: Sesaṃ kārakakaṇḍe vakkhati.
analyzed: sesam kāraka kaṇḍe vakkhati
translated: The rest he will explain in the section on the doing.

original: Nīsaddo pana nīharaṇa, nīvaraṇādīsu vattati, nīharaṇaṃ, nīvaraṇaṃiccādi.
analyzed: nī saddaḥ pana nīharaṇa nīvaraṇa ādīsu vattati nīharaṇam nīvaraṇam iccādi
translated: But the word ni means taking away, and it occurs in the senses of obstruction, etc., as in taking away, obstruction, etc.

original: Iti upasaggapadarāsi.
analyzed: iti upasagga pada rāsi
translated: So much for the mass of prefix words.

original: Nipātapadarāsi
analyzed: nipāta pada rā asi
translated: Mass of enclitic words

original: Niccaṃ ekarūpena vākyapathe patantīti nipātā. Padānaṃ ādi, majjhā’vasānesu nipatantīti nipātātipi vadanti.
analyzed: niccam eka rūpena vākya pathe patanti iti nipātā padānam ādi majjha avasānesu nipatanti iti nipāta atipi vadanti
translated: They are called enclitics because they always occur in a sentence in one and the same form, or because they occur at the beginning, in the middle, and at the end of words.

original: Asatvavācakā cādisaddā nipātā nāma. Te pana vibhattiyuttā, ayuttā cāti duvidhā honti.
analyzed: ca ādi saddāḥ nipātāḥ nāma te pana vibhatti yuttā ayuttā ca ati duvidhā honti
translated: Enclitics are words that do not express a substantive. They are of two kinds, namely, those that are connected with a case-ending and those that are not so connected.

original: Tattha vibhattiyuttā pubbe dassitā eva. Cādayo ayuttā nāma. Te pana anekasatappabhedā
analyzed: tattha vibhatti yuttā pubbe dassitā eva ca ādayaḥ ayuttāḥ nāma te pana aneka sata ppabhedā
translated: Herein, those that are connected with a case-ending have already been shown above. Those that are not so connected are called enclitics beginning with ca. They are of many hundreds of different kinds.

original: honti. Nighaṇṭusatthesu gahetabbāti.
analyzed: honti nighaṇṭu satthesu gahetabbā ati
translated: They should be learnt from the Nighaṇṭus.

original: Abyayataddhitapaccayapadarāsi
analyzed: a byaya taddhita pad caya pada rā si
translated: Mass of indeclinable, nominal-derivative, and preposition words

original: Abyayataddhitapaccayantā nāma yathā, tathā, ekadhā, ekajjhaṃ, sabbaso, kathaṃ, itthaṃ iccādayo. Tehi tatiyālopo.
analyzed: abyaya taddhita paccaya antāḥ nāma yathā tathā ekadhā ekajjham sabbaso katham ittham icca ādayaḥ tehi tatiyā lopo
translated: The indeclinables of the 3rd case ending in -aya are: yathā, tathā, ekadhā, ekajjhaṃ, sabbaso, kathaṃ, itthaṃ, etc. The 3rd case is elided after them.

original: Tvādipaccayantapadarāsi
analyzed: tva ādi pad ca yanta pada rāsi
translated: The indeclinables of the 2nd case ending in -tvā, etc.

original: Tvādipaccayantā nāma katvā, katvāna, kātuna, kātuṃ, kātave, dakkhitāye, hetuye, ādāya,
analyzed: tu ādi paccaya antā nāma katvā katvāna kātum kātave dakkhitāye hetuye ādāya
translated: The indeclinables of the 2nd case ending in -tvā, etc. are: katvā, katvāna, kātuna, kātuṃ, kātave, dakkhitāye, hetuye, ādāya,

original: upādāya, viceyya, vineyya, sakkacca, āhacca, upasampajja, samecca, avecca, paṭicca,🔽aticca, āgamma, ārabbhaiccādayo. Tesu tvā, tvānantehi paṭhamālopo. Tuṃ, tave, tāye,
analyzed: upādāya viceyya vineyya sakkacca āhacca upasampajja samecca avecca paṭicca  a ticcaḥ āgammaḥ ārabbha e c ca ādayaḥ tesu tvā tvā an antehi paṭhama ā lopaḥ tum tave tāye
translated: upādāya, viceyya, vineyya, sakkacca, āhacca, upasampajja, samecca, avecca, paṭicca,🔽aticca, āgamma, ārabbha, etc. The 1st case is elided after tvā and tvān. The 4th case is elided after tuṃ, tave, tāye,

original: tuyepaccayantehi catutthīlopoti.
analyzed: tuye paccaya antehi catutthī lopaḥ iti
translated: tuṃ, and tvā.

original: Dhātavo paccayā ceva, upasagganipātakā.
analyzed: dhātavaḥ paccayāḥ ca iva upasagga nipātakā
translated: The cases are the endings, and the prefixes and particles,

original: Anekatthāva te paṭi-sambhidā ñāṇagocarā.
analyzed: anekatthā ava te paṭisambhidā ñāṇa gocarā
translated: Are the many meanings, the sphere of the knowledge of the analytical insights.

original: Iti niruttidīpaniyā nāma moggallānadīpaniyā
analyzed: iti niruttidīpaniyā nāma moggallānadīpaniyā
translated: Thus ends the Moggallāna commentary called “The Explanation of the Analysis of the Language.”

original: Nāmakaṇḍo niṭṭhito.
analyzed: nāmakaṇḍaḥ niṭṭhitaḥ
translated: The section on nouns is finished.

original: 3. Kārakakaṇḍa
analyzed: kāraka kaṇḍa
translated: The section on verbs

original: Paṭhamāvibhattirāsi
analyzed: paṭhamā vibhattiḥ āsi
translated: The first case

original: Atha nāmavibhattīnaṃ atthabhedā vuccante.
analyzed: atha nāma vibhattīnam attha bhedāḥ vuccante
translated: Now the meanings of the case endings are stated.

original: Kasmiṃ atthe paṭhamā?
analyzed: kasmin atthe paṭhamā
translated: In what meaning is the first case?

original: 289. Paṭhamatthamatte caṃ. 2.1.93; pā. 2.3.46.
analyzed: paṭhama ttha matte cam pā
translated: And in the first meaning.

original: Nāmassa abhidheyyamatte paṭhamāvibhatti hoti.
analyzed: nāmassa abhidheyya matte paṭhamā vibhatti hoti
translated: The first case-ending is in the mere name-set.

original: Rukkho, mālā, dhanaṃ.
analyzed: rukkhaḥ mālā dhanam
translated: Tree, garland, wealth.

original: Ettha ca mattasaddena kattu, kammādike vibhatyatthe nivatteti. Tasmā atthamattanti liṅgatthoyeva vuccati.
analyzed: ettha ca matta saddena kattu kamma ādike vibhati atthe nivatteti tasmai vuccati
translated: And here the word “mere” excludes the meaning of the case-ending as the doing, the action, etc., so that the “mere meaning” is said to be the meaning of the gender only.

original: Tattha anuccārite sati suṇantassa avidito attho līnattho nāma. Taṃ līnamatthaṃ gameti bodhetīti liṅgaṃ, uccāritapadaṃ.
analyzed: tattha anuccārite sati suṇantassa aviditaḥ atthaḥ līnatthaḥ nāma tam līnam attham gama iti bodheti iti liṅgam uccārita padam
translated: And here, when it is not uttered, the meaning unknown to the listener is called “latent meaning.” It “goes” to that latent meaning, it “makes known,” therefore it is the “gender,” the word uttered.

original: Taṃ pana pakatiliṅgaṃ, nipphannaliṅganti duvidhaṃ. Tattha vibhattirahitaṃ pakatiliṅgaṃ idhādhippetaṃ liṅga, vibhattīnaṃ visuṃ visuṃ vibhāgaṭṭhānattā.
analyzed: tam pana pakati liṅgam nipphanna liṅgan ti duvidham tattha vibhatti rahitam pakati liṅgam idha adhippetam liṅga vibhattīnam visum visum vibhāga ṭṭhāna ttā
translated: But that is twofold, namely, unmanifested gender and manifested gender. Herein, the unmanifested gender is intended as the gender, for the case-endings are the place of division of each one.

original: Līnaṃ aṅganti liṅgaṃ. Tattha ‘līna’nti apākaṭaṃ. ‘Aṅga’nti avayavo. Liṅgaṃ, nāmaṃ, pāṭipadikanti atthato ekaṃ.
analyzed: līnam aṅgam ti liṅgam tattha līnam ati apākaṭam aṅgam ti avayavaḥ liṅgam nāmam pāṭipadikam ti atthataḥ ekam
translated: The gender is a part that is latent. Herein, “latent” is obscure; “part” is a component. Gender, name, and description are the same in meaning.

original: Liṅgassa attho paramattho, paññattiatthoti duvidho. Tathā visesanattho, visesyatthoti.
analyzed: liṅgassa attho paramattho paññatti attho ti duvidhaḥ tathā visesana ttho visesya ttho ti
translated: The meaning of the gender is twofold, namely, ultimate meaning and description meaning. Likewise, it is twofold as the meaning of the distinguishing and the meaning of the distinguished.

original: Tattha visesanattho nāma sakattho, tassa tassa saddassa paṭiniyato pāṭipuggalikatthoti🔽vuttaṃ hoti. Soyeva tasmiṃ tasmiṃ atthe ādimhi sadduppattiyā cirakālañca saddapavattiyā
analyzed: tattha visesana tthaḥ nāma saka atthaḥ tassa tassa saddassa paṭiniyataḥ pāṭipuggalika ttho ti  vuttam hoti saḥ yā iva tasmin tasmin atthe ādimhi sadda uppattiyā cira kālam ca sadda pavattiyā
translated: Herein, the meaning of a distinguishing term is the individual meaning of this or that word, the meaning of a particular person.🔽What is meant is that it is the meaning of a word as it is used in a particular instance. It is called the “sign meaning” because it is the cause of the word’s being fixed on that particular meaning, since the word has been used to signify that meaning from the beginning of its use and has continued to be used to signify it for a long time.

original: nibaddhakāraṇattā nimittatthoti ca vuccati. So suti, jāti, guṇa, dabba, kriyā, nāma,
analyzed: nibaddha kāraṇa ttā nimitta atthaḥ ti ca vuccati saḥ suti jāti guṇa dabba kriyā nāma
translated: It is of seven kinds as consisting of hearing, class, quality, action, name,

original: sambandhavasena sattavidho hoti.🔽Visesyattho nāma sāmaññattho, bahunimittānaṃ sādhāraṇatthoti vuttaṃ hoti, soyeva
analyzed: sambandha vasena sattavidhaḥ  visesya tthaḥ nāma sāmañña tthaḥ bahu nimittānam sādhāraṇa tthaḥ iti vuttam hoti saḥ yā iva
translated: and relation.

original: taṃtaṃnimittayogā nemittakatthoti ca vuccati, so jāti, guṇa, dabba, kriyā, nāmavasena
analyzed: ca vuccati saḥ jāti guṇa dabba kriyā nāma vasena
translated: The meaning of a distinguished term is the general meaning, what is common to many signified things. What is meant is that it is the meaning of a word as it is used in a general sense. It is called the “signified meaning” because it is the cause of the word’s being fixed on that general meaning, since the word has been used to signify that meaning from the beginning of its use and has continued to be used to signify it for a long time.🔽It is of five kinds as consisting of class, quality, action, name, and substance.

original: pañcavidho. Go, sukko, daṇḍī, pācako, tissoti.
analyzed: pañcavidhaḥ go sukkaḥ daṇḍī pācako tisso ti
translated: “Cow,” “white,” “walking,” “cook,” “three.”

original: Tattha gosaddo yadā jātimattaṃ vadati go jātīti, tadā suti visesanaṃ. Yadā dabbaṃ vadati go gacchatīti, tadā suti ca jāti ca visesanaṃ.
analyzed: tattha go saddaḥ yadā jātimattam vadati go jāti iti tadā suti visesanam yadā dabbam vadati go gacchati iti tadā suti ca jāti ca visesanam
translated: Herein, when the word “cow” signifies mere class, as in “Cow is a class,” then hearing is the distinguishing term. When it signifies quality, as in “The cow is walking,” then hearing and class are the distinguishing terms.

original: Sukkasaddo yadā guṇamattaṃ vadati sukko guṇoti, tadā suti visesanaṃ. Yadā guṇavisesaṃ
analyzed: sukka saddaḥ yadā guṇa mattam vadati sukkaḥ guṇoti tadā suti visesanam yadā guṇa visesam
translated: When the word “good” expresses mere quality, “good” is a quality, then the suffix is a distinguisher. When it expresses a particular quality,

original: vadati gossa sukkoti, tadā suti ca guṇajāti ca visesanaṃ. Yadā guṇavantaṃ dabbaṃ
analyzed: vadati gossa tadā suti ca guṇa jāti ca visesanam yadā guṇavantam dabbam
translated: “of the cow,” then the suffix and the quality are distinguishers. When it expresses a possessor of a quality,

original: vadati sukko goti, tadā suti ca guṇajāti ca guṇaviseso ca sambandho ca visesanaṃ.🔽Daṇḍīsaddo yadā jātimattaṃ vadati daṇḍī jātīti, tadā suti ca dabbañca visesanaṃ.
analyzed: vadati tadā suti ca guṇa jāti ca guṇa visesaḥ ca sambandhaḥ ca visesanam  daṇḍī saddaḥ yadā jātimattam vadati daṇḍī jātī iti tadā ca dabbam ca visesanam
translated: “the good cow,” then the suffix and the quality and the possessor of the quality and the connection are distinguishers.🔽When the word “with a stick” expresses mere class, “with a stick” is a class, then the suffix and the stick are distinguishers.

original: Yadā dabbavantaṃ dabbaṃ vadati daṇḍī purisoti, tadā suti ca dabbañca jāti ca sambandho ca visesanaṃ.🔽Pācakasaddo yadā jātimattaṃ vadati pācako jātīti, tadā suti ca kriyā ca visesanaṃ.
analyzed: yadā dabbavantam dabbam vadati daṇḍī purisaḥ iti tadā ca dabbam ca ca sambandho ca visesanam  pācaka saddaḥ yadā jātimattam vadati pācakaḥ jāti iti tadā suti ca kriyā ca visesanam
translated: When it expresses a possessor of a stick, “the man with a stick,” then the suffix and the stick and the class and the connection are distinguishers.🔽When the word “cook” expresses mere class, “cook” is a class, then the suffix and the action are distinguishers.

original: Yadā kriyānipphādakaṃ dabbaṃ vadati pācako purisoti, tadā suti ca kriyā ca jāti ca
analyzed: yadā kriyā nipphādakam dabbam vadati pācakaḥ purisaḥ ti tadā suti ca kriyā ca jāti ca
translated: When it expresses a possessor of an action, “the cook,” then the suffix and the action and the class and the

original: kriyākārakasambandho ca visesanaṃ.
analyzed: kriyā kāraka sambandhaḥ ca visesanam
translated: connection between action and instrument are distinguishers.

original: Tissasaddo yadā nāmamattaṃ vadati tisso nāmanti, tadā suti visesanaṃ. Yadā nāmavantaṃ dabbaṃ vadati, tisso bhikkhūti, tadā suti ca nāmajāti ca sambandho ca visesanaṃ.
analyzed: tissa saddaḥ yadā nāma mattam vadati tissaḥ nāma nti tadā suti visesanam yadā nāmavantam dabbam vadati tissaḥ bhikkhū ti tadā suti ca nāma jāti ca sambandhaḥ ca visesanam
translated: When the sound “Tissa” is uttered, it is a mere sound, and then the hearing is the distinction. When it is uttered as “Dabba the Mallian, Tissa the bhikkhu,” then the hearing and the name and the class and the relationship are the distinction.

original: Sabbattha yaṃ yaṃ vadatīti vuttaṃ, taṃ taṃ visesyanti ca dabbanti ca veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: sabbattha yam yam vadati iti vuttam tam tam visesyanti ca dabbanti ca veditabbam
translated: And in all these cases it should be understood that it is the name and the class that are distinguished.

original: Ettha ca suti nāma saddasabhāvā eva hoti, saddapakkhikā eva. Sabbo saddo paṭhamaṃ
analyzed: ettha ca suti nāma sadda sabhāvā eva hoti sadda pakkhikā eva sabbo saddo paṭhamam
translated: And here the hearing is only the sound’s individual essence, only the sound’s aspect. All sound is first

original: sattābhidhāyakoti ca ñāse vuttaṃ. Tasmā sabbattha sutiṭṭhāne sattā eva yuttā vattunti.
analyzed: satta abhidhāyakaḥ iti ca ñāse vuttam tasmā sabbattha sutiṭṭhāne sattāḥ eva yuttāḥ vattunti
translated: uttered as a name for a being, it is said. Therefore in all cases where there is hearing, only beings are appropriate.

original: Sattāti ca tassa tassa atthassa vohāramattenapi loke vijjamānatā vuccati, taṃ taṃ🔽saddaṃ suṇantassa ca ñāṇaṃ taṃtadatthassa atthitāmattaṃ sabbapaṭhamaṃ jānāti, tato
analyzed: sattā ati ca tassa tassa atthassa vohāra mattena api loke vijjamāna tā vuccati tam tam  saddam suṇantassa ca ñāṇam taṃ tad atthassa atthi tā mattam sabba paṭhamam jānāti tatas
translated: And “being” is said to be the mere usage in the world for this or that meaning. When one hears this or that sound,🔽the knowledge that first knows is only the mere existence of the meaning of that or that. After that,

original: paraṃ jātisadde jātiṃ jānāti. Guṇasadde guṇanti evamādi sabbaṃ vattabbaṃ. Liṅga,
analyzed: param jāti sadde jātim jānāti guṇa sadde guṇanti evamādi sabbam vattabbam liṅga
translated: in the case of a sound that is a class, one knows the class; in the case of a sound that is a quality, one knows the quality. And so on in all cases. Gender,

original: saṅkhyā, parimāṇānipi visesanatthe saṅgayhanti.
analyzed: saṅkhyā parimāṇāni pi visesana tthe saṅgayhanti
translated: Number and measure are also included in the sense of distinction.

original: Tattha liṅgaṃ nāma ye itthi, purisānaṃ liṅga, nimitta, kuttā’kappā nāma abhidhamme🔽vuttā, ye ca napuṃsakānaṃ liṅga, nimitta, kuttā’kappā nāma avuttasiddhā, ye ca saddesu
analyzed: tattha liṅgam nāma ye itthi purisānam liṅga nimitta kuttākappāḥ nāma abhidhamme  vuttāḥ ye ca napuṃsakānam avutta siddhāḥ ye ca saddesu
translated: Herein, sex is the sign, mark, or indication of a woman or man. The neuter is not mentioned in the Abhidhamma,🔽but the sign, mark, or indication of a neuter is established by implication. And the clear and unclear forms of words and meanings

original: ceva atthesu ca visadā’visadākāra, majjhimākārā sandissanti, sabbametaṃ liṅgaṃ nāma.
analyzed: ca iva atthesu ca sandissanti sabbam etam liṅgam nāma
translated: that appear as middling are all called sex.

original: Evaṃ visesana, visesyavasena duvidho attho pubbe vuttassa saddaliṅgassa attho nāma, so saliṅgo, sasaṅkhyo, saparimāṇo cāti tividho hoti.
analyzed: evam visesana visesya vasena duvidhaḥ atthaḥ pubbe vuttassa sadda liṅgassa attho nāma saḥ sa liṅgaḥ sa saṅkhyaḥ sa parimāṇaḥ ca ati tividhaḥ hoti
translated: So the meaning of the word and the sign stated above is twofold as distinction and distinguished. It is threefold as having a sign, having number, and having measure.

original: Tattha saliṅgo yathā? Saññā, phasso, cittaṃ. Kaññā, puriso, kulaṃ. Mālā, rukkho, dhananti.
analyzed: tattha sa liṅgaḥ yathā saññā phassaḥ cittam kaññā puriso kulam mālā rukkhaḥ dhananti
translated: Herein, having a sign is like saññā , phassa , citta , kaññā , purisa , kula , mālā , rukkha , dhana .

original: Sasaṅkhyo yathā? Eko, dve, tayo, bahū iccādi.
analyzed: sa saṅkhyaḥ yathā ekaḥ dve tayaḥ bahū it ca ādi
translated: Having number is like eko , dve , tayo , bahū .

original: Saparimāṇo yathā? Vidatthi, hattho, doṇo, āḷhakaṃ iccādi.
analyzed: sa parimāṇaḥ yathā vidatthi hatthaḥ doṇaḥ āḷhakam iccādi
translated: Having measure is like vidatthi , hattha , doṇa , āḷhakaṃ .

original: Api ca suddho, saṃsaṭṭhoti duvidho liṅgattho. Tattha kammādisaṃsaggarahito suddho🔽nāma. So saliṅgo, sasaṅkhyo, saparimāṇo, upasaggattho, nipātattho, pāṭi-padikatthoti
analyzed: api ca suddhaḥ saṃsaṭṭhaḥ ti duvidhaḥ liṅgatthaḥ tattha kamma ādi saṃsagga rahitaḥ suddhaḥ  nāma saḥ sa liṅgaḥ sa saṅkhyaḥ sa parimāṇaḥ upasagga atthaḥ nipāta atthaḥ pāṭipadika atthaḥ ti
translated: Moreover, the meaning of a noun is twofold: pure and mixed. Herein, one free from the contact of action, etc., is called pure.🔽That is of six kinds as having a case-ending, having a verbal-ending, having a measure-word, having a preposition, having a postposition, having a particle.

original: chabbidho. Atthi, sakkā, labbhāiccādi idha pāṭipadikaṃ nāma. Tuna, tvāna, tvā, tave,🔽tuṃ, khattuṃpaccayantāpi nipātesu gayhanti.
analyzed: chabbidhaḥ atthi pāṭipadikam nāma tave  tum khattum pacca yantā api nipātesu gayhanti
translated: Herein, there is, it is possible, there are, there is not, there are not, etc., are called postpositions.🔽The case-endings, verbal-endings, measure-words, prepositions, and postpositions are used in the case-inflected words, verbal-inflected words, measure-word-inflected words, preposition-inflected words, and postposition-inflected words.

original: Saṃsaṭṭho vuttasaṃsaṭṭho, avuttasaṃsaṭṭhoti duvidho. Tattha vuttasaṃsaṭṭho catubbidho
analyzed: saṃsaṭṭhaḥ vutta saṃsaṭṭhaḥ avutta saṃsaṭṭhaḥ ti duvidhaḥ tattha vutta saṃsaṭṭho catubbidho
translated: Mixed is twofold: mixed by statement and mixed by implication. Herein, mixed by statement is fourfold:

original: samāsena vuttasaṃsaṭṭho, taddhitena, ākhyātena, kitenāti. Tattha samāsena vutto chakārakasambandhavasena🔽sattavidho, bhāvena saddhiṃ aṭṭhavidho vā, tathā taddhitena vutto. Ākhyātena vutto
analyzed: samāsena vutta saṃsaṭṭhaḥ taddhitena ākhyātena kitena ati tattha samāsena vutto chakāraka sambandha vasena  sattavidhaḥ bhāvena saddhim aṭṭhavidhaḥ vā tathā taddhitena vuttaḥ ākhyātena vuttaḥ
translated: mixed by compound, by derivative, by description, by kit. Herein, that mixed by compound is sevenfold by the relation of the four cases beginning with the nominative,🔽or it is eightfold with the addition of the state. That mixed by derivative is similar. That mixed by description is threefold🔽by the relation of the doer, the object, and the state. That mixed by kit is sevenfold by the relation of the four cases beginning with the nominative,

original: kattu, kamma, bhāvavasena tividho. Kitena vutto chakāraka, bhāvavasena sattavidho.
analyzed: kattu kamma bhāvavasena tividhaḥ kitena vuttaḥ chakāraka bhāvavasena sattavidhaḥ
translated: or it is eightfold with the addition of the state.

original: Sabbo suddho ceva vuttasaṃsaṭṭho ca paṭhamāya visayo.
analyzed: sabbaḥ suddhaḥ ca iva vutta saṃsaṭṭho ca paṭhamāya visayo
translated: All is pure and connected with what is stated in the first case.

original: Avuttasaṃsaṭṭhopi kattusaṃsaṭṭho, kammasaṃsaṭṭhotiādinā anekavidho. So dutiyādīnaṃ
analyzed: avutta saṃsaṭṭhaḥ api kattu saṃsaṭṭhaḥ kamma saṃsaṭṭhaḥ ti ādinā anekavidhaḥ saḥ dutiya ādīnam
translated: Even though not connected with what is stated, it is connected with the doing, connected with the action, and so on, in many ways. That is the domain of the second and the rest.

original: eva visayoti. Ettha ca vibhattiyā vinā kevalo saddo payogaṃ nārahatīti katvā payogārahatthameva
analyzed: eva visayaḥ ti ettha ca vibhattiyā vinā kevalaḥ saddo payogam nā ārahati iti katvā payoga āraha ttham eva
translated: And here, since a word by itself without a case-ending cannot be used,

original: chabbidhe suddhe catubbidhe ca vuttasaṃsaṭṭhe paṭhamā payujjati, na atthajotanatthaṃ.
analyzed: chabbidhe suddhe catubbidhe ca vutta saṃsaṭṭhe paṭhamā payujjati na attha jotana attham
translated: the first case is used only for the sake of the use of the word, not for the sake of illuminating the meaning, in the six kinds of pure and the four kinds of connected with what is stated.

original: Kenaci vācakena avuttāni pana kammādīni vibhattīhi vinā viditāni na hontītikatvā🔽atthajotanatthampi kammādīsu dutiyādayo payujjanti. Tasmā atthamatteti idha desantarāvacchedake
analyzed: kenacid vācakena avuttāni pana kamma ādīni vibhattīhi vinā viditāni na honti iti katvā  kamma ādīsu dutiya ādayo payujjanti tasmai
translated: But since actions and so on that are not stated by any word are not known without case-endings,🔽the second and the rest are used in the case of actions and so on even for the sake of illuminating the meaning. So in the expression “in the mere meaning” here,

original: visayamatte bhummaṃ. Kamme dutiyāiccādīsu pana nipphādetabbe payojane bhummanti evaṃ
analyzed: visaya matte bhummam kamme pana nipphādetabbe payojane bhumman ti evam
translated: the locative is used in the mere domain that is the delimitation of a different place. But in the expressions “in the doing the second” and so on,🔽the locative is used in the instigation that is to be brought about. This is how

original: dvinnaṃ bhummānaṃ nānattaṃ veditabbanti.
analyzed: dvinnam bhummānam nānattam veditabbanti
translated: the difference between the two locatives should be understood.

original: 290. Āmantane ka. 285; rū. 70; nī. 578; caṃ. 2.1.94; pā. 2.3.47; āmantaṇe (bahūsu).🔽Pageva siddhassa vatthuno nāmena vā nipātena vā attano abhimukhīkaraṇaṃ āmantanaṃ
analyzed: āmantane ka rū nī caṃ pā  āmantaṇe bahūsu  pagā iva siddhassa vatthunaḥ nāmena vā nipātena vā attanaḥ abhimukhīkaraṇaṃ āmantanam
translated: 290. In addressing, in the case of a single person, the first is used in the case of a single person, the second in the case of many.

original: nāma. Adhikāmantane atthamatte paṭhamā hoti. Ettha ca āmantanapadaṃ nāma kriyāpekkhaṃ🔽na hoti, tasmā kārakasaññaṃ na labhati.
analyzed: nāma adhika āmantane attha matte paṭhamā hoti ettha ca āmantana padam nāma kriyā apekkham  na hoti tasmā kāraka saññam na labhati
translated: But the act of bringing a person who is already established to one’s presence by name or by a noun of address is addressing.

original: Taṃ pana duvidhaṃ sādarā’nādaravasena. Ehi samma, ehi jeti.
analyzed: tam pana duvidham sādara anādara vasena ehi ehi jeti
translated: It is of two kinds as respectful and disrespectful.🔽It is of two kinds as with life and without life.

original: Tathā sajīva, nijjīvavasena, bho purisa, vadehi bho saṅkha, vadehi bho saṅkha dī. ni. 2.426. Ummujja bho puthusile, ummujja bho puthusileti saṃ. ni. 4.358.🔽Tathā paccakkhā’paccakkhavasena, bho purisa, kahaṃ ekaputtaka, kahaṃ ekaputtakāti saṃ. ni. 2.63; dha. pa. aṭṭha. 1.2.
analyzed: tathā sa jīva nijjīva vasena bho purisa vadehi bho saṅkha vadehi bho saṅkha ni  ummujja bho puthusile ummujja bho puthusila iti sam ni  tathā paccakkha apaccakkha vasena bho purisa kaham eka puttaka kaham eka puttaka ati sam ni dha pa aṭṭha
translated: It is of two kinds as with a question and without a question.🔽It is of two kinds as with a command and without a command.🔽It is of two kinds as with a request and without a request.

original: Tathā niyamā’niyamavasena, bho purisa, acchariyaṃ vata bho abbhutaṃ vata bho dī.
analyzed: tathā niyama aniyama vasena bho purisa acchariyam vata bho abbhutam vata bho dī
translated: It is of two kinds as with a prohibition and without a prohibition.

original: ni. 2.192. Yatra hi nāma saññī samānotiādi dī. ni. 2.192. Idaṃ āmantanaṃ nāma pageva🔽siddhe eva hoti, na vidhātabbe, na hi pageva rājabhāvaṃ vā bhikkhubhāvaṃ vā appattaṃ
analyzed: yatra hi nāma saññī samānotiādi ni idam āmantanam nāma pagā iva  siddhe eva hoti na vidhātabbe na hi pagā iva rāja bhāvam vā bhikkhu bhāvam vā appattam
translated: This is called an address.

original: janaṃ “bho rājā”ti vā “bho bhikkhū”ti vā āmantentīti.
analyzed: janam bho rājā iti vā bho bhikkhū iti vā āmantenti iti
translated: It is only when something is already established that an address is used, not when it is to be established. For people do not address someone who has not already become a king or a bhikkhu as “Your Majesty” or “Sir.”

original: Paṭhamāvibhattirāsi niṭṭhito.
analyzed: paṭhamā vibhattiḥ āsi niṭṭhitaḥ
translated: The first-declension class is finished.

original: Dutiyāvibhattirāsi
analyzed: dutiyā vibhattiḥ ā asi
translated: The second-declension class

original: Kasmiṃ atthe dutiyā?
analyzed: kasmin atthe dutiyā
translated: In what sense is the second case?

analyzed: kamme dutiyā ka rū nī cam pā
translated: In the sense of action, the second case is used: rū, nī, caṃ, pā.

original: Kammatthe dutiyā hoti. Kariyateti kammaṃ, taṃ nibbattikammaṃ, vikatikammaṃ, pattikammanti tividhaṃ hoti.🔽Tattha nibbattikammaṃ yathā? Iddhimā hatthivaṇṇaṃ māpeti, rājā nagaraṃ māpeti, mātā🔽puttaṃ vijāyati, bījaṃ rukkhaṃ janeti, kammaṃ vipākaṃ janeti, āhāro balaṃ janeti,
analyzed: kamma atthe dutiyā hoti kariyate iti kammam tat nibbatti kammam vikati kammam patti kamman ti tividham hoti  tattha nibbatti kammam yathā iddhimā hatthi vaṇṇam māpeti rājā nagaram māpeti mātā  puttam vijāyati bījam rukkham janeti kammam vipākam janeti āhāraḥ balam janeti
translated: The second case is used in the sense of action. Action is what is done. It is of three kinds: action of production, action of change, and action of causing.

original: jano puññaṃ karoti, pāpaṃ karoti, buddho dhammaṃ desesi, vinayaṃ paññapesi, bhikkhu
analyzed: janaḥ puññam karoti pāpam karoti buddhaḥ dhammam desesi vinayam paññapesi bhikkhu
translated: Herein, what is action of production? It is as follows: One possessing supernormal power creates a visible form; a king founds a town; a mother gives birth to a son; a seed produces a tree; kamma produces ripening; nutriment produces bodily strength; people do merit; people do evil; the Buddha taught the Dhamma; he laid down the training rules; a bhikkhu

original: jhānaṃ uppādeti, maggaṃ uppādeti iccādi.🔽Vikatikammaṃ yathā? Gehaṃ karoti, rathaṃ karoti, ghaṭaṃ karoti, paṭaṃ vāyati, odanaṃ🔽pacati, bhattaṃ pacati, kaṭṭhaṃ aṅgāraṃ karoti, suvaṇṇaṃ kaṭakaṃ karoti, gehaṃ jhāpeti,
analyzed: jhānam uppādeti maggam uppādeti iccādi  vikati kammam yathā geham karoti ratham karoti ghaṭam karoti paṭam vāyati odanam  pacati bhattam pacati kaṭṭham aṅgāram karoti suvaṇṇam kaṭakam karoti geham jhāpeti
translated: he arouses jhāna, he arouses the path, and so on.

original: rukkhaṃ chindati, pākāraṃ bhindati, vihayo lunāti, pāṇaṃ hanati, bhattaṃ bhuñjati iccādi.
analyzed: rukkham chindati pākāram bhindati vihayaḥ lunāti pāṇam hanati bhattam bhuñjati iccādi
translated: What is the kind of action classed as making? He makes a house, he makes a chariot, he makes a pot, he weaves a cloth, he cooks rice, he cooks porridge, he makes charcoal of wood, he makes a bracelet of gold, he burns a house, he cuts down a tree, he breaks through a wall, he ploughs a field, he kills a living being, he eats rice, and so on.

original: Pattikammaṃ yathā? Gāmaṃ gacchati, gehaṃ pavisati, rukkhaṃ ārohati, nadiṃ tarati, ādiccaṃ passati, dhammaṃ suṇāti, buddhaṃ vandati payirupāsati iccādi.
analyzed: patti kammam yathā gāmam gacchati geham pavisati rukkham ārohati nadim tarati ādiccam passati dhammam suṇāti buddham vandati payirupāsati iccādi
translated: What is the kind of action classed as going? He goes to the village, he enters the house, he climbs the tree, he crosses the river, he sees the sun, he hears the Dhamma, he pays homage to the Buddha, and so on.

original: Pakatikammaṃ, vikatikammanti duvidhaṃ. Suvaṇṇaṃ kaṭakaṃ karoti, kaṭṭhaṃ aṅgāraṃ karoti,
analyzed: pakati kammam vikati kammanti duvidham suvaṇṇam kaṭakam karoti kaṭṭham aṅgāram karoti
translated: It is twofold as natural action and as action by designation. He makes a bracelet of gold, he makes charcoal of wood,

original: purisaṃ ṭhitaṃ passati, purisaṃ gacchantaṃ passati, bhikkhuṃ passati sataṃ, sampajānaṃ,
analyzed: purisam ṭhitam passati purisam gacchantam passati bhikkhum passati satam sampajānaṃ
translated: he sees a standing man, he sees a walking man, he sees a monk, mindful, clearly comprehending,

original: abhikkamantaṃ, paṭikkamantaṃ, ālokentaṃ, vilokentaṃ, samiñjentaṃ, pasārentaṃ.
analyzed: abhikkamantam paṭikkamantam ālokentam vilokentam samiñjentam pasārentam
translated: he is going out, he is coming in, he is looking straight on, he is looking away, he is bending, he is stretching.

original: Ettha ‘purisaṃ, bhikkhu’nti pakatikammaṃ, ‘ṭhitaṃ, sataṃ’iccādīni vikatikammāni.🔽Dhātukammaṃ, kāritakammanti duvidhaṃ. Gāmaṃ gacchati, purisaṃ gāmaṃ gameti.🔽Dhātukammañca dvikammikadhātūnaṃ duvidhaṃ padhānakammaṃ, appadhānakammanti. Ajapālo
analyzed: ettha purisam bhikkhunti pakati kammam ṭhitam vikati kammāni  dhātu kammam kārita kammanti duvidham gāmam gacchati purisam gāmam gameti  dhātu kammam ca dvikammika dhātūnam duvidham padhāna kammam appadhāna kammanti ajapālaḥ
translated: Herein, ‘a monk, bhikkhu’ is a natural action, ‘standing, sitting’ and so on are modified actions.🔽Action by means of a noun is of two kinds, namely, action by means of a noun in the instrumental case and action by means of a noun in the accusative case. He goes to the village, he sends a man to the village.

original: ajaṃ gāmaṃ neti, puriso bhāraṃ gāmaṃ vahati, harati, gāmaṃ sākhaṃ kaḍḍhati, gāviṃ🔽khīraṃ dohati, brāhmaṇaṃ kambalaṃ yācati, brāhmaṇaṃ bhattaṃ bhikkhati, gāviyo vajaṃ🔽avarundhati, bhagavantaṃ pañhaṃ pucchati, rukkhaṃ phalāni ocināti, sissaṃ dhammaṃ
analyzed: ajam gāmam neti purisaḥ bhāram gāmam vahati harati gāmam sākham kaḍḍhati gāvim  khīram dohati brāhmaṇam kambalam yācati brāhmaṇam bhattam bhikkhati gāviyaḥ vajam  avarundhati bhagavantam pañham pucchati rukkham phalāni ocināti sissam dhammaṃ
translated: Action by means of a noun in the instrumental case is of two kinds, namely, principal action and subordinate action. The goat goes to the village, the man carries a load to the village, he takes it, he carries a branch to the village, the cow

original: bravīti, bhagavā bhikkhū etadavoca udā. 23 (thokaṃ visadisaṃ), sissaṃ dhammaṃ anusāsati iccādi.
analyzed: bravīti bhagavā bhikkhū etat avoca udā thokam visadisam sissam dhammaṃ anusāsati iccādi
translated: milks, he asks the brahmin for a blanket, he begs the brahmin for food, the cows tie up the bull, he asks the Blessed One a question, he picks fruits from the tree, he teaches the Dhamma to the pupil, the Blessed One said this to the bhikkhus, Ud. (a little different), he instructs the pupil in the Dhamma and so on.

original: Ettha ca ‘ajaṃ, khīraṃ’ iccādi padhānakammaṃ nāma kattārā pariggahetuṃ iṭṭhatarattā. ‘Gāmaṃ, gāviṃ’iccādi appadhānakammaṃ nāma tathā aniṭṭhatarattā.
analyzed: ettha ca ajam khīram iccādi padhāna kammam nāma kattārā pariggahetum iṭṭhatara ttā gāmam gāviṃ iccādi appadhāna kammam nāma tathā aniṭṭhatara ttā
translated: And here the principal action is called ‘the making of the mat’ because it is more desired to be taken as the doer by the doers, and the non-principal action is called ‘the bringing of the village and the bringing of the cow’ because it is not so desired.

original: Tattha padhānakammaṃ kathinakammaṃ nāma, kammabhāve thirakammanti vuttaṃ hoti. Appadhānakammaṃ🔽akathinakammaṃ nāma, athirakammanti vuttaṃ hoti. Tañhi kadāci sampadānaṃ hoti, kadāci
analyzed: tattha padhāna kammam kathinakammam nāma kamma bhāve thira kamman ti vuttam hoti appadhāna kammam  akathinakammam nāma athira kammanti vuttam hoti tat hi kadāci sampadānam hoti kadāci
translated: Herein, the principal action is called ‘the making of the mat’ because it is the action that is firm in the action-process; the non-principal action

original: apādānaṃ, kadāci sāmi, kadāci okāso. Yathā – so maṃ dakāya neti, gāvito khīraṃ dohati,
analyzed: apādānam kadācid sāmi kadācid okāsaḥ yathā saḥ mam dakāya na iti khīram dohati
translated: is called ‘the non-making of the mat’ because it is not firm in the action-process. For that is sometimes a giving, sometimes a not-giving, sometimes a master, sometimes a place. As follows: ‘He leads me to the village’, ‘He milks the cow’,

original: gāviyā khīraṃ dohahi, gāviyaṃ khīraṃ dohati iccādi.
analyzed: gāviyā khīram dohahi gāviyam khīram dohati iccādi
translated: ‘Milk the cow’, ‘He milks the cow’ and so on.

original: Kamme dutiyāti vattate.
analyzed: kamme dutiyā iti vattate
translated: It is called ‘the second in the action’.🔽The meaning of the words ‘going’, ‘awakening’, ‘eating’, ‘sound’, ‘not-doing’,

original: 292. Gatibodhāhārasaddatthā kammaka bhajjādīnaṃ payojje ka. 300; rū. 286; nī. 587; caṃ. 2.1.44; pā. 1.4.52.
analyzed: gati bodha āhāra saddatthā kammaka bhajja ādīnam payojje ka rū nī cam pā
translated: ‘the use of the mat, etc.’, ‘the form’, ‘the leading’, ‘the cow’, ‘the milk’, ‘the milking’, ‘the milking of the cow’, ‘the milking of the milk’, ‘the milking of the cow’s milk’, and so on.

original: Niccavidhisuttamidaṃ. Gamanatthānaṃ bodhanatthānaṃ āhāratthānaṃ saddatthānaṃ akammakānaṃ
analyzed: nicca vidhi suttam idam gamana tthānam bodhana tthānam āhāra tthānam sadda tthānam akammakānam
translated: This is a rule of constant occurrence. ‘The going’, ‘the awakening’, ‘the eating’, ‘the sound’, ‘the not-doing’,

original: bhajjādīnañca dhātūnaṃ payojje kammani dutiyā hoti. Ettha ca payojjakammaṃ nāma kāritakammaṃ vuccati.
analyzed: bhajja ādīnam ca dhātūnam payojje kammani dutiyā hoti ettha ca payojja kammam nāma kārita kammam vuccati
translated: And in the case of the roots bhajjā, etc., the second is used in the sense of the instrument of the action. And here the instrument of the action is called the cause of the action.

original: Puriso purisaṃ gāmaṃ gamayati, sāmiko ajapālaṃ ajaṃ gāmaṃ nayāpeti, ācariyo sissaṃ🔽dhammaṃ bodheti, puriso purisaṃ bhattaṃ bhojeti, ācariyo sissaṃ dhammaṃ pāṭheti,
analyzed: purisaḥ purisam gāmam gamayati sāmikaḥ ajapālam ajam gāmam ācariyo sissam  dhammam bodheti puriso purisam bhattam bhojeti ācariyaḥ sissam dhammam pāṭheti
translated: A man causes a man to go to the village; a master causes a cowherd to take a goat to the village; a teacher causes a pupil🔽to understand a Dhamma; a man causes a man to eat food; a teacher causes a pupil to read a Dhamma;

original: puriso purisaṃ sayāpeti, acchāpeti, uṭṭhāpeti, puriso purisaṃ dhaññaṃ bhajjāpeti,
analyzed: purisaḥ purisam sayāpeti acchāpeti uṭṭhāpeti purisaḥ purisam dhaññam bhajjāpeti
translated: a man causes a man to lie down, to sit, to get up; a man causes a man to thresh grain,

original: koṭṭāpeti, uddharāpeti.
analyzed: koṭṭāpeti uddharāpeti
translated: to pound it, to winnow it.

original: Etesamīti kiṃ? Puriso purisena odanaṃ pāceti.
analyzed: etesamī iti kim purisaḥ purisena odanam pāca iti
translated: What about this? A man causes a man to cook rice.

original: Ettha ca gamanatthādīnaṃ payojje tatiyāpi rūpasiddhiyaṃ 141 piṭṭhe saddanītiyañca
analyzed: ettha ca gamana attha ādīnam payojje rūpasiddhiyam piṭṭhe saddanītiyam ca
translated: And here the second is used in the sense of the instrument of the action of going, etc., in the sense of the instrument of the action of cooking, etc., in the sense of the cause of the action of understanding, etc., in the sense of the cause of the action of eating, etc., in the sense of the cause of the action of lying down, etc., in the sense of the cause of the action of threshing, etc., in the sense of the cause of the action of cooking, etc.🔽The second is used in the sense of the instrument of the action of cooking in the expression “A man causes a man to cook rice.”🔽And here the second is used in the sense of the instrument of the action of going, etc., in the sense of the instrument of the action of cooking, etc., in the sense of the cause of the action of understanding, etc., in the sense of the cause of the action of eating, etc., in the sense of the cause of the action of lying down, etc., in the sense of the cause of the action of threshing, etc., in the sense of the cause of the action of cooking, etc.🔽The second is used in the sense of the instrument of the action of cooking in the expression “A man causes a man to cook rice.”

original: sutta-148 piṭṭhe vuttā. Saddanītiyaṃ tatiyāpayogepi kammatthameva icchati. Ñāsādīsu🔽katvatthaṃ icchanti.
analyzed: piṭṭhe vuttā saddanītiyam tatiya apayoge pi kammattham eva icchati ñāsa ādīsu 🔽katvattham icchanti
translated: And here the second is used in the sense of the instrument of the action of going, etc., in the sense of the instrument of the action of cooking, etc., in the sense of the cause of the action of understanding, etc., in the sense of the cause of the action of eating, etc., in the sense of the cause of the action of lying down, etc., in the sense of the cause of the action of threshing

original: Yadā pana paṭhamaṃ payojakaṃ añño dutiyo payojeti, tadā paṭhamo payojjo nāma. Tasmiṃ tatiyāevāti vuttiyaṃ vuttaṃ. Attanā vippakataṃ kuṭiṃ parehi pariyosāpeti pārā. 363.
analyzed: yadā pana paṭhamam payojakam aññaḥ dutiyaḥ payojeti tadā paṭhamaḥ payojjaḥ nāma tasmim tatiyā eva ati vuttiyam vuttam attanā vippakatam kuṭim parehi pariyosāpeti pārā
translated: But when one who is the instigator at first gets another to instigate, then the first one is called the instigator. In the text it is said: “in the third case, if he is himself the instigator.”🔽The instigator of the work of building a hut, etc., is the first.🔽The instigator of the work of carrying, etc., is the second.🔽The instigator of the work of eating, etc., is the third.

analyzed: hara ādīnam vā ka rū nī cam pā
translated: The instigator of the work of showing, etc., is the fourth.🔽The instigator of the work of worshipping, etc., is the fifth.

original: Harādīnaṃ payojje kammani vikappena dutiyā hoti.🔽Sāmiko purisaṃ bhāraṃ hāreti purisena vā, purisaṃ āhāraṃ ajjhohāreti purisena vā,
analyzed: hara ādīnam payojje kammani vikappena dutiyā hoti  sāmiko purisam bhāram hāreti purisena vā purisam āhāram ajjhohāreti purisena vā
translated: The instigator of the work of carrying, etc., is the second in the work of building, etc.🔽The instigator of the work of eating, etc., is the third in the work of carrying, etc.🔽The instigator of the work of showing, etc., is the fourth in the work of eating, etc.

original: purisaṃ kammaṃ kāreti purisena vā, rājā purisaṃ attānaṃ dasseti purisena vā, purisaṃ🔽buddhaṃ vandāpeti purisena vā.🔽194. Na khādādīnaṃ ka. 300; rū. 286; nī. 587; caṃ. 2.1.47; pā. 1.4.57.
analyzed: purisam kammam kāreti purisena vā rājā purisam attānam dasseti purisena vā purisam  buddham purisena vā  na kha ādi inam ka rū nī cam pā
translated: The instigator of the work of worshipping, etc., is the fifth in the work of showing, etc.🔽The instigator of the work of building, etc., is not the second in the work of carrying, etc.

original: Khādādīnaṃ payojje kammani na dutiyā hoti.🔽Sāmiko purisena khajjaṃ khādāpeti, ada-bhakkhane, bhattaṃ ādeti, sāmiko dāsena purisaṃ
analyzed: khāda ādīnam payojje kammani na dutiyā hoti 🔽sāmikaḥ purisena khajjam khādāpeti ada bhakkhane bhattam ādeti sāmikaḥ dāsena purisam
translated: The instigator of the work of carrying, etc., is not the third in the work of building, etc.🔽The instigator of the work of eating, etc., is not the fourth in the work of carrying, etc.🔽The instigator of the work of showing, etc., is not the fifth in the work of eating, etc.

original: avhāpeti, saddāyāpeti, kandayati, nādayati. Ettha ca ‘saddāyāpetī’ti saddaṃ kārāpeti,
analyzed: avhāpeti saddāya apeti kandayati nādayati ettha ca saddāya apeti iti saddam kārāpeti
translated: And here ‘he makes it carry a load’ means he makes it carry a load.

original: nāmadhātu cesā. Kanda, nadāpi saddatthāyeva.
analyzed: nāmadhātu ca isā kanda nada api
translated: This is the element of name. The carrying and the load are for the sake of the sound.

original: 295. Vahissāniyantuke ka. 300; rū. 286; nī. 587; caṃ. 2.1.48; pā. 1.4.52.
analyzed: vahissā niyantuke ka rū nī cam pā
translated: . In the section on ‘not-to-be-yoked’

original: Vahissāti dhātuniddeso i-kāro, niyāmeti payojetīti niyantā, natthi niyantā etassāti
analyzed: vahissa ati dhātu niddesaḥ ikāraḥ niyāmeti payojeti iti niyantā natthi niyantā etassa ati
translated: The letter i is the description of the element. It is a controller because it controls, it directs. That which has no controller is

original: aniyantuko. Yassa aññena payojakena kiccaṃ natthi, sayameva ñatvā vahati, so aniyantuko
analyzed: a niyantukaḥ yassa aññena payojakena kiccam natthi sayam eva ñatvā vahati saḥ a niyantukaḥ
translated: not-to-be-yoked. That which has no other director, but which carries by itself after knowing, is not-to-be-yoked.

original: nāma, vahadhātussa tādise aniyantuke payojje kammani dutiyā na hoti.
analyzed: nāma vaha dhātussa tādise a niyantuke payojje kammani dutiyā na hoti
translated: That is the name. In the action of directing the carrying element to such a not-to-be-yoked one, the second is not.

original: Sāmiko dāsena bhāraṃ vāheti.
analyzed: sāmikaḥ dāsena bhāram vāha iti
translated: The master carries a load with the slave.

original: Aniyantuketi kiṃ? Balībadde bhāraṃ vāheti.
analyzed: a niyantukā iti kim balībadde bhāram vāha iti
translated: What is not-to-be-yoked? He carries a load with oxen.

original: 296. Bhakkhissāhiṃsāyaṃ ka. 300; rū. 286; nī. 587; caṃ. 2.1.49; pā. 1.4.5.
analyzed: bhakkhissa ahiṃsā ayam ka rū nī cam pā
translated: . In the section on ‘to be eaten’

original: Bhakkhituṃ icchantassa bhakkhāpanaṃ hiṃsā nāma na hoti, anicchantassa bhakkhāpanaṃ hiṃsā nāma, bhakkhadhātussa payojje kammani ahiṃsāvisaye dutiyā na hoti.
analyzed: bhakkhitum icchantassa bhakkhāpanam hiṃsā nāma na hoti an icchantassa bhakkhāpanam hiṃsā nāma bhakkhadhātussa payojje kammani ahiṃsā visaye dutiyā na hoti
translated: For if one who wants to eat is made to eat, there is no killing, but if one who does not want to eat is made to eat, there is killing. And in the case of the element of food, the second is not found in the sphere of non-killing.

original: Sāmiko purisena modake bhakkhāpeti.
analyzed: sāmiko purisena modake bhakkhāpeti
translated: A husband makes a man eat a sweetmeat.

original: Ahiṃsāyanti kiṃ? Balībadde sassaṃ bhakkhāpeti. Ettha ‘sassa’nti thūlataraṃ sassanti vadanti.
analyzed: ahiṃsāyanti kim balībadde sassam bhakkhāpeti ettha sassanti thūlataram sassanti vadanti
translated: What is not killing? He makes a bull eat grass. Here they say that “grass” is grass that is thick.

original: Pāḷiyaṃ “sabbesaṃ viññāpetvāna apa. thera 1.1.438, tosenti sabbapāṇinaṃ apa. thera 1.1.300. Therassa patto dutiyassa gāhetabbo” iccādinā pārā. 615 payojje chaṭṭhīpi dissati.🔽297. Jhādīhi yuttā ka. 299; rū. 288; nī. 582, 586; caṃ. 2.1.50; pā. 2.3.2.
analyzed: pāḷiyam sabbesam viññāpetvāna apa thera tosenti sabba pāṇinam apa thera therassa pattaḥ dutiyassa gāhetabbaḥ iccādinā pārā payojje chaṭṭhī pi dissati  jha ādīhi yuttā ka rū nī  caṃ pā
translated: In the text “Having asked all, having satisfied all breathing things … having asked all, having satisfied all breathing things … the Elder’s bowl should be taken by the second” , etc., the sixth case is also found.🔽With jhādi, etc., the second is found with a noun.

original: Dhīiccādīhi nipātopasaggehi yuttā liṅgamhā dutiyā hoti.🔽Dhī brāhmaṇassa hantāraṃ dha. pa. 389, dhīratthu’maṃ pūtikāyaṃ jā. 1.3.129, dhīratthu
analyzed: dhī icca ādīhi nipāta upasaggehi yuttā dutiyā hoti 🔽brāhmaṇassa hantāram dha pa dhīratthumam pūti kāyam
translated: With the indeclinable prefix dhī, etc., the second is found with a noun.

original: taṃ dhanalābhaṃ jā. 1.4.36, dhīratthu bahuke kāme. Tatiyāpi dissati, dhīratthu jīvitena🔽me jā. 2.17.135. Antarā ca rājagahaṃ antarā ca nāḷandaṃ dī. ni. 1.1, abhito gāmaṃ🔽vasati, paritogāmaṃ vasati, nadiṃ nerañjaraṃ pati su. ni. 427, etesu chaṭṭhyatthe dutiyā.🔽Tathā paṭibhāti maṃ bhagavā udā. 45; saṃ. ni. 1.217, apissu maṃ tisso upamāyo paṭibhaṃsu
analyzed: tam dhana lābham jā dhīratthu bahuke kāme tatiyā api dissati dhīratthu jīvitena  me jā antarā ca rājagaham antarā ca nāḷandam abhitas gāmam  vasati paritogāmam vasati nadim nerañjaram pati su ni etesu chaṭṭhī atthe dutiyā  tathā paṭibhāti mam bhagavā udā sam ni mam tissaḥ upamāyaḥ

Paṭibhantu taṃ🔽cunda bojjhaṅgā saṃ. ni. 3.79 – ‘ma’nti mama, ‘ta’nti tava, sampadānatthe dutiyā.🔽‘Ma’nti mamañāṇe, ‘ta’nti tavañāṇetipi vaṇṇesuṃ. Na upāyamantarena atthassa siddhi,🔽natthi samādānamantarena sikkhāpaṭilābho, nevidha na huraṃ na ubhayamantarena, esevanto

original: dukkhassa ma. ni. 3.393; udā. 74. Tattha ‘antarenā’ti nipātapadametaṃ, vajjetvātyattho.
analyzed: dukkhassa ma ni udā  tattha antarena ati nipāta padam etam
translated: Herein, ‘in between’ is a particle meaning ‘having omitted’.

original: Pubbena gāmaṃ, dakkhiṇena gāmaṃ, uttarena gāmaṃ, gāmassa pubbeti attho.🔽Upasaggapubbānaṃ akammakadhātūnaṃ payoge ādhāre dutiyā, pathaviṃ adhisessati, gāmaṃ
analyzed: pubbena gāmam dakkhiṇena gāmam uttarena gāmam gāmassa pubba iti atthaḥ  upasagga pubbānam akammaka dhātūnam payoge ādhāre dutiyā pathavim adhisessati gāmam
translated: ‘To the east of the village, to the south of the village, to the north of the village, to the east of the village’ means ‘having omitted the village’.

original: adhitiṭṭhati, rukkhaṃ ajjhāvasati, mañcaṃ vā pīṭhaṃ vā abhinisīdeyya vā abhinipajjeyya
analyzed: adhitiṭṭhati rukkham ajjhāvasati mañcam vā pīṭham vā abhinisīdeyya vā abhinipajjeyya
translated: In the case of verbs with prepositions and with indeclinable verbs, the locative case is used for the basis, ‘He will settle on the earth, he will stand on the village, he will dwell in the tree, he will sit down on or lie down on a bed or chair,

original: vā pāci. 130, gāmaṃ upavasati, gāmaṃ anuvasati, pabbataṃ adhivasati, gharaṃ āvasati,
analyzed: vā pāci gāmam upavasati gāmam anuvasati pabbatam adhivasati gharam āvasati
translated: he will cook, he will live near the village, he will live along the village, he will live on the mountain, he will live in the house,

original: agāraṃ ajjhāvasati dī. ni. 1.258; pārā. 519, uposathaṃ upavasati, kāmāvacaraṃ upapajjati,
analyzed: agāram ajjhāvasati uposatham upavasati kāmāvacaram upapajjati
translated: he will live in the house’ Dīpanīya; he will go to the other side, he will observe the Uposatha, he will be reborn in the sense sphere,

original: rūpāvacaraṃ upapajjati, arūpāvacaraṃ upapajjati, sakkassa sahabyataṃ upapajjati,
analyzed: rūpāvacaram upapajjati arūpāvacaram upapajjati sakkassa sahabyatam upapajjati
translated: he will be reborn in the fine-material sphere, he will be reborn in the immaterial sphere, he will be reborn in the companionship of Sakka,

original: nipannaṃ vā upanipajjeyya dī. ni. 3.282, nisinnaṃ vā upanisīdeyya dī. ni. 3.282,
analyzed: nipannam vā upanipajjeyya ni  nisinnam vā upanisīdeyya
translated: he will sit down near one who is lying down, he will sit down near one who is sitting down,

original: ṭhitaṃ vā upatiṭṭheyya dī. ni. 3.282 iccādi.
analyzed: ṭhitam vai upatiṭṭheyya dī ni it cādi
translated: he will stand near one who is standing’ Dīpanīya.

original: Tappāna, cārepi dutiyā, nadiṃ pivati, samuddaṃ pivati, gāmaṃ carati, araññaṃ carati, nadiyaṃ, gāmeti attho.
analyzed: tappāna cāre pi dutiyā nadim pivati samuddam pivati gāmam carati araññam carati nadiyam gāma iti atthaḥ
translated: Tappāna, cārepi dutiyā, nadiṃ pivati, samuddaṃ pivati, gāmaṃ carati, araññaṃ carati, nadiyaṃ, gāmeti attho.

original: Kāla, disāsupi ādhāre eva dutiyā, taṃ khaṇaṃ, taṃ muhuttaṃ, taṃ kālaṃ, ekamantaṃ
analyzed: ādhāre eva dutiyā tam khaṇam tam muhuttam tam kālam ekamantam
translated: Kāla, disāsupi ādhāre eva dutiyā, taṃ khaṇaṃ, taṃ muhuttaṃ, taṃ kālaṃ, ekamantaṃ

original: khu. pā. 5.1, ekaṃ samayaṃ khu. pā. 5.1; dī. ni. 1.1, pubbaṇhasamayaṃ pārā. 16, sāyanhasamayaṃ,
analyzed: ekam samayam khu pā dī ni pubbaṇha samayam pārā sāyanha samayam
translated: khu. pā. ., ekaṃ samayaṃ khu. pā. .; dī. ni. ., pubbaṇhasamayaṃ pārā. , sāyanhasamayaṃ,

original: taṃ divasaṃ, imaṃ rattiṃ dī. ni. 3.285, dutiyampi, tatiyampi, catutthaṃ vā pañcamaṃ
analyzed: tam divasam imam rattim dī ni dutiyam pi tatiyam pi catuttham vā pañcamam
translated: taṃ divasaṃ, imaṃ rattiṃ dī. ni. ., dutiyampi, tatiyampi, catutthaṃ vā pañcamaṃ

original: vā appeti, tato pubbaṃ, tato paraṃ, purimaṃ disaṃ dī. ni. 2.336, dakkhiṇaṃ disaṃ
analyzed: vā appeti tatas pubbam tatas param purimam disam dī ni dakkhiṇam disam
translated: vā appeti, tato pubbaṃ, tato paraṃ, purimaṃ disaṃ dī. ni. ., dakkhiṇaṃ disaṃ

original: dī. ni. 2.336, pacchimaṃ disaṃ dī. ni. 2.336, uttaraṃ disaṃ dī. ni. 2.336, imā dasa
analyzed: pacchimam disam dī ni uttaram disam dī ni imāḥ dasa
translated: dī. ni. ., pacchimaṃ disaṃ dī. ni. ., uttaraṃ disaṃ dī. ni. ., imā dasa

original: disāyo, katamaṃ disaṃ tiṭṭhati nāgarājā jā. 1.16.104, imāsu disāsu katamāya disāya
analyzed: katamam disam tiṭṭhati nāga rājā imāsu disāsu katamāya disāya
translated: disāyo, katamaṃ disaṃ tiṭṭhati nāgarājā jā. .., imāsu disāsu katamāya disāya

original: tiṭṭhati chaddantanāgarājāti atthoiccādi.
analyzed: tiṭṭhati chaddanta nāga rājāti attho icca ādi
translated: tiṭṭhati chaddantanāgarājāti atthoiccādi.

original: 298. Lakkhaṇitthambhūtavicchāsvabhinā ka. 299; rū. 288; nī. 582, 586; caṃ. 2.1.54; pā. 1.4.90, 91; 2.3.8.
analyzed: lakkhaṇa itthambhūta vicchāsu abhinā ka rū nī  caṃ pā
translated: In the sense of characteristic, etc., the feminine is formed by adding the suffix -ī to the stem, and in the sense of desire it is formed by adding -ā to the stem.

original: Lakkhaṇādīsu atthesu pavattena abhinā yuttā liṅgamhā dutiyā hoti.
analyzed: lakkhaṇa ādīsu atthesu pavattena abhinā yuttā liṅgamhā dutiyā hoti
translated: The feminine is formed by adding -ī to the stem in the sense of characteristic, etc., and by adding -ā to the stem in the sense of desire.

original: Lakkhīyati lakkhitabbaṃ anenāti lakkhaṇaṃ. Ayaṃ pakāro itthaṃ, īdiso visesoti attho. Itthaṃ bhūto pattoti itthambhūto. Bhinne atthe byāpituṃ icchā vicchā.
analyzed: lakkhīyati lakkhitabbam anena ati lakkhaṇam ayam pakāraḥ ittham īdisaḥ visesaḥ ti atthaḥ ittham bhūtaḥ patto ti itthambhūtaḥ bhinne atthe byāpitum icchā vicchā
translated: In the sense of characteristic, etc.: it is characterized by this, thus it is a characteristic . This is the manner, thus it is such . It is of this kind, thus it is of this sort . It has become such, thus it is suchlike . In the sense of desire: desire to pervade a particular object is called desire for that object.

original: Tattha lakkhaṇe –
analyzed: tattha lakkhaṇe
translated: Herein, in the sense of characteristic:

original: Rukkhamabhi vijjotate vijju, rukkhaṃ abhi byāpetvā vijjotateti attho, vijjobhāsena byāpito rukkho vijjuppādassa lakkhaṇaṃ saññāṇaṃ hoti.
analyzed: rukkham abhi vijjotate vijju rukkham abhi byāpetvā vijjotata iti atthaḥ vijjobhāsena byāpitaḥ rukkhaḥ vijjuppādassa lakkhaṇam saññāṇam hoti
translated: The lightning flashes at the tree, the meaning is that it flashes having pervaded the tree. The tree pervaded by the lightning’s radiance is the characteristic, the sign, of the lightning’s appearance.

original: Itthambhūte –
analyzed: ittham bhūte
translated: In the sense of suchlike:🔽Devadatta is good at his mother, the meaning is that he is good having excelled his mother. Devadatta

original: Sādhu devadatto mātaramabhi, mātaraṃ abhi visiṭṭhaṃ katvā sādhūti attho, devadatto🔽sakkaccaṃ mātupaṭṭhāne aggapurisoti vuttaṃ hoti. Taṃ kho pana bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ evaṃ
analyzed: sādhu devadattaḥ mātaram abhi mātaram abhi visiṭṭham katvā sādhu iti devadatto 🔽sakkaccam mātupaṭṭhāne agga purisaḥ ti vuttam hoti tam kho pana bhavantam gotamam evam
translated: is the foremost man in attendance on his mother. That Blessed One Gotama, however,

original: kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato pārā. 1. Ettha ca ‘abbhuggato’ti abhi visiṭṭhaṃ katvā
analyzed: kalyāṇaḥ kitti saddaḥ abbhuggataḥ pārā ettha ca abbhuggataḥ iti abhi visiṭṭham katvā
translated: And here ‘has spread far and wide’ means ‘has spread out after becoming distinguished’;

original: uggatoti attho, ayaṃ kittisaddo bhoto gotamassa sakalalokaggabhāvaṃ pakāsetvā uggatoti
analyzed: uggataḥ ti atthaḥ ayam kitti saddaḥ bhotaḥ gotamassa sakala lokagga bhāvam pakāsetvā uggataḥ ti
translated: the meaning is ‘has risen up’. What is meant is that this good report, after proclaiming Master Gotama’s state of being the world’s chief, has risen up.

original: vuttaṃ hoti, kittisaddasambandhe pana tassa kho pana bhoto gotamassāti attho.
analyzed: vuttam hoti kitti sadda sambandhe pana tassa kho pana bhotaḥ gotamassa ati attho
translated: But in the case of the expression ‘of Master Gotama’s good report’ the meaning is ‘of that good report of Master Gotama’.

original: Vicchāyaṃ –
analyzed: vicchāyam
translated: In the case of the stars:

original: Rukkhaṃ rukkhaṃ abhi vijjotate cando, byāpetvā vijjotatetyattho.
analyzed: rukkham rukkham abhi vijjotate candaḥ byāpetvā
translated: The moon shines, outshining the stars. The meaning is ‘after pervading, it shines’.🔽And here the meanings of the prefix abhi in ‘shines’ are only the particularized meaning and the collective meaning, not the verbal meaning. The meanings of the prefix vi in ‘shines’ are only the verbal meaning and the pervading meaning.

original: Ettha ca lakkhaṇādiatthā abhisaddena jotanīyā piṇḍatthā eva, na vacanīyatthā, byāpanādiatthā eva vacanīyatthāti.🔽299. Patiparīhi bhāge ca ka. 299; rū. 288; nī. 582, 586; caṃ. 2.1.55; pā. 1.4.90.🔽Lakkhaṇi’tthambhūta, vicchāsu ca bhāge ca pavattehi pati, parīhi yuttā liṅgamhā dutiyā hoti.
analyzed: ettha ca lakkhaṇa ādi atthā abhisaddena jotanīyā piṇḍa atthā eva na vacanīya tthā byāpana ādi atthā eva vacanīya tthā ati  pati parīhi bhāge ca ka rū nī  caṃ pā  vicchāsu ca bhāge ca pavattehi pati parīhi yuttā liṅgamhā dutiyā hoti
translated: In the case of the words patiparīhi, ka, rū, nī, caṃ, pā:

original: Lakkhaṇe –
analyzed: lakkhaṇe
translated: The feminine is formed with the second case in the sense of characteristic and in the sense of a part, and in the sense of a portion, and in the sense of a section, and in the sense of a side, and in the sense of a direction, and in the sense of a region, and in the sense of a place, and in the sense of a time, and in the sense of a portion of a whole, and in the sense of a portion of a part, and in the sense of a section of a part, and in the sense of a side of a part, and in the sense of a direction of a part, and in the sense of a region of a part, and in the sense of a place of a part, and in the sense of a time of a part, and in the sense of a portion of a portion, and in the sense of a portion of a section, and in the sense of a portion of a side, and in the sense of a portion of a direction, and in the sense of a portion of a region, and in the sense of a portion of a place, and in the sense of a portion of a time, and in the sense of a portion of a portion of a whole, and in the sense of a portion of a portion of a part, and in the sense of a portion of a section of a part, and in the sense of a portion of a side of a part, and in the sense of a portion of a

original: Rukkhaṃ pati vijjotate vijju, rukkhaṃ pari vijjotate vijju. Tattha ‘patī’ti paṭicca, ‘parī’ti pharitvā.
analyzed: rukkham pati vijjotate vijju rukkham pari vijjotate vijju tattha pati iti paṭicca pari iti pharitvā
translated: It flashes round the tree, it flashes round the tree. Herein, ‘round’ means in dependence, ‘round about’ means having spread out.

original: Itthambhūte –
analyzed: ittham bhūte
translated: When it is in this way,

original: Sādhu devadatto mātaraṃ pati, sādhu devadatto mātaraṃ pari.
analyzed: sādhu devadattaḥ mātaram sādhu devadattaḥ mātaram pari
translated: It is good if Devadatta gives to his mother round, it is good if Devadatta gives to his mother about.

original: Vicchāyaṃ –
analyzed: vicchāyam
translated: In the case of the constellation,

original: Rukkhaṃ rukkhaṃ pati vijjotate cando, rukkhaṃ rukkhaṃ pari vijjotate cando.
analyzed: rukkham rukkham pati vijjotate cando rukkham rukkham pari vijjotate cando
translated: The moon flashes round the tree, the moon flashes round the tree.

original: Bhāge –🔽Taṃ dīyatu, yadettha maṃ pati siyā, taṃ dīyatu, yadettha maṃ pari siyā. Tattha ‘patī’ti🔽paṭicca, ‘parī’ti paricca, uddissāti attho, ‘ṭhapita’nti pāṭhaseso. Ettha maṃ uddissa
analyzed: bhāge  tam dīyatu yat itthā mam pati siyā tam dīyatu yat itthā mam pari siyā tattha pati iti  paṭicca pari iti paricca uddissa ati atthaḥ ettha mama uddissa
translated: In the case of a share,

original: yaṃ vatthu ṭhapitaṃ siyā, taṃ me dīyatūtyattho, etesu bahūsu bhāgesu yo mama bhāgo,
analyzed: yam vatthu ṭhapitam siyā tam me dīyatu utyatthaḥ etesu bahūsu bhāgesu yaḥ mama bhāgaḥ
translated: Give that which is here to me round, give that which is here to me about. Herein, ‘round’ means in dependence, ‘about’ means having set aside, the meaning is ‘having dedicated.’ The reading is ‘ṭhapita.’ Herein, whatever property is set aside dedicated to me, give that to me is the meaning. In the case of these many shares, whatever share is mine,

original: so mayhaṃ dīyatūti vuttaṃ hotīti.🔽300. Anunā ka. 299; rū. 288; nī. 582, 586; caṃ. 2.1.56; pā. 1.4.84, 90.
analyzed: saḥ mayham dīyatu iti vuttam hoti iti  anunā ka rū nī  cam pā
translated: give that to me is what is said.🔽The feminine, the locative, the genitive, the instrumental, the dative, and the ablative.

original: Lakkhaṇi’tthambhūta, vicchāsu ca bhāge ca pavattena anunā yuttā liṅgamhā dutiyā hoti.
analyzed: vicchāsu ca bhāge ca pavattena anunā yuttā liṅgamhā dutiyā hoti
translated: The feminine, the locative, the genitive, and the ablative are the second case in combination with the affix -un.

original: Lakkhaṇe –
analyzed: lakkhaṇe
translated: In the characteristic:

original: Rukkhaṃ anu vijjotate vijju, rukkhaṃ anu pharitvāti attho. Caturāsītisahassāni, sambuddhamanupabbajuṃ
analyzed: rukkham anu vijjotate vijju rukkham anu pharitvā ati catur āsīti sahassāni sambuddham anupabbajum
translated: The lightning flashed round the tree, the meaning is that it spread round the tree. Eighty-four thousand,

original: bu. vaṃ. 21.5, ‘sambuddha’nti bodhisattaṃ, anu gantvā pabbajiṃsūti attho, vipassibodhisatte🔽pabbajite sati tānipi caturāsītikulaputtasahassāni pabbajiṃsūti vuttaṃ hoti. Saccakriyamanu🔽vuṭṭhi pāvassi, ‘anū’ti anvāya, paṭiccāti attho, saccakriyāya sati saccakriyahetu🔽devo pāvassīti vuttaṃ hoti. “Hetu ca lakkhaṇaṃ bhavatī”ti vuttiyaṃ vuttaṃ. Saccakriyāya
analyzed: sambuddhanti bodhisattam anu gantvā pabbajiṃsu iti atthaḥ vipassi bodhisatte  pabbajite sati tāni api caturāsīti kula putta sahassāni pabbajiṃsu iti vuttam hoti sacca kriyam anu  vuṭṭhi pāvassi anūti anvāya paṭicca ati sacca kriyāya sati sacca kriya hetu  devo pāvassi iti vuttam hoti hetu ca lakkhaṇam bhavati iti vuttiyam vuttam sacca kriyāya
translated: followed the Sambuddha, the meaning is that they went forth after the Bodhisatta ‘Sambuddha’, when the Bodhisatta Vipassi

original: sahevātipi yujjati. “Saha sacce kate mayha”nti cariyā. 3.82 hi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: saha iva atipi yujjati saha sacce kate mayhanti cariyā hi vuttam
translated: had gone forth, it is said, those eighty-four thousand young men of good family went forth. The rain fell following the performance of the truth-act, ‘anū’ means after, the meaning is that it was in dependence on that. It is said that when the truth-act was performed, the rain fell because of the truth-act. “The cause is also the characteristic” is said in the commentary. It is also appropriate to say ‘together with the truth-act’. “When the truth was performed by me” is said in the Cariyā.

original: Itthambhūte –
analyzed: ittham bhūte
translated: In the state of being:

original: Sādhu devadatto mātaramanu. Tattha ‘anū’ti anvāya paṭicca.
analyzed: sādhu devadattaḥ mātaram anu tattha anu iti anvāya paṭicca
translated: Well done, Devadatta, following the mother. There ‘anū’ means after, in dependence on.

original: Vicchāyaṃ –
analyzed: vicchāyam
translated: In the sky:

original: Rukkhaṃ rukkhaṃ anu vijjotate cando. Tattha ‘anū’ti anu pharitvā.
analyzed: rukkham rukkham anu vijjotate candaḥ tattha anūti anu pharitvā
translated: The moon shone round the tree, there ‘anū’ means having spread round.

original: Bhāge –
analyzed: bhāge
translated: In the part:

original: Yadettha maṃ anu siyā, taṃ dīyatu. Tattha ‘anū’ti anvāya. Sesaṃ vuttanayameva.🔽301. Sahatthe ka. 299; rū. 288; nī. 582, 586; caṃ. 2.1.57; pā. 1.4.85.🔽Sahatthe anunā yuttā liṅgamhā dutiyā hoti.🔽Pabbataṃ anu tiṭṭhati pabbatamanusenā tiṭṭhati (moggallānavuttiyaṃ). Nadiṃ anvāvasitā bārāṇasī. ‘Anū’ti anugantvā, nadiyā saha ābaddhā tiṭṭhatīti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: yat ettha mam anu siyā tam dīyatu tattha anu iti anvāya sesam vutta nayam eva  sahatthe ka rū nī  cam pā  sahatthe anunā yuttā liṅgamhā dutiyā hoti  pabbatam anu tiṭṭhati pabbatam anu senā tiṭṭhati moggallānavuttiyam nadim anvāvasitā bārāṇasī anu iti anugantvā nadiyā saha ābaddhā tiṭṭhati iti vuttam hoti
translated: What is mine after you, let that be given. Herein, after you = anvāya. The rest is as already stated.

original: 302. Hīne ka. 299; rū. 288; nī. 582, 586; caṃ. 2.1.58; pā. 1.4.86.🔽Hīne pavattena anunā yuttā liṅgamhā dutiyā hoti.🔽Anu sāriputtaṃ paññavanto, anugatā pacchato gatāti attho, sabbe paññavanto sāriputtato hīnāti vuttaṃ hoti.🔽303. Upena ka. 299; rū. 288; nī. 582, 586; caṃ. 2.1.59; pā. 1.4.87.🔽Hīne upena yuttā liṅgamhā dutiyā hoti.🔽Upa sāriputtaṃ paññavanto, upecca gatā samīpe gatāti attho, hīnātveva vuttaṃ hoti.
