original: Sattāhaṃ gavapānaṃ, māsaṃ maṃsodanaṃ, saradaṃ ramaṇīyā nadī, sabbakālaṃ ramaṇīyaṃ nandanaṃ, māsaṃ sajjhāyati, vassasataṃ jīvati, tayo māse abhidhammaṃ deseti.
analyzed: satta aham gavapānam māsam maṃsodanam saradam ramaṇīyā nadī sabbakālam ramaṇīyam nandanam māsam sajjhāyati vassa satam jīvati tayaḥ māse abhidhammam deseti
translated: For seven days he drinks cow’s urine, for a month he eats rice boiled in milk, for the rainy season the river is pleasant, for all time the Nandana is pleasant, for a month he recites, he lives a hundred years, for three months he teaches the Abhidhamma.

original: Addhāne –
analyzed: addhāne
translated: In the case of distance:

original: Yojanaṃ vanarāji, yojanaṃ dīgho pabbato, kosaṃ sajjhāyati.
analyzed: yojanam vana rāji yojanam dīghaḥ pabbataḥ kosam sajjhāyati
translated: A forest-avenue a league long, a mountain a league long, he recites a text.

original: Accantasaṃyogeti kiṃ? Māse māse bhuñjati, yojane yojane vihāro.
analyzed: a c c anta saṃyoga iti kim māse māse bhuñjati yojane yojane vihāraḥ
translated: What is meant by ‘in the case of a limit’? He eats every month, there is a monastery every league.

original: Ettha ca kriyāvisesanampi kattārā sādhetabbattā kammagatikaṃ hoti, tasmā tampi ‘kamme dutiyā’ti ettha kammasaddena gayhati.
analyzed: ettha ca kriyā visesanam pi kattārā sādhetabba ttā kamma gatikam hoti tasmā tam pi kamme dutiyā ti ettha kamma saddena gayhati
translated: And here the distinction of the verb is also in the category of the noun because it has to be established by the agent, and so that too is included by the word ‘noun’ in the phrase ‘in the case of a noun, the second’.

original: Sukhaṃ seti, dukkhaṃ seti, sīghaṃ gacchati, khippaṃ gacchati, dandhaṃ gacchati, muduṃ
analyzed: sukham seti dukkham seti sīgham gacchati khippam gacchati dandham gacchati mudum
translated: He sleeps happily, he sleeps miserably, he goes quickly, he goes fast, he goes slowly,

original: pacati, garuṃ essati, lahuṃ essati, sannidhikārakaṃ bhuñjati, samparivattakaṃ otāpeti,
analyzed: pacati garum essati lahum essati sannidhi kārakam bhuñjati samparivattakam otāpeti
translated: he cooks tender , he will carry a heavy load, he will carry a light load, he eats what is stored up, he boils what is turned over ,

original: kāyappacālakaṃ gacchati pāci. 590, hatthappacālakaṃ gacchati, sīsappacālakaṃ gacchati
analyzed: kāya ppacālakam gacchati pāci hattha ppacālakam gacchati sīsa ppacālakam gacchati
translated: he goes about touching his body, he goes about touching his hands, he goes about touching his head🔽.

original: pāci. 594-595, surusurukārakaṃ bhuñjati pāci. 627, avagaṇḍakārakaṃ bhuñjati pāci.🔽622, piṇḍukkhepakaṃ bhuñjati pāci. 620, hatthaniddhunakaṃ bhuñjati pāci. 623, hatthanillehakaṃ
analyzed: pāci surusurukārakam bhuñjati pāci avagaṇḍa kārakam bhuñjati pāci  piṇḍukkhepakam bhuñjati pāci hattha niddhunakam bhuñjati pāci hattha nillehakam
translated: He eats making a slurping sound. He eats making a smacking sound. He eats licking his lumps.🔽He eats throwing his lumps about. He eats shaking his hand about. He eats licking his hand.

original: bhuñjati pāci. 628, candimasūriyā samaṃ pariyāyanti, visamaṃ pariyāyanti iccādi.
analyzed: bhuñjati candima sūriyā samam pariyāyanti visamam pariyāyanti iccādi
translated: He eats licking his lips. The moon and sun move in a straight line, they move in a crooked line, and so on.

original: Dutiyāvibhattirāsi niṭṭhito.
analyzed: dutiyā vibhattiḥ āsi niṭṭhitaḥ
translated: The second case declension class is finished.

original: Tatiyāvibhattirāsi
analyzed: tatiyā vibhattiḥ ā asi
translated: The third case declension class

original: Kasmiṃ atthe tatiyā?
analyzed: kasmin atthe tatiyā
translated: In what meaning is the third case?

analyzed: kattu karaṇesu tatiyā ka   rū   nī   cam pā
translated: In the third case in the doing and the instrument ka. , ; rū. , ; nī. , ; caṃ. ..-; pā. ...

original: Kattari karaṇe ca tatiyā hoti. Kattāti ca kārakoti ca atthato ekaṃ “karotīti kattā,
analyzed: kattari karaṇe ca tatiyā hoti kattā ati ca kārakā iti ca atthataḥ ekam karoti iti kattā
translated: The third case is in the doing and the instrument. As to doing and instrument are the same in meaning: “He does, therefore he is a doer,

original: karotīti kārako”ti, tasmā “kattukārako”ti vutte dvinnaṃ pariyāyasaddānaṃ vasena ayameva
analyzed: karoti iti tasmā kattu kārakā iti vutte dvinnam pariyāya saddānam vasena ayam eva
translated: he does, therefore he is an instrument,” therefore when it is said “doer and instrument,” by way of the two synonyms

original: kriyaṃ ekantaṃ karoti, sāmī hutvā karoti, attappadhāno hutvā karotīti viññāyati,
analyzed: kriyam ekantam karoti sāmī hutvā karoti attappadhānaḥ hutvā karoti iti viññāyati
translated: it is known that he does the action entirely, he does it as a master, he does it as one who has the chief part,

original: tato kriyā nāma kattuno eva byāpāro, na aññesanti ca, aññe pana kriyāsādhane kattuno
analyzed: tatas kriyā nāma kattuno eva byāpāraḥ na ca aññe pana kriyā sādhane kattuno
translated: Then, action is the exertion of the doer himself, not of others. But others say that the doer is the cause of the action.

original: upakārakattā kārakā nāmāti ca, tathā anupakārakattā akārakā nāmāti ca viññāyantīti.
analyzed: upakāraka ttā kārakāḥ nāma ati ca tathā anupakāraka ttā akārakāḥ nāma ati ca viññāyanti iti
translated: Then, “An action is the exertion of an agent, not of anything else,” and “Others know that a cause is so called because it helps the agent in the action, and that a non-cause is so called because it does not help.”

original: Tattha kattā tividho sayaṃkattā, payojakakattā, kammakattāti.
analyzed: tattha kattā tividhaḥ sayaṃkattā payojaka kattā kamma kattā ati
translated: Herein, an agent is of three kinds: self-acting, acting by being sent, and acting by being made.

original: Tattha dhātvatthaṃ sayaṃ karonto sayaṃkattā nāma, puriso kammaṃ karoti.
analyzed: tattha dhātvattham sayam karontaḥ sayaṃkattā nāma puriso kammam karoti
translated: Herein, one who does by himself what is denoted by the verbal root is called self-acting, as in “A man does a deed” .

original: Paraṃ niyojento payojakakattā nāma, puriso dāsaṃ kammaṃ kāreti.
analyzed: param niyojento payojakakattā nāma purisaḥ dāsam kammam kāreti
translated: One who sends another is called acting by being sent, as in “A man makes a slave work” .

original: Kammakattā nāma payojjakakattāpi vuccati, puriso dāsena kammaṃ kāreti dāsassa vā,🔽yo ca aññena kataṃ payogaṃ paṭicca kammabhūtopi sukarattā vā kammabhāvena avattukāmatāya
analyzed: kamma kattā nāma payojjaka kattā api vuccati puriso dāsena kammam kāreti dāsassa vā  yaḥ ca aññena katam payogam paṭicca kamma bhūtaḥ api vā kamma bhāvena a vattu kāma tāya
translated: And acting by being made is called acting by being sent, as in “A man makes a slave work” or “A slave works for a man” .

original: vā ajānanatāya vā vañcetukāmatāya vā kattubhāvena voharīyati, so kammakattā nāma,
analyzed: vā a jānana tāya vā vañcetu kāma tāya vā kattu bhāvena vā uharīyati saḥ kamma kattā nāma
translated: And one who, though not an agent by being sent, is called an agent by being made because he is easily available for the action or because he is unwilling to be an agent or because he is ignorant or because he wants to deceive,🔽is called acting by being made.

original: kusūlo sayameva bhijjati, ghaṭo sayameva bhijjati. Apica sukaro vā hotu dukkaro vā,
analyzed: kusūlaḥ sayam eva bhijjati ghaṭaḥ sayam eva bhijjati apica sukaraḥ vā hotu dukkaraḥ vā
translated: The basket breaks by itself, the pot breaks by itself. Moreover, whether it is easy or difficult,

original: yo kammarūpakriyāpade paṭhamanto kattā, so kammakattāti vuccati. Saddarūpena kammañca
analyzed: yaḥ kamma rūpa kriyā pade kattā so kamma kattā ati vuccati sadda rūpena kamman ca
translated: the one who is the first to act in the place of action, craft, and work is called the agent of the action. The action is with sound-form,

original: taṃ attharūpena kattā cāti kammakattā, kusūlo bhijjati, ghaṭo bhijjati, paccati munino
analyzed: tam attha rūpena kattā ca ati kamma kattā kusūlaḥ bhijjati ghaṭaḥ bhijjati paccati munino
translated: and the agent is with non-sound-form, thus the agent of the action. The basket breaks, the pot breaks, the sage’s

original: bhattaṃ, thokaṃ thokaṃ ghare ghare iccādi.
analyzed: bhattam thokam thokam ghare ghare iccādi
translated: food is cooked, a little in each house, and so on.

original: Ettha ca saddattho duvidho paramattho, paññattatthoti. Tattha paramattho ekantena
analyzed: ettha ca saddatthaḥ duvidho paramattho paññattattho ti tattha paramattho ekantena
translated: And here the meaning of sound is twofold: ultimate meaning and conventional meaning. Therein, the ultimate meaning is

original: vijjamānoyeva. Paññattattho pana koci vijjamānoti sammato. Yathā? Rājaputto, govisāṇaṃ,
analyzed: vijjamānaḥ yā iva paññatta tthaḥ pana koci vijjamānaḥ iti sammataḥ yathā rāja putto go visāṇam
translated: only what exists. But the conventional meaning is agreed upon as either existent or non-existent. How? Prince, cow’s horn,

original: campakapupphanti. Koci avijjamānoti sammato. Yathā? Vañjhāputto, sasavisāṇaṃ, udumbarapupphanti.
analyzed: campaka pupphanti koci a vijjamānaḥ ti sammataḥ yathā vañjhāputto udumbara pupphanti
translated: jasmine flower. Some is agreed upon as non-existent. Like barren woman’s son, rabbit’s horn, fig tree flower.

original: Saddo ca nāma vatticchāpaṭibaddhavuttī hoti, vattamāno ca saddo atthaṃ na dīpetīti
analyzed: saddo ca nāma vatti chā paṭibaddha vuttī hoti vattamāno ca saddo attham na dīpeti iti
translated: And sound is spoken with reference to the grammatical moods, and the present tense sound does not illuminate the meaning.

original: natthi, saṅkete sati suṇantassa atthavisayaṃ buddhiṃ na janetīti natthīti adhippāyo.
analyzed: natthi saṅkete sati suṇantassa attha visayam buddhim na janeti iti natthi iti adhippāyaḥ
translated: and it is not, for when the convention is present, the idea of the meaning does not arise in one who hears.

original: Iti avijjamānasammatopi attho saddabuddhīnaṃ visayabhāvena vijjamāno eva hoti. Itarathā
analyzed: iti avijjamāna sammataḥ api attho sadda buddhīnam visaya bhāvena vijjamānaḥ eva hoti itarathā
translated: So the meaning, though not actually present, is nevertheless present as the objective field of the sound-idea and the meaning-idea. Otherwise,

original: ‘vañjhāputto’ti padaṃ suṇantassa tadatthavisayaṃ cittaṃ nāma na pavatteyyāti, saddabuddhīnañca
analyzed: vañjhāputto ti padam suṇantassa tad attha visayam cittam nāma na pavatteyya ati sadda buddhīnam ca
translated: when one hears the word “son of a barren woman,” there would be no such state of consciousness as that of the meaning of that.

original: visayabhāvena vijjamāno nāma attho saddanānātte buddhinānātte ca sati nānā hoti,🔽visuṃ visuṃ vijjamāno nāma hotīti adhippāyo. Evaṃ saddabuddhivisayabhāvena vijjamānañca
analyzed: visaya bhāvena vijjamānaḥ nāma attho sadda nānā ātte buddhi nānā ātte ca sati nānā hoti  visum visum vijjamānaḥ nāma hoti iti adhippāyaḥ evam sadda buddhi visaya bhāvena vijjamānam ca
translated: And the meaning, which is present as the objective field of the sound-idea and the meaning-idea, is different when the sound is different and the idea is different,

original: nānābhūtañca atthaṃ paṭicca kārakanānāttaṃ kriyākārakanānāttañca hoti, na pana sabhāvato
analyzed: nānābhūtam ca attham paṭicca kāraka nānā attam kriyā kāraka nānā attam ca hoti na pana sabhāvato
translated: it is different in each case, is what is intended. So the difference in the function of the agent and the difference in the function of the action and the agent are due to the meaning that is present and is different in this way as the objective field of the sound-idea and the meaning-idea,

original: vijjamānameva nānābhūtameva ca atthanti niṭṭhamettha gantabbaṃ. Tasmā “saṃyogo jāyate”
analyzed: vijjamānam eva nānā bhūtam eva ca niṭṭham ettha gantabbam tasmā saṃyogaḥ jāyate
translated: but it should be understood that it is not due to the meaning that is actually present and is different in itself. Therefore “the combination is born”

original: iccādīsu saddabuddhīnaṃ nānāttasiddhena atthanānāttena dvinnaṃ saddānaṃ dvinnaṃ atthānañca
analyzed: icca ādīsu sadda buddhīnam nānā ātta siddhena attha nānā āttena dvinnam saddānam dvinnam atthānam ca
translated: In such passages as these, the establishment of the difference of meaning by the establishment of the difference of the ideas of the words, the establishment of the difference of the two words and the two meanings,

original: kriyākārakatāsiddhi veditabbāti.
analyzed: kriyā kāraka tā siddhi
translated: should be understood as the establishment of the difference of the action and the instrument.

original: Kayirate anenāti karaṇaṃ, kriyāsādhane kattuno sahakārīkāraṇanti vuttaṃ hoti. Taṃ duvidhaṃ ajjhattikakaraṇaṃ, bāhirakaraṇanti.
analyzed: anena ati karaṇam kriyā sādhane kattuno sahakārīkāraṇanti vuttam hoti tam duvidham ajjhattika karaṇam bāhira karaṇanti
translated: The instrument is that by which something is done; it is a co-operating cause of the doer in accomplishing the action. It is of two kinds: internal instrument and external instrument.

original: Tattha kattuno aṅgabhūtaṃ karaṇaṃ ajjhattikaṃ nāma, puriso cakkhunā rūpaṃ passati,
analyzed: tattha kattunaḥ aṅga bhūtam karaṇam ajjhattikam nāma puriso cakkhunā rūpam passati
translated: Herein, the instrument which is a factor of the doer is called internal: “A man sees visible objects with the eye,

original: manasā dhammaṃ vijānāti, hatthena kammaṃ karoti, pādena maggaṃ gacchati, rukkho phalabhārena oṇamati.
analyzed: manasā dhammam vijānāti hatthena kammam karoti pādena maggam gacchati rukkhaḥ phala bhārena oṇamati
translated: cognizes a mental object with the mind, does a deed with the hand, goes along a path with the foot, a tree bends with a fruit-laden branch.”

original: Kattuno bahibhūtaṃ bāhiraṃ nāma, puriso yānena gacchati, pharasunā parasunā (sakkataganthesu) chindati, rukkho vātena oṇamati.
analyzed: kattunaḥ bahi bhūtam bāhiram nāma purisaḥ yānena gacchati pharasunā parasunā sakkata ganthesu chindati rukkhaḥ vātena oṇamati
translated: The instrument which is external to the doer is called external: “A man goes by means of a vehicle, cuts with an axe, a tree bends with the wind.”

analyzed: sahatthena ka rū nī cam pā

original: Sahasaddassa attho yassa soti sahattho, sahatthena saddena yuttā liṅgamhā tatiyā hoti. Sahasaddassa attho nāma samavāyattho.
analyzed: saha saddassa atthaḥ yassa saḥ ti sahatthaḥ saha atthena saddena yuttā liṅgamhā tatiyā hoti saha saddassa atthaḥ nāma samavāya ttho
translated: The meaning of the word saha is “together with”; thus sahattha means “having the meaning of saha”. The instrumental case is used with the word saha. The meaning of the word saha is “co-existence”.

original: So tividho dabbasamavāyo, guṇasamavāyo, kriyāsamavāyoti. Puttena saha dhanavā pitā,
analyzed: saḥ tividhaḥ dabba samavāyaḥ guṇa samavāyaḥ kriyā samavāyaḥ ti puttena saha dhanavā pitā
translated: It is of three kinds: co-existence of substance, co-existence of quality, and co-existence of action. The father is rich together with his son,

original: puttena saha thūlo pitā, puttena saha āgato pitā. Saha, saddhiṃ, samaṃ, nānā, vināiccādiko sahatthasaddo nāma.
analyzed: puttena saha thūlaḥ pitā puttena saha āgataḥ pitā saha saddhim samam nānā sahattha saddaḥ nāma
translated: the father is stout together with his son, the father has come together with his son. The words saha, saddhim, samaṃ, nānā, vinā, etc. are called sahattha words.🔽The Blessed One sat down together with the Community of Bhikkhus.

original: Nisīdi bhagavā saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghena mahāva. 59, sahassena samaṃ mitā saṃ. ni.🔽1.32, piyehi nānābhāvo vinābhāvo dī. ni. 2.183, 207, saṅgho saha vā gaggena vinā

analyzed: māsena bhuñjati yojanena dhāvati iccādi
translated: He eats for a month, he runs for a yojana, and so on.

original: Kriyāpavaggo nāma kriyāya sīghataraṃ niṭṭhāpanaṃ, tasmiṃ jotetabbe tatiyā, ekāheneva

original: Tatiyāvibhattirāsi niṭṭhito.
analyzed: niṭṭhitaḥ
translated: The heap of the third case is finished.

original: Catutthīvibhattirāsi
analyzed: catutthī vibhattiḥ ā asi
translated: The heap of the fourth case

original: Kasmiṃ atthe catutthī?
analyzed: kasmin a tthe catutthī
translated: In what meaning is the fourth case?

original: 309. Sampadāne catutthī ka. 293; rū. 301; nī. 605; catutthī sampadāne (bahūsu), caṃ. 2.1.73; pā. 2.3.13.
analyzed: sampadāne catutthī ka rū nī catutthī sampadāne bahūsu caṃ pā
translated: The fourth case is in the sense of the recipient, the fourth case is in the sense of the recipient (in many), the fourth case is in the sense of the recipient.

original: Sampadāne catutthī hoti. Sammā padīyate assāti sampadānaṃ, sampaṭicchakanti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: sampadāne catutthī hoti sammā padīyate assa ati sampadānam sampaṭicchakanti vuttam hoti
translated: The fourth case is in the sense of the recipient. It is rightly received, thus it is the recipient, it is said to be the one who consents.

original: Taṃ vatthusampaṭicchakaṃ, kriyāsampaṭicchakanti duvidhaṃ. Bhikkhussa cīvaraṃ deti, buddhassa silāghate.
analyzed: tam vatthu sampaṭicchakam kriyā sampaṭicchakam ti duvidham bhikkhussa cīvaram deti buddhassa silāghate
translated: That is twofold: the recipient of the object, the recipient of the action. He gives robe-cloth to the monk, he gives a stone slab to the Buddha.

original: Puna anirākaraṇaṃ, anumati, ārādhananti tividhaṃ hoti. Tattha na nirākaroti na nivāretīti
analyzed: puna a nirākaraṇam anumati ārādhananti tividham hoti tattha na nirākaroti na nivāreti iti
translated: Again, it is threefold as non- refusal, consent, and approval. Herein, non- refusal is that which does not refuse, does not prevent.

original: anirākaraṇaṃ, diyyamānaṃ na paṭikkhipatīti attho. Asati hi paṭikkhipane sampaṭicchanaṃ
analyzed: a nirākaraṇam diyyamānam na paṭikkhipati iti atthaḥ asati hi paṭikkhipane sampaṭicchanam
translated: The meaning is that it does not reject what is offered. For if there is no rejection, there is consent.

original: nāma hotīti. Kāyacittehi sampaṭicchanākāraṃ dassetvā paṭiggaṇhantaṃ sampadānaṃ anumati
analyzed: nāma hoti iti kāya cittehi sampaṭicchana ākāram dassetvā paṭiggaṇhantam sampadānam anumati
translated: Consent is called “acceptance.” When one accepts by showing the mode of acceptance with body and mind, that is called “consent.”

original: nāma. Vividhehi āyācanavacanehi parassa cittaṃ ārādhetvā sampaṭicchantaṃ ārādhanaṃ
analyzed: nāma vividhehi āyācana vacanehi parassa cittam ārādhetvā sampaṭicchantam ārādhanam
translated: When one accepts by pleasing another’s mind with various kinds of supplicating words, that is called “approval.”

original: nāma. Bodhirukkhassa jalaṃ deti, bhikkhussa annaṃ deti, yācakassa annaṃ deti.
analyzed: nāma bodhi rukkhassa jalam deti bhikkhussa annam deti yācakassa annam deti
translated: He gives water to the Bodhi tree, he gives food to the bhikkhu, he gives food to the beggar.

original: Kriyāsampaṭicchakaṃ nānākriyāvasena bahuvidhaṃ.
analyzed: kriyā sampaṭicchakam nānā kriyā vasena bahuvidham
translated: The kind of consent that is an action is of many kinds according to the various kinds of action.

original: Tattha rocanakriyāyoge –🔽Tañca amhākaṃ ruccati ceva khamati ca ma. ni. 1.179; ma. ni. 2.435, pabbajjā mama
analyzed: rocana kriyā yoge  tat ca amhākam ruccati ca iva khamati ca ma ni ma ni pabbajjā mama
translated: Herein, as regards the combination of the action of consenting:

original: ruccati jā. 2.22.43, kassa sāduṃ na ruccati, na me ruccati bhaddante, ulūkassābhisecanaṃ
analyzed: ruccati jā kassa sādum na ruccati na me ruccati bhaddante ulūkassa abhisecanam
translated: And that is pleasing and acceptable to us, Ma.Ni. ; the going forth is pleasing to me, Ma.Ni. ; who would not like sweet things? I do not like it, venerable sir, the anointing of the owl,

original: jā. 1.3.60. Gamanaṃ mayhaṃ ruccati, māyasmantānampi saṅghabhedo ruccittha pārā. 418,
analyzed: gamanam mayham ruccati saṅgha bhedaḥ
translated: Jā. 1.3.60. Going is agreeable to me, but not a schism in the Community is agreeable to the venerable ones.🔽If the venerable ones do not agree, the Community does not agree.

original: yassāyasmato na khamati, khamati saṅghassa pārā. 438, bhattaṃ mayhaṃ chādeti, bhattamassa
analyzed: yassa ayasmataḥ na khamati khamati saṅghassa pārā bhattam mayham chādeti bhattam assa
translated: He does not provide me with food, but he provides him with food.

original: nacchādeti cūḷava. 282, tesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ lūkhāni bhojanāni nacchādenti mahāva. 261
analyzed: tesam bhikkhūnam lūkhāni bhojanāni na chādenti
translated: He does not provide those monks with coarse food.

original: (thokaṃ visadisaṃ). Tattha ‘chādetī’ti icchaṃ uppādetīti attho.
analyzed: thokam visadisam tattha chādeti iti iccham uppādeti iti attho
translated: (Slightly different). Herein, ‘provides’ means he arouses a wish.

original: Dhāraṇappayoge –
analyzed: dhāraṇa ppayoge
translated: In the case of the application of the verb ‘to bear’:

original: Chattaggāho rañño chattaṃ dhāreti, sampatijātassa bodhisattassa devā chattaṃ dhārayiṃsu.
analyzed: chattaggāhaḥ raññaḥ chattam dhāreti sampatijātassa bodhisattassa devā chattam dhārayiṃsu
translated: The bearer of the king’s sunshade bears the king’s sunshade. When the Bodhisatta was born the gods bore a sunshade .

original: Buddhassa silāghate, thometīti attho, tuyhaṃ hanute, tuṇhibhāvena vañcetīti attho,
analyzed: buddhassa silāghate thometi iti attho tuyham hanute tuṇhi bhāvena vañceti iti attho
translated: The Buddha’s sunshade, the meaning is, he supports. He deceives you by his silence, the meaning is.

original: bhikkhunī bhikkhussa bhuñjamānassa pānīyena vā vidhūpanena vā upaṭṭhāti pāci. 816
analyzed: bhikkhunī bhikkhussa bhuñjamānassa pānīyena vā vidhūpanena vā upaṭṭhāti
translated: A bhikkhunī attends on a bhikkhu who is eating with water or with a fan.

original: (visadisaṃ). Dutiyāpi hoti, rañño upaṭṭhāti, rājānaṃ upaṭṭhāti, ahaṃ bhotiṃ upaṭṭhissaṃ
analyzed: visadisam dutiyā api hoti raññaḥ upaṭṭhāti rājānam upaṭṭhāti aham bhotim upaṭṭhissam
translated: (Slightly different). He attends on the king, the meaning is, he attends on the king. I will attend on the lady,

original: jā. 2.22.1934, ahaṃ taṃ upaṭṭhissāmi, mātāpituupaṭṭhānaṃ khu. pā. 5.6, tuyhaṃ sapate,
analyzed: aham tam upaṭṭhissāmi mātā pitu upaṭṭhānam khu pā tuyham sapate
translated: I will attend on you, (but) the attendance on mother and father is the best,

original: sapassu me vepacitti saṃ. ni. 1.253, sapathampi te samma ahaṃ karomi jā. 2.21.407,
analyzed: sapassu me vepa citti sam ni sapathampi te samma aham karomi jā
translated: Do you have faith in me, Vepacitti, I make an oath for you, my dear,

original: tava mayi saddahanatthaṃ saccaṃ karomīti attho, rañño sataṃ dhāreti, idha kulaputto🔽na kassaci kiñci dhāreti a. ni. 4.62, tassa rañño mayaṃ nāgaṃ dhārayāma. Tattha ‘rañño
analyzed: tava mayi saddahana attham saccam karomi iti atthaḥ raññaḥ satam dhāreti idha kula putto  na kassaci kiñci dhāreti a ni tassa raññaḥ mayam nāgam dhārayāma tattha raññaḥ
translated: The meaning is: I make a truth-act for you to have confidence in me. The King holds a hundred, here a young man

original: sataṃ dhāretī’ti sataṃ balidhanaṃ vā daṇḍadhanaṃ vā nidetīti nidhetīti, nidhema (keci)🔽attho, “iṇaṃ katvā gaṇhātī”ti ca vadanti. ‘Dhārayāmā’ti puna nidema nidhetīti, nidhema
analyzed: satam dhārā iti iti satam bali dhanam vā daṇḍa dhanam vā nidā iti iti nidheti iti nidhema keci  katvā gaṇhāti iti ca vadanti dhārayāma ati puna nidema nidheti iti nidhema
translated: does not hold anything for anyone, I make an oath, we hold the King’s elephant. Herein, ‘The King holds a hundred’ means he places a hundred as a deposit, or he places a hundred as a fine, he places (it), he places (it), (is the meaning), (some) say

original: (keci), tuyhaṃ saddahati, mayhaṃ saddahati, saddahāsi siṅgālassa, surāpītassa brāhmaṇa jā. 1.1.113.
analyzed: keci tuyham saddahati mayham saddahati saddahāsi siṅgālassa surā pītassa brāhmaṇa jā
translated: the meaning is: he takes a loan. ‘We hold’ means we place (it), we place (it), we place (it), do you have confidence, do I have confidence, do you have confidence in the lion, in the drunk brāhmaṇa, Jā. 1.153.

original: Devāpi te pihayanti tādino dha. pa. 94 (tassa pihayanti), devāpi tesaṃ pihayanti,
analyzed: devāḥ api te pihayanti tādinaḥ tassa pihayanti devāḥ api tesam pihayanti
translated: The gods envy one such as this, (but) the gods envy those who are such as this,

original: sambuddhānaṃ satīmataṃ dha. pa. 181, ‘pihayantī’ti punappunaṃ daṭṭhuṃ patthentīti
analyzed: sambuddhānam satī matam pihayanti iti punappunam daṭṭhum patthenti iti
translated: ‘Longing’ means wishing again and again to see.

original: attho. Dutiyāpi hoti, sace maṃ pihayasi, dhanaṃ piheti, hiraññaṃ piheti, suvaṇṇaṃ
analyzed: atthaḥ dutiyā api hoti sace mama pihayasi dhanam piheti hiraññam piheti suvaṇṇam
translated: The second is: ‘If you long for me, long for wealth’, long for gold, long for silver.

original: piheti. Tatiyāpi dissati, rūpena piheti, saddena piheti iccādi.🔽Tassa kujjha mahāvīra jā. 1.4.49, mā me kujjha rathesabha jā. 2.22.1696 (kujjhi),
analyzed: pihā iti tatiyā api dissati rūpena pihā iti saddena pihā iti iccādi  tassa kujjha mahāvīra jā  mā me kujjha rathesabha jā  kujjhi
translated: The third is: ‘If you see, long for form’, long for sound, and so on.

original: yadihaṃ tassa kuppeyyaṃ, mātu kuppati, pitu kuppati, yo appaduṭṭhassa narassa dussati🔽dha. pa. 125; su. ni. 667; jā. 1.5.94, duhayati disānaṃ megho, pūreti vināseti vāti
analyzed: yat iham tassa kuppeyyam mātu kuppati pitu kuppati yaḥ appaduṭṭhassa narassa dussati  duhayati disānam megha pūrā iti vināsā iti vāti
translated: ‘Be angry with him, Great Hero’, ‘Do not be angry with me, Charioteer’, ‘If I were to be angry with him, he would be angry with his mother, he would be angry with his father, he who is angry with an innocent man’,

original: attho, akāle vassanto hi vināseti nāma, yo mittānaṃ na dubbhati jā. 2.22.19, aduṭṭhassa
analyzed: atthaḥ akāle vassantaḥ hi vināseti nāma yaḥ mittānam na dubbhati jāḥ aduṭṭhassa
translated: ‘The cloud rains in the directions, it fills up, it destroys, it blows’, the meaning is, for when it rains at the wrong time it is called ‘destroying’. ‘He who does not deceive friends’, ‘You deceive the innocent’,

original: tuvaṃ dubbhi jā. 1.16.295, mittānaṃ na dubbheyya, titthiyā issanti samaṇānaṃ, ussūyanti
analyzed: tuvam mittānam na dubbheyya titthiyāḥ issanti samaṇānam ussūyanti
translated: ‘Do not deceive friends’, ‘The sectarians are jealous of ascetics, they are envious of ascetics’,

original: dujjanā guṇavantānaṃ, pativissakānaṃ ujjhāpesi ma. ni. 1.226 (ujjhāpesi), mā tumhe
analyzed: dujjanā guṇavantānam pativissakānam ujjhāpesi mā ni ujjhāpesi mā tumhe
translated: The wicked people, in regard to the virtuous,🔽(said): “Do not be angry,

original: tassa ujjhāyittha udā. 26 (visadisaṃ), mahārājānaṃ ujjhāpetabbaṃ viravitabbaṃ vikkanditabbaṃ,
analyzed: tassa ujjhāyittha udā visadisam mahā rājānam ujjhāpetabbam viravitabbam vikkanditabbam
translated: (said): “You should not be angry with him,🔽(said): “I have offended the Noble Ones,🔽(said): “The Noble Ones have offended the King,

original: kyāhaṃ ayyānaṃ aparajjhāmi pārā. 383 ayye vā, rañño aparajjhati rājānaṃ vā, ārādho me rājā hoti.
analyzed: kyā aham ayyānam aparajjhāmi pārā ayye vā raññaḥ aparajjhati rājānam vā ārādhaḥ me rājā hoti
translated: (said): “The King is very gracious to me.

original: Pati, āpubbassa su-dhātussa anu, patipubbassa ca gī-dhātussa yoge sampadāne catutthī.🔽Tatra kho bhagavā bhikkhū āmantesi “bhikkhavo”ti, “bhaddante”ti te bhikkhū bhagavato
analyzed: pati ā pubbassa sudhātussa anu pati pubbassa ca gī dhātussa yoge sampadāne catutthī  tatra kho bhagavā bhikkhū āmantesi bhikkhavaḥ ti bhaddanta iti te bhikkhū bhagavato
translated: In the compound ‘pati-āpubba-su-dhātu-anu-patipubba-ca-gī-dhātu-yoge sampadāne catutthī’,

original: paccassosuṃ a. ni. 1.1. Ettha ca pubbavākye āmantanakriyāya kattā bhagavā, so paravākye
analyzed: ettha ca pubba vākye āmantana kriyāya kattā bhagavā saḥ para vākye
translated: There the Fortunate One addressed the monks, saying: “Monks!”, “Reverend Sir!” those monks replied to the Fortunate One, a. ni. .. And here in the first clause the speaker is the Fortunate One, he🔽is the one who addresses, in the second clause

original: paccāsuyoge sampadānaṃ hoti, ‘paccassosu’nti bhaddanteti paṭivacanaṃ adaṃsūti attho.
analyzed: pacca āsu yoge sampadānam hoti bhaddanta iti paṭivacanam adaṃsu iti attho
translated: the one who replies is the one who is addressed, ‘they replied’ means they gave the reply ‘Reverend Sir’.

original: Bhikkhū buddhassa āsuṇanti, rājā bimbisāro pilindavacchattherassa ārāmikaṃ paṭissutvā
analyzed: bhikkhū buddhassa āsuṇanti rājā bimbisāraḥ pilindavaccha therassa ārāmikam paṭissutvā
translated: The monks listen to the Buddha, the King Bimbisāra, after agreeing to the Elder Pilindavaccha’s request,

original: mahāva. 270, amacco rañño bimbisārassa paṭissutvā mahāva. 270, sampaṭicchitvāti attho,
analyzed: amaccaḥ raññaḥ bimbisārassa paṭissutvā mahāva sampaṭicchitvā ati attho
translated: The minister, having agreed to the king Bimbisāra’s request, having consented, is the meaning.

original: bhikkhu janaṃ dhammaṃ sāveti, jano tassa bhikkhuno anugiṇāti paṭigiṇāti, sādhukāraṃ detīti attho.
analyzed: bhikkhu janam dhammam sāveti janaḥ tassa bhikkhunaḥ anugiṇāti paṭigiṇāti sādhukāram deti iti attho
translated: The monk teaches the Dhamma to the people, the people accept it from the monk, they accept it, they give the approval, is the meaning.

original: Ārocanatthayoge –🔽Ārocayāmi vo bhikkhave ma. ni. 1.416, paṭivedayāmi vo bhikkhave ma. ni. 1.416, āmantayāmi🔽vo bhikkhave dī. ni. 2.218 (visadisaṃ), dhammaṃ vo desessāmi ma. ni. 3.105, bhikkhūnaṃ
analyzed: ārocanattha yoge  ārocayāmi vaḥ bhikkhave ma ni paṭivedayāmi vaḥ bhikkhave ma ni  āmantayāmi  vaḥ bhikkhave visadisam dhammam vaḥ desessāmi bhikkhūnam
translated: In the case of the purpose of announcing:

original: dhammaṃ deseti, yathā no bhagavā byākareyya, niruttiṃ te pavakkhāmi, ahaṃ te ācikkhissāmi,
analyzed: dhammaṃ deseti yathā naḥ bhagavā byākareyya niruttim te pavakkhāmi aham te ācikkhissāmi
translated: I announce to you, monks, the Noble Eightfold Path, I make known to you, monks, the Noble Eightfold Path, I inform you, monks, the Dhamma and Discipline … I teach the Dhamma to the monks, as the Lord has declared, I will proclaim the language, I will explain it to you,

original: ahaṃ te kittayissāmi, bhikkhūnaṃ etadavoca.
analyzed: aham te kittayissāmi bhikkhūnam etat avoca
translated: I will proclaim it to you, he said to the monks.

original: 310. Tadatthe ka. 277; rū. 303; nī. 554.
analyzed: tad a tthe ka rū nī
translated: In the case of the meaning of that: ka. ; rū. ; nī. .

original: Tassā tassā kriyāya atthoti tadattho, tadatthe sampadāne catutthī hoti.
analyzed: tassa tassa kriyāya tad atthaḥ tad atthe sampadāne catutthī hoti
translated: The meaning of that is the meaning of that particular action. In the case of the expression of that meaning the fourth case is used.

original: 311. Sassāya catutthiyā ka. 109; rū. 304; nī. 279-80.
analyzed: sassāya catutthiyā ka rū nī
translated: In the case of the fourth with the meaning of ‘for the sake of’: ka. ; rū. ; nī. -.🔽After a word ending in a vowel the fourth case becomes āyo.

original: Akārantato catutthībhūtassa sassa āyo hoti vā.
analyzed: akāra antataḥ catutthī bhūtassa sassa āyaḥ hoti vā
translated: . Or not.

original: Vinayo saṃvaratthāya, saṃvaro avippaṭisāratthāya, avippaṭisāro pāmujjatthāya, pāmujjaṃ
analyzed: vinayaḥ saṃvara tthāya saṃvaraḥ a vippaṭisāra tthāya a vippaṭisāraḥ pāmujja tthāya pāmujjam
translated: The Discipline is for the sake of restraint, restraint is for the sake of non-remorse, non-remorse is for the sake of gladdening, gladdening is for the sake of

original: pītatthāya, pīti passaddhatthāya, passaddhi sukhatthāya, sukhaṃ samādhatthāya, samādhi
analyzed: pīta tthāya pīti passaddha tthāya passaddhi sukha tthāya sukham samādha tthāya samādhi
translated: happiness, happiness is for the sake of concentration, concentration is for the sake of

original: yathābhūtañāṇadassanatthāya, yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ nibbidatthāya, nibbidā virāgatthāya,
analyzed: yathābhūta ñāṇa dassana tthāya yathābhūta ñāṇa dassanam nibbida tthāya nibbidā virāga tthāya
translated: knowledge and vision according to reality, knowledge and vision according to reality is for the sake of disenchantment, disenchantment is for the sake of dispassion,

original: virāgo vimuttatthāya, vimutti vimuttiñāṇadassanatthāya, vimuttiñāṇadassanaṃ anupādāparinibbānatthāya
analyzed: virāgaḥ vimutta tthāya vimutti vimutti ñāṇa dassana tthāya vimutti ñāṇa dassanam anupādā parinibbāna tthāya
translated: dispassion is for the sake of freedom, freedom is for the sake of the knowledge and vision of freedom, the knowledge and vision of freedom is for the sake of the destruction by non-grasping,

original: pari. 366, atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ ma. ni. 1.50, alaṃ kukkuccāya pārā.
analyzed: pari atthāya hitāya sukhāya deva manussānam mā ni alam kukkuccāya pārā
translated: for the sake of welfare, benefit, and happiness for gods and men.

original: 38, alaṃ sammohāya, pākāya vajati, yuddhāya gacchati, gāmaṃ piṇḍāya pāvisiṃ pāci. 902.
analyzed: alam sammohāya pākāya vajati yuddhāya gacchati gāmam piṇḍāya pāvisim
translated: , enough for remorse, enough for confusion, goes to maturity, goes to battle, entered the village for alms, cooked.

original: Tumatthopi tadatthe saṅgayhati, alaṃ mitte sukhāpetuṃ, amittānaṃ dukhāya ca jā. 2.17.13.
analyzed: tumatthaḥ upi tad atthe saṅgayhati alam mitte amittānam dukhāya ca
translated: , even if it has a different meaning, it is included in that meaning, enough to make friends happy, and for the suffering of enemies.

original: Lokānukampāya buddho loke uppajjati, alaṃ phāsuvihārāya, abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya
analyzed: loka anukampāya buddhaḥ loke uppajjati alam phāsu vihārāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya
translated: , out of compassion for the world, the Buddha appears in the world, enough for ease, for direct knowledge, for full enlightenment, for Nibbāna.

original: saṃvattati mahāva. 13.
analyzed: saṃvattati
translated: is successful, great one.

original: Alamatthayoge –
analyzed: alam attha yoge
translated: In the case of the Alamatthayoge:

original: Alaṃ mallo mallassa, arahati mallo mallassa, alaṃ te idha vāsena pārā. 436, alaṃ
analyzed: alam mallaḥ mallassa arahati mallaḥ mallassa alam te idha vāsena alam
translated: Alaṃ mallo mallassa, arahati mallo mallassa, alaṃ te idha vāsena pārā, alaṃ

original: te hiraññasuvaṇṇena, kiṃ me ekena tiṇṇena bu. vaṃ. 2.56, kiṃ te jaṭāhi dummedha,
analyzed: te hirañña suvaṇṇena kim me ekena tiṇṇena kim te jaṭāhi dummedha
translated: te hiraññasuvaṇṇena, kiṃ me ekena tiṇṇena bu. vaṃ. ., kiṃ te jaṭāhi dummedha,

original: kiṃ te ajinasāṭiyā dha. pa. 394.
analyzed: kim te ajinasāṭiyā
translated: kiṃ te ajinasāṭiyā dha. pa. .

original: Maññanāpayoge anādare apāṇismimeva catutthī, kaṭṭhassa tuvaṃ maññe, kaliṅgarassa kaḷiṅgarassa, kaḷaṅgarassa (ka.) tuvaṃ maññe, jīvitaṃ tiṇāyapi na maññati.
analyzed: maññana apayoge anādare a pāṇismim eva catutthī kaṭṭhassa tuvam maññe kaliṅgarassa kaḷiṅgarassa kaḷaṅgarassa ka tuvam maññe jīvitam na maññati
translated: In the case of the Maññanāpayoge anādare apāṇismimeva catutthī, kaṭṭhassa tuvaṃ maññe, kaliṅgarassa kaḷiṅgarassa, kaḷaṅgarassa (ka.) tuvaṃ maññe, jīvitaṃ tiṇāyapi na maññati.

original: Anādareti kiṃ? Suvaṇṇaṃ taṃ maññe.
analyzed: an ādara iti kim suvaṇṇam tam maññe
translated: In the case of the Anādare: kiṃ? Suvaṇṇaṃ taṃ maññe.

original: Apāṇisminti kiṃ? Gadrabhaṃ tuvaṃ maññe.
analyzed: a pāṇismin ti kim gadrabham tuvam maññe
translated: In the case of the Apāṇismim: kiṃ? Gadrabhaṃ tuvaṃ maññe.

original: Gatyatthānaṃ nayanatthānañca dhātūnaṃ kammani catutthī, appo saggāya gacchati dha.
analyzed: gati atthānam nayana tthānam ca dhātūnam kammani catutthī appo saggāya gacchati
translated: In the case of the Gatyatthānaṃ nayanatthānañca dhātūnaṃ kammani catutthī, appo saggāya gacchati dha.

original: pa. 174, yo maṃ dakāya neti jā. 1.6.97, nirayāyupakaḍḍhati dha. pa. 311, mūlāya paṭikasseyya cūḷava. 111.
analyzed: yaḥ mam dakāya neti jā  nirayāya upakaḍḍhati dha pa mūlāya paṭikasseyya cūḷava
translated: pa. , yo maṃ dakāya neti jā. .., nirayāyupakaḍḍhati dha. pa. , mūlāya paṭikasseyya cūḷava. .

original: Āsīsanakriyāyoge –
analyzed: āsīsana kriyā yoge
translated: In the case of the Āsīsanakriyāyoge –

original: Āyu bhavato hotu, bhaddaṃ te hotu, bhaddamatthu te jā. 1.8.15; jā. 2.17.1, kusalaṃ🔽te hotu, anāmayaṃ te hotu, sukhaṃ te hotu, atthaṃ te hotu, hitaṃ te hotu, kalyāṇaṃ
analyzed: āyu bhavataḥ hotu bhaddam te hotu bhaddamatthu te jā jā kusalam  te hotu anāmayam te hotu sukham te hotu attham te hotu hitam te hotu kalyāṇam
translated: May you have long life, may you be fortunate, may you have good luck, may you be well.🔽May you have what is wholesome, may you have what is harmless, may you have happiness, may you have what is beneficial, may you have what is good,

original: te hotu, svāgataṃ te hotu, sotthi te hotu sotthi gabbhassa ma. ni. 2.351, maṅgalaṃ te hotu.
analyzed: te hotu svāgatam te hotu sotthi te hotu sotthi gabbhassa ma ni maṅgalam te hotu
translated: may you have a good welcome, may you have safety, may you have safety in your womb. May you have good fortune.

original: Sammutiyoge kammatthe [chaṭṭhī], itthannāmassa bhikkhuno rūpiyachaḍḍakassa sammuti pārā. 590, pattagāhāpakassa sammutiiccādi pārā. 614.
analyzed: sammuti yoge kammatthe chaṭṭhī itthannāmassa bhikkhuno rūpiya chaḍḍakassa sammuti pārā patta gāhāpakassa sammuti iccādi pārā
translated: In the case of the sixth (case) in the sense of a connection with a conventional term, (it is used in the expression) “The agreement of the monk named so-and-so to give up silver is finished”, “The agreement of the monk named so-and-so to receive the bowl is finished”, and so on.

original: Āvikaraṇādiyoge –🔽Tuyhañcassa āvi karomi, tassa me sakko pāturahosi, tassa pahiṇeyya, bhikkhūnaṃ dūtaṃ🔽pāhesi, kappati bhikkhūnaṃ āyogo, vaṭṭati bhikkhūnaṃ āyogo, patthodano dvinnaṃ tiṇṇaṃ
analyzed: āvi karaṇa ādi yoge  tuyham ca assa āvi karomi tassa me sakko pāturahosi tassa pahiṇeyya bhikkhūnam dūtam  pāhesi kappati bhikkhūnam āyogaḥ vaṭṭati bhikkhūnam āyogaḥ patthodanaḥ dvinnam tiṇṇam
translated: In the case of the connection with the words ‘to announce’ and so on,🔽(it is used in the expressions) “I will announce to you”, “He appeared to me”, “He sent a message”, “He sent a messenger

original: nappahoti, ekassa pahoti, ekassa pariyatto, upamaṃ te karissāmi ma. ni. 1.258; jā.
analyzed: na pahoti ekassa pahoti ekassa pariyattaḥ upamam te karissāmi ma ni
translated: to the monks”, “It is allowable for the monks to have a connection”, “It is suitable for the monks to have a connection”, “The rice gruel is not enough for two or three”, “It is enough for one”, “It is just right for one”, “I will make a simile for you”, and so on.

original: 2.19.24, añjaliṃ te paggaṇhāmi jā. 2.22.327, tathāgatassa phāsu hoti, āvikatā hissa
analyzed: añjalim te paggaṇhāmi jā tathāgatassa phāsu hoti āvika tā hissa
translated: 2.19.24, I raise my clasped hands to you, Jā. 2.22.327, The Realised One is at ease, for his ease

original: phāsu mahāva. 134, lokassa attho, lokassa hitaṃ, maṇinā me attho pārā. 344, na mamattho
analyzed: phāsu lokassa atthaḥ lokassa hitam maṇinā me atthaḥ pārā na mamatthaḥ
translated: is made manifest, Mahāva. , for the benefit of the world, for the welfare of the world, I need a gem, Pārā. , I have no need

original: buddhena pārā. 52, namatthu buddhānaṃ namatthu bodhiyā jā. 1.2.17, vipassissa ca
analyzed: buddhena pārā namatthu buddhānam namatthu bodhiyā jā vipassissa ca
translated: of a Buddha, Pārā. , Honour to the Buddhas, honour to the Awakening, Jā. .., and to Vipassī

original: namatthu dī. ni. 3.277, namo karohi nāgassa ma. ni. 1.249, namo te purisājañña, namo
analyzed: namatthu dī ni namaḥ karohi nāgassa ma ni  namaḥ te purisa ajañña namaḥ
translated: honour to the Dī. ni. .., make obeisance to the Nāga, Ma. ni. .., homage to you, O Wise One, homage

original: te purisuttama apa. thera 1.2.129. Sotthi pajānaṃ dī. ni. 1.274, suvatthi pajānaṃ iccādi.
analyzed: te purisa uttama thera sotthi pajānam ni suvatthi pajānam iccādi
translated: to you, O Supreme One, O Man, Apa. thera ... Safe is the people, Dī. ni. .., well-being for the people, Iccādi.

original: Catutthīvibhattirāsi niṭṭhito.
analyzed: niṭṭhitaḥ
translated: The heap of the fourth case endings is finished.

original: Pañcamīvibhattirāsi
analyzed: pañcamī vibhattiḥ ā asi
translated: The heap of the fifth case endings

original: Kasmiṃ atthe pañcamī?
analyzed: kasmin atthe pañcamī
translated: In what meaning is the fifth case?

original: 312. Pañcamyāvadhismiṃ ka. 295; rū. 307; nī. 607; caṃ. 2.1.81; pā. 2.3.28; 1.4.24.
analyzed: pañcamyā avadhi smin ka rū nī cam pā
translated: . In the fifth case ending, in the limit, Ka. ; Rū. ; Nī. ; Caṃ. ..; Pā. ..; ...

original: Avadhiyati vavatthiyati padattho etasmāti avadhi, tasmiṃ pañcamī hoti, avadhīti ca apādānaṃ vuccati.
analyzed: avadhiyati vavatthiyati padatthaḥ etasmā ati avadhi tasmin pañcamī hoti avadhi iti ca apādānam vuccati
translated: It is a limit, it is a definition, the meaning of a word is limited by it, therefore it is a limit, in that (meaning) the fifth case ending occurs, and a limit is said to be an ablative.

original: Apanetvā ito aññaṃ ādadāti gaṇhātīti apādānaṃ. Taṃ tividhaṃ niddiṭṭhavisayaṃ, uppāṭavisayaṃ, anumeyyavisayanti.
analyzed: apanetvā itas aññam ādadāti gaṇhāti iti apādānam tam tividham niddiṭṭha visayam uppāṭa visayam anumeyya visayanti
translated: Taking away and taking from that what is other than that is ‘taking away’. That is of three kinds as having a stated object, as having an object to be supplied, and as having an object to be inferred.

original: Tattha yasmiṃ apādānavisayabhūto kriyāviseso sarūpato niddiṭṭho hoti, taṃ niddiṭṭhavisayaṃ. Yathā? Gāmā apenti munayo, nagarā niggato rājā.
analyzed: tattha yasmin apādāna visaya bhūtaḥ kriyā visesaḥ sarūpataḥ niddiṭṭhaḥ hoti tam niddiṭṭha visayam yathā gāmāḥ apenti munayaḥ nagarāḥ niggataḥ rājā
translated: Herein, that particular instance of action that is stated in its own individual essence in the object of the taking away is ‘having a stated object’. For example: Munis go from villages, The king from towns is banished.

original: Yasmiṃ pana so pāṭhasesaṃ katvā ajjhāharitabbo hoti, taṃ uppāṭavisayaṃ. Yathā? Valāhakā
analyzed: yasmim pana so pāṭha sesam katvā ajjhāharitabbaḥ hoti tam uppāṭa visayam yathā valāhakā
translated: But that particular instance of action that has to be supplied by the hearer after supplying a remainder of the statement is ‘having an object to be supplied’. For example: From the cloud

original: vijjotate vijju, agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajitoti mahāva. 30. Ettha hi ‘nikkhamitvā’ti
analyzed: vijjotate vijju agārasmai anagāriyam pabbajito ti ettha hi nikkhamitvā ati
translated: The lightning flashes, From home to homelessness he went. Herein, the word ‘after going out’

original: padaṃ ajjhāharitabbaṃ.🔽Yasmiṃ pana so niddiṭṭho ca na hoti, ajjhāharituñca na sakkā, atha kho atthato anumānavasena
analyzed: padam ajjhāharitabbam  yasmim pana saḥ niddiṭṭhaḥ ca na hoti ajjhāharitum ca na sakkā atha kho atthataḥ anumāna vasena
translated: has to be supplied.🔽But that particular instance of action that is neither stated nor can be supplied but has to be understood by inference from the meaning is ‘having an object to be inferred’. For example: More beautiful than those of Pāṭaliputta

original: so viññeyyo hoti, taṃ anumeyyavisayaṃ. Yathā? Māthurā pāṭaliputtakehi abhirūpatarā,
analyzed: saḥ viññeyyaḥ hoti tam anumeyya visayam yathā māthurā pāṭaliputtakehi abhirūpatarā
translated: Are those of Mathurā,

original: sīlameva sutā seyyo jā. 1.5.65, mayā bhiyyo na vijjati, aggohamasmi lokassa, jeṭṭhohamasmi🔽lokassa, seṭṭhohamasmi lokassa iccādi ma. ni. 3.207. Kriyaṃ vinā kārakaṃ nāma na🔽sijjhatītikatvā ukkaṃsanakriyā ettha anumetabbā hoti. Evaṃ kriyāpadarahitesu dūrayogādīsupi
analyzed: sīlam eva sutā seyyaḥ jā mayā bhiyyas na vijjati aggaḥ uham asmi lokassa jeṭṭhaḥ uham asmi  lokassa seṭṭhaḥ ham asmi lokassa iti ca ādi ma ni kriyam vinā kārakam nāma na  sijjhati iti katvā ukkaṃsana kriyā ettha anumetabbā hoti evam kriyāpada rahitesu dūra yoga ādīsu pi
translated: Virtue is better than learning. There is none better than me. I am the chief in the world, I am the elder in the world, I am the best in the world. Thus, etc.🔽Without action there is no such thing as a case. Therefore the action of praising is to be inferred here. So too in such expressions as “far-going,” etc.,

original: avinābhāvikriyānumānaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: avinābhāvi kriyā anumānam veditabbam
translated: where the word for action is absent, the action that is invariably concomitant should be understood to be inferred.

original: Puna calā’calavasena duvidhaṃ.
analyzed: punar cala acala vasena duvidham
translated: Again, it is of two kinds as moving and unmoving.

original: Calaṃ yathā? Puriso dhāvatā assā patati, dve meṇḍā yujjhitvā aññamaññato apasakkanti.
analyzed: calam yathā purisaḥ dhāvatā assā patati dve meṇḍā yujjhitvā aññam aññatas apasakkanti
translated: Moving is like this: A man falls from a running horse; two rams butt each other and move apart.

original: Ettha ca yadi calaṃ siyā, kathaṃ avadhi nāma bhaveyya. Accutilakkhaṇo hi avadhīti?🔽Vuccate-dve meṇḍā sakasakakriyāya calanti, itarītarakriyāya avadhī hontīti natthi
analyzed: ettha ca yadi calam siyā katham avadhi nāma bhaveyya accuti lakkhaṇaḥ hi avadhi iti  vuccate dve meṇḍā saka saka kriyāya calanti itarītara kriyāya avadhī honti iti natthi
translated: And here if it were moving, how could there be a boundary? For a boundary has the characteristic of delimiting, does it not?

original: ettha avadhilakkhaṇavirodhoti.
analyzed: ettha avadhi lakkhaṇa virodho ti
translated: It may be said: the two rams move by their own action, but they are a boundary by their mutual action. So there is no contradiction here with the characteristic of a boundary.

original: Acalaṃ yathā? Gāmā apenti munayo, nagarā niggato rājā.
analyzed: acalam yathā gāmāḥ apenti munayaḥ nagarāḥ niggataḥ rājā
translated: Unmoving is like this: The seers go to the village; the king goes out from the city.

original: Puna kāyasaṃsaggapubbakaṃ, cittasaṃsaggapubbakanti duvidhaṃ hoti, gāmā apenti munayo,
analyzed: puna kāya saṃsagga pubbakam citta saṃsagga pubbakam ti duvidham hoti gāmā apenti munayaḥ
translated: Again, it is of two kinds as preceded by bodily contact and as preceded by mental contact.🔽The sages go out from the village,🔽Fear arises from the thieves.

original: corā bhayaṃ jāyate. Ettha ca “kiṃva dūro ito gāmo, ito sā dakkhiṇā disā dī. ni. 3.279.
analyzed: corāḥ bhayam jāyate ettha ca kiṃva dūraḥ itas gāmaḥ itas sā dakkhiṇā disā
translated: And here, in the passage beginning, “How far is it to the village? This is the southern direction from here,”

original: Ito ekanavutikappe”ti dī. ni. 2.4 ādīsu vadantassa cittasaṃsaggapubbakampi veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: itas ekanavuti kappa iti dī ni ādīsu vadantassa citta saṃsagga pubbakam pi veditabbam
translated: it should be understood that it is also preceded by mental contact.

original: “Na mātā puttato bhāyati, na ca putto mātito bhāyati, bhayā bhīto na bhāsasī”ti jā.
analyzed: na mātā puttataḥ bhāyati na ca puttaḥ mātitaḥ bhāyati bhayā bhītaḥ na bhāsasi iti jā
translated: “A mother has no fear from her son, and a son has no fear from his mother. You speak in fear,”🔽in the passage beginning, “There is no fear for you from here,”

original: 2.21.138 pāḷi. Atthi te ito bhayaṃ ma. ni. 2.350, natthi te ito bhayaṃ, yato khemaṃ
analyzed: atthi te itas bhayam ma ni  natthi te itas bhayam yatas khemam
translated: “There is fear for you from here,”🔽“The thieves are afraid,”🔽“The thieves are fearful,”🔽“The thief is afraid,”

original: tato bhayaṃ jā. 1.9.58, corā bhāyati, corā bhīto. Chaṭṭhī ca, corassa bhāyati, corassa
analyzed: tatas bhayam jā corā bhāyati corā bhīto chaṭṭhī ca corassa bhāyati corassa
translated: “The thief is fearful,”

original: bhīto. Dutiyā ca, “kathaṃ paralokaṃ na bhāyeyya, evaṃ paralokaṃ na bhāyeyya, bhāyasi
analyzed: bhītaḥ dutiyā ca katham para lokam na bhāyeyya evam para lokam na bhāyeyya bhāyasi
translated: “How should one not be afraid of the other world? Thus one should not be afraid of the other world. You are afraid,”🔽“I am not afraid of you,”🔽“One should be afraid,”

original: maṃ samaṇa su. ni. sūcilomasutta, nāhaṃ taṃ bhāyāmi su. ni. sūcilomasutta, bhāyitabbaṃ
analyzed: mam samaṇa su ni sūcilomasutta na aham tam bhāyāmi su ni sūcilomasutta bhāyitabbam
translated: “One should not be afraid,”

original: na bhāyati, nāhaṃ bhāyāmi bhoginaṃ jā. 2.22.835, na maṃ migā uttasantī”ti jā. 2.22.307
analyzed: na bhāyati na aham bhāyāmi bhoginam jā  na mam migāḥ uttasanti iti jā
translated: the deer do not run away from me” , J.

original: pāḷipadāni dissanti. Tattha “bhogina’nti nāgaṃ, corā tasati uttasati corassa vā,
analyzed: pāḷi padāni dissanti tattha nāgam corā tasati uttasati corassa vā
translated: The lines are found there. Herein, “snake” is a nāga, thieves are afraid, run away, of a thief,

original: sabbe tasanti daṇḍassa dha. pa. 129, pāpato ottappati jigucchati harāyati pāpena vā.
analyzed: sabbe tasanti daṇḍassa dha pa pāpataḥ ottappati jigucchati harāyati pāpena vā
translated: all are afraid of punishment, Dhp. v. 131, one is ashamed of evil, is disgusted with it, is humiliated by it, or by evil.

original: Yato kiñci sippaṃ vā vijjaṃ vā dhammaṃ vā gaṇhāti, tasmiṃ akkhātari pañcamī, upajjhāyā
analyzed: yatas kiñci sippam vā vijjam vā dhammam vā gaṇhāti tasmin akkhātari pañcamī upajjhāyā
translated: When one learns any craft or science or Dhamma, the fifth case is used with regard to the teacher, the preceptor,

original: adhīte, upajjhāyā sippaṃ gaṇhāti, dvāsīti buddhato gaṇhiṃ, dve sahassāni bhikkhuto.
analyzed: adhīte upajjhāyā sippam gaṇhāti dvāsīti buddhataḥ dve sahassāni bhikkhuto
translated: the preceptor learns, the preceptor learns a craft, I learned from the Buddha two thousand and eighty, from the bhikkhus eighty-four thousand.

original: Caturāsītisahassāni, yeme dhammā pavattino theragā. 1027.
analyzed: catur āsīti sahassāni ye me dhammā pavattinaḥ thera gā
translated: Eighty-four thousand dhammas Are in the Theragāthā.

original: Yato suṇāti, tasmiṃ pañcamī, chaṭṭhī ca, ito sutvā, imassa sutvā vā, yamhā dhammaṃ vijāneyya, sammāsambuddhadesitaṃ dha. pa. 392.
analyzed: yatas suṇāti tasmim pañcamī chaṭṭhī ca itas sutvā imassa sutvā vā yamhā dhammam vijāneyya sammāsambuddha desitam
translated: When one hears, the fifth case is used with regard to that, and the sixth case is used with regard to this, “Having heard from this, having heard from this one, from whom one would understand the Dhamma taught by the Fully Enlightened One, Dhp. v. 131.

original: Yato labhati, tasmiṃ pañcamī, saṅghato labhati, gaṇato labhati.
analyzed: yatas labhati tasmin pañcamī saṅghataḥ labhati gaṇataḥ labhati
translated: When one obtains, the fifth case is used with regard to that, “One obtains from the Community, one obtains from the group.”

original: Yato parājayati, yato pabhavati, yato jāyati, tasmiṃ pañcamī, buddhasmā parājayanti
analyzed: parājayati yatas u pabhavati yatas jāyati tasmin pañcamī parājayanti
translated: From what is it defeated? From what does it come into being? From what is it born? In this, the fifth, the non-Buddhists are defeated by the Buddha.

original: aññatitthiyā, pāḷiyaṃ pana parājiyoge apādānaṃ pāṭhasesavasena labbhati, tasmiṃ kho
analyzed: añña titthiyā pāḷiyam pana parāji yoge apādānam pāṭha sesa vasena labbhati tasmim kho
translated: In the text, however, the ablative is read in the compound parājayoga, according to the method of reading the text. In this,

original: pana saṅgāme devā jiniṃsu, asurā parājiniṃsu. Ettha devehi parājiniṃsūti pāṭhaseso.
analyzed: pana saṅgāme devāḥ jiniṃsu asurā parājiniṃsu ettha devehi parājiniṃsu iti pāṭha sesaḥ
translated: in that battle, the gods were victorious, the asuras were defeated. Here, the reading is “by the gods they were defeated.”

original: “Mayaṃ jitāmhā ambakāya. Himavantā pabhavanti pañca mahānadiyo a. ni. aṭṭha. 3.8.19,
analyzed: mayam jitā amhāḥ ambakāya himavantā pabhavanti pañca mahā nadiyaḥ a ni aṭṭha
translated: “We are defeated, O mother. From the Himalayas five great rivers come forth. a. ni. aṭṭha. ..

original: ayaṃ bhāgīrathī gaṅgā, himavantā pabhāvitā”ti pāḷi apa. thera 1.1.255, corā bhayaṃ
analyzed: bhāgīrathī gaṅgā himavantā apa thera
translated: This is the Bhāgīrathī, the Ganges, which flows forth from the Himalayas.” The text apa. thera .., thieves fear is born,

analyzed: jāyate kāmataḥ jāyate bhayam jā  /
translated: fear is born from passion dha. pa. , fear is born from what is born jā. ..; ..;

analyzed: yat kiñci bhayam vā veram vā upaddavaḥ vā upasaggaḥ vā jāyati sabbam
translated: .., , , whatever fear, enmity, calamity, or misfortune is born, all that

original: taṃ bālato jāyati, no paṇḍitato, kāmato jāyatī soko dha. pa. 214, ubhato sujāto putto
analyzed: tam bālataḥ jāyati no paṇḍitataḥ kāmataḥ jāyati sokaḥ dha pa ubhataḥ su jāto putto
translated: is born from the fool, not from the wise one, sorrow is born from passion dha. pa. , a son well-born on both sides

original: dī. ni. 1.311, urasmā jāto, ure jāto vā, cīvaraṃ uppajjeyya saṅghato vā gaṇato vā
analyzed: urasmā jātaḥ ure jātaḥ vā cīvaram uppajjeyya saṅghataḥ vā gaṇataḥ vā
translated: If a robe-material should arise for a monk from a group or from a number or

original: ñātimittato vā pārā. 500 (thokaṃ visadisaṃ).🔽Aññatthānaṃ yoge pañcamī, tato aññaṃ, tato paraṃ mahāva. 346, tato aparena samayena pārā. 195.🔽Upasaggānaṃ yoge pana –🔽313. Apaparīhi vajjane ka. 272; rū. 309; nī. 558, 568; caṃ. 2.1.82; pā. 1.4.88; 2.3.10.🔽Vajjane pavattehi apa, parīhi yoge pañcamī hoti.🔽Apapabbatā vassati devo, paripabbatā vassati devo, apasālāya āyanti vāṇijā, parisālāya🔽āyanti vāṇijā, pabbataṃ sālaṃ vajjetvāti attho. Kaccāyane pana “uparipabbatā devo
analyzed: ñāti mittataḥ vā pārā thokam visadisam  aññatthānam yoge pañcamī tatas aññam tatas param tatas aparena samayena  upasaggānam yoge pana  apaparīhi vajjane ka rū nī  cam pā  vajjane pavattehi apa parīhi yoge pañcamī hoti  apapabbatā vassati devaḥ paripabbatā vassati devaḥ apasālāya āyanti vāṇijā parisālāya  āyanti vāṇijāḥ pabbatam sālam vajjetvā iti attho kaccāyane pana upari pabbatā devo
translated: from relatives or from friends or from a lay follower or from a group of lay followers or from a number of lay followers or from a guild or from a group of people traveling by boat or from a crowd or from a king or from a king’s man or from a wheel-turning monarch or from a wheel-turning monarch’s man or from a nāga or from a nāga’s man or from a gandhabba or from a gandhabba’s man or from a supaṇṇa or from a supaṇṇa’s man or from a yakkha or from a yakkha’s man or from a human or from a non-human or from a deva or from a deva’s man or from Brahmā or from Brahmā’s man,

original: vassatī”ti pāṭho porāṇapāṭho, paripabbatāti yutto. Upariyoge pana sattamīyeva dissati🔽– “tasmiṃ uparipabbate ma. ni. 3.216; jā. 1.8.16, uparipāsāde dī. ni. 2.408, uparivehāse,

analyzed: sahatthe

original: Saha sabbaññutaññāṇappaṭilābhā, saha parinibbānā dī. ni. 2.220, saha dassanuppādā.
analyzed: saha sabbaññu ta ññāṇa paṭilābhā saha parinibbānā saha dassan uppādā
translated: With the acquisition of the knowledge of omniscience, with the attainment of Nibbāna, with the arising of the seeing.

original: “Uppādā vā tathāgatānaṃ anuppādā vā tathāgatāna”nti saṃ. ni. 2.20, ettha bhāvalakkhaṇe pañcamī.
analyzed: uppādāḥ vā tathāgatānam anuppādāḥ vā tathāgatānam ti sam ni ettha bhāva lakkhaṇe pañcamī
translated: “Whether there is an arising of Tathāgatas or no arising of Tathāgatas” , here the fifth case is in the sense of state.

original: “Sahatthā dānaṃ deti, sahatthā paṭiggaṇhātī”ti ettha karaṇe.
analyzed: sahatthā dānam deti sahatthā paṭiggaṇhāti iti ettha karaṇe
translated: “He gives a gift with his own hand, he receives with his own hand” , here it is in the sense of instrument.

original: “Ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ dī. ni. 1.250, tadagge kho vāseṭṭha”iccādīsu dī. ni. 3.130, ārabbhe sattamī.
analyzed: ajja tagge pāṇ upetam dī ni tad agge kho vāsa iṭṭha aicca ādīsu dī ni  ārabbhe sattamī
translated: “Today, Vāseṭṭha, you have come to the fore in the world” , here the fifth case is in the sense of proximity.

original: “Yatvādhikaraṇaṃ dī. ni. 1.213, yatonidānaṃ su. ni. 275, tatonidānaṃ” iccādīsu ma. ni. 1.238 vākye icchite sati hetvatthe pañcamī, samāse icchite sati atthamatte pañcamī.🔽Dvinnaṃ kārakānaṃ kriyānañca majjhe pavattakāladdhānavācīhi pañcamī, luddako pakkhasmā
analyzed: ya tva adhikaraṇam dī ni yatas nidānam su ni tatas nidānam icca ādīsu ma ni  vākye icchite sati hetvatthe pañcamī samāse icchite sati attha matte pañcamī  dvinnam kārakānam kriyānam ca majjhe pañcamī luddakaḥ pakkhasmā
translated: “For the reason that … for the cause that … for the ground that … for the occasion that … for the purpose that … for the sake of that” , here the fifth case is in the sense of cause when the sentence is desired, and it is in the sense of object when the compound is desired.🔽The fifth case is used to express the time that occurs in the middle between two actions and agents: “The hunter shoots the deer from the tree.” “The elephant shoots the hunter from the thicket.” And here the hunter, having shot the deer once,

original: migaṃ vijjhati, kosā kuñjaraṃ vijjhati. Ettha ca luddako sakiṃ migaṃ vijjhitvā pakkhabbhantaramhi
analyzed: migam vijjhati kosā kuñjaram vijjhati ettha ca luddakaḥ sakim migam vijjhitvā pakkha bbhantaramhi
translated: after the lapse of a fortnight,

original: na vijjhi, pakkhe paripuṇṇe puna vijjhati, pakkhasaddo dvinnaṃ vijjhanavārānaṃ majjhe
analyzed: na pakkhe paripuṇṇe puna vijjhati pakkha saddaḥ dvinnam vijjhana vārānam majjhe
translated: It does not pierce. When the wings are fully grown, it pierces again. The sound of the wings is in the middle of the two piercings.

original: kālavācī hoti, dvepi vijjhanakriyā kārakehi saheva sijjhantīti kārakānañca majjheti
analyzed: kāla vācī dve api vijjhana kriyā kārakehi saha iva sijjhanti iti kārakānam ca majjhā iti
translated: It is called “one of time” because the two actions of piercing are accomplished together with the agents. And it is called “in the middle of the agents”

original: vuccati. Vuttiyaṃ pana “ajja bhutvā devadatto dvihe bhuñjissati, dvihā bhuñjissati,
analyzed: vuccati vuttiyam pana ajja bhutvā devadattaḥ dvihe bhuñjissati dvihā bhuñjissati
translated: because it is in the middle of the agents. But in the commentary it is said: “Devadatta will eat twice today after eating once. He will eat twice after eating once.

original: atraṭṭho’yamissāso kose lakkhaṃ vijjhati, kosā lakkhaṃ vijjhatī”ti moga. 79 evaṃ
analyzed: kose lakkham vijjhati kosāḥ lakkham vijjhati iti moga evam
translated: The meaning here is this: ‘The mark will pierce the box. The mark will pierce the box.’

original: sattamīvasena paripuṇṇavākyampi vuttaṃ. Pāḷiyaṃ “anāpatti chabbassā karoti pārā.
analyzed: sattamī vasena paripuṇṇa vākyam pi vuttam pāḷiyam anāpatti karoti pārā
translated: Thus it is said to be a complete sentence in the sense of the locative case. In the text it is said: ‘There is no offence if he makes it for six years and it is finished after six years.🔽If he makes it for more than six years and it is finished after six years.

original: 564, atirekachabbassā karotī”ti pārā. 564, “chabbassānī”tipi pāṭho.
analyzed: atireka chabbassā karoti iti pārā
translated: The reading is also ‘chabbassāni.’

original: Rakkhanatthānaṃ yoge –🔽Yañca vatthuṃ guttaṃ icchiyate, yato ca guttaṃ icchiyate, tattha pañcamī, yavehi
analyzed: rakkhana atthānam yoge  yat ca vatthum guttam icchiyate yatas ca guttam icchiyate tattha pañcamī yavehi
translated: In the compound meaning ‘to be protected’:

original: gāvo rakkhati vāreti, taṇḍulā kāke rakkhati vāreti, taṃ maṃ puññā nivāresi, pāpā
analyzed: gāvaḥ rakkhati vāreti taṇḍulā kāke rakkhati vāreti tam mama puññā nivāresi pāpā
translated: The locative case is used in the sense of the thing that is to be protected, and in the sense of the place from which it is to be protected. The cows are protected by the barley. The crows are protected by the rice. Merit protected me. Evil

original: cittaṃ nivāraye dha. pa. 116, na naṃ jāti nivāreti, duggatyā garahāya vā su. ni.
analyzed: cittam nivāraye na nam nivāreti duggatyā garahāya vā
translated: Birth does not restrain it, nor does a bad destination or blame.

original: 141 (na ne). Rājato vā corato vā ārakkhaṃ gaṇhantu.
analyzed: na ne rājataḥ vā corataḥ vā ārakkham gaṇhantu
translated: (Not it.) Let them take protection from a king or a robber.

original: Antaradhānatthayoge –
analyzed: antara dhāna ttha yoge
translated: In the case of the compound antaradhānatthāya,

original: Yassa adassanaṃ icchiyati, tasmiṃ pañcamī, upajjhāyā antaradhāyati sisso, nilīyatīti🔽attho. Pāḷiyaṃ pana yassa adassanaṃ icchiyati, tasmiṃ chaṭṭhī eva- “antaradhāyissāmi
analyzed: yassa a dassanam icchiyati tasmim pañcamī upajjhāyā antaradhāyati sissaḥ nilīyati iti  pana yassa a dassanam icchiyati tasmim chaṭṭhī eva antaradhāyissāmi
translated: if one wishes to disappear, the fifth case is used: “The pupil disappears when the preceptor disappears.”🔽The meaning is that he vanishes. But in the text the sixth case is used: “I will disappear from the recluse Gotama, I will disappear from the recluse Gotama.”

original: samaṇassa gotamassa, antaradhāyissāmi samaṇassa gotamassā”ti. “Na sakkhi me antaradhāyitu”nti
analyzed: samaṇassa gotamassa antaradhāyissāmi samaṇassa gotamassa ati na sakkhi me antaradhāyitunti
translated: The text has “I am not able to disappear.”

original: pāḷi, ‘antaradhāyissāmī’ti antarite acakkhuvisaye ṭhāne attānaṃ ṭhapessāmītyattho,
analyzed: antaradhāyissāmi iti antarite a cakkhu visaye ṭhāne attānam ṭhapessāmi iti attho
translated: The meaning is: “I will disappear” means I will place myself in a place that is out of sight.

original: nilīyissāmīti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: nilīyissāmi iti vuttam hoti
translated: It is the same as if one said “I will vanish.”

original: Yasmiṃ ṭhāne antaradhāyati, tasmiṃ sattamī eva dissati, atikhippaṃ loke cakkhu antaradhāyissati
analyzed: yasmim ṭhāne antaradhāyati tasmim sattamī eva dissati atikhippam loke cakkhu antaradhāyissati
translated: If one disappears in a certain place, the seventh case is used: “The eye will disappear too quickly in the world.”

original: dī. ni. 2.224 (visadisaṃ), jetavane antaradhāyitvā, brahmaloke antaradhāyitvā, maddakucchismiṃ
analyzed: visadisam jetavane antaradhāyitvā brahma loke antaradhāyitvā maddakucchismin
translated: (different), having disappeared in front of the Fortunate One, having disappeared in the Brahmā-world, having disappeared in Maddakucchi,

original: antaradhāyitvā, tatthevantaradhāyī saṃ. ni. 1.1 iccādi. “Bhagavato purato antaradhāyitvā”ti
analyzed: antaradhāyi tvā tattha iva antaradhāyī sam ni iccādi bhagavato puratas antaradhāyi tvā ati
translated: having disappeared there itself, saṃ. ni. . and so on. “Having disappeared in front of the Fortunate One”

original: etthapi tosaddo sattamyatthe eva. “Sakko nimissa rañño sammukhe antarahito”ti pāḷi.
analyzed: ettha api to saddo sattamī atthe eva sakkaḥ nimissa rañño sammukhe antarahitaḥ ti pāḷi
translated: here also the word tosaddo is in the sense of the locative case. “Sakka having disappeared in front of King Nimī” is the text.

original: ‘Dhajatavane antaradhāyitvā’ti jetavane aññesaṃ adassanaṃ katvā, aññesaṃ acakkhuvisayaṃ
analyzed: dhajatavane antaradhāyitvā ati jetavane aññesam a dassanam katvā aññesam a cakkhu visayam
translated: ‘Having disappeared in the Jetavana’ means having made (himself) invisible to others, having made (himself) not within the range of others’ eyes,

original: katvāti attho. “Andhakāro antaradhāyati, āloko antaradhāyati, saddhammo antaradhāyati,
analyzed: katvā iti atthaḥ andhakāraḥ antaradhāyati ālokaḥ antaradhāyati saddhammaḥ antaradhāyati
translated: this is the meaning. “Darkness disappears, light disappears, the True Dhamma disappears,

original: sāsanaṃ antaradhāyati” iccādīsu pana chaṭṭhī, sattamiyo yathāsambhavaṃ veditabbā.
analyzed: sāsanam antaradhāyati iccādīsu pana chaṭṭhī sattamiyaḥ yathāsambhavam veditabbā
translated: the Dispensation disappears” and so on, but here the locative and ablative cases should be understood as appropriate.

original: Dūratthayoge –
analyzed: dūrattha yoge
translated: In the case of the meaning of distance:

original: Kiṃva dūro ito gāmo, kacci ārā pamādamhā su. ni. 156, atho ārā pamādamhā su. ni.
analyzed: kiṃva dūraḥ itas gāmaḥ kacci ārā pamādamhā su ni atho ārā pamādamhā su ni
translated: How far is the village from here, are you far from heedlessness? su. ni. , or are you far from heedlessness? su. ni.

original: 157, gāmato avidūre, ārakā te moghapurisā imasmā dhammavinayā, ārakā tehi bhagavā,
analyzed: gāmataḥ avidūre ārakā te mogha purisāḥ imasmaā dhamma vinayāḥ ārakā tehi bhagavā
translated: Not far from the village: far from this Dhamma and Discipline are those foolish men, far from them is the Exalted One,🔽they are far from the defilements, therefore he is an Arahant, he is far from the destruction of the cankers, Dhp 157.

original: kilesehi ārakāti arahaṃ, ārā so āsavakkhayā dha. pa. 253. Dutiyā ca tatiyā ca chaṭṭhī
analyzed: kilesehi araham ārā so āsava kkhayā dha pa dutiyā ca tatiyā ca chaṭṭhī
translated: The second, third, and sixth

original: ca, ārakā imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ iminā dhammavinayena vā, ārakā mandabuddhīnaṃ visuddhi ṭī. 1.130.
analyzed: ca ārakā imam dhamma vinayam iminā dhamma vinayena vā ārakā manda buddhīnam
translated: are far from this Dhamma and Discipline, or from this Dhamma and Discipline, far from those of dull understanding is purification, Tika. ..

original: Dūratthe –
analyzed: dūratthe
translated: In the sense of far away:

original: Dūratova namassanti, addasā kho bhagavantaṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ dī. ni. 1.409, kinnu🔽tiṭṭhatha ārakā, tasmā tiṭṭhāma ārakā. Dutiyā ca tatiyā ca, dūraṃ gāmaṃ āgato, dūrena
analyzed: dūratas iva namassanti addasā kho bhagavantam dūratas iva āgacchantam ni kinnu  tiṭṭhatha ārakā tasmā tiṭṭhāma ārakā dutiyā ca tatiyā ca dūram gāmaṃ āgataḥ dūrena
translated: They worship from afar, the venerable one saw the Exalted One coming from afar, Dī. ni. ., what is it?

original: gāmena āgato, dūrā gāmā āgato iccevattho, dūraṃ gāmena vā.
analyzed: gāmena āgataḥ dūrāḥ gāmāḥ āgataḥ iccevatthaḥ dūram gāmena vā
translated: You stand far away, therefore we stand far away. The second, third, and sixth, he has come from a distant village, he has come from a distant village, the meaning is just that, from a distant village or by a distant village.

original: Antikatthayoge –
analyzed: antika ttha yoge
translated: In the sense of near:

original: Antikaṃ gāmā, āsannaṃ gāmā, samīpaṃ gāmā. Dutiyā ca tatiyā ca chaṭṭhī ca, antikaṃ gāmaṃ, antikaṃ gāmena, antikaṃ gāmassa.🔽Kāladdhānaṃ parimāṇavacane –
analyzed: antikam gāmā āsannam gāmā samīpam gāmā dutiyā ca tatiyā ca chaṭṭhī ca antikam gāmam antikam gāmena antikam gāmassa 🔽kāladdhānam parimāṇa vacane
translated: Near the village, close to the village, adjacent to the village. The second, third, and sixth, near the village, by the village, of the village.

original: Ito mathurāya catūsu yojanesu saṅkassaṃ, rājagahato pañcacattālīsayojane sāvatthi,
analyzed: itas mathurāya catūsu yojanesu saṅkassam rājagahataḥ pañcacattālīsa yojane sāvatthi
translated: Four yojanas from here to Mathura, fifty-four yojanas from here to Savatthi,

original: ito ekanavutikappe dī. ni. 2.4, ito ekatiṃse kappe dī. ni. 2.4, ito sattame divase,
analyzed: itas ekanavuti kappe dī ni  itas ekatiṃse kappe dī ni  itas sattame divase
translated: Ninety-one aeons ago, thirty-one aeons ago, seven days from now,

original: ito tiṇṇaṃ māsānaṃ accayena parinibbāyissāmi dī. ni. 2.168; udā. 51 iccādi.
analyzed: itas tiṇṇam māsānam accayena parinibbāyissāmi iccādi
translated: Three months from now I shall attain final Nibbana.

original: Pamāṇatthe –
analyzed: pamāṇa tthe
translated: In the sense of measure:

original: Āyāmato ca vitthārato ca yojanaṃ, parikkhepato navayojanasataparimāṇo majjhimadeso
analyzed: āyāmataḥ ca vitthārataḥ ca yojanam parikkhepataḥ nava yojana sata parimāṇaḥ majjhima desaḥ
translated: The Middle Land is a yojana in breadth and a yojana in length, and it is nine hundred yojanas in circumference.

original: parikkhepena vā, dīghaso navavidatthiyo pāci. 548, yojanaṃ āyāmena yojanaṃ vitthārena
analyzed: parikkhepena vā yojanam āyāmena yojanam vitthārena
translated: Or, in circumference, it is nine hundred cubits long, a yojana in breadth, and a yojana in length.

original: yojanaṃ ubbedhena sāsaparāsi saṃ. ni. 2.129 iccādi.🔽Tvālopepi pañcamī. Ettha ca tvālopo nāma paripuṇṇavākye laddhabbassa tvāntapadassa
analyzed: yojanam ubbedhena sāsa parāsi sam ni i t ca ādi  tvālope pi pañcamī ettha ca tvālopaḥ nāma paripuṇṇa vākye laddhabbassa tvā anta padassa
translated: A yojana in height, a heap of sesame seeds.🔽The fifth case is also used in the sense of a measure. Herein, a measure is the absence of what is not complete in a complete sentence of the state of being at the end of a word ending in the instrumental case.

original: aparipuṇṇavākye natthi bhāvo, yañca padaṃ tvāntapade sati kammaṃ vā hoti adhikaraṇaṃ
analyzed: a paripuṇṇa vākye na atthi bhāvaḥ yat ca padam tva anta pade sati kammam vā hoti adhikaraṇam
translated: And the word that has the function of a case-ending or the function of a base

original: vā. Taṃ tvāntapade asati padantare avadhi hoti, tasmiṃ pañcamī, pāsādā vā pāsādaṃ
analyzed: vā tam tva anta pade asati pad antare avadhi tasmin pañcamī pāsādāḥ vā pāsādam
translated: If that is not the case, then the locative case is determined by the other case, and the locative is the fifth case. From the palace to the palace,

original: saṅkameyya saṃ. ni. 1.132, hatthikkhandhā vā hatthikkhandhaṃ saṅkameyya saṃ. ni.
analyzed: saṅkameyya sam ni hatthi kkhandhā vā hatthi kkhandham saṅkameyya sam ni
translated: If there is no place for the locative, then the instrumental is used instead. One should ascend a palace from a palace, or one should ascend a palace from a chariot, or one should ascend the back of an elephant from a palace, or one should ascend the back of an elephant from the back of an elephant.🔽One should ascend a palace from a palace, or one should ascend a palace from a chariot, or one should ascend the back of an elephant from a palace, or one should ascend the back of an elephant from the back of an elephant.

original: 1.132 iccādi. Ettha ca paṭhamaṃ ekaṃ pāsādaṃ abhirūhitvā puna aññaṃ pāsādaṃ saṅkameyyāti
analyzed: iccādi ettha ca paṭhamam ekam pāsādam abhirūhitvā puna aññam pāsādam saṅkameyya ati
translated: And here, having first ascended one palace, one should ascend another palace again,

original: vā paṭhamaṃ ekasmiṃ pāsāde nisīditvā puna aññaṃ pāsādaṃ saṅkameyyāti vā evaṃ paripuṇṇavākyaṃ
analyzed: vā paṭhamam ekasmin pāsāde nisīditvā puna aññam pāsādam saṅkameyya ati vā evam paripuṇṇa vākyam
translated: or having first sat in one palace, one should ascend another palace again, in this way the complete sentence should be understood.

original: veditabbaṃ. “Andhakārā vā andhakāraṃ gaccheyya, tamā vā tamaṃ gaccheyyā”ti saṃ. ni.
analyzed: veditabbam andhakārā vai andhakāram gaccheyya tamā vā tamam gaccheyya ati sam ni
translated: One should go from darkness to darkness, or from gloom to gloom.

original: 1.132 pāḷi. Tathā raṭṭhā raṭṭhaṃ vicarati, gāmā gāmaṃ vicarati, vanā vanaṃ vicarati,
analyzed: tathā raṭṭhā raṭṭham vicarati gāmā gāmam vicarati vanā vanam vicarati
translated: This is the text. Likewise, one roams from country to country, from village to village, from forest to forest,

original: vihārato vihāraṃ gacchati, pariveṇato pariveṇaṃ gacchati, bhavato bhavaṃ gacchati,
analyzed: vihārataḥ vihāram gacchati pariveṇataḥ pariveṇam gacchati bhavataḥ bhavam gacchati
translated: one goes from monastery to monastery, from courtyard to courtyard, from existence to existence,

original: kulato kulaṃ gacchati iccādi. Tathā vinayā vinayaṃ pucchati, abhidhammā abhidhammaṃ
analyzed: kulatas kulam gacchati iccādi tathā vinayāḥ vinayam pucchati abhidhammāḥ abhidhammam
translated: one goes from family to family. And so on. Likewise, one asks about the Vinaya from the Vinaya, about the Abhidhamma from the Abhidhamma,

original: pucchati, vinayā vinayaṃ katheti, abhidhammā abhidhammaṃ katheti. Etthapi paṭhamaṃ
analyzed: pucchati vinayāḥ vinayam kathā iti abhidhammāḥ abhidhammam kathā iti ettha api paṭhamam
translated: He asks about the Vinaya, he talks about the Vinaya, he asks about the Abhidhamma, he talks about the Abhidhamma. Here too, having asked about one statement of the Vinaya first,

original: ekaṃ vinayavacanaṃ pucchitvā vā ekasmiṃ vinayavacane ṭhatvā vā puna aññaṃ vinayavacanaṃ🔽pucchatīti paripuṇṇavākyaṃ veditabbaṃ. Vuttiyaṃ pana “pāsādaṃ āruyha pekkhati, pāsādā
analyzed: ekam vinaya vacanam pucchitvā vā ekasmin vinaya vacane ṭhatvā vā puna aññam vinaya vacanam  pucchati iti paripuṇṇa vākyam veditabbam vuttiyam pana pāsādaṃ āruyha pekkhati pāsādā
translated: or having stood on one statement of the Vinaya, he asks about another statement of the Vinaya.

original: pekkhati, āsane pavisitvā pekkhati, āsanā pekkhatī”ti vuttaṃ.🔽Disatthayoge disatthe ca pañcamī, ito sā purimā disā dī. ni. 3.278, ito sā dakkhiṇā
analyzed: pekkhati āsane pavisitvā pekkhati āsanā pekkhati iti vuttam  dis attha yoge dis atthe ca pañcamī itas sā purimā disā itas sā dakkhiṇā
translated: The complete sentence should be understood thus. But in the commentary it is said: “He looks down from the palace, he looks down from the palace, he looks down after entering the seat, he looks down from the seat.”

original: disā dī. ni. 3.278, avīcito upari, uddhaṃ pādatalā, adho kesamatthakā dī. ni. 2.377; ma. ni. 1.110.
analyzed: avīceḥ upari uddham pāda talāḥ adhas kesamatthakā
translated: In the compound of the word for direction and the word for direction, the fifth case is used: “This is the eastern direction from here” (D.i,1), “This is the southern direction from here” (D.i,1), “The Avīci hell is below” (D.i,1), “Above is the top of the head” (D.i,1), “Below is the soles of the feet” (D.i,1).

original: Disatthe –
analyzed: dis atthe
translated: In the word for direction:

original: Purimato gāmassa, dakkhiṇato gāmassa, uparito pabbatassa, heṭṭhato pāsādassa, puratthimato,🔽dakkhiṇato, yato khemaṃ, tato bhayaṃ jā. 1.9.58, yato yato sammasati, khandhānaṃ
analyzed: purimataḥ gāmassa dakkhiṇataḥ gāmassa uparitas pabbatassa heṭṭhatas pāsādassa puratthimataḥ  dakkhiṇatas yatas khemam tatas bhayam jā yatas yatas sammasati khandhānaṃ
translated: “From the village in front, from the village to the south, from the mountain above, from the palace below, from the east,

original: udayabbayaṃ dha. pa. 374 iccādi.
analyzed: udaya bbayam dha pa i t ca ādi
translated: from the south, from where there is safety, from there danger has arisen” (J.i,1), “From wherever he comprehends the arising and passing away of the aggregates” (D.i,1).

original: Pubbādiyogepi pañcamī, pubbeva me sambodhā a. ni. 3.104, ito pubbe, tato pubbe, ito parā paccantimā janapadā mahāva. 259, tato pure, tato pacchā, tato uttari pārā. 499 iccādi.
analyzed: pubba ādi yoge pi pañcamī pubbā iva me sambodhā a ni itas pubbe tatas pubbe itas parā paccantimāḥ janapadāḥ tatas pure tatas pacchā tatas uttari pārā iccādi
translated: The fifth case is also used in the sense of before, etc., as follows: ‘Before my enlightenment’ (pubbeva me sambodhā), ‘before this’, ‘before that’, ‘the western countries beyond this’, ‘before that’, ‘after that’, ‘beyond that’, ‘the eastern countries beyond that’ (tato pure), ‘the western countries beyond that’ (tato pacchā), ‘the northern countries beyond that’ (tato uttari pārā).

original: Vibhattatthe ca pañcamī chaṭṭhī ca. Vibhatti nāma pageva visuṃbhūtassa atthassa kenaci
analyzed: vibhatta atthe ca pañcamī chaṭṭhī ca vibhatti nāma pagā iva visuṃbhūtassa atthassa kenaci
translated: The fifth and sixth cases are used in the sense of the state of being divided. The state of being divided is the separation of a meaning that has become divided from something else by some

original: adhikena vā hīnena vā bhāgena tadaññato puthakkaraṇaṃ, māthurā pāṭaliputtakehi abhirūpatarā,🔽yato paṇītataro vā visiṭṭhataro vā natthi, attadanto tato varaṃ dha. pa. 322, channavutīnaṃ
analyzed: adhikena vā hīnena vā bhāgena tad aññatas puthakkaraṇam māthurā pāṭaliputtakehi abhirūpatarā  yatas paṇītataraḥ vā visiṭṭhataraḥ vā na atthi atta danto tatas varam dha pa channavutīnam
translated: superior or inferior portion, as follows: ‘The women of Mathurā are more beautiful than those of Pāṭaliputta’,

original: pāsaṇḍānaṃ pavaraṃ yadidaṃ sugatavinayo, sadevakassa lokassa, satthā loke anuttaro,
analyzed: pāsaṇḍānam pavaram yat idam sugata vinayaḥ sa devakassa lokassa satthā loke anuttaraḥ
translated: ‘There is none superior or more distinguished than this’, ‘One who has self-control is better than he’ (Dhp. 35), ‘The Dispensation of the Well-Farer is the best of the sixty-two systems’ (Dhp. 35), ‘The Teacher is unsurpassed in the world with its gods’ (Dhp. 35),

original: aggohamasmi lokassa ma. ni. 3.207, jeṭṭhohamasmi lokassa ma. ni. 3.207, seṭṭhohamasmi
analyzed: aggaḥ uham asmi lokassa ma ni jeṭṭhaḥ uham asmi lokassa ma ni seṭṭhaḥ uham asmi
translated: ‘I am the chief in the world’ (Dhp. 35), ‘I am the eldest in the world’ (Dhp. 35), ‘I am the best in the world’ (Dhp. 35),

original: lokassa ma. ni. 3.207, paññavantā nāma sāriputtato hīnā sāriputtassa vā, tato adhikaṃ
analyzed: lokassa ma ni paññavantā nāma sāriputtataḥ hīnā sāriputtassa vā tatas adhikam
translated: ‘Those called wise are inferior to Sāriputta or superior to him’ (Dhp. 35),

original: vā ūnaṃ vā na vaṭṭati iccādi.
analyzed: vā ūnam vā na vaṭṭati iti cādi
translated: and less than or more than is not allowable.

original: Viramaṇatthayoge –
analyzed: viramaṇa attha yoge
translated: In the compound in the sense of abstinence:

original: Āratī viratī pāpā khu. pā. 5.8, pāṇātipātā veramaṇi khu. pā. 2.1 iccādi.
analyzed: āratī viratī pāpā khu pā  pāṇātipātā veramaṇi khu pā  iccādi
translated: Abstinence from evil, abstinence, abstinence from killing breathing things, etc.

original: Suddhatthayoge –
analyzed: suddhattha yoge
translated: In the compound in the sense of purity:

original: Lobhanīyehi dhammehi suddho iccādi.
analyzed: lobhanīyehi dhammehi suddhaḥ iccādi
translated: Pure in respect of things that cause corruption, etc.

original: Mocanatthayoge pañcamī tatiyā ca, so parimuccati jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi🔽dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi, parimutto so dukkhasmāti vadāmi saṃ. ni. 3.29, mokkhanti
analyzed: mocana attha yoge pañcamī tatiyā ca so parimuccati jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi  dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi parimuttaḥ saḥ dukkhasma ati vadāmi sam ni mokkhanti
