translated: In the compound in the sense of release, the fifth and third are used: He is released from birth, from ageing, from death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief, and despair,

original: mārabandhanā dha. pa. 37, na te muccanti maccunā iccādi, sabbattha avadhiattho veditabbo.
analyzed: māra bandhanā dha pa na te muccanti maccunā iccādi sabbattha avadhi atthaḥ veditabbo
translated: He is released from suffering, I say, he is released from suffering, thus it is said, they are released from Mara’s bonds, they are not released from death, etc.; the meaning of limit is to be understood in all these cases.

original: Hetvatthe –
analyzed: hetu atthe
translated: In the compound in the sense of cause:

original: Kasmā hetunā, kena hetunā, kasmā nu tumhaṃ kule daharā na miyyare jā. 1.10.92 (mīyare),
analyzed: kasmai hetunā kena hetunā kasmai nu tumham kule daharāḥ na miyyare jā
translated: Why, by what cause, why is it that in your families the young do not die, why is it that they die,🔽Therefore, bhikkhus, thus … The second, third, and sixth are used: for what reason, why is it that …?

original: tasmātiha bhikkhave saṃ. ni. 2.157. Dutiyā tatiyā chaṭṭhī ca, kiṃkāraṇaṃ jā. aṭṭha.
analyzed: tasmā ati ha bhikkhave sam ni dutiyā tatiyā chaṭṭhī ca kiṃkāraṇam aṭṭha
translated: The story of the Um-anga animal, for which reason, for what reason,

original: 6.22.umaṅgajātakavaṇṇanā, yatvādhikaraṇaṃ dī. ni. 1.213, yatonidānaṃ su. ni. 275,
analyzed: yatvā adhikaraṇam dī ni yatas nidānam su ni
translated: from which cause, from which source, from which reason, from which cause, from which source, from which reason, from which cause, from which source, from which reason, from which cause, from which source, from which reason, from which cause, from which source, from which reason, from which cause, from which source, from which reason, from which cause, from which source, from which reason, from which cause, from which source, from which reason, from which cause, from which source, from which reason, from which cause, from which source, from which reason, from which cause, from which source, from which reason, from which cause, from which source, from which reason, from which cause, from which source, from which reason, from which cause, from which source, from which reason, from which cause, from which source, from which reason, from which cause, from which source, from which reason, from which cause, from which source, from which reason, from which cause, from which source, from which reason, from which cause, from which source, from which reason, from which cause, from which source, from which reason, from which cause, from which source, from which reason, from which cause, from which source, from which reason, from which cause, from which source, from which

original: tatonidānaṃ ma. ni. 1.238, kena kāraṇena jā. aṭṭha. 4.20.mātaṅgajātakavaṇṇanā, taṃ
analyzed: tatonidānam ma ni kena kāraṇena jā aṭṭha tam
translated: and on that account, Ma. Ni. 1.238, for what reason, Jā. Aṭṭha. 4.20. The explanation of the Mātaṅga Birth Story, that …

original: kissahetu ma. ni. 1.2, kissa tumhe kilamatha iccādi.
analyzed: kissahetu ma ni kissa tumhe kilamathaḥ it ca ādi
translated: for what reason, Ma. Ni. …, for what reason do you weary yourselves? and so on.

original: Vivecanatthayoge –
analyzed: vivecana ttha yoge
translated: In the case of the compound for the purpose of discrimination:

original: Vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi dī. ni. 1.226, vivitto pāpakā dhammā.
analyzed: vivicca iva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi vivittaḥ pāpakā dhammā
translated: Quite secluded from sense desires, secluded from unprofitable things, Dī. Ni. … , secluded from bad things.

original: Bandhanatthayoge –
analyzed: bandhana ttha yoge
translated: In the case of the compound for the purpose of bondage:

analyzed: pañcamīṇe vā ka rū nī cam pā
translated: Either in the fifth case or in the instrumental case, Ru. ; Ni. ; Caṃ. …; Pā. …

original: Iṇabhūte hetumhi pañcamī hoti vā.
analyzed: iṇ a bhūte hetumhi pañcamī hoti vā
translated: The fifth case or the instrumental case is used when the reason is the debtor.

original: Satasmā bandho naro satena vā.
analyzed: satasmai bandho naraḥ satena vā
translated: A man is bound by a debt, or by a debt.

analyzed: guṇe cam pā
translated: And in the case of a quality, Caṃ. …; Pā. …

original: Ajjhattabhūto hetu guṇo nāma, aguṇopi idha guṇotveva vuccati, tasmiṃ pañcamī hoti vā.🔽Jaḷattā bandho naro jaḷattena vā, attano bālattāyeva bandhoti attho, paññāya bandhanā
analyzed: ajjhatta bhūtaḥ hetu guṇo nāma aguṇaḥ api vuccati tasmin pañcamī hoti vā  jaḷattā bandhaḥ naraḥ jaḷattena vā attanaḥ bāla ttāya iva bandho ti attho paññāya bandhanā
translated: An internal reason is called a quality, and a non-quality is also called a quality here, the fifth case is used in that.

original: mutto, vācāya marati, vācāya muccati, vācāya piyo hoti, vācāya desso, issariyā janaṃ
analyzed: muttaḥ vācāya marati vācāya muccati vācāya piyaḥ hoti vācāya dessaḥ issariyā janam
translated: A man is bound by dullness, or by dullness. The meaning is that he is bound by his own foolishness. He is released by wisdom, he dies by speech, he is released by speech, he is dear by speech, he is easy to talk to by speech, he is released by sovereignty, people are released by sovereignty.

original: rakkhati rājā issariyena vā, sīlato naṃ pasaṃsanti a. ni. 4.6 sīlena vā, hutvā abhāvato
analyzed: rakkhati rājā issariyena vā sīlataḥ nam pasaṃsanti a ni sīlena vā hutvā abhāvato
translated: The king protects him by his royal power, or they praise him for his virtue, or he is not,

original: aniccā, udayabbayapīḷanato dukkhā, avijjānirodhā saṅkhāranirodho udā. 2, saṅkhāranirodhā
analyzed: aniccāḥ udaya bbaya pīḷanataḥ dukkhāḥ avijjā nirodhā saṅkhāra nirodho saṅkhāra nirodhā
translated: being impermanent, suffering through the oppression of rise and subsidence, through the cessation of ignorance there is the cessation of formations, through the cessation of formations,🔽through the cessation of consciousness there is the cessation of name-and-form, through the cessation of name-and-form there is the cessation of the six sense bases, through the cessation of the six sense bases there is the cessation of contact, through the cessation of contact there is the cessation of feeling, through the cessation of feeling there is the cessation of craving, through the cessation of craving there is the cessation of clinging, through the cessation of clinging there is the cessation of becoming, through the cessation of becoming there is the cessation of birth, through the cessation of birth there is the cessation of ageing-and-death, of sorrow and lamentation, pain, grief and despair. Such is the cessation of this whole mass of suffering.🔽Through the non-understanding, the non-penetrating, of the Four Noble Truths, they wander about in this long course,

original: viññāṇanirodho udā. 2, catunnaṃ ariyasaccānaṃ anaññā appaṭivedhā dīghamaddhānaṃ saṃsaranti🔽dī. ni. 2.186 (visadisaṃ) iccādi.
analyzed: viññāṇa nirodho udā catunnam ariya saccānam anaññāḥ appaṭivedhāḥ dīgham addhānam saṃsaranti  dī ni visadisam i t ca ādi
translated: in this far-extended round, for a long time.

original: Pañhā, kathanesupi pañcamī, kuto bhavaṃ, ahaṃ pāṭaliputtato iccādi.
analyzed: pañhā kathanesu pi pañcamī kutas bhavam aham pāṭaliputtataḥ iccādi
translated: The fifth case is also used in questions and in such expressions as ‘From where do you come? I come from Pāṭaliputta’.

original: Thokatthepi asatvavacane pañcamī, satvaṃ vuccati dabbaṃ, thokā muccati thokena vā,
analyzed: thoka atthe pi a sattva vacane pañcamī satvam vuccati dabbam thokā muccati thokena vā
translated: The fifth case is also used in the expression of a small amount when there is no word for ‘little’, for ‘little’ is said to mean ‘a small amount’. He is released by a little, or he is released with a little,

original: muccanamattaṃ hotīti vuttaṃ hoti “nadiṃ taranto manaṃ vuḷho”ti mahāva. 148 ettha
analyzed: muccana mattam hoti iti vuttam hoti nadim tarantaḥ manam ettha
translated: it is said. ‘When they were crossing the river they lost their senses’ .

original: viya. Appamattakā muccati appamattakena vā, kicchā muccati kicchena vā, kicchā laddho
analyzed: viya appamattakā muccati appamattakena vā kicchā muccati kicchena vā kicchā laddho
translated: Here it is as if he is released by a small amount, or he is released with a small amount. He is released with difficulty, or he is released with a little difficulty. A dear son is obtained with difficulty,

original: piyo putto jā. 2.22.353, kicchā muttā’mha dukkhasmā, yāma dāni mahosadha jā. 2.22.700.
analyzed: piyaḥ puttaḥ jā  kicchā muttāmha dukkhasmā yāma dāni mahosadha jā
translated: ‘We are released from suffering, now we shall go, Great Sage’ .

original: Asatvavacaneti kiṃ? Paccati munino bhattaṃ, thokaṃ thokaṃ ghare ghareti theragā. 248 (kule kule).
analyzed: asattva vacanā iti kim munino bhattam thokam thokam ghare ghareti theragāḥ kule kule
translated: What if it is not a living being? The Elder’s verse: “The sage’s meal is cooked, a little in each house” .

original: “Anupubbena medhāvī, thokaṃ thokaṃ khaṇe khaṇe dha. pa. 239” iccādīsu kriyāvisesane dutiyā.
analyzed: anupubbena medhāvī thokam thokam khaṇe khaṇe dha pa iccādīsu kriyā visesane dutiyā
translated: The verse: “The wise man by degrees, a little at a time, moment after moment” .

original: Akattaripi pañcamī, tassa kammassa katattā upacitattā ussannattā vipulattā tathāgato
analyzed: pañcamī tassa kammassa kata ttā upacita ttā ussanna ttā vipula ttā tathāgataḥ
translated: The fifth case is used even when there is no doer, as in “Because of the deed’s being done, accumulated, stored up, and extended, the Tathāgata …

original: suppatiṭṭhitapādo hoti dī. ni. 3.201. Ettha ca ‘akattarī’ti akārake ñāpakahetumhīti
analyzed: su patiṭṭhita pādaḥ hoti dī ni ettha ca a kattari iti a kārake ñāpaka hetumhi iti
translated: has well-planted feet” . And here they say that “no doer” is a reason that is a declarer of what is not the cause.

original: vadanti. Ñāse pana “akattarīti hetvatthe saṅgaṇhāti. Yattha hi kattubuddhi sañjāyate,🔽sova kattā na hotīti vattuṃ sakkā”ti vuttaṃ. Etena kattusadiso janakahetu akattā
analyzed: vadanti ñāse pana a kattari iti hetvatthe saṅgaṇhāti yattha hi kattu buddhi sañjāyate  saḥ uva kattā na hoti iti vattum sakkā iti vuttam etena kattu sadisaḥ janaka hetu a kattā
translated: But in the Ñāsa it is said: “The word ‘no doer’ includes the meaning of cause. For it is only where the notion of doer arises that it is possible to say ‘he is not the doer’” .

original: nāmāti dīpeti, kammassa katattāiccādi ca janakahetu evāti.
analyzed: nāma ati dīpeti kammassa ca janaka hetu eva ati
translated: By this it is shown that the cause that is the producer is called “no doer” because it is similar to a doer. And “because of the deed’s being done” and so on are also only the producer.

original: Bhiyyatthayoge –
analyzed: bhiyyattha yoge
translated: In the sense of superiority:🔽“He who does not think himself superior to cold and heat and grass” .

original: Yodha sītañca uṇhañca, tiṇā bhiyyo na maññati dī. ni. 3.253, sukhā bhiyyo somanassaṃ
analyzed: yodha sītañca uṇhañca tiṇā bhiyyas na maññati dī ni sukhā bhiyyas somanassaṃ
translated: Superior to pleasure is joy.

original: dī. ni. 2.287, khantyā bhiyyo na vijjati saṃ. ni. 1.250, mayā bhiyyo na vijjati,
analyzed: dī ni khantyā bhiyyas na vijjati sam ni mayā bhiyyas na vijjati
translated: There is none higher than me.

original: sotukāmāttha tumhe bhikkhave bhiyyosomattāya pubbenivāsakathaṃ, attamano tvaṃ hohi
analyzed: sotu kāmā attha tumhe bhikkhave bhiyyosoma ttāya pubbenivāsa katham atta mano tvam hohi
translated: If you bhikkhus desire to hear more about the past, be pleased🔽as much as you like.

original: paraṃ viya mattāya, ahampi attamano homi paraṃ viya mattāya.
analyzed: param viya mattāya aham pi atta manaḥ homi param viya mattāya
translated: I am pleased as much as you like.

original: Pañcamīvibhattirāsi niṭṭhito.
analyzed: niṭṭhitaḥ
translated: The group of the fifth case endings is finished.

original: Chaṭṭhīvibhattirāsi
analyzed: chaṭṭhī vibhattiḥ ā asi
translated: The group of the sixth case endings

original: Kasmiṃ atthe chaṭṭhī?
analyzed: kasmin atthe chaṭṭhī
translated: In what meaning is the sixth case?

original: 320. Chaṭṭhī sambandhe ka. 301; rū. 315; nī. 609; caṃ. 2.1.95; pā. 2.3.50.
analyzed: chaṭṭhī sambandhe ka rū nī caṃ pā
translated: The sixth is in the sense of connection: rū. ; nī. ; caṃ. ..; pā. ...

original: Dvinnaṃ sambandhīnaṃ kenaci pakārena āyattabhāvo sambandho nāma, sambandhe jotetabbe visesanasambandhimhi chaṭṭhī hoti.
analyzed: dvinnam sambandhīnam kenacid pakārena āyatta bhāvaḥ sambandhaḥ nāma sambandhe jotetabbe visesana sambandhimhi chaṭṭhī hoti
translated: The connection of the two connected is the state of being extended in some way, called “connection”. The sixth case is used when connection is to be expressed in the connected thing that is the distinguishing.

original: Tattha kriyākārakasañjāto assedambhāvahetuko sambandho nāmāti vuttaṃ. Tattha dve
analyzed: tattha kriyā kāraka sañjātaḥ assa idambhāva hetukaḥ sambandhaḥ nāma ati vuttam tattha dve
translated: Herein, it is said that the connection called “the state of being extended” arises from the state of being a means of action. Herein, the two

original: sambandhino aññamaññaṃ taṃtaṃkriyaṃ karonti, taṃ disvā “ime aññamaññasambandhino”ti
analyzed: sambandhinaḥ aññam aññam taṃtaṃkriyam karonti tam disvā ime aññam añña sambandhinaḥ iti
translated: connected ones do the respective action of each other, and seeing that, “These are connected with each other”

original: jānantassa dvinnaṃ kārakānaṃ dvinnaṃ kriyānañca saṃyogaṃ nissāya sambandhopi vidito
analyzed: jānantassa dvinnam kārakānam dvinnam kriyānam ca saṃyogam nissāya sambandhaḥ api viditaḥ
translated: When he knows, he also knows the relation which is based on the conjunction of the two factors and the two actions.

original: hoti, evaṃ sambandho kriyākārakasañjāto, ‘imassa aya’nti evaṃ pavattabuddhiyā hetubhūtattā
analyzed: hoti evam sambandho kriyā kāraka sañjātaḥ imassa evam pavatta buddhiyā hetu bhūta ttā
translated: Thus the relation is born of the action and the factor, and it is the cause of the idea which occurs in the form ‘This is of that’

original: assedambhāvahetuko ca.
analyzed: ca
translated: and it is the cause of the absence of doubt.

original: Tattha sambandho tividho sāmisambandho, nānāttasambandho, kriyākārakasambandhoti.
analyzed: tattha sambandho tividhaḥ sāmi sambandhaḥ nānā ātta sambandho kriyā kāraka sambandho ti
translated: Herein, the relation is of three kinds: the relation of ownership, the relation of difference, and the relation of action and factor.

original: Tattha ‘sāmī’ti yassa kassaci visesanasambandhino nāmaṃ, tasmā visesyapadatthassa taṃtaṃvisesanabhāvena sambandho sāmisambandho nāma.
analyzed: tattha sāmī iti yassa kassaci visesana sambandhinaḥ nāmam tasmā visesya padatthassa taṃ taṃ visesana bhāvena sambandhaḥ sāmi sambandhaḥ nāma
translated: Herein, ‘ownership’ is the name of any particular thing, and so the relation of the meaning of the word that is the particular thing with the meaning of the word that is the particularizer is called the relation of ownership.

original: So visesyapadatthabhedena anekavidho.
analyzed: saḥ visesya padattha bhedena anekavidhaḥ
translated: That is of many kinds according to the division of the meanings of the words that are the particular things.

original: Tattha tassa mātā, tassa pitāiccādi janakasambandho nāma.🔽Tassā putto, tassā dhītā iccādi jaññasambandho nāma.
analyzed: tattha tassa mātā tassa pitā iccādi janaka sambandhaḥ nāma  tassā putto tassā dhītā iccādi jañña sambandhaḥ nāma
translated: Herein, ‘His mother, his father’ and so on is called the relation of begetter.🔽‘Her son, her daughter’ and so on is called the relation of offspring.

original: Tassa bhātā, tassa bhaginī iccādi kulasambandho nāma.
analyzed: tassa bhātā tassa bhaginī iccādi kula sambandhaḥ nāma
translated: ‘His brother, his sister’ and so on is called the relation of family.

original: Sakko devānamindo saṃ. ni. 1.248 iccādi sāmisambandho nāma.
analyzed: sakkaḥ devānam indo sam ni it cādi sāmi sambandhaḥ nāma
translated: ‘Sakka, lord of the devas, the Thirty-Three’ and so on is called the relation of ownership.

original: Pahūtaṃ me dhanaṃ sakka jā. 1.15.72, bhikkhussa pattacīvaraṃ iccādi saṃsambandho nāma.
analyzed: pahūtam me dhanam sakka jā bhikkhussa pattacīvaram iccādi saṃsambandhaḥ nāma
translated: “The bhikkhu’s bowl and robe,” etc. is called a related compound.

original: Ambavanassa avidūre, nibbānasseva santike dha. pa. 32 iccādi samīpasambandho nāma.
analyzed: ambavanassa avidūre nibbānassa iva santike dha pa iccādi samīpa sambandhaḥ nāma
translated: “Not far from the Mango Grove,” “near to Nibbāna,” etc. is called a proximate compound.

original: Suvaṇṇassa rāsi, bhikkhūnaṃ samūho iccādi samūhasambandho nāma.
analyzed: suvaṇṇassa rāsi bhikkhūnam samūhaḥ iccādi samūha sambandhaḥ nāma
translated: “A heap of gold,” “a multitude of bhikkhus,” etc. is called a collective compound.

original: Manussasseva te sīsaṃ jā. 1.4.81, rukkhassa sākhā iccādi avayavasambandho nāma.🔽Suvaṇṇassa bhājanaṃ, alābussa kaṭāhaṃ, bhaṭṭhadhaññānaṃ sattu iccādi vikārasambandho nāma.
analyzed: manussassa iva te sīsam jā rukkhassa sākhā iccādi avayava sambandhaḥ nāma  suvaṇṇassa bhājanam alābussa kaṭāham bhaṭṭhadhaññānam sattu iccādi vikāra sambandhaḥ nāma
translated: “The head of a man,” “the branch of a tree,” etc. is called a part compound.🔽“A golden vessel,” “a gourd dish,” “flour of roasted paddy,” etc. is called a derivative compound.

original: Yavassa aṅkuro, meghassa saddo, pupphānaṃ gandho, phalānaṃ raso, aggissa dhūmo iccādi kāriyasambandho nāma.
analyzed: yavassa aṅkuraḥ meghassa saddaḥ pupphānam gandhaḥ phalānam rasaḥ aggissa dhūmaḥ iccādi kāriya sambandhaḥ nāma
translated: “The sprout of barley,” “the sound of a cloud,” “the scent of flowers,” “the taste of fruits,” “the smoke of fire,” etc. is called a functional compound.

original: Khandhānaṃ jāti, khandhānaṃ jarā, khandhānaṃ bhedo saṃ. ni. 2.1 iccādi avatthāsambandho nāma.
analyzed: khandhānam jāti khandhānam jarā khandhānam bhedaḥ sam ni iccādi avatthā sambandhaḥ nāma
translated: “The birth of the aggregates,” “the ageing of the aggregates,” “the dissolution of the aggregates,” etc. is called a temporal compound.

original: Suvaṇṇassa vaṇṇo, vaṇṇo na khīyyetha tathāgatassa dī. ni. aṭṭha. 1.304, buddhassa kittisaddo, sippikānaṃ sataṃ natthi jā. 1.1.113, tilānaṃ muṭṭhi iccādi guṇasambandho nāma.
analyzed: suvaṇṇassa vaṇṇaḥ vaṇṇaḥ na tathāgatassa buddhassa kitti saddo sippikānam satam natthi tilānam muṭṭhi iccādi guṇa sambandhaḥ nāma
translated: The compound suvaṇṇassa vaṇṇo, vaṇṇo na khīyyetha tathāgatassa dī. ni. aṭṭha. 1.304, buddhassa kittisaddo, sippikānaṃ sataṃ natthi jā. 1.1.113, tilānaṃ muṭṭhi iccādi is called a compound of quality.

original: Pādassa ukkhipanaṃ, hatthassa samiñjanaṃ, dhātūnaṃ gamanaṃ ṭhānaṃ iccādi kriyāsambandho nāma.
analyzed: pādassa ukkhipanam hatthassa samiñjanam dhātūnam gamanam ṭhānam iccādi kriyā sambandhaḥ nāma
translated: The compound pādassa ukkhipanaṃ, hatthassa samiñjanaṃ, dhātūnaṃ gamanaṃ ṭhānaṃ iccādi is called a compound of action.

original: Cātumahārājikānaṃ ṭhānaṃ iccādi ṭhānasambandho nāma. Evamādinā nayena sāmisambandho🔽anekasahassappabhedo, so ca kriyāsambandhābhāvā kārako nāma na hoti. Yadi evaṃ “pādassa
analyzed: cātumahārājikānam ṭhānam iccādi ṭhāna sambandhaḥ nāma evamādinā nayena sāmi sambandhaḥ  aneka sahassa ppabhedaḥ saḥ ca kriyā sambandha abhāvā kārakaḥ nāma na hoti yadi evam pādassa
translated: The compound cātumahārājikānaṃ ṭhānaṃ iccādi is called a compound of place.

original: ukkhipanaṃ” iccādi kriyāsambandho nāmāti idaṃ na yujjatīti? Vuccate – kriyāsambandhābhāvāti🔽idaṃ sādhakabhāvena sambandhābhāvaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ, siddhāya pana kriyāya sambandhaṃ
analyzed: ukkhipanam iccādi kriyā sambandhaḥ nāma ati idam na yujjati iti vuccate kriyā sambandha abhāvāt  idam sādhaka bhāvena sambandha abhāvam sandhāya vuttam siddhāya pana kriyāya sambandham
translated: In this way, the compound of possession has many thousands of divisions. And it is not called a noun because it lacks a compound of action. If that is so, then it is not correct to say that the compound pādassa ukkhipanaṃ iccādi is called a compound of action.

original: sandhāya kriyāsambandho nāma vuttoti.
analyzed: sandhāya kriyā sambandhaḥ nāma vuttaḥ ti
translated: It is said: the absence of a compound of action is said🔽with reference to the absence of a compound that is a means of accomplishing something. But the compound of action is said🔽with reference to a compound that is a means of accomplishing something that has already been accomplished.

original: Nānāttasambandhe pana nānāatthesu chaṭṭhī hoti. Tattha ṇī, āvīpaccayānaṃ kamme niccaṃ
analyzed: nānā ātta sambandhe pana nānā atthesu chaṭṭhī hoti tattha ṇī āvi paccayānam kamme niccam
translated: Herein, the locative is invariable in the case of the following: ṇī, āvīpaccayānaṃ kamme niccaṃ

original: chaṭṭhī, jhānassa lābhī, cīvarassa lābhī, dhanassa lābhī, ādīnavassa dassāvī, atthi
analyzed: chaṭṭhī jhānassa lābhī cīvarassa lābhī dhanassa lābhī ādīnavassa dassāvī atthi
translated: chaṭṭhī, jhānassa lābhī, cīvarassa lābhī, dhanassa lābhī, ādīnavassa dassāvī, atthi

original: rūpānaṃ dassāvī, atthi samavisamassa dassāvī, atthi tārakarūpānaṃ dassāvī, atthi
analyzed: rūpānam dassāvī atthi sama visamassa dassāvī atthi tāraka rūpānam dassāvī atthi
translated: rūpānaṃ dassāvī, atthi samavisamassa dassāvī, atthi tārakarūpānaṃ dassāvī, atthi

original: candimasūriyānaṃ dassāvī.
analyzed: candima sūriyānam dassāvī
translated: candimasūriyānaṃ dassāvī.

original: Tu, aka, ana, ṇapaccayānaṃ yoge kvaci kammatthe chaṭṭhī.
analyzed: tu aka ana ṇa paccayānam yoge kvaci kammatthe chaṭṭhī
translated: Tu, aka, ana, ṇapaccayānaṃ yoge kvaci kammatthe chaṭṭhī.

original: Tupaccaye tāva –
analyzed: tupa c caye tāva
translated: In the case of the locative with the condition tu,

original: Tassa bhavanti vattāro ma. ni. 2.173, sahasā kammassa kattāro, amatassa dātā ma. ni. 1.203, bhinnānaṃ sandhātā dī. ni. 1.9, 164, sahitānaṃ vā anuppadātā dī. ni. 1.9, 164 iccādi.
analyzed: tassa bhavanti vattāraḥ ma ni sahasā kammassa kattāraḥ amatassa dātāraḥ ma ni bhinnānam sandhātā
translated: for example: Tassa bhavanti vattāro ma. ni. ., sahasā kammassa kattāro, amatassa dātā ma. ni. ., bhinnānaṃ sandhātā dī. ni. ., , sahitānaṃ vā anuppadātā dī. ni. .,  iccādi.

original: Kvacīti kiṃ? Gambhīrañca kathaṃ kattā a. ni. 7.37, gādhaṃ kattā novasitā a. ni. 4.107,
analyzed: kvaci iti kim gambhīram ca katham kattā a ni gādham kattā novasitā a ni
translated: Kvacīti kiṃ? Gambhīrañca kathaṃ kattā a. ni. ., gādhaṃ kattā novasitā a. ni. .,

original: kālena dhammīkathaṃ bhāsitā, sarasi tvaṃ evarūpaṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā, paresaṃ puññaṃ anumodetā,
analyzed: kālena dhammīkatham bhāsitā sarasi tvam evarūpam vācam bhāsitā paresam puññam anumodetā
translated: kālena dhammīkathaṃ bhāsitā, sarasi tvaṃ evarūpaṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā, paresaṃ puññaṃ anumodetā,

original: bujjhitā saccāni mahāni. 192 iccādi.
analyzed: bujjhitā saccāni mahāni iccādi
translated: The great Truths have been awakened to by me.

original: Akapaccaye –
analyzed: aka pad caye
translated: In the non-cause-sign

original: Kammassa kārako natthi, vipākassa ca vedako visuddhi 2.689, avisaṃvādako lokassa dī. ni. 1.9 iccādi.
analyzed: kammassa kārakaḥ natthi vipākassa ca vedakaḥ a visaṃvādakaḥ lokassa iccādi
translated: There is no doer of kamma, nor any experiencer of its result, Purification, Non-deception of the world, Dī. ni. , etc.

original: Kvacīti kiṃ? Mahatiṃ mahiṃ anusāsako, janaṃ aheṭhako, kaṭaṃ kārako, pasavo ghātako iccādi.
analyzed: kvaci iti kim mahatim mahim anusāsakaḥ janam a heṭhakaḥ kaṭam kārakaḥ pasavaḥ ghātakaḥ iti ca ādi
translated: In some cases what? The instructor of the great earth, the non-harmer of the people, the doer of the work, the killer of the animal, etc.

original: Anapaccaye –
analyzed: an apaccaye
translated: In the non-non-cause-sign

original: Pāpassa akaraṇaṃ sukhaṃ dha. pa. 61, bhārassa ukkhipanaṃ, hatthassa gahaṇaṃ, hatthassa parāmasanaṃ, aññatarassa aṅgassa parāmasanaṃ pārā. 270 iccādi.
analyzed: pāpassa akaraṇam sukham bhārassa ukkhipanam hatthassa gahaṇam hatthassa parāmasanam aññatarassa aṅgassa parāmasanam pārā iccādi
translated: The non-doing of evil is happiness, Dhp. 1, the lifting of a burden, the taking of a hand, the touching of a hand, the touching of a certain limb, Pārā. , etc.

original: Kvacīti kiṃ? Bhagavantaṃ dassanāya udā. 23 iccādi.
analyzed: kvaci iti kim bhagavantam dassanāya iccādi
translated: In some cases what? The going forth to see the Blessed One, UdA. , etc.

original: Ṇapaccaye –
analyzed: ṇa pat caye
translated: In the cause-sign

original: Acchariyo arajakena vatthānaṃ rāgo, agopālakena gāvīnaṃ doho, appapuññena lābhānaṃ lābho, hatthassa gāho, pattassa paṭiggāho iccādi.
analyzed: acchariyaḥ a rajakena vatthānam rāgaḥ a gopālakena gāvīnam dohaḥ appa puññena lābhānam lābhaḥ hatthassa gāho pattassa paṭiggāhaḥ iccādi
translated: The dyeing of cloths without a king is wonderful, the milking of cows without a cowherd, the gain of gains without merit, the taking of a hand, the receiving of an alms-bowl, etc.

original: Tvāpaccayepi kvaci kammani chaṭṭhī, alajjīnaṃ nissāya, āyasmato nissāya vacchāmi, catunnaṃ mahābhūtānaṃ upādāya pasādo dha. sa. 596-599 (upādāya) iccādi.🔽Kattari ta, tavantu, tāvī, māna’ntānaṃ yoge pana kammani dutiyā eva, sukhakāmo vihāraṃ kato, gāmaṃ gato, odanaṃ bhuttavā bhuttāvī, kammaṃ kurumāno, kammaṃ karonto iccādi.🔽Kvaci chaṭṭhīpi dissati, dhammassa gutto medhāvī dha. pa. 257 iccādi.
analyzed: tvā paccaye pi kvaci kammani chaṭṭhī alajjīnam nissāya āyasmataḥ nissāya vacchāmi catunnam mahābhūtānam upādāya pasādaḥ saḥ upādāya iccādi  kattari yoge pana kammani dutiyāḥ eva sukha kāmaḥ vihāram kataḥ gāmam gataḥ odanam bhuttavā bhuttāvī kammam kurumāno kammam karontaḥ iccādi  kvaci chaṭṭhī pi dissati dhammassa guttaḥ medhāvī dha pa iccādi
translated: In some verbal roots, the Genitive is used even when the object is not the cause: “Having taken refuge in the shameless ones”, “Having taken refuge in the venerable one”, “Having taken refuge in the four great entities”, “Having taken refuge in the five aggregates”, “Having taken refuge in the six sense-bases”, “Having taken refuge in the seven factors of Awakening”, “Having taken refuge in the eightfold noble path”, “Having taken refuge in the nine successive abidings”, “Having taken refuge in the ten wholesome courses of action”.

original: Sara, isu, cinta, isa, dayadhātūnaṃ kammani chaṭṭhī vā, mātussa sarati, mātaraṃ sarati,🔽pitussa sarati, pitaraṃ sarati, na rajjassa sarissasi jā. 2.22.1721, na tesaṃ koci
analyzed: saraḥ isu cintaḥ isa daya dhātūnam kammani chaṭṭhī vā mātuḥ sarati mātaram sarati  pitussa sarati pitaram sarati na rajjassa sarissasi jā na tesam koci
translated: In the verbal roots of the class of “to honour”, the Instrumental is used: “Having honoured the mother”, “Having honoured the father”, “Having honoured the Teacher”, “Having honoured the Elders”, “Having honoured the Community of monks”.🔽In the verbal roots of the class of “to know”, the Ablative is used: “Having known the mother”, “Having known the father”, “Having known the Teacher”, “Having known the Elders”, “Having known the Community of monks”.🔽In the verbal roots of the class of “to see”, the Locative is used: “Having seen the mother”, “Having seen the father”, “Having seen the Teacher”, “Having seen the Elders”, “Having seen the Community of monks”.

original: sarati, sattānaṃ kammapaccayā khu. pā. 7.2, āpattipariyantaṃ nassarati, rattipariyantaṃ
analyzed: sarati sattānam kamma paccayā āpatti pariyantam na ssarati ratti pariyantam
translated: In the verbal roots of the class of “to hear”, the Genitive is used: “Having heard the mother”, “Having heard the father”, “Having heard the Teacher”, “Having heard the Elders”, “Having heard the Community of monks”.🔽In the verbal roots of the class of “to remember”, the Genitive is used: “Remembering the mother”, “Remembering the father”, “Remembering the Teacher”, “Remembering the Elders”, “Remembering the Community of monks”.

original: nassarati cūḷava. 157, puttassa icchati puttaṃ vā, mātussa cinteti mātaraṃ vā, therassa
analyzed: puttassa icchati puttam vā mātussa cinteti mātaram vā therassa
translated: He wishes for a son, and he thinks of his mother. He invites an elder,

original: ajjhesati theraṃ vā, telassa dayati telaṃ vā, rakkhatīti attho.
analyzed: ajjhesati theram vā telassa dayati telam vā rakkhati iti attho
translated: and he gives oil. The meaning is: he protects.

original: Karadhātussa abhisaṅkharaṇatthavācino kamme chaṭṭhī, udakassa paṭikurute udakaṃ vā, kaṇḍassa paṭikurute kaṇḍaṃ vā iccādi.🔽Tapaccaye pūjanatthādidhātūnaṃ kattari chaṭṭhī vā, rañño sammato raññā vā, gāmassa
analyzed: kara dhātussa abhisaṅkharaṇa attha vācino kamme chaṭṭhī udakassa paṭikurute udakam vā kaṇḍassa paṭikurute kaṇḍam vā iccādi  ta paccaye pūjana ttha ādi dhātūnam kattari chaṭṭhī vā raññaḥ sammataḥ raññā vā gāmassa
translated: In the sense of the state of being made, the sixth case is used with the root dhā, which has the meaning of “making,” as in: He makes ready water, or he makes ready a paste.

original: pūjito gāmena vā, rañño sakkato raññā vā, rañño apacito raññā vā, rañño mānito dī.
analyzed: pūjitaḥ gāmena vā rañño sakkataḥ raññā vā rañño apacitaḥ raññā vā rañño mānitaḥ
translated: In the sense of worshipping, etc., the sixth case is used with the roots that have the meaning of worshipping, etc., and with the noun tappa, as in: He is approved by the king, or by the people. He is worshipped by the king, or by the people. He is honoured by the king, or by the people. He is respected by the king, or by the people. He is revered by the king, or by the people.

original: ni. 1.303 raññā vā, tathā suppaṭividdhā buddhānaṃ dhammadhātu, amataṃ tesaṃ paribhuttaṃ,🔽yesaṃ kāyagatāsati paribhuttā a. ni. 1.603, amataṃ tesaṃ viraddhaṃ, yesaṃ kāyagatāsati
analyzed: ni raññā vā tathā su paṭividdhā buddhānam dhammadhātu amatam tesam paribhuttam  yesam kāyagatā asati paribhuttā a ni amatam tesam viraddham yesam kāyagatā asati
translated: Likewise, the Dhamma-element of the Buddhas is well penetrated. The Deathless is enjoyed by them.🔽The Deathless has been lost by those who have not enjoyed mindfulness occupied with the body.

original: viraddhā a. ni. 1.603.
analyzed: viraddhā a ni
translated: The Deathless has been lost by those who have not enjoyed mindfulness occupied with the body.

original: Tipaccayepi kvaci kattari chaṭṭhī vā, sobhaṇā kaccāyanassa pakati kaccāyanena vā, sobhaṇā buddhaghosassa pakati buddhaghosena vā iccādi.
analyzed: ti paccaye pi kvaci kattari chaṭṭhī vā sobhaṇā kaccāyanassa pakati kaccāyanena vā sobhaṇā buddhaghosassa pakati buddhaghosena vā iccādi
translated: In the third construction, the locative is sometimes used with the agent, as in Sobhaṇā kaccāyanassa pakati, Sobhaṇā kaccāyanena vā, Sobhaṇā buddhaghosassa pakati, Sobhaṇā buddhaghosena vā.

original: Pūjanatthānaṃ pūraṇatthānañca karaṇe chaṭṭhī, pupphassa buddhaṃ pūjeti pupphena vā,
analyzed: pūjana thānam pūraṇa tthānam ca karaṇe chaṭṭhī pupphassa buddham pūjā iti pupphena vā
translated: In the sixth construction, the locative is used with the object of the verb of offering, as in Pupphassa buddhaṃ pūjeti, Pupphena vā,

original: ghatassa aggiṃ juhoti ghatena vā, pattaṃ udakassa pūretvā, pūraṃ nānāppakārassa asucino
analyzed: aggim juhoti ghatena vā pattam udakassa pūretvā pūram nānā appakārassa asucino
translated: Ghatassa aggiṃ juhoti, Ghatena vā, Pattaṃ udakassa pūretvā, Pūraṃ nānāppakārassa asucino

original: dī. ni. 2.377, bālo pūrati pāpassa dha. pa. 121, dhīro pūrati puññassa dha. pa. 121
analyzed: dī ni bālaḥ pūrati pāpassa dha pa  dhīro pūrati puññassa dha pa
translated: Dī. ni. . (visadisaṃ), Bālo pūrati pāpassa dha. pa. , Dhīro pūrati puññassa dha. pa.

original: pūrati dhaññānaṃ vā muggānaṃ vā māsānaṃ vā iccādi. Tatiyā vā, khemā nāma pokkharaṇī,
analyzed: pūrati dhaññānam vā muggānam vā māsānam vā iccādi tatiyā vā khemā nāma pokkharaṇī
translated: Pūrati dhaññānaṃ vā muggānaṃ vā māsānaṃ vā. In the third construction, the locative is used with the object of the verb of filling, as in Khemā nāma pokkharaṇī,

original: puṇṇā haṃsehi tiṭṭhati.
analyzed: puṇṇā haṃsehi tiṭṭhati
translated: Puṇṇā haṃsehi tiṭṭhati.

original: Tabba, rujādiyoge pana sampadāne catutthī eva, yakkhasenāpatīnaṃ ujjhāpetabbaṃ vikkanditabbaṃ
analyzed: rujā ādi yoge pana sampadāne catutthī eva yakkha senāpatīnam ujjhāpetabbam vikkanditabbam
translated: In the fourth construction, the locative is used with the object of the verb of causing pain, as in Yakkhasenāpatīnaṃ ujjhāpetabbaṃ vikkanditabbaṃ

original: viravitabbaṃ dī. ni. 3.283 (visadisaṃ), devadattassa rujjati, rajakassa vatthaṃ dadāti iccādi.
analyzed: viravitabbam dī ni visadisam devadattassa rujjati rajakassa vattham dadāti iccādi
translated: Viravitabbaṃ dī. ni. . (visadisaṃ), Devadattassa rujjati, Rajakassa vatthaṃ dadāti.

original: Bhayatthādīnaṃ apādāne bahulaṃ chaṭṭhī, kiṃ nu kho ahaṃ tassa sukhassa bhāyāmi, sabbe
analyzed: bhaya ttha ādīnam apādāne bahulam chaṭṭhī kim nu kho aham tassa sukhassa bhāyāmi sabbe
translated: In the sense of “fear of”, the locative is used in the sense of “fear of” in the following: “What should I fear of that happiness?🔽All are afraid of the rod, all fear death” (Dhp 103).

original: tasanti daṇḍassa, sabbe bhāyanti maccuno dha. pa. 129, bhīto catunnaṃ āsīvisānaṃ
analyzed: tasanti daṇḍassa sabbe bhāyanti maccunaḥ dha pa  / catunnam āsīvisānam
translated: “Fearing the four snakes” (S V 101).🔽“Do not fear merit, bhikkhus” (A I 189).

original: saṃ. ni. 4.238, mā bhikkhave puññānaṃ bhāyittha udā. 22, saṅkhātuṃ nopi sakkomi,
analyzed: sam ni mā bhikkhave puññānam bhāyittha udā saṅkhātum na upi sakkomi
translated: “I cannot even calculate” (Dhp 101).

original: musāvādassa ottapaṃ saṃ. ni. 1.184 iccādi. Tattha ‘ottapa’nti ottappanto. Tathā aggohamasmi
analyzed: musāvādassa ottapam sam ni iti ādi tattha ottapanti ottappantaḥ tathā aggo ham asmi
translated: “The height of lying” (S V 101). Herein, “height” is one who is abashed.

original: lokassa, jeṭṭhohamasmi lokassa ma. ni. 3.207 iccādi ca.
analyzed: lokassa jeṭṭhaḥ ham asmi lokassa ma ni i ca ādi ca
translated: “I am the foremost in the world, I am the chief in the world” (S V 101).

original: Kusala, kovida, pasādatthānaṃ ādhāre chaṭṭhī, kusalā naccagītassa jā. 2.22.94, kusalo
analyzed: ādhāre chaṭṭhī kusalā nacca gītassa jā kusalaḥ
translated: In the sense of “basis of”, the locative is used in the sense of “basis of” in the following: “Skilled in song and dance” (S V 101).

original: tvaṃ rathassa aṅgapaccaṅgānaṃ ma. ni. 2.87, amacce tāta jānāhi, dhīre atthassa kovide
analyzed: tvam rathassa aṅga paccaṅgānam ma ni amacce tāta jānāhi dhīre atthassa kovide
translated: “You are skilled in the parts and subdivisions of a chariot” (S V 101).🔽“Know, dear sir, the ministers, the wise, the skilled in the meaning” (S V 101).🔽“The men skilled in the Dhamma” (S V 101).

original: jā. 1.17.13, narā dhammassa kovidā jā. 1.1.37, maggāmaggassa kovidā, “keci iddhīsu
analyzed: narā dhammassa kovidā jā magga amaggassa kovidā keci iddhīsu
translated: “Skilled in the path and not in the path” (S V 101). “Some are skilled in supernormal power

original: kovidā”tipi atthi, santi yakkhā buddhassa pasannā dī. ni. 3.276 (visadisaṃ), dhammassa
analyzed: atthi santi yakkhā buddhassa pasannāḥ visadisam dhammassa
translated: There are spirits who are faithful to the Buddha, faithful to the Dhamma, faithful to the Sangha, faithful to the Buddha, faithful to the Dhamma, faithful to the Sangha.

original: pasannā, saṅghassa pasannā, buddhe pasannā, dhamme pasannā, saṅghe pasannā vā. Tathā
analyzed: pasannā saṅghassa pasannā buddhe pasannā dhamme pasannā saṅghe pasannā vā tathā
translated: Thus

original: cetopariyañāṇassa, vasī homi mahāmuni. Jhānassa vasimhi iccādi.
analyzed: cetaḥ pariya ñāṇassa vasī homi mahāmuni jhānassa vasimhi iccādi
translated: I am a great sage who has mastery over the knowledge of others' minds. I have mastery over jhāna, etc.

original: 321. Chaṭṭhī hetvatthehi rū. 163 piṭṭhe; nī. 650; caṃ. 2.1.71; pā. 2.3.26.
analyzed: chaṭṭhī hetu atthehi rū piṭṭhe nī caṃ pā
translated: . The sixth case is also used with reasons, on the back, in the beginning, at the end, in the middle, in the front, in the rear, in the east, in the south, in the west, in the north, in the northeast, in the southeast, in the southwest, in the northwest, above, below, in the sky, in the world, in the world system, in the world systems, in the world with its gods, its Māras, and its Brahmās, in this generation with its recluses and brahmins, its devas and men.

original: Hetvatthehi yoge hetumhi chaṭṭhī hoti.🔽Taṃ kissa hetu ma. ni. 1.2; caṃ. 2.1.96; pā. 2.3.72, aṅgavarassa hetu, udarassa hetu, udarassa kāraṇā pārā. 228 iccādi.🔽322. Tulyatthena vā tatiyā nī. 638.🔽Tulyatthena yoge chaṭṭhī hoti tatiyā vā.🔽Tulyo pitu pitarā vā, sadiso pitu pitarā vā. Iti nānāttasambandho.
analyzed: hetu atthehi yoge hetumhi chaṭṭhī hoti  tam kissa hetu caṃ pā aṅgavarassa hetu udarassa hetu udarassa kāraṇā iccādi  tulya tthena vā tatiyā nī  tulya tthena yoge chaṭṭhī hoti tatiyā vā  tulyaḥ pitu pitarā vā sadisaḥ pitu pitarā vā iti nānā ātta sambandhaḥ
translated: In the sense of reason, the sixth case is used with reasons.

original: Kriyākārakasambandho nāma kārakānaṃ kriyāya saha sādhaka, sādhyabhāvena aññamaññāpekkhatā
analyzed: kriyā kāraka sambandhaḥ nāma kārakānam kriyāya saha sādhaka sādhya bhāvena aññamañña apekkha tā
translated: For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For what reason? For

original: avinābhāvitā vuccati, na hi kriyaṃ vinā kārakaṃ nāma sijjhati, na ca kārakaṃ vinā
analyzed: avinābhāvitā vuccati na hi kriyam vinā kārakam nāma sijjhati na ca kārakam vinā
translated: Non-separation is what is meant. For without the action there is no such thing as an agent, and without the agent there is no such thing as an action.

original: kriyā nāma sijjhatīti, sā pana chaṭṭhīvisayo na hotīti.🔽Chaṭṭhīvibhattirāsi niṭṭhito.
analyzed: kriyā nāma sijjhati iti sā pana chaṭṭhī visayaḥ na hoti iti  chaṭṭhī vibhattiḥ āsi niṭṭhitaḥ
translated: But that is not the meaning of the sixth case.🔽The group of sixth case endings is completed.

original: Sattamīvibhattirāsi
analyzed: sattamī vibhattiḥ ā asi
translated: The group of seventh case endings

original: Kasmiṃ atthe sattamī?
analyzed: kasmin atthe sattamī
translated: In what sense is the seventh case?

original: 323. Sattamyādhāre ka. 302; rū. 313; nī. 630; caṃ. 2.1.88; pā. 1.3.45.
analyzed: sattamī ādhāre ka rū nī cam pā
translated: The seventh is in the sense of basis, as in “in the bowl,” “in the cloth,” “in the tree,” “in the house.”

original: Ādhāro, okāso, adhikaraṇanti atthato ekaṃ, ādhāratthe sattamī hoti. Kattukammaṭṭhaṃ kriyaṃ bhuso dhāretīti ādhāro.
analyzed: ādhāraḥ okāsaḥ adhikaraṇanti atthataḥ ekam ādhāra atthe sattamī hoti kattu kammaṭṭham kriyam bhusaḥ dhāreti iti ādhāraḥ
translated: Basis, location, and support are one in meaning. The seventh case is in the sense of basis. A noun that is the basis holds fast to the action that is the thing done or the thing to be done.

original: Kaṭe nisīdati puriso, thāliyaṃ odanaṃ pacati. Tattha kaṭo kattubhūte purise ṭhitaṃ nisīdanakriyaṃ dhāreti, thālī kammabhūte taṇḍule ṭhitaṃ pacanakriyaṃ dhāreti.
analyzed: kaṭe nisīdati purisaḥ thāliyam odanam pacati tattha kaṭaḥ kattu bhūte purise ṭhitam nisīdana kriyam dhāreti thālī kamma bhūte taṇḍule ṭhitam pacana kriyam dhāreti
translated: A man sits in a chair, rice is cooked in a pot. Here the chair holds fast to the action of sitting that is established in the man who is the agent, and the pot holds fast to the action of cooking that is established in the rice that is the object.

original: So catubbidho byāpikādhāro, opasilesikādhāro, sāmīpikādhāro, vesayikādhāroti.
analyzed: so catubbidhaḥ byāpikā ādhāro opasilesikā ādhāro sāmīpikā ādhāro vesayikā ādhāro ti
translated: It is of four kinds as pervading basis, contaminating basis, ownership basis, and containing basis.

original: Tattha yasmiṃ ādheyyavatthu sakale vā ekadese vā byāpetvā tiṭṭhati, so byāpiko. Yathā?
analyzed: tattha yasmin ādheyya vatthu sakale vā eka dese vā byāpetvā tiṭṭhati saḥ byāpikaḥ yathā
translated: Herein, that which is found pervading the whole of the receptacle or part of it is called the pervaded. For example:

original: Tilesu telaṃ tiṭṭhati, ucchūsu raso tiṭṭhati, jalesu khīraṃ tiṭṭhati, dadhimhi sappi tiṭṭhatīti.
analyzed: tilesu telam tiṭṭhati ucchūsu rasaḥ tiṭṭhati jalesu khīram tiṭṭhati dadhimhi sappi tiṭṭhati iti
translated: Oil is found in sesamum, juice in sugar-cane, milk in water, and ghee in curd.

original: Yasmiṃ ādheyyavatthu allīyitvā vā tiṭṭhati, adhiṭṭhitamattaṃ hutvā vā tiṭṭhati, so
analyzed: yasmin ādheyya vatthu allīyitvā vā tiṭṭhati adhiṭṭhita mattam hutvā vā tiṭṭhati so
translated: That which is found in the receptacle after being collected together or after being determined upon is called the🔽adherent. For example:

original: opasilesiko. Yathā? Ukkhaliyaṃ ācāmo tiṭṭhati, ghaṭesu udakaṃ tiṭṭhati, āsane nisīdati
analyzed: opasilesikaḥ yathā ukkhaliyam ācāmaḥ tiṭṭhati ghaṭesu udakam tiṭṭhati āsane nisīdati
translated: Rice is found in a basket, water in a pot, a monk sits on a seat,

original: bhikkhu, pariyaṅke rājā seti.
analyzed: bhikkhu pariyaṅke rājā seti
translated: a king lies on a couch.

original: Yo pana attho ādheyyassa avatthubhūtopi tadāyattavuttidīpanatthaṃ ādhārabhāvena vohariyati,
analyzed: yaḥ pana atthaḥ ādheyyassa avatthu bhūtaḥ api tad āyatta vutti dīpana attham ādhāra bhāvena
translated: But that which is found in a receptacle as a non-receptacle, which is spoken of as a receptacle in order to show that it exists in dependence on that,🔽is called the proximate. For example:

original: so sāmīpiko nāma. Yathā? Gaṅgāyaṃ ghoso tiṭṭhati, sāvatthiyaṃ viharati bhagavāti a. ni. 1.1.
analyzed: so sāmīpikaḥ nāma yathā gaṅgā ayam ghoso tiṭṭhati sāvatthiyam viharati bhagavā ati
translated: The sound is found in the Ganges, the Blessed One is found at Sāvatthī.

original: Yo ca attho attanā vinā ādheyyassa aññatthattaṃ kriyaṃ sampādetuṃ asakkuṇeyyattā
analyzed: yaḥ ca atthaḥ attanā vinā ādheyyassa aññattha ttam kriyam sampādetum a sakkuṇeyya ttā
translated: And that which is found in a receptacle as a non-receptacle, which is incapable of making the receptacle have the state of another because it is incapable of accomplishing an action without itself,🔽is called the contained.

original: ādhārabhāvena vohariyati, yo ca ādheyyassa anaññābhimukhabhāvadīpanatthaṃ ādhārabhāvena
analyzed: ādhāra bhāvena yaḥ ca ādheyyassa anañña abhimukha bhāva dīpana ttham ādhāra bhāvena
translated: It is used in the sense of a basis, and it is used in the sense of a basis in order to show that the thing based upon it is not directed towards anything else.

original: vohariyati, so vesayiko nāma. Yathā? Ākāse sakuṇā pakkhanti, bhūmīsu manussā caranti,
analyzed: vohariyati saḥ vesayikaḥ nāma yathā ākāse sakuṇā pakkhanti bhūmīsu manussā caranti
translated: As in the following: “Birds fly in the sky, people walk on the ground,

original: udake macchā caranti, bhagavantaṃ pādesu vandati, pādesu patitvā rodati, pāpasmiṃ
analyzed: udake macchā caranti bhagavantam pādesu vandati pādesu patitvā rodati pāpasmin
translated: fish swim in the water, he worships the Blessed One with his feet, he falls at his feet and weeps, his mind delights in evil,

original: ramatī mano dha. pa. 116, pasanno buddhasāsaneti dha. pa. 368.
analyzed: ramatī manaḥ dha pa pasannaḥ buddha sāsanā iti dha pa
translated: his mind is confident in the Dispensation of the Buddha” .

analyzed: nimitte ka rū nī cam pā
translated: In a sign, in a mark, in a name, in a basis, in a reason, in a cause.

original: Niminanti sañjānanti etenāti nimittaṃ, nemittakasahabhāvino saññāṇakāraṇassetaṃ nāmaṃ, tasmiṃ nimitte sattamī hoti.
analyzed: niminanti sañjānanti etena ati nimittam nemittaka sahabhāvino saññāṇa kāraṇassa itam nāmam tasmim nimitte sattamī hoti
translated: A sign is that by means of which one perceives and cognizes; this is a name for the cause of perceiving that is associated with the act of perceiving. The locative case is used in reference to that sign.

original: Dīpi cammesu haññate, kuñjaro dantesu haññate, musāvāde pācittiyaṃ pāci. 2, omasavāde pācittiyaṃ pāci. 14 iccādi.
analyzed: dīpi cammesu haññate kuñjaraḥ dantesu haññate musāvāde pācittiyam pāci  omasavāde pācittiyam pāci  iccādi
translated: “He is killed for the sake of the skin of the dīpi leopard, he is killed for the sake of the tusks of the elephant, he confesses an offence for the sake of lying, he confesses an offence for the sake of slander” .

original: 325. Yambhāvo bhāvalakkhaṇaṃ ka. 313; rū. 327; nī. 644; caṃ. 2.1.90; pā. 2.3.37; ‘yabbhā vo’ (bahūsu).
analyzed: yam bhāvaḥ bhāva lakkhaṇam ka rū nī cam pā yam bhā vaḥ bahūsu
translated: The state of being is the characteristic of the state. In the plural: “Your states” .

original: Yādiso bhāvo yambhāvo, lakkhiyati etenāti lakkhaṇaṃ, bhāvantarassa lakkhaṇaṃ bhāvalakkhaṇaṃ,
analyzed: yādisaḥ bhāvaḥ yambhāvaḥ lakkhiyati etena ati lakkhaṇam bhāvantarassa lakkhaṇam bhāva lakkhaṇam
translated: A characteristic is that by which a state is characterized. The characteristic of a state is a state that is the characteristic of another state.

original: yambhāvo bhāvantarassa lakkhaṇaṃ hoti, tasmiṃ bhāve gamyamāne sattamī hoti, chaṭṭhīpi dissati.
analyzed: yambhāvaḥ bhāvantarassa lakkhaṇam hoti tasmin bhāve gamyamāne sattamī hoti chaṭṭhī pi dissati
translated: When a state is meant that is the characteristic of another state, the locative case is used, but the instrumental case is also found.

original: Acirapakkantassa sāriputtassa brāhmaṇo kālamakāsi ma. ni. 2.452 (visadisaṃ), appamattassa te viharato itthāgāropi te appamatto viharissati saṃ. ni. 1.129 (visadisaṃ) iccādi.
analyzed: acira pakkantassa sāriputtassa brāhmaṇaḥ kālam akāsi ma ni visadisam appamattassa te viharato itthāgāraḥ api te appamattaḥ viharissati sam ni visadisam iccādi
translated: “Not long after he had left, the brahmin died” (different in meaning). “If you live heedfully, the one who has gone to the harem will live heedfully” (different in meaning).

original: Imasmiṃ sati idaṃ hoti, imasmiṃ asati idaṃ na hoti saṃ. ni. 2.21, acirapakkante bhagavati
analyzed: imasmin sati idam hoti imasmin asati idam na hoti sam ni acira pakkante bhagavati
translated: “When this exists, that comes to be; with the arising of this, that arises” (different in meaning). “Not long after the Blessed One had left,

original: brāhmaṇo kālamakāsi, sabbe maggā vivajjanti, gacchante lokanāyake ma. ni. aṭṭha.
analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ kālam akāsi sabbe maggāḥ vivajjanti gacchante loka nāyake ma ni aṭṭha
translated: the brahmin died” (different in meaning). “All roads are closed to him” (different in meaning). “When the world’s leader goes” (different in meaning).

original: 2.22. Gāvīsu duyhamānāsu gato, gāvīsu duddhāsu āgato iccādi.
analyzed: gāvīsu duyhamānāsu gataḥ gāvīsu duddhāsu āgataḥ iccādi
translated: “When the cows were lowing he went; when the cows were milked he came” (different in meaning).

original: Kvaci paṭhamāpi bahulaṃ dissati, gacchanto so bhāradvājo, addasā accutaṃ isiṃ jā. 2.22.2007 (addassa). Yāyamāno mahārājā, addā sīdantare nage jā. 2.22.566 iccādi.
analyzed: kvaci paṭhamā api bahulam dissati gacchantaḥ saḥ bhāradvājaḥ addasā accutam isim jā addassa yāyamānaḥ mahā rājā addā sīdantare nage iccādi
translated: Sometimes the first is seen more often: “Bhāradvāja, going, saw the seer Accuta” (addassa). “The great king, being carried, saw the elephant Sīdantarā” (addā).

original: Pubbaṇhasamaye gato, sāyanhasamaye āgato iccādi vesayikādhāro eva.
analyzed: pubbaṇha samaye gataḥ sāyanha samaye āgataḥ iccādi vesayika ādhāraḥ eva
translated: “He went at dawn, he came back at evening” (āgato).

original: Tathā akāle vassatī tassa, kāle tassa na vassati jā. 1.2.88; 1.8.48. Ito satasahassamhi, kappe uppajji nāyako apa. thera 2.54.28 iccādi.
analyzed: tathā akāle vassatī tassa kāle tassa na vassati jā ito sata sahassamhi kappe uppajji nāyakaḥ iccādi
translated: “It rains out of season for him, it does not rain in season for him” (vassati); “A Leader arose a hundred thousand aeons ago” (uppajji).

original: 326. Chaṭṭhī cānādare ka. 305; rū. 323; nī. 633; caṃ. 2.1.91; pā. 2.3.38.
analyzed: chaṭṭhī ca an ādare ka rū nī caṃ pā
translated: The sixth case is used in the sense of disrespect: “He is not respected by the king” (rājā); “He is not respected by the people” (janā); “He is not respected by the brahmins” (brāhmaṇā); “He is not respected by the ascetics” (samaṇā).

original: ‘Anādaro’ti dvinnaṃ lakkhaṇa, lakkhitabbakriyānaṃ ekappahārena pavattiyā adhivacanaṃ, anādarabhūte bhāvalakkhaṇe gamyamāne sattamī chaṭṭhī ca hoti.
analyzed: dvinnam eka ppahārena pavattiyāḥ adhivacanam anādara bhūte bhāva lakkhaṇe gamyamāne sattamī chaṭṭhī ca hoti
translated: “Disrespect” is a term for the simultaneous occurrence of two characteristics, the characteristic of the action to be characterized and the characteristic of disrespect. When the state of disrespect is understood, the seventh case and the sixth case are used.

original: Maccu gacchati ādāya, pekkhamāne mahājane. Ākoṭayanto so neti, sivirājassa pekkhato
analyzed: gacchati ādāya pekkhamāne mahājane ākoṭayantaḥ saḥ neti sivi rājassa pekkhataḥ
translated: “Death goes taking with it, while the great multitude looks on. He knocks and enters, while King Sīvi looks on” (pekkhato).

original: jā. 2.22.2122 (teneti). Akāmakānaṃ mātāpitūnaṃ rudantānaṃ pabbaji, anagāriyupetassa,
analyzed: jā tena iti akāmakānam mātā pitūnam rudantānam pabbaji anagāriya upetassa
translated: (By that). He went forth while his unwilling weeping parents were crying, to one who had gone forth, to one who had gone forth and was free from the household life,

original: vippamuttassa te sato. Samaṇassa na taṃ sādhu, yadaññamanusocati jā. 1.7.107 (yaṃ petamanusocasi).
analyzed: vippamuttassa te sataḥ samaṇassa na tam sādhu yat aññam anusocati jā yam petam anusocasi
translated: to one who was liberated, to one who was liberated and mindful. It is not right for a monk to grieve for another, (for one who is dead). (For whom you grieve).

original: 327. Yato niddhāraṇaṃ ka. 304; rū. 322; nī. 632; caṃ. 2.1.92; pā. 2.3.41.
analyzed: yatas niddhāraṇam ka rū nī cam pā
translated: . From which there is the extraction ka. ; rū. ; nī. ; caṃ. ...; pā. ...

original: Jāti, guṇa, kriyā, nāmehi samudāyato ekadesassa puthakkaraṇaṃ niddhāraṇaṃ, yato taṃ niddhāraṇaṃ jāyati, tasmiṃ samudāye chaṭṭhī, sattamiyo honti.
analyzed: jāti guṇa kriyā nāmehi samudāyataḥ ekadesassa puthakkaraṇam niddhāraṇam yatas tam niddhāraṇam jāyati tasmin samudāye chaṭṭhī sattamiyaḥ honti
translated: The separate making of a part of a whole by means of a class, a quality, an action, or a name is an extraction, and the sixth case is used in the whole from which the extraction is made, and the seventh case is used.

original: Jātiyaṃ tāva –
analyzed: tāva
translated: First of all, in a class:

original: Manussānaṃ khattiyo sūratamo, manussesu khattiyo sūratamo.
analyzed: manussānam khattiyaḥ sūratamaḥ manussesu khattiyaḥ sūratamaḥ
translated: Among humans, a warrior is the most courageous, among humans a warrior is the most courageous.

original: Guṇe –
analyzed: guṇe
translated: In a quality:

original: Kaṇhā gāvīnaṃ sampannakhīratamā, kaṇhāgāvīsu sampannakhīratamā.
analyzed: kaṇhā gāvīnam sampanna khīratamā kaṇhā gāvīsu sampanna khīratamā
translated: Among cows, a black one is the most perfect in milk, among black cows a black one is the most perfect in milk.

original: Kriyāyaṃ –
analyzed: kriyā ayam
translated: In an action:

original: Addhikānaṃ dhāvanto sīghatamo, addhikesu dhāvanto sīghatamo.
analyzed: addhikānam dhāvantaḥ sīghatamaḥ addhikesu dhāvantaḥ sīghatamaḥ
translated: Among runners, a horse is the swiftest, among runners a horse is the swiftest.

original: Nāme –
analyzed: nāme
translated: In a name:

original: Āyasmā ānando arahataṃ aññataro, arahantesu aññataro iccādi.
analyzed: āyasmai ānandaḥ arahatam aññataraḥ arahantesu aññataraḥ iccādi
translated: The venerable Ānanda is one of the Worthy Ones, among the Worthy Ones one of the Worthy Ones.

original: Idha nānāttasattamī vuccate.
analyzed: idha nānāttasattamī vuccate
translated: Here the seventh case is called the different-from case.

original: Kammatthe sattamī, bhikkhūsu abhivādenti pārā. 517, puttaṃ muddhani cumbitvā, purisaṃ nānābāhāsu gahetvā saṃ. ni. 2.63 iccādi.
analyzed: kamma atthe sattamī bhikkhūsu abhivādenti pārā puttam muddhani cumbitvā purisam nānā bāhāsu gahetvā sam ni iccādi
translated: In the sense of object, as in the seventh case in the passage, “They pay homage to the bhikkhus” .

original: Atha vā ‘muddhani, bāhāsū’ti ādhāre eva bhummaṃ. Yathā? Rukkhaṃ mūle chindati, rukkhaṃ khandhe chindati, purisaṃ sīse paharati, bhagavantaṃ pādesu vandati.
analyzed: atha vā muddhani bāhāsu iti ādhāre eva bhummam yathā rukkham mūle chindati rukkham khandhe chindati purisam sīse paharati bhagavantam pādesu vandati
translated: Or else, “on the head” and “on the shoulders” are locative in the sense of location, as in the passage, “Having kissed his son on the head, having seized the man by the shoulders” .

original: Karaṇe ca sattamī, hatthesu piṇḍāya caranti mahāva. 119, pattesu piṇḍāya caranti, pathesu gacchanti, sopi maṃ anusāseyya, sampaṭicchāmi matthake mi. pa. 6.4.8.
analyzed: karaṇe ca sattamī hatthesu piṇḍāya caranti pattesu piṇḍāya caranti pathesu gacchanti saḥ api mama anusāseyya sampaṭicchāmi
translated: In the sense of instrument, as in the seventh case in the passage, “They wander for alms with their hands and bowls” , and in the passage, “They wander for alms with their feet and bowls” , and in the passage, “He would instruct me” , and in the passage, “I consent to the venerable one’s placing his head on my lap” .

original: Sampadāne ca sattamī, saṅghe dinne mahapphalaṃ, saṅghe gotamī dadeyyāsi, saṅghe dinne
analyzed: sampadāne ca sattamī saṅghe dinne mahat phalam saṅghe gotamī dadeyyāsi saṅghe dinne
translated: In the sense of source, as in the seventh case in the passage, “When given to the Community it is of great fruit” , and in the passage, “Gotamī, you should give to the Community” , and in the passage, “When given to the Community” .🔽In the passage, “If I were worshipped, I would be worshipped by the Community” , the locative is appropriate in the sense of object.

original: ahañceva pūjito bhavissāmi ma. ni. 3.376, viceyya dānaṃ dātabbaṃ, yattha dinnaṃ mahapphalaṃ🔽pe. va. 329. Etesu pana visayasattamīpi yujjati.
analyzed: aham ca iva pūjitaḥ bhavissāmi viceyya dānam dātabbam yattha dinnam mahapphalam 🔽pe va etesu pana visaya sattamī pi yujjati
translated: In the passage, “Having examined, the gift should be given, where the gift given is of great fruit” , the locative is appropriate in the sense of source.

original: Apādāne ca sattamī, gadalīsu gaje rakkhantiiccādi.🔽Sāmissarādiyoge pana chaṭṭhī sattamī ca hoti, gunnaṃ sāmi, gosu sāmi, gunnaṃ issaro,🔽gosu issaro, gunnaṃ adhipati, gosu adhipati, gunnaṃ dāyādo, gosu dāyādo, gunnaṃ sakkhi,🔽gosu sakkhi, gunnaṃ patibhū, gosu patibhū, gunnaṃ pasuto, gosu pasuto, āyutto kaṭakaraṇassa,
analyzed: apādāne ca sattamī gadalīsu gaje rakkhanti iccādi  sāmissara ādi yoge pana chaṭṭhī sattamī ca hoti gunnam sāmi gosu sāmi gunnam issaro  gosu issaraḥ gunnam adhipati gosu adhipati gunnam dāyādaḥ gosu dāyādaḥ gunnam sakkhi  gosu sakkhi gunnam patibhū gosu patibhū gunnam pasutaḥ gosu pasutaḥ āyuttaḥ kaṭa karaṇassa
translated: And in the seventh case with the ablative: “They guard the elephants in the elephant kraals” and so on.

original: āyutto kaṭakaraṇeti, etesu pana sambandhe chaṭṭhī, visayādhāre sattamī. Ñāṇasmiṃ🔽pasanno, ñāṇasmiṃ ussukkoti visayādhāre sattamī. Ñāṇena pasanno, ñāṇena ussukkoti karaṇe tatiyā.🔽328. Sattamyādhikye ka. 314; rū. 328; nī. 645; caṃ. 2.1.60; pā. 2.3.9; 1.4.87.🔽Adhikabhāvatthe upena yuttā liṅgamhā sattamī hoti.
analyzed: āyuttaḥ kaṭa karaṇa iti etesu pana sambandhe chaṭṭhī visaya ādhāre sattamī ñāṇasmiṃ 🔽pasannaḥ ñāṇasmiṃ ussukkoti visaya ādhāre sattamī ñāṇena pasannaḥ ñāṇena ussukkoti karaṇe tatiyā 🔽sattamī ādhikye ka rū nī cam pā 🔽adhika bhāva tthe upena yuttā liṅgamhā sattamī hoti

original: Upa khāriyaṃ doṇo, upa nikkhe kahāpaṇaṃ, atirekadoṇā khārī, atirekakahāpaṇaṃ nikkhanti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: upa khāriyam doṇaḥ upa nikkhe kahāpaṇam atireka doṇā khārī atireka kahāpaṇam nikkhanti vuttam hoti
translated: Upa khāriyaṃ doṇo, upa nikkhe kahāpaṇaṃ, atirekadoṇā khārī, atirekakahāpaṇaṃ nikkhanti vuttaṃ hoti.

analyzed: sāmittedhinā cam pā
translated: . Sāmittedhinā caṃ. ..; pā. ..; ...

analyzed: sāmibhāvatthe adhinā yuttā liṅgamhā sattamī hoti
translated: Sāmibhāvatthe adhinā yuttā liṅgamhā sattamī hoti.

original: Adhi brahmadatte pañcālā, adhi pañcālesu brahmadatto, adhi devesu buddho. Tattha
analyzed: adhi brahmadatte pañcālāḥ adhi pañcālesu brahmadattaḥ adhi devesu buddhaḥ tattha
translated: Adhi brahmadatte pañcālā, adhi pañcālesu brahmadatto, adhi devesu buddho. Tattha

original: ‘adhi brahmadatte pañcālā’ti brahmadattissarā pañcālaraṭṭhavāsinoti vadanti, ‘pañcālā’ti
analyzed: adhi brahmadatte pañcālā ati brahmadatti ssarā pañcāla raṭṭha vāsino iti vadanti pañcālā ati
translated: ‘adhi brahmadatte pañcālā’ti brahmadattissarā pañcālaraṭṭhavāsinoti vadanti, ‘pañcālā’ti

original: vā janapadanāmattā bahuvacanaṃ, kadāci pañcālarājā brahmadatte kāsiraññe issaro,
analyzed: vā janapada nāma ttā bahuvacanam kadāci pañcāla rājā brahmadatte kāsi raññe issaraḥ
translated: vā janapadanāmattā bahuvacanaṃ, kadāci pañcālarājā brahmadatte kāsiraññe issaro,

original: kadāci brahmadatto pañcālaraññe issaroti attho.
analyzed: kadāci brahmadatto pañcāla raññe attho
translated: kadāci brahmadatto pañcālaraññe issaroti attho.

original: 330. Sabbādito sabbā caṃ. 2.1.72; pā. 2.3.27.
analyzed: sabba āditaḥ sabbā cam pā
translated: . Sabbādito sabbā caṃ. ..; pā. ...

original: Hetvatthehi yoge sabbādīhi sabbanāmehi hetvatthe sabbā vibhattiyo honti.
analyzed: hetu atthehi yoge sabba ādīhi sabba nāmehi hetu atthe sabbāḥ vibhattiyaḥ honti
translated: Hetvatthehi yoge sabbādīhi sabbanāmehi hetvatthe sabbā vibhattiyo honti.

original: Kiṃ kāraṇaṃ, kena kāraṇena jā. aṭṭha. 4.15 mātaṅgajātakavaṇṇanā, kiṃ nimittaṃ, kena
analyzed: kim kāraṇam kena kāraṇena jā aṭṭha mātaṅga jātaka vaṇṇanā kim nimittam kena
