original: nimittena, kiṃ payojanaṃ, kena payojanena, kenaṭṭhena dha. sa. aṭṭha. nidānakathā,🔽kena vaṇṇena saṃ. ni. 1.234, kimatthaṃ, kuto nidānaṃ pārā. 42, kissa hetu pārā. 39,
analyzed: nimittena kim payojanam kena payojanena kenaṭṭhena dha sa aṭṭha nidāna kathā  kena vaṇṇena sam ni kimattham kutas nidānam pārā  kissa hetu pārā
translated: By what sign? What is the purpose? For what purpose? For what reason? Dha. Sa. Aṭṭha. Nidāna-kathā,🔽For what colour? Sa. Ni. ., for what purpose? From what source? Pārā. , for what reason? Pārā. ,

original: kasmiṃ nidāne, etasmiṃ nidāne pārā. 42, etasmiṃ pakaraṇe pārā. 42 iccādi.
analyzed: kasmin nidāne etasmin nidāne pārā etasmin pakaraṇe pārā iti cādi
translated: In what source? In this source? Pārā. , in this section? Pārā. , and so on.

original: Sattamīvibhattirāsi niṭṭhito.
analyzed: niṭṭhitaḥ
translated: The collection of the seventh case endings is finished.

original: Iti niruttidīpaniyā nāma moggallānadīpaniyā
analyzed: iti niruttidīpaniyā nāma moggallānadīpaniyā
translated: Thus ends the “Light on the Analysis of Moggallāna” called “The Explanation of the Analysis”.

original: Kārakakaṇḍo niṭṭhito.
analyzed: kāraka kaṇḍaḥ niṭṭhitaḥ
translated: The section on the verb is finished.

original: 4. Samāsakaṇḍa
analyzed: samāsa kaṇḍa
translated: . The section on compounds

original: Atha yuttatthānaṃ syādyantapadānaṃ ekatthībhāvo vuccate. Ekatthībhāvoti ca idha samāso
analyzed: atha ekatthībhāvaḥ vuccate ekatthībhāvaḥ ti ca idha samāsaḥ
translated: Now the state of being one word of the words at the end of a compound is said. And the state of being one word is called here a compound.

original: vuccati. So ca samāso chabbidho abyayībhāvo, tappuriso, kammadhārayo, digu, bahubbīhi, dvandoti.
analyzed: vuccati saḥ ca samāsaḥ chabbidhaḥ abyayībhāvaḥ tappurisaḥ kammadhārayaḥ digu bahupbīhi dvandaḥ ti
translated: And that compound is of six kinds: the indeclinable compound, the compound with the following word predominant, the copulative compound, the appositional compound, the adverbial compound, and the disjunctive compound.

original: Abyayībhāvasamāsa
analyzed: abyayībhāva samāsa
translated: The indeclinable compound

original: Tattha abyayībhāvo paṭhamaṃ vuccate. Byayo vuccati vikāro, natthi byayo etassāti
analyzed: tattha abyayībhāvaḥ paṭhamam vuccate byayaḥ vuccati vikāraḥ natthi byayaḥ etassa ati
translated: Therein, the indeclinable compound is mentioned first. Decay is called change. There is no decay in this, therefore it is called

original: abyayo, abyayo hutvā bhavatīti abyayībhāvo, nānāliṅga, vibhatti, vacanesu rūpavikārarahito
analyzed: abyayaḥ abyayaḥ hutvā bhavati iti abyayībhāvaḥ vacanesu rūpa vikāra rahitaḥ
translated: The state of being an indeclinable is the state of being not a declinable, not a declinable after having been a declinable.

original: hutvā bhavatīti attho, sabbaliṅga,-vibhatti, vacanesupi yebhuyyena ekarūpena pavattatīti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: hutvā bhavati iti attho sabba liṅga vibhatti vacanesu pi yebhuyyena eka rūpena pavattati iti vuttam hoti
translated: The meaning is: after having been, it is. It is said that it occurs for the most part with the same form in all genders and in all cases.

original: Abyayanti vā upasagganipātānaṃ eva nāmaṃ, ayaṃ pana pakati abyayaṃ na hoti, asaṅkhyehi saha ekatthatāvasena abyayaṃ hoti, iti anabyayampi abyayaṃ bhavatīti abyayībhāvo.🔽331. Syādisyādinekatthaṃ ka. 316; rū. 331; nī. 675; caṃ. 2.2.1; pā. 2.1.4.
analyzed: abyayanti vā upasagga nipātānam eva nāmam ayam pana ayam pana abyayam na hoti asaṅkhyehi saha ekattha tā vasena abyayam hoti iti anabyayam pi abyayam bhavati iti abyayībhāvaḥ  syādi syādi nekattham ka rū nī cam pā
translated: Or else, indeclinable is the name for the prepositions and indeclinables. But this is not an indeclinable by nature; it is an indeclinable in the sense of being one in meaning with the infinities. So it is the state of being an indeclinable of what is not an indeclinable.🔽The indeclinables are of one meaning with the word that ends in a verbal root, with the word that ends in a preposition, and with the word that ends in an indeclinable.

original: Adhikārasuttamidaṃ. Syādi vuccati syādyantapadaṃ, ‘syādinā’ti syādyantapadena, eko attho yassa taṃ ekatthaṃ, syādipadaṃ syādipadena saha ekatthaṃ hotīti attho.
analyzed: adhikāra suttam idam syādi vuccati syādi anta padam syādinā ati syādi anta padena ekaḥ atthaḥ yassa tam ekattham syādi padam syādi padena saha ekattham hoti iti attho
translated: This is a sutta on the topic. A word that ends in a verbal root is called a word that ends in a verbal root. With a word that ends in a verbal root means with a word that ends in a verbal root. That which has one meaning is of one meaning. The word that ends in a verbal root is of one meaning with the word that ends in a verbal root. The meaning is: it is of one meaning with the word that ends in a verbal root.

original: Ettha ca ‘syādī’ti vacanena upasagga, nipātehi saddhiṃ sabbāni nāmikapadāni nāmapaṭirūpakāni ca saṅgaṇhāti, tyādyantapadāni nivatteti.🔽Tattha nāmapaṭirūpakāni nāma ‘yevāvanakadhammā’ iccādīni. Tathā saññāsaddabhāvaṃ
analyzed: ettha ca sya ādi iti vacanena upasagga nipātehi saddhim sabbāni nāmika padāni nāma paṭirūpakāni ca saṅgaṇhāti ti ādi anta padāni  tattha nāma paṭirūpakāni nāma yeva āvanaka dhammā iccādīni tathā saññā sadda bhāvam
translated: And here the word ‘and so on’ includes all nominal bases with prefixes and all nominal bases with indeclinables, and it excludes bases ending in ‘tya’ and so on.

original: pattāni “atthipaccayo, natthipaccayo, atthikhīrā brāhmaṇī, aññāsikoṇḍañño, makkhaligosālo”
analyzed: pattāni atthi paccayaḥ natthi paccayaḥ atthi khīrā brāhmaṇī aññā asi koṇḍaññaḥ makkhali gosālo
translated: Herein, ‘nominal bases with indeclinables’ are such words as ‘yevāvanakadhammā’ and so on. So too, in such passages as ‘atthi-paccayo, natthi-paccayo, atthikhīrā brāhmaṇī, aññāsi-koṇḍañño, makkhaligosālo’, the words ‘atthi’ and so on have attained the state of being indeclinables.

original: iccādīsu ‘atthi’ iccādīni.
analyzed: iccā ādīsu atthi iccā ādīni
translated: ‘Nominal bases with prefixes’ are such words as ‘atthi’ and so on.

original: ‘Ekattha’nti etena dvandasamāsepi padānaṃ ekakattu, ekakammādibhāvena ekatthībhāvo vutto hotīti.
analyzed: ekattham ti etena dvanda samāse pi padānam eka kattu eka kamma ādi bhāvena ekatthībhāvaḥ vuttaḥ hoti iti
translated: By the word ‘in the same way’ it is said that in a copulative compound the words have the same meaning by having the same case, the same verb, and so on.

original: 332. Asaṅkhyaṃ vibhattisampattisamīpasākalyābhāvayathāpacchāyugapadatthe ka. 319; rū. 330; nī. 696; caṃ. 2.2.2; pā. 2.1.6.
analyzed: asaṅkhyam vibhatti sampatti samīpa sākalya abhāva yathā pacchā yugapad atthe ka rū nī caṃ pā
translated: In the sense of numberlessness, proximity, completeness, absence, as it were, after, simultaneously, ka, ru, ni, ca, ma, pa,

original: ‘Asaṅkhya’nti upasaggapadaṃ nipātapadañca vuccati. Taṃ dvayampi hi ekatta, bahuttasaṅkhyaṃ
analyzed: upasagga padam nipāta padam ca vuccati tam dvayam pi hi ekatta bahutta saṅkhyam
translated: ‘Numberlessness’ is a prefix and also an indeclinable. For both of these are one, and they are a number of ones.

original: paṭicca rūpavikārarahitattā ‘asaṅkhya’nti vuccati. Vibhatyatthe, sampatyatthe, samīpatthe,
analyzed: paṭicca rūpa vikāra rahita ttā asaṅkhyanti vuccati vibhati atthe sampati atthe samīpa tthe
translated: because it is free from the alteration of form, it is called ‘incalculable’. The word asaṅkhya is found in the sense of ‘having a case ending’, ‘having a preposition’, ‘having a near meaning’,

original: sākalyatthe, abhāvatthe, yathātthe, pacchātthe, yugapadatthe pavattaṃ asaṅkhyaṃ nāma
analyzed: sākalya tthe abhāva tthe yathātthe pacchā tthe yugapadatthe pavattam asaṅkhyam nāma
translated: ‘having a complete meaning’, ‘having a non-existence meaning’, ‘having a just so meaning’, ‘having a later meaning’, ‘having a simultaneous meaning’.

original: syādipadaṃ aññena syādipadena saha ekatthaṃ hoti. Ayañca samāso anvatthavasena ‘asaṅkhyo’ti
analyzed: si ādi padam aññena si ādi padena saha ekattham hoti ayam ca samāsaḥ anvattha vasena
translated: This word asaṅkhya is a primary derivative noun which has one meaning with another primary derivative noun beginning with sy. This compound is called ‘asaṅkhya’

original: ca ‘abyayībhāvo’ti ca vuccati.
analyzed: ca ca vuccati
translated: and ‘abyayībhāva’ according to the meaning.

original: Vibhatyatthe tāva –
analyzed: vibhati atthe tāva
translated: First of all, in the sense of ‘having a case ending’:

original: Adhitthi. Ettha ca adhito si, tassa ‘asaṅkhyehi sabbāsa’nti suttena lopo, itthito🔽su, ‘adhi itthīsū’ti vākyaṃ, tassa ca atthaṃ kathentena niccasamāsattā aññapadena
analyzed: adhitthi ettha ca adhitaḥ si tassa asaṅkhyehi sabbāsanti suttena lopaḥ itthitaḥ  su adhi itthīsu iti vākyam tassa ca attham kathentena nicca samāsa ttā añña padena
translated: Adhitthi. And here, ‘adhito si’ is elided by the rule ‘asaṅkhyehi sabbāsa’. Itthi is the feminine form.

original: viggaho kātabbo “itthīsu pavattā kathā”ti vā “itthīsu pavatto vacanapatho”ti vā “itthīsu
analyzed: viggahaḥ kātabbaḥ itthīsu pavattā kathā iti vā itthīsu pavattaḥ vacana pathaḥ iti vā itthīsu
translated: The sentence is ‘adhi itthīsū’. And the one who explains its meaning should make a separation with another word because of the constant compounding, saying “talk that occurs in regard to women” or “the path of speech that occurs in regard to women” or “speech that occurs in regard to women”,

original: pavattaṃ vacana”nti vā, tato purimasuttena ekatthasaññā, iminā suttena asaṅkhyekatthasaññā
analyzed: pavattam vacananti vā tatas purima suttena eka attha saññā iminā suttena asaṅkhyā ikattha saññā
translated: then there is the perception of one meaning by the previous rule, and the perception of one meaning of asaṅkhya by this rule.

original: ca kariyate, ekatthasaññāya pana katāya vākyatthāya payuttānaṃ vibhattīnaṃ attho
analyzed: ca kariyate eka attha saññāya pana katāya vākya atthāya payuttānam vibhattīnam atthaḥ
translated: and is made, then the meaning of the case- endings that are appropriate to the meaning of the sentence, when the meaning of the sentence has been made,

original: ekatthapadena vutto hoti, tadā vibhattiyo vuttatthā nāma.
analyzed: eka attha padena vuttaḥ hoti tadā vibhattiyaḥ vuttatthāḥ nāma
translated: is expressed by the word that has the single meaning. Then the case-endings are said to have their meaning expressed.

original: Idāni vuttatthānaṃ appayogārahattā lopavidhānamāha.
analyzed: idāni vutta tthānam lopa vidhānam āha
translated: Now, because of the unsuitability of the expressed meaning, he states the rule for the omission of case-endings.

analyzed: ekatthatā ayam ka rū nī cam pā
translated: . In the case of a single meaning, ka. ; rū. ; nī. ; caṃ. ..; pā. ..; .., .

original: Eko attho yesaṃ tāni ekatthāni, ‘attho’ti cettha padantare kattu, kammādibhāvena
analyzed: ekaḥ atthaḥ yesam tāni ekatthāni ca ittha pada antare kattu kamma ādi bhāvena
translated: Those that have a single meaning are ekatthāni. ‘Meaning’ here is the principal meaning that is to be inflected by the other words

original: vidheyyo padhānattho eva veditabbo. Tathā hi ‘rājaputto’ti ettha puttasaddattho eva
analyzed: vidheyyaḥ padhāna atthaḥ eva veditabbaḥ tathā hi rāja puttaḥ ti ettha putta sadda atthaḥ eva
translated: in the form of the nominative case, objective case, etc. For thus, in the case of ‘the king’s son’, the meaning of the word ‘son’

original: tathāvidheyyo hoti, na rājasaddattho, sabbañca vacanavākyaṃ nāma vidheyyatthehi eva
analyzed: tathā vidheyyaḥ hoti na rāja saddattho sabbam ca vacana vākyam nāma vidheyya atthehi eva
translated: is what is to be inflected, and not the meaning of the word ‘king’. And all speech and sentence is accomplished only by means of what is to be inflected,

original: sijjhati, no aññathā, yasmā ca ‘rājaputto’ti etaṃ puttasaddatthasseva nāmaṃ hoti,
analyzed: sijjhati no aññathā yasmā ca rāja putto ti etam putta sadda tthassa iva nāmam hoti
translated: not otherwise. And because ‘the king’s son’ is the name only of the meaning of the word ‘son’,

original: na rājasaddatthassa, tasmā eko padhānabhūto puttasaddattho eva tesaṃ dvinnaṃ saddānaṃ
analyzed: na rāja saddatthassa tasmai ekaḥ padhāna bhūto putta saddatthaḥ eva tesam dvinnam saddānam
translated: not of the meaning of the word ‘king’, therefore the single meaning that is the principal word ‘son’ is the

original: attho nāma hoti, na rājasaddatthoti, ekatthānaṃ bhāvo ekatthatā, ekatthībhāvoti vuttaṃ
analyzed: atthaḥ nāma hoti na rāja sadda ttho ti ekatthānam bhāvaḥ ekatthatā ekatthībhāvaḥ iti vuttam
translated: “Meaning” is the meaning of a word, not the meaning of a sentence. “Unity” is the state of being one, the state of being one in meaning.

original: hoti. So tividho samāso, taddhito, dhātupaccayanto cāti. Tissaṃ tividhāyaṃ ekatthatāyaṃ
analyzed: hoti saḥ tividhaḥ samāsaḥ taddhitaḥ dhātu paccaya antaḥ ca ati tissam tividha ayam ekattha tā ayam
translated: It is threefold: nominal, verbal, and verbal-base. In this threefold unity

original: sabbāsaṃ vuttatthānaṃ syādivibhattīnaṃ lopo hotīti iminā sussa lopo. Bahulādhikārattā
analyzed: sabbāsam vutta tthānam sya ādi vibhattīnam lopaḥ hoti iti iminā sussa lopaḥ bahula adhikāra ttā
translated: the vowel-sign and the case-ending of the words that are stated are elided. By this rule the vowel-sign is elided. But because of the predominance of the rule🔽“The elision of the vowel-sign is optional in a compound,”

original: pana aluttasamāsopi dissati.🔽334. Taṃ napuṃsakaṃ ka. 320; rū. 335; nī. 698; caṃ. 2.2.15; pā. 2.4.18.
analyzed: pana a lutta samāsaḥ api dissati  tam napuṃsakam ka rū nī cam pā
translated: the elision of the vowel-sign is not always seen.🔽That is neuter.

original: Taṃ asaṅkhyaṃ nāma ekatthaṃ napuṃsakaṃ hotīti iminā adhitthīsaddassa napuṃsakabhāvaṃ katvā tato syādyuppatti.
analyzed: tam asaṅkhyam nāma ekattham napuṃsakam hoti iti iminā adhitthī saddassa napuṃsaka bhāvam katvā tatas
translated: That is called “indefinite” and is neuter in meaning. By this rule the word “adhitthāna” is made neuter and then the vowel-sign is added.

analyzed: sya ādīsu ras saḥ ka rū nī cam pā
translated: In the vowel-signs, the short is used.🔽In the vowel-signs, the short is used for the neuter in the case-endings. By this rule the “ī” is shortened.🔽In the first member of a compound, the short is used.

original: Napuṃsakassa ekatthassa rasso hoti syādīsu vibhattīsūti iminā īkārassa rasso.🔽336. Pubbasmāmādito ka. 343; rū. 338; nī. 375; caṃ. 2.1.40; pā. 1.1.41.
analyzed: napuṃsakassa eka atthassa rassaḥ hoti sya ādīsu vibhattīsu iti iminā īkārassa rassaḥ 🔽pup basma āma āditaḥ ka rū nī cam pā
translated: In the first member of a compound, the short is used for the neuter. By this rule the “ī” is shortened.

original: Pubbaamādi nāma pubbapadatthapadhānabhūto asaṅkhyasamāso vuccati, tato parāsaṃ sabbāsaṃ🔽vibhattīnaṃ lopo hoti, ādisaddena cettha paṭhamāvibhattipi gayhati. Atha vā amādi
analyzed: nāma pubba padattha padhāna bhūtaḥ asaṅkhyasamāsaḥ vuccati tatas parāsam sabbāsam  vibhattīnam lopaḥ hoti ādi saddena ca ittha paṭhamā vibhatti pi gayhati atha vā am ādi
translated: After that, all the case endings are elided.🔽The word “etc.” includes the first case ending.

original: vuccati tappuriso, tato pubbaṃ nāma asaṅkhyasamāso, iti amādito pubbabhūtā asaṅkhyekatthā
analyzed: vuccati tappurisaḥ tatas pubbam nāma asaṅkhya samāsaḥ iti ama āditaḥ pubba bhūtāḥ asaṅkhyekatthāḥ
translated: Or else, “beginning with a preceding word” is called a tappurisa compound.🔽After that, all the case endings are elided.

original: parāsaṃ sabbāsaṃ vibhattīnaṃ lopo hotīti iminā adhitthisaddato sabbavibhattīnaṃ lopo.🔽Adhitthi tiṭṭhati, itthīsu pavattā kathā tiṭṭhatīti attho. Adhitthi tiṭṭhanti, itthīsu
analyzed: parāsam sabbāsam vibhattīnam lopaḥ hoti iti iminā adhitthi saddataḥ sabba vibhattīnam lopaḥ  adhitthi tiṭṭhati itthīsu pavattā kathā tiṭṭhati iti atthaḥ adhitthi tiṭṭhanti itthīsu
translated: This means that all the case endings are elided after the word adhitthi.🔽The meaning is: “The discussion that occurs in the feminine remains.”

original: pavattā kathāyo tiṭṭhantīti attho. Esa nayo sesavibhattīsu sesavacanesu sesaliṅgesu
analyzed: pavattā kathāyaḥ tiṭṭhanti iti attho esa nayaḥ sesa vibhattīsu sesa vacanesu sesa liṅgesu
translated: The meaning is: “The discussions that occur in the feminine remain.”🔽The same method applies to the other case endings, to the other words, and to the other genders.

original: ca. Evaṃ sabbaliṅgesu sabbavibhattīsu sabbavacanesu ca ekeneva rūpena tiṭṭhati, tasmā
analyzed: ca evam sabba liṅgesu sabba vibhattīsu sabba vacanesu ca ekena iva rūpena tiṭṭhati tasmā
translated: Thus, it remains in the same form in all genders, in all case endings, and in all numbers. Therefore,

original: ayaṃ samāso rūpavikārarahitattā ‘abyayībhāvo’ti vuccati.
analyzed: ayam samāsaḥ rūpa vikāra rahita ttā abyayībhāvaḥ ti vuccati
translated: this compound is called an “indeclinable” because it is free from changes in form.

original: Ettha ca vibhatyattho nāma “adhitthi, bahigāmaṃ, uparigaṅga” miccādīsu sampatyādīhi
analyzed: ettha ca nāma adhitthi bahigāmam uparigaṅgam micca ādīsu sampati ādīhi
translated: And here the meaning of the case-ending is called the “meaning of the case-ending” in such passages as “adhitthi, bahigāmaṃ, uparigaṅga” .🔽But in the analysis “kathā, pavattā”

original: visesatthehi rahito kevalo vibhattīnaṃ attho vuccati. Viggahe pana “kathā, pavattā”🔽iccādīni samāsasāmatthiyena viditāni atthapadāni nāma, adhisaddassa atthapadānītipi
analyzed: visesa atthehi rahitaḥ kevalaḥ vibhattīnam atthaḥ vuccati viggahe pana kathā pavattā  iccādīni samāsa sāmatthiyena viditāni attha padāni nāma adhi saddassa attha padāni iti pi
translated: and so on, the words known as “meaning-words” are called “meaning-words of the word adhi”.

original: vadanti. Evaṃ adhikumāri, adhivadhu, adhijambuiccādi.
analyzed: vadanti evam adhi kumāri adhi vadhu adhi jambu icca ādi
translated: Thus adhikumāri, adhivadhu, adhijambu and so on.

original: Attani pavatto dhammo, pavattā vādhammāti atthe vibhattīnaṃ lope kate adhiattasaddassa napuṃsakabhāvaṃ katvā tato syādyuppatti, ‘pubbasmāmādito’ti syādīnaṃ lope sampatte –
analyzed: attani pavattaḥ dhammo pavattā vā adhammā ati atthe vibhattīnam lope kate adhiatta saddassa napuṃsaka bhāvam katvā tatas sya ādi uppatti sya ādīnam lope sampatte
translated: When the elision of the case-ending is made in the sense of “a state that occurs in oneself” or “a state that occurs in dhammas” , the word adhiatta is made feminine, and then the suffix syā is added, and when the elision of syā is effected by the rule “pubbasmāmādito” ,

analyzed: na a toma pañcamiyā ka rū nī caṃ pā mu
translated: . The fifth case ending is ka. The nominative case ending is rū. The accusative case ending is nī. The instrumental case ending is caṃ. The dative case ending is pā. The ablative case ending is mu.

original: Akārantamhā asaṅkhyekatthā paraṃ sabbāsaṃ vibhattīnaṃ lopo na hoti, pañcamīvajjitānaṃ vibhattīnaṃ aṃ hoti.
analyzed: akāra antamhā a saṅkhyā ekatthā param sabbāsam vibhattīnam lopaḥ na hoti pañcamī vajjitānam vibhattīnam aṃ hoti
translated: The elision of all case-endings does not occur after a word ending in a vowel, nor after a numeral, nor after a word meaning “one”. The fifth case ending is aṃ after the case-endings that have been excepted.

original: Ajjhattaṃ dhammo jāyati, ajjhattaṃ dhammā jāyanti, ajjhattaṃ dhammaṃ passati, ajjhattaṃ dhamme passanti.
analyzed: ajjhattam dhammaḥ jāyati ajjhattam dhammāḥ jāyanti ajjhattam dhammam passati ajjhattam dhamme passanti
translated: A dhamma arises internally, dhammas arise internally, he sees a dhamma internally, he sees dhammas internally.

original: Apañcamiyāti kiṃ? Ajjhattā apeti, ajjhattehi apeti.🔽338. Vā tatiyāsattamīnaṃ ka. 341; rū. 336; nī. 733; caṃ. 2.1.42; pā. 2.4.84; mu. 4.3.375.
analyzed: a pañcamiyā iti kim ajjhattā apeti ajjhattehi apeti  vā tatiyā sattamīnam ka rū nī cam pā mu
translated: What is the meaning of the word apañcamiya? It means: he removes from the internal, he removes by means of the internal.🔽The third and seventh are the cases.

original: Akārantamhā asaṅkhyekatthā paraṃ tatiyā, sattamīnaṃ vikappena aṃ hoti.
analyzed: akāra antamhā a saṅkhyā ikatthā param tatiyā sattamīnam vikappena aṃ hoti
translated: The particle aṃ is used after a word ending in a vowel and after a word of less than three syllables, in the third and seventh cases, optionally.

original: Ajjhattaṃ dhammena vattati ajjhattena vā, ajjhattaṃ dhammehi vattati ajjhattehi vā,
analyzed: ajjhattam dhammena vattati ajjhattena vā ajjhattam dhammehi vattati ajjhattehi vā
translated: He acts with a dhamma internally, or by means of the internal, he acts with dhammas internally, or by means of the internal,

original: ajjhattaṃ dhammassa deti, ajjhattaṃ dhammānaṃ deti, ajjhattā dhammā apeti, ajjhattehi
analyzed: ajjhattam dhammassa deti ajjhattam dhammānam deti ajjhattāḥ dhammāḥ apeti ajjhattehi
translated: he gives a dhamma internally, he gives dhammas internally, dhammas are removed from the internal, dhammas are removed by means of the internal,

original: dhammehi apeti, ajjhattaṃ dhammassa santakaṃ, ajjhattaṃ dhammānaṃ santakaṃ, ajjhattaṃ
analyzed: dhammehi apeti ajjhattam dhammassa santakam ajjhattam dhammānam santakam ajjhattam
translated: the property of a dhamma internally, the property of dhammas internally,

original: dhamme tiṭṭhati ajjhatte vā, ajjhattaṃ dhammesu tiṭṭhati ajjhattesu vā. Ettha ca
analyzed: dhamme tiṭṭhati ajjhatte vā ajjhattam dhammesu tiṭṭhati ajjhattesu vā ettha ca
translated: he stands with a dhamma internally, or in the internal, he stands with dhammas internally, or in the internal. And here

original: ‘ajjhattaṃ dhammo’ti ajjhattabhūto dhammo, ‘ajjhattaṃ dhammā’ti ajjhattabhūtā dhammā🔽iccādinā attho veditabbo. Attānaṃ adhikicca pavatto pavattāti vā vuttepi attassa
analyzed: ajjhattam dhammo ti ajjhatta bhūtaḥ dhammo ajjhattam dhammā ati ajjhatta bhūtāḥ dhammā  iccādinā atthaḥ veditabbaḥ attānam adhikicca pavattaḥ pavattā ati vā vutte pi attassa
translated: ‘An internal idea’ is an idea that is internal. ‘Internal ideas’ are ideas that are internal.🔽The meaning should be understood in this way. And although it is said that ‘it occurs with reference to self’ and ‘it occurs as the occurrence of self,’

original: ādhārabhāvo sijjhatiyeva. Evaṃ adhicittaṃ, attani visuṃ visuṃ pavattaṃ pavattāni🔽vā paccattaṃ. Ettha ca “ajjhattaṃ abhinivisitvā ajjhattaṃ vuṭṭhāti, bahiddhā abhinivisitvā
analyzed: ādhāra bhāvaḥ evam adhicittam visum visum pavattam pavattāni  vā paccattam ettha ca ajjhattam abhinivisitvā ajjhattam vuṭṭhāti bahiddhā abhinivisitvā
translated: the state of being a support of self is still established. So ‘in the mind’ is in the individual self, or it is the occurrences that occur separately in the self.

original: ajjhattaṃ vuṭṭhātī”ti dha. sa. aṭṭha. 350; saṃ. ni. aṭṭha. 2.2.32 pāṭho atthi, tasmā🔽pañcamiyā aṃbhāvavajjanaṃ appakattāti daṭṭhabbaṃ. “Ajjhattā dhammā, bahiddhā dhammā”ti
analyzed: ajjhattam vuṭṭhāti iti dha sa aṭṭha sam ni aṭṭha  pañcamiyā daṭṭhabbam ajjhattāḥ dhammāḥ bahiddhāḥ dhammā ti
translated: And here there is the reading in the Dhammasangani and the Samyuttanikāya: ‘Having resolved upon an internal idea, he emerges with respect to an internal idea; having resolved upon an external idea, he emerges with respect to an internal idea’ .🔽Therefore the fifth case should be regarded as not applicable. And there is the reading in the Dhammasangani and the Samyutta Nikāya: ‘Internal ideas, external ideas’ .

original: dha. sa. tikamātikā 20 pāṭho atthi, tasmā paṭhamādīnampi vikappo labbhatīti.
analyzed: pāṭhaḥ atthi tasmā paṭhama ādīnam pi vikappaḥ labbhati iti
translated: Therefore the first case is also possible.

original: Sampattiatthe –
analyzed: sampatti atthe
translated: In the sense of perfection:

original: Sampannaṃ brahmaṃ sabrahmaṃ, ‘brahma’nti vedo vuccati. Ettha ca ‘akāle sakatthassā’ti
analyzed: sampannam brahmam sa brahmam brahmanti vedaḥ vuccati ettha ca akāle sa katthassa ati
translated: The perfect Brahma is the Brahma of the Vedas. And here ‘at the wrong time for the meaning of one’s own’

original: suttena sahasaddassa sādeso, bhikkhānaṃ samiddhi subhikkhaṃ, ‘syādīsu rasso’ti suttena
analyzed: suttena saha saddassa sa ādesaḥ bhikkhānam samiddhi subhikkham syāt īsu rassaḥ iti suttena
translated: The word sādeso is formed by the addition of the suffix -eso to the word sādeso, which is formed by the addition of the suffix -a to the word saha.

original: katanapuṃsakassa rassattaṃ.
analyzed: kata napuṃsakassa raḥ sa ttam
translated: The word rassattaṃ is formed by the addition of the suffix -attaṃ to the word rasso, which is formed by the addition of the suffix -o to the word kata.

original: Samīpe –
analyzed: samīpe
translated: In the sense of ‘near’:

original: Nagarassa samīpaṃ upanagaraṃ, kumbhassa samīpaṃ upakumbhaṃ, maṇikāya samīpaṃ upamaṇikaṃ, vadhuyā samīpaṃ upavadhu, gunnaṃ samīpaṃ upagu, ‘gossū’ti suttena ossa uttaṃ.
analyzed: nagarassa samīpam upanagaram kumbhassa samīpam upakumbham maṇikāya samīpam upamaṇikam vadhuyā samīpam upa vadhu gunnam samīpam upagu gossūti suttena ossaḥ uttam
translated: The word upanagaraṃ is formed by the addition of the suffix -anagaraṃ to the word nagaraṃ. The words upakumbhaṃ, upamaṇikaṃ, upavadhu, upagu are formed in the same way. The word ossa is formed by the addition of the suffix -o to the word utta, which is formed by the addition of the suffix -u to the word go.

original: Sākalye –
analyzed: sākalye
translated: In the sense of ‘together’:

original: Tiṇena saha sakalaṃ satiṇaṃ, tiṇena saddhiṃ sakalaṃ vatthuṃ ajjhoharatīti attho. Sahasaddassa sādeso.
analyzed: tiṇena saha sakalam sa tiṇam tiṇena saddhim sakalam vatthum ajjhoharati iti atthaḥ saha saddassa sa ādesaḥ
translated: The word satiṇaṃ is formed by the addition of the suffix -iṇaṃ to the word saha. The meaning is: ‘he eats the entire substance together with the grass’. The word sādeso is formed by the addition of the suffix -ādeso to the word saha.

original: Abhāve –🔽Makkhikānaṃ abhāvo nimmakkhikaṃ, darathānaṃ abhāvo niddarathaṃ, bhikkhānaṃ abhāvo🔽dubbhikkhaṃ, abhāvatthopi dusaddo atthi. Yathā? Dussīlo duppaññoti. Ettha ca ‘sampannaṃ
analyzed: abhāve  makkhikānam abhāvaḥ nimmakkhikam darathānam abhāvaḥ niddaratham bhikkhānam abhāvaḥ  dubbhikkham abhāva atthaḥ api du saddaḥ atthi yathā dussīlaḥ duppaññaḥ ti ettha ca sampannam
translated: In the sense of ‘absence’:

original: brahma’ntiādinā saddabyākaraṇesu atthavacanaṃ saddatthavibhāvanamattaṃ. Suttantesu
analyzed: brahmanti ādinā suttantesu
translated: The words nimmakkhikaṃ, niddarathaṃ, dubbhikkhaṃ are formed by the addition of the suffix -a to the words makkhika, daratha, and bhikkha respectively. The word dusaddo is also used in the sense of ‘absence’. For example: ‘Dussīlo duppañño’ . In the Saddasāra, however, the meaning of the word sampanna is explained as ‘brahma’ . In the Suttas, the explanation of the meaning of the word is merely an analysis of the meaning of the word. In the Saddasāra, the explanation of the meaning of the word is merely an analysis of the meaning of the word.

original: pana imesaṃ padānaṃ yuttaṃ abhidheyyatthaṃ ñatvā tadanurūpaṃ atthavacanampi veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: pana imesam padānam yuttam abhidheyya ttham ñatvā tad anurūpam attha vacanam pi veditabbam
translated: But the meaning of the terms should be understood as the proper and suitable meaning, and the words should be understood as the words that correspond to that meaning.

original: Yathāsaddatthe –
analyzed: yathāsat datthe
translated: In the sense of according with the sound:

original: Rūpassa sabhāvassa yogyaṃ anurūpaṃ, attānaṃ attānaṃ paṭicca pavattaṃ paccattaṃ, aḍḍhamāsaṃ
analyzed: rūpassa sabhāvassa yogyam anurūpam attānam attānam paṭicca pavattam paccattam aḍḍha māsam
translated: Proper and suitable to the individual essence of material form, occurring in dependence on each individual self, is paccattaṃ.🔽Following the fortnight is anvaḍḍhamāsaṃ.🔽Following the house is anugharaṃ.🔽Following the year is anuvassaṃ.

original: aḍḍhamāsaṃ anugataṃ anvaḍḍhamāsaṃ, gharaṃ gharaṃ anugataṃ anugharaṃ, vassaṃ vassaṃ🔽anugataṃ anuvassaṃ, jeṭṭhānaṃ anupubbaṃ anujeṭṭhaṃ, sattiyā anurūpaṃ yathāsatti,
analyzed: aḍḍha māsam anugatam anvaḍḍha māsam gharam gharam anugatam anugharam vassam vassam  anugatam anuvassam jeṭṭhānam anupubbam anujeṭṭham sattiyāḥ anurūpam yathāsatti
translated: Following the elder is anujeṭṭhaṃ.🔽According to the extent of the arrow is yathāsatti.🔽According to the extent of the strength is yathābalaṃ.🔽According to the extent of the work is yathākkamaṃ.

original: balassa anurūpaṃ yathābalaṃ, kamassa anurūpaṃ yathākkamaṃ. Evaṃ yathāsaṅkhyaṃ, yathālābhaṃ.
analyzed: balassa anurūpam yathābalam kamassa anurūpam yathākkamam evam yathāsaṅkhyam yathālābham
translated: In this way, yathāsankhyaṃ and yathālābhaṃ should be understood.🔽In the opposite direction to the ear is paṭisotaṃ.🔽In the opposite direction to the wind is paṭivātaṃ.

original: Sotassa paṭilomaṃ paṭisotaṃ, paṭivātaṃ, paṭisaddaṃ.
analyzed: sotassa paṭilomam paṭisotam paṭivātam paṭisaddam
translated: In the opposite direction to the sound is paṭisaddaṃ.

original: Pacchāpadatthe –
analyzed: pacchā pada tthe
translated: In the sense of following after:

original: Rathassa pacchā anurathaṃ.
analyzed: rathassa pacchā anuratham
translated: Following after the chariot is anurathaṃ.

original: Yugabhūto padattho yugapadattho, sahabhāvīatthadvayassetaṃ nāmaṃ. Tattha asaniphalena
analyzed: yuga bhūtaḥ padatthaḥ yuga padattho nāmam tattha asani phalena
translated: The meaning of the word yugapada is the meaning of the word that is simultaneous. This is the name for the two meanings that are co-existent. Here, the meaning of the word yugapada is the meaning of the word that is simultaneous. This is the name for the two meanings that are co-existent. Here, the meaning of the word yugapada is the meaning of the word that is simultaneous. This is the name for the two meanings that are co-existent. Here, the meaning of the word yugapada is the meaning of the word that is simultaneous. This is the name for the two meanings that are co-existent. Here, the meaning of the word yugapada is the meaning of the word that is simultaneous. This is the name for the two meanings that are co-existent. Here, the meaning of the word yugapada is the meaning of the word that is simultaneous. This is the name for the two meanings that are co-existent. Here, the meaning of the word yugapada is the meaning of the word that is simultaneous. This is the name for the two meanings that are co-existent.

original: saha pavattaṃ cakkaṃ sacakkaṃ, gadāvudhena yugaḷapavattaṃ vāsudevassa cakkāvudhantipi🔽vadanti yugapadatthe sacakkaṃ nidhehi, (moggallānavuttiyaṃ). cakkena yugapata dhehi
analyzed: saha pavattam cakkam sa cakkam gadāvudhena yugaḷa pavattam vāsudevassa  vadanti yugapad atthe sa cakkam nidhehi moggallāna vuttiyam cakkena dhehi
translated: The discus that is set in motion together with the discus is the discus weapon of Gadhi, or🔽they say it is the discus weapon of Vāsudeva.

original: sacakkaṃ, (mugdhabodhavuttiyaṃ). he bisaṇu! cakkena saha yugapadekakāle gadaṃ dhāraya.
analyzed: sa cakkam mugdha bodha vuttiyam he bisaṇu cakkena saha yugapad eka kāle gadam dhāraya
translated: The word “together” in the sense of simultaneously: “Place the discus together with the discus” (in the Moggallānavuttiya), “Place the discus together with the discus” (in the Mugdhabodhavuttiya).🔽“Hold the club at the time of simultaneously setting the discus in motion together with the discus” (in the Mugdhabodhaṭīkāyaṃ piṭṭhe).

original: (mugdhabodhaṭīkāyaṃ 226 piṭṭhe), sahassa sattaṃ.
analyzed: piṭṭhe
translated: Together with a thousand seven.

original: 339. Yathā natulye ka. 319; rū. 330; nī. 696; caṃ. 2.2.3; pā. 2.1.7.
analyzed: yathā na tulye ka rū nī cam pā
translated: As in the unequal: ka. ; rū. ; nī. ; caṃ. ..; pā. ...

original: Tulyato aññasmiṃ atthe pavatto yathāsaddo syādinā saha ekattho hoti moggallāne aññathāvutti dassitā.
analyzed: tulyatas aññasmin atthe pavattaḥ yathā saddaḥ sya ādinā saha ekatthaḥ hoti moggallāne aññathāvutti dassitā
translated: The word “as” is used in the sense of one meaning together with the word “sa” in a meaning that is different from the equal. The usage in a different way is shown in the Moggallāne.

original: Yathāsatti, yathābalaṃ, yathākkamaṃ, ye ye vuḍḍhā yathāvuḍḍhaṃ, vuḍḍhānaṃ paṭipāṭi vā yathāvuḍḍhaṃ.
analyzed: yathāsatti yathābalam yathākkamam ye ye vuḍḍhāḥ yathāvuḍḍham vuḍḍhānam paṭipāṭi vā yathāvuḍḍham
translated: As much as one is able, as much as one has strength, in due order, whoever is senior, in accordance with seniority, or the order of seniority.

original: Natulyeti kiṃ? Yathā devadatto, tathā yaññadatto.
analyzed: na tulyā iti kim yathā devadattaḥ tathā
translated: What is meant by “unequal”? As Devadatta, so Yaññadatta.

original: 340. Yāvāvadhāraṇe ka. 319; rū. 330; nī. 696; caṃ. 2.2.4; pā. 2.1.8.
analyzed: y ā vā avadhāraṇe ka rū nī cam pā
translated: As far as the limitation: ka. ; rū. ; nī. ; caṃ. ..; pā. ...

original: Avadhāraṇaṃ vuccati paricchindanaṃ, avadhāraṇe pavatto yāvasaddo syādinā saha ekattho bhavati.
analyzed: avadhāraṇam vuccati paricchindanam avadhāraṇe pavattaḥ yāva saddaḥ sya ādinā saha ekatthaḥ bhavati
translated: The word avadhāraṇaṃ is said to mean “a delimitation.” The word yāvat, which occurs in an avadhāraṇa, has the same meaning as the word saha.

original: Yattakaṃ attho vattatīti yāvadatthaṃ, dāgamo. Yattakaṃ jīvo vattatīti yāvajīvaṃ, yattakaṃ āyu vattatīti yāvatāyukaṃ, takāra, kakārā āgamā.
analyzed: yattakam atthaḥ vattati iti yāvadattham da āgamaḥ yattakam jīvaḥ vattati iti yāvajīvam yattakam āyu vattati iti yāvatāyukam takāra kakārāḥ āgamāḥ
translated: Yattakaṃ attho vattati = yāvadatthaṃ, dāgamo. Yattakaṃ jīvo vattati = yāvajīvaṃ, yattakaṃ āyu vattati = yāvatāyukaṃ, takāra, kakārā āgamā.

original: 341. Parāpābahitiropurepacchā vā pañcamyā ka. 319; rū. 330; nī. 696; caṃ. 2.2.7; pā. 2.1.12, 13; ‘payyapā…’ (bahūsu).
analyzed: parā pā bahi tiras pure pacchāḥ vā pañcamyā ka rū nī caṃ pā   payya pāḥ bahūsu
translated: Parāpābahitiropurepacchā vā pañcamyā ka. ; rū. ; nī. ; caṃ. ..; pā. .., ; ‘payyapā…’ (bahūsu).

original: Pari, apa, āiccādayo saddā pañcamyantena syādinā saha ekatthā bhavanti vā.
analyzed: pari apaḥ ā it ca ādayaḥ saddā pañcamī antena sya ādinā saha ekatthāḥ bhavanti vā
translated: The words pari, apa, ā, iccādi have the same meaning as the word saha, which is in the fifth case.

original: Pabbatato pari samantā vassīti devo paripabbataṃ paripabbatā vā, pabbataṃ vajjetvā🔽vassīti attho. Pabbatato bahiddhā apapabbataṃ apapabbatā vā, pāṭaliputtato bahiddhā
analyzed: pabbatataḥ pari samantā vassi iti devaḥ paripabbatam paripabbatā vā pabbatam vajjetvā  vassī iti attho pabbatataḥ bahiddhā apapabbatam apapabbatā vā pāṭaliputtataḥ bahiddhā
translated: Devo paripabbataṃ paripabbatā vā vassati = rain falls all round the mountain, all round the mountains. The meaning is: “Rain falls after avoiding the mountain.”

original: vassīti devo āpāṭaliputtaṃ āpāṭaliputtā vā, ākumārehi kaccāyanassa yaso vattatīti
analyzed: vassīti devaḥ āpāṭaliputtam āpāṭaliputtāḥ vā ā kumārehi kaccāyanassa yasaḥ vattati iti
translated: Devo āpāṭaliputtaṃ āpāṭaliputtā vā vassati = rain falls outside Pāṭaliputta, outside Pāṭaliputtas.🔽Yaso vattati ākumārehi kaccāyanassa = the fame of Kaccāyana is current among the young men.

original: ākumāraṃ ākumārā vā, ābhavaggā bhagavato yaso vattatīti ābhavaggaṃ ābhavaggā vā,
analyzed: ākumāram ākumārāḥ vā ābha vaggāḥ bhagavataḥ yasaḥ vattati iti ābha vaggam ābha vaggāḥ vā
translated: The word ābhavagga is derived from bhaga, “glory,” and means “having glory,” or “having the glory of youth,” or “having the glory of the highest,” since the Blessed One’s glory is spoken of as “having the highest glory.”🔽The word āpāṇakoṭika is derived from pāṇaka, “life,” and means “having the end of life,” since the going for refuge is spoken of as “having the end of life.”

original: āpāṇakoṭiyā saraṇagamanaṃ vattatīti āpāṇakoṭikaṃ, kāgamo. Gāmato bahi bahigāmaṃ bahigāmā
analyzed: āpāṇakoṭiyā saraṇa gamanam vattati iti āpāṇakoṭikam kāgamaḥ gāmataḥ bahi bahigāmam bahigāmā
translated: The word bahigāma is derived from gāma, “village,” and means “outside the village,” or “outside the villages.”

original: vā, evaṃ bahinagaraṃ, bahileṇaṃ, pabbatato tiro tiropabbataṃ tiropabbatā vā, evaṃ
analyzed: vai evam bahi nagaram bahileṇam pabbatataḥ tiras tiropabbatam tiropabbatā vai evam
translated: Similarly, bahi-nagara, bahi-lena, tiro-pabbata, tiro-pabbata, tiro-pākāra, tiro-kuṭṭa.🔽Here tiro means “the other side.”

original: tiropākāraṃ, tirokuṭṭaṃ. Ettha ca ‘tiro’ti parabhāgo vuccati. Bhattamhā pure purebhattaṃ🔽purebhattā vā, aruṇamhā pure purāruṇaṃ purāruṇā vā, bhattassa pacchā pacchābhattaṃ pacchābhattā vā.
analyzed: tiro upākāram tiro kuṭṭam ettha ca tiro ti parabhāgaḥ vuccati bhattamhā pure purebhattam  purebhattā vā aruṇamhā pure purā aruṇam purāruṇā vā bhattassa pacchā pacchābhattam pacchābhattā vā
translated: The word purebhatta is derived from bhatta, “food,” and means “before the food,” or “before the foods.”🔽The word purāruṇa is derived from aruṇa, “dawn,” and means “before the dawn,” or “before the dawns.”🔽The word pacchābhatta is derived from bhatta, “food,” and means “after the food,” or “after the foods.”

original: 342. Samīpāyāmesvanu ka. 319; rū. 330; nī. 696; caṃ. 2.2.9; pā. 2.1.15, 16.
analyzed: samīpa āyāma ī su anu ka rū nī cam pā
translated: . In the vicinity, in length, anus.

original: Samīpe āyāme ca pavatto anusaddo syādinā saha ekattho bhavati vā.🔽Vanassa samīpaṃ anuvanaṃ, asani anuvanaṃ gatā, gaṅgaṃ anuyātā anugaṅgaṃ, bārāṇasī.
analyzed: samīpe āyāme ca pavattaḥ anusaddaḥ sya ādinā saha ekatthaḥ bhavati vā 🔽vanassa samīpam anu vanam asani anu vanam gatā gaṅgam anuyātā anu gaṅgam bārāṇasī
translated: The word anus, which is used in the sense of “in the vicinity” and “in length,” has the same meaning as the words beginning with syā.

original: 343. Oro pari paṭi pāre majjhe heṭṭhuddhādhonto vā chaṭṭhiyā ka. 319; rū. 330; nī. 696; caṃ. 2.2.11; pā. 2.1.18; ‘orepari…’ (bahūsu).
analyzed: oraḥ pari paṭi pāre majjhe heṭṭha uddha adhas ntaḥ vā chaṭṭhiyā ka rū nī caṃ pā ora pari bahūsu
translated: 343. The sixth case is used with the words ‘orā’, ‘pārā’, ‘majjhe’, ‘heṭṭhā’, ‘uddha’, ‘adho’, ‘anto’ and ‘uddhaṃ’ in the sense of ‘near’, ‘far’, ‘middle’, ‘below’, ‘above’, ‘beneath’, ‘inside’ and ‘upwards’ respectively.

original: Orādayo saddā chaṭṭhīyantena syādinā saha ekatthā bhavanti vā.
analyzed: oḥ ādayaḥ saddāḥ chaṭṭhī yantena sya ādinā saha ekatthāḥ bhavanti vā
translated: The words ‘orā’ etc. are synonymous with the words ending in ‘syā’ in the sixth case.

original: Ettha ca ore, pāre, majjhesaddesu ‘tadaminādīnī’ti suttena ekāro, gaṅgāya oraṃ oregaṅgaṃ,
analyzed: ettha ca ore pāre majjhe saddesu tad amina ādīni iti suttena ekāraḥ gaṅgāya oraṃ oregaṅgaṃ
translated: And here, in the words ‘orā’, ‘pārā’ and ‘majjhe’, the vowel ‘a’ is contracted by the rule ‘tadaminādī’ (i.e. the vowel ‘a’ is elided before the words ‘min’, ‘ādī’ etc.). ‘Orāgaṅgaṃ’ means ‘near the Gaṅgā’.

original: sikharassa upari uparisikharaṃ. Evaṃ uparipāsādaṃ, uparimañcaṃ, uparipabbataṃ, sotassa
analyzed: sikharassa upari upari sikharam evam upari pāsādam upari mañcam upari pabbatam sotassa
translated: ‘Uparisikharaṃ’ means ‘on the top of the peak’. Similarly, ‘uparipāsādaṃ’, ‘uparimañcaṃ’, ‘uparipabbataṃ’. ‘Paṭisotaṃ’ means ‘against the stream’.

original: paṭilomaṃ paṭisotaṃ. Evaṃ paṭivātaṃ, yamunāya pāraṃ pāreyamunaṃ, gaṅgāya majjhaṃ
analyzed: paṭilomam paṭisotam evam paṭivātam yamunāya pāram pāreyamunam gaṅgāya majjham
translated: ‘Pāreyamunaṃ’ means ‘on the other side of the Yamunā’. ‘Majjhegaṅgaṃ’ means ‘in the middle of the Gaṅgā’.

original: majjhegaṅgaṃ, pāsādassa heṭṭhā heṭṭhāpāsādaṃ, heṭṭhāmañcaṃ, gaṅgāya uddhaṃ uddhaṃgaṅgaṃ,
analyzed: majjhegaṅgam pāsādassa heṭṭhā heṭṭhā pāsādam heṭṭhāmañcam gaṅgāya uddham uddhaṃgaṅgam
translated: ‘Heṭṭhāpāsādaṃ’ means ‘below the palace’. ‘Heṭṭhāmañcaṃ’ means ‘beneath the bed’. ‘Uddhaṃgaṅgaṃ’ means ‘above the Gaṅgā’.

original: gaṅgāya adho adhogaṅgaṃ, pāsādassa anto antopāsādaṃ. Evaṃ antogāmaṃ, antonagaraṃ, antovassaṃ.
analyzed: gaṅgāya adhas adhogaṅgam pāsādassa antar antopāsādam evam antogāmam antonagaram antovassam
translated: ‘Adhogaṅgaṃ’ means ‘beneath the Gaṅgā’. ‘Antopāsādaṃ’ means ‘inside the palace’. Similarly, ‘antogāmaṃ’, ‘antonagaraṃ’, ‘antovassaṃ’.

original: Vāti kiṃ? Gaṅgāoraṃ, majjhesamuddasmiṃ iccādi.
analyzed: vāti kim majjhe samuddasmin iccādi
translated: What is the meaning of ‘vā’? ‘Gaṅgāorā’, ‘majjhesamuddasmiṃ’.

original: 344. Tiṭṭhagvādīni ka. 319; rū. 330; nī. 697; caṃ. 2.2.10; pā. 2.1.17.
analyzed: tiṭṭhagva ādīni ka rū nī cam pā
translated: The words beginning with ‘tiṭṭhagu’ are treated in Ka. 319; Rū. 330; Ni. 697; Caṃ. 2.2.10; Pā. 2.1.17.

original: Tiṭṭhaguiccādīni asaṅkhyekatthe sijjhanti.
analyzed: ti ṭṭha gu icca ādīni a saṅkhyā ikatthe sijjhanti
translated: The words beginning with ‘tiṭṭhagu’ are established in the sense of ‘one’.

original: Tiṭṭhanti gāvo yasmiṃ kāle tiṭṭhagu, vahanti gāvoyasmiṃ kāle vahagu, ‘gossū’ti suttena🔽ossa uttaṃ. Āyatiṃ yavo yasmiṃ kāleti āyatiyavo, khale yavo yasmiṃ kāleti khaleyavaṃ.
analyzed: tiṭṭhanti gāvaḥ yasmin kāle tiṭṭhagu vahanti gāvaḥ yasmin kāle vahagu gossūti suttena  āyatim yavaḥ yasmin kāla iti āyatiyavaḥ khale yavaḥ yasmin kāla iti khaleyavam
translated: The time when cows stand is ‘tiṭṭhagu’ . The time when cows are driven along is ‘vahagu’ . The word ‘gossū’ is a compound word.🔽The word ‘āyatiyavo’ is formed by adding the suffix ‘yavo’ to the word ‘āyati’ . The word ‘khaleyavo’ is formed by adding the suffix ‘yavo’ to the word ‘khala’ .

original: Pubbapade vibhattialopo. Lunā yavā yasmiṃ kāleti lunayavaṃ, ettha ‘lunā’ti lāvitā,
analyzed: pubba pade vibhatti a lopaḥ lunā yavāḥ yasmin kāle iti lunayavam ettha lunāti lāvitā
translated: The case-ending of the preceding word is dropped. The word ‘lunayavo’ is formed by adding the suffix ‘yavo’ to the word ‘lunā’ .

original: luyamānā yavā yasminti luyamānayavaṃ iccādi.🔽Tathā pāto nahānaṃ yasmiṃ kāleti pātanahānaṃ. Evaṃ sāyanahānaṃ, pāto kammakaraṇakālo
analyzed: luyamānāḥ yavāḥ yasmin ti i ca ādi  tathā pātaḥ na hānam yasmin kāle iti pātana hānam evam sāyana hānam pāto kamma karaṇa kālo
translated: The word ‘luyamānayavo’ is formed by adding the suffix ‘yavo’ to the word ‘luyamānā’ .🔽Similarly, the word ‘pātanahānaṃ’ is formed by adding the suffix ‘nahānaṃ’ to the word ‘pāto’ . The time when work is done in the morning is ‘pātakālaṃ’ .

original: yasminti pātakālaṃ. Evaṃ sāyakālaṃ, pāto vassati megho yasminti pātameghaṃ. Evaṃ
analyzed: yasmin ti pāta kālam evam sāya kālam pātaḥ vassati meghaḥ yasmin ti pāta megham evam
translated: The word ‘pātameghaṃ’ is formed by adding the suffix ‘meghaṃ’ to the word ‘pāto’ .

original: sāyameghaṃ, pāto gantabbo maggo yasminti pātamaggaṃ. Evaṃ sāyamaggaṃ iccādi. Mahāvuttinā
analyzed: sāyamegham pātaḥ gantabbaḥ maggaḥ yasmin ti pāta maggam evam sāyamaggam iccādi mahāvuttinā
translated: The word ‘pātamaggaṃ’ is formed by adding the suffix ‘maggaṃ’ to the word ‘pāto’ .

original: pātosaddassa pātattaṃ. Ettha ca ‘tiṭṭhagu’ iccādīni viggahatthavasena aññapadatthe
analyzed: pātosaddassa ettha ca tiṭṭhagu icca ādīni viggaha ttha vasena añña pada tthe
translated: and the state of being a prefix in the word pāto.

original: siddhāni viya dissanti, aññapadassa pana liṅgādīnaṃ vasena tesaṃ rūpavikāro nāma
analyzed: siddhāni viya dissanti añña padassa pana liṅga ādīnam vasena tesam rūpa vikāraḥ nāma
translated: And here the words tiṭṭhagu, etc., are seen as though they were established in the meaning of another word by the method of word-analysis, but there is no alteration in their form by the gender, etc., of the other word,

original: natthi, tasmā abyayarūpattā idha gahitāni, sabbañcetaṃ asaṅkhyasamāsapadaṃ nāma napuṃsakaṃ
analyzed: na atthi tasmai abyaya rūpa ttā idha gahitāni sabbañca itam asaṅkhya samāsa padam nāma napuṃsakam
translated: and so they are included here as invariable words. And all this is called a “copulative compound with an indeclinable first member” and it is neuter

original: eva hoti, rassantameva hoti. Sabbavibhattīnañca akārantamhā bahulaṃ aṃ hoti, ikārukārantehi lopo hoti.
analyzed: eva hoti rassa antam eva hoti sabba vibhattīnam ca akāra antamhā bahulam aṃ hoti ikāra ukāra antehi lopaḥ hoti
translated: and it is short. And in the case of all the case-endings, a is the ending in the locative case, and the other endings are lost.

original: Abyayībhāvasamāso niṭṭhito.
analyzed: abyayībhāva samāsaḥ niṭṭhito
translated: The invariable compound is ended.

original: Tappurisasamāsa
analyzed: tappurisa samāsa
translated: The tappurisa compound

original: Dutiyātappurisa🔽Atha amādisamāso vuccate, so tappurisoti ca vuccati. Tassa puriso tappuriso, tappurisasaddena🔽sadisattā ayaṃ samāso tappurisoti vuccati. Yathā hi tappurisasaddo visesanapadatthaṃ
analyzed: dutiyā tappurisa  atha am ādi samāsaḥ vuccate saḥ tad purisaḥ iti ca vuccati tassa puriso tad purisaḥ tad purisa saddena  sadisa ttā ayam samāso tappuriso ti vuccati yathā hi tappurisa saddaḥ visesana padattham
translated: The second-member tappurisa🔽Now the amādeśa compound is said. It is called the tappurisa. The man of that is the tappurisa. Because of the similarity of the word tappurisa🔽this compound is called the tappurisa. For just as the word tappurisa, abandoning the meaning of a word that specifies,

original: jahitvā visesyapadatthe tiṭṭhati, evaṃ ayaṃ samāsopīti.
analyzed: jahitvā visesya padatthe tiṭṭhati evam ayam samāsaḥ api iti
translated: stands in the meaning of a word that is specified, so does this compound.

analyzed: am ādi ka rū nī caṃ

original: Amādivibhattiyuttaṃ syādyantapadaṃ paṭhamantena syādyantapadena saha ekatthaṃ bhavati,
analyzed: am ādi vibhatti yuttam syādi anta padam paṭhama antena syādi anta padena saha ekattham bhavati
translated: A word ending in a case-ending that is suitable to be followed by am is in apposition with a word ending in a case-ending that is not am.

original: ayañca samāso anvatthavasena “amādisamāso”ti ca “tappurisasamāso”ti ca vuccati. Iminā🔽amādisahitassa vākyassa amādekatthasaññaṃ katvā vuttatthānaṃ vibhattīnaṃ lopo, tato
analyzed: ayam ca samāsaḥ anvattha vasena am ādi samāso ti ca tappurisa samāso ti ca vuccati iminā  am ādi sahitassa vākyassa am āt ekattha saññam katvā vutta tthānam vibhattīnam lopaḥ tatas
translated: And this compound is called “compound beginning with am” and “compound of tappurisa” according to the meaning. By this🔽the case-endings of a sentence accompanied by am are elided after the meaning has been stated by giving the name “am in apposition” to the words,

original: ekatthapadante syādyuppatti hoti.
analyzed: ekattha pada ante hoti
translated: and then the formation of syādyanta occurs at the end of the word in apposition.

original: So pana samāso dutiyātappuriso, tatiyātappuriso, catutthītappuriso, pañcamītappuriso,🔽chaṭṭhītappuriso, sattamītappurisoti chabbidho. Ekamekasmiñcettha “niccasamāso, aniccasamāso”ti
analyzed: saḥ pana samāsaḥ dutiyā tappurisaḥ tatiyā tappurisaḥ catutthī tappurisaḥ pañcamī tappurisaḥ  chaṭṭhī tappuriso sattamī tappuriso ti chabbidhaḥ ekam ekasmin ca ittha nicca samāsaḥ anicca samāsaḥ iti
translated: But that compound is of six kinds: compound of tappurisa with the second case, compound of tappurisa with the third case, compound of tappurisa with the fourth case, compound of tappurisa with the fifth case,🔽compound of tappurisa with the sixth case, compound of tappurisa with the seventh case. And in each of these there is a twofold division

original: ca “luttasamāso, aluttasamāso”ti ca duvidho.
analyzed: ca lutta samāsaḥ a lutta samāsaḥ ti ca duvidhaḥ
translated: into “permanent compound” and “non-permanent compound” and into “compound with a reduplication vowel” and “compound without a reduplication vowel.”

original: Tattha dutiyātappuriso kattuvācakesu gata, nissita,-atīta, atikkanta, patta, āpannaiccādīsu paresu hoti.
analyzed: tattha dutiyā tappurisaḥ kattu vācakesu gata nissita atīta atikkanta patta āpanna e c ādīsu paresu hoti
translated: Herein, the compound of tappurisa with the second case occurs with the others among the words gata, nissita, atīta, atikkanta, patta, āpanna, etc., which express the doing of an action.

original: Gāmaṃ gatoti gāmagato gāmaṃ gato vā. Evaṃ araññagato, bhūmigato, rājānaṃ nissitoti
analyzed: gāmam gataḥ iti gāma gataḥ gāmam gataḥ vā evam arañña gataḥ bhūmi gataḥ rājānam nissitoti
translated: Gone to the village: gone to the village, or gone in the village. So gone to the forest, gone to the ground, dependent on a king,

original: rājanissito. Evaṃ atthanissito, dhammanissito. Bhavaṃ atīto bhavātīto. Evaṃ bhayātīto,
analyzed: rāja nissitaḥ evam attha nissitaḥ dhamma nissitaḥ bhavam atītaḥ bhava atītaḥ evam bhaya atītaḥ
translated: dependent on a meaning, dependent on a rule, passed beyond being, passed beyond fear,

original: kālātīto, khaṇātīto, pamāṇaṃ atikkantoti pamāṇātikkanto, sukhaṃ pattoti sukhappatto.🔽Evaṃ dukkhappatto, sotaṃ āpannoti sotāpanno. Evaṃ nirodhasamāpanno, addhānamaggaṃ🔽paṭipannoti addhānamaggappaṭipanno, rukkhaṃ ārūḷhoti rukkhārūḷho, rathārūḷho, oghaṃ
analyzed: kāla atītaḥ khaṇa atītaḥ pamāṇam atikkanto ti pamāṇa atikkanto sukham patto ti sukha ppatto  evam dukkha ppatto sotam āpanno ti sotāpannaḥ evam nirodha samāpannaḥ addhāna maggam  paṭipanno ti addhāna magga ppaṭipannaḥ rukkham ārūḍhaḥ ti rukkha ārūḍhaḥ ratha ārūḍhaḥ ogham
translated: passed beyond time, passed beyond moment, passed beyond measure: passed beyond measure, attained bliss: attained bliss, attained pain, attained cessation,🔽entered upon the path of the road: entered upon the path of the road, climbed a tree: climbed a tree, mounted a chariot, crossed the flood,

original: tiṇṇoti oghatiṇṇo oghaṃ tiṇṇo vā iccādi.
analyzed: tiṇṇaḥ ti ogha tiṇṇaḥ ogham tiṇṇaḥ vā iccādi
translated: crossed the flood, and so on.

original: Kammupapadavihitehi kitantapadehi pana niccasamāsoyeva, kumbhaṃ karotīti kumbhakāro,
analyzed: kamma upapada vihitehi ki tanta padehi pana kumbham karoti iti kumbhakāro
translated: But with the words kitanta formed by the addition of the verbal suffix -anta to the past participle in -a, the compound is always a dvanda, as in: he makes a pot: a potter,

original: rathakāro, pattaṃ gaṇhātīti pattaggāho, atthaṃ kāmetīti atthakāmo, dhammakāmo, vinayaṃ
analyzed: rathakāraḥ pattam gaṇhāti iti pattaggāhaḥ attham kāmeti iti attha kāmo dhamma kāmo vinayam
translated: a chariot-maker, he takes a bowl: a bowl-holder, he desires a meaning: meaning-desiring, desiring a rule, desiring the Discipline,

original: dhāretīti vinayadharo, dhammadharo, brahmaṃ carati sīlenāti brahmacārī, bhavapāraṃ
analyzed: vinaya dharaḥ dhamma dharaḥ brahmam carati sīlena ati brahmacārī bhava pāram
translated: “He bears” (dhāreti) means “one who bears the Monastic Law” (vinayadhara), “one who bears the Teaching” (dhammadhara). “He lives the spiritual life” (brahmacārī) means “he lives the spiritual life of purity” (brahmaṃ carati sīlena). “He has gone beyond existence” (bhavapāraṃ gata) means “he has gone beyond the world” (lokapāraṃ gata).

original: gacchati sīlenāti bhavapāragū, sabbaṃ jānātīti sabbaññū, atthaññū, dhammaññūiccādi.
analyzed: gacchati sīlena ati bhava pāragū sabbam jānāti iti sabbaññū atthaññū dhammaññū iccādi
translated: He bears, thus he is a Vinaya-bearer, a Dhamma-bearer. He goes by means of virtue to the Brahma-world, thus he is a Brahma-farer. He goes by means of virtue to the far shore of becoming, thus he is one who has gone to the far shore of becoming. He knows all, thus he is all-knowing, a knower of the good, a knower of the Dhamma, and so on.

original: Bahulādhikārattā ta, tavantu, tāvī, anta, māna, tuna, tvāna, tvā, tuṃ, tavepaccayantesu
analyzed: ta tavantu tāvī anta māna tuna tvāna tvā tum
translated: In the case of the following postpositions, namely, -tā, -tve, -tvaṃ, -tāva, -tāni, -tāne, -tāsi, -tāse, -tāy, -tāyāti, -tā, -tuṃ, -tave,

original: paresu samāso na hoti, vassaṃ vuttho, odanaṃ bhutto, odanaṃ bhuttavā, odanaṃ bhuttāvī,
analyzed: paresu samāsaḥ na hoti vassam vutthaḥ odanam bhuttaḥ odanam bhuttavā odanam bhuttāvī
translated: the compound is not made, as follows: He has lived for a year, he has eaten rice, he has eaten and gone, he has eaten and gone away,

original: dhammaṃ suṇanto, dhammaṃ suṇamāno dhammaṃ sotuna, dhammaṃ sutvāna, dhammaṃ sutvā,
analyzed: dhammam suṇantaḥ dhammam suṇamānaḥ dhammam sotuna dhammam sutvāna dhammam sutvā
translated: he is listening to the Dhamma, he is hearing the Dhamma, he is listening to the Dhamma, he has listened to the Dhamma, he has listened to the Dhamma,

original: dhammaṃ sotuṃ, dhammaṃ sotave.
analyzed: dhammam sotum dhammam sotave
translated: he is listening to the Dhamma, he is listening to the Dhamma.

original: Iti dutiyātappuriso.
analyzed: iti dutiyātappurisaḥ
translated: Thus the second-case pattern.

original: Tatiyātappurisa
analyzed: tatiya atappurisa
translated: The third-case pattern

original: Tatiyātappuriso kammavācakesu kitantesu ca sampanna, sahagatādīsu ca pubba, sadisa, sama, ūnattha, kalaha, nipuṇa,-missaka, sakhilādīsu ca paresu hoti.
analyzed: tatiyā tappurisaḥ kamma vācakesu kit antesu ca sampanna sahagata ādīsu ca pubba sadisa sama ūnattha kalaha nipuṇa missaka sa khila ādīsu ca paresu hoti
translated: The third-case pattern is found in the case of the following postpositions, namely, -tāya, -tāyaṃ, -tāyaṃ, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -tāya, -

original: Buddhena bhāsito buddhabhāsito. Evaṃ buddhadesito, buddhapaññatto, buddharakkhito,
analyzed: buddhena bhāsitaḥ buddha bhāsitaḥ evam buddha desitaḥ buddha paññattaḥ buddha rakkhito
translated: Spoken by the Buddha is buddha-bhāsita. Thus taught by the Buddha, declared by the Buddha, protected by the Buddha,

original: satthārā vaṇṇito satthuvaṇṇito, viññūhi garahito viññugarahito, viññupasattho, issarena
analyzed: satthārā vaṇṇito satthu vaṇṇitaḥ viññūhi garahitaḥ viññu garahitaḥ viññu pasattho issarena
translated: Praised by the Teacher is satthu-vaṇṇita. Censured by the wise is viññugarahita. Esteemed by the wise is viññu-pasattha.

original: kataṃ issarakataṃ, attanā kataṃ sayaṃkataṃ, parehi kataṃ paraṃkataṃ, bindāgamo. Sukehi
analyzed: katam issara katam attanā katam sayaṃkatam parehi katam paraṃkatam bindāgamaḥ sukehi
translated: Done by the Lord is issara-kata. Done by oneself is sayaṃ-kata. Done by others is paraṃ-kata. The coming together of the dots is bindāgama.

original: āhaṭaṃ sukāhaṭaṃ, raññā hato rājahato, rogena pīḷito rogapīḷito, agginā daḍḍho aggidaḍḍho,
analyzed: āhaṭam sukāhaṭam raññā hataḥ rāja hataḥ rogena pīḍitaḥ roga pīḍitaḥ agginā daḍḍhaḥ aggi daḍḍhaḥ
translated: Brought by the swans is suka-āhata. Killed by the king is rāja-hata. Afflicted by disease is roga-pīḷita. Burned by fire is aggi-daḍḍha.

original: sappena daṭṭho sappadaṭṭho, sallena viddho sallaviddho, icchāya apakato abhibhūto icchāpakato.
analyzed: sappena daṭṭhaḥ sappa daṭṭhaḥ sallena viddhaḥ salla viddhaḥ icchāya apakataḥ abhibhūtaḥ icchā apakataḥ
translated: Bitten by a snake is sappa-daṭṭha. Pierced by an arrow is salla-viddha. Overcome by desire is icchā-pakata.

original: Sīlena sampanno sīlasampanno. Evaṃ sukhasahagataṃ, ñāṇasampayuttaṃ, mittasaṃsaggo,
analyzed: sīlena sampannaḥ sīla sampannaḥ evam sukha sahagatam ñāṇa sampayuttam mitta saṃsaggo
translated: Endowed with virtue is sīla-sampanna. Thus accompanied by pleasure, associated with knowledge, association with friends,

original: piyasampayogo, piyavippayogo, jātiyā andho jaccandho, guṇahīno, guṇavuḍḍho, catuvaggena
analyzed: piya sampayogaḥ piya vippayogaḥ jātiyāḥ andhaḥ jaccandhaḥ guṇa hīnaḥ guṇa vuḍḍhaḥ catuvaggena
translated: Union with the dear one, separation from the dear one, blind from birth is jaccandho, lacking in virtue is guṇa-hīno, increased in virtue is guṇa-vuḍḍho, with a group of four

original: saṅghena karaṇīyaṃ kammaṃ catuvaggakaraṇīyaṃ. Evaṃ pañcavaggakaraṇīyaṃ, kākehi peyyā kākapeyyā, nadī.🔽Ekakkharesu parapadesu niccasamāso, urena gacchatīti urago, pādena pivatīti pādapo iccādi.
analyzed: saṅghena karaṇīyam kammam catu vagga karaṇīyam evam pañca vagga karaṇīyam kākehi peyyā kāka peyyā nadī  eka akkharesu para padesu nicca samāsaḥ urena gacchati iti uragaḥ pādena pivati iti pādapaḥ iccādi
translated: A legal issue that the Sangha should resolve is a legal issue that should be resolved by a group of four.🔽In the same way, a legal issue that should be resolved by a group of five is called a “legal issue that should be resolved by a group of five.”🔽In the words kākehi peyyā and nadī, the first word is compounded with the second word.

original: Kvaci majjhepadalopo, guḷena saṃsaṭṭho odano guḷodano. Evaṃ khīrodano, assena yutto🔽ratho assaratho. Evaṃ ājaññaratho, maggena sampayuttaṃ cittaṃ maggacittaṃ, jambuyā🔽paññāto dīpo jambudīpo, ekena adhikā dasa ekādasa iccādi.🔽Pubbādīsu – māsena pubbo māsapubbo, mātarā sadiso mātusadiso. Evaṃ mātusamo, pitusamo,🔽ekena ūnā vīsati ekūnavīsati, sīlena vikalo sīlavikalo, asinā kalaho asikalaho, vācāya
analyzed: kvaci majjhe pada lopaḥ guḷena saṃsaṭṭhaḥ odanaḥ guḷodanaḥ evam khīrodanaḥ assena yuttaḥ  rathaḥ assa rathaḥ evam ājañña rathaḥ maggena sampayuttam cittam magga cittam jambuyā  paññātaḥ dīpaḥ jambudīpo ekena adhikāḥ dasa ekādasa iccādi  pubba ādīsu māsena pubbaḥ māsa pubbaḥ mātarā sadisaḥ mātu sadisaḥ evam mātu samaḥ pitu samaḥ  ekena ūnā vīsati ekūnavīsati sīlena vikalaḥ sīla vikalaḥ asinā kalahaḥ asi kalahaḥ vācāya
translated: In the words urago and pādapo, the first word is compounded with the second word, but the middle part is omitted.🔽In the words guḷodano, khīrodano, assaratho, ājaññaratho, maggacittaṃ, jambudīpo, and ekādasa, the first word is compounded with the second word, but the middle part is omitted.

original: nipuṇo vācānipuṇo. Evaṃ yāvakālikasammissaṃ, vācāsakhilo, satthārā sadiso satthukappo,
analyzed: nipuṇaḥ vācā nipuṇaḥ evam yāvakālika sammissam vācā sakhilaḥ satthārā sadisaḥ satthu kappo
translated: In the words māsapubbo, mātusadiso, mātusamo, pitusamo, ekūnavīsati, sīlavikalo, asikalaho, vācānipuṇo, vācāsakhilo, and satthukappo, the first word is compounded with the second word, but the middle part is omitted.

original: puññena attho puññattho, puññena atthiko puññatthiko. Evaṃ seyyatthiko, mahagghatthiko,
analyzed: puññena attho puññattho puññena atthiko puññatthiko evam seyyatthikaḥ mahagghatthikaḥ
translated: One who needs merit is a merit-seeker, one who needs merit is a merit-seeker. So too: one who needs what is good, one who needs what is valuable,

original: guṇena adhiko guṇādhiko iccādi.
analyzed: guṇena adhikaḥ guṇa adhikaḥ iccādi
translated: One who is superior in virtue is a virtue-superior.

original: Bahulādhikārā kvaci samāso na hoti, pharasunā chinnaṃ, kākehi pātabbā, dassanena pahātabbā dhammā, bhāvanāya pahātabbā dhammā iccādi.
analyzed: bahula adhikārā kvaci samāsaḥ na hoti pharasunā chinnam kākehi pātabbāḥ dassanena pahātabbāḥ dhammāḥ bhāvanāya pahātabbāḥ dhammāḥ iccādi
translated: But in some instances there is no compound even though there is predominance of the bahubbīhi, as in the following: cut with an axe, to be pecked by crows, ideas to be abandoned by seeing, ideas to be abandoned by development.

original: Iti tatiyātappuriso.
analyzed: iti tatiyātappurisaḥ
translated: So much for the third type of masculine noun.

original: Catutthītappurisa
analyzed: catutthī tappurisa

analyzed: catutthī tappurisaḥ tad atthe vā attha hita deyya ādīsu vā paresu hoti  kathinassa dussam kathina dussam kathina tthāya ābhaṭam dussanti evam kathina cīvaram  kathināya dussam kathināya cīvarantipi yujjati kathinatthārāya ati cīvarāya
translated: A masculine noun of the fourth type is a word meaning “for the sake of” that or a word meaning “for the sake of” another, as in the following:🔽Cloth for the kaṭhina is kaṭhina-cloth. original: Pañcamītappurisa

translated: The fifth

original: Pañcamītappuriso apagamana, bhaya, virati, mocanādiatthesu paresu hoti.🔽Methunā apetoti methunāpeto, palāsato apagatoti palāsāpagato, nagaramhā niggatoti
analyzed: pañcamītappurisaḥ apagamana bhaya virati mocana ādi atthesu paresu hoti  methunāḥ apetaḥ uti methuna apetaḥ palāsataḥ apagataḥ uti palāsa apagataḥ nagaramhā niggataḥ iti
translated: The fifth is in the sense of going away, fear, abstinence, release, and so on.

original: nagaraniggato, piṇḍapātato paṭikkantoti piṇḍapātappaṭikkanto. Evaṃ gāmanikkhanto,🔽rukkhapatito, sāsanamhā cutoti sāsanacuto, āpattiyā vuṭṭhānaṃ āpattivuṭṭhānaṃ, udakato

translated: He is free from sexual intercourse: he is free from sexual intercourse. He has gone away from the forest: he has gone away from the forest. He has gone out from the town: he has gone out from the town. He has returned from his alms round: he has returned from his alms round. Thus he has gone out from the village,

original: uggato udakuggato, bhavato nissaṭo bhavanissaṭo, khandhasaṅgahato nissaṭanti khandhasaṅgahanissaṭaṃ,🔽coramhā bhītoti corabhīto, pāpato bhāyati sīlenāti pāpabhīruko, pāpato jigucchati🔽sīlenāti pāpajigucchī, vaṭṭato nibbindatīti vaṭṭanibbinno, kāyaduccaritato virati

He has gone away from the aggregate of clinging: he has gone away from the aggregate of clinging.🔽He is afraid of thieves: he is afraid of thieves. He fears evil through virtue: he fears evil. He is disgusted with evil through virtue: he is disgusted with evil. He is dispassionate towards the round: he is dispassionate towards the round. He abstains from bodily misconduct: he abstains from bodily misconduct. Thus he abstains from verbal misconduct,

original: kāyaduccaritavirati. Evaṃ vacīduccaritavirati, bandhanā mutto bandhanamutto. Evaṃ
analyzed: kāya duccarita virati evam vacī duccarita virati bandhanāḥ muttaḥ bandhana muttaḥ evam

original: Chaṭṭhītappurisa

original: Samāsamajjhe ī, ūnaṃ bahulaṃ rassattaṃ, daṇḍino kulaṃ daṇḍikulaṃ, hatthipadaṃ, itthirūpaṃ,
analyzed: samāsa majjhe ī ūnam bahulam rassattam daṇḍino kulam daṇḍi kulam hatthi padam itthi rūpam
translated: In the middle of samāna, ī is short, ū is long, and ra is frequent. Daṇḍi-kula is a family of stick-holders. Hatthi-pada is an elephant’s foot. Itthi-rūpa is a woman’s form.

original: nadikūlaṃ, naditīraṃ, bhikkhunīnaṃ saṅgho bhikkhunisaṅgho, jambuyā sākhā jambusākhā iccādi.
analyzed: nadi kūlam nadi tīram bhikkhunīnam saṅghaḥ bhikkhuni saṅghaḥ jambuyā sākhā jambu sākhā iccādi
translated: Nadi-kūla is a river-bank. Nadi-tīra is a river-bank. Bhikkhu-nīnaṃ saṅgho is the Community of nuns. Jambu-sākhā is a branch of the rose-apple tree.

original: Anta, māna, niddhāraṇiya, pūraṇa, bhāva, suhitatthehi samāso na hoti, mamaṃ anukubbanto,
analyzed: anta māna niddhāraṇiya pūraṇa bhāva suhitatthehi samāsaḥ na hoti anukubbanto
translated: The compound is not made with the words anta, māna, niddhāraṇiya, pūraṇa, bhāva, and suhita. Anukubbanto is in conformity with me.

original: mamaṃ anukurumāno, gunnaṃ kaṇhā sampannakhīratamā. Vibhattāvadhichaṭṭhiyā pana hotiyeva,
analyzed: anukurumānaḥ gunnam kaṇhā sampanna khīratamā pana
translated: Anukurumāno is favouring me. Gunnaṃ kaṇhā is the black of the cows. But with the sixth case ending in the Vibhatti, it is made:

original: narānaṃ uttamo naruttamo, naraseṭṭho, naravaro, gaṇānaṃ uttamo gaṇuttamo, dvipadānaṃ🔽uttamo dvipaduttamo iccādi. Sissānaṃ pañcamo sisso, kappassa tatiyo bhāgo, pakkhassa
analyzed: narānam uttamaḥ naruttamaḥ naraseṭṭhaḥ naravaraḥ gaṇānam uttamaḥ gaṇuttamaḥ dvipadānam  uttamaḥ dvipad uttamaḥ iccādi sissānam pañcamaḥ sisso kappassa tatiyaḥ bhāgaḥ pakkhassa
translated: Narānaṃ uttamo is the best of men. Naruttamo is the best of men. Naraseṭṭho is the best of men. Naravaro is the best of men. Gaṇānaṃ uttamo is the best of the groups. Dvipadānaṃ uttamo is the best of the bipeds.

original: aṭṭhamī, paṭassa sukkatā, rūpassa lahutā, rūpassa mudutā, rūpassa kammaññatā. Kvaci
analyzed: aṭṭhamī paṭassa sukka tā rūpassa lahu tā rūpassa mudu tā rūpassa kammañña tā kvaci
translated: Sisso is the fifth of the pupils. Kappa-tatiyo bhāgo is the third part of the aeon. Pakkha-aṭṭhamī is the eighth of the fortnight. Paṭa-sukkatā is the whiteness of the cloth. Rūpa-lahutā is the lightness of the form. Rūpa-mudutā is the softness of the form. Rūpa-kammaññatā is the workableness of the form. In some cases,

original: hoti, kāyalahutā, cittalahutā, buddhasubuddhatā. Dhammasudhammatā, phalānaṃ suhito,
analyzed: hoti kāya lahu tā citta lahu tā buddha su buddha tā dhamma su dhamma tā phalānam su hitaḥ
translated: it is made: Kāya-lahutā is the lightness of the body. Citta-lahutā is the lightness of the mind. Buddha-subuddhatā is the well-awakenedness of the Buddha. Dhammā-sudhammatā is the well-dhammahood of the Dhamma. Phala-suhito is the well-fruitedness of the fruit.

original: phalānaṃ titto, phalānaṃ asito, karaṇatthe chaṭṭhī.
analyzed: phalānam tittaḥ phalānam asitaḥ karaṇa atthe chaṭṭhī
translated: He is satisfied with the fruits, he is not hungry for the fruits. The sixth case is used in the sense of instrument.

original: “Bhaṭo rañño putto devadattassā”ti ettha ‘rājaputto’ti na hoti aññamaññānapekkhattā.
analyzed: bhaṭaḥ rañño putto devadattassa ti ettha rāja putto ti na hoti aññamañña an apekkha ttā
translated: “The king’s son, Devadatta’s son” : here it is not “the king’s son” because of the mutual dependence.

original: “Devadattassa kaṇhā dantā”ti ettha ‘devadattakaṇhadantā’ti na hoti aññasāpekkhattā
analyzed: devadattassa kaṇhāḥ dantā ati ettha devadatta kaṇha dantā ati na hoti añña sāpekkha ttā
translated: “Devadatta’s black teeth” : here it is not “Devadatta’s black teeth” because of the dependence on another.

original: nī. 690. Aññasāpekkhattepi niccaṃ sambandhīpekkhasaddānaṃ samāso hoti vākye viya
analyzed: nī añña sāpekkha tte pi niccam sambandhi ipekkha saddānam samāsaḥ hoti vākye
translated: Even when there is dependence on another, there is a compound of the words “always” and “relative” as in a sentence,

original: samāsepi sambandhassa viditattā. Vuttañca “satipi sāpekkhatte gamakattā samāso hotī”ti🔽ka. 328; rū. 352; nī. 691, devadattagurukulaṃ, rājadāsīputto, devadāsīputto iccādi.🔽Tattha devadattassa guru devadattaguru, tassa kulaṃ devadattagurukulanti viggaho.
analyzed: samāse pi sambandhassa vidita ttā vuttam ca sati pi sāpekkha tte gamaka ttā samāsaḥ hoti iti  devadatta guru kulam rāja dāsī puttaḥ deva dāsī puttaḥ iccādi  tattha devadattassa guru devadatta guru tassa kulam devadatta guru kulam iti viggahaḥ
translated: because the relation is known even in a compound. And it is said: “Even when there is dependence, there is a compound because of the inclusive nature.”🔽Devadatta’s teacher’s family, the king’s slave’s son, Devadatta’s slave’s son, and so on.🔽Here Devadatta’s teacher is Devadatta’s teacher, his family is Devadatta’s teacher’s family. The analysis is thus.

original: Guruno kulaṃ gurukulaṃ, devadattassa gurukulaṃ devadattagurukulantipi vadanti. “Rañño
analyzed: guruno kulam guru kulam devadattassa guru kulam devadatta guru kulam ipi vadanti rañño
translated: The teacher’s family is teacher’s family, Devadatta’s teacher’s family is also said to be Devadatta’s teacher’s family. “The king’s

original: māgadhassa bimbisārassa putto”ti etthapi aññasāpekkhattā ‘bimbisāraputto’ti na hoti,🔽rañño go ca asso ca puriso cāti atthe ‘rājagavassapurisā’ti hoti dvandato pubbapadassa🔽dvandapadehipi paccekaṃ sambandhassa viditattā. Tathā dvandato parapadassapi, narānañca
analyzed: māgadhassa bimbisārassa putto ti ettha api añña sāpekkha ttā bimbisāra putto ti na hoti  raññaḥ go ca asso ca puriso ca ati atthe rājagavassapurisāti hoti dvandataḥ pubba padassa  dvanda padehi pi paccekam sambandhassa vidita ttā tathā dvandato para padassa pi
translated: and in the case of “the son of Magadha Bimbisāra” it is not “the son of Bimbisāra” because of the expectation of another.🔽But in the case of “the king’s cow, horse, and man” it is “the king’s cow, horse, and man” because of the connection of each with the second member of the compound.

original: devānañca sārathi naradevasārathi.
analyzed: devānañca sārathi naradeva sārathi
translated: And so too in the case of the second member of the compound, as in “charioteer of men and gods” .

original: Iti chaṭṭhītappuriso.
analyzed: iti chaṭṭhī tappurisaḥ
translated: So the sixth-case phrase ends here.

original: Sattamītappurisa
analyzed: sattamī tappurisa
translated: Seventh-case phrase

original: Sattamītappurise rūpe saññā rūpasaññā. Ettha ca kārakānaṃ kriyāsādhanalakkhaṇattā
analyzed: sattamī tappurise rūpe saññā rūpa saññā ettha ca kārakānam kriyā sādhana lakkhaṇa ttā
translated: In the case of the seventh-case phrase, perception of materiality is “rūpa-saññā” . And here the connection is with the verbal expression of the action because the function of the factors is the accomplishment of the action.

original: kriyāpadeheva sambandho hoti, tasmā akriyavācakena parapadena saddhiṃ samāse jāte
analyzed: sambandhaḥ tasmai akriya vācakena para padena saddhim samāse jāte
translated: So when a compound is formed with a second member that does not express an action,

original: majjhe anurūpaṃ kriyāpadaṃ viññāyati, yathā ‘assena yutto ratho assaratho’ iti ‘rūpe
analyzed: majjhe anurūpam kriyā padam viññāyati yathā assena yuttaḥ rathaḥ assa rathaḥ iti rūpe
translated: a verbal expression of the action is understood in the middle, as in “chariot yoked with horses” , where the meaning is “a chariot yoked with horses,” and as in “perception of materiality” , where the meaning is “perception arisen in regard to materiality.”

original: saññā’ti rūpe uppannā saññāti attho. Cakkhusmiṃ viññāṇaṃ cakkhuviññāṇaṃ, dhamme rato
analyzed: saññā ati rūpe uppannā saññā iti attho cakkhusmim viññāṇam cakkhu viññāṇam dhamme rataḥ
translated: Consciousness in the eye is “eye-consciousness” . One who delights in states is “dhammārāmo” .

original: dhammarato. Evaṃ dhammaruci, dhammagāravo, dāne ajjhāsayo dānajjhāsayo. Evaṃ dānādhimutti,
analyzed: dhamma rataḥ evam dhamma ruci dhamma gāravaḥ dāne ajjhāsayaḥ dāna ajjhāsayaḥ evam dāna adhimutti
translated: One who delights in Dhamma. Thus one who delights in Dhamma, one who respects Dhamma, one who is intent on giving, one who is intent on giving. Thus one who is resolved on giving,

original: vaṭṭe bhayaṃ vaṭṭabhayaṃ, vaṭṭadukkhaṃ, gāme sūkaro gāmasūkaro, vanamahiṃso, samuddamaccho,
analyzed: vaṭṭe bhayam vaṭṭa bhayam vaṭṭa dukkham gāme sūkaraḥ gāma sūkaraḥ vana mahiṃsaḥ samudda macchaḥ
translated: Fear of the round, fear of the round, suffering in the round, a pig in a village, a wild buffalo, a fish in the ocean,

original: itthīsu dhutto itthidhutto, itthisoṇḍo.
analyzed: itthīsu dhuttaḥ itthidhuttaḥ itthisoṇḍo
translated: A libertine among women, a womaniser, a woman-thief.

original: Upapadakitantesu niccasamāso nī. 682, vane caratīti vanacaro, kāmāvacaro, kucchimhi
analyzed: upapada kit antesu nicca samāsaḥ nī vane carati iti vana caraḥ kāmāvacaraḥ kucchimhi
translated: In the case of those born in the womb, the compound is always made: a cow, a deer. One who moves in the forest, a forest-goer, one who moves in sense-desire, one who lies in the womb,

original: sayatīti kucchissayo, gabbhe setīti gabbhaseyyo, thale tiṭṭhatīti thalaṭṭho, jalaṭṭho,
analyzed: sayati iti kucchissayaḥ gabbhe seti iti gabbhaseyyaḥ thale tiṭṭhati iti thalaṭṭhaḥ jalaṭṭhaḥ
translated: One who lies in the womb, one who lies in the womb, one who stands on the ground, one who stands in the water,

original: pabbataṭṭho, paṅke jātaṃ paṅkajaṃ. Evaṃ atrajo, khetrajo iccādi. Idha na hoti nī.
analyzed: pabbata ṭṭhaḥ paṅke jātam paṅka jam evam atra jaḥ khetra jaḥ iccādi idha na hoti
translated: One who stands on the mountain, a lotus born in the mud. Thus one born in that place, one born in the field, and so on. Here it is not: a cow, a deer.

original: 681, bhojane mattaññutā, indriyesu guttadvāro, āsane nisinno, āsane nisīditabbaṃ.
analyzed: bhojane mattaññu tā indriyesu gutta dvāraḥ āsane nisinnaḥ āsane nisīditabbam
translated: Moderation in food, one who guards the doors of the sense faculties, seated on a seat, one should sit on a seat.

original: Iti sattamītappuriso.
analyzed: iti sattamī tappurisaḥ
translated: Thus a man of the seventh class.

original: Luttatappurisa
analyzed: lut tap purisa
translated: A man of the lowest class

original: Tappurisapadānaṃ mahāvuttisuttena kvaci vipallāso.
analyzed: tappurisa padānam mahāvutti suttena kvaci vipallāsaḥ
translated: In some cases there is inversion of the words of the man of the lowest class by the Mahāvagga Sutta.

original: Uparigaṅgā, heṭṭhānadī, antovihāro, antosamāpatti, haṃsānaṃ rājā rājahaṃso haṃsarājā
analyzed: uparigaṅgā heṭṭhānadī antovihāraḥ antosamāpatti haṃsānam rājā rājahaṃsaḥ haṃsarājā
translated: The upper Ganges, the lower river, the inside of the monastery, the inside of the attainment, the king of the geese, the royal goose, the goose-king,

original: vā, māsassa aḍḍhaṃ aḍḍhamāsaṃ, kahāpaṇassa aḍḍhaṃ aḍḍhakahāpaṇaṃ, aḍḍhamāsaṃ, rattiyā🔽aḍḍhaṃ aḍḍharattaṃ. Evaṃ pubbarattaṃ, pararattaṃ, issa attaṃ. Kāyassa pubbabhāgo
analyzed: vā māsassa aḍḍham aḍḍha māsam kahāpaṇassa aḍḍham aḍḍha kahāpaṇam aḍḍha māsam rattiyā  aḍḍham aḍḍha rattam evam pubba rattam para rattam issa attam kāyassa pubba bhāgaḥ
translated: half a month, a half-month, half a kahāpaṇa, a half-kahāpaṇa, half a night,🔽half a watch of the night, in the first watch, in the last watch, the self of the self, the front part of the body,

original: pubbakāyo, parakāyo, ahassa pubbo pubbaṇho, majjhaṇho, sāyanho, pubbediṭṭho diṭṭhapubbo,
analyzed: pubba kāyaḥ para kāyaḥ ahassa pubbaḥ pubbaṇhaḥ majjhaṇhaḥ sāyanhaḥ pubbediṭṭhaḥ diṭṭha pubbaḥ
translated: the front part of the body, the back part of the body, the dawn of the day, the forenoon, the afternoon, what was seen before,

original: tathāgataṃ diṭṭhapubbo thero, tathāgato diṭṭhapubbo therena iccādi.
analyzed: tathāgatam diṭṭha pubbaḥ thero tathāgataḥ diṭṭha pubbaḥ therena iccādi
translated: one who has seen the Tathāgata before, the elder, the Tathāgata who has been seen before by the elder, and so on.

original: Iti luttatappuriso.
analyzed: iti lutta tappurisaḥ
translated: Thus, a person who is bent over.

original: Aluttatappurisa
analyzed: a l ut ta p purisa
translated: A person who is not bent over

original: Idāni aluttatappurisā vuccante.
analyzed: idāni alutta tappurisāḥ vuccante
translated: Now, those who are not bent over are mentioned.

original: Dīpaṅkaro, pabhaṅkaro, amatandado, purindado, vessantaro, attantapo, parantapo, raṇañjaho,
analyzed: dīpaṅkaro pabhaṅkaro amatandadaḥ purindadaḥ vessantaraḥ attantapo parantapaḥ raṇañjaho
translated: Dīpaṅkara, Pabhaṅkara, Amatandada, Purindada, Vessantara, Attantapa, Parantapa, Raṇañjaha,

original: jutindharo, vijjandharo, dassanenapahātabbadhammo, kutojo, tatojo, itojo, bhayato
analyzed: jutindharaḥ vijjandharaḥ dassanena apahātabba dhammo kutojaḥ tatojaḥ itojaḥ bhayataḥ
translated: Jutindhara, Vijjandhara, a thing to be abandoned by seeing, one born from somewhere, one born from there, one born from here, from fear,

original: upaṭṭhānaṃ bhayatupaṭṭhānaṃ, kaṭattākammaṃ, kaṭattārūpaṃ, parassapadaṃ, attanopadaṃ,
analyzed: upaṭṭhānam kaṭattā kammam kaṭattā rūpam parassa padam attano padam
translated: The basis, the basis of fear, the action of the doing, the visible form of the doing, the words of another, the words of oneself,

original: devānamindo, devānaṃpiyatisso, gavampatitthero, pubbenivāso, majjhekalyāṇaṃ, dūrerūpaṃ,
analyzed: devānamindaḥ devānaṃpiya tissaḥ gavampati theraḥ pubbenivāsaḥ majjhe kalyāṇam dūrerūpam
translated: The Lord of the Gods, dear to the gods, the Elder Gavampati, the previous life, the middle good, the distant visible form,

original: santikerūpaṃ, dūrenidānaṃ, santikenidānaṃ, antevāsiko, janesuto, kāmesumicchācāro
analyzed: santikerūpam dūrenidānam santikenidānam antevāsikaḥ janesutaḥ kāmesu micchā ācāraḥ
translated: The near visible form, the distant source, the near source, the pupil, the son of the people, sexual misconduct,

original: iccādi ka. 327; rū. 351; nī. 686.
analyzed: i t ca ādi ka rū nī
translated: and so on.

original: Iti aluttatappuriso.
analyzed: iti a lutta tap purisaḥ
translated: Thus, the person is not first.

original: Sabbo cāyaṃ amāditappuriso abhidheyyavacano parapadaliṅgo ca.
analyzed: sabbaḥ ca ayam am ādi tappurisaḥ abhidheyya vacano para pada liṅgo ca
translated: And all this person is first in the sense of a name, and has the gender of a word for another.

original: Amāditappuriso niṭṭhito.
analyzed: niṭṭhito
translated: The person is first in the sense of not being first is finished.

original: Kammadhārayasamāsa
analyzed: kammadhāraya samāsa
translated: The compound called a kammadhāraya

original: Atha kammadhārayasaññito paṭhamātappuriso vuccate.🔽Kammamiva dvayaṃ dhāretīti kammadhārayo. Yathā kammaṃ kriyañca payojanañca dvayaṃ
analyzed: atha kammadhāraya saññitaḥ paṭhamā tappurisaḥ vuccate  kammam iva dvayam dhārā iti iti kammadhārayaḥ yathā kammam kriyam ca payojanam ca dvayam
translated: Now, the first person called a kammadhāraya is said to be.🔽It bears a pair like a kamma, thus it is a kammadhāraya. Just as a kamma bears a pair, namely, the action and the purpose,

original: dhāreti kamme sati tassa dvayassa sambhavato, tathā ayaṃ samāso ekassa atthassa dve
analyzed: dhārā iti kamme sati tassa dvayassa sambhavataḥ tathā ayam samāsaḥ ekassa atthassa dve
translated: because when there is a kamma, that pair comes into being, so this compound bears a pair, namely, two meanings,

original: nāmāni dhāreti imasmiṃ samāse sati ekatthajotakassa nāmadvayassa sambhavatoti ka.
analyzed: nāmāni dhārā iti imasmin samāse sati eka attha jotakassa nāma dvayassa sambhavato ti ka
translated: because when this compound is present there is the possibility of a pair of names denoting one meaning.

analyzed: rū nī

original: Api ca kattabbanti kammaṃ, dhāretabbanti dhāriyaṃ, kammañca taṃ dhāriyañcāti kammadhāriyaṃ,
analyzed: api ca kattabbanti kammam dhāretabbanti dhāriyam kammam ca tam dhāriyam ca ati kammadhāriyam
translated: Moreover, what is to be done is action, what is to be borne in mind is what should be borne in mind, and action and what should be borne in mind are action-to-be-borne-in-mind.

original: yaṃkiñci hitakammaṃ, kammadhāriyasaddasadisattā sabbo cāyaṃ samāso kammadhārayoti
analyzed: yaṃ kiñci hita kammam kammadhāriya sadda sadisa ttā sabbaḥ ca ayam samāsaḥ kammadhārayo ti
translated: And because of the similarity to the word action-to-be-borne-in-mind, this whole compound is called action-to-be-borne-in-mind.

original: vuccati issa attaṃ katvā. Yathā hi kammadhāriyasaddo ekassa atthassa dve nāmāni dhāreti,
analyzed: vuccati katvā yathā hi kammadhāriya saddaḥ ekassa atthassa dve nāmāni dhāreti
translated: Just as the word action-to-be-borne-in-mind bears two names for one meaning,
