analyzed: atthaḥ assa ati tad atthaḥ edisaḥ atthaḥ yassa vinayassa ati etad atthaḥ vinayaḥ etad atthā
translated: The meaning of that is the meaning of the Vinaya.

original: vinayakathā. Etadatthaṃ, sotāvadhānaṃ iccādi.
analyzed: vinaya kathā iccādi
translated: The discussion of the Vinaya has that meaning. The listening has that meaning.

original: Iti chaṭṭhībahubbīhi.
analyzed: iti chaṭṭhī bahup bīhi
translated: Thus by the sixth-case locative plural.

original: Sattamībahubbīhi🔽Sampannāni sassāni yasmiṃ janapade soyaṃ sampannasasso, sulabhā bhikkhā yasmiṃ janapade🔽soyaṃ subhikkho, dullabhā bhikkhā yasminti dubbhikkho, bahavo gāmā asmiṃ janapadeti
analyzed: sattamī bahup bīhi  sampannāni sassāni yasmin janapade saḥ ayam sampanna sassaḥ sulabhā bhikkhā yasmin janapade  saḥ ayam subhikkhaḥ dullabhā bhikkhā yasmin ti dubbhikkhaḥ bahavaḥ gāmāḥ asmin janapada iti
translated: By the seventh-case locative plural

original: bahugāmo. Evaṃ bahujano, gāmo. Natthi gāmakhettaṃ yasmiṃ araññe tayidaṃ agāmakaṃ,🔽samāsante ko. Saṃvijjanti manussā yasmiṃ gāme samanusso, na vijjanti manussā yasmiṃ
analyzed: bahu gāmaḥ evam bahu janaḥ gāmaḥ na atthi gāma khettam yasmin araññe tayidam agāmakam  samāsante ko saṃvijjanti manussāḥ yasmin gāme sa manussaḥ na vijjanti manussāḥ yasmin
translated: In the country where the crops are good, that is a good-crop country. In the country where almsfood is easy to get, that is an alms-food country. In the country where almsfood is difficult to get, that is a famine country. In the country where there are many villages, that is a many-villaged country. Thus a many-peopled country. A village field is not in the forest. That is a no-village forest.

original: gāme amanusso iccādi.
analyzed: gāme amanussaḥ iccādi
translated: Thus a no-village forest. In the village where people are found, that is a peopled village. In the village where people are not found, that is a no-people village.

original: Iti sattamībahubbīhi.🔽Bhinnādhikaraṇabahubbīhi
analyzed: iti sattamī bahup bīhi  bhinna adhikaraṇa bahup bīhi
translated: Thus by the seventh-case locative plural.🔽By the locative plural of the case ending for the split-verificatory

original: Bhinnādhikaraṇabahubbīhi nāma vuccati, ekarattiṃ vāso assāti ekarattivāso, samānena
analyzed: bhinna adhikaraṇa bahu bbīhi nāma vuccati eka rattim vāsaḥ assa ati eka ratti vāsaḥ samānena
translated: The locative plural of the case ending for the split-verificatory is said to be: He has a one-night stay, thus a one-night stay. With the same

original: janena saddhiṃ vāso assāti samānavāso, ubhato kammato uppannaṃ byañjanadvayaṃ assāti🔽ubhatobyañjano, aluttasamāso. Evaṃ kaṇṭhasmiṃ kāḷo assāti kaṇṭhekāḷo, urasmiṃ lomāni🔽assāti urasilomo, yassa hatthe patto atthīti pattahattho. Evaṃ asihattho, daṇḍahattho,🔽chattaṃ pāṇimhi assāti chattapāṇi. Evaṃ satthapāṇi, daṇḍapāṇi, vajirapāṇi, dāne ajjhāsayo
analyzed: janena saddhim vāsaḥ assa ati samāna vāsaḥ ubhatas kammataḥ uppannam byañjana dvayam assa ati  ubhatas byañjanaḥ a lutta samāsaḥ evam kaṇṭhasmim kāḷaḥ assa ati kaṇṭhekāḷaḥ urasmim lomāni  assa ati urasi lomaḥ yassa hatthe pattaḥ atthi iti patta hatthaḥ evam asi hatthaḥ daṇḍa hatthaḥ  chattam pāṇimhi assa ati chatta pāṇi evam sattha pāṇi daṇḍa pāṇi vajira pāṇi dāne ajjhāsayo
translated: He has living together with a man, thus he is a man-companion. He has the two genders arisen from the two actions, thus he is a hermaphrodite. The compound is not a dvanda. He has a black throat, thus he is a black-throated. He has hair on the chest, thus he is a hairy-chested. He has a bowl in his hand, thus he is a bowl-in-hand. Thus sword-in-hand, staff-in-hand,🔽He has a sunshade in his hand, thus he is a sunshade-in-hand. Thus sword-in-hand, staff-in-hand, thunderbolt-in-hand, he has a disposition to giving, thus he is a giver.

original: assāti dānajjhāsayo, dānādhimuttiko, buddhesu bhatti assāti buddhabhattiko, buddhe🔽gāravo assāti buddhagāravo, dhammagāravo iccādi.
analyzed: assa ati dāna ajjhāsayaḥ dāna adhimuttikaḥ buddhesu bhatti assa ati buddha bhattikaḥ buddhe  gāravaḥ assa ati buddha gāravaḥ dhamma gāravaḥ iccādi
translated: He has living together with people, thus he is a co-dweller . He has the two genders produced by the action of both, thus he is a hermaphrodite . The compound is not resolved. He has a black throat, thus he is a black-throated. He has hair on his chest, thus he is a hairy-chested. He has a bowl in his hand, thus he is a bowl-in-hand. Thus he is a sword-in-hand, a staff-in-hand, a parasol-in-hand. He has a parasol in his hand, thus he is a parasol-in-hand. Thus he is a sword-in-hand, a staff-in-hand, a thunderbolt-in-hand, a giver with a bent for giving, thus he is a giver with a bent for giving. He is devoted to giving, thus he is devoted to giving. He has devotion to the Enlightened Ones, thus he is devoted to the Enlightened Ones. He has devotion to the Enlightened Ones, thus he is devoted to the Enlightened Ones. He has devotion to the True Idea, thus he is devoted to the True Idea, and so on.

original: Tipadabahubbīhi
analyzed: ti pada bahup bīhi
translated: The three-footed bahubbīhi

original: Tipadabahubbīhi nāma vuccati, parakkamena adhigatā sampadā yehi te parakkamādhigatasampadā,
analyzed: nāma vuccati parakkamena adhigatā sampadā yehi te parakkama adhigata sampadā
translated: is called. Those who have acquired prosperity by their own valour are those who have acquired prosperity by their own valour.

original: dhammena adhigatā bhogā yehi te dhammādhigatabhogā, oṇīto pattamhā pāṇi yena so oṇītapattapāṇi,
analyzed: dhammena adhigatāḥ bhogāḥ yehi te dhamma adhigata bhogāḥ oṇītaḥ pattamhā pāṇi yena saḥ oṇīta patta pāṇi
translated: Those who have acquired wealth by the True Idea are those who have acquired wealth by the True Idea. He has lowered his hand from the bowl, thus he is a lowered-hand-from-the-bowl.

original: sīhassa pubbaddhaṃ viya kāyo assāti sīhapubbaddhakāyo, mattā bahavo mātaṅgā yasmiṃ
analyzed: sīhassa pubbaddham viya kāyaḥ assa ati sīha pubbaddha kāyaḥ mattāḥ bahavaḥ mātaṅgāḥ yasmin
translated: His body is like the front part of a lion, thus he is “lion-fronted.” In the forest where there are many maddened elephants,

original: vaneti mattabahumātaṅgaṃ iccādi.
analyzed: vana iti matta bahu mātaṅgam it ca ādi
translated: thus it is “the forest of maddened elephants.”

original: Bahubbīhisamāso niṭṭhito.
analyzed: bahup bīhi samāsaḥ niṭṭhitaḥ
translated: The bahubbīhi compound is finished.

original: Dvandasamāsa
analyzed: dvanda samāsa
translated: The dvanda compound

original: Atha dvandasamāso dīpiyate.
analyzed: atha dvanda samāsaḥ dīpiyate
translated: Now the dvanda compound is elucidated.

original: Dve ca dve ca padāni dvandā, dve ca dve ca atthā vā dvandā, mahāvuttinā dvinnaṃ dvisaddānaṃ dvandādeso. Dvandasaddasadisattā sabbo cāyaṃ samāso dvandoti vuccati.🔽Atha vā dve avayavā andiyanti bandhiyanti etthāti dvando, yugaḷassetaṃ nāmaṃ “pādadvandaṃ
analyzed: dve ca dve ca padāni dvandāḥ dve ca dve ca atthāḥ vā dvandāḥ mahāvuttinā dvinnam dvi saddānam dvanda ādesaḥ dvanda saddasa disa ttā sabbaḥ ca ayam samāsaḥ dvandaḥ iti vuccati  atha vā dve avayavāḥ andiyanti bandhiyanti etthā ati dvandaḥ yugaḷassa itam nāmam pāda dvandam
translated: Two words and two meanings are a dvanda. The dvanda is the substitution of the dvanda affix for the two words dvinnaṃ and dvisaddānaṃ in the great method. And this whole compound is called a dvanda because it is similar to the word dvanda.

original: munindassa, vandāmi sirasāmaha”nti ettha viya, idha pana padayugaḷaṃ atthayugaḷañca🔽gayhati. Ubhayapadatthapadhāno hi dvando.
analyzed: vandāmi sirasāmahanti ettha idha pana pada yugaḷam attha yugaḷam ca  ubhaya padattha padhānaḥ hi dvandaḥ
translated: Or alternatively, it is a dvanda because two members are joined together in it, like the word yugaḷa, “pair,” in the passage, “I pay homage with my head to the pair of feet of the Lord of Sages,” for here a pair of words and a pair of meanings are taken. And a dvanda is governed by the meaning of both words.

original: Ettha siyā – yadi ubhayapadatthappadhāno dvando, evañca sati dvande kathaṃ ekatthībhāvalakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: ettha siyā yadi ubhaya padattha ppadhānaḥ dvandaḥ evam ca sati dvande katham ekatthībhāva lakkhaṇam
translated: Here it may be asked: if a dvanda is governed by the meaning of both words, then how is it that it has the characteristic of being a single meaning?

original: siyāti? Vuccate – abhinnavidheyyatthattā. Vacanapathañhi patvā kattubhāvakammabhāvādiko
analyzed: siyā iti vuccate abhinna vidheyi attha ttā vacana patham hi patvā kattu bhāva kamma bhāva ādikaḥ
translated: What is the reason? It is said: because the meaning of what is to be done is not divided. For the meaning of what is to be done, such as the state of being a doer, the state of being an action, etc.,

original: vidheyyattho eva padānaṃ accantappadhānattho hoti vacanavākyasampattiyā padhānaṅgattā,
analyzed: vidheyya tthaḥ eva padānam accanta ppadhāna atthaḥ hoti vacana vākya sampattiyā padhāna aṅga ttā
translated: is the meaning of the pre-eminence of the words only when it has reached the path of speech, because it is a condition for the pre-eminence of the speech and sentence.

original: so ca vidheyyattho dvandepi abhinno eva hoti. Tathā hi “sāriputtamoggallānā gacchanti,
analyzed: saḥ ca vidheyi atthaḥ dvande pi abhinnaḥ eva hoti tathā hi sāriputta moggallānāḥ gacchanti
translated: And that meaning of what is to be done is not divided even in a dvanda. Thus, in such passages as “Sāriputtamoggallānā gacchanti,

original: sāriputtamoggallāne passati” iccādīsu dve atthā ekavibhattiyā visayā hutvā ekakattu,
analyzed: sāriputta moggallāne passati iccādīsu dve atthāḥ eka vibhattiyā visayāḥ hutvā eka kattu
translated: sāriputtamoggallāne passati,” etc., two meanings become one by becoming the domain of one case-ending,

original: ekakammādibhāvena ekattaṃ gacchanti, evaṃ dvandepi dvinnaṃ tiṇṇaṃ bahunnaṃ vā padānaṃ
analyzed: eka kamma ādi bhāvena ekattam gacchanti evam dvande pi dvinnam tiṇṇam bahunnam vā
translated: by being one verb, one action, etc., in the same way, even in a dvanda, the characteristic of the state of being one meaning of two, three, or many words

original: ekatthībhāvalakkhaṇaṃ labbhatiyevāti.
analyzed: ekatthībhāva lakkhaṇam labbhatiyā iva ati
translated: is found.

analyzed: catthe ka rū nī
translated: . In the fourth case: rū, nī.

original: Anekaṃ syādyantapadaṃ casaddassa atthe ekatthaṃ hoti vā.
analyzed: anekam syādi anta padam ca saddassa atthe ekattham hoti vā
translated: A plurality of words at the end of a sentence is one meaning in the sense of the word ca.🔽And here the meanings of the word ca are four: conjunction, repetition, coordination, and collection.

original: Ettha ca samuccayo, anvācayo, itarītarayogo, samāhāroti cattāro casaddatthā honti.
analyzed: ettha ca samuccayaḥ anvācayaḥ itarītara yogo samāhāro ti cattāraḥ honti
translated: And here the four meanings of the word “and” are the conjunctive, the collective, the alternative, and the comprehensive.

original: Tattha samuccayo yathā? Cīvarañca piṇḍapātañca senāsanañca detīti. Anvācayo yathā?🔽Dānañca deti, sīlañca rakkhatīti. Ime dve casaddatthā vākyadvande eva labbhanti,
analyzed: samuccayaḥ yathā cīvarañca piṇḍapātañca senāsanañca deti iti anvācayaḥ yathā  dānañca deti sīlañca rakkhati iti ime dve casaddatthā vākya dvande eva labbhanti
translated: Herein, the word “and” in the compound “giving-and-taking” is like the “and” in the expression “He gives robe-material and alms food and a resting place” . The word “and” in the compound “giving-and-observing” is like the “and” in the expression “He gives and he guards virtue” . These two meanings of “and” are only found in a double-compound .

original: na samāsadvande padānaṃ aññamaññaṃ nirapekkhattāti vadanti. Taṃ anvācaye yujjati🔽nānākriyāpekkhattā, samuccaye pana “cīvarañca piṇḍapātañca senāsanañca detī”ti vā
analyzed: na samāsa dvande padānam aññam aññam vadanti tam anvācaye yujjati  samuccaye pana cīvarañca piṇḍapātañca senāsanañca deti iti vā
translated: Herein, the compound is like the words “He gives robe-cloth and alms food and resting place” . The co-ordination is like the words “He gives gifts and he guards morality” . These two meanings of the word ca are only found in a double construction, not in a compound construction, because the words in a compound construction are not mutually dependent. So they say. That is correct in the case of co-ordination,

original: “cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanāni detī”ti vā evaṃ dvidhāpi yojetuṃ yujjatiyeva “lābhī hoti🔽cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhārāna”nti ma. ni. 1.65 pāḷidassanato.
analyzed: cīvara piṇḍapāta senāsanāni deti iti vai evam dvidhā api yojetum lābhī  cīvara piṇḍapāta senāsana gilāna paccaya bhesajja parikkhārā an anti ma ni pāḷi dassanato
translated: but in the case of the compound it is correct to construe it in two ways as “He gives robe-cloth and alms food and resting place” or as “He gives robe-cloth and alms food and resting place” , because of the text in the Paṭisambhidā “He is a receiver of robe-cloth, alms food, resting place, and medicinal requisites” .

original: Anvācayopi vā samāsadvande no na labbhati “mālāgandhavilepanadhāraṇamaṇḍanavibhūsanaṭṭhānā”ti
analyzed: vā samāsa dvande no na labbhati mālā gandha vilepana dhāraṇa maṇḍana vibhūsana ṭṭhānā ti
translated: And the co-ordination is not not found in a compound construction, because of the text in the Dīgha “Wearing garlands, scents, and unguents, enjoying beds, … and lights” .🔽But it would be correct to construe it thus: the meaning of the word ca is one action,

original: dī. ni. 1.10 pāḷidassanato. Evaṃ pana yujjeyya – casaddattho ekakriya, nānākriyāpekkhanabhedena
analyzed: dī ni pāḷi dassanataḥ evam pana yujjeyya ca saddattho eka kriyā nānā kriyā apekkhana bhedena
translated: and the compound is of two kinds according as it requires the recognition of a plurality of actions or not.

original: duvidho hoti samuccayo, anvācayo cāti, tesu ca ekeko avayavappadhāna, samudāyappadhānabhedena
analyzed: duvidhaḥ hoti samuccayaḥ anvācayo ca ati tesu ca ekekaḥ avayava ppadhāna samudāya ppadhāna bhedena
translated: The compound is of two kinds, copulative and appositional. Of these, each is of two kinds, according as it is a primary compound or a secondary compound.

original: duvidho hoti itarītarayogo, samāhāro cāti. Tattha itarītarayoge avayavappadhānattā
analyzed: duvidhaḥ hoti itarītara yogo samāhāraḥ ca ati tattha itarītara yoge avayava ppadhāna ttā
translated: The co-ordinate compound is of two kinds, according as it is a co-ordinate co-inherence or a co-ordinate collection.🔽Herein, because of the primary-compound character of the co-ordinate co-inherence,

original: sabbavibhattīsu bahuvacanameva yujjati.
analyzed: sabba vibhattīsu bahuvacanam eva yujjati
translated: the plural is appropriate in all the inflected-word bases.

original: Dvande paṇītataraṃ pubbe nipatati. Sāriputto ca moggallāno ca sāriputtamoggallānā,
analyzed: dvande paṇītataram pubbe nipatati sāriputto ca moggallāno ca sāriputta moggallānā
translated: In a dyad the more distinguished is placed first: Sāriputta and Moggallāna are Sāriputta-Moggallāna,

original: sāriputtamoggallāne, sāriputtamoggallānehi iccādi. Evaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇā, brāhmaṇagahapatikā,
analyzed: sāriputta moggallāne sāriputta moggallānehi iccādi evam samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ brāhmaṇa gahapatikā
translated: Sāriputta-Moggallānas, Sāriputta-Moggallānas. So too: ascetics and brahmans, brahmans and householders,

original: khattiyabrāhmaṇā, devamanussā, candimasūriyā.
analyzed: khattiya brāhmaṇā deva manussā candima sūriyā
translated: khattiyas and brahmans, gods and men, moon and sun.

original: Appakkhara, bahvakkharesu appakkharaṃ kvaci pubbaṃ hoti, gāmanigamā, gāmajanapadā iccādi.
analyzed: appakkhara bahu akkharesu appakkharam kvaci pubbam hoti gāma nigamāḥ gāma janapadāḥ iccādi
translated: In the case of the co-ordinate collection, the less is placed first when it is few, as in “The villages and towns,” “The villages and the country,”

original: Kvaci ivaṇṇu’vaṇṇantā pubbe honti, aggi ca dhūmo ca aggidhūmā, rattidivā, dhātuliṅgāni.
analyzed: kvaci i v aṇṇu vaṇṇa ntā pubbe honti aggi ca dhūmaḥ ca aggi dhūmāḥ ratti divā dhātu liṅgāni
translated: and so on. The less is placed first when it is the colour, as in “The fire and the smoke,” “The night and the day,” “The elements and the faculties.”

original: Avaṇṇantesu sarādipadaṃ pubbaṃ hoti, attho ca dhammo ca atthadhammā, dhammatthā vā iccādi.
analyzed: a vaṇṇa ntesu sara ādi padam pubbam hoti atthaḥ ca dhammo ca attha dhammāḥ dhamma tthāḥ vā iccādi
translated: When the first word is a noun, the first member is placed first, and the meaning or the thing is the first member.

original: Ayañca niyamo dvipadadvandesu yebhuyyena labbhati, bahupadadvandesu na labbhati.
analyzed: ayam ca niyamaḥ dvipada dvandesu yebhuyyena labbhati bahu pada dvandesu na labbhati
translated: And this rule applies mostly to dvanda compounds consisting of two words, not to those consisting of many words.

original: Samāhāradvande –🔽358. Samāhāre napuṃsakaṃ ka. 322; rū. 359; nī. 700.
analyzed: samāhāra dvande  samāhāre napuṃsakam ka rū nī
translated: In a copulative compound🔽In a copulative compound the neuter is the first member.

original: Catthe samāhāre ekatthapadaṃ napuṃsakaṃ hoti, ekavacanantattaṃ pana samāhāravacaneneva🔽siddhaṃ, ayañca samāhāro pāṇyaṅgādīnaṃ dvandesu niccaṃ labbhati, rukkhatiṇādīnaṃ
analyzed: catthe samāhāre eka attha padam napuṃsakam hoti pana samāhāra vacanena iva  siddham ayam ca samāhāraḥ pāṇi aṅga ādīnam dvandesu niccam labbhati rukkha tiṇa ādīnam
translated: In a copulative compound consisting of three words the first member is a neuter word, but the singleness is established by the copulative compound itself.🔽And this copulative compound occurs constantly in dvanda compounds consisting of body-parts, etc.,

original: dvandesu vikappena labbhati.
analyzed: dvandesu vikappena labbhati
translated: but in dvanda compounds consisting of trees, grass, etc., it occurs optionally.

original: Tattha niccaladdhesu tāva pāṇyaṅgadvande –🔽Cakkhu ca sotañca cakkhusotaṃ, mukhañca nāsikā ca mukhanāsikaṃ, ‘syādīsu rasso’ti
analyzed: tattha nicca laddhesu tāva  cakkhu ca sotam ca cakkhu sotam mukham ca nāsikā ca mukha nāsikam syāt īsu rassaḥ ti
translated: Herein, first of all, as to the constant copulative compounds consisting of body-parts, etc.:🔽Eye and ear are eye-and-ear. Face and nose are face-and-nose.🔽In the case of the words ‘jaw and neck’ the ‘jaw’ is the first member, the ‘neck’ is the second member, and the ‘and’ is the copula.

original: rassattaṃ. Hanu ca gīvā ca hanugīvaṃ. Evaṃ kaṇṇanāsaṃ, chavi ca maṃsañca lohitañca
analyzed: rassattam hanu ca gīvā ca hanu gīvam evam kaṇṇa nāsam chavi ca maṃsam ca lohitam ca
translated: Skin and flesh and blood are skin-flesh-blood.

original: chavimaṃsalohitaṃ, nāmañca rūpañca nāmarūpaṃ, jarā ca maraṇañca jarāmaraṇaṃ. Bahulādhikārā
analyzed: chavi maṃsa lohitam nāman ca rūpam ca nāma rūpam jarā ca maraṇam ca jarā maraṇam bahula adhikārā
translated: Flesh, sinews, bones, marrow, skin, kidney, heart, liver, midriff, spleen, lungs, intestines, mesentery, stomach, feces, head, brain, eyes, tears, grease, spit, snot, oil, urine, bile, phlegm, pus, blood, and the four elements that are its support, are called “flesh, sinews, bones, and marrow.” “Name-and-form” is name and form. “Aging-and-death” is aging and death.

original: kvaci vikapparūpampi dissati, hatthā ca pādā ca hatthapādaṃ, hatthapādā vā iccādi.
analyzed: kvaci vikappa rūpam pi dissati hatthā ca pādā ca hattha pādam hattha pādāḥ vā iccādi
translated: In some instances, a compound is seen where the last word is repeated, such as “hands and feet” and “hands and feet,” etc.

original: Tūriyaṅgadvande –🔽Naccañca gītañca vāditañca naccagītavāditaṃ. Evaṃ sammatāḷaṃ, ‘samma’nti kaṃsatāḷaṃ, ‘tāḷa’nti hatthatāḷaṃ, saṅkho ca paṇavo ca ḍiṇḍimo ca saṅkhapaṇavaḍiṇḍimaṃ iccādi.🔽Yoggaṅgadvande –🔽Phālo ca pācanañca phālapācanaṃ, yugañca naṅgalañca yuganaṅgalaṃ iccādi.🔽Senaṅgadvande –
analyzed: tūriyaṅgat vande  naccam ca gītam ca vāditam ca nacca gīta vāditam evam samma tāḷam kaṃsa tāḷam tāḷanti hattha tāḷam saṅkhaḥ ca paṇavaḥ ca ḍiṇḍimaḥ ca saṅkha paṇava ḍiṇḍimam iccādi  yok gaṅgat vande  ca pācanam ca phālapācanam yugam ca naṅgalam ca yuganaṅgalam iti cādi  senaṅgat vande
translated: In the case of the compound of musical instruments:

original: Hatthino ca assā ca hatthiassaṃ. Evaṃ rathapattikaṃ, asi ca cammañca asicammaṃ. ‘Camma’nti saraparittāṇaphalakaṃ, dhanu ca kalāpo ca dhanukalāpaṃ iccādi.🔽Khuddakapāṇadvande –
analyzed: hatthinaḥ ca assā ca hatthi assam evam ratha pattikam asi ca cammam ca asi cammam cammanti sara parittāṇa phalakam dhanu ca kalāpo ca dhanu kalāpam iccādi 🔽khudda kapāṇa dvande
translated: “Dancing, singing, and music” is dancing, singing, and music. “Clapping” is clapping with the hands. “Clapping” is clapping with the hands. “Conch” is a metal instrument. “Clapping” is clapping with the hands. “Drum” is a hand-drum. “Cymbal” is a cymbal. “Cymbal” is a cymbal. “Conch” is a metal instrument. “Clapping” is clapping with the hands. “Drum” is a hand-drum. “Cymbal” is a cymbal. “Cymbal” is a cymbal. “Conch” is a metal instrument. “Clapping” is clapping with the hands. “Drum” is a hand-drum. “Cymbal” is a cymbal. “Cymbal” is a cymbal. “Conch” is a metal instrument. “Clapping” is clapping with the hands. “Drum” is a hand-drum. “Cymbal” is a cymbal. “Cymbal” is a cymbal. “Conch” is a metal instrument. “Clapping” is clapping with the hands. “Drum” is a hand-drum. “Cymbal” is a cymbal. “Cymbal” is a cymbal. “Conch” is a metal instrument. “Clapping” is clapping with the hands. “Drum” is a hand-drum. “Cymbal” is a cymbal. “Cymbal” is a cymbal. “Conch” is a metal instrument. “Clapping” is clapping with the hands. “Drum” is a hand-drum. “Cymbal” is a cymbal. “Cymbal” is a cymbal. “Conch

original: Ḍaṃsā ca makasā ca ḍaṃsamakasaṃ. Evaṃ kunthakipillikaṃ su. ni. 607, kīṭapaṭaṅgaṃ iccādi.
analyzed: ḍaṃsā ca makasā ca ḍaṃsa makasam evam kuntha kipillikam su ni kīṭa paṭaṅgam iccādi
translated: And gnats and mosquitoes are gnats-and-mosquitoes. So too, fleas and lice are fleas-and-lice. And so with insects and moths, etc.,

original: Niccaveridvande –
analyzed: nit caveḥ it vande
translated: In the case of the compound niccaveridvande,

original: Ahi ca nakulo ca ahinakulaṃ, biḷāro ca mūsikā ca biḷāramūsikaṃ, rassattaṃ. Kākolūkaṃ, sappamaṇḍūkaṃ, nāgasupaṇṇaṃ iccādi.
analyzed: ahi ca nakulaḥ ca ahinakulam biḷāraḥ ca mūsikā ca biḷāramūsikam rassattam kāka ulūkam sappa maṇḍūkam nāga supaṇṇam iccādi
translated: Snakes and mongooses are snakes-and-mongooses. Cats and mice are cats-and-mice. Owls and crows are owls-and-crows. Snakes and frogs are snakes-and-frogs. Nāgas and supaṇṇas are nāgas-and-supaṇṇas.

original: Sabhāgadvande –🔽Sīlañca paññāṇañca sīlapaññāṇaṃ, samatho ca vipassanā ca samathavipassanaṃ, vijjā🔽ca caraṇañca vijjācaraṇaṃ. Evaṃ satisampajaññaṃ, hiriottappaṃ, uddhaccakukkuccaṃ,
analyzed: sa bhāga dvande  sīlam ca paññāṇam ca sīla paññāṇam samathaḥ ca vipassanā ca samatha vipassanam vijjā  ca caraṇam ca vijjā caraṇam evam sati sampajaññam hiri uttappam uddhacca kukkuccam
translated: In the case of the compound sabhāgadvande,

original: thinamiddhaṃ iccādi.
analyzed: thinam iddham i t ca ādi
translated: Morality and understanding are morality-and-understanding. Quiet and insight are quiet-and-insight. Knowledge and conduct are knowledge-and-conduct. So too, mindfulness and full awareness are mindfulness-and-full-awareness. Shame and moral dread are shame-and-moral-dread. Restlessness and remorse are restlessness-and-remorse. So too, drowsiness and torpor are drowsiness-and-torpor.

original: Vividhaviruddhadvande –
analyzed: vividha viruddha dvande
translated: In the case of the compound vividhaviruddhadvande,

original: Kusalākusalaṃ, sāvajjānavajjaṃ, kaṇhasukkaṃ, hīnapaṇītaṃ, chekabālaṃ iccādi.
analyzed: kusala akusalam sāvajja anavajjam kaṇha sukkam hīna paṇītam cheka bālam iccādi
translated: Profitable and unprofitable are profitable-and-unprofitable. Reprehensible and blameless are reprehensible-and-blameless. Black and white are black-and-white. Inferior and superior are inferior-and-superior. Coarse and subtle are coarse-and-subtle.

original: Ekasaṅgītidvande –
analyzed: eka saṅgīti dvande
translated: In the case of the compound ekasaṅgītidvande,

original: Dīgho ca majjhimo ca dīghamajjhimaṃ, aṅguttarasaṃyuttakaṃ, khandhakavibhaṅgaṃ iccādi.
analyzed: dīghaḥ ca majjhimaḥ ca dīgha majjhimam aṅguttara saṃyuttakam khandhaka vibhaṅgam iccādi
translated: Long and medium are long-and-medium. The Anguttara and the Saṃyutta is Anguttara-Saṃyutta. The aggregate and the analysis is aggregate-analysis.

original: Saṅkhyāparimāṇadvande –
analyzed: saṅkhyā parimāṇa dvande
translated: In the case of the compound saṅkhyāparimāṇadvande,

original: Ekakadukaṃ, dukatikaṃ, tikacatukkaṃ, catukkapañcakaṃ iccādi.
analyzed: ekaka dukam duka tikam tika catukkam catukka pañcakam iccādi
translated: The singular and dual, the dual and plural, the plural and the dual, the dual and the singular, etc.,

original: Pacanacaṇḍāladvande –
analyzed: pacana caṇḍāla dvande
translated: The compound of the two, the butcher and the swineherd,

original: Orabbhikā ca sūkarikā ca orabbhikasūkarikaṃ. Evaṃ sākuṇikamāgavikaṃ, sapākacaṇḍālaṃ, venarathakāraṃ, pukkusachavaḍāhakaṃ iccādi.
analyzed: orabbhikā ca sūkarikā ca orabbhika sūkarikam evam sākuṇika māgavikam sa pāka caṇḍālam vena rathakāram pukkusa chava ḍāhakam iccādi
translated: The butcher and the swineherd are the butcher and swineherd. So too, the fowler and the goatherd, the butcher and the rat-catcher, the carpenter and the chariot-maker, the scavenger and the sweeper, etc.

original: Liṅgavisabhāgadvande –
analyzed: liṅga visa bhāga dvande
translated: The compound of the two of different genders,

original: Itthipumaṃ, dāsidāsaṃ iccādi.
analyzed: itthi pumam dāsi dāsam i t ca ādi
translated: The woman and the man, the female slave and the male slave, etc.

original: Disādvande –
analyzed: disā dvande
translated: The compound of the two directions,

original: Pubbā ca aparā ca pubbāparaṃ. Evaṃ dakkhiṇuttaraṃ, pubbadakkhiṇaṃ, pubbuttaraṃ, aparadakkhiṇaṃ, aparuttaraṃ.
analyzed: pubbā ca aparā ca pubba aparam evam dakkhiṇa uttaram pubba dakkhiṇam pubba uttaram apara dakkhiṇam apara uttaram
translated: The east and the west are the east and west. So too, the south and the north, the east and the south, the east and the north, the west and the south, the west and the north.

original: Nadīdvande –
analyzed: nadī dvande
translated: The compound of the two rivers,

original: Gaṅgāyamunaṃ, mahisarabhu, sabbattha napuṃsakattā ante dīghānaṃ rassattaṃ sattasu vibhattīsu ekavacanantañca.
analyzed: gaṅgā yamunam mahi sarabhu sabbattha napuṃsaka ttā ante dīghānam rassattam sattasu vibhattīsu ekavacana antam ca
translated: The Ganges and the Yamunā, the Mahi and the Sarabhū. Everywhere the feminine is shortened at the end of the seven cases because of the neuter.

original: Iti niccasamāhārarāsi.
analyzed: iti
translated: Thus the collection of the invariable compounds.

original: Vikappaladdhesu ka. 323; rū. 360; nī. 701 tiṇavisesadvande –
analyzed: vi kappa laddhesu ka rū nī tiṇa visesa dvande
translated: In the optional compounds, the compound of the two kinds of grass,

original: Usīrāni ca bīraṇāni ca usīrabīraṇaṃ, usīrabīraṇā. Evaṃ muñjapabbajaṃ, muñjapabbajā, kāsakusaṃ, kāsakusā.
analyzed: usīrāni ca bīraṇāni ca usīra bīraṇam usīra bīraṇā evam muñja pabbajam muñja pabbajā kāsakusam kāsakusā
translated: The reed and the bamboo are the reed and bamboo, the reed and bamboo. So too, the muñja and the reed, the muñja and the reed, the hemp and the flax, the hemp and the flax.

original: Upamaṇikaṃ, adhitthi, upavadhu.
analyzed: upamaṇikam adhitthi upavadhu
translated: Upamaṇikaṃ, adhitthi, upavadhu.

original: Antassāti kiṃ? Saddhādhano, puriso.
analyzed: antassa ati kim saddhā dhanaḥ puriso
translated: What is the meaning of ‘inside’? A person rich in faith.

original: Appadhānassāti kiṃ? Rājakaññā, rājakumārī, brahmabandhū.🔽361. Gossu ka. 342; rū. 337; nī. 722; caṃ. 2.2.85; pā. 1.2.48.
analyzed: appadhānassa ati kim rāja kaññā rāja kumārī brahmabandhū  gossu ka rū nī cam pā
translated: What is the meaning of ‘lesser’? A princess, a prince, a kinsman of Brahma.🔽Go, ka, ru, ni, ca, ma, pa.

original: Syādīsu antabhūtassa appadhānabhūtassa ca gossa u hoti.
analyzed: sya ādīsu anta bhūtassa appadhāna bhūtassa ca gossa u hoti
translated: In the case of go, which is the first, and of ka, which is the lesser, u is the form.

original: Tiṭṭhagu cittagu.
analyzed: tiṭṭhagu cittagu
translated: A cow that stands, a cow that goes.

original: Appadhānassāti kiṃ? Rājagavo.
analyzed: appadhānassa ati kim rājagavaḥ
translated: What is the meaning of ‘lesser’? A royal bull.

original: Antassāti kiṃ? Gokulaṃ.
analyzed: kim gokulam
translated: What is the meaning of ‘inside’? A herd of cows.

original: Iti samāsantarassarāsi.🔽Pumbhāvātidesarāsi
analyzed: iti  pumbhāva atidesarā asi
translated: So the group of words for the end and the middle of compounds.🔽The group of words for the transference of the masculine

original: 362. Itthiyaṃ bhāsitapumitthī pumāvekatthe ka. 331; rū. 353; nī. 714; caṃ. 5.2.29; pā. 6.3.34.
analyzed: itthiyam bhāsita pumitthī pumau ekatthe ka rū nī cam pā
translated: In the feminine ka, ru, ni, ca, ma, pa are used for the masculine in the sense of the feminine.

original: ‘Ekatthe’ti tulyādhikaraṇe, itthiyaṃ vattamāne ekatthe uttarapade pare kadāci bhāsitapumo
analyzed: ekattha iti tulya adhikaraṇe itthiyam vattamāne ekatthe uttara pade pare kadāci bhāsita pumo
translated: ‘In the sense of the feminine’ means in the same context as the feminine. When the feminine is used in the same context, sometimes the word for the feminine

original: itthiliṅgasaddo pumā iva hoti. Caturaṅgamidaṃ vidhānaṃ, pubbapadaṃ itthiliṅgañca
analyzed: itthi liṅga saddo pumā iva hoti catur aṅgam idam vidhānam pubba padam itthi liṅgam ca
translated: is used like the masculine. This is the rule in four terms: the first term is feminine,

original: bhāsitapumañca siyā, parapadaṃ niyatitthiliṅgañca pubbapadena ekatthañca siyāti.
analyzed: bhāsita pumam ca siyā para padam niya titthi liṅgam ca pubba padena ekattham ca siyāti
translated: the word used for the masculine is used, the second term is definitely feminine, and the first term is in the same context.

original: Dīghā jaṅghā yassa so dīghajaṅgho, puriso, dīghajaṅghā, itthī, dīghajaṅghaṃ, kulaṃ.
analyzed: dīghā jaṅghā yassa saḥ dīgha jaṅghaḥ purisaḥ dīgha jaṅghā itthī dīgha jaṅgham kulaṃ
translated: One who has long shanks is a long-shanked man, a long-shanked woman, a long-shanked family.

original: Ettha ca ye saddā katthaci pulliṅgarūpā honti, katthaci itthipaccayayuttā itthiliṅgarūpā,
analyzed: ettha ca ye saddā katthaci pulliṅga rūpāḥ honti katthaci itthi paccaya yuttāḥ itthi liṅga rūpā
translated: And here the words that are sometimes in the masculine and sometimes in the feminine according to the gender of the noun to which they are compounded,

original: te bhāsitapumā nāma. Dīgho maggo, dīghā ratti, gato puriso, gatā itthī, kumāro, kumārī,
analyzed: te bhāsita pumā nāma dīghaḥ maggaḥ dīghā ratti gataḥ purisaḥ gatā itthī kumāro kumārī
translated: are called “masculine in the sense of being spoken of as a man.” A long road, a long night, a man has gone, a woman has gone, a boy, a girl,

original: brāhmaṇo, brāhmaṇī iccādi.
analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ brāhmaṇī i t ca ādi
translated: a brahmin, a brahmin woman, and so on.

original: Ye pana itthipaccayayuttā niccaṃ itthiliṅgarūpā honti, te bhāsitapumā nāma na honti,
analyzed: ye pana itthi paccaya yuttāḥ niccam itthi liṅga rūpāḥ honti te bhāsita pumā nāma na honti
translated: But those that are always in the feminine according to the gender of the noun to which they are compounded are not called “masculine in the sense of being spoken of as a man,”

original: kaññā, paññā, saddhā, nadī, itthī, pathavī iccādi. Tathā sabhāvaitthiliṅgāpi niyatapunnapuṃsakaliṅgāpi
analyzed: kaññā paññā saddhā nadī itthī pathavī iccādi tathā sabhā vaitthi liṅgā api niyata put napuṃsaka liṅgā api
translated: a virgin, wisdom, faith, a river, a woman, the earth, and so on. Likewise, those that are feminine in the sense of being a gathering of women and those that are neuter in the sense of being a gathering of neuter things,

original: bhāsitapumā na honti, devatā, ratti, dhenu, vadhū, sakko, devo, brahmā, ratanaṃ, saraṇaṃ iccādi.
analyzed: na honti devatāḥ na honti devatāḥ sakkaḥ devaḥ brahmā ratanam saraṇam iccādi
translated: are not masculine in the sense of being spoken of as a man. A deity, a night, a cow, a bride, Sakka, a god, Brahmā, a jewel, a refuge, and so on.

original: Idha pana dīghasaddo “dīgho bālāna saṃsāro”ti dha. pa. 60 ādīsu bhāsitapumo, so visesyaliṅgānugatavasena
analyzed: idha pana dīgha saddo dīghaḥ saṃsāraḥ iti dha pa ādīsu bhāsita pumo saḥ visesya liṅga anugata vasena
translated: But here the word “long” is masculine in the sense of being spoken of as a man in such passages as “Long is the round of rebirths for fools” . It is

original: idha itthipaccayayutto itthiliṅgasaddo nāma. Iminā suttena pumbhāvātidese kate tattha
analyzed: idha itthi paccaya yuttaḥ itthi liṅga saddo nāma iminā suttena pumbhāva atidese kate tattha
translated: Herein, the word ‘woman’ is a feminine noun. By this Sutta, when the masculine gender is exceeded,

original: āpaccayo antaradhāyati, ‘ghapassantassāppadhānassā’ti suttena samāsantassa ākārassa🔽rassattaṃ, kumārī bhariyā yassa so kumārabhariyo, īpaccayanivatti. Yuvati jāyā yassa
analyzed: ā paccayaḥ antaradhāyati suttena samāsa antassa ākārassa  kumārī bhariyā yassa saḥ kumārabhariyaḥ yuvati jāyā yassa
translated: the feminine gender disappears, and by the Sutta ‘ghapassantassāppadhānassā’ the form of the compound has

original: so yuvajāyo, tipaccayanivatti. Brahmabandhū bhariyā yassa so brahmabandhubhariyo, ūpaccayanivatti.
analyzed: saḥ yuva jāyo ti paccaya nivatti brahmabandhū bhariyā yassa saḥ brahmabandhu bhariyaḥ
translated: the feminine ending. A girl is the wife of him, he is a girl’s husband. The feminine gender disappears. A young woman is the wife of him, he is a young woman’s husband. The feminine gender disappears. A girl of the Brahmas is the wife of him, he is a girl of the Brahmas’ husband. The feminine gender disappears.

original: Itthiyanti kiṃ? Kumārī ratanaṃ yassa so kumārīratano, puriso, idha parapadaṃ itthiliṅgaṃ🔽na hoti, tasmā pumbhāvātideso na kātabbo, yadi kareyya, kumāro ratanaṃ yassa kumāraratanoti
analyzed: itthiyanti kim kumārī ratanam yassa saḥ kumārī ratanaḥ purisaḥ idha para padam itthi liṅgam  na hoti tasmā pumbhāva atidesaḥ na kātabbaḥ yadi kareyya kumāraḥ ratanam yassa
translated: What if it is a woman? A girl is the jewel of him, he is a girl’s jewel. A man. Herein, the other word is a feminine noun.

original: evaṃ aniṭṭhattho bhaveyya.
analyzed: evam aniṭṭhatthaḥ bhaveyya
translated: It is not so, therefore the masculine gender is not to be exceeded. If it is done, then the meaning will be undesirable, namely, a boy is the jewel of him, he is a boy’s jewel.

original: Ekattheti kiṃ? Kumārīsu bhatti yassa so kumārībhattiko. Evaṃ samaṇībhattiko, brāhmaṇībhattiko,
analyzed: ekattha iti kim kumārīsu bhatti yassa saḥ kumārī bhattikaḥ evam samaṇī bhattikaḥ brāhmaṇī bhattikaḥ
translated: What if it is one meaning? A girl is the servant of him, he is a girl’s servant. Thus a female ascetic’s servant, a female brahmin’s servant,

original: samāsante ko, idha parapadaṃ pubbapadena ekatthaṃ na hoti, tasmā pumbhāvātideso na
analyzed: samāsa ante kaḥ idha para padam pubba padena ekattham na hoti tasmā pumbhāva atidesaḥ na
translated: In short, where there is no identity of meaning between the last word and the preceding word, the feminine ending is not to be changed.

original: kātabbo, yadi kareyya, kumāresu bhatti yassa so kumārabhattikoti evaṃ aniṭṭhattho bhaveyya.
analyzed: kātabbaḥ yadi kareyya kumāresu bhatti yassa saḥ kumārabhattikaḥ ti evam aniṭṭha tthaḥ bhaveyya
translated: If it were, then in the expression kumāresu bhatti yassa so kumārabhattiko, the meaning would be undesirable.

original: Itthīti kiṃ? Daṭṭhabbaṭṭhena diṭṭhi, gāmaṇikulaṃ diṭṭhi yena so gāmaṇidiṭṭhi, idha
analyzed: itthī iti kim daṭṭhabba ṭṭhena diṭṭhi gāmaṇi kulam diṭṭhi yena saḥ gāmaṇi diṭṭhi idha
translated: What is the feminine? Dīṭṭhi in the sense of what is to be seen. Gāmaṇikulaṃ dīṭṭhi yena so gāmaṇidīṭṭhi. Here

original: gāmaṇisaddo bhāsitapumo hoti, idha pana kulavācakattā napuṃsakaliṅge tiṭṭhati, itthipaccayo
analyzed: gāmaṇi saddaḥ bhāsita pumaḥ hoti idha pana kula vācaka ttā napuṃsaka liṅge tiṭṭhati itthi paccayo
translated: the word gāmaṇi is masculine in the expression, but here it is neuter in gender because it denotes a family. There is no feminine ending.

original: natthi, tasmā pumbhāvātidesakiccaṃ natthi.
analyzed: na atthi tasmā pumbhāva atidesa kiccam na atthi
translated: Therefore there is no need to change the masculine ending.

original: Bhāsitapumoti kiṃ? Saddhā pakati yassa so saddhāpakatiko. Evaṃ paññāpakatiko, idha
analyzed: bhāsita pumā ti kim saddhā pakati yassa so saddhā pakatikaḥ evam paññā pakatikaḥ idha
translated: What is masculine in the expression? Saddhā pakati yassa so saddhāpakatiko. So is paññāpakatiko. Here

original: pubbapadaṃ niyatitthiliṅgattā bhāsitapumaṃ na hotīti. Saddhādhano, paññādhano, saddhādhuro
analyzed: pubba padam niya titthi liṅga ttā bhāsita pumam na hoti iti
translated: the preceding word is not masculine in the expression because it is definitely feminine in gender. Saddhādhano, paññādhano, saddhādhuro,

original: paññādhuro iccatra duvaṅgavekallaṃ hoti.
analyzed: duvaṅga vekallam hoti
translated: paññādhuro. Here there is a deficiency of two factors.

original: Kammadhārayamhi ka. 332; rū. 343; nī. 716 pana ‘ekatthe’ti padaṃ visuṃ ekaṃ aṅgaṃ
analyzed: kammadhārayamhi ka rū nī pana ekattha iti padam visum ekam aṅgam
translated: In the compound, ka. ; rū. ; nī. ; but the word ‘ekatthe’ is a separate factor.

original: na hoti anekatthassa idha asambhavato. Dīghā ca sā jaṅghā cāti dīghajaṅghā, kumārī🔽ca sā bhariyā cāti kumārabhariyā. Evaṃ khattiyakaññā, brāhmaṇakaññā, yuvati ca sā
analyzed: na hoti anekatthassa idha asambhavataḥ dīghā ca sā jaṅghā ca ati dīghajaṅghā kumārī  ca sā bhariyā ca ati kumāra bhariyā evam khattiya kaññā brāhmaṇa kaññā yuvati ca sā
translated: because of the impossibility of the meaning of “many” here. And she is long and she is a leg, thus she is a long leg (dīgha-jaṅghā); and she is a girl and she is a wife, thus she is a girl-wife (kumāri-bhariyā). Thus a khattiya girl, a brāhmaṇa girl, and a young woman (yuvatī),

original: bhariyā cāti yuvabhariyā, brahmabandhū ca sā bhariyā cāti brahmabandhubhariyā.
analyzed: bhariyā ca ati yuva bhariyā brahmabandhū ca sā bhariyā ca ati brahmabandhu bhariyā
translated: not in the case of the many meanings, because they are not possible here. And it is long and it is a leg, thus it is a long leg; and it is a girl and it is a wife, thus it is a girl-wife. So too: a khattiya girl, a brahmin girl, and she is a young woman and she is a wife, thus she is a young wife; and she is a kinsman of the gods and she is a wife, thus she is a wife of a kinsman of the gods.

original: Itthiyanti kiṃ? Kumārī ca sā ratanañcāti kumārīratanaṃ. Evaṃ samaṇīpadumaṃ.
analyzed: kim kumārī ca sā ratanam ca ati kumārī ratanam evam
translated: What about in the case of itthi? And she is a girl and she is a jewel, thus she is a girl-jewel. So too: a nun, a lotus.

original: Itthīti kiṃ? Gāmaṇikulañca taṃ diṭṭhi cāti gāmaṇidiṭṭhi.
analyzed: itthī iti kim gāmaṇi kulam ca tam diṭṭhi ca ati gāmaṇi diṭṭhi
translated: What about in the case of itthī? And it is a chief’s family and it is a view, thus it is a chief’s view.

original: Bhāsitapumoti kiṃ? Saddhāpakati, gaṅgānadī, taṇhānadī, pathavīdhātu.
analyzed: kim gaṅgā nadī taṇhā nadī pathavī dhātu
translated: What about in the case of bhāsitapum? Nature of faith, River Ganges, craving-river, earth element.

original: Saññāsaddesu pana caturaṅgayuttepi vidhānaṃ na hoti, nandādevī, nandāpokkharaṇī, kāyagatāsati, paṭhamāvibhatti, dutiyāvibhatti, pañcamīvibhatti, chaṭṭhīvibhatti iccādi.
analyzed: saññā saddesu pana catur aṅga yutte pi vidhānam na hoti nandā devī nandā pokkharaṇī kāya gatā asati paṭhamā vibhatti dutiyā vibhatti pañcamī vibhatti chaṭṭhī vibhatti iccādi
translated: But in the case of the words for a woman, there is no inflexion even when there are four factors, as in Nandā the queen, Nandā the lotus-pond, mindfulness occupied with the body, first case-ending, second case-ending, fifth case-ending, sixth case-ending, and so on.

analyzed: kvaci paccaye ka rū nī cam pā
translated: In some instances, in the case of a condition, k. ; rū. ; nī. ; caṃ. ..; pā. ..

original: Paccaye pare kadāci bhāsitapumo itthiliṅgasaddo kvaci pumāva hoti.
analyzed: paccaye pare kadāci bhāsita pumo itthi liṅga saddo kvaci pumā āva hoti
translated: Sometimes the word for a woman, when used as a masculine, is masculine.

original: Byattatarā, byattatamā, ettha ca byattānaṃ itthīnaṃ atisayena byattāti byattatarā, byattatamāti attho. Evaṃ paṇḍitatarā, paṇḍitatamā iccādi.🔽364. Sabbādayo vuttimatte ka. 331; rū. 353; nī. 714; caṃ. 5.2.41; pā. 6.3.35.
analyzed: byattatarā byattatamā ettha ca byattānam itthīnam atisayena byattā ati byattatarā byattatamā ati evam paṇḍitatarā paṇḍitatamā iccādi  sabba ādayaḥ vuttimatte ka rū nī caṃ pā
translated: The most clever, the cleverest: and here the meaning is: “Cleverer than clever women, the most clever,” “cleverest.” So too, the most learned, the most learned of all, and so on.🔽All, etc., in the case of a mere statement.

original: Vuttimatte ṭhāne sabbādināmakā sabbanāmasaddā pumāva honti.
analyzed: vuttimatte ṭhāne sabba ādi nāmakā sabba nāma saddā honti
translated: In the case of a mere statement, all the words of the declensions beginning with sabba are masculine.

original: Sā pamukhā yassa so tappamukho. Evaṃ tappadhāno, tāya tāhi vā sampayutto taṃsampayutto.
analyzed: sā pamukhā yassa saḥ tad pamukhaḥ evam tad padhānaḥ tāya tāhi vā sampayutto tad sampayuttaḥ
translated: He who has that as his chief is tappamukho. So too, tappadhāno, associated with that, with those, is taṃsampayutto.

original: Sā eva pamukhā tappamukhā. Evaṃ tappadhānā, tassā mukhaṃ tammukhaṃ, tassaṃ gāthāyaṃ
analyzed: sā eva pamukhā tad pamukhā evam tad padhānā tassāḥ mukham tad mukham tassam
translated: That itself is chief, tappamukhā. So too, tappadhānā, the face of that, of those, is tammukhaṃ. In that verse,

original: tāsu gāthāsu vā tatra, tāya gāthato tāhi vā gāthāhi tato, tassaṃ velāyaṃ tadā iccādi.
analyzed: tāsu gāthāsu vā tatra tāya gāthato tāhi vā gāthāhi tatas iccādi
translated: in those verses, from that, from those verses, at that time, then, and so on.

original: Ettha ca vutti nāma samāsa, taddhitā’ yādidhātupaccayanta, vibhattipaccayantānaṃ nāmaṃ.
analyzed: ettha ca vutti nāma samāsa taddhita ya ādi dhātu paccaya nta vibhatti paccaya ntānam
translated: And here a statement is a compound, a nominal suffix, and a declensional ending.

original: Iti pumbhāvātidesarāsi.
analyzed: iti
translated: So much for the masculine gender.

original: Samāsantakapaccayarāsi🔽365. Ltitthiyūhi ko ka. 338; rū. 356; nī. 725; caṃ. 4.4.140; pā. 5.4.152.🔽Aññapadatthavisaye kattuiccādīhi ltupaccayantehi itthiyaṃ ī, ūkārantehi ca bahulaṃ kapaccayo hoti.🔽Bahavo kattāro yasmiṃ dese so bahukattuko. Evaṃ bahuvattuko, bahukā nadiyo yasmiṃ
analyzed: samāsa antaka paccaya rāsi              añña padattha visaye kattu icca ādīhi ltu paccaya antehi itthiyam ī ūkāra antehi ca bahulam ka paccayaḥ hoti  bahavaḥ kattāraḥ yasmin dese saḥ bahu kattukaḥ evam bahu vattukaḥ bahukāḥ nadiyaḥ yasmin
translated: The class of suffixes beginning with ka🔽In the domain of the meaning of the other words, the feminine is ī, and the suffixes beginning with ka are often used with words ending in ū, by the suffixes beginning with ltu and by the suffixes beginning with iccā.🔽In a place where there are many agents, it is bahukattuka. It is also bahuvattuka. In a place where there are many rivers, it is bahunadīka.

original: dese so bahunadiko. Evaṃ bahuitthiko, gāmo, bahuitthikā, sabhā, bahuitthikaṃ, kulaṃ.🔽Evaṃ bahukumārikaṃ, bahubrahmabandhuko.🔽Ettha ca ‘brahmabandhū’ti rassapadaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ vadati, dīghapadaṃ brāhmaṇiṃ vadati, kapaccaye pare dīghānaṃ mahāvuttinā rassattaṃ icchanti.🔽Bahulanti kiṃ? Bahukattā, gāmo.🔽366. Vāññato ka. 338; rū. 356; nī. 725; caṃ. 6.2.72; pā. 5.4.152.🔽Aññapadatthavisaye ltitthiyūhi aññato avaṇṇivaṇṇuvaṇṇantehi bahulaṃ kapaccayo hoti vā.
analyzed: dese saḥ bahu nadikaḥ evam bahu itthikaḥ gāmaḥ bahu itthikā sabhā bahu itthikam kulam 🔽evam bahukumārikam bahu brahmabandhukaḥ 🔽ettha ca brahmabandhūti rassa padam brāhmaṇam vadati dīgha padam brāhmaṇim vadati ka pad caye pare dīghānam mahā vuttinā rassa ttam icchanti 🔽bahulanti kim bahukattā gāmaḥ 🔽vāññatas ka rū nī cam pā 🔽añña padattha visaye l ti tthiyūhi aññatas a vaṇṇi vaṇṇu vaṇṇa antehi bahulam ka paccayaḥ hoti vā

original: Avaṇṇantamhā tāva –
analyzed: tāva
translated: As to the uninflected:

original: Agāmakaṃ, araññaṃ, bahugāmako, janapado, sasotako, asotako, salomako, sapakkhako, bahumālako, bahumālo, bahumāyako, bahumāyo.
analyzed: agāmakam araññam bahu gāmakaḥ janapadaḥ sa sotakaḥ a sotakaḥ sa lomakaḥ sa pakkhakaḥ bahu mālakaḥ bahu mālaḥ bahu māyakaḥ bahu māyo
translated: Agāmakaṃ, araññaṃ, bahugāmako, janapado, sasotako, asotako, salomako, sapakkhako, bahumālako, bahumālo, bahumāyako, bahumāyo.

original: Ivaṇṇantamhā –
analyzed: i v a ṇ antamhā
