original: Sundarā diṭṭhi yassa so sammādiṭṭhiko, sammādiṭṭhi, micchādiṭṭhiko, micchādiṭṭhi, matapatikā, itthī, saddhāpakatiko, paññāpakatiko, bahuhatthiko, bahudaṇḍiko.
analyzed: sundarā diṭṭhi yassa so sammādiṭṭhiko sammādiṭṭhi micchādiṭṭhiko micchādiṭṭhi mata patikā itthī saddhā pakatiko paññā pakatiko bahu hatthikaḥ bahu daṇḍiko
translated: Sundarā diṭṭhi yassa so sammādiṭṭhiko, sammādiṭṭhi, micchādiṭṭhiko, micchādiṭṭhi, matapatikā, itthī, saddhāpakatiko, paññāpakatiko, bahuhatthiko, bahudaṇḍiko.

original: Uvaṇṇantamhā –
analyzed: uvaṇṇantamhā
translated: As to the uninflected and inflected:

original: Sahetuko, ahetuko, sacakkhuko, acakkhuko, sabhikkhuko, abhikkhuko, dīghāyuko, appāyuko, bahudhenuko, vajo, bahurattaññuko, bhikkhusaṅgho.🔽Itthiliṅge kamhi pare akārassa mahāvuttinā vā ‘adhātussa ke…’ti suttena vā bahulaṃ ikārattaṃ hoti, bahuputtikā, itthī, bahuputtakā vā, ekaputtikā, ekaputtakā iccādi.🔽Iti samāsantakapaccayarāsi.
analyzed: sa hetukaḥ a hetukaḥ sa cakkhukaḥ a cakkhukaḥ sa bhikkhukaḥ abhikkhukaḥ dīgha āyukaḥ appa āyukaḥ bahu dhenukaḥ vajaḥ bahu rattaññukaḥ bhikkhu saṅghaḥ  itthi liṅge kamhi pare akārassa mahāvuttinā vā a dhātussa ka iti suttena vā bahulam i kāra ttam hoti bahu puttikā itthī bahu puttakā vā eka puttikā eka puttakā iccādi  iti samāsa antaka paccaya rāsi
translated: Sahetuko, ahetuko, sacakkhuko, acakkhuko, sabhikkhuko, abhikkhuko, dīghāyuko, appāyuko, bahudhenuko, vajo, bahurattaññuko, bhikkhusaṅgho.

original: Samāsantaapaccayarāsi
analyzed: samāsa anta a paccaya ra āsi
translated: In the feminine noun, in the case of the base ending in a vowel, the vowel i is often lengthened by the rule ‘In the feminine, in the case of the base ending in a vowel, the vowel i is lengthened in the nominative singular and in the vocative singular, except in the case of a noun in the feminine ending in a vowel and in the case of a noun in the feminine ending in a vowel and in the case of a noun in the feminine ending in a vowel and in the case of a noun in the feminine ending in a vowel and in the case of a noun in the feminine ending in a vowel and in the case of a noun in the feminine ending in a vowel and in the case of a noun in the feminine ending in a vowel and in the case of a noun in the feminine ending in a vowel and in the case of a noun in the feminine ending in a vowel and in the case of a noun in the feminine ending in a vowel and in the case of a noun in the feminine ending in a vowel and in the case of a noun in the feminine ending in a vowel and in the case of a noun in the feminine ending in a vowel and in the case of a noun in the feminine ending in a vowel and in the case of a noun in the feminine ending in a vowel and in the case of a noun in the feminine ending in a vowel and in the case

original: 367. Samāsanta ka. 337; rū. 350; nī. 722; caṃ. 4.4.52; pā. 5.4.68; ‘tva’ (bahūsu).
analyzed: samāsanta ka rū nī cam pā tva bahūsu
translated: 367. Samāsanto+a.

original: ‘Samāsanto+a’ iti dvipadamidaṃ, samāsanto hutvā apaccayo hotīti attho. Adhikārasuttamidaṃ.
analyzed: iti dvipadam idam samāsantaḥ hutvā apaccayaḥ hoti iti attho adhikāra suttam idam
translated: This is a two-word formula. The meaning is: having become a compound, it becomes a postposition. This is a sutra of extension.

original: 368. Pāpādīhi bhūmiyā ka. 337; rū. 350; nī. 722; caṃ. 4.4.72; …pe… 5.4.75; ‘godāvarīnaṃ’ (bahūsu).
analyzed: bahūsu
translated: . Pāpādīhi bhūmiyā ka. ; rū. ; nī. ; caṃ. ..; …pe… ..; ‘godāvarīnaṃ’ (bahūsu).

original: Pāpādīhi parāya bhūmiyā samāsanto ahoti, ‘bhūmisaddassā’ti vattabbe niyatitthiliṅgadassanatthaṃ ‘bhūmiyā’ti vuttaṃ. Evaṃ aññatthapi.
analyzed: pāpa ādīhi parāya bhūmiyā samāsa antaḥ aho ti bhūmi saddassa ati vattabbe niya titthi liṅga dassana attham bhūmiyā iti vuttam evam aññattha api
translated: Having become a compound with a following word beginning with pāpa, it becomes a, but ‘bhūmi’ is said instead of ‘bhūmisaddassa’ in order to show the invariable gender of the noun. So too in other cases.

original: Pāpānaṃ bhūmi pāpabhūmaṃ, pāpānaṃ uppattibhūmityattho, jātiyā bhūmi jātibhūmaṃ, satthujātaraṭṭhaṃ. Evaṃ pacchābhūmaṃ, majjhimadese pacchābhāgaraṭṭhaṃ.
analyzed: pāpānam bhūmi pāpa bhūmam pāpānam uppatti bhūmi iti attho jātiyāḥ bhūmi jāti bhūmam satthu jāta raṭṭham evam pacchā bhūmam majjhima dese pacchā bhāga raṭṭham
translated: The land of pāpas is pāpabhūmaṃ, the meaning is: the land of the arising of pāpas. The land of birth is jātibhūmaṃ, the country of the birth of the Teacher. So too pacchābhūmaṃ, the country of the rear guard in the middle country.

analyzed: saṅkhyāhi ka rū nī cam pā
translated: . Saṅkhyāhi ka. ; rū. ; nī. ; caṃ. ..; pā. ...

original: Saṅkhyāhi parāya bhūmiyā samāsanto a hoti.
analyzed: saṅkhyāhi parāya bhūmiyā samāsantaḥ a hoti
translated: Having become a compound with a following word beginning with a numeral, it becomes a.

original: Dve bhūmiyo etthāti dvibhūmo, dvibhūmako, pāsādo, dvibhūmiko vā, tisso bhūmiyo etesanti
analyzed: dve bhūmiyaḥ ettha ati dvi bhūmaḥ dvi bhūmakaḥ pāsādaḥ dvi bhūmikaḥ vā tissaḥ bhūmiyaḥ etesanti
translated: Or they are called two-storied because they are included in three floors.

original: vā tīsu bhūmisu pariyāpannāti vā tebhūmakā, dhammā, catubhūmakā, dhammā, tebhūmikā,
analyzed: vā tīsu bhūmisu pariyāpannā ati vā tebhūmakāḥ dhammā catu bhūmakāḥ dhammā tebhūmikā
translated: Or they are called three-storied, four-storied, three-storied,

original: catubhūmikā vā. Digumhi-dve bhūmiyo dvibhūmaṃ, tisso bhūmiyo tibhūmaṃ, catasso bhūmiyo catubhūmaṃ iccādi.
analyzed: catu bhūmikā vā digumhi dve bhūmiyaḥ dvi bhūmam tissaḥ bhūmiyaḥ ti bhūmam catassaḥ bhūmiyaḥ catu bhūmam iccādi
translated: four-storied. In the two-storied one there are two floors, in the three-storied one there are three floors, in the four-storied one there are four floors, and so on.

original: 370. Nadīgodhāvarīnaṃ ka. 337; rū. 350; nī. 722; caṃ. 4.4.73; pā. 5.4.75.
analyzed: nadī godhā varī nam ka rū nī cam pā
translated: . In the compound of the river and the Godhāvarī, ka. ; rū. ; nī. ; caṃ. ..; pā. ...

original: Saṅkhyāhi parāsaṃ nadī, godhāvarīnaṃ samāsanto a hoti.
analyzed: saṅkhyāhi parāsam nadī samāsantaḥ a hoti
translated: The compound of the river and the Godhāvarī has a final a when the number is more than one.

original: Pañca nadiyo pañcanadaṃ, pañca vā nadiyo yasmiṃ padese so pañcanado, satta godhāvariyo sattagodhāvaraṃ.
analyzed: pañca pañcanadam pañca vā nadiyaḥ yasmin padese saḥ pañcanadaḥ satta godhāvariyaḥ satta godhāvaram
translated: Five rivers is a five-rivered place, or a five-rivered country. Seven Godhāvarīs is a seven-Godhāvarī.

original: 371. Asaṅkhyehi caṅgulyānaññāsaṅkhyatthesu ka. 337; rū. 350; nī. 722; caṃ. 4.4.74; pā. 5.4.86.
analyzed: asaṅkhyehi ca aṅguli anañña asaṅkhya tthesu ka rū nī caṃ pā
translated: . In the meaning of an indefinite number, ka. ; rū. ; nī. ; caṃ. ..; pā. ...

original: Aññattho ca asaṅkhyattho ca aññāsaṅkhyatthā. Tattha ‘aññattho’ti aññapadattho bahubbīhisamāso,
analyzed: aññatthaḥ ca asaṅkhya tthaḥ ca aññā asaṅkhya tthā tattha aññatthaḥ iti añña pada tthaḥ bahubbīhi samāsaḥ
translated: The indefinite number is the indefinite number. Therein, ‘indefinite number’ means the meaning of another word, a bahubbīhi compound,🔽.

original: ‘asaṅkhyattho’ti asaṅkhyatthasamāso abyayībhāvasamāsoti vuttaṃ hoti, na aññāsaṅkhyatthā
analyzed: asaṅkhya ttho ti asaṅkhya ttha samāsaḥ abyayībhāva samāso ti vuttam hoti na aññā asaṅkhya tthā
translated: ‘The meaning of an incalculable number’ means that the compound is a non-copulative compound, a non-copulative determinative compound. It is not a compound with another meaning of a number.

original: anaññāsaṅkhyatthā, aññāsaṅkhyatthavajjitesu samāsesu asaṅkhyehi upasaggehi ca saṅkhyāhi
analyzed: an aññā saṅkhyā tthāḥ aññā saṅkhyā ttha vajjitesu samāsesu asaṅkhyehi upasaggehi ca saṅkhyāhi
translated: Not with another meaning of a number: in compounds with the exclusion of another meaning of a number, with incalculable numbers, and with

original: ca parāya aṅguliyā samāsanto a hoti. Casaddena “sugataṅgulena, pamāṇaṅgulena” iccādīni sijjhanti.
analyzed: ca parāya aṅguliyā a hoti ca saddena sugata ṅgulena pamāṇa ṅgulena icca ādīni sijjhanti
translated: numbers, the vowel a is the ending when combined with the numeral ‘more than’. By the word ‘ca’ it is allowed that ‘sugataṅgula’, ‘pamāṇaṅgula’ and so on are correct.

original: Aṅgulīhi niggataṃ niraṅgulaṃ, aṅguliyo atikkantaṃ accaṅgulaṃ, ime dve amādisamāsā, dve aṅguliyo samāhaṭāti dvaṅgulaṃ.
analyzed: aṅgulīhi niggatam niraṅgulam aṅguliyaḥ atikkantam accaṅgulam ime dve am ādi samāsāḥ dve aṅguliyaḥ dvi aṅguliyaḥ dvi aṅguliyaḥ
translated: ‘Niraṅgula’ is that which is devoid of fingers; ‘acchaṅgula’ is that which exceeds the fingers. These two are compounds beginning with a, and ‘dvaṅgula’ is that which is combined with two fingers.

original: Anaññāsaṅkhyatthesūti kiṃ? Pañca aṅguliyo asminti pañcaṅguli, hattho. Aṅguliyā samīpaṃ
analyzed: anaññā saṅkhya tthesu iti kim pañca aṅguliyaḥ asmin ti pañca aṅguli hatthaḥ aṅguliyā samīpam
translated: ‘Not with another meaning of a number’: what is the example? ‘Pañcaṅguli’ means ‘in this there are five fingers’, namely, the hand. ‘Upaṅguli’ is the vicinity of the finger.

original: upaṅguli. “Caturaṅgulaṃ kaṇṇaṃ osāretvā mahāva. 66, aṭṭhaṅgulaṃ dantakaṭṭhaṃ, dvaṅgulaparamaṃ,
analyzed: upaṅguli catur aṅgulam kaṇṇam osāretvā aṭṭhaṅgulam dantakaṭṭham dvaṅgula paramam
translated: ‘Having drawn the ear back four fingers’s breadth, Great Sage, a tooth-stick eight fingers’ breadth, two fingers’ breadth at the most,

original: caturaṅgulaparamaṃ, aṭṭhaṅgulaparama”ntiādīsu ‘aṅgula’nti akārantaṃ pamāṇavācīsaddantaraṃ.
analyzed: catur aṅgula paramam aṭṭha aṅgula paramanti ādīsu aṅgula anti akāra antam
translated: four fingers’ breadth at the most, eight fingers’ breadth at the most’—in these examples ‘aṅgula’ is a word denoting a measure without a case-ending and without another word.

original: 372. Dārumhaṅgulyā ka. 337; rū. 350; nī. 722; caṃ. 4.4.97; pā. 5.4.114; ‘dārumyaṅgulyā’ (bahūsu).
analyzed: dārumī aṅgulyā ka rū nī caṃ pā dārumī aṅgulyā bahūsu
translated: ‘A finger of wood’: ‘a finger of wood’ (in the plural).

original: Dārusaṅkhāte aññapadatthe pavattāya aṅguliyā samāsanto ahoti.
analyzed: dāru saṅkhāte añña padatthe pavattāya aṅguliyā samāsantaḥ
translated: The compound ending in ‘a finger’ is made with the word ‘wood’ in the sense of ‘another word’.

original: Pañca aṅguliyo assāti pañcaṅgulaṃ, dāru. Ettha ca aṅgulipamāṇāvayavo dhaññādīnaṃ mānaviseso ‘dārū’ti vuccati.🔽373. Dīghāhovassekadesehi ca ratyā ka. 337; rū. 350; nī. 722; caṃ. 4.4.75; pā. 5.4.87.🔽Dīgho ca aho ca vasso ca ekadeso cāti dvando, ekadeso nāma pubba, parādi, anaññāsaṅkhyatthesu
analyzed: pañca aṅguliyaḥ assa ati pañca aṅgulam dāru ettha ca aṅguli pamāṇa avayavaḥ dhañña ādīnam māna visesaḥ dāru iti vuccati  dīgha a ha u vassa ika desehi ca ratyā ka rū nī caṃ pā  dīghaḥ ca aho ca vasso ca ekadeso ca ati dvandaḥ ekadesaḥ nāma pubba para ādi anaññā saṅkhya tthesu
translated: ‘Five fingers’: ‘five fingers’. ‘Wood’ (in the plural). And here the measure of grain, etc., which is a part the size of a finger is called ‘wood’.🔽‘Long night’: ‘long night’ (in the plural).🔽‘Long’ and ‘night’ and ‘rain’ and ‘part’ are a copulative compound, and a ‘part’ is a prefix, a suffix, and a non-associated numerical category.

original: dīghādīhi ca asaṅkhyehi ca saṅkhyāhi ca parāya rattiyā samāsanto a hoti. Casaddena
analyzed: dīgha ādīhi ca asaṅkhyehi ca saṅkhyāhi ca parāya rattiyā samāsantaḥ a hoti ca saddena
translated: The compound ending in ‘a’ is made with the words ‘long’, etc., and with the numericals, and with the ‘night’ that is beyond the ‘long’ night. The word ‘and’

original: “ciraratta”nti sijjhati.
analyzed: sijjhati
translated: makes it possible to say ‘long night’.

original: Dīghā rattiyo dīgharattaṃ, dīghā rattidivaparaṃparātyattho. Aho ca ratti ca ahorattaṃ,
analyzed: dīghāḥ rattiyaḥ dīgha rattam dīghāḥ ratti diva paraṃparā atyattho aho ca ratti ca ahorattam
translated: ‘Long night’ is a long succession of nights, the meaning is, a long succession of nights and days. ‘Night and day’ is a copulative compound.

original: vassena temitā ratti vassarattaṃ, rattiyā pubbaṃ pubbarattaṃ, rattiyā paraṃ pararattaṃ,
analyzed: vassena temitā ratti vassa rattam rattiyā pubbam pubba rattam rattiyā param para rattam
translated: A night wet with rain is a rainy night. The first part of the night is the first part of the night. The last part of the night is the last part of the night.

original: rattiyā aḍḍhaṃ aḍḍharattaṃ, rattiṃ atikkanto atiratto, dve rattiyo dvirattaṃ. Evaṃ
analyzed: rattiyāḥ aḍḍham aḍḍha rattam rattim atikkantaḥ ati rattaḥ dve rattiyaḥ dvi rattam evam
translated: The middle of the night is the middle of the night. Having passed the night, it is the night passed. Two nights are two nights. Thus

original: tirattaṃ, caturattaṃ, pañcarattaṃ, chārattaṃ, vādhikārattā “ekarattaṃ, ekarattī”ti sijjhati.
analyzed: tirattam caturattam pañcarattam chārattam vā adhikārattā eka rattam ekarattī iti sijjhati
translated: three nights, four nights, five nights, six nights, more than a night. “One night, one night” is correct.

original: Anaññāsaṅkhyatthesūti kiṃ? Dīghā ratti etthāti dīgharatti, hemanto. Rattiyā samīpaṃ uparatti.
analyzed: anaññā saṅkhya tthesu iti kim dīghā ratti ettha ati dīgha ratti hemantaḥ rattiyā samīpam uparatti
translated: In the sense of non-other-number? A long night here is a long night, winter. Near the night is the near night.

original: 374. Go tvacatthe cālope ka. 337; rū. 350; nī. 722; caṃ. 4.4.77; pā. 5.4.92.
analyzed: go tvacatthe ca a lope ka rū nī caṃ pā
translated: . The word “cow” in the sense of animal is “alopa” in the sense of “ca”. ; rū. ; nī. ; caṃ. ..; pā. ...

original: Acatthe ca anaññā’saṅkhyatthesu ca pavattā gosaddamhā alopaṭṭhāne samāsanto a hoti.
analyzed: a c atthe ca an aññā saṅkhyā tthesu ca pavattā go sadda mhā a lopa ṭṭhāne samāsa antaḥ a hoti
translated: The compound ending in “alopa” occurs in the sense of animal and in the sense of non-other-number.

original: Rañño go rājagavo, attano go sagavo, paresaṃ go paragavo, pañcagavo, pañcagavaṃ. Evaṃ dasagavaṃ.
analyzed: raññaḥ go rājagavaḥ attanaḥ go sagavaḥ paresam go paragavaḥ pañcagavaḥ pañcagavam evam dasagavam
translated: The king’s cow is the royal cow. One’s own cow is one’s own cow. Another’s cow is another’s cow. Five cows, five cows. Thus ten cows.

original: Alopeti kiṃ? Pañcahi gohi kīto pañcagu. Ettha ca tena kītoti etasmiṃ atthe taddhitapaccayassa lopo, tena ayaṃ apaccayo na hoti, ‘gossū’ti ossuttaṃ.
analyzed: a lopa iti kim pañcahi gohi pañcagu ettha ca tena kīto iti etasmin atthe taddhita paccayassa lopo tena ayam a paccayaḥ na hoti gossu iti ossuttam
translated: What is the affixing? The five cows are the five-cow-pen. And here the elision of the affix -ttha is in the sense of ‘by that’, thus the affix -ttha is not here. The -ss- is the substitute for -ss- in go.

original: Acattheti kiṃ? Gavajā ca gāvo ca gavajagavo, yomhi gossa gavattaṃ.
analyzed: acattha iti kim gavajāḥ ca gāvaḥ ca gavajagavaḥ yomhi gossa gavattam
translated: What is the elision of the case-ending? The cows and the cow-pen are the cow-pen. I am the owner of the cow.

original: Anaññāsaṅkhyatthesūti kiṃ? Cittagu, upagu.
analyzed: an aññā saṅkhyā tthesu iti kim cittagu upagu
translated: What is the elision in the sense of ‘not another’s number’? The five-hundred, the five-hundred-pen.

original: 375. Rattidiva dāragava caturassā ka. 337; rū. 350; nī. 722; caṃ. 4.4.62; pā. 5.4.77.
analyzed: rattidiva dāragava caturassā ka rū nī caṃ pā
translated: Night and day are the night-and-day. Wife and cows are the wife-and-cows. He who has four horses is the four-horse. The affix -ttha is not. The -ss- is the substitute for -ss- in assu.

original: Ete tayo saddā aantā nipaccante.
analyzed: ete tayo saddāḥ a antāḥ nipaccante
translated: These three words end in a vowel.

original: Ratti ca divā ca rattidivaṃ, dārā ca gāvo ca dāragavaṃ, catasso assiyo yassa so caturasso, apaccayo, assissa issa attaṃ.🔽376. Āyāmenugavaṃ ka. 337; rū. 350; nī. 722; caṃ. 4.4.69; pā. 5.4.83.🔽Āyāme gamyamāne anugavanti nipaccate.🔽Gohi anuṭṭhitaṃ sakaṭaṃ anugavaṃ.
analyzed: ratti ca divā ca ratti divam dārā ca gāvaḥ ca dāragavam catassaḥ assiyaḥ yassa saḥ caturasso apaccayaḥ assissa issa attam  āyā menugavam ka rū nī cam pā  āyāme gamyamāne anugavanti nipaccate  gohi anuṭṭhitam sakaṭam anugavam
translated: Night and day are the night-and-day. Wife and cows are the wife-and-cows. He who has four horses is the four-horse. The affix -ttha is not. The -ss- is the substitute for -ss- in assu.🔽. The cart that goes along with the cows is the cow-cart.

original: Āyāmeti kiṃ? Gunnaṃ pacchā anugu.
analyzed: āyāma iti kim pacchā anugu
translated: What is the elision of the case-ending? The cows that go behind the cart are the behind-cows.🔽. The cart that goes along with the cows is the cow-cart.🔽What is the elision of the case-ending? The cows that go behind the cart are the behind-cows.

original: 377. Akkhismāññatthe ka. 337; rū. 350; nī. 722; caṃ. 4.4.96; pā. 5.4.113.
analyzed: akkhisma aññatthe ka rū nī cam pā
translated: In the sense of ‘eye’ it is a indeclinable.

original: Aññapadatthe pavattā akkhimhā samāsanto a hoti.🔽Visālāni akkhīni yassa so visālakkho, virūpāni akkhīni yassa so virūpakkho, anekasahassāni
analyzed: añña pada atthe pavattā akkhimhā samāsa antaḥ a hoti  visālāni akkhīni yassa saḥ visālakkhaḥ virūpāni akkhīni yassa saḥ virūpakkhaḥ aneka sahassāni
translated: When it occurs in the sense of ‘other’ it is a indeclinable in compounds.

original: akkhīni yassa so sahassakkho, lohitāni akkhīni yassa so lohitakkho. Evaṃ nīlakkho,
analyzed: akkhīni yassa so sahassakkhaḥ lohitāni akkhīni yassa saḥ lohitakkhaḥ evam nīlakkhaḥ
translated: He who has large eyes is ‘large-eyed’ (visālakkho); he who has ugly eyes is ‘ugly-eyed’ (virūpakkho); he who has many thousands of eyes is ‘thousand-eyed’ (sahassakkho); he who has red eyes is ‘red-eyed’ (lohitakkho). So too ‘blue-eyed’ (nīlakkho);

original: nīlakkhi vā. Bahulādhikārā anaññatthepi, akkhīnaṃ paṭimukhaṃ paccakkhaṃ, akkhīnaṃ
analyzed: vā bahula adhikārā an aññatthe pi akkhīnam paṭimukham paccakkham akkhīnam
translated: or ‘blue-eyed’ (nīlakkhi vā). By the rule of ‘many and more’ it is also used in the sense of ‘not other’ . The eyes’ face-to-face is ‘face-to-face with the eyes’ (akkhīnaṃ paṭimukhaṃ paccakkhaṃ);

original: parabhāgo parokkhaṃ, akkhīnaṃ tirobhāgo tirokkhaṃ. Akkhisaddena cettha pañcindriyāni gayhanti.
analyzed: parabhāgaḥ parokkham akkhīnam tirobhāgaḥ tirokkham akkhi saddena ca ittha pañca indriyāni gayhanti
translated: the eyes’ opposite side is ‘opposite to the eyes’ (akkhīnaṃ parabhāgo parokkhaṃ); the eyes’ concealed side is ‘concealed from the eyes’ (akkhīnaṃ tirobhāgo tirokkhaṃ). And here the word ‘eye’ signifies the five faculties.

original: Mahāvuttinā kvaci samāsanto a, ā, ipaccayā honti.
analyzed: mahāvuttinā kvaci samāsa antaḥ a ā i paccayāḥ honti
translated: In some instances, by the rule of ‘great’ , it is a indeclinable, a , and a i respectively.

original: Tattha apaccaye –
analyzed: tattha a paccaye
translated: Herein, as a indeclinable:

original: Vāyuno sakhā vāyusakho, vāyusaṅkhāto sakhā assāti vā vāyusakho, aggi, sabbesaṃ piyā’piyamajjhattānaṃ
analyzed: vāyunaḥ sakhā vāyu sakhaḥ vāyu saṅkhātaḥ sakhā assa ati vā vāyu sakhaḥ aggi sabbesam piya apiya majjhattānam
translated: He who is a friend of the wind is ‘wind-friend’ (vāyusakho); or he who is a friend called ‘wind’ is ‘wind-friend’ (vāyusaṅkhāto sakhā assa vāyusakho); fire; of all dear, neutral, and indifferent persons

original: sakhāti sabbasakho, sabbe vā sakhāyo assāti sabbasakho, mettāvihārī. “Sabbamitto🔽sabbasakho”ti theragā. 648 pāḷi. Pāpānaṃ sakhāti pāpasakho, pāpā sakhāro yassāti🔽vā pāpasakho. “Pāpamitto pāpasakho”ti dī. ni. 3.253 pāḷi. Pahito pesito attā yenāti🔽pahitatto, majjhimo attā sabhāvo yassāti majjhatto, chātaṃ ajjhattasantānaṃ saṇṭhānaṃ
analyzed: sakhā ati sabba sakhaḥ sabbe vā sakhāyaḥ assa ati sabba sakhaḥ mettā vihārī sabba mittaḥ  sabbasakho ti theragā pāḷi pāpānam sakhā ati pāpasakho pāpā sakhāraḥ yassa ati  vā pāpa sakhaḥ pāpa mittaḥ pāpa sakhaḥ iti ni pahitaḥ pesitaḥ attā yena ati  pahitattaḥ majjhimaḥ attā sabhāvaḥ yassa ati majjhattaḥ chātam ajjhatta santānam saṇṭhānam
translated: ‘Friend’ is ‘all-friend’; or all are his friends, thus he is ‘all-friend’, he who abides in loving-kindness. ‘All-friend’ is the reading in the Theragatha . ‘Evil friend’ is ‘evil-friend’; or he has evil for a friend, thus he is ‘evil-friend’. ‘Evil friend’ is the reading in the Dhammapada . ‘Self-collected’ is ‘self-collectedness’; he whose self is collected, thus he is ‘self-collected’. ‘Middling’ is ‘middlingness’; he whose self is middling, thus he is ‘middling’. ‘Inner’ is ‘inner-connectedness’;

original: (mūlapāṭhe) yassāti chātajjhatto, suhito attā yassāti suhitatto, yato saṃyato attā🔽yassāti yatatto, ṭhito attā assāti ṭhitattoiccādi.
analyzed: mūlapāṭhe yassa ati chātajjhattaḥ suhitaḥ attā yassa ati suhitattaḥ yataḥ saṃyataḥ attā  yassa ati yatattaḥ ṭhitaḥ attā assa ati
translated: ‘Friend’ is all-friend, or he has all as friends, he is all-friend, one who abides in loving-kindness. ‘All-friend’ is the Elder’s reading. ‘Pāpa’s friend’ is pāpasakho, or he has evil as a friend, he is pāpasakho. ‘Evil friend’ is the reading of the Dīpa and the Nīti. ‘He has the self sent forth’ is pahitatto, ‘he has the self middling’ is majjhatto, ‘he has the self’s shape concealed’ is chātajjhatto, ‘he has the self well-disposed’ is suhitatto, ‘he has the self restrained’ is yatatto, ‘he has the self standing’ is ṭhitatto, and so on.

original: Āpaccaye –
analyzed: āpad caye
translated: In the sense of ‘cause’ :

original: Paccakkho dhammo yassāti paccakkhadhammā, chādetīti chado, moho, vivaṭo chado yasminti vivaṭacchadā, sammāsambuddho.
analyzed: paccakkhaḥ dhammaḥ yassa ati paccakkha dhammā chādeti iti chadaḥ mohaḥ vivaṭaḥ chadaḥ yasmin ti vivaṭa chadā sammāsambuddho
translated: ‘He has the Dhamma in opposition’ is paccakkhadhammā, ‘he conceals’ is chado, delusion, ‘in whom the concealment is open’ is vivaṭacchadā, a Fully Enlightened One.

original: Ipaccaye –
analyzed: i pad caye
translated: In the sense of ‘cause’ :

original: Sundaro gandho yassāti sugandhi, kucchito gandho yassāti duggandhi, pūtino gandho
analyzed: sundaraḥ gandhaḥ yassa ati sugandhi kucchitaḥ gandhaḥ yassa ati duggandhi pūtinaḥ gandhaḥ
translated: ‘He has a good smell’ is sugandhi, ‘he has a bad smell’ is duggandhi, ‘he has a smell of corruption’ is pūtigandhi,

original: yassāti pūtigandhi, surabhino gandho surabhigandhi. “Sarīrassa sugandhino, guṇagandhiyutto aha”nti pāḷi.
analyzed: yassa ati pūti gandhi surabhinaḥ gandho surabhi gandhi sarīrassa sugandhinaḥ guṇa gandhi yuttaḥ ahanti
translated: “Whose” is pūtigandhi, “of a fragrant smell” is surabhigandhi. The text has: “I am endowed with the smell of virtue, of the fragrant body.”

original: Iti samāsantaapaccayarāsi.
analyzed: iti samāsa anta a paccaya rāsi
translated: Thus ends the collection of the conditions for the analysis.

original: Nānādesarāsi🔽378. Uttarapade ka. 333-334; rū. 344-345; nī. 717-718.
analyzed: nānā desarā asi  uttara pade ka rū nī
translated: The collection of various countries

original: Uttarapade pare pubbapade vidhi hotīti attho. Adhikārasuttamidaṃ.🔽“Abrāhmaṇo, anariyo, abhikkhuko, ananto”iccādīsu samāse uttarapade pare na-kārassa a, ana honti.
analyzed: uttara pade pare pubba pade hoti iti atthaḥ adhikāra suttam idam  a brāhmaṇaḥ an ariyaḥ a bhikkhukaḥ an antaḥ icca ādīsu samāse uttara pade pare nakārassa a a na honti
translated: In the northern part of the compound, the rule is that the preceding word is changed. The meaning is: this is a discourse on the subject.

analyzed: nakha ādayaḥ ka rū nī cam pā
translated: In compounds such as “not a brahmin,” “not a noble one,” “not a beggar,” “not infinite,” the “na” is changed to “a” and “ana” when the following word begins with a vowel.

original: Nakhādayo saddā napakatikā sijjhanti.
analyzed: nakha ādayo saddāḥ sijjhanti
translated: The words “nail” and so on are formed in this way.🔽The words “nail” and so on are formed with the prefix “na.”

original: Nā’ssa khamatthīti nakho, ‘kha’nti sukhaṃ, dukkhañca, nā’ssa kulamatthīti nakulo,
analyzed: na assa kham atthi iti nakhaḥ khanti sukham dukkham ca na assa kulam atthi iti nakulaḥ
translated: “There is no comfort” is “nail,” “kha” means happiness and suffering. “There is no family” is “nakula,”

original: evaṃnāmako brāhmaṇo, pumassa sakaṃ puṃsakaṃ natthi puṃsakaṃ etasminti napuṃsako,
analyzed: evaṃnāmakaḥ brāhmaṇo pumassa sakam puṃsakam na atthi puṃsakam etasmin ti napuṃsakaḥ
translated: a brahmin with such a name. “There is no male organ” is “napumsaka,” “male organ” is puṃsaka.

original: khañjanaṃ vekallagamanaṃ khattaṃ, natthi khattaṃ etassāti nakkhattaṃ, kaṃ vuccati
analyzed: khañjanam vekallagamanam khattam na atthi khattam etassa ati nakkhattam kam vuccati
translated: “There is no astrology” is “nakkhatta,” “kha” means moving in a crooked way, “khatta” is astrology.

original: sukhaṃ, tabbiruddhattā akaṃ vuccati dukkhaṃ, natthi akaṃ etasminti nāko, saggo, na
analyzed: sukham tad biruddha ttā akam vuccati dukkham na atthi akam etasmin ti nākaḥ saggaḥ na
translated: Pleasure is called “pain” because it is opposed to pain. There is no “not-pain” in this, thus it is a “happy place” (nako), a heaven.

original: muñcatīti namuci, māro. Na galati na cavatīti nagaraṃ, gehe vattabbe ‘agāra’nti sijjhati.
analyzed: muñcati iti namuci māraḥ na galati na cavati iti nagaram gehe vattabbe agāranti sijjhati
translated: It does not release, thus it is a “non-releaser” (namuci), a Mara. It does not flow, does not pass away, thus it is a “non-flowing” (nagara), a city. In the case of what is to be stated as “house” (agāra), “house” is established.🔽“A naga or a bird” (in many places).

original: 380. Nago vā pāṇini ka. 333-334; rū. 344-345; nī. 717-718; caṃ. 5.2.96; pā. 6.3.77; ‘nago vāppāṇini’ (bahūsu).🔽Apāṇimhi nagoti sijjhati vā.
analyzed: nagaḥ vā pāṇini ka rū nī cam pā nagaḥ bahūsu  a pāṇimhi nagoti sijjhati vā
translated: In the case of “non-bird” (apāṇi), “naga” is established.

original: Na gacchantīti nagā, rukkhā. Nagā, pabbatā. Agā, rukkhā, agā, pabbatā.
analyzed: na gacchanti iti nagāḥ rukkhāḥ nagāḥ pabbatāḥ agāḥ rukkhāḥ agāḥ pabbatā
translated: They do not go, thus they are “non-goers” (nagā), trees. “Nagā” , mountains. “Agā” , trees. “Agā” , mountains.

original: Apāṇinīti kiṃ? Ago vasalo kiṃ tena. Ettha ‘ago’ti duggatajano, ‘vasalo’ti lāmako, ‘kiṃ tenā’ti nindāvacanaṃ, “sītenā”tipi pāṭho. Evaṃ neke, aneke, nekāni, anekāni iccādi.
analyzed: apāṇinī iti kim agaḥ vasalo kim tena ettha agaḥ iti duggata janaḥ lāmakaḥ kim tena ati nindā vacanam evam neke aneke nekāni anekāni iccādi
translated: What is the meaning of “non-bird”? “What is the use of a non-bird (ago)?” Here “ago” is a low-born person, “vasala” is a contemptible person, “what is the use of that?” is a word of contempt. The reading “with cold” is also found. Thus “many” , “various” , “many” , “various” , etc.

original: Iti na-rāsi.🔽381. Sahassa soññatthe ka. 404; rū. 370; nī. 859; caṃ. 5.2.97; pā. 6.3.82.
analyzed: iti narā asi  sahassa sa uññatthe ka rū nī cam pā
translated: Thus the “na” group.🔽“Thousand” in the sense of “together” (soññatthe).

original: Aññapadatthe samāse uttarapade pare sahassa so hoti vā.
analyzed: añña pada atthe samāse uttara pade pare sahassa so hoti vā
translated: In a compound with another word in the sense of “different” (aññapadatthe), “thousand” becomes “so” after a following word.

original: Puttena saha yo vattatīti saputto, sahaputto.
analyzed: puttena saha yaḥ vattati iti sa puttaḥ saha puttaḥ
translated: One who acts together with a son is “with-son” (saputto), “together-son” (sahaputto).

original: Aññattheti kiṃ? Saha katvā, saha yujjhitvā.
analyzed: aññattha iti kim saha katvā saha yujjhitvā
translated: In the sense of ‘together with’?—Saha katvā, saha yujjhitvā.

analyzed: saññā yam ka rū nī cam pā
translated: In a compound with saññā, the words ka, rū, nī, caṃ, pā become so.

original: Saññāyaṃ uttarapade pare sahassa so hoti.
analyzed: saññāyam uttara pade pare sahassa saḥ hoti
translated: In a compound with saññā, the words ka, rū, nī, caṃ, pā become so when the following word begins with a vowel.

original: Saha āyattaṃ sāyattaṃ, saha palāsaṃ sapalāsaṃ, agarukārassetaṃ nāmaṃ.
analyzed: sahaḥ āyattam sa āyattam saha palāsam sa palāsam agarukārassa etam nāmam
translated: Saha āyattaṃ sāyattaṃ, saha palāsaṃ sapalāsaṃ, agarukārassetaṃ nāmaṃ.🔽In a compound with apaccakkha, the words ka, rū, nī, caṃ, pā become so.

original: 383. Apaccakkhe ka. 404; rū. 307; nī. 859; caṃ. 5.2.99; pā. 6.3.80.🔽Apaccakkhe gamyamāne uttarapade pare sahassa so hoti.
analyzed: a paccakkhe ka rū nī cam pā  a paccakkhe gamyamāne uttara pade pare sahassa saḥ hoti
translated: In a compound with apaccakkha, the words ka, rū, nī, caṃ, pā become so when the following word begins with a vowel.

original: Oḍḍiyati etāyāti oḍḍi, pāso. Oḍḍiyā saha yo vattatīti soḍḍi, kapoto. Idha ‘oḍḍi’
analyzed: oḍḍiyati etāyāti oḍḍi pāsaḥ oḍḍiyā saha yaḥ vattati iti soḍḍi kapoto
translated: Oḍḍiyati etāyāti oḍḍi, pāso. Oḍḍiyā saha yo vattatīti soḍḍi, kapoto. Here ‘oḍḍi’

original: apaccakkhā. “Sāggi kapoto”tipi pāṭho, picunā saha vattatīti sapicukā, vātamaṇḍalikā,🔽sā ca apaccakkhā, uggantvā ākāse paribbhamantaṃ picusaṅghāṭaṃ disvā ñātabbā. “Sapisācā
analyzed: apaccakkhā sa aggi kapoto tipi pāṭhaḥ picunā saha vattati iti sa picukā vātamaṇḍalikā  sā ca apaccakkhā uggantvā ākāse paribbhamantam picu saṅghāṭam disvā ñātabbā sa pisācā
translated: is apaccakkha. The reading ‘sāggi kapoto’ is also found. Vattatīti yo vattatīti sapicukā, vātamaṇḍalikā,

original: vātamaṇḍalikā”tipi pāṭho. Evaṃ sarajā, vātā, sarakkhasī, ratti.
analyzed: evam sa rajāḥ vātā sa rakkhasī
translated: and that is apaccakkha. It should be known by seeing a flock of pigeons flying and wandering in the sky. The reading ‘sapisācā vātamaṇḍalikā’ is also found. So sarajā, vātā, sarakkhasī, ratti.

original: 384. Akāle sakatthassa ka. 404; rū. 370; nī. 859; caṃ. 5.2.110; pā. 6.3.81.
analyzed: a kāle sa katthassa ka rū nī cam pā
translated: In a compound with a word meaning ‘season’, the words ka, rū, nī, caṃ, pā become so.

original: Sakatthappadhānassa sahasaddassa so hoti akāle uttarapade pare.
analyzed: sa kattha ppadhānassa saha saddassa saḥ hoti a kāle uttara pade pare
translated: The word saha, which is governed by the word it precedes, is so used before a following word when the latter is not in the accusative case.

original: Sabrahmaṃ, sacakkaṃ.
analyzed: sa brahmam sa cakkam
translated: Saha brahmunā, saha cakkhunā.

original: Akāleti kiṃ? Saha pubbaṇhaṃ, saha paraṇhaṃ, sunakkhattena saha pavattaṃ pubbaṇhaṃ, paraṇhanti attho.
analyzed: akāle iti kim saha pubbaṇham saha paraṇham su nakkhattena saha pavattam pubbaṇham paraṇhanti attho
translated: When is it not so used? Saha pubbaṇhena, saha paraṇṇhena. The meaning is: the morning that occurs with the good constellation.

original: 385. Ganthantādhikye ka. 404; rū. 370; nī. 859; caṃ. 5.2.101; pā. 6.3.79.🔽Ganthassa anto ganthanto. Yathā taṃ kaccāyanaganthassa anto uṇādikappo, adhikabhāvo ādhikyaṃ, ganthante ca ādhikye ca vattamānassa sahasaddassa so hoti uttarapade pare.
analyzed: ganth anta ādhikye ka rū nī cam pā  ganthassa antaḥ ganthantaḥ yathā tam kaccāyana ganthassa antaḥ uṇ ādi kappaḥ adhika bhāvaḥ ādhikyam ganthante ca ādhikye ca vattamānassa saha saddassa saḥ hoti uttara pade pare
translated: Ganthantādhikye ka. ; rū. ; nī. ; caṃ. ..; pā. ...🔽The word saha is so used before a following word when the latter is in the locative case and the word saha is governed by the word preceding it.

original: Saha uṇādinā’ yaṃ adhiyateti taṃ soṇādi, sakalaṃ kaccāyanaṃ adhītetyattho. Saha muhuttena sakalaṃ jotiṃ adhīte samuhuttaṃ, jotīti nakkhattasatthaṃ.
analyzed: saha uṇ ādinā yam adhiyata iti tam sa uṇ ādi sakalam kaccāyanam adhīta iti attho saha muhuttena sakalam jotim adhīte sa muhuttam joti iti nakkhatta sattham
translated: Soṇādi is that which is studied with the uṇādi. The meaning is: he studies the whole of Kaccāyana. Samuhuttaṃ jotī is the whole of the Joti that is studied in a moment. The meaning is: the Joti is the treatise on astrology.

original: Ādhikye – sadoṇā, khārī, sakahāpaṇaṃ, nikkhaṃ, samāsakaṃ, kahāpaṇaṃ. Niccatthamidaṃ suttaṃ.
analyzed: ādhikye sa doṇā khārī sa kahāpaṇam nikkham sa māsakam kahāpaṇam
translated: In the locative case: sadoṇā, khārī, sakahāpaṇaṃ, nikkhaṃ, samāsakaṃ, kahāpaṇaṃ. This is a permanent locative compound.

original: 386. Samānassa pakkhādīsu vā ka. 404; rū. 370; nī. 859; caṃ. 5.2.103-4; pā. 6.3.84-86.🔽Pakkhādīsu uttarapadesu samānassa so hoti vā.
analyzed: samānassa pakkha ādīsu vā ka rū nī cam pā  pakkha ādīsu uttara padesu samānassa saḥ hoti vā
translated: In the northern parts of the words pakkha, etc., the form so is used.

original: Samāno pakkho sahāyo sapakkho, samāno pakkho yassāti vā sapakkho, samānapakkho vā. Evaṃ sajāti, samānajāti, sajanapado, saratti.
analyzed: samānaḥ pakkhaḥ sahāyaḥ sa pakkhaḥ samānaḥ pakkhaḥ yassa ati vā sa pakkhaḥ samāna pakkhaḥ vā evam sajāti samāna jāti sa janapadaḥ sa ratti
translated: The same wing is a companion, a fellow wing, or a fellow wing is his, thus he is a fellow wing. So too, a fellow kind, a fellow clan, a fellow country, a fellow race.

original: Samāno pati yassā sā sapati. Evaṃ sanābhi, sabandhu, sabrahmacārī, sanāmo. Avhayaṃ🔽vuccati nāmaṃ, candena samānaṃ avhayaṃ yassa so candasavhayo, sagotto, indena samānaṃ🔽gottaṃ yassa so indasagotto, sarūpaṃ, saṭṭhānaṃ. Hari vuccati suvaṇṇaṃ, harinā samāno
analyzed: samānaḥ pati yassā sā sapati evam sanābhi sabandhu sabrahmacārī sanāmaḥ avhayam  vuccati nāmam candena samānam avhayam yassa so canda savhayaḥ sa gottaḥ indena samānam  gottam yassa so indasagotto sarūpam saṭṭhānam hari vuccati suvaṇṇam harinā samāno
translated: The same wife is his, thus she is a fellow wife. So too, a fellow navel, a fellow kinsman, a fellow monk, a fellow name.

original: vaṇṇo yassa so harissavaṇṇo, sassa dvittaṃ. Evaṃ siṅgīnikkhasavaṇṇo, savayo, sadhano, sadhammo, sajātiyo.
analyzed: vaṇṇaḥ yassa saḥ harissavaṇṇaḥ evam siṅgīnikkhasavaṇṇaḥ sa vayaḥ sa dhanaḥ sa dhammo sa jātiyo
translated: Name is called avhaya. The same avhaya as the moon is his, thus he is moon-named. The same clan as Indra is his, thus he is Indra-clanned. The same colour as the golden-hued is his, thus he is golden-hued. The same as the second of the six is his, thus he is second-of-the-six-named. So too, he is lion-spotted-named, he is of the same age, he is of the same wealth, he is of the same Dhamma, he is of the same kind.

original: Pakkhādīsūti kiṃ? Samānasīlo.
analyzed: pakkha ādīsu iti kim samāna sīlaḥ
translated: In the same wing, etc., what? He is of the same virtue.

analyzed: udare iye ka rū nī cam pā
translated: The form of the word udara is udare.

original: Iyayutte udare pare samānassa so hoti vā.
analyzed: udare pare samānassa saḥ hoti vā
translated: The form of the word samāna is samānassa.🔽The form of the word udare is udare.🔽The form of the word pare is pare.🔽The form of the word samānassa is samānassa.🔽The form of the word so is hoti.🔽The form of the word samāna is samāna.🔽The form of the word udare is udare.🔽The form of the word jāto is jāto.

original: Samāne udare jāto sodariyo, samānodariyo.
analyzed: samāne udare jātaḥ sodariyaḥ samānodariyaḥ
translated: The form of the word sodariyo is sodariyo.🔽The form of the word samānodariyo is samānodariyo.🔽The form of the word iyeti is iyeti.

original: Iyeti kiṃ? Samānodaratā.
analyzed: iyā iti kim samāna udara tā
translated: The form of the word samānodaratā is samānodaratā.🔽The form of the word aññesupi is aññesupi.🔽The form of the word samānassa is samānassa.🔽The form of the word so is hoti.🔽The form of the word candena is candena.🔽The form of the word samānā is samānā.🔽The form of the word sirī is sirī.🔽The form of the word yassa is yassa.🔽The form of the word taṃ is taṃ.🔽The form of the word candassasirīkaṃ is candassasirīkaṃ.🔽The form of the word mukhaṃ is mukhaṃ.🔽The form of the word padumassasirīkaṃ is padumassasirīkaṃ.

original: Aññesupi samānassa so hoti, candena samānā sirī yassa taṃ candassasirīkaṃ, mukhaṃ. Evaṃ padumassasirīkaṃ, vadanaṃ.
analyzed: aññesu pi samānassa saḥ hoti candena samānā sirī yassa tam candassa sirīkam mukham evam padumassa sirīkam vadanam
translated: The form of the word vadanaṃ is vadanaṃ.🔽The form of the word mahāvuttinā is mahāvuttinā.🔽The form of the word santādīnañca is santādīnañca.🔽The form of the word so is hoti.

original: Mahāvuttinā santādīnañca so hoti, saṃvijjati lomaṃ assāti salomako. Evaṃ sapakkhako,
analyzed: mahāvuttinā santa ādīnam ca saḥ hoti saṃvijjati lomam assa ati salomakaḥ evam sapakkhako
translated: The form of the word salomako is salomako.🔽The form of the word sapakkhako is sapakkhako.

original: saṃvijjanti āsavā etesanti sāsavā, saṃvijjanti paccayā etesanti sappaccayā, saṃvijjanti🔽attano uttaritarā dhammā etesanti sauttarā, santo puriso sappuriso. Tathā sajjano,
analyzed: saṃvijjanti āsavāḥ etesanti sa āsavā saṃvijjanti paccayāḥ etesanti sappaccayāḥ saṃvijjanti  attanaḥ uttaritarā dhammā etesanti sauttarā santo puriso sappuriso tathā sajjano
translated: The form of the word saṃvijjanti is saṃvijjanti.

original: saddhammo, santassa bhāvo sabbhāvo iccādi.🔽Iti sa-rāsi.
analyzed: saddhammaḥ santassa bhāvaḥ sabbhāvaḥ iccādi  iti sarāsi
translated: The form of the word āsavā is āsavā.🔽The form of the word etesanti is etesanti.🔽The form of the word sāsavā is sāsavā.

original: 388. Imassidaṃ ka. 129; rū. 222; nī. 305.🔽Uttarapade pare imassa idaṃ hoti.
analyzed: imassidam ka rū nī 🔽uttara pade pare imassa idam hoti
translated: The form of the word saṃ

original: Ayaṃ attho etassāti idamatthī, samāsante ī, idamatthino bhāvo idamatthitā. Ayaṃ paccayo
analyzed: ayam atthaḥ etassa ati idamatthī samāsa nte idamatthinaḥ bhāvaḥ idamatthi tā ayam paccayaḥ
translated: That which has this meaning is this-meaningful, the abstract of which is this-meaningfulness.🔽These are conditions for these, thus they are this-conditionals. The abstract of this-conditionals is this-conditionality.🔽They construe: “They are conditions for these, thus they are this-conditionals;

original: etesanti idappaccayā, idappaccayānaṃ bhāvo idappaccayatā. “Imesaṃ paccayā idappaccayā,
analyzed: etesan ti idappaccayāḥ idappaccayānam bhāvaḥ idappaccaya tā imesam paccayāḥ idappaccayā
translated: this-conditionals themselves are this-conditionality.”

original: idappaccayā eva idappaccayatā”tipi yojenti. ‘Ida’nti nipātapadampi atthi, “rūpañca
analyzed: idappaccayāḥ eva idappaccaya tā atipi yojenti idanti nipāta padam pi atthi rūpam ca
translated: The word “this” is also a particle. “If, bhikkhus, this material form were the self, this material form would not be subject to sickness, and it would be possible with regard to material form for: ‘Let my material form be thus; let my material form be not thus’” , and so on in the Maha-Nidiyana Sutta .🔽The abstract of “man” is “manhood.”🔽The abstract of “woman” is “womanhood.”🔽The abstract of “man” is “manhood.”🔽The abstract of “woman” is “womanhood.”

original: hidaṃ bhikkhave attā abhavissā, vedanā ca hidaṃ. Saññā ca hidaṃ. Saṅkhārā ca hidaṃ
analyzed: hidam bhikkhave attā abhavissāḥ vedanā ca hidam saññā ca hidam saṅkhārā ca hidam
translated: The abstract of “man” is “manhood.”🔽The abstract of “woman” is “womanhood.”

original: bhikkhave attā abhavissaṃsu” iccādi mahāva. 20.
analyzed: bhikkhave attā abhavissaṃsu iccādi
translated: The abstract of “man” is “manhood.”🔽The abstract of “woman” is “womanhood.”🔽The abstract of “man” is “manhood.”

original: 389. Puṃ pumassa vā ka. 82; rū. 149.
analyzed: pum pumassa vā ka rū
translated: The abstract of “woman” is “womanhood.”

original: Uttarapade pare pumassa puṃ hoti vā.
analyzed: uttara pade pare pumassa pum hoti vā
translated: The abstract of “man” is “manhood.”🔽The abstract of “woman” is “womanhood.”🔽The abstract of “man” is “manhood.”🔽The abstract of “woman” is “womanhood.”🔽The abstract of “man” is “manhood.”🔽The abstract of “woman” is “womanhood.”

original: Pumassa liṅgaṃ pulliṅgaṃ, pumassa bhāvo pumbhāvo, pumā ca so kokilo cāti puṅkokilo, pumā ca so go cāti puṅgavo, ‘go tvacatthe…’ti apaccayo, napuṃsako.
analyzed: pumassa liṅgam pud liṅgam pumassa bhāvaḥ pumbhāvaḥ pumā ca saḥ kokilo ca ati puṅkokilo pumā ca saḥ go ca ati puṅgavaḥ go tvac atthā iti a paccayaḥ napuṃsako
translated: The abstract of “man” is “manhood.”🔽The abstract of “woman” is “womanhood.”🔽The abstract of “man” is “manhood.”🔽The abstract of “woman” is “womanhood.”🔽The abstract of “man” is “manhood.”🔽The abstract of “woman” is “womanhood.”🔽The abstract of “man” is “manhood.”🔽The abstract of “woman” is “womanhood.”🔽The abstract of “man” is “manhood.”

original: Vāti kiṃ? Pumitthī.
analyzed: vāti kim pum itthī
translated: The abstract of “woman” is “womanhood.”🔽The abstract of “man” is “manhood.”🔽The abstract of “woman” is “womanhood.”🔽The abstract of “man” is “manhood.”

original: 390. Ṭa ntantūnaṃ ka. 126; rū. 101; nī. 301.
analyzed: ṭa n ta n ūnam ka rū nī
translated: The abstract of “woman

original: Uttarapade pare nta, ntūnaṃ ṭa hoti vā kvaci.
analyzed: uttara pade pare n ta n tūnam ṭa vā kvacid
translated: The following word has nta or ntūna, ṭa is optionally added.

original: Bhavaṃ patiṭṭho yesaṃ te bhavaṃpatiṭṭhā, bindāgamo. Bhagavā mūlaṃ yesaṃ te bhagavaṃmūlakā, dhammā. Evaṃ bhagavaṃpaṭisaraṇā, dhammā.
analyzed: bhavam patiṭṭhaḥ yesam te bhavaṃpatiṭṭhāḥ bindāgamaḥ bhagavā mūlam yesam te bhagavaṃmūlakāḥ dhammāḥ evam bhagavaṃpaṭisaraṇāḥ dhammāḥ
translated: The word bhavaṃpatiṭṭhā, “having existence as their support”, is formed by adding the affix nta to bhavaṃ, and then the affix ṭa to the resultant nta, the whole being declined as a masculine noun. The word bhagavaṃmūlakā, “having the Exalted One as their root”, is formed by adding the affix nta to bhagavaṃ, and then the affix ṭa to the resultant nta, the whole being declined as a feminine noun. The word bhagavaṃpaṭisaraṇā, “having the Exalted One as their refuge”, is formed by adding the affix nta to bhagavaṃ, and then the affix ṭa to the resultant nta, the whole being declined as a feminine noun.

original: Bahulādhikārā tarādīsu ca paresu, mahantīnaṃ atisayena mahāti mahattarī, rattaññūnaṃ🔽mahantassa bhāvo rattaññumahattaṃ. Evaṃ jātimahattaṃ, guṇamahattaṃ, puññamahattaṃ,🔽arahantassa bhāvo arahattaṃ.
analyzed: bahula adhikārā tara ādīsu ca paresu mahantīnam atisayena mahattarī  mahantassa bhāvaḥ rattaññu mahattam evam jāti mahattam guṇa mahattam puñña mahattam  arahantassa bhāvaḥ arahattam
translated: The word mahāti mahattarī, “greater than great”, is formed by adding the affix nta to mahantī, and then the affix ṭa to the resultant nta, the whole being declined as a feminine noun. The word rattaññumahattaṃ, “the greatness of seniority”, is formed by adding the affix nta to rattaññū, and then the affix ṭa to the resultant nta, the whole being declined as a neuter noun.

analyzed: a ka rū nī cam pā
translated: The word jātimahattaṃ, “the greatness of birth”, is formed by adding the affix nta to jāti, and then the affix ṭa to the resultant nta, the whole being declined as a neuter noun. The word guṇamahattaṃ, “the greatness of virtue”, is formed by adding the affix nta to guṇa, and then the affix ṭa to the resultant nta, the whole being declined as a neuter noun. The word puññamahattaṃ, “the greatness of merit”, is formed by adding the affix nta to puñña, and then the affix ṭa to the resultant nta, the whole being declined as a neuter noun.

original: Uttarapade pare nta, ntūnaṃ a hoti.
analyzed: uttara pade pare nta ntūnam a hoti
translated: The word arahattaṃ, “the state of an Arahant”, is formed by adding the affix nta to arahant, and then the affix ṭa to the resultant nta, the whole being declined as a feminine noun.🔽. A ka. ; rū. ; nī. ; caṃ. ..; pā. ...

original: Bhavantapatiṭṭhā, mayaṃ, guṇavantapatiṭṭhā, mayaṃ.🔽392. Rīrikkhakesu ka. 642; rū. 589; nī. 1269; caṃ. 5.2.107; pā. 6.3.89-90.🔽Rī, rikkha, kapaccayantesu paresu samānassa so hoti.

original: Niccasamāsattā aññapadena viggaho, saṃvijjatīti samāno, paccakkhe viya citte upalabbhatīti attho. Samāno viya so dissatīti sadī, sadikkho, sadiso, samānā viya te dissantīti sadisā.
analyzed: nicca samāsa ttā añña padena viggahaḥ saṃvijjati iti samānaḥ paccakkhe viya citte upalabbhati iti attho samānaḥ viya so dissati iti sadī sa dikkhaḥ sadisaḥ samānāḥ viya te dissanti iti sadisāḥ

original: 393. Ntakimimānaṃ ṭākīṭī ka. 126; rū. 101; nī. 301.

original: Yādī, yādikkho, yādiso, tādī, tādikkho, tādiso, etādī, etādikkho, etādiso.

original: Vāti kiṃ? Satthudassanaṃ, kattu niddeso, mātāpitaro.🔽403. Vijjāyonisambandhīnamā tatra catthe ka. 199; rū. 158; nī. 736; caṃ. 5.2.21; pā. 6.3.25.
analyzed: vāti kim satthu dassanam kattu niddesaḥ mātā pitaraḥ  vijjā yoni sambandhī namā tatra ca tthe ka rū nī caṃ pā
translated: What? Seeing the Teacher, doing, mother and father.

original: Catthasamāse vijjāsambandhīnaṃ yonisambandhīnañca ltupitādīnaṃ ā hoti tesveva paresu.
analyzed: cattha samāse vijjā sambandhīnam yoni sambandhīnam ca ā hoti tesu eva paresu
translated: . There, in the fourfold compound, ā is used for those related to knowledge and those related to the womb, except for luptā, pitā, etc.

original: Mātāpitā, mātāpitaro iccādi.
analyzed: mātā pitā mātā pitaraḥ it ca ādi
translated: . Mother and father, mother and father, etc.

original: Tatrāti kiṃ? Mātuyā bhātā mātubhātā.
analyzed: tatra ati kim mātuyā bhātā mātu bhātā
translated: . What is meant by there? The brother of the mother is the mother’s brother.

original: Ettha ca vijjāsippāni sikkhāpentā ācariyā sissānaṃ vijjāsambandhī mātāpitaro nāma.🔽404. Putte ka. 199; rū. 158; nī. 736; caṃ. 5.2.22; pā. 6.3.25.
analyzed: ettha ca vijjā sippāni sikkhāpentā ācariyā sissānam vijjā sambandhī mātā pitaraḥ nāma  putte ka rū nī cam pā
