original: Catte putte pare vijjāyonisambandhīnaṃ ltupitādīnaṃ ā hoti.🔽Mātāputtā gacchanti, pitāputtā gacchanti. Mahāvuttinā tesañca i hoti, mātipakkho,
analyzed: catte putte pare vijjā yoni sambandhīnam ā hoti  mātā puttāḥ gacchanti pitā puttāḥ gacchanti mahāvuttinā tesam ca i hoti māti pakkho
translated: . Sons, there, in the fourfold compound, ā is used for those related to knowledge and the womb, except for luptā, pitā, etc.🔽. Mother and sons go, father and sons go. By the Great Method, i is used for them too: the side of the mother,🔽the side of the father. The mother’s side🔽. The father’s side

original: pitipakkho. Mātigho labhate dukhaṃ jā. 2.19.118, pitigho labhate dukhaṃ, māttikaṃ
analyzed: piti pakkhaḥ mātighaḥ labhate dukham jā pitighaḥ labhate dukham māttikam
translated: . The mother’s side

original: dhanaṃ, pettikaṃ dhanaṃ pārā. 34. Ettha ca mātuyā santakaṃ māttikaṃ, pituno santakaṃ
analyzed: dhanam pettikam dhanam pārā ettha ca mātuyā santakam māttikam pituno santakam
translated: and wealth, and wealth of the ancestors.🔽Herein, what belongs to the mother is “maternal,”🔽what belongs to the father is “paternal.”

original: pettikaṃ, dvittaṃ vuddhi ca. Mātito, pitito, bhātā eva bhātiko, bhātikarājā.
analyzed: pettikam dvittam ca mātitaḥ pititaḥ bhātā eva bhātikaḥ bhātika rājā
translated: The two, and increase, are from the mother, from the father, and the brother is a “brother’s son,” and the king of the brother’s son.

original: 405. Jāyāya jāyaṃ patimhi ka. 339; rū. 358; nī. 731; ‘…jayaṃ patimhi’ (bahūsu).
analyzed: jāyāya jāyam patimhi jayam patimhi bahūsu
translated: In the wife, the wife in the husband, k.

original: Patimhi pare jāyāsaddassa jāyaṃ hoti.
analyzed: patimhi pare jāyā saddassa jāyam hoti
translated: In the husband, the word for wife becomes “wife” .🔽She generates a son, thus she is a “wife” . The wife and the husband are “wife and husband” , “wife and lord” (in the plural).

original: Puttaṃ janetīti jāyā, jāyā ca pati ca jāyampatī jayampatī (bahūsu). Atha vā “jāyampatī”ti
analyzed: puttam janeti iti jāyā jāyā ca pati ca jāyampatī jayampatī bahūsu atha vā jāyampatī iti
translated: Or this “wife and husband”

original: idaṃ sandhividhināva siddhaṃ, tasmā “jampatī”tipāṭho siyā yathā “devarājā sujampatī’
analyzed: idam sandhi vidhinā ava siddham siyāḥ yathā devarājā sujampatī
translated: is established by the rule of sandhi . Therefore the reading “wife and lord” may be as in “the god-king, the good wife and lord”

original: saṃ. ni. 1.264’ti, yathā ca sakkataganthesu “dāro ca pati ca dampatī”ti. Idha pana🔽mahāvuttinā patimhi sujātāya sujaṃ hoti, dārassa ca daṃ hoti, tathā jāyā ca pati
analyzed: sam ni yathā ca sakkataganthesu dāro ca pati ca dampatī iti idha pana  mahāvuttinā patimhi sujātāya sujam hoti dārassa ca hoti tathā jāyā ca pati
translated: and as in the Sakka-suttas “the wife and the husband are a couple” . But here

original: ca jampatīti niṭṭhaṃ gantabbaṃ.
analyzed: ca jampati iti niṭṭham gantabbam
translated: by the rule of the Great Commentary “good” becomes “good wife” in the husband, and “good” becomes “good husband” in the wife. So too “wife and husband” should be taken as established.

original: Yañca vuttiyaṃ “jānipatīti pakatyantarena siddhaṃ, tathā dampatī”ti vuttaṃ. Tattha🔽puttaṃ janetīti jānī. Jānī ca pati ca jānīpatīti yujjati. “Tudampatī”ti pāṭho. Kaccāyane
analyzed: yat ca vuttiyam jānipati iti pakati antarena siddham tathā dampati iti vuttam tattha  puttam janeti iti jānī jānī ca pati ca jānīpatī iti yujjati tudampatī iti pāṭhaḥ kaccāyane
translated: And in the Vutti it is said: “Jānīpatī is established by the ordinary meaning of the words, and so too dampatī.” Herein,🔽it is a jānī because it causes a son to be born, and it is a pati, thus it is a jānīpatī, and that is right. The reading “tudam-patī” is also allowable.

original: ca ‘jāyāya tu daṃjāni patimhī’ti. Tattha tusaddo padapūraṇamatte yujjati.
analyzed: ca jāyāya tu patimhi iti tattha tu saddaḥ pada pūraṇa matte yujjati
translated: And in the Kaccāyana grammar: “tudamjāni patimhi.” Herein, the word tu is allowable in the sense of filling out the line.

original: 406. Saññāyamudodakassa ka. 404; rū. 370; nī. 257; caṃ. 5.2.65; pā. 6.3.57.
analyzed: saññā yamudodakassa ka rū nī caṃ pā
translated: . In saññāyamudodaka, ka. ; rū. ; nī. ; caṃ. ..; pā. ...

original: Saññāyaṃ gamyamānāyaṃ uttarapade pare udakassa udo hoti.
analyzed: saññā ayam gamyamānā ayam uttara pade pare udakassa udaḥ hoti
translated: When saññāyam is the word governing the compound, udo is the form of udaka in the word following.

original: Udakaṃ dhāretīti udadhi, mahantaṃ udakaṃ dhāretīti mahodadhi, udakaṃ pivanti etthāti udapānaṃ, udakaṃ pivanti etāyāti udapāti.
analyzed: udakam dhāreti iti udadhi mahantam udakam dhāreti iti mahā udadhi udakam pivanti etthā ati udapānam udakam pivanti etāya ati udapāti
translated: It holds water, thus it is an ud-dhi; it holds great water, thus it is a maho-dhi; they drink water here, thus it is an ud-apānaṃ; they drink water by means of this, thus it is an ud-apāti.

analyzed: kumbha ādīsu vā ka rū nī cam pā
translated: . In kumbhādīsu vā ka. ; rū. ; nī. ; caṃ. ..; pā. ...🔽In the words kumbha, etc., the form udo is also allowable for udaka.

original: Kumbhādīsu paresu udakassa udo hoti vā.
analyzed: kumbha ādīsu paresu udakassa udaḥ hoti vā
translated: . In udakassa udo hoti vā ka. ; rū. ; nī. ; caṃ. ..; pā. ...🔽In the words udaka, etc., the form udo is allowable for udaka.

original: Udakassa kumbho udakumbho, udakakumbho. Evaṃ udapatto, udakapatto, udabindu, udakabindu. Mahāvuttinā syādīsupi, “nīlodā pokkharaṇī”ti pāḷi.
analyzed: udakassa kumbhaḥ uda kumbhaḥ udaka kumbhaḥ evam uda pattaḥ udaka pattaḥ uda bindu udaka bindu mahāvuttinā syādi īsupi nīlodā pokkharaṇī iti pāḷi
translated: A pot of water is an udakumbha, an udakumbha, an udakakumbha. So too udapatta, udakapatta, udabindu, udakabindu. In the Mahāvagga, in the Sutta of the Great Forty, the reading is “nīlodakā pokkharaṇī”.

original: 408. Sotādīsu lopo ka. 404; rū. 370; nī. 256.
analyzed: sota ādīsu lopaḥ ka rū nī
translated: In the words sota, etc., the a is elided.

original: Sotādīsu paresu udakassa ussa lopo hoti.
analyzed: sota ādīsu paresu udakassa ussa lopaḥ hoti
translated: In the other words beginning with sota, the a of udaka is elided.

original: Udakassa sotaṃ dakasotaṃ, udake rakkhaso dakarakkhaso, udakaṃ āsayo yesaṃ te dakāsayā, pāṇā. Mahāvuttinā syādīsupi, “dake dakāsayā sentī”ti saṃ. ni. 3.78 (thokaṃ visadisaṃ) pāḷi.
analyzed: udakassa sotam daka sotam udake rakkhasaḥ daka rakkhasaḥ udakam āsayaḥ yesam te daka āsayā pāṇāḥ mahāvuttinā dake daka āsayā senti iti sam ni thokam visadisam
translated: The stream of water is a dakasota, the demon of the water is a dakarakkhaso, those who have water as their abode are dakāsayā, the creatures. In the Mahāvagga, in the Saṃyutta, the reading is “dake dakāsayā sentī” .

original: 409. Pubbāparajjasāyamajjhehāhassa ṇho ka. 404; rū. 370; nho (sī.).
analyzed: pubba aparajja sāyamajjheha ahassa ṇhaḥ ka rū nhaḥ sī
translated: In the words pubba, aparā, ajja, sāya, majjha, the ṇho is elided.

original: Pubbādīhi parassa ahassa ṇho hoti.
analyzed: pubba ādīhi parassa ahassa ṇhaḥ hoti
translated: In the words beginning with pubba, the ṇho of the other is elided.

original: Pubbaṇho, aparaṇho, ajjaṇho, sāyaṇho sāyanho, majjhaṇho.
analyzed: pubbaṇhaḥ aparaṇhaḥ ajjaṇhaḥ sāyaṇhaḥ sāyanhaḥ majjhaṇhaḥ
translated: Pubbaṇho, aparaṇho, ajjaṇho, sāyaṇho sāyanho, majjhaṇho.

original: Nānādesarāsi niṭṭhito.
analyzed: niṭṭhito
translated: The collection of various countries is finished.

original: Abyayarāsi
analyzed: a byaya rā asi
translated: The collection of indeclinables

original: 410. Kupādayo niccamasyādividhimhi ka. 324; rū. 339; caṃ. 2.2.24; pā. 2.2.18.
analyzed: kupa ādayaḥ niccam asi ādi vidhimhi ka rū cam pā
translated: In the rules for the invariable and variable endings, etc., the a is elided.

original: Syādividhito aññattha kuādayo pādayo ca saddā syādyantena saha niccaṃ ekatthā honti.
analyzed: syādi vidhitaḥ aññattha ku ādayo pādayo ca saddā syādi antena saha niccam ekatthāḥ honti
translated: The words ku, ā, and so on, and the words pā, ā, and so on, are always synonymous with the words ending in syā, when used in other senses.

original: Kucchito brāhmaṇo kubrāhmaṇo, īsakaṃ uṇhaṃ kaduṇhaṃ, pākaṭo hutvā bhavatīti pātubhūto,
analyzed: kucchitaḥ brāhmaṇaḥ ku brāhmaṇaḥ īsakam uṇham kaduṇham pākaṭaḥ hutvā bhavati iti pātubhūtaḥ
translated: A brahmin with a bad stomach is a kubrāhmaṇa. A little hot is kaduṇha. Having become manifest is pātubhūta.

original: āvī ‘āvi’pi dissati hutvā bhavatīti āvībhūto, tuṇhī bhavatīti tuṇhībhūto, pamukho
analyzed: āvī āvipi dissati hutvā bhavati iti āvībhūtaḥ tuṇhī bhavati iti tuṇhībhūtaḥ pamukhaḥ
translated: Having become visible is āvībhūta. Having become silent is tuṇhībhūta. Having become with face turned towards is pamukha.

original: nāyako panāyako, pakārena karitvā pakaritvā pakārena kataṃ pakataṃ, paṭhamaṃ vā kataṃ
analyzed: pakārena karitvā pakaritvā pakārena katam pakatam paṭhamam vā katam
translated: A leader is a nāyaka. Having made by way of a pakāra is pakaritvā. Made by way of a pakāra is pakataṃ. Or made first is pakataṃ.

original: pakataṃ, virūpo puriso duppuriso. Evaṃ dukkaṭaṃ, sobhaṇo puriso supuriso. Evaṃ sukataṃ,
analyzed: pakatam virūpaḥ purisaḥ duppurisaḥ evam dukkaṭam sobhaṇaḥ purisaḥ su purisaḥ evam su katam
translated: An ugly man is a duppuriso. So is dukkaṭa. A handsome man is a supuriso. So is sukata.

original: abhidhammo, abhitthuto, bhusaṃ kaḷāro ākaḷāro, bhusaṃ bandho ābandho iccādi.
analyzed: abhidhammaḥ abhitthutaḥ bhusam kaḷāraḥ ākaḷāraḥ bhusam bandhaḥ ābandhaḥ iccādi
translated: Abhidhammo, abhitthuto, bhusaṃ kaḷāro ākaḷāro, bhusaṃ bandho ābandho, and so on.

original: Pādayo pakatādyatthe paṭhamāya ekatthā honti, pakato ācariyo pācariyo. Evaṃ payyako, paro antevāsī pantevāsī, paro putto paputto, paro nattā panattā.
analyzed: pādayaḥ pakata ādi atthe paṭhamāya ekatthāḥ honti pakataḥ ācariyo pācariyo evam payyako paraḥ antevāsī pantevāsī paraḥ putto pa putto paraḥ nattā pa nattā
translated: The words ending in pā are synonymous with the words ending in kata, when used in the sense of first. A teacher who is pakata is pācariyo. So is payyako. A pupil who is para is pantevāsī. A son who is para is paputto. A kinsman who is para is panattā.

original: Atyādayo atikkantādyatthe dutiyāya, mañcaṃ atikkanto atimañco. Evaṃ atibālo, ativelā.
analyzed: ati ādayaḥ atikkanta ādi atthe dutiyāya mañcam atikkantaḥ atimañcaḥ evam atibālaḥ ativelā
translated: Atyādayo atikkantādyatthe dutiyāya, mañcaṃ atikkanto atimañco. Evaṃ atibālo, ativelā.

original: Avādayo kuṭṭhādyatthe tatiyāya, kokilāya avakuṭṭhaṃ vanaṃ avakokilaṃ, ‘avakuṭṭha’nti chaḍḍitanti vadanti. Evaṃ avamayūraṃ.
analyzed: ava ādayaḥ kuṭṭha ādi atthe tatiyāya kokilāya ava kuṭṭham vanam ava kokilam ava kuṭṭhanti vadanti evam ava mayūram
translated: Avādayo kuṭṭhādyatthe tatiyāya, kokilāya avakuṭṭhaṃ vanaṃ avakokilaṃ, ‘avakuṭṭha’nti chaḍḍitanti vadanti. Evaṃ avamayūraṃ.

original: Pariyādayo gilānādyatthe catutthiyā, ajjhāyituṃ gilāno pariyajjheno.
analyzed: pariya ādayaḥ gilāna ādi atthe catutthiyāḥ gilānaḥ
translated: Pariyādayo gilānādyatthe catutthiyā, ajjhāyituṃ gilāno pariyajjheno.

original: Nyādayo nikkhantādyatthe pañcamiyā, kosambiyā nikkhanto nikkosambi, vānato nikkhantaṃ nibbānaṃ.
analyzed: ni ādayaḥ nikkhanta ādi atthe pañcamiyā kosambiyāḥ nikkhantaḥ nikkosambi vānataḥ nikkhantam nibbānam
translated: Nyādayo nikkhantādyatthe pañcamiyā, kosambiyā nikkhanto nikkosambi, vānato nikkhantaṃ nibbānaṃ.

original: Asyādividhimhīti kiṃ? Rukkhaṃ pati vijjotate.
analyzed: asya ādi vidhimhi iti kim rukkham pati vijjotate
translated: Asyādividhimhīti kiṃ? Rukkhaṃ pati vijjotate.

original: 411. Cī kriyatthehi caṃ. 2.2.25; pā. 1.4.60, 61.
analyzed: cī kriyatthehi cam pā
translated: Cī kriyatthehi caṃ. ..; pā. .., .

original: Cīpaccayanto saddo kriyatthehi saddehi saha ekattho hoti.
analyzed: cī pacca yantaḥ saddaḥ kriyatthehi saddehi saha ekatthaḥ hoti
translated: The word cī together with words in the sense of action has one meaning.

original: Balasā kiriya balīkiriya, pākaṭīkiriya, pākaṭībhuyya, pākaṭībhaviya.
analyzed: balasā kiriya balīkiriya pākaṭīkiriya pākaṭībhuyya
translated: Balasā kiriya balīkiriya, pākaṭīkiriya, pākaṭībhuyya, pākaṭībhaviya.🔽. Bhūsanādarānādarādīsvehi saha caṃ. ..; pā. .., .

original: 412. Bhūsanādarānādarādīsvehi saha caṃ. 2.2.27; pā. 1.4.63, 64.
analyzed: bhū san ādara an ādara ādi sva ihi saha cam pā
translated: And with the adornments, the disrespect, the respect, etc., themselves.🔽

original: Alamādayo saddā bhūsanādīsu atthesu etehi kriyatthehi saha ekatthā honti.
analyzed: alam ādayaḥ saddāḥ bhūsana ādīsu atthesu etehi kriyatthehi saha ekatthāḥ honti
translated: The words alam, etc., have the same meaning as the words kriyā, etc., in the following senses:

original: Bhūsanaṃ akāsīti alaṃkiriya, samaṃ ādaraṃ akāsīti sakkacca, asamaṃ anādaraṃ akāsīti asakkacca, binduno pararūpattaṃ.
analyzed: bhūsanam akāsi iti alaṃkiriya samam ādaram akāsi iti sakkacca asamam anādaram akāsi iti asakkacca binduno
translated: Alaṃkiriya = alaṃkiriya, ‘he made an ornament’. Sakkaccam = sakkaccam, ‘he made respect’. Asakkaccam = asakkaccam, ‘he made disrespect’. Binduno = binduno, ‘of the moon’.

original: Bhūsanādīsūti kiṃ? Alaṃ bhutvā gato, ‘ala’nti pariyattaṃ, sakkatvā gato, sobhaṇaṃ
analyzed: bhūsana ādīsu iti kim alam bhutvā gataḥ pariyattam sakkatvā gataḥ sobhaṇam
translated: Bhūsanādīsūti kiṃ? Alaṃ bhutvā gato, ‘ala’nti pariyattaṃ, sakkatvā gato, sobhaṇaṃ

original: katvātyattho. “Kacca, kiriya” iccādinā saṃkhittarūpehi upapadena saha siddhehi eva
analyzed: katvā atyattho kacca kiriye iccādinā saṃkhitta rūpehi upapadena saha siddhehi eva
translated: katvātyattho. “Kacca, kiriya” iccādinā saṃkhittarūpehi upapadena saha siddhehi eva

original: ekatthasaññā, na “katvā” iccādinā asaṃkhittarūpehi visuṃ siddhehīti adhippāyo.
analyzed: ekattha saññā na katvā iccādinā asaṃkhitta rūpehi visum siddhehi iti adhippāyaḥ
translated: ekatthasaññā, na “katvā” iccādinā asaṃkhittarūpehi visuṃ siddhehīti adhippāyo.

analyzed: aññe ca ka   rū   nī caṃ      pā

original: Aññe ca saddā kriyatthehi syādyantehi saha bahulaṃ ekatthā honti.
analyzed: aññe ca saddā kriyatthehi syādi antehi saha bahulam ekatthāḥ honti
translated: And other words have the same meaning as the words kriyā, etc., in the following senses:

original: Atirekaṃ abhavīti parobhuyya. Evaṃ tirobhuyya, parokiriya, tirokiriya, urasikiriya, manasikiriya, majjhekiriya, tuṇhībhuyya.
analyzed: atirekam abhavīti parobhuyya evam tirobhuyya parokiriya tirokiriya urasikiriya manasikiriya majjhekiriya tuṇhībhuyya
translated: Atirekaṃ abhavīti parobhuyya. Evaṃ tirobhuyya, parokiriya, tirokiriya, urasikiriya, manasikiriya, majjhekiriya, tuṇhībhuyya.

original: Tyādisaddāpi saññābhāvaṃ pattā nipātarūpā honti, syādirūpā ca. Tasmā tepi imasmiṃ sutte saṅgayhanti.
analyzed: tyādi saddā api saññā bhāvam pattā nipāta rūpāḥ honti ca tasmā te pi imasmin sutte saṅgayhanti
translated: Such words as these, having become mere nouns, are in the form of indeclinables and in the form of prepositions. That is why they are included in this Thread.

original: Atthikhīrā gāvī, nasantiputtā itthī, atthi hutvā paccayo atthipaccayo. Evaṃ natthipaccayo,
analyzed: atthi khīrā gāvī nasanti puttā itthī atthi hutvā paccayaḥ atthi paccayo evam natthi paccayo
translated: A cow with milk in her udder, a woman with a dead child, a condition that is existent, an existent condition. So too, a non-existent condition,

original: ahosi eva kammaṃ ahosikammaṃ, ehi ca passa ca ehipassa, ehipassa iti vidhānaṃ arahatīti
analyzed: ahosi eva kammam ahosi kammam ehi ca passa ca ehi passa ehi passa iti vidhānam arahati iti
translated: An action that was, an action that was, come and see, come and see. Come and see is worthy of the injunction.

original: ehipassiko, ayaṃ taddhitantasamāso nāma. Evaṃ parattha.🔽Ehi bhaddanteti vuttopi na etīti naehibhaddantiko dī. ni. 1.394, tiṭṭha bhaddanteti
analyzed: ehipassikaḥ ayam taddhi tanta samāsaḥ nāma evam parattha  ehi bhaddanta iti vuttaḥ api na eti iti naehibhaddantikaḥ dī ni tiṭṭha bhaddanta iti
translated: Come and see is the name of a compound with a verbal root as its last member. So too, in the sense of another.

original: vuttopi na tiṭṭhatīti natiṭṭhabhaddantiko, ehi svāgataṃ tuyhanti vadanasīlo ehisvāgatiko,
analyzed: vuttaḥ api na tiṭṭhati iti ehi svāgatam tuyhanti vadana sīlaḥ ehi svāgatikaḥ
translated: Though told “Come, good sir”, he does not come. He is not a come-good-sir. Dī. ni. ., though told “Stand, good sir”, he does not stand. He is not a stand-good-sir. Though told “Come, welcome to you”, he has the habit of saying “Welcome”. He is a come-welcome-to-you.

original: ehisvāgatavādī pārā. 432 vā, ehi bhikkhūti vacanena siddhā upasampadā ehibhikkhūpasampadā,
analyzed: ehisvāgata vādī pārā vā ehi bhikkhu iti vacanena siddhā upasampadā ehibhikkhu upasampadā
translated: He is a come-welcome-to-you speaker. Or else, come, bhikkhu, is the name of the ordination that is established by the words “Come, bhikkhu”.

original: evaṃ porāṇā āhaṃsu vā, evaṃ pure āsiṃsu vāti evaṃ pavattaṃ vidhānaṃ ettha atthīti
analyzed: evam porāṇāḥ āhaṃsu vā evam pure āsiṃsu vā ati evam pavattam vidhānam ettha atthi iti
translated: The ancient teachers say that it is so. Or else, they were thus in the past. Thus, the injunction that occurs here is this.

original: itihāso dī. ni. 1.256, purāṇagantho, yaṃ pubbe anaññātaṃ, taṃ idāni ñassāmi iti pavattassa🔽indriyaṃ anaññātaññassāmītindriyaṃ, asuko iti āha asuko iti āha, asukasmiṃvā ganthe
analyzed: itihāsaḥ dī ni purāṇa ganthaḥ yam pubbe an aññātam tam idāni ñassāmi iti pavattassa  indriyam anaññātaññassāmi iti indriyam asukaḥ iti āha asukaḥ iti āha asukasmin vā ganthe
translated: The words “Iti” and “Hi” are used in the sense of “I shall know what was not known before.”🔽The words “Tena” and “Tena hi” are used in the sense of “He said thus and thus” or “In such and such a text he said thus and thus.”

original: iti āha asukasmiṃ ganthe iti āhāti evaṃ pavattavacanaṃ itihitihaṃ, aññāsi iti byākato
analyzed: iti āha asukasmin ganthe iti āha ati evam itihitiham aññāsi iti byākataḥ
translated: The words “Tena kho pana samayena” are used in the sense of “He understood thus.”

original: koṇḍañño aññāsikoṇḍañño mahāva. 8 iccādi.
analyzed: koṇḍaññaḥ aññāsikoṇḍañaḥ mahāvaḥ iccādi
translated: Koṇḍañño aññāsi is an example of the words “Aññāsi” and “Koṇḍañño.”

original: Keci pana “sacchikaroti, manasikaroti, pākaṭīkaroti, āvīkaroti, pātukaroti, alaṅkaroti,
analyzed: keci pana sacchikaroti manasikaroti pākaṭīkaroti āvīkaroti pātukaroti alaṅkaroti
translated: Some say that the words “Sacchikaroti,” “manasikaroti,” “pākaṭīkaroti,” “āvīkaroti,” “pātukaroti,” “alaṅkaroti,”🔽“sakkaroti,” “pabhavati,” and “parābhavati” are synonyms.

original: sakkaroti, pabhavati, parābhavati” iccādīnampi ekatthībhāvaṃ vadanti. Tumantatvantādikāpi🔽ettha saṅgayhanti, gantuṃ kāmetīti gantukāmo, kattukāmo, daṭṭhukāmo, gantuṃ mano
analyzed: sakkaroti pabhavati parābhavati icca ādīnam pi ekatthībhāvam vadanti  ettha saṅgayhanti gantum kāmeti iti gantu kāmo kattu kāmo daṭṭhu kāmo gantum mano
translated: The words “Tum,” “Anta,” “Tva,” and so on are also included here.🔽The words “Gantuṃ kāmetī” are analyzed as follows: “Gantuṃ” is the gerund of the verb “gam,” “Kāmetī” is the present tense of the verb “icch.”

original: etassāti gantumano, saṃvidhāya avahāro saṃvidhāvahāro, yalopo. Evaṃ upādāya uppannaṃ
analyzed: etassa ati gantu manaḥ saṃvidhāya avahāraḥ saṃvidha avahāraḥ ya lopaḥ evam upādāya uppannam
translated: The words “Gantumano” are analyzed as follows: “Gantuṃ” is the gerund of the verb “gam,” “Mano” is the present tense of the verb “man.”🔽The words “Saṃvidhāvahaṭṭha” are analyzed as follows: “Saṃvidhāya” is the gerund of the verb “vidh,” “Avahaṭṭha” is the present tense of the verb “vah.”🔽The words “Evaṃ upādāya uppanna” are analyzed as follows:

original: rūpaṃ upādārūpaṃ, anupādāya vimutto anupādāvimutto, paṭiccasamuppādo, āhaccabhāsito,
analyzed: rūpam upādā arūpam an upādāya vimuttaḥ an upādā vimuttaḥ paṭiccasamuppādaḥ āhacca bhāsito
translated: Matter, derived matter, not-subject-to-conflict, liberated by non-clinging, dependent origination, to be spoken, to be spoken of,

original: upahaccaparinibbāyī pu. pa. 37, aveccappasādo, chakkhattuparamaṃ, sattakkhattuparamo pu. pa. 31 iccādi.
analyzed: upahacca parinibbāyī pu pa avecca ppasādaḥ cha khattu paramam satta khattu paramaḥ pu pa  iccādi
translated: one who attains Nibbāna upon landing, one who attains Nibbāna without exertion, full confidence, at most six times, one who attains Nibbāna after returning seven times at most.

original: Abyayarāsi niṭṭhito.
analyzed: niṭṭhitaḥ
translated: The Collection on the Indeclinables is finished.

original: Saṅkhyārāsi
analyzed: saṅkhyā rāj asi
translated: The Collection on Numerals

original: Idāni saṅkhyārāsi vuccate.
analyzed: idāni saṅkhyā rāsi vuccate
translated: Now the collection on numerals is stated.

original: 414. Vidhādīsu dvissa du ka. 386; rū. 410; nī. 811.
analyzed: vidha ādīsu dvis sa du ka rū nī
translated: In the case of the declinables beginning with “two,” the dual is du, ka, rū, nī.

original: Vidhādīsu paresu dvissa du hoti.
analyzed: vidha ādīsu paresu dvis sa du hoti
translated: In the case of the other declinables beginning with “two,” the dual is du.

original: Dve vidhā pakārā yassāti duvidho, dve paṭṭāni yassāti dupaṭṭaṃ, cīvaraṃ, duvaṅgikaṃ, jhānaṃ iccādi.
analyzed: dve vidhā pakārāḥ yassa ati duvidhaḥ dve paṭṭāni yassa ati du paṭṭam cīvaram duvaṅgikam jhānam iccādi
translated: He who has two kinds, modes, is duvidha; he who has two panels is dupaṭṭa, a robe; the jhāna has two factors, and so on.

original: 415. Di guṇādīsu ka. 386; rū. 410; nī. 811.🔽Guṇādīsu dvissa di hoti.
analyzed: di guṇa ādīsu ka rū nī  guṇa ādīsu dvis sa di hoti
translated: In the case of the declinables beginning with “two” and “quality,” the dual is di, ka, rū, nī.🔽In the case of the other declinables beginning with “two” and “quality,” the dual is di.

original: Dve guṇā paṭalā yassāti diguṇā, saṅghāṭi, dve gāvo digu, dve rattiyo dirattaṃ, dvirattaṃ vā.
analyzed: dve guṇā paṭalā diguṇā saṅghāṭi dve gāvaḥ dve rattiyaḥ dirattam dvirattam vā
translated: He who has two qualities, two layers, is diguṇa, a cloak; two cows are digu; two nights are diratta, or dviratta.

original: 416. Tīsva ka. 383; rū. 253; nī. 815.🔽Tīsu paresu dvissa a hoti.
analyzed: tīsva ka rū nī  tīsu paresu dvissa a hoti
translated: In the case of the declinables beginning with “three,” the dual is a, ka, rū, nī.🔽In the case of the other declinables beginning with “three,” the dual is a.

original: Dve vā tayo vā vārā dvattikkhattuṃ, dve vā tayo vā pattā dvattipattā.
analyzed: dve vā tayaḥ vā vārāḥ dvattikkhattum dve vā tayaḥ vā pattāḥ dvatti pattā
translated: Two or three times is dvattikkhattuṃ; two or three robes is dvattipattā.

original: 417. Ā saṅkhyāyāsatādonaññatthe ka. 383; rū. 253; nī. 815; caṃ. 5.2.52; pā. 6.3.47.
analyzed: ā saṅkhyā yāsa tā āda ūnaññatthe ka rū nī cam pā
translated: 417. The affix ā is added to sat, etc., and to aṅga, etc., when the number is not the principal factor in the compound.

original: Aññapadatthavajjite samāse satādito aññasmiṃ saṅkhyāpade pare dvissa ā hoti.
analyzed: añña padattha vajjite samāse sa ta āditaḥ aññasmin saṅkhyā pade pare dvis saḥ ā hoti
translated: When the number is not the principal factor in the compound, ā is added to sat, etc., and to any other number word other than aṅga, etc., when the latter follows.

original: Dve ca dasa ca dvādasa, dvīhi vā adhikā dasa dvādasa, dvāvīsati, dvattiṃsa, rassattaṃ.
analyzed: dve ca dasa ca dvādasa dvīhi vā adhikāḥ dasa dvādasa dvāvīsati dvattiṃsa
translated: Dve ca dasa ca = dvādasa, or dvīhi vā adhikā dasa = dvādasa. Dvāvīsati, dvattiṃsa, rassattaṃ.

original: Asatādoti kiṃ? Dvisataṃ, dvisahassaṃ.
analyzed: kim dvisatam dvi sahassam
translated: Asatādo ti kiṃ? Dvisataṃ, dvisahassaṃ.

original: Anaññattheti kiṃ? Dve dasa yasminti dvidasa.
analyzed: an aññattha iti kim dve dasa yasmin ti dvidasa
translated: Anaññatthe ti kiṃ? Dve dasa yasmin ti dvidasa.

analyzed: tisse ka rū cam pā
translated: . Tisse ka. ; rū. ; caṃ. ..; pā. ...

original: Anaññatthe asatādo saṅkhyāpade pare tissa e hoti.
analyzed: an aññatthe a sata ādaḥ saṅkhyā pade pare tissaḥ e hoti
translated: When the number is not the principal factor in the compound, e is added to tis when a number word other than aṅga, etc., follows.

original: Tayo ca dasa ca terasa, tīhi vā adhikā dasa terasa. Evaṃ tevīsati, tettiṃsa.🔽419. Cattālīsādo vā ka. 404; rū. 370; caṃ. 5.2.54; pā. 6.3.49.
analyzed: tayo ca dasa ca terasa tīhi vai adhikāḥ dasa terasaḥ evam tevīsati tettiṃsa  cattālīsa ādaḥ vā ka rū cam pā
translated: Tayo ca dasa ca = terasa, or tīhi vā adhikā dasa = terasa. Evaṃ tevīsati, tettiṃsa.🔽. Cattālīsādo vā ka. ; rū. ; caṃ. ..; pā. ...🔽When cattālīsā, etc., follow, e is added to tis optionally.

original: Cattālīsādīsu paresu tissa e hoti vā.
analyzed: cattālīsa ādīsu paresu tissaḥ e hoti vā
translated: . Paññāsādo vā ka. ; rū. ; caṃ. ..; pā. ...🔽When paññāsā, etc., follow, e is added to pañca optionally.

original: Tecattālīsaṃ, ticattālīsaṃ, tepaññāsaṃ, tipaññāsaṃ, tesaṭṭhi, tisaṭṭhi, tesattati, tisattati, teasīti, tiasīti, tenavuti, tinavuti.
analyzed: tecattālīsam ticattālīsam tepaññāsam tipaññāsam tesaṭṭhi tisaṭṭhi tesattati tisattati te asi iti ti asi iti tenavuti tinavuti
translated: Thirty-three, thirty-three, fifty, fifty, sixty, sixty, seventy, seventy, eighty, eighty, ninety, ninety.

original: 420. Dvissā ca ka. 404; rū. 370 caṃ. 5.2.54; pā. 6.3.69.🔽Cattālīsādo dvissa e hoti vā ā ca.🔽Dvecattālīsaṃ, dvācattālīsaṃ, dvicattālīsaṃ, dvepaññāsaṃ, dvipaññāsaṃ, dvāsaṭṭhi,
analyzed: dvis sā ca ka rū cam pā  cattālīsa adaḥ hoti vā ā ca  dvecattālīsam dvācattālīsam dvicattālīsam dvepaññāsam dvipaññāsam dvāsaṭṭhi
translated: Thirty-three, thirty-four, thirty-five, thirty-six, thirty-seven, thirty-eight, thirty-nine, forty, forty-one, forty-two, forty-three, forty-four, forty-five, forty-six, forty-seven, forty-eight, forty-nine, fifty, fifty-one, fifty-two, fifty-three, fifty-four, fifty-five, fifty-six, fifty-seven, fifty-eight, fifty-nine, sixty, sixty-one, sixty-two, sixty-three, sixty-four, sixty-five, sixty-six, sixty-seven, sixty-eight, sixty-nine, seventy, seventy-one, seventy-two, seventy-three, seventy-four, seventy-five, seventy-six, seventy-seven, seventy-eight, seventy-nine, eighty, eighty-one, eighty-two, eighty-three, eighty-four, eighty-five, eighty-six, eighty-seven, eighty-eight, eighty-nine, ninety, ninety-one, ninety-two, ninety-three, ninety-four, ninety-five, ninety-six, ninety-seven, ninety-eight, ninety-nine.🔽With two and with forty, with form, with a, with pa, with …🔽With forty and more, with two, with e, with ho, with ā, with ca.

original: dvesaṭṭhi, dvāsattati, dvesattati, dvāsīti, dvānavuti, dvenavuti. Vāsaddena paññāsamhi🔽āttaṃ, asītimhi ettañca natthi.
analyzed: dvesaṭṭhi dvāsattati dvesattati dvāsīti dvānavuti dvenavuti vā saddena paññāsamhi  āttam asītimhi ettam ca natthi
translated: Forty-two, forty-four, fifty-two, fifty-four, fifty-six,

original: 421. Bācattālīsādo vā ka. 380; rū. 255; nī. 810.🔽Acattālīsādo pare dvissa bā hoti vā.
analyzed: bācat tālīsādaḥ vā ka rū nī  a cattālīsa ādaḥ pare dvissa bā hoti vā
translated: fifty-eight, sixty-two, sixty-four, sixty-six, sixty-eight, seventy-two, seventy-four, seventy-six, seventy-eight, eighty-two,🔽eighty-four, eighty-six, eighty-eight, ninety-two,🔽ninety-four, ninety-six, ninety-eight.🔽With forty and more, with two, with bā, with a, with rū, with nī, with …🔽With forty and more, with two, with bā, with a, with ho, with vā.

original: Bārasa, dvādasa, bāvīsati, dvāvīsati, bāttiṃsa, dvattiṃsa.
analyzed: bārasa dvādasa bāvīsati dvāvīsati bāttiṃsa dvattiṃsa
translated: Twelve, twelve, twenty-two, twenty-two, thirty-two, thirty-two.

original: Acattālīsādoti kiṃ? Dvācattālīsaṃ.🔽422. Catussa cuco dase ka. 390; rū. 256; nī. 826.🔽Dase pare catussa cu, co honti vā.
analyzed: kim dvācattālīsam  catuḥ sa cu caḥ dase ka rū nī  dase pare catussa cu caḥ honti vā
translated: What is with forty and more? Forty-two.🔽With four and more, with cu, with co, with dase, with ka, with rū, with nī, with …

original: Cuddasa, coddasa, catuddasa.
analyzed: cuddasa coddasa catuddasa
translated: With four and more, with cu, with co, with ho,

original: 423. Vīsatidasesu pañcassa paṇṇapannā ka. 404; rū. 370; nī. 814.🔽Esu pañcassa paṇṇa, pannā honti vā yathākkamaṃ.
analyzed: vīsatidasesu pañcassa paṇṇa pannā ka rū nī  esu pañcassa pannā honti vā yathākkamam
translated: In the twenties, the five has two forms, paṇṇa and pañca.🔽In these, the five has the forms paṇṇa and pañca, respectively.

original: Paṇṇavīsati, pañcavīsati, pannarasa, pañcadasa.
analyzed: paṇṇavīsati pañcavīsati pannarasa pañcadasa
translated: Paṇṇavīsati, pañcavīsati, pannarasa, pañcadasa.

original: 424. Chassa so ka. 374; rū. 408; nī. 806.🔽Dase pare chassa so hoti.
analyzed: chassa saḥ ka rū nī  dase pare chassa saḥ hoti
translated: In the thirties, the six has two forms, soḷasa and soḷasa.🔽In the thirties, the six has the forms soḷasa and soḷasa, respectively.

original: Soḷasa.🔽425. Ekaṭṭhānamā ka. 383; rū. 253; nī. 815.
analyzed: soḷasa
translated: Soḷasa.🔽In the tens, the one has two forms, eka and aṭṭha.

original: Dase pare eka, aṭṭhānaṃ ā hoti.
analyzed: dase pare eka aṭṭhānaṃ ā hoti
translated: In the tens, the one has the forms eka and aṭṭha, respectively.

original: Ekādasa, aṭṭhārasa.🔽426. Ra saṅkhyāto vā ka. 381; rū. 254; nī. 812.
analyzed: ekādasa aṭṭhārasa  ra saṅkhyātaḥ vā ka rū nī
translated: Ekādasa, aṭṭhārasa.🔽In the twenties, the ten has two forms, dasa and dvādasa.

original: Ekādisaṅkhyamhā parassa dasassa ra hoti vā.
analyzed: eka ādi saṅkhyamhā parassa dasassa ra hoti vā
translated: In the twenties, the ten has the forms dasa and dvādasa, respectively.

original: Ekārasa, ekādasa, bārasa, dvādasa, pannarasa, pañcadasa, sattarasa, sattadasa, aṭṭhārasa, aṭṭhādasa, bādese pannādese ca niccaṃ. Idha na hoti, catuddasa.🔽427. Chatīhi ḷo ca ka. 379; rū. 258; nī. 809.
analyzed: ekārasa ekādasa bārasa dvādasa pannarasa pañcadasa sattarasa sattadasa aṭṭhārasa aṭṭhādasa ca niccam idha na hoti catuddasa  chatī hi ḷo ca ka rū nī
translated: Ekārasa, ekādasa, bārasa, dvādasa, pannarasa, pañcadasa, sattarasa, sattadasa, aṭṭhārasa, aṭṭhādasa, bādese pannādese ca niccaṃ. Here it is not: catuddasa.🔽In the thirties, the three has two forms, tīhi and teḷu.

original: Cha, tīhi parassa dassa ḷo hoti ro ca.
analyzed: cha tīhi parassa dassa ḷaḥ hoti ro ca
translated: In the thirties, the three has the forms tīhi and teḷu, respectively.

original: Soḷasa, terasa, teḷasa.
analyzed: soḷasa terasa teḍasa
translated: Soḷasa, terasa, teḷasa.

original: 428. Catutthatatiyānamaḍḍhuḍḍhatiyā ka. 387; rū. 411; nī. 819.🔽‘Aḍḍhuḍḍhatiyā’ti aḍḍhā+uḍḍhatiyāti chedo, aḍḍhamhā paresaṃ catuttha, tatiyānaṃ uḍḍha, tiyā honti yathākkamaṃ.
analyzed: catuttha tatiya namaḥ huḍḍhatiyā ka rū nī  aḍḍhuḍḍhatiyā ati chedaḥ aḍḍhamhā paresam uḍḍha tiyā honti yathākkamam
translated: The fourth and the third, the half and the half-plus.🔽The fourth of the half is the half-plus, the half-plus of the third is the half-plus-third.

original: Aḍḍhena catuttho aḍḍhuḍḍho, aḍḍhena tatiyo aḍḍhatiyo.🔽Sakatthe ṇyamhi aḍḍhateyyo.🔽429. Dutiyassa saha diyaḍḍhadivaḍḍhā ka. 387; rū. 411; nī. 819.
analyzed: aḍḍhena catutthaḥ aḍḍhuḍḍhaḥ aḍḍhena tatiyaḥ aḍḍhatiyaḥ  saka tthe ṇyamhi aḍḍhateyyaḥ  dutiyassa saha diyaḍḍha divaḍḍhā ka rū nī
translated: The half-plus-fourth is the half-plus-plus.🔽The half-plus-third is the half-plus-third.🔽In the sense of a vehicle the half-plus-third is the half-plus-third.🔽The second, together with the half, the half-plus, the half-plus-plus.

original: Aḍḍhamhā parassa dutiyassa saha aḍḍhena diyaḍḍha, divaḍḍhā honti.
analyzed: aḍḍhamhā parassa dutiyassa saha aḍḍhena diyaḍḍha divaḍḍhā honti
translated: The second together with the half is the half-plus, the half-plus-plus.

original: Aḍḍhena dutiyo diyaḍḍho, divaḍḍho.🔽Yathā ca eka, dvi,ti, catu, pañca, cha, satta, aṭṭha, nava, dasasaddā paccekaṃ attano
analyzed: aḍḍhena dutiyaḥ diyaḍḍhaḥ divaḍḍhaḥ  yathā ca eka dviti catu pañca cha satta aṭṭha nava dasa saddā paccekam attano
translated: The half-plus-second is the half-plus, the half-plus-plus.🔽And just as the words one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten, each fall into their own

original: atthesu nipatanti, tathā vīsati, tiṃsati, cattālīsa, paññāsa, saṭṭhi, sattati, asīti,
analyzed: atthesu nipatanti tathā vīsati tiṃsati cattālīsa paññāsa saṭṭhi sattati asīti
translated: meanings, so the words twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, sixty, seventy, eighty,

original: navutisaddā paccekaṃ attano atthesu nipatanti, dasasaddassa kāriyā na honti, evaṃ
analyzed: navuti saddā paccekam attanaḥ atthesu nipatanti dasa saddassa kāriyāḥ na honti evam
translated: ninety, each fall into their own meanings, and do not take the word ten,

original: satasahassasaddāpīti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: sata sahassa saddā api iti daṭṭhabbam
translated: so too the words hundred and thousand should be regarded.

original: Tato paraṃ pana dasa sahassāni dasasahassaṃ, idaṃ ‘nahuta’nti ca vuccati, sataṃ sahassāni🔽satasahassaṃ, idaṃ ‘lakkha’nti ca vuccati, dasa satasahassāni dasasatasahassanti🔽evaṃ digusamāsavasena etāni padāni sijjhanti.🔽Dve satāni dvisataṃ, tīṇi satāni tisataṃ, dve sahassāni dvisahassaṃ, tīṇi sahassāni tisahassaṃ iccādīni digumhi vuttāneva.🔽Gaṇanapathe pana ekaṭṭhānaṃ, dasaṭṭhānaṃ, sataṭṭhānaṃ, sahassaṭṭhānaṃ, dasasahassaṭṭhānaṃ,🔽satasahassaṭṭhānaṃ, dasasatasahassaṭṭhānanti imāni satta ṭhānāni kamena dasaguṇitāni🔽honti. translated: But after that, ten thousands are a ‘myriad’, ten myriads are a ‘hundred-thousand’,🔽a hundred hundred-thousands are a ‘lakh’, ten hundred-thousands are a ‘ten-lakh’,🔽ten hundred-thousands are a ‘hundred-lakh’, ten hundred-lakhs are a ‘thousand-lakh’, ten thousand-lakhs are a ‘ten-thousand-lakh’, ten ten-thousand-lakhs are a ‘hundred-thousand-lakh’, ten hundred-thousand-lakhs are a ‘ten-hundred-thousand-lakh’, ten ten-hundred-thousand-lakhs are a ‘hundred-hundred-thousand-lakh’, ten hundred-hundred-thousand-lakhs are a ‘ten-hundred-hundred-thousand-lakh’, ten ten-hundred-hundred-thousand-lakhs are a ‘thousand-hundred-hundred-thousand-lakh’, ten thousand-hundred-hundred-thousand-lakhs are a ‘ten-thousand-hundred-hundred-thousand-lakh’, ten ten-thousand-hundred-hundred-thousand-lakhs are a ‘hundred-thousand-hundred-hundred-thousand-lakh’, ten hundred-thousand-hundred-hundred-thousand-lakhs are a ‘ten-hundred-thousand-hundred-hundred-thousand-lakh’, ten ten-hundred-thousand-hundred-hundred-thousand-lakhs are a ‘thousand-hundred-hundred-thousand-hundred-hundred-thousand-lakh’, ten thousand-hundred-hundred-thousand-hundred-hundred-thousand-lakhs are a ‘ten-thousand-hundred-hundred-thousand-hundred-hundred-thousand-lakh’, ten ten-thousand-hundred-hundred-thousand-hundred-hundred-thousand-lakhs are a ‘hundred-thousand-hundred-hundred-thousand-hundred-hundred-thousand-lakh’, ten hundred-thousand-hundred-hundred-thousand-hundred-hundred-thousand-lakhs are a ‘ten-hundred-thousand-hundred-hundred-thousand-hundred-hundred-thousand-lakh’, ten ten-hundred-thousand-hundred-hundred-thousand-hundred-hundred-thousand-lakhs are a ‘thousand-hundred-hundred-thousand-hundred-hundred-thousand-hundred-hundred-thousand-lakh’, ten thousand-hundred-hundred-thousand-hundred-hundred-thousand-hundred-hundred-thousand-lakhs are a ‘ten

original: tiṃsaṃ iccādi. Sataṭṭhānaṃ nāma sataṃ, dvisataṃ, tisataṃ iccādi. Sahassaṭṭhānaṃ nāma
analyzed: tiṃsam iccādi sata ṭṭhānam nāma satam dvisatam tisatam iccādi sahassa ṭṭhānam nāma
translated: But after that, ten thousands are a ‘myriad’, ten myriads are a ‘lakh’, ten lakhs are a ‘ten-lakh’, ten ten-lakhs are a ‘hundred-thousand’, ten hundred-thousands are a ‘million’, ten millions are a ‘ten-million’, ten ten-millions are a ‘billion’, ten billions are a ‘ten-billion’, ten ten-billions are a ‘hundred-billion’, ten hundred-billions are a ‘thousand-billion’, ten thousand-billions are a ‘ten-thousand-billion’, ten ten-thousand-billions are a ‘hundred-thousand-billion’, ten hundred-thousand-billions are a ‘ten-hundred-thousand-billion’, ten ten-hundred-thousand-billions are a ‘thousand-hundred-thousand-billion’, ten thousand-hundred-thousand-billions are a ‘ten-thousand-hundred-thousand-billion’, ten ten-thousand-hundred-thousand-billions are a ‘hundred-thousand-hundred-thousand-billion’, ten hundred-thousand-hundred-thousand-billions are a ‘ten-hundred-thousand-hundred-thousand-billion’, ten ten-hundred-thousand-hundred-thousand-billions are a ‘thousand-hundred-thousand-hundred-thousand-billion’, ten thousand-hundred-thousand-hundred-thousand-billions are a ‘ten-thousand-hundred-thousand-hundred-thousand-billion’, ten ten-thousand-hundred-thousand-hundred-thousand-billions are a ‘hundred-thousand-hundred-thousand-hundred-thousand-billion’, ten hundred-thousand-hundred-thousand-hundred-thousand-billions are a ‘ten-hundred-thousand-hundred-thousand-hundred-thousand-billion’, ten ten-hundred-thousand-hundred-thousand-hundred-thousand-billions are a ‘thousand-hundred-thousand-hundred-thousand-hundred-thousand-billion’, ten thousand-hundred-thousand-hundred-thousand-hundred-thousand-billions are a ‘ten-thousand-hundred-thousand-hundred-thousand-hundred-thousand-billion’, ten ten-thousand-hundred-thousand-hundred-thousand-hundred-thousand-billions are a ‘hundred-thousand-hundred-thousand-hundred-thousand-hundred-thousand-billion’, ten hundred-thousand-hundred-thousand-hundred-thousand-hundred-thousand-billions are a ‘ten-hundred-thousand-hundred-

original: sahassaṃ, dvisahassaṃ, tisahassaṃ iccādi. Evaṃ uparipi. Ekamekasmiñca ṭhāne nava
analyzed: sahassam dvi sahassam ti sahassam iccādi evam upari pi ekam ekasmin ca ṭhāne nava
translated: a thousand, two thousand, three thousand, and so on. And so above. And in each place there are nine

original: padāni ca nava antaranavantāni ca honti. Ayaṃ mūlabhūmi nāma.
analyzed: padāni ca nava antaranavantāni ca honti ayam mūlabhūmi nāma
translated: words, nine intermediate spaces, and nine spaces. This is called the basic plane.

original: Taduttari koṭibhūmi nāma. Tatthapi ekaṭṭhānaṃ, dasaṭṭhānaṃ, sataṭṭhānaṃiccādīni satta
analyzed: tad uttari koṭibhūmi nāma tattha api eka ṭṭhānam dasa ṭṭhānam sata ṭṭhānam icca ādīni satta
translated: Beyond that is the plane of koṭis. There too there are seven

original: ṭhānāni honti. Tattha mūlabhūmiyā antimaṭṭhānaṃ gahetvā dasaguṇite kate koṭibhūmiyaṃ
analyzed: ṭhānāni honti tattha mūlabhūmiyāḥ antima ṭṭhānam gahetvā dasa guṇite kate koṭibhūmiyam
translated: places, namely, one place, ten places, a hundred places, and so on. Therein, taking the last place of the basic plane and multiplying it by ten, it becomes

original: ekaṭṭhānaṃ hoti, idhapi satta ṭhānāni kamena dasaguṇitāniyeva, idha dasakoṭisatasahassaṃ
analyzed: eka ṭṭhānam hoti idha api satta ṭhānāni kamena dasa guṇitāni iva idha dasa koṭi sata sahassam
translated: one place in the plane of koṭis. Here too the seven places are multiplied by ten in order. Here a hundred thousand koṭis

original: antimaṭṭhānaṃ bhavati.
analyzed: antimaṭṭhānam bhavati
translated: is the last place.

original: Taduttari pakoṭibhūmi nāma. Etthapi satta ṭhānāni honti. Tattha koṭibhūmiyā antimaṭṭhānaṃ🔽gahetvā dasaguṇite kate pakoṭibhūmiyaṃ ekaṭṭhānaṃ hoti, idhapi satta ṭhānāni dasaguṇitāniyeva,
analyzed: tad uttari pakoṭibhūmi nāma ettha api satta ṭhānāni honti tattha koṭibhūmiyāḥ antima ṭṭhānaṃ  gahetvā dasa guṇite kate pakoṭi bhūmiyam eka ṭṭhānam hoti idha api satta ṭhānāni
translated: Beyond that is the plane of pakowaṭṭhis. There too there are seven places. Therein, taking the last place of the plane of koṭis🔽and multiplying it by ten, it becomes one place in the plane of pakowaṭṭhis. Here too the seven places are multiplied by ten in order.

original: dasapakoṭisatasahassaṃ antimaṭṭhānaṃ, iminā nayena sabbabhūmīsu uparūpari bhūmisaṅkanti
analyzed: dasapa koṭi sata sahassam antima ṭṭhānam iminā nayena sabba bhūmīsu upari upari
translated: A hundred thousand koṭis of pakowaṭṭhis is the last place. By this method, in all the planes, the transference of the planes is

original: ca ṭhānabhedo ca veditabbo.
analyzed: ca ṭhāna bhedaḥ ca veditabbo
translated: and the different levels should be understood.

original: Ayaṃ panettha bhūmikkamo-mūlabhūmi, koṭibhūmi, pakoṭibhūmi, koṭipakoṭibhūmi, nahutabhūmi,🔽ninnahutabhūmi, akkhobhiṇībhūmi bhinī, bhanītipi dissanti, bindubhūmi, abbudabhūmi,
analyzed: ayam pana ittha bhūmikkamaḥ mūla bhūmi koṭi bhūmi pakoṭi bhūmi koṭi pakoṭi bhūmi nahuta bhūmi  ninna huta bhūmi akkhobhiṇībhūmi bhinī bhanī tipi dissanti bindu bhūmi abbuda bhūmi
translated: But the order of the levels here is this: the root level, the tip level, the subtip level, the subtip of the tip level, the burnt level,🔽the well-burnt level, the unagitated level, the agitated level, the drop level, the bubble level,

original: nirabbudabhūmi, ahahabhūmi, abababhūmi, aṭaṭabhūmi, sogandhikabhūmi, uppalabhūmi,
analyzed: nirabbuda bhūmi ahahabhūmi abababhūmi aṭaṭa bhūmi sogandhika bhūmi uppala bhūmi
translated: the non-bubble level, the day-and-night level, the not-a-bit level, the not-a-bit-of-a-bit level, the not-a-bit-of-a-not-a-bit level, the fragrant-creeper level, the water-lily level,

original: kumudabhūmi, puṇḍarīkabhūmi, padumabhūmi, kathānabhūmi, mahākathānabhūmi, asaṅkhyeyyabhūmīti
analyzed: kumuda bhūmi puṇḍarīka bhūmi paduma bhūmi kathāna bhūmi mahā kathāna bhūmi asaṅkhyeyya bhūmi iti
translated: the white-water-lily level, the night-water-lily level, the lotus level, the talk level, the great talk level, the incalculable level.

original: ekavīsati bhūmiyo sattacattālīsasataṃ ṭhānāni ca honti.
analyzed: ekavīsati bhūmiyaḥ ṭhānāni ca honti
translated: There are twenty-one levels and seven hundred and forty places.

original: Nirayabhūmīnaṃ kamena pana abbudabhūmi, nirabbudabhūmi, abababhūmi, aṭaṭabhūmi, ahahabhūmi,
analyzed: niraya bhūmīnam kamena pana abbuda bhūmi nirabbuda bhūmi ababa bhūmi aṭaṭa bhūmi ahaha bhūmi
translated: But in the order of the hells the drop level, the non-bubble level, the not-a-bit-of-a-not-a-bit level, the not-a-bit level, the day-and-night level,

original: kumudabhūmi, sogandhikabhūmi, uppalabhūmi, puṇḍarīkabhūmi, padumabhūmīti vattabbo.
analyzed: kumuda bhūmi sogandhika bhūmi uppala bhūmi puṇḍarīka bhūmi paduma bhūmi iti vattabbo
translated: the fragrant-creeper level, the water-lily level, the white-water-lily level, the night-water-lily level, and the lotus level should be mentioned.

original: Ettha ca yasmā pāḷibhāsāyaṃ dasasatasahassaṃ nāma sattamaṭṭhānaṃ natthi, cha ṭhānāni
analyzed: ettha ca yasmā pāḷibhāsāyam dasasatasahassam nāma sattama ṭṭhānam natthi cha ṭhānāni
translated: And here, since in the text of the scriptures there is no seventh place called a hundred thousand,

original: eva atthi, tasmā garū aṭṭhakathāsu saṃ. ni. 1.181 āgatanayena sattamaṭṭhānaṃ ullaṅghetvā🔽chaṭṭhaṭṭhānato upari bhūmisaṅkantiṃ kathentā sataguṇitaṃ katvā kathenti, satasahassānaṃ
analyzed: eva atthi tasmai garū aṭṭhakathāsu sam ni āgata nayena sattama ṭṭhānam ullaṅghetvā  chaṭṭha ṭṭhānataḥ upari bhūmi saṅkantim kathentā sata guṇitam katvā kathenti sata sahassānam
translated: Therefore, in the commentaries, the teachers, having extended the seventh stage by the method stated in the Atthakathā,

original: sataṃ koṭi, koṭisatasahassānaṃ sataṃ pakoṭi iccādi.
analyzed: satam koṭi koṭi sata sahassānam satam iccādi
translated: speak of the transition to the next stage above the sixth stage by multiplying it by a hundred, saying that a hundred times a hundred thousand is ten million, a hundred times ten million is a billion, and so on.

original: Tattha satasahassānaṃ sataṃ nāma dasasatasahassānaṃ dasakameva hoti, tasmā tathā
analyzed: tattha sata sahassānam satam nāma dasa sata sahassānam dasakam eva hoti tasmā tathā
translated: Herein, a hundred times a hundred thousand is ten million, so when they speak thus,

original: kathentāpi bhūmīnaṃ sabbaṭṭhānānañca dasaguṇasiddhimeva kathentīti veditabbaṃ. Yasmā
analyzed: kathentā api bhūmīnam sabba ṭṭhānānam ca dasaguṇa siddhim eva kathenti iti veditabbam yasmā
translated: it should be understood that they are speaking of the increase of the stages and of all the positions by ten.

original: ca gaṇanabhūmisaṅkhāto gaṇanapatho nāma nānādesavāsīnaṃ vasena nānāvidho hoti, tasmā
analyzed: ca gaṇana bhūmi saṅkhātaḥ gaṇana pathaḥ nāma nānā desa vāsīnam vasena nānāvidhaḥ tasmā
translated: And since the method of counting called the “stage of counting” is of various kinds according to the various countries where it is used,

original: dīpavaṃse akkhobhiṇī, bindu, kathāna, mahākathānāni vajjetvā pāḷinayena sattarasa
analyzed: dīpavaṃse akkhobhiṇī bindu kathāna mahākathānāni vajjetvā pāḷinayena sattarasa
translated: in the Dīpavaṃsa, after omitting the akkhobhinī, bindu, kathāna, and mahākathāna, the seventeen stages are given according to the texts.

original: bhūmiyova vuttā. Kaccāyane ka. 394, 395; rū. 416, 417 pubbe dassitā ekavīsati bhūmiyo,
analyzed: bhūmiyaḥ iva vuttā kaccāyane ka       pubbe dassitāḥ ekavīsati bhūmiyaḥ
translated: In the Kaccāyana grammar, the twenty-one stages shown above,

original: sakkataganthesu tato sādhikabhūmiyo, katthaci pana mahābalakkhandhapariyantā saṭṭhi bhūmiyoti āgatā.
analyzed: sakkata ganthesu tatas sādhika bhūmiyaḥ katthaci pana mahā balakkhandha pariyantā saṭṭhi bhūmiyaḥ ti āgatā
translated: In the texts of the Sutta Pitaka the stages are given as sixty, ending with the stage of the great earth consisting of the four primary elements.

original: Tattha sakasakabhūmito atirekavatthūni gaṇanapathavītivattāni nāma honti, yesaṃ pana mūlabhūmimattaṃ atthi, tesaṃ koṭimattānipi vatthūni gaṇanapathātikkantāni eva.
analyzed: tattha saka saka bhūmitaḥ atireka vatthūni gaṇana pathavītivattāni nāma honti yesam pana mūla bhūmi mattam atthi tesam koṭi mattāni api vatthūni gaṇana patha atikkantāni eva
translated: Herein, the things that are more than the stage of the particular counting are called “beyond number.” But those that have only the stage of the root-cause are called “beyond measure.”

original: Api ca ‘gaṇanapathavītivatta’nti ca ‘gaṇanapathātikkanta’nti ca ‘asaṅkhyeyya’nti🔽ca atthato ekaṃ. Tasmā idhapi vīsati bhūmiyo eva anukkamena dasaguṇitā gaṇanapathā
analyzed: api ca gaṇana patha vītivattanti ca gaṇana patha atikkantanti ca asaṅkhyeyyanti  ca atthataḥ ekam tasmai idha api vīsati bhūmiyaḥ eva anukkamena dasa guṇitāḥ gaṇana pathā
translated: Besides, “beyond number” and “beyond measure” and “incalculable”

original: nāma honti. Asaṅkhyeyyanti pana dasaguṇavinimuttā gaṇanapathātikkantabhūmi eva vuccati.🔽Mahākathānabhūmātikkantato paṭṭhāya hi anantamahāpathaviyā sabbapaṃsucuṇṇānipi idha
analyzed: nāma honti asaṅkhyeyyanti pana dasaguṇa vinimuttā gaṇana patha atikkanta bhūmi eva vuccati  mahā kathāna bhūma atikkantato paṭṭhāya hi ananta mahā pathaviyā sabba paṃsu cuṇṇāni pi idha
translated: are the same in meaning. So here too the twenty stages are called “number” when they are in order of tenfold increase. But “incalculable” is said of the stage that is beyond the stage of “number” when it is freed from tenfold increase.

original: asaṅkhyeyyabhūmiyaṃ saṅgayhanti. Itarathā asaṅkhyeyyanti ca gaṇanapathabhūmīti ca viruddhametanti.
analyzed: asaṅkhyeyya bhūmi iyam saṅgayhanti itarathā asaṅkhyeyyanti ca gaṇana patha bhūmi iti ca viruddham etat ti
translated: For all the dust and soil of the infinite great earth is included here in the “incalculable” stage. Otherwise “incalculable” and “stage of number” would be contradictory.

original: Dīpavaṃse ca “tato upari abhūmi, asaṅkhyeyyanti vuccatī”ti vuttaṃ. Tattha ‘abhūmī’ti
analyzed: dīpa vaṃse ca tatas upari abhūmi asaṅkhyeyyanti vuccati iti vuttam tattha abhūmi iti
translated: Herein, by the word “period”

original: vacanena gaṇanapathabhūmi eva paṭisiddhā, na tu gaṇanapathātikkantā visuṃ asaṅkhyeyyabhūmi
analyzed: vacanena gaṇana patha bhūmi eva paṭisiddhā na tu gaṇana patha atikkantā visum asaṅkhyeyya bhūmi
translated: the reckoning of the number is denied, but no “incalculable period” is mentioned as a separate period beyond reckoning.

original: nāma. Cariyāpiṭakasaṃvaṇṇanāyampi cariyā. aṭṭha. nidānakathā ayamattho vutto. Asaṅkhyeyyabhūmiyampi
analyzed: nāma cariyā piṭaka saṃvaṇṇanāyam pi cariyā aṭṭha nidāna kathāḥ ayam atthaḥ vuttaḥ asaṅkhyeyya bhūmiyam pi
translated: And in the Cariyāpiṭaka Commentary the meaning is stated thus: “Eight are the cariyā, the nidāna is the ninth” .

original: asaṅkhyeyyānaṃ cūḷa, mahādivasena anekappabhedo dakkhiṇavibhaṅgasuttena ma. ni. 3.370 dīpetabbo.
analyzed: asaṅkhyeyyānam cūḷa mahādivasena aneka ppabhedaḥ dakkhiṇa vibhaṅga suttena ma ni dīpetabbaḥ
translated: And the incalculable period is of many kinds as “lesser incalculable” and “greater incalculable” and so on. It can be demonstrated by the Dakkhiṇāvibhanga Sutta in the Majjhima Nikāya .

original: Saddanītiyaṃ nī. 833 pana pāḷinayaṃ gahetvā “vīsati abbudāni ekaṃ nirabbudaṃ nāma.
analyzed: saddanītiyam nī pana pāḷi nayam gahetvā vīsati abbudāni ekam nirabbudam nāma
translated: But in the Saddanīti it is said, taking the method of the texts, that “twenty abbudas make one nirabbuda,

original: Vīsati nirabbudāni ekaṃ ababaṃ nāma” iccādinā nirabbudādīnaṃ saṅkhyānampi vīsatimattaguṇaṃ
analyzed: vīsati nirabbudāni ekam ababam nāma icca ādinā nirabbuda ādīnam
translated: twenty nirabbudas make one ababa” and so on, and so on, and that the number of the nirabbuda and so on is said to be twenty times the last mentioned.

original: nāma vuttaṃ. Taṃ na yujjati. Nirayesu hi vīsatimattaguṇena abbuda, nirabbudādīnaṃ
analyzed: nāma vuttam tam na yujjati nirayesu hi vīsati matta guṇena abbuda nirabbuda ādīnam
translated: That is incorrect. For in the hells the abbudas are twenty times the last mentioned, and the nirabbudas and so on are twenty times the abbudas.

original: dasannaṃ nirayānaṃ tāni nāmāni siddhāni bhavanti. Garū pana tāni nāmāni gahetvā dasaguṇasiddhesu
analyzed: tāni nāmāni siddhāni bhavanti tāni nāmāni gahetvā dasaguṇa siddhesu
translated: The names of the ten hells are established in the texts. But the Garu people took those names and put them in the counting systems established in tenfold units.

original: gaṇanapathesu pakkhipiṃsu, tasmā nāmamattena sadisāni bhavanti, guṇavidhi pana visadisoeva.🔽Evañcakatvā pāḷiyampi bakabrahmāsutte saṃ. ni. 1.175 “sataṃ sahassānaṃ nirabbudānaṃ,
analyzed: gaṇana pathesu tasmai nāma mattena sadisāni bhavanti guṇa vidhi pana  evam cakatvā pāḷiyam pi bakabrahmāsutte sam ni satam sahassānam nirabbudānam
translated: Therefore they are similar only in name, but the method of qualities is quite different.🔽If it were not so, in the text of the Bakabrahmā Sutta, the following would be stated: “I know your life-span, O Brahmā, of a hundred thousand nirayas.”

original: āyuṃ pajānāmi tavāhaṃ brahme”ti vuttaṃ. Ettha ca yadi gaṇanabhūmipathepi nirabbudānaṃ
analyzed: āyum pajānāmi tava aham brahmā iti vuttam ettha ca yadi gaṇana bhūmi pathe pi
translated: And here, if in the counting and stage systems, the twenty-fold niraya would be the ababa stage,

original: vīsatimattena abababhūmi bhaveyya, evaṃ sati nirabbudānaṃ satasahassaṃ nāma na vucceyya.
analyzed: vīsati mattena bhaveyya evam sati nirabbudānam sata sahassam nāma na vucceyya
translated: then it would not be said that a hundred thousand nirayas is called a niraya.

original: Jātakaṭṭhakathāyañca jā. aṭṭha. 3.7.69 “nirabbudasatasahassānaṃ ekaṃ ahahaṃ nāma,
analyzed: jātaka ṭṭhakathāyam ca jā aṭṭha nirabbuda sata sahassānam ekam ahaham nāma
translated: And in the commentary to the Jātaka, it is said: “A hundred thousand nirayas is one ahaha,

original: ettakaṃ bakassa brahmuno tasmiṃbhave avasiṭṭhaṃ āyū”ti vuttaṃ. Tasmā imaṃ gaṇanabhūmipathaṃ
analyzed: ettakam bakassa brahmunaḥ tasmiṃbhave avasiṭṭham āyu iti vuttam tasmai imam gaṇana bhūmi patham
translated: so much of the life-span of the Bakabrahmā remained in that existence.” Therefore, this counting and stage system

original: patvā vīsatiguṇaṃ nāma natthīti siddhaṃ hoti. Akkhobhiṇī, bindu, kathāna, mahākathānānipi
analyzed: patvā vīsatiguṇam nāma natthi iti siddham hoti
translated: and it is established that there is no such thing as a number twenty times twenty. The Akkhobhinī, Bindu, Kathāna, and Mahākathāna are also included from elsewhere.

original: aññato gahetvā pakkhittāni siyuṃ. Evaṃ pakkhittānañca cuddasannaṃ saṅkhyānaṃ kaccāyane
analyzed: aññatas gahetvā pakkhittāni siyum evam pakkhittānam ca saṅkhyānam kaccāyane
translated: And of the fourteen numbers included in this way, the Kaccāyana

original: kamokkamatā pana pacchājātā siyāti.
analyzed: kama ukkama tā pana pacchājātā siyāti
translated: is the last to be introduced.

original: Iti niruttidīpaniyā nāma moggallānabyākaraṇadīpaniyā
analyzed: iti niruttidīpaniyā nāma moggallāna byākaraṇa dīpaniyā
translated: Thus the commentary called the Elucidator of the Path of Purification,

original: Samāsakaṇḍo catuttho.
analyzed: samāsa kaṇḍaḥ catutthaḥ
translated: The fourth chapter called “The Section on Prefixes”

original: 5. Taddhita
analyzed: taddhita
translated: Taddhita

original: Atha taddhitavidhānaṃ dīpiyate.🔽Taddhitavutti nāma vicitrā hoti, sātisayena vicitrañāṇahitaṃ vahati, tasmā tesaṃ
analyzed: atha taddhita vidhānam dīpiyate  nāma vicitrā hoti sa atisayena vicitra ñāṇa hitam vahati tasmā tesam
translated: Now the exposition of the taddhita is undertaken.🔽The taddhita usage is varied, and it conveys a very varied knowledge, and so it is for the benefit of those young men

original: tesaṃ kulaputtānaṃ hitanti taddhitaṃ, imasmiṃ kaṇḍe sabbavidhānassa nāmaṃ. Taṃ pana
analyzed: tesam kula puttānam hitam ti tad hitam imasmin kaṇḍe sabbavidhānassa nāmam tam pana
translated: who are called taddhita, that is, “those for whom this is beneficial,” and it is the name of the whole exposition in this chapter. But

original: aṭṭhavidhaṃ hoti apaccaṃ, anekatthaṃ, assatthi, bhāvakammaṃ, parimāṇaṃ, saṅkhyā,
analyzed: aṭṭhavidham hoti apaccam anekattham assatthi bhāva kammam parimāṇam saṅkhyā
translated: that is of eight kinds as non-subsidiary, in many places, not a noun, a verbal noun, measure, number,

original: khuddakaṃ, nānāttanti.
analyzed: khuddakam
translated: small, and various.

original: Apaccarāsi
analyzed: apaccarā asi
translated: The non-subsidiary class

original: 430. Ṇo vāpacce ka. 344; rū. 361; nī. 752; caṃ. 2.4.16; pā. 4.1.92; ‘sarānamādissā…’ (bahūsu).
analyzed: ṇaḥ vā a pacce ka rū nī cam pā sara ānam ādissā bahūsu
translated: Or in the sense of ‘from’

original: Chaṭṭhyantā nāmamhā tassa apaccanti atthe vikappena ṇapaccayo hoti. Vāsaddo vākya,
analyzed: chaṭṭhī antāḥ tassa a paccanti atthe vikappena ṇa paccayaḥ hoti vā saddaḥ vākya
translated: The sixth-case form of a noun has the suffix ṇapaccaya in the sense of ‘from’ optionally. The word vās is a sentence.

original: samāsānaṃ vikappanattho, ito paraṃ anuvattate, tena sabbattha vikappavidhi sijjhati.
analyzed: samāsānam vikappana atthaḥ itas param anuvattate tena sabbattha vikappa vidhi sijjhati
translated: The sense of ‘optionally’ in the compound is implied here and so the rule of option is established in all cases.

original: Ṇānubandho vuddhyattho, so payogaappayogī. Vasiṭṭhassa apaccanti atthe iminā suttena
analyzed: vuddhi atthaḥ saḥ payoga appayogī vasiṭṭhassa atthe iminā suttena
translated: The suffix ṇan is in the sense of ‘increase’; it is used optionally. In the sense of ‘from’ in the case of Vasiṭṭha, the suffix ṇapaccaya is formed by this sutta.

original: vasiṭṭhamhā ṇapaccayo, so sāmyatthañca apaccatthañca ubhayaṃ vadati, chaṭṭhī ca apaccapadañca
analyzed: saḥ sāmi attham ca a paccattham ca ubhayam vadati chaṭṭhī ca a pacca padam ca
translated: It expresses both the sense of equality and the sense of ‘from’. The sixth case and the word apacca

original: tena vuttatthā nāma honti, vasiṭṭhapadaṃ paccayena saha ekatthaṃ hoti, ubhayaṃ ekato
analyzed: tena vutta tthāḥ nāma honti vasiṭṭhapadam paccayena saha ekattham hoti ubhayam ekatas
translated: Therefore the words are said to have the same meaning. The word Vasiṭṭha becomes one word with the suffix. Both are together.

original: hutvā puttassa nāmaṃ hotīti attho. Tato ‘ekatthatāya’nti chaṭṭhiyā lopo, apaccapadaṃ
analyzed: hutvā puttassa nāmam hoti iti atthaḥ tatas ekatthatāyanti chaṭṭhiyāḥ lopaḥ a pacca padam
translated: The meaning is: having offered, it is the name of the son. Then, by the sixth case ‘because of having the same meaning’, the elision is of the apacca word.

original: pana vuttatthamattena luppati. Tañhi sutte padhānabhāvena niddiṭṭhaṃ hoti, na chaṭṭhīti,
analyzed: pana vutta ttha mattena luppati tat hi sutte padhāna bhāvena niddiṭṭham hoti na chaṭṭhī iti
translated: but it is satisfied with the mere statement. For it is demonstrated in the sutta as the predominant factor, not as the sixth case.

original: mahāvuttinā vā padānaṃ lopo. Evaṃ sabbattha.🔽431. Padānamādissāyuvaṇṇassāeo ṇānubandhe ka. 405; rū. 365; nī. 860.
analyzed: mahāvuttinā vā padānam lopaḥ evam sabbattha  padānam ādi ssā yu vaṇ ṇassā eaḥ ṇa anubandhe ka rū nī
translated: Or else the omission of the words is a great omission. So in all instances.🔽In the case of the first letter of a word, the vowel i or u is lengthened before a following ṇ,

original: Padānaṃ ādibhūtassa akārassa ca ivaṇṇu’vaṇṇassa ca ā, e, o vuddhiyo honti ṇānubandhe paccaye pareti padādia-kārassa āvuddhi, syādyuppatti.
analyzed: padānam ādi bhūtassa akārassa ca ā e o vuddhiyaḥ honti ṇa anubandhe paccaye parā iti pada ādi akārassa
translated: The vowel a, e, or o is lengthened in the first letter of a word and in the vowel i or u before a following ṇ,

original: Vāsiṭṭho, puriso, vāsiṭṭhī, itthī, vāsiṭṭhaṃ, kulaṃ, vasiṭṭhassa putto vāsiṭṭho, vasiṭṭhassa dhītā vāsiṭṭhī, vasiṭṭhassa kulaṃ vāsiṭṭhanti evampi yojetuṃ yujjati.
analyzed: vāsiṭṭhaḥ purisaḥ vāsiṭṭhī itthī vāsiṭṭham kulam vasiṭṭhassa puttaḥ vāsiṭṭhaḥ vasiṭṭhassa dhītā vāsiṭṭhī vasiṭṭhassa kulam vāsiṭṭhanti evam pi yojetum yujjati
translated: Vasiṭṭho, puriso, vāsiṭṭhī, itthī, vāsiṭṭhaṃ, kulaṃ, vasiṭṭhassa putto vāsiṭṭho, vasiṭṭhassa dhītā vāsiṭṭhī, vasiṭṭhassa kulaṃ vāsiṭṭhanti evampi yojetuṃ yujjati.

original: Tattha ‘vasiṭṭhassā’ti etena gottasseva pitubhūtaṃ ādipurisaṃ vadati. Kasmā? Gottasaddattā. Evañhi sati tasmiṃ gotte paccājātā sabbepi janā tassa apaccā nāma honti.
analyzed: tattha vasiṭṭhassa ati etena gottassa iva pitu bhūtam ādi purisam vadati kasmai gotta saddattā evam hi sati tasmin gotte paccājātā sabbe api janā tassa apaccā nāma honti
translated: Herein, by ‘vasiṭṭhassā’ he speaks of the first man who was the father of the clan. Why? Because of the word ‘clan.’ For if it were so, then all the people born in that clan would be called ‘not his own.’

analyzed: majjhe ka rū nī
translated: In the middle ka. ; rū. ; nī. .

original: Majjhe pavattānaṃ a, yuvaṇṇānaṃ ā, e, ovuddhiyo honti vā kvaci.🔽Vāseṭṭho, vāseṭṭhī, vāseṭṭhaṃ. Vāsaddena “vasiṭṭhassa putto dhītā kula”nti vākyaṃ vā “vasiṭṭhaputto vasiṭṭhadhītā vasiṭṭhakula”nti samāsaṃ vā vikappeti. Evaṃ sabbattha.🔽Bharadvājassa apaccaṃ bhāradvājo, visāmittassa bhāradvājassa… vesāmittassa… (rū.)🔽apaccaṃ vesāmitto, gotamassa apaccaṃ gotamo, kassapassa apaccaṃ kassapo, vasudevassa🔽apaccaṃ vāsudevo. Evaṃ bāladevo.
analyzed: majjhe pavattānam a yuvaṇṇānam ā e ovuddhiyaḥ honti vā kvaci  vāseṭṭhaḥ vāseṭṭhī vāseṭṭham vā saddena vasiṭṭhassa puttaḥ dhītā kulanti vākyam vā vasiṭṭha puttaḥ vasiṭṭha dhītā vasiṭṭha kulanti samāsam vā vikappeti evam sabbattha  bharadvājassa apaccam bhāradvājaḥ visāmittassa bhāradvājassa vesāmittassa  apaccam vesāmittaḥ gotamassa apaccam gotamaḥ kassapassa apaccam kassapaḥ vasudevassa  apaccam vāsudevaḥ evam bāladevaḥ
translated: The vowel a of the middle syllable becomes ā, e, or o, or sometimes it is lengthened.

original: Upagussa apaccanti ettha ‘uvaṇṇassāvaṅa…’ti ṇānubandhe paccaye pare uvaṇṇassa avaṅa🔽hoti. Opagavo, opagavī, opagavaṃ, manuno apaccaṃ mānavo, bhagguno apaccaṃ bhaggavo,🔽paṇḍuno apaccaṃ paṇḍavo, upavindussa apaccaṃ opavindavo iccādi.
analyzed: upagussa a paccanti ettha u vaṇṇassa avaṅa ti ṇa anubandhe paccaye pare u vaṇṇassa avaṅa 🔽hoti opagavaḥ opagavī opagavam manunaḥ apaccam mānavaḥ bhaggunaḥ apaccam bhaggavaḥ 🔽paṇḍunaḥ apaccam paṇḍavaḥ upavindussa apaccam opavindavaḥ iccādi
translated: Vāseṭṭho, vāseṭṭhī, vāseṭṭhaṃ. The word vāseṭṭha is derived from the word vasiṭṭha. The word vāseṭṭha is used in the sense of “the son of a brahmin of the Vasiṭṭha clan, the daughter of a brahmin of the Vasiṭṭha clan, the family of a brahmin of the Vasiṭṭha clan.” The word vāseṭṭha is used in the sense of “the son of a brahmin of the Vasiṭṭha clan, the daughter of a brahmin of the Vasiṭṭha clan, the family of a brahmin of the Vasiṭṭha clan.” The word vāseṭṭha is used in the sense of “the son of a brahmin of the Vasiṭṭha clan, the daughter of a brahmin of the Vasiṭṭha clan, the family of a brahmin of the Vasiṭṭha clan.” The word vāseṭṭha is used in the sense of “the son of a brahmin of the Vasiṭṭha clan, the daughter of a brahmin of the Vasiṭṭha clan, the family of a brahmin of the Vasiṭṭha clan.” The word vāseṭṭha is used in the sense of “the son of a brahmin of the Vasiṭṭha clan, the daughter of a brahmin of the Vasiṭṭha clan, the family of a brahmin of the Vasiṭṭha clan.” The word vāseṭṭha is used in the sense of “the son of a brahmin of the Vasiṭṭha clan, the daughter of a brahmin of the Vasiṭṭha clan, the family of a brahmin of the Vasiṭṭha clan.” The word vāseṭṭha is used in the sense of “the son of a brahmin of the Vasiṭṭha clan, the daughter of a brahmin of the Vasiṭṭha clan, the family of a brahmin of the Vasiṭṭha clan.” The word vāseṭṭha is used in the sense of “the son of a brahmin of the Vasiṭṭha clan, the daughter of a brahmin of the Vasi

original: 433. Vacchādito ṇānaṇāyanā ka. 345; rū. 366; nī. 754; pā. 4.1.93, 94, 162, 163.
translated: The -āno, -āyano, -āṇī, -āṇī, -āṇam, -āyanam are formed by adding the -āno, -āyano, -āṇī, -āṇī, -āṇam, -āyanam endings to the stems vaccha-, etc., in the sense of ‘having been used for’ (apaccanti).

original: Chaṭṭhuntehi vacchādīhi gottasaddagaṇehi tassa apaccanti atthe ṇānubandhā āna, āyanapaccayā honti vā.
analyzed: cha ṭṭha untehi vaccha ādīhi gotta sadda gaṇehi tassa a paccanti atthe ṇa anubandhāḥ ānaḥ āyana paccayāḥ honti vā
translated: The -āno, -āyano, -āṇī, -āṇī, -āṇam, -āyanam endings are added to the stems vaccha-, etc., in the sense of ‘having been used for.’

original: Vacchassa apaccaṃ vacchāno, vacchāyano, vacchānī, vacchāyanī, vacchānaṃ, vacchāyanaṃ.
analyzed: vacchassa apaccam vacchānaḥ vacchāyanaḥ vacchānī vacchāyanī vacchānam vacchāyanam
translated: The forms vacchāno, vacchāyano, vacchānī, vacchāṇī, vacchānaṃ, vacchāyanam are formed in this way.

original: Evaṃ kaccāno, kaccāyano, kātiyāno, kātiyāyano, sākaṭāno, sākaṭāyano, kaṇhāno, kaṇhāyano,
analyzed: evam kaccāno kaccāyanaḥ kātiyānaḥ kātiyāyanaḥ sākaṭānaḥ sākaṭāyanaḥ kaṇhānaḥ kaṇhāyanaḥ
translated: So too: kaccāno, kaccāyano, kātiyāno, kātiyāyano, sākaṭāno, sākaṭāyano, kaṇhāno, kaṇhāyano,

original: moggallāno, moggallāyano, aggivessāno aggivessanotipi dissati dī. ni. 1.176; ma.🔽ni. 1.353 ādayo, aggivessāyano, muñcāno, muñcāyano, kuñcāno, kuñcāyano iccādi.🔽434. Kattikāvidhavādīhi ṇeyyaṇerā ka. 346; rū. 367; nī. 755; pā. 4.1.120, 123, 126, 127, 128, 129, 131.
analyzed: moggallānaḥ moggallāyanaḥ aggivessānaḥ aggivessanaḥ tipi dissati dī ni ma  ni ādayaḥ aggivessāyanaḥ muñcānaḥ muñcāyano kuñcānaḥ kuñcāyanaḥ iccādi  kattikā vidhavā ādīhi ṇeyya ṇerā ka rū nī pā
translated: moggallāno, moggallāyano, aggivessāno, aggivessāyano, muñcāno, muñcāyano, kuñcāno, kuñcāyano, etc.🔽The -eyya, -er endings are added to the stems kattika-, etc., and vidhava-, etc., in the sense of ‘having been used for.’

original: Chaṭṭhyantehi kattikādīhi vidhavādīhi ca tassa apaccanti atthe kamena ṇānubandhā eyya, erapaccayā honti vā.
analyzed: chaṭṭhī antehi kattikā ādīhi vidhavā ādīhi ca tassa a paccanti atthe kamena ṇa anubandhāḥ eyyaḥ era paccayāḥ honti vā
translated: The -eyya, -er endings are added to the stems kattika-, etc., and vidhava-, etc., in the sense of ‘having been used for.’

original: Ṇeyye – kattikāya nāma devadhītāya apaccaṃ kattikeyyo, vinatāya nāma deviyā apaccaṃ🔽venateyyo, rohiṇiyā nāma deviyā apaccaṃ rohiṇeyyo, bhaginiyā apaccaṃ bhāgineyyo,🔽nadiyā nāma itthiyā apaccaṃ nādeyyo. Evaṃ anteyyo, āheyyo, kāmeyyo, suciyā apaccaṃ
analyzed: ṇeyye kattikāya nāma deva dhītāya apaccam kattikeyyaḥ vinatāya nāma deviyāḥ apaccam  venateyyaḥ rohiṇiyāḥ nāma deviyāḥ apaccam rohiṇeyyaḥ bhaginiyāḥ apaccam bhāgineyyaḥ  nadiyā nāma itthiyā apaccam nādeyyaḥ evam anteyyaḥ āheyyaḥ kāmeyyaḥ suciyā apaccam
translated: Neyya: Kattikeyya, Vinateyya, Rohiṇeyya, Bhāgineyya, Nādeyya.

original: soceyyo, bālāya apaccaṃ bāleyyo iccādi.🔽Ṇere – vidhavāya apaccaṃ vedhavero, vidhavā nāma matapatikā itthī. Bandhukiyā apaccaṃ🔽bandhukero, nāḷikiyā nāma itthiyā putto nāḷikero, samaṇassa upajjhāyassa putto sāmaṇero,
analyzed: soceyyaḥ bālāya a paccam bāleyyaḥ iccādi  ṇere vidhavāya apaccam vedhaveraḥ vidhavā nāma mata patikā itthī bandhukiyā apaccam  bandhukeraḥ nāḷikiyā nāma itthiyā putto nāḷikeraḥ samaṇassa upajjhāyassa putto sāmaṇero
translated: Thus anteyya, āheyya, kāmeyya, soceyya, bāleyya.

original: samaṇiyā pavattiniyā dhītā sāmaṇerī iccādi.
analyzed: samaṇiyā pavattiniyā dhītā sāmaṇerī iccādi
translated: Nere: Vedhavero, bandhukero, nāḷikero, sāmaṇero, sāmaṇerī.

original: 435. Ṇya diccādīhi ka. 347; rū. 368; nī. 756; caṃ. 2.4.2; pā. 4.1.85.
analyzed: ṇya dicca ādīhi ka rū nī cam pā
translated: Ṇya diccādīhi ka. ; rū. ; nī. ; caṃ. ..; pā. ...

original: Chaṭṭhuntehi ditiiccādīhi tassa apaccanti atthe ṇānubandho yapaccayo hoti vā.
analyzed: cha ṭṭha untehi diti icca ādīhi tassa a paccanti atthe ṇa anubandhaḥ ya paccayaḥ hoti vā
translated: With the sixth-case forms of diti and so on, the affix yap is added to the base with the meaning of ‘descendant’, optionally.

original: 436. Lopovaṇṇivaṇṇānaṃ ka. 261; rū. 369; nī. 509.
analyzed: lopa uvaṇṇi vaṇṇānam ka rū nī
translated: Lopovaṇṇivaṇṇānaṃ ka. ; rū. ; nī. .

original: Ye pare avaṇṇassa ivaṇṇassa ca lopo hotīti ṇyamhi pare avaṇṇi’vaṇṇānaṃ lopo.
analyzed: ye pare a vaṇṇassa i vaṇṇassa ca lopaḥ hoti iti ṇ yamhi pare a vaṇṇi vaṇṇānam lopaḥ
translated: When the syllable following is a nasal, there is elision of the vowel and the nasal.

original: Ditiyā nāma devadhītāya apaccaṃ decco, aditiyā apaccaṃ ādicco.🔽Tattha ivaṇṇalope ‘tavaggavaraṇānaṃ ye cavaggabayañā’ti yamhi pare tavaggassa cavaggattaṃ, puna ‘vaggalasehi te’ti yassa pubbarūpattaṃ, kuṇḍaniyā apaccaṃ koṇḍañño.🔽437. Uvaṇṇassāvaṅa sare ka. 348; rū. 371; nī. 757.
analyzed: ditiyāḥ nāma deva dhītāya apaccam deccaḥ aditiyāḥ apaccam ādiccaḥ  tattha i va ṇ na lope ta vagga vara ṇānam ye ca vagga bayañā ati yamhi pare ta vaggassa ca vagga ttam puna vagga lasehi ta iti yassa  u va ṇ as āvaṅa sare ka rū nī
translated: The moon is the son of Diti, the sun is the son of Aditi.

original: Sare pare uvaṇṇassa avaṅa hotīti uvaṇṇassa avattaṃ. ‘Tavaggavaraṇāna…’nti suttena vassa battaṃ, puna ‘vaggalasehi te’ti suttena yassa pubbarūpattaṃ, bhātuno apaccaṃ bhātabyo.
analyzed: sare pare u vaṇṇassa hoti iti u vaṇṇassa avattam suttena vassa battam puna vagga lasehi te ti suttena yassa
translated: Herein, in the elision of the vowel, in the words tavaggavaraṇānaṃ ye cavaggabayañā, the syllable ta of tavaggassa becomes the syllable ca of cavaggattaṃ, and again in the words vaggalasehi te, the syllable ta of yassa becomes the syllable ya of pubbarūpattaṃ. Koṇḍañño is the son of Kuṇḍanī.🔽In the word avagga, the vowel of the first syllable is elided.

original: 438. Ā ṇi ka. 347; rū. 368; nī. 756; caṃ. 2.4.19; pā. 4.1.95.🔽Rassā’kārantato apaccatthe ṇānubandho rassi’paccayo hoti vā.
analyzed: ā ṇi ka rū nī cam pā 🔽rassa ākāra antataḥ a paccatthe ṇa anubandhaḥ rassi paccayaḥ hoti vā
translated: In the word batta, the vowel of the first syllable is elided. In the word bhātabyo, the vowel of the first syllable is elided.

original: Dakkhassa apaccaṃ dakkhi. Evaṃ doṇi, vāsavi, sakyaputti, nāṭaputti, dāsaputti, dāruno
analyzed: dakkhassa apaccam dakkhi evam doṇi vāsavi sakyaputti nāṭaputti dāsaputti dāruno
translated: Dakkhassa apaccaṃ dakkhi. Thus: Doṇi, Vāsavi, Sakyaputti, Nāṭaputti, Dāsaputti, Dāruno

original: apaccaṃ dāravi vicāretabbamidaṃ, varuṇassa apaccaṃ vāruṇi. Evaṃ kaṇḍi, bāladevi,
analyzed: apaccam dāravi vicāretabbam idam varuṇassa apaccam vāruṇi evam kaṇḍi bāla devi
translated: apaccaṃ Dāravi. Vicāretabbamidaṃ, Varuṇassa apaccaṃ Vāruṇi. Thus: Kaṇḍi, Bāladevi,

original: pāvaki, jinadattassa apaccaṃ jenadatti, suddhodani, anuruddhi iccādi.
analyzed: pāvaki jinadattassa apaccam jenadatti suddhodani anuruddhi iccādi
translated: Pāvaki, Jinadattassa apaccaṃ Jenadatti, Suddhodani, Anuruddhi, etc.

original: 439. Rājato ño jātiyaṃ ka. 347; rū. 368; nī. 756; caṃ. 2.4.70; pā. 4.1.137.
analyzed: rājataḥ ñaḥ jāti yam ka rū nī cam pā
translated: . From rāja, ñ from jātiyaṃ ka. ; rū. ; nī. ; caṃ. ..; pā. ...

original: Jātiyaṃ gamyamānāyaṃ rājasaddamhā apaccatthe ñapaccayo hoti vā.
analyzed: jātiyam gamyamānāyam rāja saddamhā a paccatthe ña paccayaḥ hoti vā
translated: When jātiyaṃ is being said, ñapaccayo is from rāja, the word for apaccaṃ, is or is not.

original: Rañño apaccaṃ rājañño, rājakulassa puttoti attho.
analyzed: raññaḥ apaccam rājaññaḥ rāja kulassa putto ti attho
translated: Rājassa apaccaṃ Rājañño, the son of the royal family, is the meaning.

original: Jātiyanti kiṃ? Rājaputto.
analyzed: jātiyanti kim rāja putto
translated: What in jātiyaṃ? Rājaputto.

analyzed: khattā yiyā ka rū nī caṃ pā
translated: . Khatta, ya, iy from ka. ; rū. ; nī. ; caṃ. ..; pā. ...

original: Jātiyaṃ gamyamānāyaṃ khattasaddamhā apaccatthe ya, iyapaccayā honti.
analyzed: jātiyam gamyamānā iyam khatta saddamhā a paccatthe yaḥ iya paccayāḥ honti
translated: When jātiyaṃ is being said, ya, iyapaccayo is from khatta, the word for apaccaṃ.

original: Khattakulassa apaccaṃ khatyo, khattiyo.
analyzed: khatta kulassa apaccam khatyaḥ khattiyaḥ
translated: Khattakulassa apaccaṃ Khatto, Khattiyo.

original: Jātiyantveva? Khatti.
analyzed: jātiyantu eva
translated: But only in jātiyaṃ? Khatti.🔽. Manuta, ssasaṇa from ka. ; rū. ; nī. ; caṃ. .., ; pā. ...

analyzed: manu taḥ ssasaṇa ka rū nī cam   pā

original: Jātiyaṃ gamyamānāyaṃ manusaddamhā apaccatthe ssa, saṇapaccayā honti.
analyzed: jātiyam gamyamānā iyam manu saddamhā a paccatthe ssa saṇa paccayāḥ honti
translated: When the affix -u is added to the words manu, apaccaṃ, and saṇapaccaṃ, the following forms are obtained:

original: Manuno apaccaṃ manusso, mānuso, manu nāma kappe ādikhattiyo mahāsammatarājā, itthiyaṃ manussī, mānusī,
analyzed: manunaḥ apaccam manussaḥ mānusaḥ manu nāma kappe ādikhattiyaḥ mahāsammata rājā itthiyam manussī mānusī
translated: Manuno apaccaṃ is manussaṃ, mānusaṃ, manu is the name of the first king of the world, Mahāsammata, itthiyaṃ is manussī, mānusī.

original: Jātiyantveva? Māṇavo.🔽442. Janapadanāmasmā janakhattiyā raññe ca ṇo ka. 352; rū. 376; nī. 765; caṃ. 2.4.96; pā. 4.1.168; “janapadanāmasmā khattiyā…” (bahūsu).
analyzed: jātiyantu eva māṇavaḥ  janapada nāmasmā jana khattiyāḥ raññe ca ṇo ka rū nī caṃ pā janapada nāmasmā khattiyāḥ bahūsu
translated: But only in the feminine? Māṇavo.🔽From the name of a country and from khattiya, ṇo is added to the words for king and apaccaṃ.

original: Janavācinā ca khattiyavācinā ca janapadanāmamhā raññe ca apacce ca ṇo hoti.
analyzed: jana vācinā ca khattiya vācinā ca janapada nāmamhā raññe ca a pacce ca ṇaḥ hoti
translated: From the words for a country and from the words for a khattiya, ṇo is added to the words for king and apaccaṃ.

original: Pañcālānaṃ janānaṃ rājā pañcālo, pañcālassa khattiyassa apaccaṃ pañcālo. Evaṃ kosalo, māgadho, okkāko dī. ni. 1.267.
analyzed: pañcālānam janānam rājā pañcālaḥ pañcālassa khattiyassa apaccam pañcālaḥ evam kosalaḥ māgadhaḥ okkākaḥ
translated: The king of the people of Pañcāla is Pañcāla, apaccaṃ of the khattiya Pañcāla is Pañcāla. So too, Kosala, Māgadha, Okkāka.

original: Janapadanāmasmāti kiṃ? Dasaratharañño putto dāsarathi dāsaraṭṭhi.
analyzed: janapada nāmasma ati kim dasa ratha rañño putto dāsa rathi dāsa raṭṭhi
translated: What is the purpose of the words janapadanāmasmā? The son of King Dasaratha is Dāsaraṭṭhi, Dāsaraṭṭhi.

original: Janakhattiyāti kiṃ? Pañcālassa brāhmaṇassa apaccaṃ pañcāli.🔽443. Ṇya kurusivīhi ka. 346; rū. 367; nī. 755; caṃ. 2.4.101 …pe… 4.1.172.
analyzed: jana khattiyā ati kim pañcālassa brāhmaṇassa apaccam pañcāli 🔽
translated: What is the purpose of the words janakhattiya? Apaccaṃ of the brāhmaṇa Pañcāla is Pañcāli.

original: Kuru, sivisaddehi apacce raññe ca ṇyo hoti.
analyzed: kuru sivi saddehi a pacce raññe ca ṇyaḥ hoti
translated: The affix ṇyo is added to the names of kings when the meaning of “country” is intended.

original: Kururañño apaccaṃ korabyo jā. 1.14.228, 232, 236, kururaṭṭhavāsīnaṃ rājā korabyo, korabbo, pubbarūpattaṃ, sivirañño apaccaṃ sebyo, siviraṭṭhavāsīnaṃ rājā sebyo.
analyzed: kururaññaḥ apaccam korabyaḥ jā kururaṭṭha vāsīnam rājā korabyaḥ korabbo pubbarūpattam siviraññaḥ apaccam sebyo siviraṭṭha vāsīnam rājā sebyaḥ
translated: The country of King Kuru is Korabhya, Korabhya is the name of the country of the inhabitants of Kuru, the country of Kuru. The country of King Sivi is Seyyha, Seyyha is the name of the country of the inhabitants of Sivi, the country of Sivi.

original: Apaccarāsi niṭṭhito.
analyzed: a paccarāsi niṭṭhitaḥ
translated: The section on apacca is finished.

original: Anekattharāsi
analyzed: anekattharā asi
translated: The section on many kinds of words

original: 444. Ṇa rāgā tena rattaṃ ka. 347; rū. 368; nī. 756; caṃ. 3.1.1 …pe… 4.2.1.
analyzed: rattam ka rū nī cam pe
translated: . Ṇo is added to the words for dyes when the meaning of “dyed” is intended: ka. ; rū. ; nī. ; caṃ. .. …pe… ...

original: Rajjanti vatthaṃ etenāti rāgo, rajanavatthu, rāgavācimhā tena rattanti atthe ṇo hoti.
analyzed: rajjanti vattham etena ati rāgaḥ rajana vatthu rāga vācimhā tena atthe ṇo hoti
translated: The word for a dye is a word for a substance that dyes. The meaning is “dyed with that.”

original: Kasāvena rattaṃ vatthaṃ kāsāvaṃ dha. pa. 9, kāsāyaṃ vā. Evaṃ kosumbhaṃ, haliddiyā rattaṃ hāliddaṃ, pāṭaṅgena rattaṃ pāṭaṅgaṃ, mañjiṭṭhaṃ, kuṅkumaṃ iccādi.
analyzed: kasāvena rattam vattham kāsāvam kāsāyam vā evam kosumbham haliddiyā rattam hāliddam pāṭaṅgena rattam pāṭaṅgam mañjiṭṭham kuṅkumam iccādi
translated: Cloth dyed with kasāva is kasāva, kasāva. Or it is kasāvaṃ. In the same way, kosumbhaṃ, haliddiyaṃ, pāṭaṅgaṃ, mañjiṭṭhaṃ, kuṅkumaṃ.

original: “Nīlaṃ vatthaṃ, pītaṃ vattha”ntiādīsu pana nīla, pītādisaddā guṇasaddattā paccayena vinā guṇanissayaṃ dabbaṃ vadanti. Evaṃ sabbesu guṇasadda, jātisadda, nāmasaddesu.
analyzed: nīlam vattham pītam vatthanti ādīsu pana nīla pīta ādi saddāḥ guṇa sadda ttā paccayena vinā guṇa nissayam dabbam vadanti evam sabbesu guṇa sadda jāti sadda nāma saddesu
translated: But in the words nīlaṃ vatthaṃ, pītaṃ vatthaṃ, the words nīla, pīta, etc., are words for qualities. Therefore, without a preposition, they are allowed to have a noun as their base. In the same way, in all words for qualities, words for kinds, and words for names.

original: 445. Nakkhatteninduyuttena kāle ka. 352; rū. 376; nī. 765; caṃ. 3.1.5; pā. 4.2.3.
analyzed: nakkhattena indu yuttena kāle ka rū nī caṃ pā
translated: At the time marked by the moon’s mansion, by the lunar mansion.

original: Induyuttena nakkhattena lakkhite kāle tannakkhattavācīhi ṇo hoti.
analyzed: indu yuttena nakkhattena lakkhite kāle tad nakkhatta vācīhi ṇo hoti
translated: The locative case ending is added to the name of the lunar mansion that marks the time.

original: Puṇṇacandayuttena phussanakkhattena lakkhitā phussā, ratti, phusso, aho. Evaṃ māgho iccādi.
analyzed: puṇṇa canda yuttena phussa nakkhattena lakkhitā phussā ratti phussaḥ aho evam māghaḥ iccādi
translated: The night marked by the full moon’s mansion is Phussa, the night is Phussa, the day is Phussa. So too with Magha, etc.

original: Nakkhattenāti kiṃ? Garugahena lakkhitā ratti.🔽Induyuttenāti kiṃ? Phussena lakkhito muhutto.
analyzed: nakkhattena ati kim garu gahena lakkhitā ratti  indu yuttena ati kim phussena lakkhitaḥ muhuttaḥ
translated: What is the meaning of the word nakkhattaṃ ? The night marked by Garuhas is Garuhas.🔽What is the meaning of the word indūyuṃ ? The moment marked by Phussa is Phussa.

original: Kāleti kiṃ? Phussena lakkhitā atthasiddhi.🔽446. Sāssa devatā puṇṇamāsī ka. 352; rū. 376; nī. 765; caṃ. 3.1.18, 19 …pe… 4.2.21-24.
analyzed: kāla iti kim phussena lakkhitā attha siddhi  sā assa devatā puṇṇamāsī ka rū nī caṃ  pe
translated: What is the meaning of the word kāle ? The success marked by Phussa is Phussa.🔽That is his deity, the full moon.

original: Sā assa devatā, sā assa puṇṇamāsīti atthe paṭhamantā ṇo hoti.
analyzed: sā assa devatā sā assa puṇṇamāsī iti atthe paṭhama antā ṇo hoti
translated: The locative case ending is added to the name of the deity that is his, that is his full moon.

original: Buddho assa devatāti buddho, yo buddhaṃ attano ārakkhadevataṃ viya garuṃ katvā vicarati,
analyzed: buddhaḥ assa devatā iti buddhaḥ yaḥ buddham attanaḥ ārakkha devatam viya garum katvā vicarati
translated: He who goes about regarding the Enlightened One as his deity, as his protector,🔽or who constantly utters the word “Enlightened One,” “Enlightened One,”

original: nirantaraṃ vā “buddho buddho”ti vācaṃ nicchāreti, tassetaṃ nāmaṃ. Sugato assa devatāti
analyzed: nirantaram vā buddhaḥ buddha uti vācam tassa etam nāmam sugataḥ assa devatā iti
translated: has that name.

original: sogato, mahindadevo assa devatāti māhindo. Evaṃ yāmo, somo, vāruṇo.
analyzed: so gataḥ mahinda devaḥ assa devatāti māhindaḥ evam yāmaḥ somaḥ vāruṇaḥ
translated: and so on. The god of the Yāma heaven is Yāma, the god of the Soma heaven is Soma, the god of the Varuṇa heaven is Varuṇa.

original: Phussī assa puṇṇamāsīti phusso, māso. Evaṃ māgho, phagguno, citto, vesākho, jeṭṭhamūlo, āsaḷho, sāvaṇo, poṭṭhapādo, assayujo, kattiko, māgasiro.
analyzed: phussī assa puṇṇamāsī iti phussaḥ māsaḥ evam māghaḥ phaggunaḥ cittaḥ vesākhaḥ jeṭṭhamūlaḥ āsaḷhaḥ sāvaṇaḥ poṭṭhapādaḥ assayujaḥ kattikaḥ māgasiraḥ
translated: The full-moon day of the lunar month of Phussa is Phussa, the lunar month. So too, Māgha, Phālguna, Citta, Vesākha, Jeṭṭha, Āsāḷha, Sāvana, Pausa, Māgasira, and Kattika.

original: Puṇṇamāsīti kiṃ? Phussī assa pañcamī tithī.
analyzed: puṇṇamāsī iti kim phussī assa pañcamī tithī
translated: What is the full-moon day? The fifth day of the lunar month of Phussa is Phussa.

original: 447. Tamadhīte taṃ jānāti kaṇikā ca ka. 351; rū. 374; nī. 764; caṃ. 3.1.37 …pe… 4.2.59.
analyzed: tam adhīte tam jānāti kaṇikā ca ka rū nī caṃ pe
translated: When he has learnt it, he knows it. And kaṇikā and ka. ; rū. ; nī. ; caṃ. .. …pe… ...

original: Etesu atthesu dutiyantā ṇo ca ko ca ṇiko cāti ete paccayā honti.
analyzed: etesu atthesu dutiya antā ṇo ca ko ca ṇi ko ca ati ete paccayāḥ honti
translated: In these meanings, the suffixes ṇo, ko, and ṇiko are the formations.

original: Ṇamhi – byākaraṇaṃ adhīte jānāti vā veyyākaraṇo dī. ni. 1.256. Pakkhe “veyyākaraṇiko, byañjanaṃ adhīte jānāti vā veyyañjaniko”ti imāni ṇikena sijjhanti.
