analyzed: tam assa parimāṇanti atthe paṭhamantā ṇikaḥ hoti kaḥ ca parimīyate anena ati parimāṇam  doṇo parimāṇam assa ati doṇikaḥ evam khārikaḥ kumbhikaḥ asīti vassāni parimāṇam assa ati
translated: The measure of that is, in the sense of “the measure of that is,” the first is ṇiko and ko. It is measured by this, thus it is a measure .🔽The measure of that is a doṇa, thus it is a doṇika. So too a khārika, a kumbhika, the measure of that is eighty years, thus

original: āsītiko, vayo. Evaṃ nāvutiko, upaḍḍhakāyo parimāṇamassāti upaḍḍhakāyikaṃ, bimbohanaṃ,
analyzed: āsītikaḥ vayaḥ evam nāvutikaḥ upaḍḍha kāyo parimāṇam assa ati upaḍḍhakāyikam bimbohanam
translated: it is an āsītika, an age. So too a nāvutika, the measure of that is half a body, thus it is a upaḍḍhakāyika, a bimbohana,

original: dve parimāṇamassāti dukaṃ. Evaṃ tikaṃ, catukkaṃ, pañcakaṃ, chakkaṃ, dvittaṃ. Dasakaṃ, satakaṃ.
analyzed: dve parimāṇam assa ati dukam evam tikam catukkam pañcakam chakkam dvittam dasakam satakam
translated: Two, measure, and so on: the dyad. Thus the triad, the tetrad, the pentad, the hexad, the dyad, the decade, the century.

original: 496. Yatetehi ttako ka. 391; rū. 423; nī. 830; pā. 5.1.22, 23
analyzed: yat e t e hi ka ru nī pā
translated: . These are the ttaka, the rū, the nī, the pā.

original: Tamassa parimāṇanti atthe ya, ta, etasaddehi sadisadvibhūto ttako hoti.
analyzed: tamassa parimāṇa nti atthe ya te eta saddehi sadisa dvi bhūtaḥ ttakaḥ hoti
translated: . In the sense of ‘that measure of it’ the ttaka is like the ya, the ta, the etasaddehi.

original: Yaṃ parimāṇamassāti yattakaṃ. Evaṃ tattakaṃ.
analyzed: yam yattakam evam tattakam
translated: . As much as is the measure of it is yattakaṃ. Thus tattakaṃ.🔽. In the ttake the etasaddehi the eṭa is like the rū, the nī.

original: 497. Etasseṭa ttake ka. 404; rū. 370; nī. 859.
analyzed: e tassa iṭa ttake ka rū nī
translated: . In the ttake the etasaddehi the eṭa is like the rū, the nī.

original: Ttake pare etasaddassa eṭa hoti.
analyzed: ttake pare eta saddassa e ṭa hoti
translated: . In the sense of ‘that measure of it’ the ettaka is like the etassa dvittaṃ.

original: Etaṃ parimāṇamassāti ettakaṃ, yāva parimāṇamassāti yāvattakaṃ. Evaṃ tāvattakaṃ, etāvattakaṃ. ‘Yatetehī’ti vacanena yāva, tāva, etāvāpi gayhanti.
analyzed: etam parimāṇam assa ati ettakam yāva parimāṇam assa ati yāvattakam evam tāvattakam etāvattakam vacanena yāva tāva etāva api gayhanti
translated: . As much as is the measure of it is yāvattakaṃ. Thus tāvattakaṃ, etāvattakaṃ. By the words ‘yatetehī’ also yāva, tāva, etāvā are included.

original: 498. Sabbā ca ṭāvantu ka. 391; rū. 423; nī. 830; caṃ. 4.2.43; pā. 5.2.39; ‘sabbā cacavantu’ (bahūsu).
analyzed: sabbā ca ṭāvantu ka rū nī caṃ pā sabbā bahūsu
translated: . And all the ṭāvantu are like the rū, the nī, the caṃ, the pā.🔽. In the sense of ‘that measure of it’ the ṭāvantu is like the ya, the te, the sabbato.

original: Tamassa parimāṇanti atthe ya, te’tehi ca sabbato ca ṭāvantu hoti, etassa dvittaṃ.
analyzed: tamassa parimāṇa nti atthe ya te tehi ca sabbatas ca hoti etassa dvittam
translated: . The etassa dvittaṃ is like the sabbato.

original: Sabbaṃ parimāṇaṃ assāti sabbāvantaṃ, sabbāvā, attho, sabbāvanto, sabbāvantā, atthā,🔽sabbāvati, atthe, sabbāvantesu, atthesu, itthiyaṃ sabbāvatī, sabbāvantī, parisā.🔽Evaṃ yāvā, yāvantā, yāvanto, tāvā, tāvantā, tāvanto, ettāvā, ettāvantā, ettāvanto iccādi.🔽Kvaci mahāvuttinā ekassa ta-kārassa lopo, yāvatako kāyo, tāvatako byāmo dī. ni. 3.200, yāvatikā yānassa bhūmi.
analyzed: sabbam parimāṇam assa ati sabbāvantam sabbāvā attho sabbāvanto sabbāvantā atthā  sabbāvati atthe sabbāvantesu atthesu itthiyam sabbāvatī sabbāvantī parisā  evam yāvāḥ yāvantā yāvantaḥ tāvā tāvantā tāvantaḥ ettāvāḥ ettāvantaḥ ettāvantaḥ iccādi  kvaci mahāvuttinā ekassa takārassa lopaḥ yāvatakaḥ kāyaḥ tāvatakaḥ byāmaḥ dī ni yāvatikā yānassa bhūmi
translated: All is sabbāvantaṃ, sabbāvā, attho, sabbāvanto, sabbāvantā, atthā,🔽sabbāvati, atthe, sabbāvantesu, atthesu, in the feminine sabbāvatī, sabbāvantī, a company.🔽So yāvā, yāvantā, yāvanto, tāvā, tāvantā, tāvanto, ettāvā, ettāvantā, ettāvanto, etc.🔽In some instances the ta- of the singular is dropped by the great-usage, yāvatako kāyo, tāvatako byāmo, D. iii, 200, yāvatikā yānassa bhūmi.

original: 499. Kiṃmhā rati rīva rīvataka rittakā ka. 391; rū. 423; nī. 830; caṃ. 4.2.45; pā. 5.2.41.🔽Taṃ assa parimāṇanti atthe kiṃsaddato ete cattāro paccayā bhavanti.🔽500. Rānubandhentasarādissa ka. 539; rū. 558; nī. 1124.🔽Rānubandhe paccaye pare padantasarādissa lopo hoti. Ādisaddena padantabyañjanaṃ gayhati, suttavibhattena rīvantu, rittāvantupaccayā ca honti.
analyzed: rati rīva rīvataka rittakā ka  rū nī caṃ pā 🔽tam assa parimāṇanti atthe kiṃsaddato ete cattāro paccayāḥ bhavanti 🔽ra anubandha inta sa ra ādissa ka rū nī 🔽ra anubandhe paccaye pare pada anta sara ādissa lopaḥ hoti ādi saddena pada anta byañjanam gayhati sutta vibhattena ca honti
translated: All is the whole, the entire, the total, the totality, the whole of, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them, the whole of it, the whole of them

original: Kiṃ parimāṇamassāti kati. Pañcakkhandhā kati kusalā, kati akusalā vibha. 151, kativassosi
analyzed: kim parimāṇam assa ati kati pañca kkhandhā kati kusalā kati akusalā vibha kati vassā asi
translated: How much is it? How many? Five categories. How many are profitable? How many unprofitable? How many?

original: tvaṃ bhikkhu, ekavasso ahaṃ bhagavā mahāva. 78, kiṃ parimāṇaṃ assāti kīvaṃ, kiṃva
analyzed: tvam bhikkhu eka vassaḥ aham bhagavā mahāva kim parimāṇam assa ati kīvam kiṃva
translated: How many years old are you? I am a year older than you, Blessed One.

original: dūro ito gāmo. Evaṃ kīvatakaṃ, kittakaṃ.🔽Rīvantumhi – kīvanto hontu yācakā jā. 2.20.103 ti.
analyzed: dūraḥ itas gāmaḥ evam kīvatakam kittakam  rīvantumhi kīvantaḥ hontu yācakāḥ ti
translated: How much is it? How many? How much is this village from here? So much, so many.🔽In the sense of being measured: How many beggars are there?

original: Rittāvantumhi – kittāvatā khandhānaṃ khandhapaññatti saṃ. ni. 3.82, kittāvatā nu kho bhante rūpanti vuccati, kittāvatā nu kho bhante māroti vuccati saṃ. ni. 3.161.🔽Pubbasuttena ṭāvantumhi – ettāvatā khandhānaṃ khandhapaññatti, ettāvatā rūpanti vuccati, ettāvatā māroti vuccati.
analyzed: kittāvatā khandhānam khandha paññatti sam ni kittāvatā nu kho bhante rūpan ti vuccati kittāvatā nu kho bhante māro ti vuccati sam ni  pubba suttena ettāvatā khandhānam khandha paññatti ettāvatā rūpan ti vuccati ettāvatā māro ti vuccati
translated: In the sense of being measured out: To what extent is there a description of the categories as categories? To what extent is there said to be materiality? To what extent is there said to be mind?

analyzed: māne matto ka rū nī cam pā
translated: In the sense of being measured by the preceding statement: To this extent there is a description of the categories as categories; to this extent is there said to be materiality; to this extent is there said to be mind.🔽In the sense of being measured by conceit: Materiality, mind, perception, formations, consciousness.

original: Mīyate etenāti mānaṃ, taṃ ummānaṃ, parimāṇanti duvidhaṃ, uddhaṃ mānaṃ ummānaṃ, tadaññaṃ
analyzed: mīyate etena ati mānam tam ummānam parimāṇanti duvidham uddham mānam ummānam tad aññam
translated: It is measured by this, thus it is conceit . That is of two kinds: conceit and over-conceit .

original: mānaṃ parimāṇaṃ, imasmiṃ sutte pana sāmaññavacanattā duvidhampi labbhati, duvidhe🔽māne pavattā hatthādisaddamhā tamassa parimāṇanti atthe mattapaccayo hoti.
analyzed: mānam parimāṇam imasmin sutte pana sāmañña vacana ttā duvidham pi labbhati duvidhe  māne pavattā hattha ādi saddamhā tamassa parimāṇam ti atthe matta paccayaḥ hoti
translated: and measure is a quantity. But in this sutta both are allowable because of the word samāna.🔽The indeclinable matta is a measure-indeclinable in the sense of a quantity of the measure of a hand, etc., in the case of the two kinds of conceit that occur in the passage: “Conceit, monks, is born in the foolish, the incompetent, the unlearned, the uncultured, when there is a quantity of the measure of a hand, a span, a cubit, a fathom, a league, a yojana, a grain, a kulla, a gāma, a nigama, a country, a world, a world system, a world sphere, a world ocean, a world net, a world’s extent, a world’s measure, a world’s bound, a world’s end, a world’s extent and measure, a world’s extent and bound, a world’s extent and end, a world’s measure and bound, a world’s measure and end, a world’s bound and end, a world’s extent, measure, bound and end. ”

original: Hattho parimāṇaṃ assāti hatthamattaṃ, dve hatthā parimāṇaṃ assāti dvihatthamattaṃ,🔽dve aṅguliyo parimāṇaṃ assāti dvaṅgulamattaṃ. Evaṃ caturaṅgulamattaṃ, vidatthimattaṃ,
analyzed: hatthaḥ parimāṇam assa ati hattha mattam dve hatthā parimāṇam assa ati dvi hattha mattam  dve aṅguliyaḥ parimāṇam assa ati dvi aṅgula mattam evam catur aṅgula mattam vidatthi mattam
translated: Hand is a measure, thus it is a hand’s measure . Two hands are a measure, thus it is two hands’ measure .

original: yojanamattaṃ, tīṇi yojanāni parimāṇaṃ assāti tiyojanamattaṃ, nāḷimattaṃ, patthamattaṃ,
analyzed: yojana mattam tīṇi yojanāni parimāṇam assa ati ti yojana mattam nāḷi mattam pattha mattam
translated: Two fingers are a measure, thus it is two fingers’ measure . So too, four fingers’ measure , a span’s measure , a league’s measure , three leagues’ measure , a bamboo’s measure , a leaf’s measure ,

original: doṇamattaṃ, palaṃ vuccati ummānasaṅkhāto pātiviseso, palaṃ parimāṇaṃ assāti palamattaṃ,
analyzed: doṇa mattam palam vuccati ummāna saṅkhāto pātivisesaḥ palam parimāṇam assa ati pala mattam
translated: a bushel’s measure , a pala is a measure of weight called an umma , thus it is a pala’s measure .

original: pañcamattaṃ, pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi saddhiṃ pārā. 1, tiṃsamattaṃ, saṭṭhimattaṃ,
analyzed: pañcamattam pañcamattehi bhikkhu satehi saddhim pārā tiṃsamattam saṭṭhimattam
translated: Five is a measure, thus it is five’s measure . Together with five hundred monks, together with thirty’s measure , together with sixty’s measure ,

original: satamattaṃ, sahassamattaṃ, koṭimattaṃ, kumbhamattaṃ, cāṭimattaṃ, hatthimattaṃ, pabbatamattaṃ iccādi.
analyzed: sata mattam sahassa mattam koṭi mattam kumbha mattam cāṭi mattam hatthi mattam pabbata mattam iccādi
translated: together with a hundred’s measure , together with a thousand’s measure , together with a koṭṭha’s measure , together with a cāṭa’s measure , together with an elephant’s measure , together with a mountain’s measure , and so on.

original: ‘Mattā’ti vā parimāṇavācisaddantaraṃ, hattho mattā etassāti hatthamattaṃ. Evaṃ dvihatthamattaṃ,
analyzed: mattā ati vā parimāṇa vāci sadda antaram hatthaḥ mattā etassa ati hattha mattam evam dvi hattha mattam
translated: ‘Matta’ is a synonym for ‘parimāṇa’ (measure). ‘Hatthamatta’ means ‘having the measure of a hand’. Thus ‘dvihatthamatta’ (two hands’ measure).

original: iccādinā samāsopi yujjati. Abhedūpacārena pana hatthaparimāṇaṃ hatthoti katvā “dvihatthaṃ
analyzed: iccādinā samāsaḥ api yujjati abheda upacārena pana hattha parimāṇam hattha uti katvā dvi hattham
translated: In this way, the compound is also appropriate. But by the usage of non-differentiation, having made the measure of the hand ‘hand’, ‘dvihattha’ (two hands)

original: vatthaṃ, doṇo vīhi, doṇo māso”ti sijjhati.
analyzed: vattham doṇaḥ vīhi doṇaḥ māso ti sijjhati
translated: is established. ‘Vattha’ (cloth), ‘doṇa’ (a measure), ‘vīhi’ (rice), ‘doṇa’ (a measure), ‘māsa’ (month).

original: 502. Taggho cuddhaṃ ka. 328; rū. 352; nī. 708; caṃ. 4.2.39; pā. 5.2.37.
analyzed: taggho cuddham ka rū nī cam pā
translated: Taggha, cuddhaṃ, ka. ; rū. ; nī. ; caṃ. ..; pā. ...

original: Uddhaṃmāne pavattā saddā tamassa parimāṇanti atthe tagghapaccayo hoti matto ca.
analyzed: pavattā saddā tamassa atthe taggha paccayaḥ hoti matto ca
translated: The word ‘taggha’ is a particle used in the sense of ‘measure’ in the expression of a measure above. And ‘matta’.

original: Jaṇṇu parimāṇamassāti jaṇṇutagghaṃ, jaṇṇumattaṃ.🔽503. Ṇo ca purisā ka. 352; rū. 376; nī. 765; caṃ. 4.2.40 …pe… 5.2.38.
analyzed: jaṇṇu parimāṇam assa ati jaṇṇu taggham jaṇṇu mattam  ṇaḥ ca purisā ka rū nī cam pe
translated: ‘Jaṇṇutaggha’ means ‘having the measure of a knee’. ‘Jaṇṇumatta’.🔽. Ṇo ca purisā ka. ; rū. ; nī. ; caṃ. .. …pe… ...

original: Uddhaṃmāne pavattā purisamhā ṇo ca hoti taggho ca matto ca.
analyzed: pavattā purisamhā ṇo ca hoti ca matto ca
translated: The word ‘purisa’ is used in the sense of ‘measure’ in the expression of a measure above. And ‘ṇo’ is used. And ‘taggha’ is used. And ‘matta’.

original: Catuhattho puriso parimāṇamassāti porisaṃ, tiporisaṃ, sataporisaṃ, gambhīraṃ. Evaṃ
analyzed: catu hatthaḥ puriso parimāṇam assa ati porisam ti porisam sata porisam gambhīram evam
translated: ‘Porisa’ means ‘having the measure of a man’. ‘Tiporisa’ (three men’s measure), ‘sataporisa’ (six men’s measure), ‘gambhīra’ (deep). In this way,

original: purisatagghaṃ, purisamattaṃ, uddhaṃ pasāritahatthena saddhiṃ pañcahatthaṃ purisapamāṇaṃ
analyzed: purisa taggham purisa mattam uddham pasārita hatthena saddhim pañca hattham purisa pamāṇam
translated: ‘porisataggha’ (men’s measure), ‘porisamatta’ (men’s measure), ‘purisapamāṇa’ (men’s measure), five hands together with a hand stretched upwards.

original: porisanti vadanti, “ekūnatīso vayasā”ti dī. ni. 2.214 (ekūnatiṃso) ettha ekūnatīsa
analyzed: vadanti ekūnatīsaḥ vayasāti ekūnatiṃsaḥ ettha ekūnatīsa
translated: Herein, the measure of life is nineteen years, thus he is nineteen.

original: vassāni āyuparimāṇaṃ assāti ekūnatīso. Evaṃ vīso, tīso, cattālīso, paññāso, sahasso
analyzed: vassāni āyu parimāṇam ekūnatīsaḥ evam vīsaḥ tīsaḥ cattālīsaḥ paññāsaḥ sahasso
translated: Thus twenty, thirty, forty, fifty,

original: brahmā, dvisahasso brahmā, dasasahasso brahmā. Ettha ca “sahassaparimāṇaṃ cakkavāḷaṃ
analyzed: brahmā dvi sahassaḥ brahmā dasa sahassaḥ brahmā ettha ca sahassa parimāṇam cakkavāḷam
translated: Brahmā, Dvisahassabrahmā, Dasasahassabrahmā. And here the measure of a world-system is a thousand,

original: assāti sahasso”-iccādinā ṇapaccayena sijjhati.
analyzed: assa ati sahassa u iti ca ādinā ṇa paccayena sijjhati
translated: thus he is a Sahasso, and so on, is made by the affix ṇapaccaya.

original: Parimāṇarāsi niṭṭhito.
analyzed: parimāṇa rāsi niṭṭhito
translated: The section on measure is finished.

original: Saṅkhyārāsi
analyzed: saṅkhyā rāj asi
translated: The section on number🔽. One, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten,🔽eleven, twelve, thirteen, fourteen, fifteen, sixteen,🔽seventeen, eighteen, nineteen, twenty, thirty, forty,

original: 504. Ekā kākyasahāye ka. 391; rū. 423; nī. 835; caṃ. 4.2.67; pā. 5.3.52.
analyzed: ekā kākya sahāye ka rū nī cam pā
translated: fifty, sixty, seventy, eighty, ninety, hundred,🔽thousand, ten thousand, hundred thousand, million,🔽ten million, hundred million, billion, ten billion,🔽hundred billion, thousand billion, ten thousand billion,

original: Asahāyatthe ekamhā ka, ākī honti vā.
analyzed: a sahāya tthe ekamhā ka ākī honti vā
translated: hundred thousand billion, a hundred thousand times a hundred thousand,🔽a hundred thousand times a million, a hundred thousand times a billion,🔽a hundred thousand times ten billion, a hundred thousand times a hundred billion,

original: Asahāyo eko, ekako, ekākī, eko vā.🔽Itthiyaṃ ekikā, ekākinī, ekā vā, ‘adhātussa ke’ti suttena itthiyaṃ kamhi pare assa ittaṃ.
analyzed: asahāyaḥ ekaḥ ekakaḥ ekākī ekaḥ vā  itthiyam ekikā ekākinī ekā vā a dhātussa ka iti suttena itthiyam kamhi pare assa ittam
translated: a hundred thousand times a thousand billion, a hundred thousand times ten thousand billion,🔽a hundred thousand times a hundred thousand billion, a hundred thousand times a hundred thousand times a hundred thousand,🔽a hundred thousand times a hundred thousand times a million, a hundred thousand times a hundred thousand times a billion,🔽a hundred thousand times a hundred thousand times ten billion, a hundred thousand times a hundred thousand times a hundred billion,🔽a hundred thousand times a hundred thousand times a thousand billion, a hundred thousand times a hundred thousand times ten thousand billion,🔽a hundred thousand times a hundred thousand times a hundred thousand billion, a hundred thousand times a hundred thousand times a hundred thousand times a hundred thousand,🔽a hundred thousand times a hundred thousand times a hundred thousand times a million, a hundred thousand times a hundred thousand times a hundred thousand times a billion,

original: 505. Dviti catūhi tīyatthā ka. 385; rū. 409; nī. 817; tisatthā?.🔽Tehi tassa pūraṇanti atthe tīyo ca ttho ca honti.
analyzed: dviti catūhi tīyatthā ka rū nī tisatthā 🔽tehi tassa atthe ca ttho ca honti
translated: a hundred thousand times a hundred thousand times a hundred thousand times ten billion, a hundred thousand times a hundred thousand times a hundred thousand times a hundred billion,🔽a hundred thousand times a hundred thousand times a hundred thousand times a thousand billion, a hundred thousand times a hundred thousand times a hundred thousand times ten thousand billion,🔽a hundred thousand times

original: 506. Dvitīnaṃ dutā tīye ka. 386, 410; nī. 818; tiye?.
analyzed: dvitīnam du tā tīye ka nī tiye
translated: 506. Of two, of three, in the third.

original: Tīye pare dvi, tisaddānaṃ du, tādesā honti.
analyzed: tīye pare dvi ti saddānam du ta ādesāḥ honti
translated: In the third, of two, of three, the forms du and tāde are used.

original: Dvinnaṃ pūraṇo dutīyo chaṭṭhasaṃgīti pāṭhesu dutiyotyādinā dissanti, dvinnaṃ pūraṇī
analyzed: dvinnam pūraṇaḥ dutīyaḥ chaṭṭha saṃgī ti pāṭhesu dutiya utyādinā dissanti dvinnam pūraṇī
translated: In the reading of the sixth recitation, “of two, the filler is the second,” etc., are seen; of two, the filler

original: dutīyā, dvinnaṃ pūraṇaṃ dutīyaṃ. Evaṃ tatīyo, tatīyā, tatīyaṃ. Catunnaṃ pūraṇo catuttho,
analyzed: dutīyā dvinnam pūraṇam dutīyam evam tatīyaḥ tatīyā tatīyam catunnam pūraṇaḥ catutthaḥ
translated: is the second, of two, the filler is the second. So too, the third, the third, the third. Of four, the filler is the fourth,

original: catutthī, catutthaṃ.🔽507. Ma pañcādikatihi ka. 373; rū. 406; nī. 802; caṃ. 4.2.55; pā. 5.2.49.
analyzed: catutthī catuttham  ma pañca ādi kati hi ka rū nī caṃ pā
translated: the fourth, the fourth.🔽. Of five, etc., of how many?

original: Pañcādīhi ca katimhā ca tassa pūraṇanti atthe mo hoti.
analyzed: pañca ādīhi ca katimhā ca tassa pūraṇa nti atthe mo hoti
translated: In the sense of “the filler of five, etc., of how many,” mo is used.

original: Pañcamo, pañcamī, pañcamaṃ. Evaṃ sattama, aṭṭhama, navama, dasama, ekādasamādi. Katinnaṃ pūraṇo katimo, katimī, tithī.🔽508. Tassa pūraṇekādasādito vā ka. 374; rū. 412; nī. 805; caṃ. 4.2.51; pā. 5.2.48.
analyzed: pañcamaḥ pañcamī pañcamam evam sattama aṭṭhama navama dasama ekādasama ādi katinnam pūraṇaḥ katimaḥ katimī tithī  tassa pūraṇa ekādasa āditaḥ vā ka rū nī cam pā
translated: The fifth, the fifth, the fifth. So too, the seventh, the eighth, the ninth, the tenth, the eleventh, etc. Of how many, the filler is the how-manyth, the how-manyth, the how-manyth.🔽. Of that filler, of eleven, etc., or?🔽In the sense of “of that filler, of eleven, etc.,” the suffix ṭānubandha ap is used optionally.

original: Pūrate anenāti pūraṇaṃ, ekādasādito tassa pūraṇanti atthe ṭānubandho apaccayo hoti vā.
analyzed: pūrate anena ati pūraṇam ekādasa āditaḥ tassa pūraṇam ti atthe ṭa anubandhaḥ a paccayaḥ hoti vā
translated: . The filler is that by which there is filling.

original: Ekādasannaṃ pūraṇo ekādaso, ekādasī, ekādasaṃ, ekādasamo vā. Evaṃ dvādaso, dvādasamo,
analyzed: pūraṇaḥ ekādasaḥ ekādasī ekādasam ekādasamaḥ vai evam dvādasaḥ dvādasamaḥ
translated: So too dvādasa, dvādasī, dvādasaṃ, dvādasamo;

original: teraso, terasamo, cuddaso, cuddasamo, pañcadaso, pañcadasamo, pannaraso, pannarasamo,
analyzed: terasaḥ terasamaḥ cuddasaḥ cuddasamaḥ pañcadasaḥ pañcadasamaḥ pannarasaḥ pannarasamaḥ
translated: terasa, terasī, terasaṃ, terasamo; cuddasa, cuddasī, cuddasaṃ, cuddasamo; pañcadasa, pañcadasī, pañcadasaṃ, pañcadasamo; pannarasa, pannarasī, pannarasaṃ, pannarasamo;

original: soḷaso, soḷasamo, sattaraso, sattarasamo, aṭṭhāraso, aṭṭhārasamo.
analyzed: soḷasaḥ soḷasamaḥ sattarasaḥ sattarasamaḥ aṭṭhārasaḥ aṭṭhārasamaḥ
translated: soḷasa, soḷasī, soḷasaṃ, soḷasamo; sattarasā, sattarasī, sattarasā, sattarasamo; aṭṭhārasā, aṭṭhārasī, aṭṭhārasā, aṭṭhārasamo.

original: 509. Ṭe satissa tissa ka. 389; rū. 413; nī. 824.
analyzed: ṭe satissa tissa ka rū nī
translated: . Ṭe satissa tissa ka. ; rū. ; nī. .

original: Ṭe pare satissa ti-kārassa lopo hotīti vīsati, tīsatīnaṃ tissa lopo.
analyzed: ṭe pare satissa tikārassa lopaḥ hoti iti vīsati tīsatīnam tissa lopaḥ
translated: The ṭe and the satissa of tissa are dropped, so there are twenty. The tissa of tīsatīnaṃ is dropped.

original: Ekūnavīso, ekūnavīsatimo, vīso, vīsatimo, tīso, tīsatimo, cattālīso, cattālīsamo, paññāso, paññāsamo. Saṭṭhyādito purimasuttena mo, saṭṭhimo, sattatimo, asītimo, navutimo.
analyzed: ekūnavīsaḥ ekūnavīsatimaḥ vīsaḥ vīsatimaḥ tīsaḥ tīsatimaḥ cattālīso cattālīsamaḥ paññāsaḥ paññāsamaḥ saṭṭhi āditaḥ purima suttena mo saṭṭhimaḥ sattatimaḥ asītimaḥ navutimaḥ
translated: Ekūnavīsa, ekūnavīsatimo, vīsa, vīsatimo, tīsa, tīsatimo, cattālīsa, cattālīsamo, paññāsā, paññāsamo. The mo of saṭṭhyādito is changed to o by the preceding sutta, so there are sixty, sixty-one, seventy, eighty, ninety.

analyzed: sata ādi nami ca ka rū nī caṃ pe
translated: . Satādīnami ca ka. ; rū. ; nī. ; caṃ. .. …pe… .

original: Satādito tassa pūraṇatthe mo hoti, satādīnaṃ antassa ittañca hoti.
analyzed: sa t āditaḥ tassa pūraṇa atthe maḥ hoti sa t ādīnam antassa it tat ca hoti
translated: The mo is added to satādito for the meaning of “filled with,” and the ittañca is added to the end of satādito.

original: Satassa pūraṇo satimo, dvisatimo, tisatimo, sahassimo.
analyzed: satassa pūraṇaḥ satimaḥ dvisatimaḥ tisatimaḥ sahassimaḥ
translated: The eleventh is satimo, the twentieth is dvisatimo, the thirtieth is tisatimo, the thousandth is sahassimo.

original: 511. Chā ṭṭhaṭṭhamā ka. 384; rū. 407; nī. 803.🔽Chamhā tassa pūraṇanti atthe ṭṭha, ṭṭhamā honti.🔽Chaṭṭho, chaṭṭhī, chaṭṭhaṃ, chaṭṭhamo, chaṭṭhamī, chaṭṭhamaṃ.
analyzed: chā ṭṭhaṭṭhamā ka rū nī  chamhā tassa pūraṇanti atthe ṭṭha ṭṭhamā honti  chaṭṭhaḥ chaṭṭhī chaṭṭham chaṭṭhamaḥ chaṭṭhamī chaṭṭhamam
translated: 511. The sixth, etc.

original: 512. Saṅkhyāya saccutīsāsadasantāyādhikāsmiṃ satasahasse ṭa ka. 328; rū. 352; nī. 701; caṃ. 4.2.50 …pe… 5.2.45, 46; ‘…ḍo’ (bahūsu).🔽Sati, uti, īsa, āsa, dasantāhi saṅkhyāhi te adhikā asmiṃ satasahasseti atthe ṭānubandho apaccayo hoti.🔽Ettha ca ‘satasahasse’ti sate vā sahasse vāti attho.🔽Tattha sahassasaddena sahassaṃ dasasahassaṃ satasahassaṃ dasasatasahassañca gayhati.🔽Dasanta, satyanta, īsanta, āsanta, utyantāti evaṃ anukkamo veditabbo.🔽Tattha dasa, ekādasato paṭṭhāya yāva aṭṭhārasā navasaṅkhyā dasantā nāma.
analyzed: saṅkhyāya sat cuti isa asat asantāya adhikā asmin sata sahasse ṭa ka rū nī caṃ pe   ḍaḥ bahūsu 🔽sati uti īsaḥ āsa dasantāhi saṅkhyāhi te adhikāḥ asmin sata sahassā iti atthe ṭa anubandhaḥ a paccayaḥ hoti 🔽ettha ca sata sahassa iti sate vā sahasse vā ati attho 🔽tattha sahassa saddena sahassam dasa sahassam sata sahassam dasa sata sahassam ca gayhati 🔽evam anukkamaḥ veditabbo 🔽tattha dasa ekādasataḥ paṭṭhāya aṭṭhārasā nava saṅkhyā dasantā nāma
translated: The sixth, etc., are formed by adding ṭṭha, ṭṭhamā to cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha, cha

original: Vīsati, ekavīsatito paṭṭhāya yāva aṭṭhavīsatiyā navasaṅkhyā ca tīsati, ekatīsatito paṭṭhāya yāva aṭṭhatīsatiyā navasaṅkhyā ca satyantā nāma.
analyzed: vīsati ekavīsatitaḥ paṭṭhāya yāva aṭṭhavīsatiyā nava saṅkhyā ca tīsati ekatīsatitaḥ paṭṭhāya yāva aṭṭhatīsatiyā nava saṅkhyā ca satyantā nāma
translated: The twenty, from the one-and-twenty up to the twenty-eight, and the nine-hundreds from the twenty-nine up to the thirty-eight, are called “the end in three” .

original: Cattālīsa, ekacattālīsato paṭṭhāya yāva aṭṭhacattālīsāya navasaṅkhyā īsantā nāma.🔽Paññāsa, ekapaññāsato paṭṭhāya yāva aṭṭhapaññāsāya navasaṅkhyā āsantā nāma.🔽Navuti, ekanavutito paṭṭhāya yāva aṭṭhanavutiyā nava saṅkhyā utyantā nāma.
analyzed: cattālīsaḥ ekacattālīsato paṭṭhāya yāva aṭṭhacattālīsāya nava saṅkhyā īsantā nāma  paññāsa eka paññāsataḥ paṭṭhāya yāva aṭṭhapaññāsāya nava saṅkhyāḥ āsantāḥ nāma  navuti ekanavutitaḥ paṭṭhāya yāva aṭṭhanavutiyā nava saṅkhyā uti antā nāma
translated: The forty, from the forty-one up to the forty-eight, and the nine-hundreds from the forty-nine up to the fifty-eight, are called “the end in eight” .🔽The fifty, from the fifty-one up to the fifty-eight, and the nine-hundreds from the fifty-nine up to the sixty-eight, are called “the end in five” .🔽The ninety, from the ninety-one up to the ninety-eight, and the nine-hundreds from the ninety-nine up to the ninety-eight, are called “the end in one” .

original: Sesā ṭṭhunta, tyantāpi idha saṅgayhanti. Ṭṭhuntā nāma saṭṭhi,-ekasaṭṭhyādikā navasaṅkhyā. Tyantā nāma sattati, ekasattatyādikā navasaṅkhyā ca asīti, ekāsītyādikā navasaṅkhyā ca.
analyzed: sesāḥ ṭṭhunta tyantā api idha saṅgayhanti ṭṭhuntāḥ nāma saṭṭhi ekasaṭṭhī ādikā nava saṅkhyā tyantāḥ nāma sattati ekasattati ādikā nava saṅkhyā ca asīti ekā asīti ādikā nava saṅkhyā ca
translated: The rest, namely, the sixty, from the sixty-one up to the sixty-eight, and the nine-hundreds from the sixty-nine up to the seventy-eight, are called “the end in six” . The seventy, from the seventy-one up to the seventy-eight, and the nine-hundreds from the seventy-nine up to the eighty-eight, are called “the end in seven” . The eighty, from the eighty-one up to the eighty-eight, and the nine-hundreds from the eighty-nine up to the ninety-eight, are called “the end in eight” .

original: Dasantāsu tāva – dasa adhikā yasmiṃ sate tayidaṃ dasasataṃ. Evaṃ dasasahassaṃ, dasasatasahassaṃ,
analyzed: dasantāsu tāva dasa adhikāḥ yasmin sate tayidam dasa satam evam dasa sahassam dasa sata sahassam
translated: As to the “ends in ten” , the hundred that has ten added to it is the hundred-and-ten. So too the thousand-and-ten, the hundred-thousand-and-ten,

original: ekādasa adhikā yasmiṃ sate tayidaṃ ekādasasataṃ. Evaṃ ekādasasahassaṃ, ekādasasatasahassaṃ.
analyzed: ekādasa adhikāḥ yasmin sate tayidam ekādasa satam evam ekādasa sahassam ekādasa sata sahassam
translated: When eleven are added to a hundred, it is one thousand one hundred. So too, one thousand one hundred times one thousand one hundred is one million one hundred thousand.

original: Evaṃ dvādasasatamiccādīni.
analyzed: evam dvādasa satam id ca ādīni
translated: So too, twelve hundred, and so on.

original: Satyantāsu – ṭamhi ti-kāralopo, vīsati adhikā yasmiṃ sate tayidaṃ vīsasataṃ. Evaṃ
analyzed: sati antāsu tikāra lopaḥ vīsati adhikā yasmin sate evam
translated: In satya, satya is satya with elision of the middle syllable, and twenty is vīsati. When twenty are added to a hundred, it is two hundred. So too,

original: ekavīsasataṃ, dvāvīsasataṃ iccādi, tīsati adhikā yasmiṃ sate tayidaṃ tīsasataṃ. Evaṃ
analyzed: ekavīsasatam dvāvīsasatam iti ca ādi tīsati adhikā yasmin sate evam
translated: one hundred and twenty, two hundred and twenty, and so on. Thirty is tīsa. When thirty are added to a hundred, it is three hundred. So too,

original: ekatīsasataṃ, dvattīsasataṃ iccādi. Esa nayo sahassepi.
analyzed: ekatīsa satam dvattīsa satam iccādi e sa nayo sahasse pi
translated: one hundred and thirty, two hundred and thirty, and so on. So too, in the case of a thousand.🔽In īsa, forty is cattālīsa. When forty are added to a hundred, it is four hundred. So too,

original: Īsantāsu – cattālīsaṃ adhikā yasmiṃ sate tayidaṃ cattālīsasataṃ. Evaṃ ekacattālīsasataṃ, dvecattālīsasataṃ iccādi. Esa nayo sahassepi.
analyzed: cattālīsam adhikā yasmin sate tayidam cattālīsa satam evam eka cattālīsa satam dve cattālīsa satam iccādi esa nayaḥ sahasse pi
translated: one hundred and forty, two hundred and forty, and so on. So too, in the case of a thousand.🔽In āsa, fifty is paññāsa. When fifty are added to a hundred, it is five hundred. So too,

original: Āsantāsu – paññāsaṃ adhikā yasmiṃ sate tayidaṃ paññāsasataṃ. Evaṃ ekapaññāsasataṃ, dvepaññāsasataṃ iccādi. Esa nayo sahassepi.
analyzed: āsantāsu paññāsam adhikā yasmin sate tayidam paññāsa satam evam eka paññāsa satam dve paññāsa satam iccādi esa nayo sahasse pi
translated: one hundred and fifty, two hundred and fifty, and so on. So too, in the case of a thousand.

original: Ṭṭhuntāsu – saṭṭhi adhikā yasmiṃ sate tayidaṃ saṭṭhisataṃ. Evaṃ ekasaṭṭhisataṃ, dvāsaṭṭhisataṃ iccādi. Esa nayo sahassepi.🔽Tyantāsu – sattati adhikā, ekasattati adhikā, asīti adhikā, ekāsīti adhikā iccādinā vattabbā.
analyzed: ṭṭhu untāsu saṭṭhi adhikā yasmin sate tayidam saṭṭhi satam evam eka saṭṭhi satam dvāsaṭṭhi satam iccādi esa nayaḥ sahasse pi  ti antāsu sattati adhikā ekasattati adhikā asīti adhikā ekāsīti adhikā icca ādinā vattabbā
translated: In the case of the words ending in -ṭṭhun, the sixty is added to the hundred, thus making one hundred and sixty. So too with one hundred and sixty-two, and so on. The same method applies in the case of the words ending in -sahassa.🔽In the case of the words ending in -tyan, the seventy is added to the hundred, thus making one hundred and seventy. So too with one hundred and seventy-one, and so on.

original: Utyantāsu – navuti adhikā yasmiṃ sate tayidaṃ navutisataṃ. Evaṃ ekanavutisataṃ, dvenavutisataṃ iccādi. Esa nayo sahassepi.
analyzed: uti antāsu navuti adhikā yasmin sate tayā idam navuti satam evam eka navuti satam dve navuti satam iccādi esa nayaḥ sahasse pi
translated: In the case of the words ending in -utyan, the ninety is added to the hundred, thus making one hundred and ninety. So too with one hundred and ninety-one, and so on. The same method applies in the case of the words ending in -sahassa.

original: Atha vā dasantā nāma ekato paṭṭhāya dasasaṅkhyā.🔽Satyantā nāma ekādasato paṭṭhāya vīsasaṅkhyā.🔽Īsantā nāma ekatīsato paṭṭhāya dasasaṅkhyā.
analyzed: atha vā dasantā nāma ekatas paṭṭhāya dasa saṅkhyā  satyantāḥ nāma paṭṭhāya vīsa saṅkhyā  īsantā nāma ekatīsataḥ paṭṭhāya dasa saṅkhyā
translated: Or alternatively, the words ending in -dasa are those beginning with the number ten.🔽The words ending in -sata are those beginning with the number eleven and ending with the number twenty.🔽The words ending in -īsā are those beginning with the number twenty-one and ending with the number thirty.

original: Āsantā nāma ekacattālīsato paṭṭhāya dasasaṅkhyā.
analyzed: āsantā nāma paṭṭhāya dasa saṅkhyā
translated: The words ending in -āsā are those beginning with the number forty-one and ending with the number fifty.

original: Evaṃ ṭṭhunta, tyanta, utyantāpi veditabbā.
analyzed: evam veditabbā
translated: So too with the words ending in -ṭṭhun, -tyan, and -utyan.

original: Eko adhiko yasmiṃ sate tayidaṃ ekasataṃ, “athetthekasataṃ khatyā, anuyantā yasassino”ti
analyzed: ekaḥ adhikaḥ yasmin sate tayi idam eka satam atha itthā eka satam khatyāḥ anuyantāḥ yasassinā iti
translated: The hundred is added to the one, thus making one hundred and one. “Then a hundred and one Khattiyas, famous, followed him” .

original: jā. 2.22.594 pāḷi. “Dve adhikā yasmiṃ sate tayidaṃ dvisataṃ” iccādinā sabbaṃ vattabbaṃ,
analyzed: dve adhikā yasmin sate tayā idam dvi satam iti ādinā sabbam vattabbam
translated: All this should be stated.

original: suvicittamidaṃ vidhānanti.
analyzed: su vicittam idam
translated: This is well analysed.

original: Yathā pana “eko ca dasa ca ekādasa, ekādhikā vā dasa ekādasā”ti sijjhati, tathā idhapi
analyzed: yathā pana ca dasa ca ekādasa eka adhikāḥ vā dasa ekādasā ati sijjhati tathā idha api
translated: But just as “one and ten are eleven” and “ten plus one is eleven” are correct, so too here

original: “dasa ca satañca dasasataṃ, dasādhikaṃ vā sataṃ dasasata”ntiādinā vutte sabbaṃ taṃ
analyzed: dasa ca satam ca dasa satam dasa adhikam vā satam dasa sata iti ādinā vutte sabbam tam
translated: “ten and a hundred are one hundred and ten” and “a hundred plus ten is one hundred and ten” and so on are correct.

original: vidhānaṃ samāsavasena sijjhati.🔽Tattha pana “dve satāni dvisataṃ, tīṇi satāni tisata”miccādīni ca “dve sahassāni🔽dvisahassaṃ, tīṇi sahassāni tisahassa”miccādīni ca “dve satasahassāni dvisatasahassaṃ,
analyzed: vidhānam samāsa vasena sijjhati  tattha pana dve satāni dvisatam tīṇi satāni tisatam iccādīni ca dve sahassāni  dvi sahassam tīṇi sahassāni ti sahassam iccādīni ca dve sata sahassāni dvi sata sahassam
translated: All that rule is correct by the method of the compound.

original: tīṇi satasahassāni tisatasahassa”miccādīni ca digusamāse sijjhanti.🔽513. Vārasaṅkhyāyakkhattuṃ ka. 646; rū. 419; nī. 1282; caṃ. 4.4.5; pā. 5.4.17.
analyzed: tīṇi sata sahassāni ti sata sahassam iccādīni ca digu samāse sijjhanti
translated: But here “two hundreds are two hundred” and “three hundreds are three hundred” and so on, and “two thousands are two thousand” and “three thousands are three thousand” and so on, and “two hundred thousands are two hundred thousand” and “three hundred thousands are three hundred thousand” and so on are correct in the long compound.🔽. The number words that are related to the word for “day” are declined in the same way as the word for “day” (khattuṃ).

original: Vārasambandhibhūtā saṅkhyāsaddā kkhattuṃpaccayo hoti.
analyzed: vāra sambandhi bhūtā saṅkhyā saddā kkhattuṃpaccayaḥ hoti
translated: The number words that are related to the word for “day” take the case ending -uṃ.

original: Dve vārā dvikkhattuṃ. Evaṃ tikkhattuṃ, catukkhattuṃ, pañcakkhattuṃ, dasakkhattuṃ, satakkhattuṃ, sahassakkhattuṃ.
analyzed: dve vārā dvi kkhattum evam ti khattum catur khattum pañca khattum dasa khattum sata khattum sahassa khattum
translated: Two times is twice. Thus three times, four times, five times, ten times, a hundred times, a thousand times.

analyzed: katimhā ka rū nī cam pā
translated: How many times? How many times? Form? Blue? Yellow? Red? White?

original: Vārasambandhibhūtā katisaddā kkhattuṃ hoti. Kati vārā katikkhattuṃ.
analyzed: vāra sambandhi bhūtā kati saddā kkhattum hoti kati vārā katikkhattum
translated: The word how many times, which is related to the word time, is in the locative case. How many times?

original: 515. Bahumhā dhā ca paccāsattiyā ka. 646; rū. 419; nī. 1282; ‘paccāsattiyaṃ’ (bahūsu).🔽Vārasambandhibhūtā bahusaddā paccāsattiyā sati dhā ca hoti kkhattuñca.
analyzed: bahumhā dhā ca paccāsattiyā ka rū nī paccāsattiyam bahūsu  vāra sambandhi bhūtā bahu saddā paccāsattiyā sati dhā ca hoti kkhattun ca
translated: Many times, in the locative case, and the word time.🔽The word many times, which is related to the word time, is in the locative case, and the word time is in the locative case.

original: Bahuvārā bahukkhattuṃ, bahusaddena anekavāraṃ upalakkheti, anekavārā anekakkhattuṃ.
analyzed: bahu vārāḥ bahu kkhattum bahu saddena aneka vāram upalakkheti aneka vārāḥ aneka kkhattum
translated: Many times is many times. Many times indicates many times. Many times is many times.

original: Evaṃ bahuvārā bahudhā, anekavārā anekadhā. Paccāsatti nāma vārānaṃ accāsannatā vuccati,
analyzed: evam bahu vārāḥ bahudhā aneka vārāḥ anekadhā paccāsatti nāma vārānam acca āsanna tā vuccati
translated: Thus many times is in many ways. Many times is in many ways. The locative case is said to be the nearness of times.

original: divasassa bahukkhattuṃ bhuñjati, bahudhā bhuñjati, vārānaṃ dūrabhāve sati te paccayā
analyzed: divasassa bahu kkhattum bhuñjati bahudhā bhuñjati vārānam dūra bhāve sati te paccayā
translated: He eats many times a day, he eats in many ways. When the times are far away, those conditions

original: na honti, māsassa bahuvāre bhuñjati.
analyzed: na honti māsassa bahu vāre bhuñjati
translated: do not exist. He eats many times a month.

analyzed: sa kim vā ka rū nī cam pā
translated: 516. Once, or …🔽

original: Ekavāranti atthe sakinti nipaccate vā.
analyzed: ekavāram atthe sakinti nipaccate vā
translated: Once, or at one time.🔽The word sakim is formed from the noun sakam by the addition of the suffix in.

original: Sakiṃ bhuñjati, ekavāraṃ bhuñjati.
analyzed: sakim bhuñjati eka vāram bhuñjati
translated: He eats once, he eats at one time.

original: Saṅkhyārāsi niṭṭhito.🔽Khuddakarāsi
analyzed: saṅkhyā rāsi niṭṭhitaḥ  khudda karā asi
translated: The chapter on the collection of numerals is finished.

original: Pakārarāsi
analyzed: pakāra rāsi
translated: The Minor Collection

analyzed: dhā saṅkhyāhi ka rū nī cam pā
translated: The Collection on the Ending

original: Saṅkhyāvācīhi pakāre dhā hoti.🔽Dvīhi pakārehi dvidhā. Evaṃ tidhā, catudhā, pañcadhā, dasadhā, satadhā, sahassadhā, bahudhā, ekadhā, anekadhā.
analyzed: saṅkhyā vāci ihi pakāre dhā ho ti  dvīhi pakārehi dvidhā evam tidhā catudhā pañcadhā dasadhā satadhā sahassadhā bahudhā ekadhā anekadhā
translated: The verbal root dhā has the ending in the sense of a numeral.

original: 518. Vekā jjhaṃ ka. 397; rū. 420; nī. 837; caṃ. 4.3.24; pā. 5.3.46.🔽Ekamhā pakāre jjhaṃ hoti vā.
analyzed: ekamhā pakāre jjham hoti vā
translated: In two ways. In the same way, in three ways, in four ways, in five ways, in ten ways, in a hundred ways, in a thousand ways, in many ways, in one way, in various ways.🔽The verbal root veka has the ending in the sense of one.

original: Ekena pakārena ekajjhaṃ, ekadhā vā.🔽519. Dvitīhedhā ka. 404; rū. 420-370; nī. 859; caṃ. 4.3.24; pā. 5.3.46.
analyzed: ekena pakārena ekajjham ekadhā vā  dvitīya idhā ka rū nī caṃ pā
translated: In one way, in one way.

original: Dvitisaddehi pakāre edhā hoti vā.
analyzed: pakāre edhā hoti vā
translated: The verbal root dvitīya has the ending in the sense of two.

original: Dvedhā, tedhā, dvidhā, tidhā vā.
analyzed: dvedhā tedhā dvidhā tidhā vā
translated: In two ways, in three ways, in two ways, in three ways.🔽The verbal root sabba has the ending in the sense of all.

original: 520. Sabbādīhi pakāre thā ka. 398; rū. 421; nī. 844; caṃ. 4.3.26; pā. 5.3.69.
analyzed: sabba ādīhi pakāre thā ka rū nī caṃ pā
translated: In every way, in every way.

original: Bahubhedo vā sāmaññassa bhedako viseso vā pakāro, sabbādīhi pakāre thā hoti.
analyzed: bahu bhedaḥ vā sāmaññassa bhedakaḥ visesaḥ vā pakāraḥ sabba ādīhi pakāre thā hoti
translated: Or else, the various kinds of commonality are the different kinds, the modes, of the word.

original: Sabbena pakārena sabbathā, sabbehi pakārehi sabbathā, yādisena pakārena yathā, yādisehi pakārehi yathā. Evaṃ tathā, aññathā, ubhayathā, itarathā.
analyzed: sabbena pakārena sabbathā sabbehi pakārehi sabbathā yādisena pakārena yathā yādisehi pakārehi yathā evam tathā aññathā ubhayathā itarathā
translated: The forms are: sabbā, sabbathā, sabbehi, sabbathā, yādisā, yathā, yādisāhi, yathā, evaṃ, tathā, aññathā, ubhayathā, itarathā.

original: 521. Kathamitthaṃ ka. 399; rū. 422; nī. 845; pā. 5.3.24, 25.
analyzed: katham ittham
translated: How? Ka. ; rū. ; nī. ; pā. .., .

original: Ete saddā pakāre nipaccanti.
analyzed: ete saddāḥ pakāre nipaccanti
translated: These words are reduced to the mode.

original: Kena pakārena kathaṃ, iminā pakārena itthaṃ. Iminā suttena kiṃ, imasaddehi thaṃ, tthaṃpaccaye katvā kiṃssa kattaṃ, imassa ittañca kariyati.
analyzed: kena pakārena katham iminā pakārena ittham iminā suttena kim ima saddehi tham ttham paccaye katvā kim ssa imassa ittam ca kariyati
translated: By what mode? How? By this mode, thus. By this sutta, what? By these words, thaṃ, tthaṃ, having made the affix paccaya, what is its function? Of this, it is made ittañca.

original: 522. Tabbati jātiyo ka. 398; rū. 421; nī. 844; caṃ. 4.3.26; pā. 5.3.69.
analyzed: tabbati jātiyaḥ ka rū nī caṃ pā
translated: . In that, the class is ka. ; rū. ; nī. ; caṃ. ..; pā. ...

original: So pakāro assa atthīti tabbā, tasmiṃ tabbati, pakāravante dabbeti attho. Taṃsāmaññavācimhā tabbati jātiyapaccayo hoti.
analyzed: saḥ pakāraḥ assa atthi iti tabbā tasmin tabbati pakāravante dabbā iti atthaḥ tad sāmañña vācimhā tabbati jātiya paccayaḥ hoti
translated: That mode is in it, therefore, in that, in that which has the mode, the meaning is in the mode. That commonality is expressed by the affix tabba. The affix tabba is the affix of the class.

original: Visesena paṭurūpo paṇḍito paṭujātiyo. Visesena mudurūpaṃ vatthu mudujātiyaṃ.
analyzed: visesena paṭu rūpaḥ paṇḍitaḥ paṭu jātiyaḥ visesena mudu rūpam vatthu mudu jātiyam
translated: One who is clever by virtue of a special kind is paṭujātiyo. A basis that is soft by virtue of a special kind is mudujātiyaṃ.

original: 523. So vīcchāppakāresu ka. 397; rū. 420; nī. 836; caṃ. 4.4.2 …pe… 5.4.43.
analyzed: saḥ vīcchā appakāresu ka rū nī cam pe

original: Vīcchāyaṃ pakāre ca sopaccayo hoti.
analyzed: vīccha ayam pakāre ca sa upaccayaḥ hoti
translated: In the case of the analysis and the mode,

original: Vīcchāyaṃ –
analyzed: vīccha ayam
translated: In the case of the analysis,

original: Padaṃ padaṃ vāceti padaso vāceti. Khaṇḍaṃ khaṇḍaṃ karoti khaṇḍaso karoti, bilaṃ bilaṃ vibhajjati bilaso vibhajjati iccādi. Ettha ca ‘padaṃ padaṃ’ iccādīsu kriyāvisesane dutiyā.
analyzed: padam padam vācā iti padasaḥ vācā iti khaṇḍam khaṇḍam karoti karoti bilam bilam vibhajjati bilasaḥ vibhajjati iccādi ettha ca padam padam icca ādīsu kriyā visesane dutiyā
translated: he recites word by word, he recites by the syllable, he breaks it up into parts, he breaks it up by the syllable, he divides it into sections, he divides it by the section, and so on. And here in the case of ‘word by word’ and so on, the second is a term for a particular kind of action.

original: Pakāre –
analyzed: pakāre
translated: In the case of the mode,

original: Bahūhi pakārehi puthuso, sabbehi pakārehi sabbaso iccādi.
analyzed: bahūhi pakārehi puthuso sabbehi pakārehi sabbaso iccādi
translated: by many modes, separately, by all modes, altogether, and so on.

original: “Yoniso upāyaso, ṭhānaso, hetuso, atthaso, dhammaso, suttaso, anubyañjanaso” iccādīsu pana mahāvuttinā tatiyekavacanassa sottaṃ. Tathā dīghaso, oraso iccādi.
analyzed: yonisaḥ upāyasaḥ ṭhānasaḥ hetusaḥ atthasaḥ dhammasaḥ suttasaḥ anubyañjanasaḥ iccādīsu pana mahāvuttinā tatiya ekavacanassa sottam tathā dīghasaḥ orasaḥ iccādi
translated: But in the case of ‘by reason of right method,’ ‘by reason of the place,’ ‘by reason of the cause,’ ‘by reason of the meaning,’ ‘by reason of the law,’ ‘by reason of the text,’ ‘by reason of the phrasing,’ and so on, the singular of the third case is the form in the Great Collection. Likewise by length, by breadth, and so on.

original: Iti pakārarāsi.
analyzed: iti pakāra rāsi
translated: This is the Mode-group.

original: Kularāsi🔽524. Pitito bhātari reyyaṇa ka. 352; rū. 376; nī. 765.
analyzed: kularā asi  pit itaḥ bhātari reyyaṇa ka rū nī
translated: The Group of Relatives🔽The brother of the father is the father’s brother.

original: Pitusaddamhā tassa bhātāti atthe reyyaṇa hoti.
analyzed: tassa bhātā ati atthe hoti
translated: The meaning is ‘the brother of him who has the name father.’

original: Pitu bhātā petteyyo a. ni. 6.44. ‘Rānubandhentasarādissā’ti ussa lopo, tassa dvittaṃ.🔽525. Mātito ca bhaginiyaṃ cho ka. 352; rū. 376; nī. 765.
analyzed: pitu bhātā petteyyaḥ a ni  ra anubandha inta sa rā t issā ati ussa lopaḥ tassa dvittam  ca bhaginiyam cho ka rū nī
translated: The brother of one’s father is one’s uncle.🔽The sister of one’s mother is one’s aunt.

original: Mātito pitito ca bhaginiyaṃ cho hoti.🔽Mātu bhaginī mātucchā udā. 22, pitu bhaginī pitucchā saṃ. ni. 2.243.
analyzed: mātitaḥ pititaḥ ca bhaginiyam chaḥ hoti  mātu bhaginī mātucchā udā pitu bhaginī pitucchā sam ni
translated: The sister of one’s father is one’s father’s sister.🔽The mother’s sister is one’s maternal aunt.🔽The father’s sister is one’s paternal aunt.

original: 526. Mātāpitūsvāmaho ka. 352; rū. 376; nī. 765; caṃ. 3.1.60; pā. 4.2.36.
analyzed: ka rū nī caṃ pā
translated: The mother’s mother is one’s maternal grandmother.

original: Mātāpitūhi tesaṃ mātāpitūsu āmaho hoti.
analyzed: mātā pitūhi tesam mātā pitūsu āmahaḥ hoti
translated: The mother’s father is one’s maternal grandfather.🔽The father’s mother is one’s paternal grandmother.

original: Mātu mātā mātāmahī, mātu pitā mātāmaho ma. ni. 2.411, pitu mātā pitāmahī, pitu pitā pitāmaho.
analyzed: mātu mātā mātāmahī mātu pitā mātāmahaḥ ni pitu mātā pitāmahī pitu pitā pitāmahaḥ
translated: The father’s father is one’s paternal grandfather.

original: Iti kularāsi.🔽Hita, sādhu, araharāsi🔽527. Hite reyyaṇa ka. 352; rū. 376; nī. 765.
analyzed: iti kularāsi  hita sādhu araharāsi  hite reyyaṇa ka rū nī
translated: Thus the family group.

original: Mātāpitūhi tesaṃ hite reyyaṇa hoti.🔽Mātu hito metteyyo, pitu hito petteyyo. Mātāpitūsu suppaṭipanno.
analyzed: mātā pitūhi tesam hite hoti  mātu hitaḥ metteyyaḥ pitu hitaḥ petteyyaḥ mātā pitūsu su paṭipannaḥ
translated: The mother’s brother is one’s maternal uncle.🔽The father’s brother is one’s paternal uncle.🔽The mother’s sister is one’s maternal aunt.

original: 528. Iyo hite ka. 356; rū. 381; nī. 773.
analyzed: iyaḥ hite ka rū nī
translated: The father’s sister is one’s paternal aunt.

original: Tassa hitanti atthe iyo hoti.
analyzed: tassa hita nti atthe iyaḥ hoti
translated: The mother’s father is one’s maternal grandfather.🔽The father’s mother is one’s paternal grandmother.

original: Upādānānaṃ hitaṃ upādāniyaṃ. Evaṃ oghaniyaṃ, yoganiyaṃ, ganthaniyaṃ, nīvaraṇiyaṃ, suttavibhattiyā aññatthesupi iyo, samānodare sayito sodariyo.
analyzed: upādā nānam hitam upādāniyam evam oghaniyam yoganiyam ganthaniyam nīvaraṇiyam sutta vibhattiyā aññatthesu pi iyaḥ samāna udare sodariyaḥ
translated: What is helpful to the clingings is called clinging-nutriment. So too, what is floodable is called a flood, what is yoke-able is called a yoke, what is fetterable is called a fetter, what is besettable is called a besetment, what is hindranceable is called a hindrance. In the Thread-analysis, in other instances too, this is the same method. He who lies in the same belly is a uterine brother.

original: 529. Cakkhvādito sso ka. 353; rū. 378; nī. 767.🔽Tassa hitanti atthe cakkhvādīhi sso hoti.
analyzed: cakkhu ādi taḥ ssaḥ ka rū nī  tassa hitanti atthe cakkhu ādīhi ssaḥ hoti
translated: That which is beneficial to the kinds of clinging is upādānīya. So too in the case of oghaniya, yoganiya, ganthaniya, nīvaraṇiya. The form sso is used in the same way in other instances in the Suttas, as in sodariyo, “a brother.”🔽The form sso is used in the sense of “eye” and so on, as in cakkhussa, rūpassa, nīlassa.

original: Cakkhussa hitaṃ cakkhussaṃ a. ni. 5.208, subharūpaṃ cakkhubhesajjañca. Āyuno hitaṃ āyussaṃ a. ni. 5.231, āyuvaḍḍhanavidhi.🔽530. Ṇyo tattha sādhu ka. 353; rū. 378; nī. 767; caṃ. 3.4.100, 103; pā. 4.4.98, 103, 105.🔽Tasmiṃ sādhūti atthe ṇyo hoti.🔽Sabhāyaṃ sādhu sabbho, ‘sādhū’ti kusalo yogyo hito vā. Mittānaṃ hitaṃ mettaṃ. Suttavibhāgā aññatrapi ṇyo, rathaṃ vahatīti racchā, rathavīthi.
analyzed: cakkhussa hitam cakkhussam a ni subha rūpam cakkhu bhesajjam ca āyunaḥ hitam āyussam a ni āyu vaḍḍhana vidhi  ṇyaḥ tattha sādhu ka rū nī caṃ   pā  tasmin sādhu iti atthe ṇyaḥ  sādhu sabbho sādhu iti kusalaḥ yogyaḥ hitaḥ vā mittānam hitam mettam sutta vibhāgāḥ aññatra api ṇyaḥ ratham vahati iti racchā rathavīthi
translated: The form sso is used in the sense of “beneficial to,” as in cakkhussa, subharūpaṃ, cakkhubhesajjaṃ, āyussa, āyuvaḍḍhanavidhi.🔽The form ṇyo is used in the sense of “good in,” as in sabhāyaṃ, rathavīthi, mittānaṃ, kammamhā.

original: 531. Kammāniyaññā ka. 353; rū. 378; nī. 767.🔽Tasmiṃ sādhūti atthe kammamhā niya, ññā honti.
analyzed: kamma aniyaññā ka rū nī  tasmin sādhu uti atthe kammamhā ññā honti
translated: The form ṇyo is used in the sense of “good,” as in sabhāyaṃ, “good in the assembly,” “skilled,” “fit,” “beneficial”; mittānaṃ, “good to friends,” “friendly.” The form ṇyo is used in other instances in the Suttas, as in rathaṃ vahatīti racchā, “a chariot-road.”

original: Kamme sādhu kammaniyaṃ, kammaññaṃ.
analyzed: kamme sādhu kammaniyam kammaññam
translated: The forms kammamhā, niya, ñña are used in the sense of “good in,” as in kammaniyaṃ, kammaññaṃ.
The one who is a theorist, Ka. 353; Ru. 378; Ni. 767; Caṃ. 3.4.104; Pā. 4.4.102.

original: Tattha sādhūti atthe kathādīhi iko hoti.
analyzed: tattha sādhu uti atthe kathā ādīhi i kaḥ hoti
translated: The -iko affix is added to kathā, etc., in the sense of ‘good’.

original: Kathāyaṃ sādhu kathiko, dhammakathāyaṃ sādhu dhammakathiko, saṅgāme sādhu saṅgāmiko, gāmavāse sādhu gāmavāsiko, upavāse sādhu upavāsiko.
analyzed: kathā ayam sādhu kathikaḥ dhamma kathā ayam sādhu dhamma kathikaḥ saṅgāme sādhu saṅgāmikaḥ gāma vāse sādhu gāma vāsiko upavāse sādhu upavāsikaḥ
translated: Herein, kathāyaṃ sādhu = kathīko, ‘good at a discussion’, dhammakathāyaṃ sādhu = dhammakathiko, ‘good at a talk on the Dhamma’, saṅgāme sādhu = saṅgāyiko, ‘good in battle’, gāmavāse sādhu = gāmavāsiko, ‘good at living in a village’, upavāse sādhu = upavāsiko, ‘good at living near’.

original: 533. Pathādīhi ṇeyyo ka. 352; rū. 376; nī. 765; caṃ. 3.4.105; pā. 4.4.104.🔽Tattha sādhūti atthe pathādīhi ṇeyyo hoti.
analyzed: patha ādīhi ṇeyyaḥ ka rū nī cam pā  tattha sādhu iti atthe patha ādīhi ṇeyyaḥ hoti
translated: The -eyya affix is added to pathā, etc., in the sense of ‘good’.

original: Pathe sādhu pātheyyaṃ, saṃ vuccati dhanaṃ, tassa pati sapati, sapatimhi sādhu sāpateyyaṃ.🔽534. Dakkhiṇāyārahe ka. 352; rū. 376; nī. 765; caṃ. 4.1.80; pā. 5.1.69.
analyzed: pathe sādhu pātheyyam sam vuccati dhanam tassa pati sapati sapatimhi sādhu sāpateyyam  dakkhiṇāya arahe ka rū nī caṃ pā
translated: Herein, pathena sādhu = pātheyyaṃ, ‘good for the path’, saṃ vuccati dhanaṃ, ‘wealth is called a path’, tassa pati = sapati, ‘he is a husband of that’, sapatimhi sādhu = sāpateyyaṃ, ‘good for a husband’.

original: Dakkhiṇāsaddamhā arahatthe ṇeyyo hoti.🔽Dakkhiṇaṃ arahatīti dakkhiṇeyyo.
analyzed: arahatthe ṇeyyaḥ hoti  dakkhiṇam arahati iti dakkhiṇeyyaḥ
translated: The -eyya affix is added to dakkhiṇāyāraha in the sense of ‘worthy of an offering’.🔽Herein, dakkhiṇāyārahatthe = dakkhiṇeyya, ‘worthy of an offering’.

original: 535. Āyo tumantā ka. 352; rū. 376; nī. 765; ‘rāyo tumantā’ (bahūsu).
analyzed: āyo tumantā ka rū nī rāyo tumantā bahūsu
translated: The -eyya affix is added to āyo in the sense of ‘worthy of’.

original: Tumantamhā arahatthe āyo hoti.
analyzed: arahatthe āyaḥ hoti
translated: Herein, tumantā arahatthe = āyo, ‘worthy of’.

original: Ghātetuṃ arahatīti ghātetāyo, jāpetuṃ arahatīti jāpetāyo, ‘jāpetu’nti hāpetuṃ, pabbājetuṃ arahatīti pabbājetāyo, mahāvuttinā āyamhi sabinduno ussa lopo.🔽Iti hita, sādhu, araharāsi.🔽Vikatirāsi🔽536. Tassa vikārāvayavesu ṇa ṇika ṇeyyamayā ka. 352, 351, 372; rū. 376, 374, 385; nī. 765, 764, 798; caṃ. 3.3.103; pā. 4.3.134.🔽Tassa vikāro, tassa avayavoti atthesu ṇādayo honti, pakatiyā uttari avatthantarāpatti vikāro.🔽Udumbarassa vikati odumbaraṃ, bhasmā, udumbarassa avayavo odumbaraṃ, paṇṇādi. Kapotāvayavo kāpotaṃ, maṃsalohitapattādi.🔽Ṇikamhi-kappāsassa vikati kappāsikaṃ, suttaṃ vatthañca.
analyzed: ghātetum arahati iti ghāteta ayaḥ jāpetum arahati iti jāpeta ayaḥ jāpetunti hāpetum pabbājetum arahati iti mahāvuttinā āyamhi sa bindunaḥ ussa lopaḥ  iti hita sādhu araharāsi  vikatirā asi  tassa vikāra avayavesu ṇa ṇika ṇeyya mayā ka    rū    nī    caṃ pā  tassa vikāraḥ tassa avayavaḥ ti atthesu ṇa ādayaḥ honti pakatiyā uttari vikāro  udumbarassa odumbaram bhasmā udumbarassa avayavo odumbaram paṇṇa ādi kapota avayavo kāpotam maṃsa lohita patta ādi  ṇika mhi kappāsassa vika ti kappāsikam suttam vattham ca
translated: One who is fit to kill is a killer, one who is fit to make speak is a maker speak, one who is fit to make go away is a maker go away, one who is fit to banish is a banisher. The long vowel and the anusvara are dropped in the word mahāvutti.🔽Thus: hita, sādhu, araharāsi.🔽The group of synonyms🔽In the sense of “its modification,” “its component,” etc., the suffixes ṇā, ṇika, ṇeya, and maya are added.🔽In the sense of “its modification,” “its component,” etc., the suffixes ṇā, etc., are added. Modification is the occurrence of a subsequent state different from the original state.🔽The modification of udumbara is odumbara, ashes; the component of udumbara is odumbara, a leaf, etc. The component of dove is kāpota, flesh, blood, wing, etc.🔽In the sense of “its product,” the suffix ṇika is added: the product of cotton is kappāsika, thread and cloth.

original: Ṇeyyamhi-eṇissa avayavo eṇeyyaṃ, maṃsaṃ. Kosakimīnaṃ vikati koseyyaṃ, suttaṃ vatthañca.
analyzed: avayavaḥ eṇeyyam maṃsam kosaki mīnam vikati koseyyam suttam vattham ca
