original: Mayamhi-tiṇānaṃ vikati tiṇamayaṃ. Evaṃ dārumayaṃ, naḷamayaṃ, mattikāmayaṃ, gunnaṃ vikati gomayaṃ, karīsaṃ.
analyzed: tiṇa mayam evam dāru mayam naḷa mayam mattikā mayam gunnam vikati go mayam karīsam
translated: That which is made of grass is grass-made. So too, wood-made, reed-made, clay-made, cow-dung-made, excrement-made.

original: 537. Jatuto mayaṇa vā ka. 372; rū. 385; nī. 798; caṃ. 3.3.108; pā. 4.3.138; jatuto saṇa vā (bahūsu).🔽Tassa vikārāvayavesu jatuto mayaṇa hoti vā.
analyzed: vā ka rū nī cam pā jatutaḥ vā bahūsu  tassa vikāra avayavesu jatutaḥ hoti vā
translated: That which is made of jute is jute-made or jute-made.🔽In its modifications and parts it is jute-made or jute-made.

original: Jatuno vikāro jatumayaṃ.
analyzed: jatunaḥ vikāraḥ jatu mayam
translated: That which is a modification of jute is jute-made.

original: Iti vikatirāsi.
analyzed: iti
translated: So much for the class of modifications.

original: Visesarāsi🔽538. Taratamissikiyiṭṭhātisaye ka. 363; rū. 390; nī. 786; caṃ. 4.3.45; pā. 5.3.55, 57.
analyzed: visesarāsi  tara tamissi kiyi ṭṭha atisaye ka rū nī caṃ pā
translated: The class of superlatives🔽That which is the most in the sense of the highest is the most.

original: Atisayatthe ete paccayā bhavanti.🔽Pāpānaṃ atisayena pāpoti pāpataro, pāpatamo, pāpissiko, pāpiyo, pāpiṭṭho, itthiyaṃ pāpatarā, atisayatopi atisayapaccayo hoti, atisayena pāpiṭṭho pāpiṭṭhataro.
analyzed: ati saya tthe ete paccayāḥ bhavanti  pāpānam atisayena pāpaḥ ti pāpataraḥ pāpatamaḥ pāpissikaḥ pāpiyaḥ pāpiṭṭho itthiyam pāpatarā atisayataḥ pi atisaya paccayaḥ hoti atisayena pāpiṭṭhaḥ pāpiṭṭhataro
translated: These are the conditions in the sense of the highest.

original: 539. Vacchādīhi tanutte taro ka. 363; rū. 390; nī. 786; caṃ. 4.3.74; pā. 5.3.91.
analyzed: vacchādīhi tanutte taro ka rū nī caṃ pā
translated: He who is the most in the sense of the highest in evil is the most evil, the most evil of all, the most wicked, the wickeder, the wickediest. In the feminine: the most evil, the most evil of all, the wickeder, the wickediest. Even when there is no highest, the superlative is used: the wickediest of all, the wickediest of all.

original: Vacchādīhi sabbatanubhāve taro hoti.
analyzed: vaccha ādīhi sabba tanu bhāve taraḥ hoti
translated: That which is the most in the sense of the smallest is the smallest.🔽That which is the most in the sense of the smallest among oxen, etc., is the smallest.

original: Atitaruṇo vaccho vacchataro, itthiyaṃ vacchatarī. Yobbanassa tanutte yobbanapattānaṃ🔽susuttassa tanutte atitaruṇo usabho ukkhataro, assabhāvassa tanutte taruṇaasso assataro,
analyzed: ati taruṇaḥ vacchaḥ vacchataro itthiyam vacchatarī yobbanassa tanutte yobbana pattānam  susuttassa tanutte atitaruṇaḥ usabhaḥ ukkhataraḥ assabhāvassa tanutte taruṇaassaḥ assataraḥ
translated: A very young bull is a bull-calf, in a cow a bull-calf. In a young man, in one who has reached youth,🔽in one who is well-slept, a very young bull is a bull-calf, in a stallion a horse-calf,

original: itthiyaṃ assatarī. Sāmatthiyassa tanutte taruṇausabho usabhataro.
analyzed: itthiyam assatarī sāmatthiyassa tanutte taruṇausabhaḥ usabhataraḥ
translated: in a cow a horse-calf. In one who is capable, a young bull is a bull-calf.

original: 540. Kiṃmhā niddhāraṇe taratamā ka. 363; rū. 390; nī. 786; caṃ. 4.3.77; pā. 5.3.92, 93; ‘…ratara ratamā’ (bahūsu).
analyzed: kiṃmhā niddhāraṇe taratamā ka rū nī caṃ pā   ratara ratamā bahūsu
translated: What is the superlative in the sense of ‘distinguishing’? ka, rū, nī, caṃ, pā. .., ‘…ratara ratamā’ (in many).

original: Kiṃsaddā niddhāraṇe gamyamāne tara, tamā honti.
analyzed: niddhāraṇe gamyamāne tara tamā honti
translated: The forms tara, tamā are used when the superlative is being expressed.

original: Kataro bhavataṃ devadatto, kataro bhavataṃ yaññadatto, katamo bhavataṃ devadatto, katamo bhavataṃ yaññadatto, ‘kissa ko’ti suttena tara, tamesu kissa kattaṃ.
analyzed: kataraḥ bhavatam devadatto kataraḥ bhavatam yaññadatto katamaḥ bhavatam devadatto katamaḥ bhavatam yaññadatto kissa koti suttena tara tamesu kissa kattam
translated: Which of you is Devadatta, which of you is Yaññadatta, which is Devadatta, which is Yaññadatta? ‘Kissa ko’ti suttena tara, tamesu kissa kattaṃ.

original: Iti visesarāsi.
analyzed: iti
translated: Thus the class of particularities.

original: Samūharāsi🔽541. Samūhe kaṇaṇaṇikā ka. 354; rū. 379; nī. 771; caṃ. 3.1.43-47; pā. 4.2.37-42.
analyzed: samūharāsi  samūhe kaṇaṇaṇikā ka rū nī cam pā
translated: The class of collections🔽. In a collection kaṇa, ṇa, ṇikā ka, rū, nī, caṃ. ..-; pā. ..-.

original: Tassa samūhoti atthe kaṇa, ṇa, ṇikā honti.
analyzed: tassa samūhaḥ iti atthe ka ṇa ṇa ṇikā honti
translated: The forms kaṇa, ṇa, ṇikā are used in the sense of ‘its collection’.🔽.

original: Gottapaccayantehi tāva – rājaññānaṃ samūho rājaññakaṃ, mānussakaṃ.
analyzed: gotta paccaya antehi tāva rājaññānam samūhaḥ rājaññakam mānussakam
translated: The words ending in -ttapaccaya are formed thus: The group of Rajjhas is Rajjhakaṃ, the group of human beings is Mānusakaṃ.

original: Ukkhādīhi-ukkhānaṃ usabhānaṃ samūho okkhakaṃ, oṭṭhānaṃ samūho oṭṭhakaṃ, urabbhānaṃ
analyzed: ukkha ādīhi ukkhānam usabhānam samūhaḥ okkhakam oṭṭhānam samūhaḥ oṭṭhakam urabbhānam
translated: The group of oxen is Okkaṃ, the group of goats is Oṭṭhakaṃ, the group of sheep is Orrabhakaṃ.

original: samūho orabbhakaṃ. Evaṃ rājakaṃ, rājaputtakaṃ, hatthikaṃ, dhenukaṃ, sasaṃ adenti
analyzed: samūhaḥ orabbhakam evam rājakam rājaputtakam hatthikam dhenukam sasam adenti
translated: So too: the group of kings is Rājakaṃ, the group of princes is Rājaputtakaṃ, the group of elephants is Hatthikaṃ, the group of cows is Dhenukaṃ, the group of rabbits is Sasaṃ.

original: bhakkhantīti sasādakā, tesaṃ samūho sasādakakaṃ. Ikkhaṇikaṃ.
analyzed: bhakkhanti iti sasādakā tesam samūhaḥ sasādakakam ikkhaṇikam
translated: Those who eat rabbits are Sasādakā, the group of them is Sasādakakaṃ.

original: Ṇamhi-amittānaṃ samūho amittaṃ.
analyzed: samūhaḥ amittam
translated: The group of enemies is Amittaṃ.

original: Ṇikamhi-apūpānaṃ samūho āpūpikaṃ, sakuṇānaṃ samūho sākuṇiko saṃkulānaṃ samūho saṃkulikaṃ?.🔽542. Janādīhi tā ka. 355; rū. 380; nī. 771; caṃ. 3.1.69; pā. 4.2.43.🔽Tassa samūhoti atthe tā hoti.
analyzed: samūhaḥ āpūpikam sakuṇānam samūhaḥ sākuṇikaḥ saṃkulānam samūhaḥ saṃkulikam           tassa samūhoti atthe tā hoti
translated: The group of cakes is Āpūpikaṃ, the group of birds is Sākuṇikaṃ, the group of crows is Saṃkulikaṃ.

original: Janatā, rājatā, bandhutā, gāmatā, sahāyatā, nagaravāsīnaṃ samūho nāgaratā iccādi.🔽543. Ayūbhadvitīhaṃse ka. 354; rū. 379; nī. 771; caṃ. 4.2.47, 48; pā. 5.2.43, 44.
analyzed: jana tā rāja tā bandhu tā gāma tā sahāya tā nagara vāsīnam samūhaḥ nāgara tā iccādi  a yūbha dvitīya haṃse ka rū nī caṃ   pā
translated: . The words ending in -ttapaccaya are formed thus: The group of people is Janatā, the group of kings is Rājatā, the group of relatives is Bandhutā, the group of villagers is Gāmatā, the group of friends is Sahāyatā, the group of town-dwellers is Nāgaratā.🔽. The words ending in -ttapaccaya are formed thus: The group of two swords is Ayūbhadvittikaṃ, the group of two geese is Ayūbhadvittikaṃ, the group of three is Ayūbhattitikaṃ.

original: Ubha, dvi, tīhi tassa aṃsatthe ayo hoti.
analyzed: ubha dvi tīhi tassa aṃsatthe ayaḥ hoti
translated: The group of two, of three, of many is Ayūbhadvittikaṃ, Ayūbhattitikaṃ, Ayūbhamassakaṃ.

original: Ubho aṃsā bhāgā assāti ubhayaṃ, dve aṃsā assāti dvayaṃ, tayo aṃsā assāti tayaṃ, vatthuttayaṃ, ratanattayaṃ, dve vā tayo vā aṃsā assāti dvattayaṃ.
analyzed: ubho aṃsāḥ bhāgāḥ assa ati ubhayam dve aṃsāḥ assa ati dvayam tayaḥ aṃsāḥ assa ati tayam vatthuttayam ratanattayam dve vā tayaḥ vā aṃsāḥ assa ati dvattayam
translated: Both shoulders are parts: thus both is a pair. Two shoulders: thus a pair. Three shoulders: thus a triple. A triple of material qualities. A triple of jewels. Two or three shoulders: thus a couple.

original: Iti samūharāsi.
analyzed: iti
translated: Thus a collection is a heap.

original: Datta, nibbattarāsi🔽544. Tena datte liyā ka. 358, 356; rū. 383, 381; nī. 778, 773.
analyzed: datta nibbattarā asi  tena dā
translated: Given, born, heap🔽. Thereby, given, ka, rū, nī.

original: Tena dattoti atthe la, iyā honti. Mahāvuttinā dinnasaddassa dattattaṃ.
analyzed: tena datta uti atthe la iyāḥ honti mahāvuttinā dinna saddassa datta ttam
translated: Thereby given: the meanings are la, iyā. The Great Commentary’s statement that the word dinna has the meaning of given.

original: Devena dattoti devalo jā. 1.8.65. ‘Devilo’tipi devīlo? pāḷi. Deviyo, devadatto vā.
analyzed: devena dattā iti devalaḥ jā devilā utipi devīlā deviyaḥ devadattaḥ vā
translated: Given by a god: thus a god-given is a devala . … ‘Devilo’ is also a reading. Goddesses, a gift from a goddess, is a devadatta .

original: Evaṃ brahmalo, brahmiyo, brahmadatto, sivena bissanudevarājena datto sīvalo, sīviyo, itthiyaṃ sīvali, sīviyi, sissa dīgho.
analyzed: evam brahmalaḥ brahmiyaḥ brahmadatto sivena bissanu devarājena datto sīvalaḥ sīviyaḥ itthiyam sīvali sīviyi sissa dīghaḥ
translated: Thus a Brahmā-given is a brahmalo . A Brahmā-born is a brahmiyo . A gift from Brahmā is a brahmadatta . Given by the king of the gods, the lord of the Thirty-three, is a sīvalo . A sīviyo . In the feminine: a sīvali . A sīviyi . A disciple is a sissa . Long is a dīgho .

original: 545. Tena nibbatte ka. 353; rū. 378; nī. 767; ‘tena nibbatte imo’?.
analyzed: tena nibbatte ka rū nī  tena nibbatte imo
translated: Thereby, born, ka, rū, nī. ‘Thereby born is this’?.

original: Tena nibbatte imo hoti.
analyzed: tena nibbatte imaḥ hoti
translated: Thereby born is this:

original: Pākena nibbattaṃ pākimaṃ, pheṇena nibbattaṃ pheṇimaṃ, veṭhanena nibbattaṃ veṭhimaṃ.
analyzed: pākena nibbattam pākimam pheṇena nibbattam pheṇimam veṭhanena nibbattam veṭhimam
translated: Cooked is pākimaṃ . Froth-born is pheṇimaṃ . A wrapping is veṭhimaṃ .

original: Evaṃ vedhimaṃ, gopphanena nibbattaṃ gopphimaṃ pārā. aṭṭha. 2.431, pupphadāmaṃ, karaṇena
analyzed: evam vedhimam gopphanena nibbattam gopphimam pārāḥ aṭṭha puppha dāmam karaṇena
translated: So the bone is the mother, the ankle-bone is the father, the ankle-bone is the mother, the knee-bone is the father, the knee-bone is the mother, the thigh-bone is the father, the thigh-bone is the mother, the hip-bone is the father, the hip-bone is the mother, the spine is the father, the spine is the mother, the shoulder-blade is the father, the shoulder-blade is the mother, the neck-bone is the father, the neck-bone is the mother, the jaw-bone is the father, the jaw-bone is the mother, the teeth are the father, the teeth are the mother, the tongue is the father, the tongue is the mother, the palate is the father, the palate is the mother, the nose is the father, the nose is the mother, the eye is the father, the eye is the mother, the head is the father, the head is the mother, the skin is the father, the skin is the mother, the flesh is the father, the flesh is the mother, the sinew is the father, the sinew is the mother, the vein is the father, the vein is the mother, the blood is the father, the blood is the mother, the sweat is the father, the sweat is the mother, the fat is the father, the fat is the mother, the tears are the father, the tears are the mother, the oil of the joints is the father, the oil of the joints is the mother, the marrow is the father, the marrow is the mother, the kidney is the father, the kidney is the mother, the heart is the father, the heart is the mother, the liver is the father, the liver is the mother, the pleura is the father, the pleura is the mother, the spleen is the father, the spleen is the mother, the lungs are the father, the lungs are the mother, the intestines are the father, the intestines are the mother, the mesentery is the father, the mesentery is the mother, the gorge is the father, the gorge is the mother, the excrement is the father, the excrement is the mother, the urine is the father, the urine is the mother, the semen is the father, the semen is the mother, the womb is the father, the womb is the mother, the foetus is the father, the foetus is the mother, the navel is the father

original: nibbattaṃ kittimaṃ, kuttimaṃ vā, mahāvuttinā karaṇassa kittaṃ kuttañca. Suttavibhattena🔽saṃhārimaṃ, āhārimaṃ iccādīni sijjhanti.🔽Iti datta, nibbattarāsi.
analyzed: nibbattam kittimam kuttimam vā mahāvuttinā karaṇassa kittam kuttam ca sutta vibhattena  saṃhārimam āhārimam icca ādīni sijjhanti  iti datta nibbattarā asi
translated: Thus the word vedhimaṃ is formed. The word gopphimaṃ is formed by adding -maṃ to gopphanaṃ. The word kittimaṃ is formed by adding -maṃ to kittaṃ. The word kuttimaṃ is formed by adding -maṃ to kuttaṃ. The word mahāvuttinā is formed by adding -nā to mahāvutti. The word kittaṃ is formed by adding -taṃ to kittaṃ. The word kuttaṃ is formed by adding -taṃ to kuttaṃ. The word saṃhārimaṃ is formed by adding -maṃ to saṃhāri. The word āhārimaṃ is formed by adding -maṃ to āhāri.

original: La, ita, karāsi
analyzed: le ita karāsi
translated: Thus the word datta is formed. The word nibbattarāsi is formed by adding -rāsi to nibbatta.🔽The word la is formed by adding -la to ita. The word karāsi is formed by adding -āsi to kara.

original: 546. Tannissite lo ka. 358; rū. 383; nī. 778; ‘llo’ (bahūsu).
analyzed: tad nissite laḥ ka rū nī l laḥ bahūsu
translated: The word lo is formed by adding -lo to ka. The word rū is formed by adding -rū to ka. The word nī is formed by adding -nī to ka. The word llo is formed by adding -llo to ka (in the plural).

original: Tannissitatthe lo hoti.
analyzed: tad nissita tthe laḥ hoti
translated: The word lo is formed by adding -lo to ka in the sense of ‘depending on that’.

original: Vedaṃ ñāṇaṃ nissitaṃ vedallaṃ, lassa dvittaṃ, duṭṭhu nissitaṃ duṭṭhullaṃ. “Madanīyaṃ,
analyzed: vedam ñāṇam nissitam vedallam lassa dvittam duṭṭhu nissitam duṭṭhullam madanīyam
translated: The word vedalla is formed by adding -lla to vedaṃ ñāṇaṃ nissitaṃ. The word duṭṭhulla is formed by adding -ulla to duṭṭhu nissitaṃ. The words madanīyaṃ, bandhanīyaṃ, mucchanīyaṃ, rajanīyaṃ, gamanīyaṃ, dassanīyaṃ are formed by adding -īyaṃ to madanaṃ, bandhanaṃ, mucchanā, rajanaṃ, gamanā, dassanā respectively.

original: bandhanīyaṃ, mucchanīyaṃ, rajanīyaṃ, gamanīyaṃ, dassanīyaṃ” iccādīni karaṇe vā adhikaraṇe🔽vā anīyapaccayena sijjhanti.
analyzed: bandhanīyam mucchanīyam rajanīyam gamanīyam dassanīyam iccādīni karaṇe vā adhikaraṇe  vā anīya paccayena sijjhanti
translated: The words madanīyaṃ, bandhanīyaṃ, mucchanīyaṃ, rajanīyaṃ, gamanīyaṃ, dassanīyaṃ are formed by adding -īyaṃ to madanaṃ, bandhanaṃ, mucchanā, rajanaṃ, gamanā, dassanā respectively.

original: ‘Dhūmāyitatta’ntiādīsu dhūmo viya attānaṃ ācaratīti dhūmāyitaṃ, gaganaṃ, dhūmāyitaṃ
analyzed: dhūmāyita ttanti ādīsu dhūmaḥ viya attānam ācarati iti dhūmāyitam gaganam dhūmāyitam
translated: The word dhūmāyitaṃ is formed by adding -itaṃ to dhūmo viya attānaṃ ācaratīti dhūmāyitaṃ. The word

original: eva dhūmāyitattaṃ, sakatthe tta. Evaṃ timirāyitattaṃ, nāmadhātuto saṃ. ni. 3.87 āyapaccayena siddhaṃ.
analyzed: eva dhūmāyitattam saka tthe tte evam timirāyitattam nāma dhātutaḥ sam ni āya paccayena siddham
translated: Thus there is the state of being smoky, the state of being smoky being in its own place. Thus there is the state of being misty, the state of being misty being from the element of name.🔽It is established by the condition of going out.

original: 547. Sañjātā tārakādvitvito ka. 555; rū. 612; nī. 1142; caṃ. 4.2.37 …pe… 5.2.36; ‘sañjātaṃ…’ (bahūsu).
analyzed: sañjātā ka rū nī cam pe sañjātam bahūsu
translated: They have arisen from the stars, etc., ka. ; rū. ; nī. ; caṃ. .. …pe… ..; ‘They have arisen’ (in many).

original: Tārakādīhi te assa sañjātāti atthe ito hoti.
analyzed: tārakā ādīhi te assa sañjātā ati atthe i taḥ hoti
translated: They have arisen from the stars, etc., is the meaning here.

original: Tārakā sañjātā assāti tārakitaṃ, gaganaṃ. Pupphāni sañjātāni assāti pupphito. Evaṃ
analyzed: tārakā sañjātā assa ati tārakitam gaganam pupphāni sañjātāni assa ati pupphitaḥ evam
translated: The stars have arisen is starry, the sky. The flowers have arisen is flowery. Thus

original: phalito, rukkho. Pallavāni sañjātāni assāti pallavitā, latā. Dukkhaṃ sañjātaṃ assāti
analyzed: phalitaḥ rukkhaḥ pallavāni sañjātāni assa ati pallavitā latā dukkham sañjātam assa ati
translated: the fruit has arisen is fruity, the tree. The shoots have arisen is leafy, the creeper. Suffering has arisen is

original: dukkhito, sukhaṃ sañjātaṃ assāti sukhito.
analyzed: dukkhitaḥ sukham sañjātam assa ati sukhitaḥ
translated: painful, happiness has arisen is pleasant.

original: Paṇḍā vuccati paññā, paṇḍā sañjātā assāti paṇḍito, daṇḍo sañjāto assāti daṇḍito.
analyzed: paṇḍā vuccati paññā paṇḍā sañjātā assa ati paṇḍitaḥ daṇḍaḥ sañjātaḥ assa ati daṇḍitaḥ
translated: Wisdom is called wisdom, the wisdom has arisen is wise, the rod has arisen is roddy.

original: Mahāvuttinā tassa natte malaṃ sañjātaṃ assāti malinaṃ. Tathā pipāsā sañjātā assāti
analyzed: mahāvuttinā tassa natte malam sañjātam assa ati malinam tathā pipāsā sañjātā assa ati
translated: By the great occurrence, the stain has arisen in it is stained. Thus thirst has arisen is

original: pipāsito, jighacchā sañjātā assāti jighacchito, bubhukkhā sañjātā assāti bubhukkhito,
analyzed: pipāsitaḥ jighacchā sañjātā assa ati jighacchitaḥ bubhukkhā sañjātā assa ati bubhukkhitaḥ
translated: thirsty, hunger has arisen is hungry, hunger has arisen is hungry,

original: mucchā sañjātā assāti mucchito, visaññā sañjātā assāti visaññito, nindā sañjātā assāti nindito.
analyzed: mucchā sañjātā assa ati mucchitaḥ visaññā sañjātā assa ati visaññitaḥ nindā sañjātā assa ati ninditaḥ
translated: He has become faint, has lost consciousness, is called faint, unconscious. He has become reviled, is called reviled.🔽So too with the rest.

original: Evaṃ gabba-thambhe gabbito. Dabba-pāṭave dabbito. Antaraṃ sañjātaṃ assāti antarito, vaccaṃ sañjātaṃ assāti vaccito.
analyzed: evam gabba thambhe gabbitaḥ dabba pāṭave dabbitaḥ antaram sañjātam assa ati antaritaḥ vaccam sañjātam assa ati vaccitaḥ
translated: In the word gabbho he is enclosed in the womb, in the word dabbo he is beaten, in the word antarā he is born inside, in the word vaccho he is born as dung.

original: 548. Nindāññātappapaṭibhāgarassadayāsaññāsu ko ka. 391; rū. 423; nī. 835; caṃ. 4.3.62, 63, 64; pā. 5.3.73-79, 96, 97.🔽Nindādīsu jotaniyesu nāmasmā ko hoti.
analyzed: nindā aññā tappa paṭibhāga rassa dayā saññāsu ko ka rū nī caṃ     pā  nindā ādīsu jotaniyesu nāmasmai kaḥ hoti
translated: In the words nindā, aññāta, appa, paṭibhāga, rasada, and saññā, what is the meaning of the k?

original: Nindāyaṃ – kucchito samaṇo samaṇako. Evaṃ muṇḍako, assako, uddhumātakaṃ, vinīlakaṃ, vipubbakaṃ, aṭṭhikaṃ iccādi.🔽Aññāte – aññāto asso assako, kassa ayaṃ assoti vā assako iccādi.
analyzed: kucchitaḥ samaṇaḥ samaṇakaḥ evam muṇḍakaḥ assakaḥ uddhumātakam vinīlakam vipubbakam aṭṭhikam iccādi  aññāte aññātaḥ assaḥ assako kassa ayam asso ti vā assako iccādi
translated: In the word nindā it is the meaning of reviling: a monk is reviled, a recluse is reviled. So too with the rest.🔽In the word aññāta it is the meaning of unknown: an unknown horse is a horse-unknown. Whose horse is this? Horse-unknown.

original: Appatthe – appakaṃ telaṃ telakaṃ. Evaṃ ghatakaṃ, khuddakaṃ dhanu dhanukaṃ, rathakaṃ, gāmakaṃ iccādi.
analyzed: appatthe appakam telam telakam evam ghatakam khuddakam dhanu dhanukam rathakam gāmakam iccādi
translated: In the word appa it is the meaning of little: a little oil is oil-little. So too with the rest.

original: Paṭibhāgatthe – hatthirūpakaṃ hatthikaṃ. Evaṃ assakaṃ, balībaddako iccādi.
analyzed: paṭibhāga atthe hatthi rūpakam hatthikam evam assakam balībaddakaḥ iccādi
translated: In the word paṭibhāga it is the meaning of likeness: an elephant-like man is a man-elephant. So too with the rest.

original: Rasse-rasso manusso manussako. Evaṃ rukkhako, pilakkhako iccādi.
analyzed: rasserassaḥ manussaḥ manussakaḥ evam rukkhakaḥ pilakkhakaḥ iccādi
translated: A man of small stature is a man-man. So a tree-tree, a pilu-tree.

original: Dayāyaṃ-anukampito putto puttako. Evaṃ vacchako, itthikā, ambakā, kumārikā iccādi.
analyzed: putto puttako evam vacchakaḥ itthikā ambakā kumārikā iccādi
translated: A son who is pitied is a son-son. So a calf, a woman, a mango, a girl.

original: Saññāyaṃ-nāmamattena moro viya morako iccādi.
analyzed: saññāyaṃnāma mattena moraḥ viya morako iccādi
translated: By means of a name, a peacock is like a peacock.

original: Iti la, ita, ka rāsi.
analyzed: iti la ita ka rāsi
translated: Thus la, ita, ka, a heap.

original: Abhūtatabbhāvarāsi🔽549. Abhūtatabbhāve karāsabhūyoge vikārācī ka. 391; rū. 423; nī. 835; caṃ. 4.4.35; pā. 5.4.50.
analyzed: a bhūta tad bhāvarā asi  a bhūta tad bhāve ka rāsa bhū yoge vikārācī ka rū nī caṃ pā
translated: The heap of what is not and what is not possible

original: Pubbe tassa abhūtassa vatthuno kadāci tathā bhavanaṃ abhūtatabbhāvo, tasmiṃ abhūtatabbhāve jotaniye sati karā’sa, bhūdhātūnaṃ yoge vikāravācimhā nāmasmā cānubandho īpaccayo hoti.
analyzed: pubbe tassa abhūtassa vatthunaḥ kadāci tathā bhavanam abhūta tad bhāvo tasmin abhūta tad bhāve jotaniye sati bhū dhātūnam yoge vikāra vācimhā nāmasmā ca anubandhaḥ hoti
translated: . In the non-existence of what is not and what is not possible, in the combination of the elements of earth, water, fire, and air, there is a change, and the suffix ī is added to the noun.

original: Adhavalaṃ dhavalaṃ karoti dhavalīkaroti, adhavalo dhavalo siyā dhavalīsiyā, adhavalo dhavalo bhavati dhavalībhavati. Evaṃ dhavalīkāro, dhavalībhūto.
analyzed: adhavalam dhavalam karoti dhavalīkaroti adhavalaḥ dhavalaḥ siyā dhavalīsiyā adhavalaḥ dhavalaḥ bhavati dhavalībhavati evam dhavalīkāraḥ dhavalībhūtaḥ
translated: The making of what was not white white is the making white. What was not white may become white. What was not white becomes white. Thus the making white, the becoming white.

original: Abhūtatabbhāveti kiṃ? Ghaṭaṃ karoti, ghaṭo atthi, ghaṭo bhavati.🔽Karāsabhūyogeti kiṃ? Adhavalo dhavalo jāyate.
analyzed: abhūta tad bhāva iti kim ghaṭam karoti ghaṭaḥ atthi ghaṭaḥ bhavati  kim adhavalaḥ dhavalaḥ jāyate
translated: What is meant by the non-existent as existent? He makes a pot, there is a pot, a pot comes to be.🔽What is meant by the non-existent as a cause? The white becomes the black.

original: Vikārāti kiṃ? Pakatiyā mā hotu, suvaṇṇaṃ kuṇḍalaṃ karoti, suvaṇṇassa kuṇḍalakaraṇaṃ nāma loke pakatirūpanti vuttaṃ hoti. Evaṃ suvaṇṇaṃ kuṇḍalaṃ siyā, suvaṇṇaṃ kuṇḍalaṃ bhavatīti.
analyzed: vikārā ati kim pakatiyā mā hotu suvaṇṇam kuṇḍalam karoti suvaṇṇassa kuṇḍala karaṇam nāma loke pakati rūpan ti vuttam hoti evam suvaṇṇam kuṇḍalam siyā suvaṇṇam kuṇḍalam bhavati iti
translated: What is meant by alteration? Let it not be as it was before. He makes an earring of gold. The making of an earring of gold is a natural form in the world. Thus it may be gold and an earring, gold is an earring.

original: Iti abhūtatabbhāvarāsi.
analyzed: iti a bhūta tad bhāva rā asi
translated: So much for the heap of the non-existent as existent.

original: Sakattharāsi
analyzed: sakattharā asi
translated: The heap of the conventional

analyzed: sa ka tthe ka rū     nī
translated: . In the conventional, ka. , , ; rū. , , , ; nī. , , , .

original: Sakatthepi paccayā dissanti. ‘Sakattho’ti sakapadattho, pakatiliṅgapadatthoti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: saka atthe pi paccayāḥ dissanti saka attho ti saka pada ttho pakati liṅga pada ttho ti vuttam hoti
translated: Conditions are seen in the conventional. “Conventional” is the meaning of the word saka, the meaning of the word of the natural gender is what is meant.

original: Hīno eva hīnako, poto eva potako, devo eva devatā, yathābhūtameva yathābhuccaṃ, karuṇā
analyzed: eva hīnakaḥ potaḥ eva potakaḥ devaḥ eva devatā yathābhūtam eva yathābhuccam karuṇā
translated: The low only is the low one, the young only is the young one, the god only is the god, just as it is, just as it is said, compassion

original: eva kāruññaṃ, pattakālameva pattakallaṃ, ākāsānantameva ākāsānañcaṃ, pāguññameva
analyzed: eva kāruññam pattakālam eva pattakallam ākāsānantam eva ākāsānañcam pāguññam eva
translated: only is pity, the time of ripening only is the ripened, the infinite space only is the sphere of infinite space, the good quality only is🔽the good

original: pāguññatā, kammaññameva kammaññatā, dānaṃ eva dānamayaṃ, sīlaṃ eva sīlamayaṃ. Evaṃ
analyzed: pāguñña tā kammaññam eva kammañña tā dānam eva dāna mayam sīlam eva sīla mayam evam
translated: and the state of being skilled is skillfulness, and the state of being workable is workableness. And giving is the giving-essence, virtue is the virtue-essence. So too

original: bhāvanāmayaṃ iccādi.
analyzed: bhāvanā mayam i t ca ādi
translated: in the case of the jhāna-essence, etc.

original: Yathā ca amaccaputtā eva ‘amaccaputtiyā’ti vuccanti, evaṃ “sakyaputto eva sakyaputtiyo, asamaṇo hoti asakyaputtiyo pārā. 55, evaṃ nāṭaputtiyo, dāsaputtiyo”tipi yujjati.
analyzed: yathā ca amacca puttāḥ eva amacca puttiyā ati vuccanti evam sakya puttaḥ eva sakyaputtiyaḥ asamaṇaḥ hoti asakyaputtiyaḥ evam nāṭa puttiyaḥ dāsa puttiyaḥ iti pi yujjati
translated: And just as the sons of ministers are called “sons of ministers” , so too it is proper to say “a son of the Sakyans is a Sakyan, a non-ascetic is a non-ascetic Sakyan, a non-ascetic is a non-ascetic Nāṭa, a non-ascetic is a non-ascetic Dāsa” .

original: ‘Bhayadassivā, atthadassimā’ti vantu, mantupaccayāsakatthepi yujjanti. ‘Brahmavaṇṇī,
analyzed: bhaya dassivā attha dassimā ati vantu mantu paccayā asakatthe pi yujjanti brahma vaṇṇī
translated: And in the case of the words bhayadassiva and atthadassimā , the -va and -mā are proper as a suffix in the sense of a reason. In the case of the words brahmavaṇṇī and

original: devavaṇṇī’ti ettha brahmuno vaṇṇo brahmavaṇṇo, brahmavaṇṇo viya vaṇṇo assa atthīti
analyzed: deva vaṇṇī iti ettha brahmunaḥ vaṇṇaḥ brahma vaṇṇaḥ brahma vaṇṇaḥ viya vaṇṇaḥ assa atthi iti
translated: devavaṇṇī , the -vaṇṇī is a suffix in the sense of “having the appearance of” .

original: atthe sati īpaccayo paccayattho eva hoti, na sakattho. Brahmavaṇṇo viya vaṇṇo yassa
analyzed: atthe sati ī paccayaḥ paccaya ttho eva hoti na saka tthaḥ brahma vaṇṇaḥ viya vaṇṇaḥ yassa
translated: When the meaning is “having the appearance of Brahmā” the suffix -vaṇṇī is in the sense of a reason, not in the sense of a suffix. But when the meaning is “having an appearance like the appearance of Brahmā” the suffix -vaṇṇī is in the sense of a suffix.

original: soyaṃ brahmavaṇṇīti atthe sati sakatthoyeva. Api ca ekasmiṃ aññapadatthe dve samāsa,
analyzed: saḥ ayam brahma vaṇṇī iti atthe sati api ca ekasmin añña padatthe dve samāsa
translated: And in the case of the words brahmavaṇṇī and brahmavaṇṇo , there are two kinds of compounds in the single meaning of “having the appearance of Brahmā” .

original: taddhitā vattantītipi yujjati, tathā ‘paguṇassa bhāvo pāguññatā’tiādīsu dve taddhitapaccayā bhāvattheti.
analyzed: taddhitāḥ vattanti itipi yujjati tathā paguṇassa bhāvaḥ pāguñña tā ati ādīsu dve taddhita paccayāḥ bhāva atthe iti
translated: and it is also proper to say that they are formed by a nominal affix. Likewise in such passages as ‘The state of being devoid of merit is lack of merit’ (Pāc 29), there are two nominal-affix bases in the sense of state.

original: Iti sakattharāsi.
analyzed: iti sakattharā asi
translated: So much for the collection of the basic nouns.

original: Niddiṭṭhapaccayarāsi
analyzed: niddiṭṭha paccaya rāsi
translated: The collection of the demonstrated nominal-affix bases

original: 551. Aññasmiṃ ka. 352; rū. 376; nī. 765.
analyzed: aññasmin ka rū nī
translated: In other meanings, ka, rū, nī.

original: Pubbe niddiṭṭhā ṇādayo paccayā niddiṭṭhatthato aññesupi atthesu dissanti.
analyzed: pubbe niddiṭṭhāḥ ṇa ādayaḥ paccayāḥ niddiṭṭha tthataḥ aññesu pi atthesu dissanti
translated: The nominal-affix bases beginning with ṇā, which were demonstrated above, are found in other meanings as well.

original: Magadhesu jāto māgadho, magadhesu saṃvaḍḍhito māgadho, magadhesu nivuttho māgadho, magadhānaṃ magadhesu vā issaro māgadho iccādi, ṇo.
analyzed: magadhesu jātaḥ māgadhaḥ magadhesu saṃvaḍḍhitaḥ māgadhaḥ magadhesu nivutthaḥ māgadhaḥ magadhānam magadhesu vā issaraḥ māgadhaḥ icca ādi ṇo
translated: One born in Magadha is a Māgadhan, one brought up in Magadha is a Māgadhan, one who has lived in Magadha is a Māgadhan, one who is a lord of the Magadhans in Magadha is a Māgadhan.

original: Kāsiṃ agghatīti kāsiyo cūḷava. 376, ‘kāsī’ti sataṃ vā sahassaṃ vā vuccati, iyo.
analyzed: kāsim agghati iti kāsiyaḥ cūḷava kāsīti satam vā sahassam vā vuccati iyaḥ
translated: One who values Kāsī highly is a Kāsiyan, a small amount, i.e. a hundred or a thousand, is called ‘Kāsī’ here.

original: Evamaññepi paccayā yathānurūpaṃ veditabbā.🔽552. Dissantaññepi paccayā ka. 351, 352; rū. 374, 376; nī. 764, 765.
analyzed: evam aññe pi paccayāḥ yathānurūpam veditabbā  dissanta ññe pi paccayā ka rū   nī
translated: So too in other cases the nominal-affix bases should be understood according to the meaning.🔽They are found in other meanings too, ka, rū, nī.

original: Pubbe niddiṭṭhapaccayehi aññepi paccayā niddiṭṭhesu aniddiṭṭhesu ca atthesu dissanti.
analyzed: pubbe niddiṭṭha paccayehi aññe api paccayāḥ niddiṭṭhesu a niddiṭṭhesu ca atthesu dissanti
translated: The nominal-affix bases demonstrated above are found in other meanings, both demonstrated and undemonstrated.

original: Visadisā vividhā (moga.) mātaro vimātaro, tāsaṃ puttā vemātikā netti 95, ikaṇa.🔽Pathe gacchantīti pathāvino ma. ni. 2.347, aghaṃ dukkhaṃ pāpaṃ vā gacchatīti aghāvī, āvī.🔽Issā assa atthīti issukī jā. 1.6.43, ukī.
analyzed: visadisāḥ vividhāḥ moga mātaraḥ vimātaraḥ tāsam puttāḥ vemātikāḥ  pathe gacchanti iti pathāvinaḥ ma ni agham dukkham pāpam vā gacchati iti aghāvī āvī  issā assa atthi iti issukī jā  ukī
translated: Mothers are different, various (Mogg.), and fathers are different; their sons are half-brothers, (and) step-brothers.🔽Those who go on a path are path-goers.🔽Evil goes to him, therefore he is an evildoer.

original: Dhuraṃ vahantīti dhorayhā a. ni. 3.58, yhaṇa.🔽Lobhassa hitā lobhaneyyā. Evaṃ dosaneyyā, mohaneyyā, aneyyo.🔽Dassanaṃ arahatīti dassaneyyo. Evaṃ vandaneyyo, pūjaneyyo, namassaneyyo, eyyo.🔽Oghānaṃ hitā oghaniyā, yoganiyā, ganthaniyā, kammaniyaṃ, attaniyaṃ, dassaniyaṃ, pūjaniyo, namassaniyo iccādi, aniyo.🔽Yaṃ parimāṇaṃ assāti yāvaṃ, yāvantassa bhāvo yāvatvaṃ. Evaṃ tāvatvaṃ, tva.🔽Paramānaṃ uttamapurisānaṃ bhāvo kammaṃ vā pāramī, samaggānaṃ bhāvo kammaṃ vā sāmaggī, ṇī.
analyzed: dhuram vahanti iti a ni 🔽lobhassa hitā lobhaneyyā evam dosaneyyā mohaneyyā 🔽dassanam arahati iti dassaneyyaḥ evam vandaneyyaḥ pūjaneyyaḥ namassaneyyaḥ eyyaḥ 🔽oghānam hitā ogha niyā yoga niyā gantha niyā kamma niyam atta niyam dassa niyam pūja niyaḥ namassa niyaḥ iccādi aniyaḥ 🔽yam parimāṇam assa ati yāvam yāvantassa bhāvaḥ evam tāvatvam 🔽paramānam uttama purisānam bhāvaḥ kammam vā pāramī samaggānam bhāvaḥ kammam vā sāmaggī
translated: Mothers are different, various, (and so are) stepmothers; their sons are half-brothers, (and so are) stepbrothers, (and so are) brothers-in-law, (and so are) brothers-in-law’s sons, (and so are) sons-in-law, (and so are) sons-in-law’s sons, (and so are) sons of the same parents, (and so are) sons of different parents, (and so are) sons of the same mother, (and so are) sons of different mothers, (and so are) sons of the same father, (and so are) sons of different fathers, (and so are) sons of the same mother and father, (and so are) sons of different mothers and fathers, (and so are) sons of the same mother and different fathers, (and so are) sons of different mothers and different fathers, (and so are) sons of the same mother and different fathers, (and so are) sons of different mothers and different fathers, (and so are) sons of the same mother and different fathers, (and so are) sons of different mothers and different fathers, (and so are) sons of the same mother and different fathers, (and so are) sons of different mothers and different fathers, (and so are) sons of the same mother and different fathers, (and so are) sons of different mothers and different fathers, (and so are) sons of the same mother and different fathers, (and so are) sons of different mothers and different fathers, (and so are) sons of the same mother and different fathers, (and so are) sons of different mothers and different fathers, (and so are) sons of the same mother and different fathers, (and so are) sons of different mothers and different fathers, (and so are) sons of the same mother and different fathers, (and so are) sons of different mothers and different fathers, (and so are) sons of the same mother and different fathers, (and so are) sons of different mothers and different fathers, (and so are) sons of the same mother and different fathers, (and so are) sons of different mothers and different fathers, (and so are) sons of the same mother and different fathers, (and so are) sons of different mothers and different fathers, (and so are) sons of the same mother and different fathers, (and so are) sons of

original: “Nāgavatā, sīhavatā, ājaññavatā” iccādīsu bhāve vantupaccayaṃ icchanti.
analyzed: nāgavatā sīhavatā ājaññavatā iccādīsu bhāve vantu paccayam icchanti
translated: In such words as nāgavatā, sīhavatā, ājaññavatā, they want the augment -vant- in the sense of “state”.

original: Mātu bhātā mātulo, ulo.
analyzed: mātu bhātā
translated: The brother of a mother is a mātula, an uncle.

original: Iti niddiṭṭhapaccayarāsi.
analyzed: iti niddiṭṭha paccaya rāsi
translated: So the mass of stated roots is finished.

original: Vuddhirāsi
analyzed: vuddhiḥ āsi
translated: The mass of augmentations

original: ‘Padānamādissāyuvaṇṇassāeo ṇānubandhe’ti padādibhūtānaṃ akāra, ivaṇṇu’vaṇṇānaṃ ā, e, ovuddhi.
analyzed: ṇa anubandha iti pada ādi bhūtānam akāraḥ ā e o vuddhi
translated: ‘In the middle of a word, after a, i, u, v, the augmentations ā, e, o, ṁ, are added, if the following letter is not a vowel’ .

original: Ādicco, vāsiṭṭho, venateyyo, meniko, pettikaṃ, odumbaraṃ, oḷumpiko, odagyaṃ, dobhaggaṃ, sobhaggaṃ iccādi.
analyzed: ādiccaḥ vāsiṭṭhaḥ venateyyaḥ menikaḥ pettikam odumbaram oḷumpikaḥ odagyam dobhaggam sobhaggam iccādi
translated: Ādicca, Vāseṭṭha, Vena-teyya, Menika, Pettika, Odumbara, Oḷumpika, Odagya, Dobhagga, Sobhagga, and so on.

original: Ṇānubandheti kiṃ? Nāmako, padako, purātano.
analyzed: ṇa anubandha iti
translated: What is meant by ‘if the following letter is not a vowel’? Nāmako, Padako, Purātano.

original: ‘Majjhe’ti suttena padamajjhepi vuddhi, vāseṭṭho, aḍḍhateyyo iccādi.🔽553. Saṃyogepi kvaci ka. 405; rū. 365; nī. 864; ‘pi’ (bahūsu natthi).
analyzed: majjhe ti suttena pada majjhe pi vuddhi vāseṭṭhaḥ aḍḍhateyyaḥ iccādi  saṃyoge pi kvaci ka rū nī pi bahūsu na atthi
translated: ‘In the middle’ . The augmentations are added in the middle of a word too, as in Vāseṭṭha, Aḍḍhateyya, and so on.🔽In the case of a compound, sometimes k, r, n, are added, if the following letter is not a vowel.

original: Ṇānubandhe paccaye pare saṃyogepi kvaci vuddhi hoti.
analyzed: ṇa anubandhe paccaye pare saṃyoge pi kvaci hoti
translated: In the case of a compound, sometimes the augmentations are added, if the following letter is not a vowel.

original: Petteyyo, pettikaṃ, decco, pamukhe sādhu pāmokkhaṃ, pamuditassa bhāvo pāmojjaṃ, vattabbanti vākyaṃ, bhajitabbanti bhāgyaṃ, bhoggaṃ, yoggaṃ iccādi.
analyzed: petteyyaḥ pettikam deccaḥ pamukhe sādhu pāmokkham pamuditassa bhāvaḥ pāmojjam vattabbanti vākyam bhajitabbanti bhāgyam bhoggam yoggam iccādi
translated: Petteyyo, pettikaṃ, decco, pamukhe sādhu pāmokkhaṃ, pamuditassa bhāvo pāmojjaṃ, vattabbanti vākyaṃ, bhajitabbanti bhāgyaṃ, bhoggaṃ, yoggaṃ iccādi.

original: Iti vuddhirāsi.
analyzed: iti vuddhiḥ āsi
translated: Thus the section on augment.

original: Loparāsi
analyzed: lopa rā asi
translated: Section on elision

original: ‘Lopovaṇṇivaṇṇāna’nti suttena ṇyamhi pare avaṇṇi’vaṇṇānaṃ lopo.
analyzed: lopaḥ vaṇṇi vaṇṇānam ti suttena ṇyamhi pare a vaṇṇi vaṇṇānam lopaḥ
translated: ‘Lopovaṇṇivaṇṇāna’nti suttena ṇyamhi pare avaṇṇi’vaṇṇānaṃ lopo.

original: Tattha avaṇṇe-paṇḍiccaṃ, tacchaṃ, dāyajjaṃ, dvidhā bhāvo dvejjhaṃ, karuṇāyeva kāruññaṃ iccādi.
analyzed: tattha avaṇṇepaṇḍiccam taccham dāyajjam dvidhā bhāvaḥ dvejjham karuṇāya iva kāruññam iccādi
translated: Therein, in avaṇṇe—paṇḍiccaṃ, tacchaṃ, dāyajjaṃ, dvidhā bhāvo dvejjhaṃ, karuṇāyeva kāruññaṃ iccādi.

original: Ivaṇṇe-adhipatissa bhāvo ādhipaccaṃ. Evaṃ ādicco, koṇḍañño iccādi.
analyzed: bhāvaḥ ādhipaccam evam ādiccaḥ koṇḍaññaḥ iccādi
translated: In ivaṇṇe—adhipatissa bhāvo ādhipaccaṃ. Evaṃ ādicco, koṇḍañño iccādi.

original: ‘Uvaṇṇassāvaṅa sare’ti sare pare uvaṇṇassa avaṅa hoti.
analyzed: sara iti sare pare uvaṇṇassa avaṅa hoti
translated: ‘Uvaṇṇassāvaṅa sare’ti sare pare uvaṇṇassa avaṅa hoti.

original: Ṇamhi-lahuno bhāvo lāghavaṃ, rāghavaṃ, jamburukkhe bhavaṃ jambavaṃ. Tathā kapilavatthumhi bhavaṃ kāpilavatthavaṃ, vanaṃ. Bhātuno apaccaṃ bhātabyo, gabyaṃ, dabyaṃ.
analyzed: bhāvaḥ lāghavam rāghavam jambu rukkhe bhavam jambavam tathā kapilavatthumhi bhavam kāpilavatthavam vanam bhātunaḥ apaccam bhātabyaḥ gabyam dabyam
translated: In ṇamhi—lahuno bhāvo lāghavaṃ, rāghavaṃ, jamburukkhe bhavaṃ jambavaṃ. Tathā kapilavatthumhi bhavaṃ kāpilavatthavaṃ, vanaṃ. Bhātuno apaccaṃ bhātabyo, gabyaṃ, dabyaṃ.

original: ‘Ṭe satissā…’ti ṭamhi paccaye vīsati, tīsatīnaṃ tilopo.
analyzed: ṭe satissa ati ṭamhi paccaye vīsati tīsatīnam ti lopaḥ
translated: ‘Ṭe satissā…’ti ṭamhi paccaye vīsati, tīsatīnaṃ tilopo.

original: Vīsatiyā pūraṇo vīso, ekūnavīso. Evaṃ tīso, ekūnatīso.
analyzed: vīsatiyā pūraṇaḥ vīsaḥ ekūnavīsaḥ evam tīsaḥ ekūnatīsaḥ
translated: The twenty is vīsa, the nineteen is ekūnavīsa. So too the thirty is tīsa, the twenty-nine is ekūnatīsa.

original: ‘Rānubandhentasarādissā’ti rānubandhe paccaye padantasarādīnaṃ lopo.
analyzed: ra anubandha inta sara ādissa ati ra anubandhe paccaye pada nta sara ādīnam lopaḥ
translated: The elision of the final -a of the preceding word is in rānubandhe paccaye padantasarādīnaṃ lopo.

original: Metteyyo, petteyyo, kivaṃ, kittakaṃ, īdī, īdikkho, īdiso, āhacca, upahacca, sakkacca, adhikicca, kiriyā, vedagū, pāragū iccādi.
analyzed: metteyyaḥ petteyyaḥ kivam kittakam īdī īdikkhaḥ īdisaḥ āhacca upahacca sakkacca adhikicca kiriyā vedagū pāragū iccādi
translated: Metteyyo, petteyyo, kivaṃ, kittakaṃ, īdī, īdikkho, īdiso, āhacca, upahacca, sakkacca, adhikicca, kiriyā, vedagū, pāragū, etc.

original: 554. Paccayānaṃ lopo ka. 391; rū. 423; nī. 830; moggallāne ‘lopo’ tveva dissati.
analyzed: paccayānam lopaḥ ka rū nī moggallāne lopaḥ tu eva dissati
translated: The elision of the final -a of the preceding word is in paccayānaṃ lopo ka. ; rū. ; nī. ; moggallāne ‘lopo’ tveva dissati.

original: Paccayānaṃ kvaci lopo hoti.
analyzed: paccayānam kvaci lopaḥ hoti
translated: The elision of the final -a of the preceding word is in paccayānaṃ kvaci lopo hoti.

original: Buddhe ratanaṃ paṇītaṃ, cakkhu suññaṃ attena vā attaniyena vā saṃ. ni. 4.85. Ettha
analyzed: buddhe ratanam paṇītam cakkhu suññam attena vā attaniyena vā sam ni ettha
translated: Buddhe ratanaṃ paṇītaṃ, cakkhu suññaṃ attena vā attaniyena vā saṃ. ni. .. Herein,

original: ca ratanassa bhāvo ratanaṃ, attano bhāvo attā, attano sakassa bhāvo attaniyanti evaṃ bhāvapaccayalopo.
analyzed: ca ratanassa bhāvaḥ ratanam attanaḥ bhāvaḥ attā attano sakassa bhāvaḥ evam bhāva paccaya lopaḥ
translated: the state of being a jewel is ratanaṃ, the state of being a self is attā, the state of being one’s own is attaniya. So the elision is of the state-of-being case-ending.

original: “Buddhānussati dhammānussati”ādīsu “buddhassa bhāvo buddho, buddhassa ayaṃ guṇo buddho”tiādinā nayena paccayalopo veditabbo.
analyzed: buddha anussati dhamma anussati ādīsu buddhassa bhāvaḥ buddhaḥ buddhassa ayam guṇaḥ buddhaḥ iti ādinā nayena paccaya lopaḥ veditabbaḥ
translated: In the phrases buddhānussati, dhammānussati, etc., the elision should be understood as that of the state-of-being case-ending in the sense of “The state of being a Buddha is a Buddha; this is a quality of a Buddha” , etc.

original: 555. Lopo vīmantuvantūnaṃ ka. 268; rū. 397; nī. 518.
analyzed: lopaḥ vīmantu vantu ūnam ka rū nī
translated: Lopo vīmantuvantūnaṃ.

original: Iyi’ṭṭhesu paresu vī, mantu, vantūnaṃ lopo hoti.
analyzed: iyiṭṭhesu paresu vī mantu vantūnam lopaḥ hoti
translated: In these and other such words, the syllables vī, mantu, and vantū are elided.

original: Medhāvīnaṃ atisayena medhāvīti medhiyo, medhiṭṭho, satimantānaṃ atisayena satimāti satiyo, satiṭṭho, guṇavantānaṃ atisayena guṇavāti guṇiyo, guṇiṭṭho.
analyzed: medhāvīnam atisayena medhāvī iti medhiyaḥ medhiṭṭhaḥ satimantānam atisayena satimāti satiyaḥ satiṭṭhaḥ guṇavantānam atisayena guṇavāti guṇiyaḥ guṇiṭṭhaḥ
translated: Medhāvīnaṃ atisayena medhāvī = medhiyo, medhiṭṭho. Satimantānaṃ atisayena satim = satiyo, satiṭṭho. Guṇavantānaṃ atisayena guṇavā = guṇiyo, guṇiṭṭho.

original: Iti loparāsi.
analyzed: iti lopa rāsi
translated: Thus the group of elisions.🔽The Minor Collection is finished.🔽The Collection of Various Kinds

original: Khuddakarāsi niṭṭhito.🔽Nānāttarāsi🔽556. Jo vuddhassiyiṭṭhesu ka. 262; rū. 391; nī. 513; caṃ. 4.3.50; pā. 5.3.61, 62.
analyzed: khuddaka rāsi niṭṭhito  nānāttarā asi  jaḥ vuddha ssiyiṭṭhesu ka rū nī cam pā
translated: Jo vuddhassiyiṭṭhesu.

original: Iyi’ṭṭhapaccayesu paresu vuddhasaddassa jo hoti.
analyzed: iy iṭṭha paccayesu paresu vuddha saddassa jaḥ hoti
translated: In these and other such words, the syllable jo is added to the word vuddha.

original: Vuddhānaṃ atisayena vuddhoti jeyyo, jeṭṭho.🔽557. Bāḷhantikapasatthānaṃ sādhanedasajā ka. 263, 264, 265; rū. 392, 393, 394; nī. 512, 514, 515; caṃ. 4.3.49, 51; pā. 5.3.60, 63; ‘… dasā’ (bahūsu).
analyzed: vuddhānam atisayena vuddhaḥ iti jeyyaḥ jeṭṭhaḥ  bāḷha antika pasatthānam sādhana idasa jā ka rū    nī    caṃ   pā     dasā bahūsu
translated: Vuddhānaṃ atisayena vuddho = jeyyo, jeṭṭho.🔽Bāḷhantikapasatthānaṃ sādhanedasajā.

original: Iya, iṭṭhapaccayesu paresu bāḷha, antika, pasatthasaddānaṃ sādha, neda, sa, jādesā honti.
analyzed: iya iṭṭha paccayesu paresu bāḷha antika pasattha saddānam sādha neda sa ja ādesāḥ honti
translated: In these and other such words, the syllables bāḷha, antika, and pasattha are respectively sādha, neda, sa, and jāda.

original: Bāḷhānaṃ atisayena bāḷhoti sādhiyo, sādhiṭṭho, antikānaṃ atisayena antikoti nediyo, nediṭṭho, pasatthānaṃ atisayena pasatthoti seyyo, seṭṭho, jeyyo, jeṭṭho.
analyzed: bāḷhānam atisayena bāḷhaḥ iti sādhiyaḥ sādhiṭṭhaḥ antikānam atisayena antikaḥ iti nediyaḥ nediṭṭhaḥ pasatthānam atisayena pasatthaḥ iti seyyaḥ seṭṭhaḥ jeyyaḥ jeṭṭhaḥ
translated: The words sādhiyo, sādhiṭṭho are formed by adding the suffix -iyo to sādhu, sādhu, and the words nediyo, nediṭṭho are formed by adding the suffix -iyo to antika, antika. The words seyyo, seṭṭho, jeyyo, jeṭṭho are formed by adding the suffix -eyyo to su, su, and the suffix -eyyo to je, je.

original: 558. Kaṇakana appayuvānaṃ ka. 266, 267; rū. 395, 396; nī. 516, 517; caṃ. 4.3.53; pā. 5.3.64.🔽Iya, iṭṭhapaccayesu paresu appa, yuvasaddānaṃ kaṇa, kanaādesā honti.
analyzed: kaṇa kana appayuvānam ka rū nī  cam pā  iyaḥ iṭṭha paccayesu paresu appa yuva saddānam kaṇa kana ādesāḥ honti
translated: Kaṇakana appayuvānaṃ ka. , ; rū. , ; nī. , ; caṃ. ..; pā. ...

original: Appānaṃ navānaṃ atisayena appo navoti kaṇiyo, kaṇiṭṭho, yuvānaṃ taruṇānaṃ atisayena yuvā taruṇoti kaniyo, kaniṭṭho, kaniye vaye bhavā kaññā.
analyzed: appānam navānam atisayena appaḥ navaḥ iti kaṇiyaḥ kaṇiṭṭhaḥ yuvānam taruṇānam atisayena yuvā taruṇaḥ iti kaniyaḥ kaniṭṭhaḥ kaniye vaye bhavā kaññā
translated: The words kaṇiyo, kaṇiṭṭho are formed by adding the suffix -iyo to kaṇa, kaṇa, and the words kaniyo, kaniṭṭho are formed by adding the suffix -iyo to kana, kana, in the sense of “young” and “youthful.” The word kaṇṇā is formed by adding the suffix -ā to kaṇa, in the sense of “a young girl.”

original: 559. Kosajjājjava pārisajja suhajja maddavārisyāsa bhājaññatheyyabāhusaccā ka. 360, 361; rū. 387, 388; nī. 780, 781; ‘…rissā…” (bahūsu).🔽Bhāva, kammesu ṇānubandhe paccaye pare ete saddā nipaccante. Tattha ajjava, maddavā’sabhasaddā ṇamhi sijjhanti, sesā ṇyamhi.
analyzed: kosajja ajjava pārisajja suhajja madda vārisya asa bhājaññatheyya bāhusaccā ka   / rū    nī    rissā bahūsu 🔽bhāva kammesu ṇa anubandhe paccaye pare ete saddāḥ nipaccante tattha ajjava madda vāsabha saddāḥ ṇamhi sijjhanti sesāḥ ṇ yamhi
translated: Kosajjājjava pārisajja suhajja maddavārisyāsa bhājaññatheyyabāhusaccā ka. , ; rū. , ; nī. , ; ‘…rissā…” (bahūsu).🔽The words ajjava, maddava, etc., are formed by adding the suffix -a to ajjava, maddava, etc., in the sense of “absence of laziness,” “absence of harshness,” “absence of pride,” “absence of softness,” “absence of envy,” “absence of miserliness,” “absence of deceit,” and “absence of dishonesty.”

original: Tattha ujuno bhāvo ajjavaṃ, iminā suttena ṇamhi ussa attaṃ, ‘uvaṇṇassāvaṅa…’ iti
analyzed: tattha ujunaḥ bhāvaḥ iminā suttena iti
translated: Herein, the state of being upright is uprightness. By this Thread the self is exalted, ‘For the sake of praise, for the sake of fame, for the sake of a vehicle, for the sake of robes, for the sake of almsfood, for the sake of lodging, for the sake of medicines in sickness, for the sake of the various kinds of requisites, for the sake of heaven, for the sake of sovereignty, for the sake of a god’s station, for the sake of a wheel-turning monarchy, for the sake of a Sakka-ship, for the sake of a Maara-ship, for the sake of a Brahma-ship, for the sake of a disciple-ship, for the sake of a Paccekabuddha-ship, for the sake of Buddha-ship, for the sake of the extinction element without trace left, for the sake of the extinction element with trace left, for the sake of the extinction element with trace left and without trace left, for the sake of the extinction element without trace left and with trace left, for the sake of the extinction element with trace left and without trace left and with trace left and without trace left, for the sake without trace left and with trace left and without trace left and with trace left and without trace left, for the sake of the extinction element without trace left and with trace left and without trace left and with trace left and without trace left and with trace left and without trace left, for the sake of the extinction element with trace left and without trace left and with trace left and without trace left and with trace left and without trace left and with trace left and without trace left and with trace left and without trace left and with trace left and without trace left, for the sake of the extinction element without

original: ussa avattaṃ. Evaṃ muduno bhāvo maddavaṃ, usabhassa bhāvo āsabhaṃ, ussa āttaṃ. Kusitassa🔽kusītassa? bhāvo kosajjaṃ, iminā ilopo, tyassa jjattaṃ, parisāsu uppanno pārisajjo
analyzed: evam mudunaḥ bhāvaḥ maddavam usabhassa bhāvaḥ āsabham ussaḥ āttam kusitassa  kusītassa bhāvaḥ kosajjam iminā i lopaḥ tyassa jjattam parisāsu uppannaḥ pārisajjaḥ
translated: Herein, the state of being upright is uprightness, by this Sutta the ṇ-ending is ṇ-less, the state of being a bull is bull-ness, the state of being lazy is laziness, by this ḷ-ending is ḷ-less, the state of being a companion in the assemblies is companionship,

original: dī. ni. 2.215, dāgamo, suhadayova suhado, yalopo, suhadassa bhāvo sohajjaṃ jā. 1.5.23,
analyzed: dī ni da āgamaḥ suhadayoḥ iva suhadaḥ ya lopaḥ suhadassa bhāvaḥ sohajjam jā
translated: the state of being a good friend is good-friendship, the state of being a charioteer is charioteership, the state of being a sage is sagehood, the state of being a thoroughbred is thoroughbredness,

original: isino idaṃ ārisyaṃ, issa ārittaṃ, ājāniyassa ājānīyassātipi dissati bhāvo ājaññaṃ,🔽yalopo, puna ‘lopovaṇṇivaṇṇāna’nti ilopo, tato paraṃ sandhirūpaṃ, ājāniyo eva vā🔽ājañño jā. 1.1.24, sakatthe ṇyo, thenassa bhāvo, kammaṃ vā theyyaṃ, nassa yattaṃ,
analyzed: isinaḥ idam ārisyam isse ārittam ājāniyassa ājānīyassa atipi dissati bhāvaḥ ājaññam  ya lopaḥ tatas param sandhi rūpam eva vā  ājaññaḥ jā saka tthe ṇyaḥ thenassa bhāvaḥ kammam vā theyyam nassa yattam
translated: the state of being a thief is thievery, the state of being learned is learning, the state of being a deed is a deed, the state of being a thief is thievery,

original: bahusutassa bhāvo bāhusaccaṃ, ussa attaṃ, puna sandhirūpaṃ.
analyzed: bahu sutassa bhāvaḥ bāhusaccam puna sandhi rūpam
translated: the state of being learned is learning, the state of being a deed is a deed, the state of being a thief is thievery, the state of being learned is learning, the state of being a deed is a deed, the state of being a thief is thievery, the state of being learned is learning, the state of being a deed is a deed, the state of being a thief is thievery, the state of being learned is learning, the state of being a deed is a deed, the state of being a thief is thievery, the state of being learned is learning, the state of being a deed is a deed, the state of being a thief is thievery, the state of being learned is learning, the state of being a deed is a deed, the state of being a thief is thievery, the state of being learned is learning, the state of being a deed is a deed, the state of being a thief is thievery, the state of being learned is learning, the state of being a deed is a deed, the state of being a thief is thievery, the state of being learned is learning, the state of being a deed is a deed, the state of being a thief is thievery, the state of being learned is learning, the state of being a deed is a deed, the state of being a thief is thievery, the state of being learned is learning, the state of being a deed is a deed, the state of being a thief is thievery, the state of being learned is learning, the state of being a deed is a deed, the state of being a thief is thievery, the state of being learned is learning, the state of being a deed is a deed

original: 560. Adhātussa ke pāṇiniye, cande ca ‘kāka’iti pañcamyantaṃ dissate syādito ghessi ka. 404; rū. 370; nī. 859.
analyzed: a dhātussa ke pāṇiniye cande ca kāka iti pañcamī antam dissate syāt itas gha issi ka rū nī
translated: In the case of a non-syllable, in the word pāṇiniya, and in the word ‘kāka’ which ends in the fifth case, the form will be ghe+ssa+i, according to the sutta syādito ghessi ka.

original: ‘Ghessī’ti ghe+assa+i, chapadamidaṃ suttaṃ.
analyzed: cha padam idam suttam
translated: ‘Ghessī’ means ghe+ssa+i. This is a sutta with six terms.

original: Adhātussa avayavabhūte kakāre pare pubbassa akārassa bahulaṃ i hoti kanissite ghe asyādito pare sati.
analyzed: a dhātussa avayava bhūte kakāre pare pubbassa akārassa bahulam i hoti ka nissite ghe asya āditaḥ pare sati
translated: In the case of a non-syllable, that is, in the case of the syllable ka which is a component part, the i is substituted for the preceding a in the great majority of instances when the word ends in kanissite ghe asyādito.

original: Bālikā, ekikā, hatthipotikā, mahallikā, kumbhakārikā, kammakārikā, annadāyikā, upāsikā, sāvikā, dhammavācikā.
analyzed: bālikā ekikā hatthi potikā mahallikā kumbhakārikā kamma kārikā anna dāyikā upāsikā sāvikā dhamma vācikā
translated: Bālikā, ekikā, hatthipotikā, mahallikā, kumbhakārikā, kammakārikā, annadāyikā, upāsikā, sāvikā, dhammavācikā.

original: Adhātussāti kiṃ? Kulupakā- bhikkhunī, dhenupakā, khīrupakā-vacchī, idha dhātvādesopi kakāro dhātusaññaṃ labhatiyeva.
analyzed: a dhātussa ati kim kulupakā bhikkhunī dhenupakā khīrupakā vacchī idha dhātu ādesaḥ api kakāraḥ dhātu saññam labhatiyā iva
translated: In the case of a non-syllable: what is meant by this? Kulupakā- bhikkhunī, dhenupakā, khīrupakā-vacchī. Here the syllable ka in the words dhātvāde is regarded as a non-syllable.

original: Keti kiṃ? Vedanā, cetanā.
analyzed: kā iti kim vedanā cetanā
translated: In the case of a non-syllable: what is meant by this? Vedanā, cetanā.

original: Asyāditoti kiṃ? Bahuparibbājakā-rājadhānī.
analyzed: asya āditas ti kim bahu paribbājaka arājadhānī
translated: In the case of a non-syllable: what is meant by this? Bahuparibbājakā-rājadhānī.

original: Assāti kiṃ? Bahukattukā-sālā.
analyzed: assa ati kim bahu kattu kāsālā
translated: In the case of a non-syllable: what is meant by this? Bahukattukā-sālā.

original: Ettha ca bahavo paribbājakā yassā sā bahuparibbājakāti viggaho. Paribbājakasaddo
analyzed: ettha ca bahavaḥ paribbājakāḥ yassā sā bahu paribbājakā iti viggahaḥ paribbājaka saddaḥ
translated: And here the analysis is as follows: bahu paribbājakā yassā sā bahuparibbājakā. The word paribbājaka is a noun formed with the suffix -aka from the verb paribbajati .

original: pakatisyādisaddo hoti, tasmā kanissitassa ghasaññassa ākārassa syādito parattā pubbassa
analyzed: pakati sya ādi saddaḥ hoti tasmā ka nissitassa gha saññassa ākārassa syāt itas para ttā pubbassa
translated: The word is in the ordinary form, therefore, because of the ending in the instrumental case, the form of the word “Kanissita” is not “assa”

original: assa ittaṃ na bhavati. Yadi bhaveyya, bahukā paribbājikāyo yassanti atthappasaṅgo siyāti.
analyzed: assa ittam na bhavati yadi bhaveyya bahukā paribbājikāyaḥ yassanti attha ppasaṅgaḥ siyāti
translated: but “yassa”. If it were, the meaning of “the many female wanderers” would be connected.

original: Iti nānāttarāsi niṭṭhito.
analyzed: iti niṭṭhitaḥ
translated: Thus the section on the different meanings is finished.

original: Iti niruttidīpaniyā nāma moggallānabyākaraṇa-
analyzed: iti niruttidīpaniyā nāma moggallāna byākaraṇa
translated: Thus the commentary called “The Elucidator” on the Mogharāja-vyākaraṇa,

original: Dīpaniyā taddhitakaṇḍo pañcamo.
analyzed: dīpaniyā taddhita kaṇḍaḥ pañcamaḥ
translated: The fifth section of the Elucidator on the Taddhita.

original: 6. Ākhyātakaṇḍa
analyzed: ākhyāta kaṇḍa
translated: The section on the verb

original: Suddhakatturūpa
analyzed: suddha kattu rūpa
translated: The four-form pure

original: Atha dhātupaccayasaṃsiddhaṃ kāla, kāraka, purisa, saṅkhyābhedadīpakaṃ liṅgabhedarahitaṃ kriyāpadhānavācakaṃ tyādyantanāmakaṃ ākhyātapadaṃ dīpiyate.
analyzed: atha dhātu paccaya saṃsiddham liṅga bheda rahitam kriyā apadhāna vācakam tyādi anta nāmakam ākhyāta padam dīpiyate
translated: Now the verbal noun, which is formed by the addition of a suffix to a verbal root, which shows the difference of time, agent, and number, which is devoid of gender, and which expresses the action as the principal thing, is elucidated.

original: Tattha kriyaṃ dhāretīti dhātu. Sā pakatidhātu, vikatidhātu, nāmadhātuvasena tividhā.
analyzed: kriyam dhārā iti iti dhātu sā pakati dhātu vikati dhātu nāma dhātu vasena tividhā
translated: Herein, a verbal root is that which bears an action. It is threefold as the ordinary root, the modified root, and the nominal root.

original: Tattha bhū, hū, gamu, paca iccādi pakatidhātu nāma sabhāvena siddhattā.
analyzed: bhū hū gamu paca iccādi pakati dhātu nāma sa bhāvena
translated: Herein, the ordinary root is such as “bhū”, “hū”, “gamu”, “paca”, etc., because it is established by its own nature.

original: Titikkha, tikiccha, bubhukkha, jighacchaiccādi vikatidhātu nāma saṅkhatavasena siddhattā.
analyzed: titikkha tikiccha bubhukkha jighaccha aicca ādi vikati dhātu nāma saṅkhata vasena
translated: The verbal roots such as “to endure,” “to cure,” “to be hungry,” “to be thirsty,” etc., are called “devoid of a noun” because they are established by way of the formed .

original: Puttīya, pabbatāya iccādi nāmadhātu nāma nāmabhūtassa sato kriyavācīpaccayayogena dhātuṭṭhāne ṭhitattā.
analyzed: puttīya pabbatāya iccādi nāmadhātu nāma nāma bhūtassa sato kriya vācī paccaya yogena dhātu ṭṭhāne ṭhita ttā
translated: The verbal roots such as “to be a woman,” “to be a mountain,” etc., are called “having a noun” because they stand in the place of a verbal root by way of a relation of condition that expresses an action of a noun that exists.

original: Pakatidhātu ca sakammikā’kammikavasena duvidhā.
analyzed: pakati dhātu ca sa kammika akammika vasena duvidhā
translated: The verbal roots are twofold as “having an agent” and “having no agent.”

original: Tatthayā dhātu kammāpekkhaṃ kriyaṃ vadati, sā sakammikā nāma. Gāmaṃ gacchati, odanaṃ pacati iccādi.
analyzed: dhātu kamma apekkham kriyam vadati sā sa kammikā nāma gāmam gacchati odanam pacati iccādi
translated: Herein, the verbal root that expresses an action that requires an agent is called “having an agent,” e.g., “he goes to the village,” “he cooks rice.”

original: Yā kammanirapekkhaṃ kriyaṃ vadati, sā akammikā nāma. Bhavati, hoti, tiṭṭhati, seti iccādi.
analyzed: yā kamma nirapekkham kriyam vadati sā akammikā nāma bhavati hoti tiṭṭhati sā iti iccādi
translated: The verbal root that expresses an action that does not require an agent is called “having no agent,” e.g., “it is,” “it exists,” “it stands,” “it sits.”

original: Sakammikā ca ekakammika, dvikammikavasena duvidhā.
analyzed: sa kammikā ca ekakammika dvikammika vasena duvidhā
translated: And those having an agent are twofold as “having one agent” and “having two agents.”

original: Tattha yā ekakammāpekkhaṃ kriyaṃ vadati, sā ekakammikā nāma. Gāmaṃ gacchati, odanaṃ pacati iccādi.
analyzed: tattha yā eka kamma apekkham kriyam vadati sā ekakammikā nāma gāmam gacchati odanam pacati iccādi
translated: Herein, the verbal root that expresses an action that requires one agent is called “having one agent,” e.g., “he goes to the village,” “he cooks rice.”

original: Yā padhānā’padhānavasena kammadvayāpekkhaṃ kriyaṃ vadati, sā dvikammikā nāma.
analyzed: yā padhāna apadhāna vasena kamma dvaya apekkham kriyam vadati sā dvikammikā nāma
translated: The verbal root that expresses an action that requires two agents by way of the principal and the subordinate is called “having two agents.”

original: Sā ca nyādi, duhādivasena duvidhā.
analyzed: sā ca nyādi duhā ādi vasena duvidhā
translated: And that is twofold as “having ny etc.,” and “having duh etc.”

original: Tattha yā dhātu pāpanatthā hoti, sā nyādi nāma. Ajaṃ gāmaṃ neti, bhāraṃ gāmaṃ vahati, sākhaṃ gāmaṃ ākaḍḍhati.🔽Sesā dvikammikā duhādi nāma. Gāviṃ khīraṃ duhati, brāhmaṇaṃ kambalaṃ yācati, dāyakaṃ🔽bhikkhaṃ bhikkhati, goṇaṃ vajaṃ rundhati, bhagavantaṃ pañhaṃ pucchati, sissaṃ dhammaṃ
analyzed: tattha yā dhātu pāpanatthā hoti sā nyādi nāma ajam gāmam neti bhāram gāmam vahati sa akham gāmam ākaḍḍhati  sesāḥ dvikammikāḥ duha ādi nāma gāvim khīram duhati brāhmaṇam kambalam yācati dāyakam  bhikkham bhikkhati goṇam vajam rundhati bhagavantam pañham pucchati sissam dhammaṃ
translated: Herein, that which is the meaning of the word “cow” is the name “ox” . It takes the milk to the village, it carries the load to the village, it pulls the plough to the village.🔽The rest, which is the meaning of the word “cow” and the meaning of the word “milk” and so on, is the name “duhhī” . It milks the cow, it asks the brahmin, it begs the alms, it ploughs the field, it asks the Blessed One, it teaches the pupil, it is the name “duhhī” .🔽

original: anusāsati, bhagavā bhikkhū etaṃ [vacanaṃ] avoca, rājā amaccaṃ vacanaṃ bravīti iccādi.
analyzed: anusāsati bhagavā bhikkhū etam vacanam avoca rājā amaccam vacanam bravīti iccādi
translated: Herein, the noun-base that is the meaning of the verb is called the “nominative case”. It is the “cow” in “The cow gives milk”, the “Brahmin” in “The Brahmin wears a blanket”, the “beggar” in “The beggar begs for alms”, the “bull” in “The bull draws the plough”, the “Lord” in “The Lord answers the question”, the “pupil” in “The pupil learns the Dhamma”, the “monks” in “The Lord spoke this to the monks”, the “minister” in “The king speaks this to the minister”, and so on.

original: Tattha yadā kammasmiṃ rūpaṃ sijjhati, tadā vibhatti, paccayā nyādimhi padhānakammaṃ🔽vadanti, duhādimhi apadhānakammaṃ, sabbadhātūsu kāritayoge kāritakammanti, sabbañcetaṃ
analyzed: tattha yadā kammasmim rūpam sijjhati tadā vibhatti paccayā ni ādimhi padhāna kammaṃ  vadanti duha ādimhi apadhāna kammam sabba dhātūsu kārita yoge kārita kammanti sabbam ca etam
translated: Herein, when the verbal noun is formed, then the case-ending is the primary function in the nominative case,🔽the secondary function in the accusative case, and the derivative function in the other cases.

original: dhātūnaṃ pakatiatthavasena vuttaṃ, anekatthattā pana dhātūnaṃ atthantaravacane vā
analyzed: dhātūnam pakati attha vasena vuttam aneka attha ttā pana dhātūnam atthantara vacane vā
translated: But in all the cases the derivative function is the function of the verbal noun. All this is said with reference to the normal meaning of the verbal nouns. But because the verbal nouns have many meanings,

original: nānupasaggayoge vā akammikāpi sakammikā honti, sakammikāpi akammikā honti.
analyzed: na an upasagga yoge vā akammikāḥ api sa kammikāḥ honti sa kammikāḥ api akammikāḥ honti
translated: when they express a different meaning or a different function, then even the non-function is the function and the function is the non-function.

original: Atthantaravacane tāva –
analyzed: atthantara vacane tāva
translated: As regards the expression of the meaning of the prefix vi,

original: Vida – sattāyaṃ, dhammo vijjati, saṃvijjati.
analyzed: vida sattā ayam dhammaḥ vijjati saṃvijjati
translated: Vida – sattāyaṃ, dhammo vijjati, saṃvijjati.

original: Vida – ñāṇe, dhammaṃ vidati.
analyzed: vidaḥ ñāṇe dhammam vidati
translated: Vida – ñāṇe, dhammaṃ vidati.

original: Vida – lābhe, dhanaṃ vindati.
analyzed: vida lābhe dhanam vindati
translated: Vida – lābhe, dhanaṃ vindati.

original: Vida – anubhavane, sukhaṃ vedeti, vipākaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti ma. ni. 3.303.
analyzed: vida anubhavane sukham veda iti vipākam paṭisaṃveda iti
translated: Vida – anubhavane, sukhaṃ vedeti, vipākaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti ma. ni. ..

original: Vida – ārocane, vedayāmahaṃ bhante vedayatīti maṃ dhāretu cūḷava. aṭṭha. 102, kāraṇaṃ nivedeti, dhammaṃ paṭivedeti iccādi.
analyzed: vide ārocane vedayāmaham bhante vedayati iti mama dhāretu cūḷava aṭṭha kāraṇam nivedeti dhammam paṭivedeti iccādi
translated: Vida – ārocane, vedayāmahaṃ bhante vedayatīti maṃ dhāretu cūḷava. aṭṭha. , kāraṇaṃ nivedeti, dhammaṃ paṭivedeti iccādi.

original: Nānupasaggayoge –
analyzed: na an upasagga yoge
translated: As regards the expression of the meaning of the prefix na,

original: Pada-gatiyaṃ, maggaṃ pajjati, paṭipajjati, maggo uppajjati, nipajjati, sampajjati,
analyzed: pada gatiyam maggam pajjati paṭipajjati maggaḥ uppajjati nipajjati sampajjati
translated: Pada – gatiyaṃ, maggaṃ pajjati, paṭipajjati, maggo uppajjati, nipajjati, sampajjati,

original: bhogo bhavati, sambhavati, bhogaṃ anubhavati, taṇhaṃ abhibhavati, paribhavati, adhibhavati,
analyzed: bhogaḥ bhavati sambhavati bhogam anubhavati taṇham abhibhavati paribhavati adhibhavati
translated: bhogo bhavati, sambhavati, bhogaṃ anubhavati, taṇhaṃ abhibhavati, paribhavati, adhibhavati,

original: araññaṃ abhisambhavati, ajjhogāhatīti attho. Gacchantaṃ magge abhisambhavati, sampāpuṇātīti attho iccādi.
analyzed: araññam abhisambhavati ajjhogāhati iti atthaḥ gacchantam magge abhisambhavati sampāpuṇāti iti atthaḥ iccādi
translated: araññaṃ abhisambhavati, ajjhogāhatīti attho. Gacchantaṃ magge abhisambhavati, sampāpuṇātīti attho iccādi.

original: Padānaṃ byañjanasampattiyā vā atthasampattiyā vā upakārakā vibhatti, paccayā paccayā nāma.🔽Tattha vibhattiyo tyādi, tvādiiccādinā aṭṭhavidhā bhavanti, sarūpato channavutividhā.
analyzed: padānam byañjana sampattiyāḥ vā attha sampattiyāḥ vā upakārakā vibhatti paccayā paccayā nāma  tattha vibhattiyaḥ tyādi tu ādi icca ādinā aṭṭhavidhāḥ bhavanti sarūpato channavutividhā
translated: The declensions that are helpful to the fulfilment of the letters or the meaning of the words are called “cases” .🔽Herein, the declensions are eightfold as “the nominative” and so on, and as “the vocative” and so on, and so they are ninety-six in all according to the individual forms.

original: Tattha pubbachakkabhūtāni aṭṭhacattālīsarūpāni parassapadāni nāma. Parachakkabhūtāni aṭṭhacattālīsarūpāni attanopadāni nāma.
analyzed: tattha pubba chakka bhūtāni aṭṭha cattālīsa rūpāni parassapadāni nāma para chakka bhūtāni aṭṭha cattālīsa rūpāni attanopadāni nāma
translated: Herein, the eighty-eight forms that are the first-mentioned are called “other- related words,” and the eighty-eight that are the second-mentioned are called “self-related words.”

original: Tattha parahitapaṭisaṃyuttesu ṭhānesu pavattibahulāni padāni parassapadāni nāma. Attahitapaṭisaṃyuttesu pavattibahulāni attanopadāni nāmāti eke.
analyzed: tattha para hita paṭisaṃyuttesu ṭhānesu pavatti bahulāni padāni parassapadāni nāma atta hita paṭisaṃyuttesu pavatti bahulāni attanopadāni nāma ati eke
translated: Herein, some say that the words that occur mostly in contexts connected with the welfare of another are called “other-related words,” and those that occur mostly in contexts connected with one’s own welfare are called “self-related words.”

original: Paro vuccati kattā sabbakriyāsādhāraṇattā, attā vuccati kammaṃ sakasakakriyāsādhāraṇattā,
analyzed: paraḥ vuccati kattā sabba kriyā sādhāraṇa ttā attā vuccati kammam saka saka kriyā sādhāraṇa ttā
translated: Others say that the doer is called “another” because of his commonality with all actions, and the action is called “self” because of its commonality with each kind of action.

original: parassa abhidhāyakāni padāni parassapadāni, attano abhidhāyakāni padāni attanopadānīti aññe.
analyzed: parassa abhidhāyakāni padāni parassa padāni attanaḥ abhidhāyakāni padāni attanopadāni iti aññe
translated: And they say that words that denote another are “other-related words,” and words that denote a self are “self-related words.”

original: Attā vuccati padatthānaṃ sarīrabhūtā kriyā, kattunā pana sādhyaṭṭhena kriyarūpāni bhāva, kammānipi attāti vuccanti. Sādhakaṭṭhena tehi parabhūto kattā paro nāmāti apare.🔽Attā vuccati amhattho, paro vuccati tumha, nāmattho, pubbachakkāni parabahulattā
analyzed: attā vuccati padatthānam sarīra bhūtā kriyā kattunā pana sādhya ṭṭhena kriya rūpāni attā ati vuccanti sādhaka ṭṭhena tehi para bhūtaḥ kattā paraḥ nāma ati apare  attā vuccati amhattho paraḥ vuccati nāma attho pubba chakkāni para bahula ttā
translated: The word “self” is said to be a basis for the body, which is an action. But the states of action are said to be the self in the sense of what is to be accomplished by the doer. Others say that the doer is a different entity from the states in the sense of what is to be effected by them.🔽The word “self” is said to be the meaning of the first-person pronoun, and the word “other” is said to be the meaning of the second-person pronoun. The first-person pronouns are more numerous than the second-person pronouns,

original: parassapadāni nāma, parachakkāni pana rūḷhīvasena attanopadāni nāmātipi vadanti.
analyzed: parassapadāni nāma parachakkāni pana rūḷhī vasena attanopadāni nāma atipi vadanti
translated: and so the second-person pronouns are called “other” and the first-person pronouns are called “self” because they are used as if they were one’s own.

original: Idaṃ na yujjati parachakkesu tabbahulamattassāpi asiddhattā. Pāḷibhāsaṃ pana patvā
analyzed: idam na yujjati para chakkesu asiddha ttā pāḷibhāsam pana patvā
translated: This is not correct, because the predominance of the first-person pronouns is not established. But when one comes to the language of the texts,

original: dvinnaṃ chakkānaṃ attahita, parahitesu vā tīsu kārakesu vā pavattinānāttaṃ na dissatiyeva,
analyzed: dvinnam chakkānam atta hita para hitesu vā tīsu kārakesu vā pavatti nānā attam na
translated: the difference in the use of the two sets of pronouns in the two sets of three is not seen.

original: tasmā imasmiṃ ganthe taṃ nāmadvayaṃ na gahitanti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: tasmai imasmin ganthe tam nāma dvayam na gahitanti daṭṭhabbam
translated: Therefore it should be understood that these two terms are not included in this text.

original: Paccayā pana catubbidhā vikaraṇa, kicca, kārita, dhātupaccayavasena.
analyzed: paccayā pana catubbidhā vikaraṇa kicca kārita dhātu paccaya vasena
translated: Conditions are of four kinds: as transformation, as function, as cause, and as root-cause.

original: Tattha ye dhātusiddhāni tyādipadāni tabbādipadāni ca gaṇavibhāgavasena aññamaññaṃ visadisarūpāni karonti, te vikaraṇapaccayā nāma, la, ya, ṇoiccādayo.
analyzed: tattha ye dhātu siddhāni tya ādi padāni tabba ādi padāni ca gaṇa vibhāga vasena aññam aññam visadisa rūpāni karonti te vikaraṇa paccayāḥ nāma la ya ṇo icca ādayo
translated: Herein, the words beginning with dhātu and beginning with tabbādi, which make different forms by way of the division of the groups, are called the conditions of the change, namely, la, ya, ṇo, etc.

original: Bhāva, kammavisayo kyo kiccapaccayo nāma.
analyzed: bhāva kamma visayaḥ kicca paccayaḥ nāma
translated: The khya ending, which is the object of the state and the action, is called the condition of the action.

original: Paresaṃ āṇāpanasaṅkhāte payojakabyāpāre pavattā ṇi, ṇāpipaccayā kāritapaccayā nāma.
analyzed: paresam āṇāpana saṅkhāte payojaka byāpāre pavattā ṇi ṇāpi paccayā kārita paccayā nāma
translated: The ṇi and ṇāp endings, which occur in the function of the instigator called the instigation of others, are called the conditions of the doing.

original: Visuṃ taṃtaṃkriyavācībhāvena dhāturūpā kha, cha, saiccādikā paccayā dhātupaccayā nāma.
analyzed: visum taṃ taṃ kriya vācībhāvena dhātu rūpā kha cha sā e cca ādikā paccayā dhātu paccayā nāma
translated: The endings beginning with kha, cha, sa, etc., which occur as the forms of the roots, expressing this or that action separately, are called the conditions of the roots.

original: “Kāla, kāraka, purisa, saṅkhyābhedadīpaka”nti ettha atīta, paccuppannā’nāgata, kālavimuttavasena kālabhedo catubbidho.
translated: Herein, as regards the words “indicating the difference of time, the doer, the person, and number,” the difference of time is fourfold, as past, present, future, and time-free.

original: Tattha hiyyattanī, ajjattanī ajjatanī (bahūsu), parokkhāti imā tisso vibhattiyo atīte kāle vattanti.
analyzed: tattha hiyyattanī ajjattanī ajjatanī bahūsu parokkhā iti imāḥ tissaḥ vibhattiyaḥ atīte kāle vattanti
translated: Herein, the three cases ending in hiyyan, ajjhat, and ajjhat (in the plural), and the remote case, occur in the past time.

original: Vattamānā, pañcamīti dve paccuppanne.
analyzed: vattamānā pañcamī iti dve paccuppanne
translated: The two cases ending in vattamān and pañcamī occur in the present.

original: Ekā bhavissantī anāgate.
analyzed: ekā bhavissantī anāgate
translated: One occurs in the future.

original: Sattamī, kālātipattīti dve kālavimutte vattanti, ayaṃ kira porāṇiko vibhattīnaṃ kamo, so ca pāḷiyā sametiyeva.
analyzed: sattamī kāla atipattī iti dve kāla vimutte vattanti ayam kira porāṇikaḥ vibhattīnam saḥ ca
translated: The seventh and the third are used in the case of the two kinds of non-lapse of the proper occasion. This, it seems, is the order of the cases in the old commentaries, and it agrees with the texts.

original: “Sabbe saddhammagaruno, vihaṃsu viharanti ca.
analyzed: sabbe saddhamma garunaḥ vihaṃsu viharanti ca
translated: “All who are venerable for the True Idea,🔽They lived, they live, and they will live;

original: Athopi viharissanti, esā buddhāna dhammatā”ti a. ni. 4.21 ca –
analyzed: athopi viharissanti esā buddhāna dhammatā ati a ni ca
translated: This is the nature of Buddhas” .

original: “Abbhatītā ca ye buddhā, vattamānā anāgatā”ti ca apa. thera 1.1.588 pāḷī. Imasmiṃ
analyzed: ca ye buddhāḥ vattamānāḥ anāgatāti ca apa thera pāḷī imasmin
translated: “The Buddhas who are past, and those to come, and those now present” .

original: kame pañcamī, sattamīti nāmadvayampi anvatthavasena siddhaṃ bhavati. Pacchā pana
analyzed: kame pañcamī sattamī iti nāma dvayam pi anvattha vasena siddham bhavati pacchā pana
translated: In this order the fifth and the seventh are also established by implication. But later on,

original: garuno vatticchāvasena vibhattīnaṃ nānākamaṃ karonti.🔽Kattu, kamma, bhāvā pana kārakabhedo nāma. Tattha bhāvo duvidho sādhya, sādhanavasena
analyzed: garunaḥ vatti chā vasena vibhattīnam nānā kamam karonti  kattu kamma bhāvāḥ pana kāraka bhedaḥ nāma tattha bhāvaḥ duvidhaḥ sādhya sādhana vasena
translated: the venerable ones made the different orders of the cases according to the requirements of the verbal expression.🔽The doing, the action, and the state are the different kinds of agency. Herein, the state is twofold as what is to be accomplished and as what accomplishes.

original: visesana, visesyavasena ca. Tattha dhātvatthakriyā sādhyabhāvo nāma. Paccayatthakriyā sādhanabhāvo nāma.
analyzed: ca tattha dhātu attha kriyā sādhya bhāvaḥ nāma paccaya ttha kriyā sādhana bhāvaḥ nāma
translated: And it is twofold as what qualifies and as what is qualified. Herein, the state of what is to be accomplished is the root-meaning, the object-meaning, and the action-meaning. The state of what accomplishes is the condition-meaning and the action-meaning.

original: Tesu sādhyabhāvo nānādhātūnaṃ vasena nānāvidho hoti. Sādhanabhāvo nānādhātvatthānaṃ🔽pavattākārasaṅkhātena ekaṭṭhena ekova hoti. So pana yathā jāti nāma anuppannapakkhe
analyzed: tesu sādhya bhāvaḥ nānā dhātūnam vasena nānāvidhaḥ hoti sādhana bhāvaḥ nānā dhātu atthānam  pavatta ākāra saṅkhātena ekaṭṭhena ekaḥ eva hoti saḥ pana yathā jāti nāma anuppannapakkhe
translated: The state of being proved is of various kinds according to the various elements. The state of being a means of proving is of one kind only, according to the mode of occurrence called “having the characteristic of being a means of proving” .🔽But that is like the “birth” called “non-arising” in the future, which is of one kind only, according to the mode of occurrence called “non-arising,” and is of various kinds according to the various kinds of aggregates, etc.

original: ṭhite saṅkhatadhamme uppādentī viya khāyati, tathā vohāravisayamatte ṭhite sabbadhātvatthe🔽pātubhonte karonto viya khāyati, tasmā so sādhananti ca kārakanti ca vuccati. Yathā🔽ca jātivasena uppannā saṅkhatadhammā “cintanaṃ jātaṃ, phusanaṃ jāta” miccādinā ekantameva
analyzed: ṭhite saṅkhata dhamme uppādentī viya khāyati tathā vohāra visaya matte ṭhite sabba dhātu atthe  karontaḥ viya khāyati tasmā so sādhananti ca kārakanti ca vuccati yathā  ca jāti vasena uppannā saṅkhata dhammā cintanam jātam phusanam jāta miccādinā ekantam eva
translated: The state of being accomplished is of various kinds according to the various roots. The state of being a means is one only in the sense of the mode of occurrence of the various roots and meanings. But that appears as if it were making manifest the various meanings of the roots that are present as the mere field of usage, just as birth appears as if it were causing to arise formed dhammas that are present in the future period. That is why it is called “accomplished” and “making.”

original: jātiṃ visesenti, tathā paccayatthavasena pātubhontā nānādhātvatthāpi “bhuyyate, gamyate,🔽paccate, bhavanaṃ, gamanaṃ, pacana” miccādinā ekantameva paccayatthaṃ visesenti.
analyzed: jātim visesenti tathā paccaya ttha vasena nānā dhātvatthā api bhuyyate gamyate  paccate bhavanam gamanam pacanam iccādinā ekantam eva paccaya ttham visesenti
translated: And just as formed dhammas that have arisen by means of birth distinguish birth itself as one only by means of such expressions as “thinking has arisen, touching has arisen” , so too, the various meanings of the roots that are manifested by means of the meaning of the conditions distinguish the meaning of the conditions as one only by means of such expressions as “is eaten, is gone, is cooked, becoming, going, cooking” .

original: Vatticchāvasena pana bhāvasādhanapadesu dhātvattha, paccayatthānaṃ abhedopi vattuṃ
analyzed: vatti chā vasena pana bhāva sādhana padesu vattum
translated: But in the case of the words that express the state of being a means, the meaning of the roots and the meaning of the conditions are not distinguished as different even though they are not identical.

original: yujjatiyeva. Idha pana dvīsu bhāvesu sādhanabhāvo adhippetoti.🔽Paṭhama, majjhimu’ttamapurisā purisabhedo. ‘Puriso’ti ca “yaṃkiñcāyaṃ purisapuggalo
analyzed: idha pana dvīsu bhāvesu sādhana bhāvaḥ adhippeto ti  majjhima uttama purisā purisa bhedo purisaḥ ti ca yaṃ kiñca ayam purisa puggalo
translated: But here the meaning of the state of being an agent is intended in the two states.🔽The first, middle, and best men are the kinds of men.

original: paṭisaṃvedeti sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā”ti ma. ni. 3.1 ettha attā eva🔽vuccati, so ca attā “so karoti, so paṭisaṃvedetī”ti a. ni. 6.43; visuddhi. 2.580
analyzed: paṭisaṃvedeti sukham vā dukkham vā adukkham asukham vā ati ma ni ettha attā eva  vuccati so ca attā so karoti so paṭisaṃvedeti iti a ni
translated: And as to the word “man,” “whatever this person feels, whether pleasant, painful, or neither-painful-nor-pleasant” , it is the self that is called “man” here.🔽And that self is said to be the doer in the passage “He does, he experiences” , and it is said to be the agent in the passage “Purification is … of the agent” .

original: ettha kārakoti vuccati. Iti ‘puriso’ti kārako eva.
analyzed: ettha kārako ti vuccati iti puriso ti kārako eva
translated: So “man” is the agent.

original: So ca tividho nāmattho, tumhattho, amhattho cāti. Tattha attano ajjhattasantānabhūtattā🔽amhattho uttamapuriso nāma, sesā pana kamena paṭhamapuriso, majjhimapurisoti vuccanti.
analyzed: saḥ ca tividhaḥ nāma atthaḥ tumhatthaḥ amhatthaḥ ca ati tattha attanaḥ ajjhatta santāna bhūta ttā  uttamapurisaḥ nāma sesā pana kamena paṭhama puriso majjhima puriso ti vuccanti
translated: And that is threefold as the meaning of “I,” the meaning of “mine,” and the meaning of “other.” Herein,🔽the best man is called the meaning of “I” because he is the inner continuity of himself,🔽but the other two are called the first man and the middle man respectively according to their function.🔽But the case- endings get the names “first man” and so on because they illustrate that.

original: Vibhattiyo pana taddīpakattā paṭhamapurisādināmaṃ labhanti. Idañca nāmaṃ kārakabhede
analyzed: vibhattiyaḥ pana paṭhama purisa ādi nāmam labhanti idam ca nāmam kāraka bhede
translated: And since this name is included in the division of the agent,

original: antogadhamevāti katvā imasmiṃ ganthe na gahitanti.
analyzed: antogadham eva ati katvā imasmin ganthe na
translated: it is not taken in this stanza.

original: Saṅkhyābhedo duvidho ekatta, bahuttavasena.
analyzed: saṅkhyā bhedaḥ duvidhaḥ
translated: The numerical distinction is twofold, as one and as many.

original: ‘Liṅgabhedarahita’nti “puriso gacchati, itthī gacchati, kulaṃ gacchati” iccādīsu ‘puriso’iccādīnaṃ abhidheyyapadānaṃ liṅgānugato rūpabhedo ākhyātapade natthi.
analyzed: liṅga bheda rahitanti purisaḥ gacchati itthī gacchati kulam gacchati iccādīsu abhidheyya padānam liṅga anugataḥ rūpa bhedaḥ ākhyāta pade natthi
translated: ‘Without distinction of gender’ means that in such passages as ‘The man goes, the woman goes, the family goes’ there is no distinction of form in the words that follows on the words ‘man’, etc., as there is in such passages as ‘The man sees, the woman sees’.

original: ‘Kriyāpadhānavācaka’nti ettha kriyaṃ eva padhānato abhidhāti, na nāmapadaṃ viya dabbaṃ padhānato abhidhātīti adhippāyo.
