analyzed: kriyā padhāna vācakanti ettha kriyam eva padhānataḥ abhidhāti na nāma padam viya dabbam padhānataḥ abhidhāti iti adhippāyaḥ
translated: ‘Denoting the verb as the principal thing’ means that it denotes the verb as the principal thing, not as the mere thing denoted, as does a noun.

original: Tattha kriyā nāma dhātvatthabhāvo vuccati, sā ca kālavasena atītakriyā, paccuppannakriyā, anāgatakriyā, kālavimuttakriyāti catubbidhā hoti.
analyzed: tattha kriyā nāma dhātvattha bhāvaḥ vuccati sā ca kāla vasena atīta kriyā paccuppanna kriyā anāgata kriyā kāla vimutta kriyā ati catubbidhā hoti
translated: Herein, the verb is said to be the meaning of the root, and that is of four kinds as past, future, present, and timeless.

original: Āṇattikriyā, āsiṭṭhakriyā, anumatikriyā, parikappakriyā, araha, sakka, vidhi, nimantanā’mantanādikriyāti bahuvidho kriyābhedoti.
analyzed: āṇatti kriyā āsiṭṭha kriyā anumati kriyā parikappa kriyā araha bahuvidhaḥ kriyā bhedaḥ iti
translated: And the verb is of many kinds as optative, imperative, infinitive, gerund, and so on.

original: Bhū-sattāyaṃ, santassa bhāvo sattā, tassaṃ sattāyaṃ, bhūdhātu sattāyamatthe vattate, sabbapadatthānaṃ sadda, buddhivisayabhāvena vijjamānabhāve vattatetyattho.🔽561. Kriyatthā ka. 432, 455; rū. 362, 530; nī. 905, 936; pā. 3.1.91.
analyzed: bhū sattā ayam santassa bhāvaḥ sattā tassam sattā ayam bhū dhātu sattā ayam atthe vattate sabba pada tthānam buddhi visaya bhāvena vijjamāna bhāve  kriyatthā ka rū nī
translated: The state of being of the being is sattā. The state of being of that being is bhūdhātu. The word sattā is used in the sense of the state of being of all things. The meaning is: it is used in the sense of the state of being that exists by way of being the object of cognition.🔽The meaning of action: ka, ru, ni, pa.

original: Adhikārasuttamidaṃ, kriyatthā paraṃ vibhatti, paccayā bhavantīti attho. Kriyā attho
analyzed: adhikāra suttam idam param vibhatti paccayāḥ bhavanti iti attho kriyā attho
translated: This sutta is about the topic. The case endings are used for the meaning of action. The meaning is: they are conditions. The meaning of action

original: yassāti kriyattho. Pakatidhātu, vikatidhātu, nāmadhātuvasena tividho dhātu, kāritapaccayantarūpampi
analyzed: kriyatthaḥ pakati dhātu vikati dhātu nāma dhātu vasena tividhaḥ dhātu
translated: is that which has. The dhātu is threefold as the natural dhātu, the modified dhātu, and the nominal dhātu. The form that is the condition of action

original: vikatidhātumhi saṅgayhati.
analyzed: vikati dhātumhi saṅgayhati
translated: is included in the modified dhātu.

original: 562. Vattamāneti anti si tha mi ma te ante se vhe e mhe ka. 414; rū. 428; nī. 872; caṃ. 1.2.82; pā. 3.2.123.🔽Ārabhitvā niṭṭhaṃ anupagato bhāvo vattamāno nāma, taṃsambandhīkālopi tadūpacārena
analyzed: vattamāna iti anti si tha mi ma te ante se vhe e mhe ka rū nī caṃ pā  ārabhitvā niṭṭham anupagataḥ bhāvaḥ vattamānaḥ nāma
translated: The present: anti, si, tha, mi, ma, te, ante, se, vhe, e, mhe, ka, ru, ni, caṃ, pa.🔽The state that has begun but has not yet reached completion is called the present. The time that is related to that is also called the present by extension.

original: vattamānoti vuccati. Vattamāne kāle kriyatthā paraṃ tyādivibhattiyo bhavanti. Ayañca
analyzed: vattamānaḥ iti vuccati vattamāne kāle param tya ādi vibhattiyaḥ bhavanti ayam ca
translated: The case endings beginning with tyādi are used for the present time. This

original: vibhatti tyādīti ca vattamānakālavisayattā vattamānāti ca sijjhati.
analyzed: tyādi iti ca vattamāna kāla visaya ttā ca sijjhati
translated: And the expression “the case-ending -t- and so on” is established as “the present” because it is the domain of the present tense.

original: 563. Pubbāparachakkānamekānekesu tumhamhasesesu dve dve majjhimuttamapaṭhamā ka. 408; rū. 431; nī. 867.
analyzed: pubba apara chakkānam eka anekesu tumha mha sesesu dve dve majjhima uttama paṭhamā ka rū nī
translated: In the two sets of six, the middle, the last, and the first are the two each in the singular and plural.

original: Tumhanāmaṃ, amhanāmaṃ, tadubhayato sesanāmanti tīsu nāmesu payujjamānesu vā gamyamānesu🔽vā ekasmiṃ vā anekesu vā atthesu pubbachakka, parachakkānaṃ dve dve majjhima, uttama,
analyzed: tumha nāmam amha nāmam tat ubhayatas tīsu nāmesu payujjamānesu vā gamyamānesu  vā ekasmin vā anekesu vā atthesu pubba chakka para chakkānam dve dve majjhima uttama
translated: When the three kinds of noun are used or referred to, namely, the noun with the name-declension, the noun with the personal-declension, and the noun with the other-declension,

original: paṭhamā vibhattiyo bhavanti. “Uttamanti uttaraṃ antima”nti cūḷamoggallāne vuttaṃ.
analyzed: paṭhamāḥ vibhattiyaḥ bhavanti uttamanti uttaram antimanti cūḷamoggallāne vuttam
translated: then in the matter of the one or the many, the middle, the last, and the first case-endings of the two sets of six are the two each. “The last is the last, the last” is said in the Cullasaccaka Sutta.

original: Ettha ca vibhattividhānamukhena taṃtaṃsaññāvidhānampi siddhaṃ hoti.🔽Kathaṃ?Ti, anti, si, tha, mi, ma iti pubbachakkaṃ nāma.
analyzed: ettha ca vibhatti vidhāna mukhena taṃ taṃ saññā vidhānam pi siddham hoti  katham ti anti si tha mi me iti pubbachakkam nāma
translated: And here the demonstration of the various names is established by way of the demonstration of the case-endings.🔽How? The set of six “ti, anti, si, tha, mi, ma” is called the first set of six.

original: Te, ante, se, vhe, e, mhe iti parachakkaṃ nāma.
analyzed: te ante se vhe e mhe iti parachakkam nāma
translated: The set of six “te, ante, se, vhe, e, mhe” is called the second set of six.

original: Pubbachakke ca-ti, antidvayaṃ paṭhamadukaṃ nāma, si, thadvayaṃ majjhimadukaṃ nāma, mi, madvayaṃ uttamadukaṃ nāma. Evaṃ parachakke.
analyzed: pubba chakke anti dvayam paṭhama dukam nāma tha dvayam majjhima dukam nāma mi ma dvayam uttama dukam nāma evam para chakke
translated: And in the previous section: the first pair is called the first couplet, the second pair is called the middle couplet, and the third pair is called the last couplet. So too in the next section.

original: Tattha tulyādhikaraṇabhūte sesanāme payujjamāne vā gamyamāne vā paṭhamadukaṃ bhavati.
analyzed: tulya adhikaraṇa bhūte sesa nāme payujjamāne vā gamyamāne vā paṭhama dukam bhavati
translated: Herein, when the other names occurring in the same case are used or referred to, the first couplet is used.

original: Tathā tumhanāme majjhimadukaṃ, amhanāme uttamadukaṃ. Dukesu ca ekasmiṃ atthe vattabbe
analyzed: tathā tumha nāme majjhima dukam amha nāme uttama dukam dukesu ca ekasmin atthe vattabbe
translated: So too, when the names in the vocative case are used, the middle couplet is used, and when the names in the nominative case are used, the last couplet is used. And when a single person is to be spoken of in the couplets,

original: ekavacanaṃ, bahumhi vattabbe bahuvacanaṃ.🔽Ettha ca nāmānaṃ atthanissitā katvattha, kammatthā idha nāmatthāti vuccanti. Kattu,
analyzed: ekavacanam bahumhi vattabbe bahuvacanam  ettha ca nāmānam attha nissitā katvattha kammatthā idha nāmatthā ati vuccanti kattu
translated: the singular number is used, and when many are to be spoken of, the plural number is used.🔽And here the names are called “name-meanings” since they are based on meanings, and “action-meanings” since they are the meanings of verbs. The name-meaning is

original: kammasaṅkhāte yasmiṃ nāmatthe tyādivibhattiyo bhavanti, so nāmattho tyādivācakānaṃ
analyzed: kamma saṅkhāte yasmin nāmatthe tyādi vibhattiyaḥ bhavanti saḥ nāmatthaḥ tyādi vācakānam
translated: the meaning of a name in which the case endings such as the accusative, etc., occur. It is called a “name” because it is the mere expression of the meaning of the case endings such as the accusative, etc.,

original: eva vāccabhūto vuttattho nāma hoti, na syādivibhattīnaṃ.
analyzed: eva vācca bhūtaḥ vuttatthaḥ nāma hoti na
translated: and not the case endings themselves such as the accusative, etc.

original: Vuttakattu, kammādhiṭṭhānassa ca liṅgatthassa vācakaṃ nāmapadaṃ abhidheyyapadaṃ nāma, etadeva tulyādhikaraṇapadanti ca vuccati.
analyzed: vutta kattu kamma adhiṭṭhānassa ca liṅga tthassa vācakam nāma padam abhidheyya padam nāma etat eva tulya adhikaraṇa padan ti ca vuccati
translated: The word that expresses the name-meaning, which is the meaning of the gender of the nominative case, etc., is called a “word that denotes an entity.” This is also called a “word that has the same case-relation” .

original: Amādayo ca atthavācakavibhattiyo etasmiṃ okāsaṃ na labhanti, liṅgatthamattajotikā
analyzed: ama ādayo ca attha vācaka vibhattiyaḥ etasmin okāsam na labhanti liṅga attha matta jotikā
translated: And the case-endings which express the meaning of the case do not find room here,🔽only the first case-ending which indicates the mere meaning of the noun finds room.

original: paṭhamāvibhatti eva okāsaṃ labhati. Evarūpāni tulyādhikaraṇabhūtāni abhidheyyapadāni
analyzed: paṭhamā vibhatti eva okāsam labhati evarūpāni tulya adhikaraṇa bhūtāni abhidheyya padāni
translated: With reference to such words as are the subject of a sentence,

original: sandhāya sutte ‘tumhamhasesesū’ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: sandhāya sutte tumhamhasesesu iti vuttam
translated: it is said in the Suttas: ‘tumhamhasesesū’.

original: Idañca suttaṃ suddhehi tumha’mha, sesanāmehi yuttavākye ca missakehi yuttavākye cāti dvīsu dvīsu vākyesu veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: idam ca suttam suddhehi tumhamha sesa nāmehi yutta vākye ca missakehi yutta vākye ca ati dvīsu dvīsu vākyesu veditabbam
translated: And this Sutta should be understood in two kinds of sentences, namely, in those with pure tumha and amha and in those with mixed names.

original: Tattha suddhehi yutte paccekaṃ dukāni vattanti. Yathā? So gacchati, te gacchanti, tvaṃ gacchasi, tumhe gacchatha, ahaṃ gacchāmi, mayaṃ gacchāmāti.
analyzed: tattha suddhehi yutte paccekam dukāni vattanti yathā saḥ gacchati te gacchanti tvam gacchasi tumhe gacchatha aham gacchāmi mayam gacchāma iti
translated: Herein, in those with pure tumha and amha, the duals occur separately, as follows: He goes, they go, you go, you two go, I go, we go.

original: Tathā suddhadvandepi. Yathā? So ca so ca gacchati, gacchanti vā. Te ca te ca gacchanti,
analyzed: tathā suddhadvandā ipi yathā saḥ ca saḥ ca gacchati gacchanti vā te ca te ca gacchanti
translated: And so in the case of the pure vocative, as follows: He and he go, or they go. They and they go,

original: so ca te ca gacchanti, tvañca tvañca gacchasi, gacchatha vā. Tumhe ca tumhe ca gacchatha,🔽tvañca tumhe ca gacchathāti.
analyzed: sā u ca te ca gacchanti tvañca tvañca gacchasi gacchatha vā tumhe ca tumhe ca gacchatha 🔽tvañca tumhe ca gacchatha ati
translated: He and they go, you and you go, or you two go, you and you two go, you and they go.

original: Missakehi yutte dvandavākye pana ‘vippaṭisedhe’ti saṅketattā paradukāni eva okāsaṃ
analyzed: missakehi yutte dvanda vākye pana vippaṭisedheti saṅketa ttā paradukāni eva okāsam
translated: But in a compound of two words with a copula, because of the convention ‘vippaṭisedhe’, only the other’s dukas get the opportunity,

original: labhanti, tesu ca bahuvacanāni eva. Yathā? So ca tvañca gacchatha, so ca ahañca gacchāma,
analyzed: labhanti tesu ca bahuvacanāni eva yathā saḥ ca tvañca gacchatha saḥ ca ahañca gacchāma
translated: and among them only the plurals. How? You and he go. He and I go.

original: tvañca ahañca gacchāma, so ca tvañca ahañca gacchāma. Ekavacanacatukkaṃ.🔽Te ca tumhe ca gacchatha, te ca mayañca gacchāma, tumhe ca mayañca gacchāma, te ca tumhe ca mayañca gacchāma. Bahuvacanacatukkaṃ.🔽So ca tumhe ca gacchatha, so ca mayañca gacchāma, tvañca mayañca gacchāma, so ca tvañca mayañca gacchāma. Ekavacanamūlacatukkaṃ.
analyzed: tvañca aham ca gacchāma saḥ u ca tvañca aham ca gacchāma ekavacana catukkam  te ca tumhe ca gacchatha te ca mayan ca gacchāma tumhe ca mayan ca gacchāma te ca tumhe ca mayan ca gacchāma bahuvacana catukkam  saḥ ca tumhe ca gacchatha saḥ ca mayan ca gacchāma tvañca mayan ca gacchāma saḥ ca tvañca mayan ca gacchāma ekavacana mūla catukkam
translated: You and I go. He and you and I go. The singular set of four.🔽You and they go. They and we go. You and we go. They and you and we go. The plural set of four.🔽He and you go. He and we go. You and we go. He and you and we go. The set of four based on the singular.

original: Te ca tvañca gacchatha, te ca ahañca gacchāma, tumhe ca ahañca gacchāma, te ca tumhe ca ahañca gacchāma. Bahuvacanamūlacatukkaṃ.
analyzed: te ca tvañca gacchatha te ca aham ca gacchāma tumhe ca aham ca gacchāma te ca tumhe ca aham ca gacchāma bahuvacana mūla catukkam
translated: They and you go. They and I go. You and I go. They and you and I go. The set of four based on the plural.

original: Api ca tvañca so ca gacchatha, ahañca so ca gacchāma, tvañca ahañca so ca gacchāma,
analyzed: api ca tvam ca saḥ u ca gacchatha ahan ca saḥ u ca gacchāma tvam ca ahan ca saḥ u ca gacchāma
translated: And you and he are going, and you and he are coming, and you and he and I are going,

original: tumhe ca so ca gacchatha, mayañca so ca gacchāma, tvañca te ca gacchatha, ahañca
analyzed: tumhe ca saḥ ca gacchatha mayan ca saḥ ca gacchāma tvañca te ca gacchatha ahañca
translated: and you and he are going, and we and he are coming, and you and they are going, and we and they are coming,

original: te ca gacchāmaiccādīnipi catukkāni veditabbāni.
analyzed: te ca catukkāni veditabbāni
translated: and so on.

original: Atrimā pāḷī – tuvañca putto suṇisā ca nattā, sammodamānā gharamāvasetha jā. 1.8.7. Ahañca putto suṇisā ca nattā, sammodamānā gharamāvasema jā. 1.8.7.
analyzed: tuvam ca puttaḥ suṇisā ca nattā sammodamānā gharam āvasetha jā  aham ca puttaḥ suṇisā ca nattā sammodamānā gharam āvasema jā
translated: The following is the text: “You and your son and daughter-in-law and grandson, all of you, should live in the house, delighting in the house” . . . “We and our son and daughter-in-law and grandson, all of us, should live in the house, delighting in the house” . . .

original: Ahañca dāni āyasmā ca sāriputto bhikkhusaṅghaṃ pariharissāma ma. ni. 2.160.
analyzed: aham ca dāni āyasmā ca sāriputto bhikkhu saṅgham pariharissāma
translated: “We and the venerable Sāriputta will look after the community of bhikkhus” . . .

original: Ahañca ime ca bhikkhū samādhinā nisīdimhā.
analyzed: ahañca ime ca bhikkhū samādhinā nisīdimhā
translated: “We and these bhikkhus have been sitting in meditation with concentration” . . .🔽“We and our wife were givers of alms” . . .

original: Ahañca bhariyā ca dānapatī ahumhā jā. 2.22.1593.🔽Ahañca sāmiko ca dānapatī ahumhā jā. 2.22.1617 iccādi.
analyzed: aham ca bhariyā ca dānapatī jā  aham ca sāmikaḥ ca dānapatī iccādi
translated: “We and our husband were givers of alms” . . .

original: Yaṃ pana “so ca gacchati, tvañca gacchasī”ti vattabbe “tumhe gacchathā”ti vā “so
analyzed: yam pana saḥ ca gacchati tvam ca gacchasi iti vattabbe tumhe gacchatha ati vā so
translated: But when it should be said “He is going and you are going” or “He is coming and you are coming,” it is said “You are going” or “You are coming” or “They are going” or “They are coming” or “We are going” or “We are coming” or “They are coming” or “We are coming” in the way already stated.

original: ca gacchati, ahañca gacchāmī”ti vattabbe “mayaṃ gacchāmā”ti vā vacanaṃ, taṃ pakatibahuvacanameva,
analyzed: ca gacchati aham ca gacchāmi iti vattabbe mayam gacchāma iti vā vacanam tam pakati bahuvacanam eva
translated: and if he says, “I am going too,” and “We are going,” this is the normal plural form,

original: na paropurisabahuvacanaṃ.
analyzed: na paropurisa bahuvacanam
translated: not the plural form of the other-gender noun.

original: Yañca kaccāyane – “sabbesamekābhidhāne paro puriso”ti nī. 216 piṭṭhe suttaṃ, tatthapi
analyzed: yat ca kaccāyane sabbesam eka abhidhāne paraḥ puriso ti nī piṭṭhe suttam tattha api
translated: And in the passage in the Kaccāyana Grammar beginning, “In the case of all in the singular, the other-person form,” the meaning is not impossible,

original: sabbesaṃ dvinnaṃ vā tiṇṇaṃ vā missakabhūtānaṃ nāma, tumha’mhānaṃ ekato abhidhāne
analyzed: sabbesam dvinnam vā tiṇṇam vā missaka bhūtānam nāma tumhamhānam ekatas abhidhāne
translated: namely, that in a mixed dvanda compound consisting of two or three names, when there is a singular form in the expression of the “you” and “I” together,🔽the other-person form should be used.

original: missakadvandavākye paro puriso yojetabboti attho na na sambhavatīti.🔽564. Kattari lo ka. 455; rū. 433; nī. 925.🔽Aparokkhesu māna, nta, tyādīsu paresu kriyatthā paraṃ kattari lānubandho apaccayo hoti. Lānubandho ‘ūlasse’ti sutte visesanattho.
analyzed: missaka dvanda vākye paraḥ purisaḥ yojetabbaḥ iti atthaḥ na na sambhavati iti  kattari laḥ ka rū nī  aparokkhesu māna nta tya ādīsu paresu param kattari la anubandhaḥ a paccayaḥ hoti la anubandhaḥ ūlassa iti sutte visesana tthaḥ
translated: In the case of the other-person ending in the passive, the passive is formed by adding the passive ending -y- to the present stem of the verb.🔽In the case of the other-person ending in the passive, the passive is formed by adding the passive ending -y- to the present stem of the verb.🔽In the case of the other-person ending in the passive, the passive is formed by adding the passive ending -y- to the present stem of the verb.🔽In the case of the other-person ending in the passive, the passive is formed by adding the passive ending -y- to the present stem of the verb.🔽In the case of the other-person ending in the passive, the passive is formed by adding the passive ending -y- to the present stem of the verb.🔽In the case of the other-person ending in the passive, the passive is formed by adding the passive ending -y- to the present stem of the verb.🔽In the case of the other-person ending in the passive, the passive is formed by adding the passive ending -y- to the present stem of the verb.🔽In the case of the other-person ending in the passive, the passive is formed by adding the passive ending -y- to the present stem of the verb.🔽In the case of the other-person ending in the passive, the passive is formed by adding the passive ending -y- to the present stem of the verb.

original: Etena yattha māna, nta, tyādayo kattari vattanti, tattha ayaṃ lapaccayoti lapaccayena tesaṃ kattuvācakabhāvaṃ ñāpeti, esa nayo “kyo bhāvakammesu…” iccādīsupi.
analyzed: etena yattha māna nta tya ādayaḥ kattari vattanti tattha ayam la paccayaḥ ti la paccayena tesam kattu vācaka bhāvam ñāpeti esa nayaḥ kyaḥ bhāva kammesu iccādīsu pi
translated: In the case of the other-person ending in the passive, the passive is formed by adding the passive ending -y- to the present stem of the verb.🔽In the case of the other-person ending in the passive, the passive is formed by adding the passive ending -y- to the present stem of the verb.🔽In the case of the other-person ending in the passive, the passive is formed by

original: Ettha ca vikaraṇapaccayā nāma byañjanapūraṇā eva honti, na atthapūraṇā, tasmā yasmiṃ🔽payoge tehi vinā padarūpaṃ na sijjhati, tattheva te vattanti. Yattha sijjhati, tattha
analyzed: ettha ca vikaraṇa paccayāḥ nāma byañjana pūraṇāḥ eva honti na attha pūraṇā tasmai yasmin  payoge tehi vinā pada rūpam na sijjhati tattha iva te vattanti yattha sijjhati tattha
translated: And here the conditions of inflection are only the filling of the inflexion, not the filling of the meaning, so they occur only in the construction where the word-form is not possible without them. Where it is possible,

original: na vattanti, ayampi lapaccayo dhātuto paraṃ vibhattisare vā āgamasare vā asante vattati,
analyzed: na vattanti ayam pi la paccayaḥ dhātutaḥ param vibhatti sare vā āgama sare vā a sante vattati
translated: And here the function-concordance condition is only a concordance in the letters, not in the meaning, so it is only in the case where the word-form is not possible without them that they occur. Where it is possible, they do not occur. This condition also occurs when there is no ending-declensional-state or verbal-state after the verbal root,

original: sante pana “pacāmi, pacāma, pacāhi, gameti, gamenti, vajjeti, vajjenti”-iccādīsu🔽kāriyantaratthāya vattati. Yattha ca paccayānaṃ lopo vihito, tattha gaṇantara, rūpantarappasaṅgapaṭisiddhāya
analyzed: sante pana pacāmi pacāma pacāhi gama iti gamenti vajja iti vajjenti iccādīsu  kāriya antara tthāya vattati yattha ca paccayānam lopaḥ vihitaḥ tattha gaṇa antara rūpa antara ppasaṅga paṭisiddhāya
translated: but it occurs for the purpose of a different function in such forms as pacāmi, pacāma, pacāhi, gameti, gameti, vajjeti, vajjenti, etc., when there is one.

original: vattati, aññattha na vattati.🔽565. Yuvaṇṇānameo paccaye ka. 485; rū. 434; nī. 975; caṃ. 1.1.82; pā. 3.1.60.
analyzed: vattati aññattha na vattati  yu v a ṇ ā nam e o paccaye ka rū nī caṃ pā
translated: And where the omission of conditions is prescribed, it occurs in the case of a different group and a different form, but not in any other case.🔽. The condition for the vowels and consonants is ka. ; rū. ; nī. ; caṃ. ..; pā. ...

original: Vibhatti, paccayā paccayo nāma. I, kī, khi, ci, ji iccādayo ivaṇṇā nāma. Cu, ju,
analyzed: vibhatti paccayā paccayaḥ nāma i kī khi ci ji i ca ādayaḥ i vaṇṇā nāma cu ju
translated: The declensional-state, the condition, is called the condition. I, kī, khi, ci, ji, etc., are called vowels. Cu, ju,🔽bhū, hū, etc., are called consonants.

original: bhū, hū iccādayo uvaṇṇā nāma. Paccaye pare ekakkharadhātvantānaṃ ivaṇṇu’vaṇṇānaṃ
analyzed: bhū hū icca ādayaḥ u vaṇṇāḥ nāma paccaye pare eka kkhara dhātu antānam i v aṇ u vaṇṇānam
translated: For the last letter of a single-consonant verbal root, the vowels and consonants

original: kamena e, ovuddhiyo honti. ‘Paro kvacī’ti parasaralopo.
analyzed: kamena e o vuddhiyaḥ honti paraḥ kvaci iti para sara lopaḥ
translated: by the rule: ‘Paro kvacī’ means the elision of the vowel of the following syllable.

original: Saṃpubbo-sambhoti, sambhonti, sambhosi, sambhotha, sambhomi, sambhoma.
analyzed: saṃpubbosambhoti sambhonti sambhosi sambhotha sambhomi sambhoma
translated: Saṃpubbo-sambhoti, sambhonti, sambhosi, sambhotha, sambhomi, sambhoma.

original: Anupubbo-anubhavane, so bhogaṃ anubhoti, te bhogaṃ anubhonti, tvaṃ bhogaṃ anubhosi, tumhe bhogaṃ anubhotha, ahaṃ bhogaṃ anubhomi, mayaṃ bhogaṃ anubhoma.
analyzed: so bhogam anubhoti te bhogam anubhonti tvam bhogam anubhosi tumhe bhogam anubhotha aham bhogam anubhomi mayam bhogam anubhoma
translated: Anupubbo-anubhavane, so bhogaṃ anubhoti, te bhogaṃ anubhonti, tvaṃ bhogaṃ anubhosi, tumhe bhogaṃ anubhotha, ahaṃ bhogaṃ anubhomi, mayaṃ bhogaṃ anubhoma.

original: Tattha yathā “nīlo paṭo”ti ettha nīlasaddassa attho duvidho vāccattho, abhidheyyatthoti.
analyzed: tattha yathā nīlaḥ paṭaḥ ti ettha nīla saddassa atthaḥ duvidhaḥ vācca tthaḥ abhidheyya tthaḥ ti
translated: Herein, just as in the case of the expression “a blue cloth” the meaning of the word “blue” is twofold, namely, the meaning as statement and the meaning as what is stated,

original: Tattha guṇasaṅkhāto sakattho vāccattho nāma.
analyzed: tattha guṇa saṅkhāto sakatthaḥ vāccatthaḥ nāma
translated: Herein, the meaning as statement is called the meaning as quality,

original: Guṇanissayo dabbattho abhidheyyattho nāma.
analyzed: guṇa nissayaḥ dabba atthaḥ abhidheyya tthaḥ nāma
translated: and the meaning as what is stated is called the meaning as the support for the quality.

original: Nīlasaddo pana vaccātthameva ujuṃ vadati, nīlasaddamattaṃ suṇanto nīlaguṇameva ujuṃ jānāti, tasmā “paṭo” iti padantarena nīlasaddassa abhidheyyattho ācikkhīyati.
analyzed: nīla saddaḥ pana vacca attham eva ujum vadati nīla sadda mattam suṇantaḥ nīla guṇam eva ujum jānāti tasmā paṭaḥ iti pada antarena nīla saddassa abhidheyyatthaḥ ācikkhīyati
translated: But the word “blue” states only the meaning as statement; and when one hears only the word “blue,” he knows only the meaning as statement, namely, the word “blue” itself. That is why the meaning as what is stated, namely, the quality blue, is indicated by the other word “cloth.”

original: Tathā “anubhotī”ti ettha tisaddassa attho duvidho vāccattho, abhidheyyatthoti.
analyzed: tathā anubhoti iti ettha ti saddassa atthaḥ duvidhaḥ vācca atthaḥ abhidheyya tthaḥ ti
translated: Similarly, in the expression “he experiences,” the meaning of the word “he” is twofold, namely, the meaning as statement and the meaning as what is stated.

original: Tattha kattusattisaṅkhāto sakattho vāccattho nāma.
analyzed: tattha kattu satti saṅkhātaḥ sa katthaḥ vāccatthaḥ nāma
translated: Herein, the meaning of the selfhood consisting of the three roots of action is the meaning of the word.

original: Sattinissayo liṅgattho abhidheyyattho nāma.
analyzed: satti nissayaḥ liṅga tthaḥ abhidheyya tthaḥ nāma
translated: The meaning of the gender dependent on the three is the meaning of the name.🔽But the word “three” states the meaning of the word straightforwardly, not the meaning of the name. “He experiences” is the doer together with the action to be done in the hearing.

original: Tisaddo pana vāccatthameva ujuṃ vadati, na abhidheyyatthaṃ. “Anubhotī”ti suṇantosādhyakriyāsahitaṃ🔽kattārameva ujuṃ jānāti, na kiñci dabbanti attho. Tasmā “so” iti padantarena tisaddassa
analyzed: ti saddaḥ pana vācca attham eva ujum vadati na abhidheyya ttham anubhoti iti  kattāram eva ujum jānāti na kiñci dabbanti attho tasmā saḥ iti pada antarena ti saddassa
translated: It is only the doer that is stated straightforwardly, not anything else.

original: abhidheyyattho ācikkhīyati, vāccatthassa pana tisaddeneva ujuṃ vuttattā tatiyāvibhattiyā
analyzed: abhidheyya tthaḥ ācikkhīyati vācca tthassa pana ti saddena iva ujum vutta ttā tatiyā vibhattiyā
translated: Therefore the meaning of the name of the word “three” is stated by the other word “he” . But since the meaning of the word is stated straightforwardly by the word “three” itself,🔽there is no need to state it again by the instrumental case-ending.

original: puna ācikkhitabbakiccaṃ natthi, liṅgatthajotanatthaṃ abhidheyyapade paṭhamāvibhatti
analyzed: punar ācikkhitabba kiccam na atthi liṅga attha jotana attham abhidheyya pade paṭhamā vibhatti
translated: The first case-ending occurs in the word “name” only for the purpose of showing the meaning of the gender.

original: eva pavattatīti. Esa nayo sabbattha.
analyzed: eva pavattati iti esa nayo sabbattha
translated: This is the method in all instances.

original: 566. Eonamayavā sare ka. 513, 514; rū. 435, 491; nī. 1027, 1028.🔽Sare pare e, onaṃ kamena aya, avā honti. Ya, vesu a-kāro uccāraṇattho.🔽Bhavati, bhavanti, bhavasi, bhavatha.🔽567. Himimesvassa ka. 478; rū. 438; nī. 959.
analyzed: e o na ma ya vā sa re ka   rū   🔽sare pare e onam kamena aya avāḥ honti ya vesu akāraḥ uccāraṇa atthaḥ 🔽bhavati bhavanti bhavasi bhavatha 🔽hi mi me svassa ka rū nī
translated: . The three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the three, the

original: Hi, mi, mesu paresu a-kārassa dīgho hoti.
analyzed: hi mi mesu paresu akārassa dīghaḥ hoti
translated: In the other three cases, namely, mi, me, and mese, the a is long.

original: Bhavāmi, bhavāma.
analyzed: bhavāmi bhavāma
translated: Bhavāmi, bhavāma.

original: Parachakke – bhavate, bhavante, bhavase, bhavavhe, bhave, bhavamhe.
analyzed: bhavate bhavante bhavase bhavavhe bhave bhavamhe
translated: In the other-clans system: bhavate, bhavante, bhavase, bhavavhe, bhave, bhavamhe.

original: Papubbo bhū-pavattiyaṃ, nadī pabhavati.
analyzed: papubbaḥ bhū pavattiyam nadī pabhavati
translated: The prefix pa- is used in the sense of origination: nadī pabhavati.

original: Adhyā’bhi, paripubbo hiṃsāyaṃ, adhibhavati, abhibhavati, paribhavati.
analyzed: paripubbaḥ hiṃsāyam adhibhavati abhibhavati paribhavati
translated: The prefix adhi- is used in the sense of overcoming: adhibhavati, abhibhavati, paribhavati.

original: Vipubbo vināse, pākaṭe, sobhaṇe ca, vibhavati.
analyzed: vipubbaḥ vināse pākaṭe sobhaṇe ca vibhavati
translated: The prefix vi- is used in the sense of destruction, manifestation, and beauty: vibhavati.

original: Parāpubbo parājaye, parābhavati.
analyzed: parāpubbaḥ parājaye parābhavati
translated: The prefix para- is used in the sense of defeat: parābhavati.

original: Abhi, saṃpubbo pattiyaṃ, ajjhogāhe ca, abhisambhavati, tathā pātubbhavati, āvibhavati iccādi.
analyzed: abhi pattiyam ajjhogāhe ca abhisambhavati tathā pātubbhavati āvibhavati iccādi
translated: The prefix abhi- is used in the sense of attainment and submergence: abhisambhavati, pātubbhavati, āvibhavati, etc.

original: Iti suddhakatturūpaṃ.
analyzed: iti suddha kattu rūpam
translated: Thus it is pure matter.

original: Suddhabhāvakammarūpa🔽568. Kyo bhāvakammesvaparokkhesu māna nta tyādīsu ka. 440; rū. 445; nī. 920; caṃ. 1.1.80; pā. 3.1.67.
analyzed: suddha bhāva kamma rūpa  kyaḥ bhāva kammesu aparokkhesu māna nta tya ādīsu ka rū nī caṃ pā
translated: Pure verbal action🔽In the other-clans system, the suffix ka is used in the sense of action: kīḷati, māyati, tyādayo, ka; rūhati, nīhati, cahati, pāhati, etc.

original: Parokkhāvajjitesu māna, ntapaccayesu tyādīsu ca paresu kriyatthā bhāvasmiṃ kammani ca kānubandho yapaccayo hoti, bahulādhikārā kvaci kattari ca.
analyzed: parokkha avajjitesu mān nta paccayesu tya ādīsu ca paresu kriyatthā bhāvasmim kammani ca ka anubandhaḥ ya paccayaḥ hoti bahula adhikārā kvaci kattari ca
translated: In the other-clans system, the suffix ka is used in the sense of action, in the sense of the agent, and in the sense of the object, in the sense of the instrument, and in the sense of the cause, in the sense of the manner, and in the sense of the location, in the sense of the time, and in the sense of the purpose, in the sense of the condition, and in the sense of the inherence, and in the sense of the class, and in the sense of the number, and in the sense of the verbal root, and in the sense of the verbal prefix, and in the sense of the verbal ending, and in the sense of the verbal root and the verbal prefix, and in the sense of the verbal root and the verbal ending, and in the sense of the verbal prefix and the verbal ending, and in the sense of the verbal root and the verbal prefix and the verbal ending.

original: Rūpaṃ vibhuyyati, so pahīyissati saṃ. ni. 1.249, bhattaṃ paccati, gimhe udakaṃ chijjati, kusūlo bhijjati.
analyzed: rūpam vibhuyyati saḥ pahīyissati sam ni bhattam paccati gimhe udakam chijjati kusūlaḥ bhijjati
translated: Food is cooked, in summer the water is cut, the bag is broken.

original: 569. Na te kānubandhanāgamesu.
analyzed: na te ka anubandhana āgamesu
translated: They are not in the continuative and future.

original: Kānubandhe nāgame ca ivaṇṇu’vaṇṇānaṃ assa ca te e, o,-ā na hontīti kyamhi vuddhi natthi.
analyzed: ka anubandhe na āgame ca assa ca te e o na honti iti kyamhi natthi
translated: In the continuative and future, the vowel u and the vowel a of the words ivaṇṇu and ivaṇṇānaṃ are not, therefore there is no augment in the continuative.

original: Kamme-tena purisena bhogo anubhūyati, tena bhogā anubhūyanti, tena tvaṃ anubhūyasi,
analyzed: kammetena purisena bhogaḥ anubhūyati tena bhogāḥ anubhūyanti tena tvam anubhūyasi
translated: By that man wealth is experienced, by that wealth is experienced, by that you are experienced,🔽by that you are experienced, by that I am experienced, by that we are experienced.

original: tena tumhe anubhūyatha, tena ahaṃ anubhūyāmi, tena mayaṃ anubhūyāma. Yassa dvittaṃ🔽rassattañca, anubhuyyati, anubhuyyanti.
analyzed: tena tumhe anubhūyatha tena aham anubhūyāmi tena mayam anubhūyāma yassa  rassattañca anubhuyyati anubhuyyanti
translated: In the case of the one who has the dual and the long, it is extended, they are extended.

original: Tattha “anubhūyatī”ti ettha kyapaccayasahitassa tisaddassa attho duvidho vāccattho, abhidheyyatthoti.
analyzed: tattha anubhūyati iti ettha kya paccaya sahitassa ti saddassa atthaḥ duvidhaḥ vācca atthaḥ abhidheyya tthaḥ ti
translated: Herein, in the case of “is experienced”, the meaning of the word ti, together with the continuative affix, is twofold, namely, the meaning of the word and the meaning of the thing to be expressed.

original: Tattha kammasattisaṅkhāto sakattho vāccattho nāma.
analyzed: tattha kamma satti saṅkhāto sakatthaḥ vāccatthaḥ nāma
translated: Herein, the meaning of the word called the meaning of the word is the meaning of the verb called the threefold verb.

original: Sattinissayo liṅgattho abhidheyyattho nāma.
analyzed: satti nissayaḥ liṅga tthaḥ abhidheyya tthaḥ nāma
translated: The meaning of the thing to be expressed called the meaning of the gender is dependent on the noun.

original: Tisaddo pana kyapaccayasahito vāccatthameva ujuṃ vadati, na abhidheyyatthaṃ. “Anubhūyatī”ti
analyzed: ti saddaḥ pana kya paccaya sahitaḥ vācca attham eva ujum vadati na abhidheyya ttham anubhūyati iti
translated: But the three-fold sound, when accompanied by the case-endings, expresses only the meaning of the verb, not the meaning of the noun.

original: suṇanto sādhyakriyāsahitaṃ kammasattiṃ eva ujuṃ jānāti, na kiñci dabbanti vuttaṃ
analyzed: suṇantaḥ sādhya kriyā sahitam kamma sattim eva ujum jānāti na kiñci dabban ti vuttam
translated: The hearer, when he hears, knows only the verbal root accompanied by the mode of the action to be accomplished, not that anything is to be cut down.

original: hoti. Sesaṃ pubbe vuttanayameva.
analyzed: hoti sesam pubbe vutta nayam eva
translated: The rest is as already stated.

original: Anubhūyate, anubhuyyate, anubhūyante, anubhuyyante, anubhūyase, anubhūyavhe, anubhūye, anubhuyye, anubhūyamhe, anubhuyyamhe.
analyzed: anubhūyate anubhuyyate anubhūyante anubhuyyante anubhūyase anubhūyavhe anubhūye anubhuyye anubhūyamhe anubhūyamhe
translated: Anubhūyate, anubhuyyate, anubhūyante, anubhuyyante, anubhūyase, anubhūyavhe, anubhūye, anubhuyye, anubhūyamhe, anubhuyyamhe.

original: 570. Garupubbā rassā re ntentīnaṃ ka. 517; rū. 488; nī. 1105; ‘guru…’ (bahūsu).
analyzed: garu pubbā rassā re nta intīnam ka rū nī guru bahūsu
translated: Garupubbā rassā re ntentīnaṃ ka. ; rū. ; nī. ; ‘guru…’ (bahūsu).

original: Garupubbamhā rassato nte, ntīnaṃ reādeso hoti.
analyzed: rassataḥ nte ntīnam re ādesaḥ hoti
translated: Garupubbamhā rassato nte, ntīnaṃ reādeso hoti.

original: Jāyare, jāyanti, jāyare, jāyante, gacchare, gacchanti, gacchare, gacchante, gamissare, gamissanti, gamissare, gamissante.
analyzed: jāyare jāyanti jāyare jāyante gacchare gacchanti gacchare gacchante gamissare gamissanti gamissare gamissante
translated: Jāyare, jāyanti, jāyare, jāyante, gacchare, gacchanti, gacchare, gacchante, gamissare, gamissanti, gamissare, gamissante.

original: Garupubbāti kiṃ? Pacanti, pacante.
analyzed: kim pacanti pacante
translated: Garupubbāti kiṃ? Pacanti, pacante.

original: Rassāti kiṃ? Pācenti, pācante.
analyzed: kim pācenti pācante
translated: Rassāti kiṃ? Pācenti, pācante.

original: Ettha ca suttavibhāgena “sabbaṃ hidaṃ bhañjare kālapariyāyaṃ jā. 1.15.370, muñcare bandhanasmā jā. 2.22.1648, jīvare’ vāpi sussatī”ti jā. 2.22.840 etāni pāḷipadāni sijjhanti.
analyzed: ettha ca sutta vibhāgena sabbam hidam bhañjare kāla pariyāyam jā  muñcare bandhanasmā jā  jīvare vā api sussati iti  etāni pāḷi padāni sijjhanti
translated: And here the following lines from the Suttas are applicable: “All this is subject to decay, O monks, and to change; Let go of it, O monks, and be free from bondage; Let go of it, O monks, and be free from disease. ”

original: Tattha ‘bhañjare’ti bhijjati, ‘muñcare’ti muñcantu, ‘jīvare’ vāpī’ti jīvanto’vāpi. Anubhūyare, anubhūyanti, anubhūyare, anubhūyante.
analyzed: bhañjara iti bhijjati muñcara iti muñcantu jīvare vāpi iti anubhūyare anubhūyanti anubhūyare anubhūyante
translated: Herein, ‘bhañjare’ means ‘is subject to decay’; ‘muñcare’ means ‘let go’; ‘jīvare vāpī’ means ‘is subject to disease’. Anubhūyare, anubhūyanti, anubhūyare, anubhūyante.

original: Bhāvo nāma bhavana, gamanādiko kriyākāro, so dhātunā eva tulyādhikaraṇabhāvena visesīyati,
analyzed: bhāvaḥ nāma bhavana gamana ādikaḥ kriyākāraḥ saḥ dhātunā eva tulya adhikaraṇa bhāvena
translated: The state is the process of becoming, the process of going, etc., and that is distinguished by the verbal root itself as having the same reference,

original: na nāmapadena, tasmā tattha tumha’mha, sesanāmavasena tyādidukavisesayogo nāma natthi,
analyzed: na nāma padena tasmā tattha tumhamha sesa nāma vasena tyādi duka visesa yogaḥ nāma natthi
translated: not by the nominal base. Therefore, there is no such distinction as ‘tumha’, ‘amha’, ‘tyā’ and so on, by way of the other nominal bases.

original: paṭhamadukameva tattha bhavati, dabbasseva ca tassa abyattasarūpattā saṅkhyābhedopi
analyzed: tattha bhavati dabbassa iva ca tassa abyatta sarūpa ttā saṅkhyā bhedaḥ api
translated: Only the first distinction is there. And because of the non-differentiation of the form,

original: natthi, ekavacanameva bhavati.
analyzed: natthi ekavacanam eva bhavati
translated: there is no distinction of number either. There is only the singular.

original: Tena bhogaṃ anubhūyati, anubhuyyati, anubhūyate, anubhuyyate, anubhavanaṃ hotīti attho.
analyzed: tena bhogam anubhūyati anubhuyyati anubhūyate anubhuyyate anubhavanam hoti iti
translated: Therefore, the meaning is: ‘One experiences enjoyment, one is experienced, one is experienced, one is experienced, there is the state of being experienced.’

original: Iti suddhabhāvakammarūpāni.
analyzed: iti suddha bhāva kamma rūpāni
translated: So the materiality of the mere action is of two kinds.

original: Hetukatturūpa🔽571. Payojakabyāpāre ṇāpi ca ka. 438; rū. 540; nī. 914.
analyzed: hetu kattu rūpa  payojaka byāpāre ca ka rū nī
translated: The materiality of the mere cause🔽And also ṇā in the function of instigator.

original: Yo suddhakattāraṃ payojeti, tassa payojakassa kattuno byāpāre kriyatthā ṇi ca ṇāpi ca honti. Ṇānubandhā vuddhutthā.
analyzed: yaḥ suddha kattāram payojeti tassa payojakassa kattunaḥ byāpāre kriyatthāḥ ca ca api ca honti
translated: When one instigates another who is a mere agent, then in the function of the instigator as agent the ṇi and ṇā are the verbal noun. The ṇi is the passive.

original: Tesu ca ākārantato ‘ato’ (moga.) ṇāpiyeva hoti, dāpeti, dāpayati.
analyzed: tesu ca hoti dāpa iti dāpayati
translated: And of these, in the case of the passive, ṇā is only used when the passive is expressed by a word, as dāpeti, dāpayati.

original: Uvaṇṇantato ṇiyeva, sāveti, sāvayati.
analyzed: sāvayati
translated: In the case of the causative, ṇi is only used when the causative is expressed by a word, as sāveti, sāvayati.

original: Sesato dvepi, pāceti, pācayati, pācāpeti, pācāpayati.
analyzed: sesataḥ dve pi pāca iti pācayati pācāpa iti pācāpayati
translated: In the case of the other, both are used, as pāceti, pācayati, pācāpeti, pācāpayati.

original: Payojakabyāpāropi kriyā evāti tadatthavācīhi ṇi,-ṇāpīhi paraṃ vibhatti, paccayā bhavanti, dhātvantassa ca ṇi, ṇāpīnañca vuddhi.
analyzed: payojaka byāpāraḥ api kriyā eva ati tad attha vācīhi ṇi ṇāpīhi param vibhatti paccayāḥ bhavanti dhātu antassa ca ṇi ṇāpīnam ca
translated: And since the function of the instigator is an action, the case-endings ṇi and ṇā are used after it to express that meaning. The ṇi is added to the verbal base, and the ṇā is added to the passive.

original: So maggaṃ bhāveti, te maggaṃ bhāventi, tvaṃ maggaṃ bhāvesi, tumhe maggaṃ bhāvetha, ahaṃ maggaṃ bhāvemi, mayaṃ maggaṃ bhāvema.
analyzed: saḥ maggam bhāveti te maggam bhāventi tvam maggam bhāvesi tumhe maggam bhāvetha aham maggam bhāvemi mayam maggam bhāvema
translated: He develops the path; they develop the path; you develop the path; you all develop the path; I develop the path; we develop the path.🔽The ṇi is added to the passive

original: 572. Āyāvā ṇānubandhe ka. 515; rū. 541; nī. 1029.
analyzed: āyāvā ṇa anubandhe ka rū nī
translated: 572. Āyāvā ṇānubandhe ka. 515; rū. 541; nī. 1029.

original: E, onaṃ kamena āya, āvā honti sarādo ṇānubandhe paccaye pare, suttavibhattiyā aṇānubandhepi āyā’vā honti.🔽Ge-sadde, gāyati, gāyanti.🔽Apapubbo ce-pūjāyaṃ, apacāyati, apacāyanti.🔽Jhe-cintāyaṃ, jhāyati, jhāyanti, ujjhāyati, nijjhāyati iccādi.🔽573. Ṇiṇāpyāpīhi ca “…vā” (bahūsu).🔽Ṇi, ṇāpi, āpīhi ca kattari lo hoti vā.
analyzed: e onam kamena āyaḥ āvāḥ honti sa ra ādaḥ ṇa anubandhe paccaye pare sutta vibhattiyā a ṇa anubandhe pi āya avāḥ honti  gesadde gāyati gāyanti  apacāyati apacāyanti  jhecintā ayam jhāyati jhāyanti ujjhāyati nijjhāyati iccādi  ṇi ṇ āpi āpīhi ca vā bahūsu  ṇi ṇa api āpīhi ca kattari laḥ hoti vā
translated: In one’s own action, āya is, and āvā are, in the sense of “having come,” when the following conditions are not in apposition to the verb, and āyā and āvā are, when the following conditions are in apposition to the verb.🔽In the sense of “singing,” gāyati, gāyanti.🔽In the sense of “honouring,” apacāyati, apacāyanti.🔽In the sense of “thinking,” jhāyati, jhāyanti, ujjhāyati, nijjhāyati, etc.🔽And with ṇi, ṇāpi, āpīhi, “or” (in many).🔽In the nominative case, lo is, or is not, when the following conditions are not in apposition to the verb.

original: Kārayati, kārāpayati, saddāpayati.🔽Iminā asare ṭhāne ayādesato paraṃ akāro hoti, so maggaṃ bhāvayati, bhāvayanti, bhāvayasi, bhāvayatha, bhāvayāmi, bhāvayāma.🔽Iti hetukatturūpāni.🔽Tyādi🔽‘Kyo bhāvakammesū…’ti ṇi, ṇāpipaccayantato yo.🔽574. Kyassa ka. 442; rū. 448; nī. 922.🔽Kriyatthā parassa kyassa ādimhi īña hoti.
analyzed: kārayati kārāpayati saddāpayati 🔽iminā a sare ṭhāne param akāraḥ hoti saḥ maggam bhāvayati bhāvayanti bhāvayasi bhāvayatha bhāvayāmi bhāvayāma 🔽iti hetu kattu rūpāni 🔽tya ādi 🔽kyaḥ bhāva kammesu iti ṇi ṇāpi paccaya ntataḥ yaḥ 🔽kyassa ka rū nī 🔽kriyatthā parassa kyassa ādimhi īña hoti
translated: The forms āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āyanti, āy

original: Tena maggo bhāvīyati, tena maggā bhāvīyanti, tena tvaṃ bhāvīyasi, tena tumhe bhāvīyatha, tena ahaṃ bhāvīyāmi, tena mayaṃ bhāvīyāma.🔽Rassatte-bhāviyati, bhāviyanti.
analyzed: tena maggaḥ bhāvīyati tena maggāḥ bhāvīyanti tena tvam bhāvīyasi tena tumhe bhāvīyatha tena aham bhāvīyāmi tena mayam bhāvīyāma  bhāviyanti
translated: In the locative case: In it the path is brought into being, in it the paths are brought into being, in it you are brought into being, in it they are brought into being, in it I am brought into being, in it we are brought into being.

original: Dvitte-bhāviyyati, bhāviyyanti. Tathā bhāvayīyati, bhāvayīyanti.🔽Rassatte-bhāvayiyati, bhāvayiyanti.
analyzed: tathā bhāvayīyati bhāvayīyanti  rassattebhāvayiyati
translated: In the ablative case: By it the path is brought into being, by it the paths are brought into being, by it you are brought into being, by it they are brought into being, by it I am brought into being, by it we are brought into being.🔽In the dative case: For it the path is brought into being, for it the paths are brought into being, for it you are brought into being, for it they are brought into being, for it I am brought into being, for it we are brought into being.

original: Dvitte-bhāvayiyyati, bhāvayiyyanti.🔽Akammikāpi yā dhātu, kārite tve’kakammikā;
analyzed: dvittebhāvayiyyati bhāvayiyyanti  akammikā api yā dhātu kārite tu ekakammikā
translated: In the ablative case: From it the path is brought into being, from it the paths are brought into being, from it you are brought into being, from it they are brought into being, from it I am brought into being, from it we are brought into being.

original: Ekakammā dvikammā ca, dvikammā ca tikammakā.🔽Iti suddhakatturūpaṃ, suddhakammarūpaṃ, hetukatturūpaṃ, hetukammarūpanti ekadhātumhi cattāri nipphannarūpāni labbhanti.
analyzed: eka kammā dvi kammā ca dvi kammā ca ti kammakā  iti suddha kattu rūpam suddha kamma rūpam hetu kattu rūpam hetu kamma rūpanti eka dhātumhi cattāri nipphanna rūpāni labbhanti
translated: In the locative case: In it the path is brought into being, in it the paths are brought into being, in it you are brought into being, in it they are brought into being, in it I am brought into being, in it we are brought into being.🔽In the ablative case: By it the path is brought into being, by it the paths are brought into being, by it you are brought into being, by it they are brought into being, by it I am brought into being, by it we are brought into being.🔽In the dative case: For it the path is brought into being, for it the paths are brought into being, for it you are brought into being, for it they are brought into being, for it I am brought into being, for it we are brought into being.

original: Katturūpena cettha kammakatturūpampi saṅgayhati. Kusūlo bhijjati, bhijjanadhammo bhijjati.
analyzed: kattu rūpena ca ittha kamma kattu rūpam pi saṅgayhati kusūlaḥ bhijjati bhijjana dhammaḥ bhijjati
translated: In the ablative case: From it the path is brought into being, from it the paths are brought into being, from it you are brought into being, from it they are brought into being, from it I am brought into being, from it we are brought into being.🔽In the locative case

original: Kammarūpena ca kattukammarūpampi saṅgayhati. Tattha yaṃ padaṃ kattuvācakaṃ samānaṃ saddarūpena kammarūpaṃ bhavati, taṃ kattukammarūpaṃ nāma, taṃ pāḷiyaṃ bahulaṃ dissati.
analyzed: kamma rūpena ca kattu kamma rūpam pi saṅgayhati tattha yam padam kattu vācakam samānam sadda rūpena kamma rūpam bhavati tam kattu kamma rūpam nāma tam pāḷiyam bahulam dissati
translated: And the form of the action that is done is included in the form of the action that is the means. Herein, that word which is the same as the word expressing the doing is the form of the action that is the means, and that is the form of the action that is the doing. That is found in the texts in many places.

original: Rūpaṃ vibhāviyyati mahāni. 108, atikkamiyyati, samatikkamiyyati, vītivattiyyati,
analyzed: rūpam vibhāviyyati mahāni atikkamiyyati samatikkamiyyati vītivattiyyati
translated: Rūpaṃ vibhāviyyati mahāni, atikkamiyyati, samatikkamiyyati, vītivattiyyati,

original: nimittaṃ abhibhuyyatīti gotrabhu paṭi. ma. 1.59, pavattaṃ abhibhuyyati paṭi. ma.
analyzed: nimittam abhibhuyyati iti gotrabhu paṭi ma
translated: Nimittaṃ abhibhuyyati paṭi. ma. ., pavattaṃ abhibhuyyati paṭi. ma.

original: 1.59, cutiṃ abhibhuyyati, upapattiṃ abhibhuyyatīti paṭi. ma. 1.59 gotrabhu iccādi.
analyzed: cutim abhibhuyyati upapattim abhibhuyyati iti gotrabhu iti ca ādi
translated: ., cutiṃ abhibhuyyati, upapattiṃ abhibhuyyatīti paṭi. ma. . gotrabhu iccādi.

original: Tathā so pahīyethāpi nopi pahīyetha saṃ. ni. 1.249, so pahīyissati saṃ. ni. 1.249,
analyzed: tathā saḥ pahīyetha api na upi pahīyetha sam ni saḥ pahīyissati sam ni
translated: Tathā so pahīyethāpi nopi pahīyetha saṃ. ni. ., so pahīyissati saṃ. ni. .,

original: nihiyyati yaso tassa dī. ni. 3.246, hiyyoti hiyyati poso, pareti parihāyati jā. 1.15.348,
analyzed: nihiyyati yaso tassa dī ni   / poso pareti parihāyati jā
translated: Nihiyyati yaso tassa dī. ni. ., hiyyoti hiyyati poso, pareti parihāyati jā. ..,

original: ājānīyā hasīyanti jā. 2.22.2369, vidhurassa hadayaṃ dhaniyati jā. 2.22.1350 iccādi.
analyzed: ājānīyā hasīyanti jā vidhurassa hadayam dhaniyati jā  iccādi
translated: Ājānīyā hasīyanti jā. .., vidhurassa hadayaṃ dhaniyati jā. .. iccādi.

original: Yañca ‘yamhi dā dhā mā thā hā pā maha mathādīnamī’ti kaccāyane suttaṃ, taṃ kammani🔽icchanti, kattari eva yujjati kammani ivaṇṇāgamassa sabbhāvā. Saddanītiyaṃ pana “so
analyzed: yam ca yamhi dā dhā mā thā hā pā maha matha ādīnami iti kaccāyane suttam tam kammani  icchanti kattari eva yujjati kammani sabbhāvā saddanītiyam pana saḥ
translated: The sutta in the Kaccāyana grammar beginning, “Yamhi dā dhā mā thā hā pā maha mathādīnamī” is held to refer to the act of doing.🔽But it is only appropriate to the doer, as in the case of the vowel-change in the word kammani.

original: pahīyissatī”ti padānaṃ bhāvarūpattaṃ daḷhaṃ vadati, tāni pana kattukammarūpāni evāti.
analyzed: pahīyissati iti padānam bhāva rūpa ttam daḷham vadati tāni pana kattu kamma rūpāni eva ati
translated: But in the Saddanīti it is strongly asserted that the words “so pahīyissatī” are in the mode of being; and they are in the mode of being as the act of doing.

original: Ettha ca vattamānaṃ catubbidhaṃ niccapavattaṃ, pavattāvirataṃ, pavattuparataṃ, samīpavattamānanti.
analyzed: ettha ca vattamānam catubbidham nicca pavattam pavatta aviratam pavattu paratam samīpa vattamānam iti
translated: And here the present is of four kinds as continuous occurrence, occurrence without break, occurrence that has ceased, and occurrence in the vicinity.

original: Tattha niccapavatte – idhāyaṃ pabbato tiṭṭhati, candimasūriyā pariyāyanti, disā bhanti virocamānā a. ni. 4.69.
analyzed: tattha nicca pavatte idha ayam pabbataḥ tiṭṭhati candima sūriyā pariyāyanti disā bhanti virocamānāḥ a ni
translated: Herein, in the continuous occurrence: “Here this mountain stands, the moon and sun go round, the quarters shine resplendent” .

original: Pavattāvirate – api nu te gahapati kule dānaṃ dīyatīti, dīyati me bhante kule dānaṃ a. ni. 9.20.
analyzed: api nu te gahapati kule dānam dīyati iti dīyati me bhante kule dānam
translated: In the occurrence without break: “Is alms given in your family, householder?” “Alms is given in my family, venerable sir” .

original: Ettha ca yāva dāne saussāho, tāva yathāpavattā dānakriyā vattamānā eva nāma hoti ussāhassa aviratattā.
analyzed: ettha ca yāva dāne saussāhaḥ tāva yathā pavattā dāna kriyā vattamānā eva nāma hoti ussāhassa a virata ttā
translated: And here, as long as there is eagerness for the giving, so long the act of giving, which goes on as it began, is called present, because the eagerness has not ceased.

original: Pavattuparate – na khādati ayaṃ maṃsaṃ, neva pāṇaṃ hanati a. ni. 3.67, na adinnaṃ
analyzed: na khādati ayam maṃsam na iva pāṇam hanati na adinnam
translated: In the past tense: He does not eat meat, he does not kill living beings, he does not take what is not given.

original: ādiyati a. ni. 3.67. Ettha yāva tabbipakkhakriyaṃ na karoti, tāva viramaṇakriyā vattamānā eva nāma hoti.
analyzed: ettha yāva tad bipakkha kriyam na karoti tāva viramaṇa kriyā vattamānā eva nāma hoti
translated: Herein, so long as he does not perform the action that is the counterpart of the abstention, the abstention itself goes on occurring.

original: Samīpe – atīte – kuto nu tvaṃ āgacchasi saṃ. ni. 1.130, rājagahato āgacchāmīti. Anāgate – dhammaṃ te desemi, sādhukaṃ suṇohi.
analyzed: samīpe atīte kutas nu tvam āgacchasi sam ni rājagahataḥ āgacchāmi iti anāgate dhammam te desemi sādhukam suṇohi
translated: In the present: In the future: Where are you coming from? From Rājagaha. I will teach you the Dhamma. Listen to it well.

original: Suttavibhattena tadāyoge atītepi ayaṃ vibhatti hoti, vākacīrāni dhunanto, gacchāmi ambare tadā bu. vaṃ. 2.37.🔽Yāva, pure, purāyoge anāgatepi-idheva tāva tiṭṭhāhi, yāvāhaṃ āgacchāmi, yaṃnūnāhaṃ
analyzed: sutta vibhattena tadā yoge atīte api ayam hoti vāka cīrāni dhunantaḥ gacchāmi ambare tadā  yāva pure tāva tiṭṭhāhi yāva aham āgacchāmi yat nūna aham
translated: In the future too this is the case when the future is expressed by the present tense, as in “Shaking the bark-cloth garments I will go to the sky then” .

original: dhammañca vinayañca saṅgāyeyyaṃ pārā. aṭṭha. 1.paṭhamamahāsaṅgītikathā, pure adhammo🔽dibbati, dhammo paṭibāhiyyati cūḷava. 437, dante ime chinda purā marāmi jā. 1.16.127.
analyzed: dhammañca vinayañca saṅgāyeyyam pārāḥ aṭṭha paṭhama mahā saṅgīti kathā pure adhammaḥ 🔽dibbati dhammo paṭibāhiyyati cūḷava dante ime chinda purā marāmi jā
translated: In the future too this is the case when the future is expressed by the past tense, as in “Here only stay until I come,” “Let me now collect the Dhamma and Discipline,” “In the past unrighteousness prevailed, righteousness disappeared” .

original: Ekaṃsatthepi-nirayaṃ nūnagacchāmi, ettha me natthi saṃsayo jā. 2.22.331. Avassambhāviyatthepi-dhuvaṃ buddho bhavāmahaṃ bu. vaṃ. 2.109, dhuvaṃ buddho bhavissati bu. vaṃ. 2.81 vā.
analyzed: nūna gacchāmi ettha me natthi saṃsayaḥ  dhuvam buddhaḥ bhavāmaham bu vaṃ  dhuvam buddhaḥ bhavissati vā
translated: In the sense of ‘not to be expected’ (the words are used as follows): ‘I shall certainly become a Buddha.’

original: Aniyamatthepi-manasā ce pasannena, bhāsati vā karoti vā dha. pa. 2 cintetīti cittaṃ dha. sa. aṭṭha. 1, phusatīti phasso dha. sa. aṭṭha. 1, bujjhatīti buddho.
analyzed: ce pasannena bhāsati vā karoti vā dha pa cinteti iti cittam dha sa aṭṭha  phusati iti phassaḥ dha sa aṭṭha  bujjhati iti buddhaḥ
translated: In the sense of ‘not fixed’ (the words are used as follows): ‘If with a mind that is serene, one speaks or acts, one thinks, the mind is the forerunner of dhammas. One touches, the touch is the forerunner of dhammas. One awakens, the awakened one is the forerunner of dhammas.’

original: Kadā karahiyogepi-kadā gacchati, karahi gacchati, gamissati vā.
analyzed: kadā karahi yoge pi kadā gacchati karahi gacchati gamissati vā
translated: In the sense of ‘when’ (the words are used as follows): ‘When does he go? When does he go away? He will go.’

original: Iti tyādi.
analyzed: iti tyādi
translated: Thus, etc.

original: Tvādi
analyzed: tva ādi
translated: Tvādi

original: Atha tvādi vuccate.
analyzed: atha tva ādi vuccate
translated: Now, tvādi is stated.

original: 575. Tu antu hi tha mi ma taṃ antaṃ su vho e āmase ka. 424; rū. 450; nī. 897; caṃ. 1.3.122; pā. 3.3.162.
analyzed: tu antu hi tha mi ma tam antam su ka rū nī caṃ pā
translated: Tu, antu, hi, tha, mi, ma, taṃ, antaṃ, su, vho, e, āmase, ka; rū; nī; caṃ; pā.

original: Vattamāne kāle pañha, patthanā, vidhīsu kriyatthā tvādayo honti.
analyzed: vattamāne kāle kriyatthā tva ādayaḥ honti
translated: In the present time, in questions, in wishes, and in injunctions, the meanings of action are tvādayo.

original: Pañhe-dhammaṃ vā tvaṃ adhiyassu vinayaṃ vā pāci. 471 (atthato sadisaṃ).
analyzed: pañhedhammam vā tvam adhiyassu vinayam vā pāci atthato sadisam
translated: In questions: ‘You should study the Dhamma or the Vinaya.’ (The meaning is the same as in the Pali.)

original: Patthanāsaddena āsīsādayopi saṅgayhanti.
analyzed: patthanā saddena āsīsa ādayaḥ api saṅgayhanti
translated: By the word ‘wish’ also desires, etc., are included.
