original: Nāgame-ñāpanako, viññāpanako, saññāpanako, adhiṭṭhātīti adhiṭṭhāyako, adhiṭṭhāpetīti adhiṭṭhāpako, detīti dāyako, dāpetīti dāpako.
analyzed: nāga meñāpanakaḥ viññāpanakaḥ saññāpanakaḥ adhiṭṭhāti iti adhiṭṭhāyakaḥ adhiṭṭhāpeti iti adhiṭṭhāpakaḥ deti iti dāyakaḥ dāpeti iti dāpakaḥ
translated: The maker of a nāga is a nāgāyaka; the maker of a viññāpana is a viññāpayaka; the maker of a saññāpana is a saññāpayaka; the maker of an adhiṭṭhāna is an adhiṭṭhāyaka; the maker of an adhiṭṭhāpana is an adhiṭṭhāpaka; the giver is a dāyaka; the maker of a dāpana is a dāpaka.

original: Ṇāpimhi yāgamo natthi, samādapetīti samādapako, ubhayattha rasso. Vidhetīti vidhāyako, pajahatīti pajahāyako, avahiyyatīti ohiyako, āssa ittaṃ iccādi.🔽Ivaṇṇesu-ajjhetīti ajjhāyako, mantaṃ ajjhetīti mantajjhāyako, kiṇātīti kāyako, kiṇāpetīti🔽kāyāpako, ācinātīti ācinako, vicinako, parājayatīti pārājiko, alopo, puggalo, parājetīti
analyzed: ya āgamaḥ natthi samādapeti iti samādapakaḥ ubhayattha rassaḥ vidheti iti vidhāyakaḥ pajahati iti pajahāyakaḥ avahiyyati iti ohiyakaḥ āssa ittam iccādi  iva aṇṇesu ajjheti iti ajjhāyakaḥ mantam ajjheti iti manta jjhāyakaḥ kiṇāti iti kāyakaḥ kiṇāpeti iti  kāyāpakaḥ ācināti iti ācinakaḥ vicinakaḥ parājayati iti pārājikaḥ a lopo puggalo parājeti iti
translated: There is no nāga in nāpimhi, the encourager is a samādapaka, both are dissyllabic. The maker of a vidhana is a vidhāyaka; the abandoner is a pajahāyaka; the one who goes away is an ohiyaka; the one who has it is an itthaka, and so on.

original: pārājiko, alopo kāritalopo ca, dhammo, bhāyāpetīti bhayānako, nāgamo ādirasso ca.
analyzed: pārājikaḥ a lopo kārita lopo ca dhammo bhāyā apeti iti bhayānakaḥ na āgamaḥ ādi rasso ca
translated: In the i-words: the one who recites is an ajjhāyaka; the one who recites a text is a mantajjhāyaka; the buyer is a kāyaka; the maker of a kiṇāpana is a kāyāpaka; the one who collects is an ācinaka; the one who searches is a vicinaka; the one who is defeated is a pārājika; the one who is lost is an alopa; the person is a puggala; the one who defeats is a pārājika; the one who is lost and the one who causes loss are an alopa and a kāritalopa; the Dhamma is a dhamma; the one who causes fear is a bhayānaka; the nāga and the dissyllabic ādi are nāgamo and ādirasso.

original: Bhūmiyaṃ setīti bhūmisāyako, sayāpetīti sayāpako, pāhetīti pahiṇako iccādi.
analyzed: bhūmi iyam sā iti iti bhūmisāyakaḥ sayāpa iti iti sayāpakaḥ iccādi
translated: In the bhūmi-words: the one who ploughs the land is a bhūmisāyaka; the one who causes to lie down is a sayāpaka; the one who sends is a pahiṇaka, and so on.

original: Uvaṇṇesu-punāti sodhetīti pāvako-aggi, bhavatīti bhāvako, vibhāvetīti vibhāvako, lunātīti lāvako, suṇātīti sāvako-puriso, sāvikā-itthī, juhotīti hāvako iccādi.
analyzed: sodheti iti pāvakaḥ aggi bhavati iti bhāvakaḥ vibhāveti iti vibhāvakaḥ lunāti iti lāvakaḥ suṇāti iti sāvakaḥ purisaḥ sāvikā itthī juhoti iti hāvakaḥ iccādi
translated: In the case of the words uvaṇṇesu-punāti sodheti, the word pāvako is a name for fire. The word bhāvako is derived from the verb bhāveti. The word vibhāvako is derived from the verb vibhāveti. The word lāvako is derived from the verb lunāti. The word sāvako is a name for a man. The word sāvikā is a name for a woman. The word hāvako is a name for one who offers oblations.

original: Apa-pāpuṇane, pāpetīti pāpako, sampāpetīti sampāpako, upāsatīti upāsako-puriso, upāsikā-itthī,🔽upāsakaṃ-kulaṃ, karotīti kārako, kārikā, kārakaṃ, upakārako, kāretīti kārāpako, saṅkharotīti
analyzed: apapāpuṇane pāpeti iti pāpako sampāpeti iti sampāpakaḥ upāsati iti upāsako purisaḥ upāsikā itthī  upāsakaṃkulam karoti iti kārako kārikā kārakam upakārako kāreti iti kārāpako saṅkharoti iti
translated: In the case of the words apa-pāpuṇane, the word pāpako is derived from the verb pāpeti. The word sampāpako is derived from the verb sampāpeti. The word upāsako is a name for a man. The word upāsikā is a name for a woman.

original: saṅkhārako, abhisaṅkhārako, khipatīti khipako, ukkhipako, nikkhipako, khepako, ukkhepako,
analyzed: saṅkhārakaḥ abhisaṅkhārakaḥ khipati iti khipakaḥ ukkhipakaḥ nikkhipakaḥ khepakaḥ ukkhepakaḥ
translated: The word upāsakaṃ is a name for a family. The word kārako is derived from the verb karotī. The words kārikā, kārakaṃ, upakārako are names for a plough. The word kārāpako is derived from the verb kārāpeti. The word saṅkhārako is derived from the verb saṅkharoti. The word abhisaṅkhārako is derived from the verb abhisaṅkharoti. The word khipako is derived from the verb khipati. The words ukkhipako, nikkhipako, khepako, ukkhepako, nikkhepako are names for one who throws.

original: nikkhepako, nāgamekhipanako.
analyzed: nikkhepakaḥ nāga mekhipanakaḥ
translated: The word nāgamekhipanako is a name for one who throws a discus.

original: Gaṇhātīti gāhako, gaṇhāpetīti gāhāpako. Evaṃ gopako, pādamūle caratīti pādacārako, pupphaṃ ocināyatīti ocināyako, edanto dhātu.
analyzed: gaṇhāti iti gāhakaḥ evam gopako pāda mūle carati iti pāda cārako puppham ocināyati iti ocināyako e t antaḥ dhātu
translated: In the case of the words gaṇhāti, the word gāhako is derived from the verb gaṇhāti. The word gāhāpako is derived from the verb gāhāpeti. The words gopako, pādacārako are names for a watchman. The word ocināyako is derived from the verb ocināyati. The word edanto is a name for a root.

original: Chindatīti chedako, chindako, chedāpetīti chedāpako, chindāpako, janetīti janako-puriso, janikāmātā, janakaṃ-kammaṃ, kāritalopo.🔽Jhāpa-dāhe, jhāpetīti jhāpako.🔽Ñapa-paññāpane, paññapetīti paññāpako.🔽Ṭhāpa-ṭhāne, patiṭṭhāpetīti patiṭṭhāpako.🔽Ṇāpa-pesane, āṇāpetīti āṇāpako, tudatīti tudako, santussatīti santussako, visesena passatīti vipassako, sandassetīti sandassako, dūsetīti dūsako, ādidīgho.🔽Pacatīti pācako, pācetīti pācāpako, āpādetīti āpādako, nipphādako, sampādako, paṭipajjako, paṭipādako, pūretīti pūrako, garupantattā na vuddhi.🔽Phusatīti phusako, tudādittā na vuddhi.
analyzed: chindati iti chedako chindako chedāpeti iti chedāpako chindāpakaḥ janeti iti janakopurisaḥ janikā mātā jana kaṃkammam kārita lopo  jhāpa dāhe jhāpa iti iti  ñapa paññāpane paññapeti iti paññāpakaḥ  ṭhāpa ṭhāne patiṭṭhāpeti iti patiṭṭhāpakaḥ  āṇāpeti iti āṇāpakaḥ tudati iti tudakaḥ santussati iti santussakaḥ visesena passati iti vipassakaḥ sandasseti iti sandassakaḥ dūseti iti dūsakaḥ ādi dīghaḥ  pacati iti pācako pāceti iti pācāpako āpādeti iti āpādakaḥ nipphādako sampādako paṭipajjako paṭipādako pūreti iti pūrakaḥ garu panta ttā na  phusati iti na

original: bhojako, gāmabhojako, bujjhatīti bujjhako, bodhako, maratīti miyyako, māretīti mārako,
analyzed: bhojakaḥ gām abhojakaḥ bujjhati iti bujjhakaḥ bodhakaḥ marati iti miyyakaḥ māreti iti mārakaḥ
translated: One who eats is a bhojaka. One who eats a village is a gāmabhojaka. One who wakes is a bujjhako. One who awakens is a bodhako. One who dies is a miyyako. One who kills is a mārako.

original: muñcatīti muñcako, mocako, yācatīti yācako, yajatīti yājako, yuñjatīti yuñjako, anuyuñjako,
analyzed: muñcati iti muñcakaḥ mocakaḥ yācati iti yācakaḥ yajati iti yājakaḥ yuñjati iti yuñjakaḥ anuyuñjakaḥ
translated: One who releases is a muñcako, a mocako. One who begs is a yācako. One who sacrifices is a yājako. One who yokes is a yuñjako, an anuyuñjako.

original: yojako, payojako, yujjhatīti yujjhako, yodhako, rundhatīti rundhako, avarodhako,
analyzed: yojakaḥ payojakaḥ yujjhati iti yujjhakaḥ yodhakaḥ rundhati iti rundhakaḥ avarodhakaḥ
translated: One who joins is a yojako, a payojako. One who fights is a yujjhako, a yodhako. One who obstructs is a rundhako, an avarodhako.

original: vacatīti vācako, ovadatīti ovādako, ovajjako, vīṇaṃ vādetīti vīṇāvādako, bherivādako,🔽garuṃ abhivādetīti abhivādako, vidatijānātīti vedako, vindati paṭilabhatīti vindako,
analyzed: vacati iti vācakaḥ ovadati iti ovādakaḥ ovajjakaḥ vīṇam vādeti iti vīṇā vādakaḥ bherī vādakaḥ  garum abhivāda iti iti abhivādakaḥ
translated: One who speaks is a vācako. One who advises is an ovādako, an ovajjako. One who plays the lute is a vīṇāvādako, a bherivādako.🔽One who pays respect is an abhivādako. One who knows by cutting is a vedako. One who finds, who obtains, is a vindako.

original: anuvijjati vicāretīti anuvijjako, paṭisaṃvedetīti paṭisaṃvedako, vijjhatīti vedhako,
analyzed: anuvijjati vicāreti iti anuvijjakaḥ paṭisaṃvedeti iti paṭisaṃvedakaḥ vijjhati iti vedhako
translated: One who investigates, who examines, is an anuvijjako. One who experiences is a paṭisaṃvedako. One who is pierced is a vedhako.

original: aṭṭhiṃ vijjhatīti aṭṭhivedhako, pattaṃ vijjhatīti pattavedhako.
analyzed: aṭṭhim vijjhati iti aṭṭhi vedhako pattam vijjhati iti patta vedhako
translated: One who is pierced in the bone is an aṭṭhivedhako. One who is pierced in the leaf is a pattavedhako.

original: Bahulādhikārā kammepi dissati, antare vāsīyati nivāsīyatīti antaravāsako, pasīdatīti
analyzed: bahula adhikārā kamme pi dissati antare vāsīyati nivāsīyati iti antaravāsakaḥ pasīdati iti
translated: Because of frequent usage, it is also seen in the sense of an action: One who is clothed is an antaravāsako. One who is cooled is a pasīdako.

original: pasīdako, pasādako vā, dīpappasādako, udakappasādako, sibbatīti sibbako, sevatīti
analyzed: pasīdako pasādako vā dīpa pasādako udaka ppasādako sibbati iti sibbako sevati iti
translated: Pasīdako, pasādako, dīpappasādako, udakappasādako, sibbatīti sibbako, sevatīti

original: sevako, hanatīti ghātako, gāvo hanatīti goghātako, hanassa ghāto. Haratīti hārako.
analyzed: sevakaḥ hanati iti ghātakaḥ gāvaḥ hanati iti go ghātakaḥ hanassa ghātaḥ harati iti hārako
translated: sevako, hanatīti ghātako, gāvo hanatīti goghātako, hanassa ghāto. Haratīti hārako.

original: Kamme – “pādehi paharīyatīti pādapahārako”ti vuttiyaṃ vuttaṃ. Titikkhatīti titikkhako,
analyzed: kamme pādehi paharīyati iti pāda pahārako ti vuttiyam vuttam titikkhati iti titikkhako
translated: In the sense of ‘he is struck with his feet’ the reading is pādapahārako. Titikkhatīti titikkhako,

original: tikicchatīti tikicchako, vīmaṃsatīti vīmaṃsako, bubhukkhatīti bubhukkhako, pabbatāyatīti pabbatāyako iccādi.🔽Iti akapaccayarāsi.
analyzed: tikicchati iti tikicchakaḥ vīmaṃsati iti vīmaṃsakaḥ bubhukkhati iti bubhukkhakaḥ pabbatāyati iti pabbatāyakaḥ iccādi  iti a ka pad ca ya rā si
translated: tikicchatīti tikicchako, vīmaṃsatīti vīmaṃsako, bubhukkhatīti bubhukkhako, pabbatāyatīti pabbatāyako iccādi.

original: Ivaṇṇantarūparāsi
analyzed: i va ṇ ṇ anta rūpa rā asi
translated: Thus the section on the indeclinable particles.🔽The section on the change of vowel sound

original: Atha ivaṇṇantarūpāni vuccante.🔽792. Dādhātvi ka. 551; rū. 598; nī. 1138.
analyzed: atha i v a ṇ anta rūpāni vuccante  dādhātvi ka rū nī
translated: Now the change of vowel sound is stated.🔽Dādhātvi ka. ; rū. ; nī. .

original: Dā, dhāhi bhāvakārakesu ipaccayo hoti.
analyzed: dā dhā hi bhāva kārakesu i paccayaḥ hoti
translated: The particle i is used in the sense of the root dā, dhā, bhā, and kā.

original: Paṭhamaṃ cittena ādīyatītiādi, taṇhādiṭṭhīhi upādīyatīti upādi, khandhupādi, kilesupādi,
analyzed: paṭhamam cittena ādīyati itiādi taṇhā diṭṭhīhi upādīyati iti upādi khandhu pādi kilesu pādi
translated: Paṭhamaṃ cittena ādīyatītiādi, taṇhādiṭṭhīhi upādīyatīti upādi, khandhupādi, kilesupādi,

original: vidhānaṃ vidhi, vidhiyyati etenāti vidhi, nidhiyyatīti nidhi, sandhiyate sandhi,
analyzed: vidhānam vidhi vidhiyyati etena ati vidhi nidhiyyati iti nidhi sandhiyate sandhi
translated: Vidhānaṃ vidhi, vidhiyyati etenāti vidhi, nidhiyyatīti nidhi, sandhiyate sandhi,

original: abhisandhi, paṭisandhi, sannidahanaṃ sannidhi, samādhānaṃ samādhi, samādahanti etenāti🔽samādhi, paṇidahanaṃ paṇidhi, odhi, avadhi, upanidhi, paṭinidhi, udakaṃ dahati tiṭṭhati🔽etthāti udadhi, mahanto udadhi mahodadhi, vālāni dahanti tiṭṭhanti etthāti vāladhi.🔽793. Ikitī sarūpe ka. 669; rū. 679; nī. 1315.
analyzed: abhisandhi paṭisandhi sannidahanam sannidhi samādhānam samādhi samādahanti etena ati  samādhi paṇidahanam paṇidhi odhi avadhi upanidhi paṭinidhi udakam dahati tiṭṭhati  ettha ati udadhi mahantaḥ udadhi mahodadhi vālāni dahanti tiṭṭhanti ettha ati vāladhi  i k itī sarūpe ka rū nī
translated: The meaning of the word abhisandhi is “a joining to” (abhisandhi). The meaning of the word paṭisandhi is “a re-joining” (paṭisandhi). The meaning of the word sannidhi is “a storing up” (sannidhi). The meaning of the word samādhi is “a putting together” (samādhi). The meaning of the word paṇidhi is “a putting down” (paṇidhi). The meaning of the word odhi is “a burning” (adhi). The meaning of the word avadhi is “a burning” (adhi). The meaning of the word upanidhi is “a burning” (adhi). The meaning of the word paṭinidhi is “a burning” (adhi). The meaning of the word udadhi is “a standing of waters” (udakaṃ dahati tiṭṭhati etthāti udadhi). The meaning of the word mahodadhi is “a great standing of waters” (mahanto udadhi mahodadhi). The meaning of the word vāladhi is “a burning of hairs” (vālaṃ dahanti tiṭṭhanti etthāti vāladhi).🔽The word ika is a synonym for the word sarūpa.

original: Dhātūnaṃ sutisaṅkhāte sarūpe vattabbe kriyatthā paraṃ i, ki, tipaccayā honti.🔽Avaṇṇupantehi i, gami, paci iccādi.🔽Uvaṇṇupantehi ki, budhi, rudhi iccādi.🔽Kehiciti, karotissa, atthissa iccādi.🔽794. Sīlābhikkhaññāvassakesu ṇī ka. 532, 636; rū. 590, 659; nī. 1114, 1245.🔽Sīlaṃ vuccati pakaticariyā, abhikkhaṇameva abhikkhaññaṃ, punappunakriyā, āyatiṃ avassaṃbhāvī

original: avassakaṃ nāma, sīlaggahaṇena dhamma, sādhukārāpi saṅgayhanti, etesu sīlādīsu kriyāvisesesu
analyzed: avassakam nāma sīla ggahaṇena dhamma sādhukārāḥ api saṅgayhanti etesu sīla ādīsu kriyā visesesu
translated: “One who does not let slip” is one who does not let slip the Dhamma by taking up virtue. The words of approval are included here.

original: gamyamānesu kattari ṇī hoti. Ādantesu ‘āssāṇāpimhi yuka’iti yāgamo.
analyzed: gamyamānesu kattari ṇī hoti ā t antesu yu ka eti yā gamaḥ
translated: When these are being done, the -ṇī affix is added to the verbal noun formed from the root meaning the agent, and the -ā suffix is added to the verbal noun formed from the root meaning the instrument.

original: Akkhāyatīti akkhāyī, akkhāyanasīlo, akkhāyanadhammo, akkhāne sakkaccakāritā yuttoti attho. Kālattayepi sijjhati sāmaññavidhānattā.
analyzed: akkhāyati iti akkhāyī akkhāyana sīlaḥ akkhāyana dhammaḥ akkhāne sakkacca kāri tā yuttaḥ ti attho kāla ttaye pi sijjhati sāmañña vidhāna ttā
translated: “One who teaches the Dhamma” is one who teaches the Dhamma, one who has the habit of teaching the Dhamma, one who has the nature of teaching the Dhamma, one who is occupied with teaching the Dhamma. The meaning is: “one who is occupied with teaching the Dhamma.” It is used in all three tenses because the general rule applies.

original: Avassakaṃ pana anāgatameva, dhammakkhāyī-puriso, dhammakkhāyinī-itthī, dhammakkhāyi-kulaṃ,
analyzed: avassakam pana anāgatam eva dhammakkhāyī purisaḥ dhammakkhāyinī itthī dhammakkhāyi kulam
translated: But “one who does not let slip” is only used in the future tense. A man who teaches the Dhamma is a dhammakkhāyī-puriso. A woman who teaches the Dhamma is a dhammakkhāyinī-itthī. A family that teaches the Dhamma is a dhammakkhāyi-kula.

original: gītaṃ abhiṇhaṃ gāyatīti gītagāyī, kappaṃ avassaṃ ṭhāssatīti kappaṭṭhāyī, saṃvaṭṭamānaṃ🔽asaṅkhyeyyaṃ ṭhāssatīti saṃvaṭṭaṭṭhāyī. Evaṃ vivaṭṭaṭṭhāyī.
analyzed: gītam abhiṇham gāyati iti gīta gāyī kappam avassam ṭhāssati iti kappa ṭṭhāyī saṃvaṭṭamānam  asaṅkhyeyyam ṭhāssati iti saṃvaṭṭa ṭhāyī evam vivaṭṭa ṭhāyī
translated: “One who sings songs” is one who sings songs again and again. “One who endures for an aeon” is one who will endure for an aeon, that is, for as long as the aeon lasts. “One who endures for the duration of the world” is one who will endure for as long as the world endures, that is, for as long as the aeon lasts.

original: Adinnaṃ ādadāti sīlenāti adinnādāyī. Tathā dinnameva ādadātīti dinnādāyī, annaṃ dadāti sīlenāti annadāyī.
analyzed: a dinnam ādadāti sīlena ati a dinna ādāyī tathā dinnam eva ādadāti iti dinna ādāyī annam dadāti sīlena ati anna dāyī
translated: “One who steals what is not given” is one who steals what is not given. “One who takes what is given” is one who takes only what is given. “One who gives food” is one who gives food.

original: Dā-suppane. Niddāyanasīlo niddāyī, majjaṃ pivanasīlo majjapāyī, majjaṃ abhiṇhaṃ pivatīti
analyzed: dāsuppane niddāyana sīlaḥ niddāyī majjam pivana sīlaḥ majja pāyī majjam abhiṇham pivati iti
translated: Dā-suppane. Niddāyanasīlo niddāyī, majjaṃ pivanasīlo majjapāyī, majjaṃ abhiṇhaṃ pivatīti

original: majjapāyī, sīghaṃ yāyanasīlo sīghayāyī, sasaṅkhārena sappayogena avassaṃ parinibbāyissatīti
analyzed: majja pāyī sīgham yāyana sīlo sīgha yāyī sa saṅkhārena sa payogena avassam parinibbāyissati iti
translated: majjapāyī, sīghaṃ yāyanasīlo sīghayāyī, sasaṅkhārena sappayogena avassaṃ parinibbāyissatīti

original: sasaṅkhāraparinibbāyī. Tathā asaṅkhāraparinibbāyī, āyukappassa antare vemajjhe avassaṃ
analyzed: sa saṅkhāra parinibbāyī tathā asaṅkhāra parinibbāyī āyu kappassa antare vemajjhe avassam
translated: sasaṅkhāraparinibbāyī. Tathā asaṅkhāraparinibbāyī, āyukappassa antare vemajjhe avassaṃ

original: parinibbāyissatīti antarāparinibbāyī, āyukappapariyosānaṃ upahacca avassaṃ parinibbāyissatīti
analyzed: parinibbāyissati iti antarāparinibbāyī āyu kappa pariyosānam upahacca avassam parinibbāyissati iti
translated: parinibbāyissatīti antarāparinibbāyī, āyukappapariyosānaṃ upahacca avassaṃ parinibbāyissatīti

original: upahaccaparinibbāyī iccādi.
analyzed: upahacca parinibbāyī iccādi
translated: upahaccaparinibbāyī iccādi.

original: Ivaṇṇesu-mantaṃ niccakālaṃ ajjhāyatīti mantajjhāyī, dhammajjhāyī, dhaññaṃ niccakālaṃ
analyzed: niccakālam ajjhāyati iti manta jjhāyī dhamma jhāyī dhaññam niccakālam
translated: Ivaṇṇesu-mantaṃ niccakālaṃ ajjhāyatīti mantajjhāyī, dhammajjhāyī, dhaññaṃ niccakālaṃ

original: vikkiṇātīti dhaññavikkāyī, bhāyanasīlo bhāyī, bhūmiyaṃ sayanasīlo, bhūmiyaṃ vā niccakālaṃ
analyzed: vikkiṇāti iti dhañña vikkāyī bhāyana sīlaḥ bhāyī bhūmiyam sayana sīlaḥ bhūmiyam vā niccakālam
translated: vikkiṇātīti dhaññavikkāyī, bhāyanasīlo bhāyī, bhūmiyaṃ sayanasīlo, bhūmiyaṃ vā niccakālaṃ

original: sayatīti bhūmisāyī, kaṇṭake apassayanasīlo kaṇṭakāpassayī iccādi.
analyzed: sayati iti bhūmi sāyī kaṇṭake apassayana sīlaḥ kaṇṭaka apassayī iccādi
translated: sayatīti bhūmisāyī, kaṇṭake apassayanasīlo kaṇṭakāpassayī iccādi.

original: Edantāpi idha vattabbā, uddhaṃ vaḍḍhanasīlo udāyī, vuddhesu apacāyanasīlo vuddhāpacāyī.
analyzed: e t antā api idha vattabbā uddham vaḍḍhana sīlaḥ udāyī vuddhesu apacāyana sīlaḥ vuddha apacāyī
translated: The following should be mentioned here too: Edantāpi idha vattabbā, uddhaṃ vaḍḍhanasīlo udāyī, vuddhesu apacāyanasīlo vuddhāpacāyī.

original: Evaṃ jeṭṭhāpacāyī, jhāyanasīlo, jhāyanadhammo, jhāyane sakkaccakriyāyuttoti jhāyī,
analyzed: evam jeṭṭha apacāyī jhāyana sīlaḥ jhāyana dhammaḥ jhāyane sakkacca kriyā yuttaḥ ti jhāyī
translated: Evaṃ jeṭṭhāpacāyī, jhāyanasīlo jhāyanadhammo jhāyane sakkaccakriyāyuttoti jhāyī,

original: niccakālaṃ jhāyatīti vā jhāyī, pajjhāyī, ujjhāyī, nijjhāyī, abhijjhāyī, bhāyanasīlo
analyzed: niccakālam jhāyati iti vā jhāyī pajjhāyī ujjhāyī nijjhāyī abhijjhāyī bhāyana sīlo
translated: Niccakālaṃ jhāyatīti vā jhāyī, pajjhāyī, ujjhāyī, nijjhāyī, abhijjhāyī, bhāyanasīlo

original: bhāyī, tiṇaṃ abhiṇhaṃ lāyatīti tiṇalāyī, tantaṃ niccakālaṃ vāyatīti tantavāyī, palāyanasīlo
analyzed: bhāyī tiṇam abhiṇham lāyati iti tiṇa lāyī tantam niccakālam vāyati iti tanta vāyī palāyana sīlaḥ
translated: Bhāyī, tiṇaṃ abhiṇhaṃ lāyatīti tiṇalāyī, tantaṃ niccakālaṃ vāyatīti tantavāyī, palāyanasīlo

original: palāyī, na palāyī apalāyī iccādi.
analyzed: palāyī na palāyī apalāyī iccādi
translated: Palāyī, na palāyī apalāyī iccādi.

original: Uvaṇṇesu-yathābhūtaṃ atthaṃ vibhāvanasīlo vibhāvīpuriso, vibhāvinī-itthī, āyatiṃ avassaṃ bhavissatīti bhāvī, sāliṃ lunāti sīlenāti sālilāvī iccādi.
analyzed: attham vibhāvana sīlaḥ vibhāvī purisaḥ vibhāvinī itthī āyatim avassam bhavissati iti bhāvī sālim lunāti sīlena ati sāli lāvī iccādi
translated: Uvaṇṇesu-yathābhūtaṃ atthaṃ vibhāvanasīlo vibhāvīpuriso, vibhāvinī-itthī, āyatiṃ avassaṃ bhavissatīti bhāvī, sāliṃ lunāti sīlenāti sālilāvī iccādi.

original: Byāpanasīlo byāpī, kāmeti icchati sīlenāti kāmī, dhammakāmī, atthakāmī, karaṇasīlo kārī, pāpakārī, puññakārī.
analyzed: byāpana sīlaḥ byāpī kāmeti icchati sīlena ati kāmī dhamma kāmī attha kāmī karaṇa sīlaḥ kārī pāpa kārī puñña kārī
translated: Byāpanasīlo byāpī, kāmeti icchati sīlenāti kāmī, dhammakāmī, atthakāmī, karaṇasīlo kārī, pāpakārī, puññakārī.

original: Avassaṃ āgamissatīti āgāmī. Rassatte-āgaminīratti, āgaminī-puṇṇamāsī, ācayaṃ vaṭṭaṃ🔽gacchati sīlenāti ācayagāmī, apacayaṃ vivaṭṭaṃ gacchati sīlenāti apacayagāmī, sakiṃ
analyzed: avassam āgamissati iti āgāmī āgaminī puṇṇamāsī ācayam vaṭṭam  gacchati sīlena ati ācaya gāmī apacayam vivaṭṭam gacchati sīlena ati apacaya gāmī sakim
translated: He will come again, it seems, so he is a “come-againer” . The night that comes again is the full moon night; the round of existence that comes again is the round of rebirths.

original: avassaṃ āgamissatīti sakadāgāmī. Tathā na āgamissatīti anāgāmī.
analyzed: avassam āgamissati iti sakadāgāmī tathā na āgamissati iti anāgāmī
translated: He goes by the way of accumulation, so he is an “accumulator” . He goes by the way of diminution, so he is a “diminisher” . He will come again once, it seems, so he is a “once-returner” . He will not come again in that way, so he is a “non-returner” .

original: Ādhānaṃ vuccati daḷhaṭṭhiti, ādhānaṃ katvā gahaṇasīlo ādhānagāhī, daḷhagāhī, dhammaṃ carati sīlenāti dhammacārī, brahmaṃ seṭṭhaṃ carati sīlenāti brahmacārī.🔽Apicettha dhammo nāma kulācāradhammo, taṃ dhammaṃ carāmīti daḷhaṃ gaṇhitvā yāva na🔽vijahati, tāva avītikkamanaṭṭhena dhammaṃ carati sīlenāti dhammacārī nāma. Tathācaranto
analyzed: ādhānam vuccati daḷha ṭṭhiti ādhānam katvā gahaṇa sīlaḥ ādhāna gāhī daḷha gāhī dhammam carati sīlena ati dhamma cārī brahmam seṭṭham carati sīlena ati brahmacārī  apica ittha dhammo nāma kula ācāra dhammo tam dhammam carāmi iti daḷham gaṇhitvā yāva na  vijahati tāva a vītikkamana ṭṭhena dhammam carati sīlena ati dhamma cārī nāma tathā ācarantaḥ
translated: “Taking up” is called firm maintenance. He has the habit of taking up by taking up firmly, so he is a “taker-up” . He is a “firm-grasper” . He goes by the way of the Dhamma, so he is a “Dhamma-goer” . He goes by the way of the supreme, so he is a “Brahma-goer” .🔽And here the Dhamma is the Dhamma of families’ custom. He goes by the way of that Dhamma, taking it up firmly, so long as he does not abandon it, since he does not transgress it, he is called a “Dhamma-goer” .

original: ca antarāvītikkamanīyavatthusamāyoge sati taṃ dhammaṃ apatamānaṃ katvā dhārento saṃvaraṇaṭṭhena
analyzed: ca antarā avītikkamanīya vatthu samāyoge sati tam dhammam a patamānam katvā dhārento saṃvaraṇa ṭṭhena
translated: And while he is going in this way, if there is occasion for transgression of the minor training rules, he maintains that Dhamma without letting it go, so he is a “maintainer” .

original: dhammaṃ carati dhammenāti dhammacārī nāma, tathādhārento ca taṃ dhammaṃ attukkaṃsana,
analyzed: dhammam carati dhammena ati dhammacārī nāma tathā dhārentaḥ ca tam dhammam attukkaṃsana
translated: He is called “virtuous” because he conducts himself by the Dhamma.

original: paravambhanādīhi pāpadhammehi anupakkiliṭṭhañca appicchatādīhi santaguṇehi supariyodātañca
analyzed: para vambhana ādīhi pāpa dhammehi anupakkiliṭṭham ca appiccha tā ādīhi santa guṇehi su pariyodātam ca
translated: And he is called “virtuous” because he conducts himself by the Dhamma in the sense of purifying it, by not defiling it with evil conduct such as boasting about himself and disparaging others, and by making it very bright with such good qualities as fewness of wishes.

original: karonto pariyodāpanaṭṭhena dhammaṃ carati sādhukārenāti dhammacārī nāma.
analyzed: karontaḥ pariyodāpana ṭṭhena dhammam carati sādhukārena ati dhammacārī nāma
translated: He is called “virtuous” because he conducts himself by the Dhamma in the sense of purifying it by making it very bright.

original: Brahmaṃ vuccati tato seṭṭhataraṃ sikkhāpadasīlaṃ, tampi gaṇhitvā avijahanto antarā
analyzed: brahmam vuccati tatas seṭṭhataram sikkhāpada sīlam tam pi gaṇhitvā a vijahantaḥ antarā
translated: The training precepts are called “the divine life” because they are better than that. He is called “one who lives the divine life” because he takes up and does not cast aside,

original: ca apatamānaṃ katvā dhārento anupakkiliṭṭhaṃ supariyodātañca karonto tividhena atthena
analyzed: ca a patamānam katvā dhārentaḥ an upakkiliṭṭham su pariyodātam ca karontaḥ tividhena atthena
translated: and because he conducts himself by the divine life in the sense of purifying it by not defiling it and by making it very bright, in the three ways

original: brahmacārī nāma, samādāna, sampatta, samucchedaviratīnaṃ vasena viyojetuṃ vaṭṭati,🔽yo pana gaṇhanto tathā na dhāreti, dhārento vā upakkiliṭṭhaṃ karoti, so ekadesena
analyzed: brahmacārī nāma vasena viyojetum vaṭṭati  yaḥ pana gaṇhantaḥ tathā na dhāreti dhārentaḥ vā upakkiliṭṭham karoti saḥ ekadesena
translated: of meaning. He is called “one who lives the divine life” in the sense of the undertaking, the arrival, and the cutting off.

original: atthena brahmacārī nāma.
analyzed: atthena brahmacārī nāma
translated: But one who takes it up and does not conduct himself by it, or who conducts himself by it and defiles it, is called “one who lives the divine life” in one sense only.

original: Yo pana tividhena atthena mutto hutvā kadāci taṃ dhammaṃ carati, tassa caraṇakriyā
analyzed: yaḥ pana tividhena atthena muttaḥ hutvā kadāci tam dhammam carati tassa caraṇa kriyā
translated: But one who is free in the three ways and sometimes conducts himself by the divine life, his action of conducting himself by it

original: tassīlakriyā na hoti, so dhammacārīti na vuccati, etenupāyena sesesu pāpa, kalyāṇabhūtesu🔽tassīlapadesu atthavibhāgo veditabbo.
analyzed: tassa sīla kriyā na hoti so dhamma cārī iti na vuccati etena upāyena sesesu pāpa kalyāṇa bhūtesu  attha vibhāgaḥ veditabbo
translated: His virtue is not done, he is not called one who lives by Dhamma. By this means the exposition of the meaning should be understood in the case of the other bad and good ideas.

original: Brahmacārinī-itthī, visesena dassanasīlo vipassī, atthadassī, dhammadassī, piyadassī,
analyzed: brahmacārinī itthī visesena dassana sīlaḥ vipassī attha dassī dhamma dassī piya dassī
translated: A woman who is chaste: a woman who is a celibate. One who has the habit of seeing, one who sees specifically, is a vipassī. One who sees meaning, one who sees ideas, is a dhammadassī. One who sees what is dear, is a piyadassī.

original: sudassī, dussanasīlo dussīmāro, dhāraṇasīlo dhārī, iṇadhārī, chattadhārī, bhusaṃ
analyzed: su dassī dussana sīlaḥ dussīmāraḥ dhāraṇa sīlaḥ dhārī iṇa dhārī chatta dhārī bhusam
translated: One who sees well, is a sudassī. One who has the habit of seeing what is bad, one who sees a bad state, is a dussī. One who has the habit of bearing, one who bears, is a dhārī. One who bears a debt, is an iṇadhārī. One who bears an umbrella, is a chattadhārī. One who bears a burden, is a bhusaṃbhārī.

original: nahanasīlo upanāhī, pariniṭṭhitapaccayekadesattā āyatiṃ avassaṃ uppajjissatīti uppādī,
analyzed: nahana sīlaḥ upanāhī pariniṭṭhita paccaya eka desa ttā āyatim avassam uppajjissati iti uppādī
translated: One who has the habit of bathing, one who bathes, is an upaṇāhī. Because of the possession of a part of the conditions for the completion, he will arise in the future without fail, thus he is an uppādī.

original: uppādino dhammā dha. sa. tikamātikā 17.
analyzed: uppādinaḥ dhammā sa tika mātikā
translated: The ideas that are arising are dhammas. Sa. The three-factored Matrix.

original: Bhara-dhāraṇe, mālaṃ niccakālaṃ bharatīti mālabhārī, bhājanasīlo bhājī, uṇhaṃ bhuñjanasīlo🔽uṇhabhojī, attānaṃ maññati sīlenāti attamānī, attānaṃ paṇḍitaṃ maññatīti paṇḍitamānī,
analyzed: bhara dhāraṇe mālam nicca kālam bharati iti māla bhārī bhājana sīlaḥ bhājī uṇham bhuñjana sīlaḥ  uṇha bhojī attānam maññati sīlena ati atta mānī attānam paṇḍitam maññati iti paṇḍita mānī
translated: One who bears a burden, one who bears a garland, is a mālabhārī. One who has the habit of a vessel, is a bhājī. One who has the habit of eating hot food, is an uṇhabhojī.🔽He thinks himself virtuous, thus he is an attamānī. He thinks himself wise, thus he is a paṇḍitamānī.

original: labhanasīlo lābhī, vacanasīlo vācī. Evaṃ vādī, atthavādī, dhammavādī, yuttavādī,
analyzed: labhana sīlaḥ lābhī vacana sīlaḥ vācī evam vādī attha vādī dhamma vādī yutta vādī
translated: One who has the habit of receiving, one who receives, is a lābhī. One who has the habit of speech, one who speaks, is a vādī. One who speaks thus, is an evaṃvādī. One who speaks about meaning, is an atthavādī. One who speaks about ideas, is a dhammavādī. One who speaks appropriately, is a yuttavādī.

original: muttavādī, vibhajjavādī, niccaṃ vasatīti vāsī, gāmavāsī, nagaravāsī, bhāraṃ vahanasīlo🔽bhāravāhī, dhammaṃ paññaṃ anusarati anugacchatīti dhammānusārī. Evaṃ saddhānusārī,🔽virūpaṃ pāpapakkhaṃ paṭimukhaṃ abhiṇhaṃ sarati cintetīti vippaṭisārī, pāṇaṃ hanati🔽sīlenāti pāṇaghātī, hanassa ghāto.
analyzed: mutta vādī vibhajja vādī niccam vasati iti vāsī gāma vāsī nagara vāsī bhāram vahana sīlaḥ  bhāra vāhī dhammam paññam anusarati anugacchati iti dhamma anusārī evam saddhā anusārī  virūpam pāpa pakkham paṭimukham abhiṇham sarati cinteti iti vippaṭisārī pāṇam hanati  sīlena ati pāṇa ghātī hanassa ghāto
translated: “One who speaks what is true” is a truth-speaker. “One who speaks after analysis” is an analyzer. “One who always lives” is a dweller. “One who lives in a village” is a villager. “One who lives in a town” is a town-dweller. “One who has the habit of carrying a load” is a carrier. “One who follows, who goes after, the Dhamma and wisdom” is a follower of the Dhamma. Thus “one who follows by faith” is a faith-follower.🔽“One who often remembers, who often thinks, the ugly side, the bad side, face to face” is a repenter. “One who kills breathing things” is a killer.🔽“By means of virtue” is a killer by means of virtue. “The killing” is the killing.

original: Haritabbaṃ sabbaṃ harati sīlenāti hārahārī iccādi.🔽‘Kagā cajāna’nti suttavibhattiyā aghānubandhepi cajānaṃ kagādeso, samaṃ vipācetīti🔽samavepākī-udaraggi, samavepākinī-gahaṇī, upadhi phalaṃ vipaccatīti upadhivepākinī,🔽socanasīlo sokī, sokinī-pajā, mutto hutvā cajanasīlo muttacāgī, saṃvibhājanasīlo🔽saṃvibhāgī, kāmasukhaṃ bhuñjanasīlo kāmabhogī, visuṃ avibhattaṃ bhogaṃ bhuñjanasīlo
analyzed: haritabbam sabbam harati sīlena ati hāra hārī iccādi 🔽ka gā ca jānanti sutta vibhattiyā agha anubandhe pi ca jānam ka ga ādesaḥ samam vipāceti iti 🔽sama vepākī udara ggi sama vepākinī gahaṇī upadhi phalam vipaccati iti upadhivepākinī 🔽socana sīlaḥ sokī sokinī pajā muttaḥ hutvā cajana sīlaḥ mutta cāgī saṃvibhājana sīlaḥ 🔽saṃvibhāgī kāma sukham bhuñjana sīlaḥ kāma bhogī visum a vibhattam bhogam bhuñjana sīlaḥ
translated: One who speaks what is true is a truth-speaker . One who speaks after analysis is an analyst . One who always lives is a dweller . One who lives in a village is a villager . One who lives in a town is a town-dweller . One who has the habit of carrying a load is a bearer . One who follows, who goes after, the faith is a faith-follower . One who follows, who goes after, the Dhamma is a Dhamma-follower . One who follows, who goes after, the Plight is a Plight-follower . One who follows, who goes after, the view is a view-follower . One who follows, who goes after, the persuasion is a persuasion-follower . One who follows, who goes after, the tradition is a tradition-follower . One who follows, who goes after, the reasoning is a reasoning-follower . One who follows, who goes after, the intimation is an intimation-follower . One who follows, who goes after, the doctrine is a doctrine-follower . One who follows, who goes after, the discipline is a discipline-follower . One who follows, who goes after, the teaching is a teaching-follower . One who follows, who goes after, the instruction is an instruction-follower . One who follows, who goes after, the Thread is a Thread-follower . One who follows, who goes after, the path is a path-follower . One who follows, who goes after, the way is a way-follower . One who follows, who goes after, the practice is a practice-follower . One who follows, who goes after, the undertaking is an undertaking-follower . One who follows, who goes after, the observance is an observance-follower . One who follows, who goes after, the rightness is a rightness-follower . One who follows, who goes after, the right way is a right-way-follower . One who follows, who goes after, the right practice is a right-practice-follower . One who follows, who goes after, the rightness of practice is a right-practice-rightness-follower . One who follows, who goes after, the rightness of the way is a right-way-rightness-follower . One who follows, who goes after, the rightness of undertaking is an undertaking-rightness-follower . One who follows, who goes after, the rightness of observance is an observance-rightness-follower . One who follows

original: Muda-hāse, modanaṃ mudā, pamudā, sujjhati etāyāti sudhā, vasuṃ ratanaṃ dhāretīti vasudhā iccādi.
analyzed: muda hāse modanam mudā pamudā sujjhati etā āyāti sudhā vasum ratanam dhārā iti iti vasudhā iccādi
translated: Mudā hāso = mudahāso, the laughter of joy. Modanaṃ mudā = modanaṃ mudā, the delight of delight. Pamudā = pamudā, the delight of delight. Sujjhati etāya = suddhā, it purifies. Vasuṃ ratanaṃ dhāreti = vasudhā, it bears the treasure of the earth.

original: Amhi-saṅkhāyanti etāyāti saṅkhā. Tathā saṅkhyā, pajānātīti paññā, ājānātīti aññā,🔽sañjānātīti saññā, sañjānanti etāyāti vā saññā, sañjānanaṃ vā saññā, abhijānanaṃ
analyzed: amhisaṅkhāyanti etāya ati saṅkhā tathā saṅkhyā pajānāti iti paññā ājānāti iti aññā  sañjānāti iti saññā sañjānanti etāya ati vā saññā sañjānanam vā saññā abhijānanam
translated: Amhi saṅkhāyāti etāya = saṅkhā, it is reckoned by this. Saṅkhyā = saṅkhā, it is counted by this. Paññāyati = paññā, it is known. ājānāti = aññā, it is understood.

original: abhiññā, paṭijānanaṃ paṭiññā, paricchijja jānanaṃ pariññā, paṭicca tiṭṭhati etthāti patiṭṭhā.
analyzed: abhiññā paṭijānanam paṭiññā paricchijja jānanam pariññā paṭicca tiṭṭhati ettha ati patiṭṭhā
translated: Sañjānāti = saññā, it is perceived. Sañjānanti etāya = saññā, it is perceived by this. Sañjānanaṃ = saññā, perception. Abhiññāyati = abhiññā, it is directly known. Paṭijānāti = paṭiññā, it is admitted. Parikkhiṇṇaṃ jānanaṃ = pariññā, it is fully known. Paṭicca tiṭṭhati ettha = patiṭṭhā, it is the support.

original: Thā-ṭhāne, avadhibhāvena ṭhāti tiṭṭhatīti avatthā, upādīyatīti upādā-paññatti, aññamaññaṃ

original: gacchati etāyāti māyā, likhīyate lekhā, vuccateti vācā, harati manoramaṃ pavattetīti
analyzed: gacchati māyā likhīyate lekhā vuccate iti vācā harati manoramam iti
translated: Going by this is māyā, writing is likhā, speaking is vāci, taking away what is delightful is pavattana,

original: hārā-muttāvali iccādi.
analyzed: iti ca ādi
translated: therefore it is hārā-muttāvali, etc.

original: Yakpaccaye-saha kathanaṃ sākacchā, tathanaṃ tacchā, nipajjanaṃ nipajjā, vidati jānātīti vijjā, vidanti jānanti etāyāti vā vijjā, vijjāpaṭipakkhā avijjā, nisajjanaṃ nisajjā.
analyzed: kathanam sākacchā tathanam tacchā nipajjanam nipajjā vidati jānāti iti vijjā vidanti jānanti etāya ati vā vijjā vijjā paṭipakkhā avijjā nisajjanam nisajjā
translated: The word together with is sākacchā, the word thus is tacchā, lying down is nipajjā, knowing is vijjā, they know by this is vijjā, the opposite of vijjā is avijjā, sitting down is nisajjā.

original: Idha-ijjhane, samijjhanaṃ samijjhā.
analyzed: idha ejjhane samijjhanam samijjhā
translated: Here-ijjhane, success is samijjhā.

original: Sidha-nipphattiyaṃ, sijjhanaṃ sijjhā iccādi.
translated: Sidha-accomplishment, success is sijjhā, etc.

original: Yamhi-maja-saṃsuddhiyaṃ, sammajjanaṃ sammajjā, apecca vajanaṃ gamanaṃ pabbajjā, caraṇaṃ cariyā, paricaraṇaṃ pāricariyā, ‘ūbyañjanassā’ti īāgamo rasso ca.
analyzed: sammajjanam sammajjā apecca vajanam gamanam pabbajjā caraṇam cariyā paricaraṇam pāricariyā ū byañjanassa ati ī āgamaḥ rassaḥ ca
translated: In which-maja-purification, cleansing is sammajjā, going away is pabbajjā, conduct is cariyā, attending is pāricariyā, ‘ūbyañjanassā’ is īāgamo rasso ca.

original: Jāgara-niddakkhaye, jāgaraṇaṃ jāgariyā, seti etthāti seyyā, dvittaṃ.
analyzed: jāgara nidda khaye jāgaraṇam jāgariyā sā iti ettha ati seyyā
translated: Jāgara-destruction of sleep, keeping awake is jāgariyā, he sleeps here is seyyā, the second.

original: 802. Jāhāhi ni.
analyzed: jāhāhi ni
translated: . Jāhāhi ni.

original: Etehi ni hoti.
analyzed: etehi ni hoti
translated: Ni is formed with these.

original: Jā-hāniyaṃ, jiyyate jāni, dhanajāni, bhogajāni, mahantī jāni assāti mahājāniyo, hiyyate hāni, vaṇṇahāni, balahāni, āyuhāni, avahāni, parihāni.
analyzed: jāhāniyam jiyyate jāni dhana jāni bhoga jāni mahantī jāni assāti mahājāniyaḥ hiyyate hāni vaṇṇa hāni bala hāni āyu hāni avahāni parihāni
translated: Jā is the same as jāni, it is earned, jāni, wealth-jāni, enjoyment-jāni, he has great jāni, thus mahājāniyo, it is lost, hāni, loss of beauty, loss of strength, loss of life, loss of wealth, loss of merit, loss of all.

original: 803. Karā ririyo ka. 554; rū. 601; nī. 1141.
analyzed: ka rū
translated: . Karā ririyo ka. ; rū. ; nī. .

original: Karamhā itthiyaṃ ririyo hoti.
analyzed: karamhā itthiyam ririyaḥ hoti
translated: Ririyo is formed from karamha with itthiyaṃ.

original: Karīyate kiriyā, nipātanena kriyāti sijjhati.
analyzed: karīyate kiriyā nipātanena sijjhati
translated: It is done, kiriyā, by the nipāta it is accomplished, kriyā.

original: Iti itthiliṅgarūparāsi.
analyzed: iti itthi liṅga rūpa rā asi
translated: Thus the collection of feminine nouns and words.

original: Rīrikkhādipaccayarāsi🔽804. Samānaññabhavantayāditūpamānā disā kamme rīrikkhakā ka. 642; rū. 588; nī. 1269.
analyzed: rīrikkha ādi paccaya rāsi  samān añña bhavanta ya ādi tu upamānāḥ disā kamme rīrikkhakā ka rū nī
translated: The collection of words with the suffixes rī, rikkha, etc.🔽. Samānaññabhavantayāditūpamānā disā kamme rīrikkhakā ka. ; rū. ; nī. .

original: Samāno ca añño ca bhavanto ca yādi ca etehi upamānabhūtehi paraṃ disamhā kammerī
analyzed: samānaḥ ca aññaḥ ca bhavanto ca ya ādi ca etehi upamāna bhūtehi param kammerī
translated: Rī, rikkha, and ka are the suffixes when disā is the base and kamme is the state, with samāna, añño, bhavanto, yādi, and other words used as the standard of comparison.

original: ca rikkho ca ko cāti ete paccayā honti, rī, rikkhesu ‘rānubandhentasarādissā’ti suttena
analyzed: ca rikkho ca ko ca ati ete paccayāḥ honti rī rikkhesu ra anubandha inta sa ra ādissa ati suttena
translated: Rī is the suffix in rī, rikkhesu ‘rānubandhentasarādissā’ti suttena

original: disassa antassarādīnaṃ lopo, kānubandho avuddhattho, ‘rīrikkhakesu’iccādīhi samāsasuttehi
analyzed: disassa antassara ādīnam lopaḥ ka anubandhaḥ a vuddha tthaḥ rīrikkha kesu icca ādīhi samāsa suttehi
translated: The elision of the end of the word, the beginning of the word, etc., is a connection with ka, and the meaning of avuddha is ‘in the case of the ririkkha-s’.

original: pubbapadānaṃ rūpaṃ sādhetabbaṃ.
analyzed: pubba padānam rūpam sādhetabbam
translated: The form of the first words should be established by the compound suttas beginning with ‘rīrikkhakesu’.

original: So viya dissatīti tādī, tādikkho, tādiso.🔽Eso viya dissatīti edī, edikkho, ediso, etādī, etādikkho, etādiso vā.
analyzed: saḥ viya dissati iti tādī tādikkho tādiso  esaḥ viya dissati iti edī edikkhaḥ edisaḥ etādī etādikkhaḥ etādisaḥ vā
translated: ‘It appears as if it were he’ = tādī, tādikkho, tādiso.🔽‘It appears as if it were he’ = edī, edikkho, ediso, etādī, etādikkho, etādiso.

original: Ayaṃ viya dissatīti īdī, īdikkho, īdiso.
analyzed: ayam viya dissati iti īdī īdikkho īdiso
translated: ‘It appears as if it were he’ = īdī, īdikkho, īdiso.

original: Ko viya dissatīti kīdī, kīdikkho, kīdiso.
analyzed: kaḥ viya dissati iti kīdī kīdikkho kīdiso
translated: ‘It appears as if it were he’ = kīdī, kīdikkho, kīdiso.

original: Tvaṃ viya dissatīti tādī, tādikkho, tādiso.
analyzed: tvam viya dissati iti tādī tādikkho tādiso
translated: ‘It appears as if it were you’ = tādī, tādikkho, tādiso.

original: Ahaṃ viya dissatīti mādī, mādikkho, mādiso.
analyzed: aham viya dissati iti mādī mādikkhaḥ mādisaḥ
translated: Like myself it appears, therefore, it is called mādi, mādikkha, mādisa.

original: Bahutte pana tumhe viya dissantīti tumhādī, tumhādikkho, tumhādiso.
analyzed: bahutte pana tumhe viya dissanti iti tumhādī tumhādikkho tumhādiso
translated: But in the case of many, like you it appears, therefore, it is called tumhādi, tumhādikkha, tumhādisa.

original: Amhe viya dissantīti amhādī, amhādikkho, amhādiso.
analyzed: amhe viya dissanti iti amhādī amhādikkho amhādiso
translated: Like us it appears, therefore, it is called amhādi, amhādikkha, amhādisa.

original: Bhavaṃ viya dissatīti bhavādī, bhavādikkho, bhavādiso.
analyzed: bhavam viya dissati iti bhava ādī bhava ādikkhaḥ bhava ādisaḥ
translated: Like your honour it appears, therefore, it is called bhavādī, bhavādikkha, bhavādisa.

original: Samāno viya dissatīti sadī, sadikkho, sadiso.
analyzed: samānaḥ viya dissati iti sadī sa dikkhaḥ sadisaḥ
translated: Like oneself it appears, therefore, it is called sadī, sadikkha, sadisa.

original: Añño viya dissatīti aññādī, aññādikkho, aññādiso.
analyzed: aññaḥ viya dissati iti añña ādī añña ādikkho añña ādiso
translated: Like another it appears, therefore, it is called aññādī, aññādikkha, aññādisa.

original: Itthiyaṃ-yā viya dissatīti yādisā-itthī, yādisī-itthī. Tādisā-itthī, tādisī-itthī iccādi.
analyzed: itthiyaṃyā viya dissati iti yādisā itthī yādisī itthī tādisā itthī tādisī itthī iccādi
translated: Like a woman it appears, therefore, it is called yādisā-itthī, yādisī-itthī, tādisā-itthī, tādisī-itthī, etc.🔽With vamādīhi thu is added.

original: 805. Vamādīhi thu ka. 644; rū. 661; nī. 1271-3; ‘vamādīhyathu’ (bahūsu).🔽Vamādīhi bhāvakārakesu thu hoti.🔽Vamīyateti vamathu, davīyateti davathu iccādi.
analyzed: vam ādīhi thu ka rū nī bahūsu  vam ādīhi bhāva kārakesu thu hoti  vamīyata iti vamathu davīyata iti davathu iccādi
translated: With vamādīhi, which denote the act of vomiting, thu is added.

analyzed: kvi ka rū nī
translated: Vamīyate, therefore, it is called vamathu; davīyate, therefore, it is called davathu, etc.

original: Bhāvakārakesu kvi hoti.🔽807. Kvissa ka. 639; rū. 585; nī. 1266.
analyzed: bhāva kārakesu kvi hoti  kvis sa ka rū nī
translated: With kvi ka is added.🔽With kvi, which denotes the act of vomiting, ka is added.

original: Kvissa lopo hoti.
analyzed: kvissa lopaḥ hoti
translated: With kvissa lopa is added.

original: Ivaṇṇesu tāva-bhuso cayati vaḍḍhatīti acci, dvittaṃ rassattañca, vividhena cayati
analyzed: cayati vaḍḍhati iti a ci dvittam vividhena cayati
translated: In the case of the vowel a, it is called accī because it burns, it increases, the reduplicated form being accā; it is called vīcī because it increases, it increases in various ways;

original: vaḍḍhatīti vīci, pañca māre jinātīti māraji, bhaddaṃ jinātīti bhaddaji. Evaṃ puṇṇaji,
analyzed: vaḍḍhati iti vīci pañca māre jināti iti māra ji bhaddam jināti iti bhadda ji evam puṇṇa ji
translated: it is called māraji because it conquers the five kinds of Māra; it is called bhaddaji because it conquers what is good. So too puṇṇaji.

original: gāmaṃ samūhaṃ netīti gāmaṇī, nassa ṇattaṃ. Senaṃ netīti senānī iccādi.🔽Uvaṇṇesu-māreti cāveti cāti maccu, mahāvuttinā rassa pararūpattaṃ, vividhena javati
analyzed: gāmam samūham neti iti gāmaṇī nassa senam neti iti senānī iccādi  vividhena
translated: It is called gāmaṇī because it leads a village, a multitude; it is called senānī because it leads an army.🔽In the case of the vowel ā, it is called maccu because it kills, it causes to go, the long form being maccā; it is called vijju because it flashes, it moves quickly, it moves in various ways;

original: sīghaṃ pharatīti vijju, bhavanti etthāti bhū-bhūmi, pabhavati issaraṃ karotīti pabhū,
analyzed: sīgham pharati iti bhavanti ettha ati bhūbhūmi pabhavati issaram karoti iti
translated: it is called bhū because it is, it is the earth; it is called pabhū because it arises, it makes itself lord;

original: vibhavanaṃ vibhū, abhibhavatīti abhibhū, sayaṃ bhavatīti sayambhū, gottaṃ abhibhavatīti
analyzed: vibhavanam vibhū abhibhavati iti abhibhū sayam bhavati iti sayambhū gottam abhibhavati iti
translated: it is called vibhū because it is divided; it is called abhibhū because it overcomes; it is called sayambhū because it is self-existent; it is called gottabhū because it overcomes the clan;

original: gottabhū, gotrabhū iccādi.
analyzed: gottabhū gotrabhū it ca ādi
translated: it is called gotrabhū, and so on.

original: Byañjanantesu –🔽808. Kvimhi lopontabyañjanassa ka. 615; rū. 586; nī. 1220.
analyzed: byañjana antesu  kvimhi lopa u nta byañjanassa ka rū nī
translated: In the case of the consonants:🔽The final consonant of a root may be elided in the k-present tense

original: Dhātūnaṃ antabyañjanassa lopo hoti kvimhi.
analyzed: dhātūnam anta byañjanassa lopaḥ hoti kvimhi
translated: The final consonant of a root may be elided in the k-present tense.

original: Antaṃ karotīti antako, nandaṃ karotīti nandako, jīvaṃ karotīti jīvako, cittaṃ vicittaṃ
analyzed: antam karoti iti antakaḥ nandam karoti iti nandakaḥ jīvam karoti iti cittam vicittam
translated: “It makes an end” , thus it is an “ender” ; “it makes delight” , thus it is a “delighter” ; “it makes living” , thus it is a “liver” ; “it makes the mind variegated” , thus it is a “variegator” .

original: karotīti cittako, sukhena khamitabbanti sukhaṃ, dukkhena khamitabbanti dukkhaṃ, parito🔽khaññateti parikkhā, saṃ attānaṃ khanatīti saṅkho, na gacchatīti ago-nago, sīsaṃ
analyzed: karoti iti cittakaḥ sukhena khamitabbanti sukham dukkhena khamitabbanti dukkham paritas  khaññatā iti parikkhā sam attānam khanati iti saṅkhaḥ na gacchati iti agonagaḥ sīsam
translated: “It is to be endured pleasantly” , thus it is “pleasant” ; “it is to be endured painfully” , thus it is “painful” ; “it is endured all round” , thus it is a “perduring” .🔽“It digs itself” , thus it is a “digger” ; “it does not go” , thus it is a “non-goer” ; “it goes to the head” , thus it is a “head-goer” . So too with “neck-goer” .

original: upagacchatīti sīsūpago. Evaṃ gīvūpago, ninnaṭṭhānaṃ gacchatīti ninnagā-nadī, turaṃ🔽sīghaṃ gacchatīti turaṅgo, majjhe bindāgamo.🔽Bhujena kuṭilena gacchatīti bhujago, urena gacchatīti urago, khena ākāsena gacchatīti khago, vehāse gacchatīti vihago, mahāvuttinā vehāsassa vihādeso.
analyzed: upagacchati iti sīsūpagaḥ evam gīvūpagaḥ ninna ṭṭhānam gacchati iti ninnagā nadī turam  sīgham gacchati iti turaṅgaḥ majjhe binda āgamaḥ  bhujena kuṭilena gacchati iti bhujagaḥ urena gacchati iti uragaḥ khena ākāsena gacchati iti khagaḥ vehāse gacchati iti vihagaḥ mahāvuttinā vehāsassa vihā ādesaḥ
translated: “It goes to a low place” , thus it is a “low-goer” ; “it goes quickly” , thus it is a “quick-goer” ; “it goes in the middle” , thus it is a “middle-goer” .🔽“It goes crookedly by means of the arm” , thus it is an “arm-goer” ; “it goes by means of the chest” , thus it is a “chest-goer” ; “it goes by means of the sky” , thus it is a “sky-goer” ; “it goes in the air” , thus it is an “air-goer” . The word vihaṅga is a derivative noun formed from the gerundive vihaṭṭhaṃ gantumarahaṃ .

original: “Go gacchati, gāvo gacchantī”tiādīsu pana “gocaro, godhano, gottaṃ, gotrabhū”tiādīsu
analyzed: gaḥ gacchati gāvaḥ gacchanti itiādīsu pana gocaraḥ go dhanaḥ gottam gotra bhūti ādīsu
translated: But in the words “A cow goes” , “Cows go” , etc., and in the words “Its range is” , “Its pasture is” , “Its lineage is” , “Its family is” ,

original: ca kvimhi antabyañjanalope kvilope ca kate mahāvuttinā upantassa ottaṃ katvā goiti
analyzed: ca kvimhi anta byañjana lope kvi lope ca kate mahāvuttinā upa antassa ottam katvā go iti
translated: And in what? In the case of the omission of the final consonant and the omission of the vowel, the word mahā is made to have the augment ot by the Great Vow, and then it is go.

original: pakatirūpaṃ veditabbaṃ, balaṃ gaṇīyati etthāti balaggaṃ, bhattaṃ gaṇhanti etthāti
analyzed: pakati rūpam veditabbam balam gaṇīyati ettha ati balaggam bhattam gaṇhanti ettha ati
translated: The word pakati should be understood as that in which bala is gathered; the word balagga is analysable as follows: balaṃ gaṇīyati ettha;

original: bhattaggaṃ. Evaṃ salākaggaṃ, uposathaggaṃ.
analyzed: bhatta aggam evam salāka aggam uposatha aggam
translated: the word bhattagga is analysable as follows: bhattaṃ gaṇhanti ettha. So too, salākagga, uposathagga.

original: Kammena jāyatīti kammajo. Evaṃ cittajo, utujo, attani jātoti atrajo, pubbe jāto pubbajo,
analyzed: kammena jāyati iti kamma jaḥ evam citta jaḥ utu jaḥ attani jātaḥ iti atra jaḥ pubbe jātaḥ pubba jaḥ
translated: The word kammaja is analysable as follows: kammena jāyati; so too, cittaja, utuja, atraja, pubbajo,

original: pacchā jāto anujo, saha jāyatīti sahajo, thale jāyatīti thalajaṃ. Evaṃ dakajaṃ, vārijaṃ,
analyzed: pacchā jātaḥ anujaḥ saha jāyati iti sahajaḥ thale jāyati iti thala jam evam daka jam vāri jam
translated: anujo, sahajo, thalajaṃ. So too, dakajaṃ, vārijaṃ,

original: ambujaṃ. Aṇḍe jāyatīti aṇḍajo, dvikkhattuṃ jāyatīti dvijo, saha bhāsanti etthāti
analyzed: ambu jam aṇḍe jāyati iti aṇḍa jaḥ dvi khattum jāyati iti dvijaḥ saha bhāsanti ettha ati
translated: ambujaṃ. The word aṇḍaja is analysable as follows: aṇḍe jāyati; the word dvijo is analysable as follows: dvikkhattuṃ jāyati; the word sabhā is analysable as follows: saha bhāsanti ettha;

original: sabhā, kuñje ramatīti kuñjaro iccādi.
analyzed: sabhā kuñje ramati iti
translated: the word kuñjaro is analysable as follows: kuñje ramatī.

original: 809. Kvimhi gho paripaccāsamohi ka. 538; rū. 595; nī. 1123; ‘…pacca…’ (bahūsu).
analyzed: kvimhi ghaḥ pari pacca a samohi ka rū nī pacca bahūsu
translated: In what? In the case of the omission of the final consonant and the omission of the vowel, the word paripacca is made to have the augment han by the Great Vow, and then it is go.

original: Pari ca pati ca ā ca sañca o ca etehi parassa hanassa gho hoti kvimhi.
analyzed: pari ca pati ca ā ca san ca o ca etehi parassa hanassa ghaḥ hoti kvimhi
translated: The form paripacca is analysable as follows: pari ca pati ca ā ca sañca o ca etehi parassa hanassa gho hoti kvimhi.

original: Parihaññatīti paligho, rassa lattaṃ. Patihanatīti paṭigho, tassa ṭattaṃ. Bhuso hanati🔽bādhatīti aghaṃ-dukkhaṃ pāpañca, visesena bhuso hanatīti byaggho, diṭṭhi, sīlasāmaññena🔽saṃhatoti saṅgho-samūho, devasaṅgho, brahmasaṅgho, migasaṅgho, ohanati adhobhāgaṃ
analyzed: parihaññati iti palighaḥ rassa lattam patihanati iti paṭighaḥ tassa ṭattam bhusaḥ hanati  bādhati iti agham dukkham pāpam ca visesena bhusaḥ hanati iti byagghaḥ sīla sāmaññena  saṃhatā iti saṅghosamūhaḥ deva saṅghaḥ brahma saṅghaḥ miga saṅghaḥ adhobhāgam
translated: is a hindrance, a bond, a tie, a fetter, a shackle, a chain, a restraint, a hindrance, a covering, a covering over, a covering up, a covering closely, a covering completely.🔽It is a burden, a heavy burden, a great burden, a load, a great load, a great big load, a yoke, a great yoke, a great big yoke, a burden, a great burden, a great big burden, a burden, a great burden, a great big burden, a burden, a great burden, a great big burden, a burden, a great burden, a great big burden, a burden, a great burden, a great big burden, a burden, a great burden, a great big burden, a burden, a great burden, a great big burden, a burden, a great burden, a great big burden, a burden, a great burden, a great big burden, a burden, a great burden, a great big burden, a burden, a great burden, a great big burden, a burden, a great burden, a great big burden, a burden, a great burden, a great big burden, a burden, a great burden, a great big burden, a burden, a great burden, a great big burden, a burden, a great burden, a great big burden, a burden, a great burden, a great big burden, a burden, a great burden, a great big burden, a burden, a great burden, a great big burden, a burden, a great burden, a great big burden, a burden, a great burden, a great big burden, a burden, a great burden, a great big burden, a burden, a great burden, a great big burden, a burden, a great burden, a great big burden, a burden, a great burden, a great big burden, a burden, a great burden, a great big burden, a burden, a great burden, a great big burden, a burden, a great burden, a great big burden, a burden, a great burden, a great big burden, a burden, a great burden, a great big burden, a burden, a great burden, a great big burden, a burden, a great burden, a great big burden, a burden, a great burden, a great big burden, a burden, a great burden, a great big burden, a burden, a great burden, a great big burden, a burden, a great burden, a

original: katvā māretīti ogho, kilesogho, saṃsārogho, udakogho.🔽Suttavibhattiyā aññatopi gho hoti, mātaraṃ hanatīti mātugho. Evaṃ pitugho iccādi.🔽810. Ṇvādayo ka. 650; rū. 651; nī. 1288.🔽Kriyatthā bhāvakārakesu ṇuādayo honti, upari vuccamāno sabbo ṇvādikaṇḍo imassa suttassa niddeso hoti, tasmā idha kiñcimattaṃ vuccate.🔽Karotīti kāru-sippī, ayati vaḍḍhatīti āyu, ayanti vaḍḍhanti sattā etenāti vā āyu-jīvitaṃ,
analyzed: katvā mā āreti iti ogho kilesa ogho saṃsāra oghaḥ udaka ogho 🔽sutta vibhattiyā aññatas pi ghaḥ hoti mātaram hanati iti mātu ghaḥ evam pitu ghaḥ iccādi 🔽ṇu ādayaḥ ka rū nī 🔽kriyatthāḥ bhāva kārakesu ṇu ādayaḥ honti upari vuccamānaḥ sabbaḥ ṇu ādi kaṇḍaḥ imassa suttassa niddeso hoti tasmai idha kiñcimattam vuccate 🔽karoti iti kārusippī ayati vaḍḍhati iti āyu ayanti vaḍḍhanti sattāḥ etena ati vā āyu jīvitam

original: sobhāvisesaṃ rahanti jahanti canda, sūriyā etenāti rāhu-asurindo, hitasukhaṃ sādhetīti🔽sādhu-sappuriso, vāyatīti vāyuvāto iccādi.
analyzed: rahanti jahanti canda sūriyāḥ etena ati rāhu asuḥ indo hita sukham sādha iti iti  sādhu sappurisaḥ vāyati iti vāyuvātaḥ iccādi
translated: The moon and sun abandon and give up their special beauty, therefore Rāhu, the lord of the Asuras, is so called. He brings about welfare and happiness, therefore

original: Iti rīrikkhādipaccayarāsi.
analyzed: iti rīrikkha ādi paccaya rāsi
translated: a good person is so called. He blows, therefore a wind is so called. Thus the mass of causes such as ‘to move about’.

original: Pakatirūparāsi niṭṭhito.
analyzed: niṭṭhito
translated: The mass of primary matter is finished.

original: Iti niruttidīpaniyā nāma moggallānadīpaniyā
analyzed: iti niruttidīpaniyā nāma moggallānadīpaniyā
translated: Thus the ‘Mogharāja’s Explanation of the Meaning of Words’ called ‘The Explanation of the Meaning of Words’ is finished.

original: Tabbādikaṇḍo nāma kitakaṇḍo niṭṭhito.
analyzed: tabba ādi kaṇḍaḥ nāma kita kaṇḍaḥ niṭṭhitaḥ
translated: The ‘Tabbādikaṇḍa’ called ‘The Chapter on the Kit’ is finished.
